title: The Dance: Revelations
description: Revelations has all the marks of a masterpiece. It not only makes an enormously moving impression once, but also has the staying power to keep doing so season after season, through varieties of casts. The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater presented the work for the first time this season Friday evening.

title: Fire in Brooklyn Synagogue Is Attributed to Vandals
description: A ?? apparently set by vandals destroyed a gymnasium floor and caused heavy smoke damage elsewhere in the Flathush Park Jewish Center in Brooklyn early yesterday morn ing according to fire marshals.

title: Cahill Aide Warns Jersey Faces Economic Crisis Because of Fuel Shortages
description: TRENTON, Dec. 1  The chairman of the Governor's Cabinet Energy Committee has warned that New Jersey faces an economic crisis as a result of the increasing shortages of gasoline, oil and petrochemical products.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Pleasures of Duck Hunting
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass. For two days, thousands of whitewinged scoters rode the choppy waters of the bay several hundred yards away, but only now and then did a few new arrivals swing over our decoys.

title: Kissinger, in City, Confers With U.N. Aide on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 1 (Renters) Secretary of State Kissinger, on a private visit to New York, conferred today with Under Secretary General F. Bradford Morse of the United Nations about arrangements for the projected Middle East peace conference.Mr. Morse, a former Republican Congressman from Massachusetts, is the ranking Atnerican in the United Nations' Secretarial.

title: Counting the Energy Costs
description: The impact of the oil shortage on business and industry is still largely conjectural. But market analysts have been rushing out their calculations on which industries are the most energyintensive and thus most vulnerable to production cutbacks from allocation and rainning programs.

title: Comet of Century to Get Dim Showing Over L.I.
description: The recently discovered comet Kohoutek, which is hurtling into the inner solar system at more than 100,000 miles an hour, and according to Fred L. Whipple of the Harvard Observatory may well be the comet of the century, is expected to be visible from earth with the naked eye last week, but it is not likely that many Long Islanders witnessed the celestial debut.

title: The cahow: saved from hog, rat and man
description: Many fond farewellsand some foolish oneshave been written to the several hundred birds and other living beings whom human activity has put on the road to extinction. Far less has been said about whether some might be pulled back from the brink, and if so, howand by whom.

title: People and Business
description: Taxicabs in New Jersey suburbs and towns are going to be seriously affected by the weekend ban on gasoline sales. Since a large percentage are driverowners who operate single cabs, they generally buy fuel supplies as needed from the corner filling station, as does the average consumer.

title: MOTORISTS LINE UP FOR GASOLINE HERE
description: Anticipating widespread voluntary closings of service stations today, motorists lined up at gasoline pumps throughout the New York area and across the United States yesterday to stock up on fuel.

title: Buying Your First Guitar
description: What do you mean, you want to learn to play a guitar? How can I buy a guitar? I don't know the first thing about them

title: W. S. CARPENTER 3D, DU PONT EXECUTIVE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. W. Sam Carpenter 3d a director of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., and a member of its finance committee, died yesterday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived here.

title: Sather Makes It 44
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1It is almost axiomatic that a player traded in professional sports usually returns to haunt his former teammates.

title: Travel Notes
description: ONE of the side effects of Secretary of State Henry Kissinger's rapidfire trips through the Middle East is that the Egyptian Consulate in Washington, D.C. (2310 Decatur Place, N.W., 20008), is again issuing visas to residents of the United States. The fee is now $2.60 for American citizens and $4.50 for noncitizens. Applicants must provide the consulate with a completed application, a passport, an extra photograph and a check or money order. If the visa is approved, it will be waiting for the applicant at his point of entry into Egypt. In addition, group visas are available on receipt of a letter from the organizer that includes a list of passengers and their passport numbers.

title: Mrs. Young Shares Lead In Japan
description: CHIBA, Japan, Dec. 1 (AP) Mrs. Donna Caponi Young of the United States and Japan's top golfer, Hisako (Chako) Higuchi, charged into a fourway tie for the lead with twounderpar 70's today in the second round of the $50,000 Japan's women's golf classic.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As a principal spokesman for the country's property and liability insurance business, we wish to register our objection to several inaccuracies, misleading statements and the overall tone of Russell Baker's Sunday Observer column (fine print) of Nov. 11.

title: Choral Society Performs B Minor Mass
description: The New York Choral Society, Robert DeCormier conducting, took a game try at Bach's Mass in B minor at Fisher Hall on Friday night, filling out the frame of this mighty work with reasonably accurate singing and playing. This in itself was no mean accomplishment for an amateur chorus.

title: Victorian Glitter Revived in Newark
description: NEWARK  To aid in the restoration of Ballantine House, a landmark Victorianera residence that is owned by the Newark Museum, the museum's December exhibition of Victorian paintings will get under way with a formal ball next Saturday night.

title: Nutcracker Begins a 26Show Tour
description: NEWARK  The Garden State Ballet's holiday production of The Nutcracker is on the road again. By the end of December, the second annual statewide tour will have given 26 performances eight for the general public and 18 others for special audiences.

title: HEPATITIS LINKED TO EARPIERCING
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 (UPI) Women who have their ears pierced may run the risk of contracting viral hepatitis, the National Center for Disease Control says.

title: Radio Free Europe Drops 55 Employes in New York
description: Radio Free Europe has discharged 55 of 86 employes in its New York office and will let go over a hundred more in its Munich, West Germany, office, its New York director, Horst S. Petzall, said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Louisiana's Governor Blames Northeast for Gas Shortages in His State
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 1 Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana has charged that the Northeastern states are unfairly consuming natural gas procluced in his state. He asserted that he could sharply cut Louisiana's production if the Northeast continued to refuse to develop its own energy resources in the name of protecting its environment.

title: Millville to Get Glass Museum
description: MILLVILLEIn 1739, New Jersey had the first successful glassworks in the Western Hemisphereit was in Alioway, in Salem Countyand since then it has continuously been a major American producer of glass.

title: NOISE POLLUTION DISCUSSED HERE
description: About 120 government officials, educators and engineers gathered in New York for two days last week to learn how to keep things quiet.

title: Dozen Buildings in Queens Win Awards
description: A dozen of the newest buildings in Queens have earned for their owners, architects and builders citations for excellence of design and civic value in the latest of a series of annual competitions that began in 1920.

title: Senators Will Vote Today In Debt Ceiling Deadlock
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Senate failed today to break a deadlock over campaign spending legislation that has forced the Federal Government to operate with a total debt about $63billion over the legal ceiling.

title: Army Routed by Navy, 510, for 10th Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1In the mostonesided contest of the 74 ArmyNavy football games, Navy trounced the Cadets, 510, today to make a bright ending to another Navy losing season but also to create one of the darkest days in the 84year history of Army football.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Holds Open House
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1Mayor Thomas Bradley honored a campaign pledge this week and opened his office to local citizens.

title: Items for the Traveler's Rucksack
description: The best of the latest outpouring of travel books, in the estimation of one who has read, fought and slashed his way through a horde of them in recent months, sometimes wielding his blue pencil like pirate's cutlass, is WINTER IN CASTILLE by the English novelist and essayist Honor Tracy (Random $5.95). Why this choice? Well, quite apart from the fact that the competition is not particularly fierce, Miss Tracy's virtues are radiant. To begin with, she is a compassionate satirist whose embrace of the proud Castilian both deflates and caresses. And that is a humane delight. Second, and more to the point for this report, she has a superb and often pleasantly surprising knack for conveying a sense of place.

title: Oil Industry: Powerful, Little Known
description: The oil business, though one of the world's largest industries, is also one of the least understood. Here is an explanation by William D. Smith, The New York Times oil specialist:

title: Poll Finds Law Career Rising in Favor
description: A recent nationwide Gallup survey released yesterday found that a law career is far more popular than it was a decade ago, particularly among young adults.

title: Hamptons Fear Tourism Loss
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.Although only an inconvenience to some, the fuel shortage could spell economic disaster to eastern Long Island where tourism is the major and in some cases, the onlyindustry.

title: ST. THOMAS KILLING IS VIEWED AS RACIAL
description: ST. THOMAS, V.I., Dec. 1 (UPI)The police said today that the knife killing of a white businessman this week, the latest in a series of unsolved murders of whites, appeared to he racially motivated.

title: Woman Fills Role Training Athletes
description: EDISONWhen Kathy Gallagher became the athletic trainer at Middlesex County College this fall, some people were shocked and others wondered how she would do her job.

title: NIXON WILL CREATE AN ENERGY AGENCY IN MAJOR SHAKEUP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1In a major executivebranch shakeup, President Nixon has decided to create a Federal Energy Administration, high Administration sources reported today. They said it would be headed by William E. Simon, the former Wall Street investment banker who has been Deputy Secretary of the Treasury for the last 11 months.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Rutgers Is Loser To Tampa, 34 to 6
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 1 (UPI)  Freddie Solomon passed for two touchdowns and ran for a third tonight as Tampa beat Rutgers, 34.6.

title: Young Horse Instructors Find Career Trails Cross
description: Mike Henaghan and Mrs. Pam Hart met a couple of weeks ago when both were riding instructors at Primrose Farms in Somers, N. Y.

title: Oil Independence;U.S. Self Sufficiency By 1980 Is Unfeasible
description: The elements that make up today's energy emergency have been around for some time, but it took the Arab oil embargo to reveal them starkly and cause broad concern from Main Street to the White House.

title: Debra Feiger Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Feiger of Rosedale, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debra Jill Feiger, a senior at Jackson College of Tufts University, to Robert J. Schwebet, who graduated cum laude in June from Tufts. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schwebet of Glen Rock, N. J.

title: Dance
description: IT is a thousand pities that the United States never saw the original Peking Opera from mainland China, and at least another thousand that it probably now never will. It seems that the classic Peking Opera was one of the moral victims of the Chinese cultural revolution during 196669.

title: Iowa College Wins
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 1 (AP). Curt Krull's 66yard touchdown pass play on a thirddown play rallied Northwestern College of Iowa to a 10.3 victory today over Glenville (W. Va.) State for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Division 11 football championship, The victory gave the Red Raiders a perfect 120 wonlost record for the season.

title: G.O.P. Legislature Not Through Yet
description: TRENTON  The 194th Legislature ostensibly ended its twoyear session on Thursday evening, when the Senate adjourned. However, there is still some life left in it.

title: Hawks Beat Sonics for 3d in Row
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 (AP) Lou Hudson and Pete Maravich combined for 71 points to lead the Atlanta Hawks to their third consecutive National Basketball Association victory as they routed the Seattle SuperSonics, 120110, in a nationally televised game today.

title: A Pair of Perfect Fools
description: THEY gaze at you from the Playbill cover. If you were going to animalize them, Peter Cook astonished eyes staring out of his elegantly boned long facewould be a blooded horse, Dudley Moore a shaggy puppy, antecedents unknown.

title: La. Tech Gains Bowl Berth, 1813
description: RUSTON, La., Dec. 1 (AP) Denny Duron passed 68 yards to Mike Barber to give Louisiana Tech an 1813 victory over Western Illinois today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II football quarterfinal playoffs.

title: Princeton Limits Shockley Audience
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1The WhigCliosophic Society, a student debating group at Princeton University, will strictly limit attendance and press coverage at a debate here Tuesday between Roy Innis, the director of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. William B. Shockley, the Nobel Prizewinning physicist who has propounded controversial racial theories.

title: In the Bronx, the Gentry Live On
description: The Bronx, the city's mainland borough, has been a favored address ever since its rural Westchester County beginnings. It has become a place of apartment houses and urban commerce, of blight and renewal. But it is also a place of homesthe homes of the middleclass, the notsomiddleclass and the suburban gentry of elegant Riverdale and Fieldston, who in a sense naturally descended from the country gentlefolk of yesterday's Bronx.

title: Argentine Officials Killed
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec 1 (UPI) The governor and the lieutenant governor of the northern Argentina province of Misiones and their wives were killed along with the pilot of their small plane in a crash near the Iguassu Falls, the Government said today.

title: CROYDON ORDERS TENANTS TO LEAVE
description: Most of the 346 tenants of the Croydon, on Madison Avenue between 85th and 86th Streetone of the largest and most select apartment hotels in the cityhave been ordered to move by Dec. 31 so the owner can renovate the 16story building.

title: ASK SAYS '74 BUDGET IS OFF 2 TO 3 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. I (AP) Roy Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today the Administration would fall short of its goal of a balanced budget this, fiscal year by $2billion to $13billion.

title: Oh, Say, Can You See
description: What is American about American art? That perennial question is raised, again and again, by the latest crop of art books. In addition, confronted by MAXFIELD PARRISH: The Early Yeari, 18931930 by Paul W. Skeeter (Nash, $59.95) or THE STARS AND THE STRIPES: The American Flag as Art and as History from the Birth of the Republic to the Present by Boleslaw and MarieLouise d'Otrange Mastai (Knopf, $25), one is forced to pay at least passing attention to the subsidiary issue of what is considered art in America and, on a more mundane level, what subjects or artists are considered worthy of booklength treatment by American publishers in 1973.

title: Middle East Stirs Arabs in Brooklyn
description: In the mosque on State Street and in the Arabian Club on the corner of State and Court Streets the talk is about the oil boycott and the possibility of a new flareup in the Mideast war.

title: Suburban Life: Big Schools Are Springing Up in Fields
description: BUFFALO GROVE, Ill., Dec. 1Buffalo Grove High School had a Homecomingwith alumni. It will have a prom with no seniors. And there will he no graduation at all.

description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Diana Maria Tarasca Married In Lady Chapel to Paul Coates
description: Miss Diana Maria Tarasca, daughter of Mrs. Milton Pilalas of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and of Ric Tarasca of this city, was married yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Paul David Coates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Coates of New Vernon, N. J.

title: Horsemeat Market Closes
description: FRANKLIN, N. H., Dec. 1 (AP)The state's first and only horsemeat market has closed after a 10week flurry of business that just petered out. SavOn Ivicats, which opened on Sept. 12. sold more than 2,000 pounds of horsemeat in four days, said David Miller, former owner of the market.

title: Numismatics
description: THE SECOND annual New York International Numismatic Convention (N.Y.I.N.C.) opens to the public at noon next Friday in the Albert Hall of the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street. This is the one coin show in the East (there is a counterpart in California) where the silver bar and ingot collector will be out in the cold. The exhibits and dealer bourse are truly International; they are devoted toand strictly limited to  foreign coins, medals and paper money, ancient Greek. Roman Byzantine and medieval coins and, to some extent, early American material.

title: Ann Lauer Is Married to Harold Jesup
description: BEDFORD, N Y., Dec. 1ln SL. Matlhew's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Martha Ann Marshall Lauer. daughter of Mr. and MN. Thomas W. L. Lauer of Katonah, was married to Hanold Phillips Jesup, son of Mrs. Edward N. Jesup of Essex, Conn., and the late Mr. Jesup. The Rev. Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony. assisted by the Rev. Paul Young.

title: PROSECUTOR ASKS NIXON BANK DATA
description: MIAMI, Dec. 1State's Attorney Richard E. Gerstein has asked for a court order to compel the production of records relating a $100,000 certificate of deposit owned by President Nixon and held by a Key Biscayne bank headed by Charles G. Rebozo, Mr. Nixon's close friend.

title: 2 Gold Medals to Be Given By Geographical Society
description: The American Geographical Society announced yesterday that it would present two gold medal awards at its annual dinner at the Delmonico Hotel on Tuesday.

title: J. D. Danas to Wed Carole D. Romaner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Romaner of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Diane Romaner, to Joseph David Danas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Danas of Rego Park, Queens.

title: Janine Coren Sets Winter Bridal
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec, 1  Miss Janine Scot Coren, editor of Pepsico Ink, the monthly corporate publication of PepsiCo, Inc., plans to be married this winter to David Eugene Dawson, a reporter for The White Plains Reporter Dispatch.

title: John Glendon Marries Mary Di Tolla, Nurse
description: In the Guardian Angel Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary Ann Di Toila, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Di Tolla of New York and Belle Harbor, Queens, became the bride of John F. Glendon. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Glendon of Orange, Conn.

title: Barry Stein to Marry Andrea Jane LoBell
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 1Mr. and Mrs. Gene LoBell have announced the engagement of Mr. LoBell's daughter, Miss Andrea Jane LoBell, to Barry Jay Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Stein of Forest Hills, Queens. The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Mrs. Irma Jeanne LoBell. The wedding is planned for Jan. 26 at the SI. RegisSheraton Hotel in New fork.

title: Trend Is Seen in Mall Rejection
description: A proposal for a shopping mall on Brooklyn's Seventh Avenue that had drawn withering crossfire of community opposition was dropped by the city last week. Abandonment of the plan for a Seventh Avenue mall clouds the prospects of proposals for similar developments elsewhere in the city.

title: John Flannagan: The Force of An Archetype
description: THE American sculptor John B. Flannagan died a suicide in January, 1942. Later that year the Museum of Modern Art mounted a oneman show of his work and Curt Valentin published a volume of Flannagan's Letters, with an introduction by W. R. Valentiner, then director of the Detroit Institute of Arts. During his lifetimeFlannafan was only 46 at the time of his death he was widely regarded as one of our leading sculptors. Museums eagerly acquired his work, and critics and collectors held him in high esteem.

title: The First Component Of Your HiFi SystemYour Phono Stylus
description: The stylus is the first link in the reproducing chain of the phonograph record and, unfortunately, often the most neglected. Giving more attention to the state of your stylus will pay off for you in better listening, but will also allow you to protect your most precious investmentyour favorite records. If you are typical, you tend to spend much more on your records than on hardware or your equipment. And some records are irreplaceable.

title: Machines The New Bank Tellers
description: Banks are presenting a new lace to the world these days, one that always offers the same cold, metallic stare and never beams a smile or says thankyou.

title: Prohibition Of Children In Dorms Faces Test
description: A Federal District court judge in Brooklyn has directed the State University at Stony Brook to explain why its prohibition against children in the married students quarters on the Long Island campus is not unconstitutional.

title: Grand St. Bridge to Be Shut
description: The roadway of the Grand Street Bridge linking Queens and Brooklyn will be closed for repairs for four months starting tomorrow, according toManuel Carhallo, acting highways commissioner. Queensbound Grand Street traffic will be detoured by way of Metropolitan Avenue to Flushing Avenue, to 54th Street and to Grand Avenue. Queens. Brooklynhound traffic will he de toured On 55th Street to the North Service Road of Flushing Avenue, to Metropolitan Avenue and to Grand Street, Brooklyn.

title: Riverhead Aims to Be Cultural Center
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  To many outoftowners, Suffolk's county seat is best known for its traffic circle on summer weekends and long queues at the Motor Vehicles Department.

title: Southern Airways to Get Subsidy for a Skyjacking
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 (UPI) Southern Airways says that its regionalcarrier Federal subsidy will be increased to cover a $2million ransom seized by the Cuban Government after a skyjacking last year.

title: JAZZ: a beginner's library
description: Gary Giddins is a freelance writer specializing in jazz and film.

title: HOUSE UNIT LOOKS TO IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Members of the House Judiciary Committee are prepared, by substantial majority, to recommend the impeachment of Preslident Nixon if they find evidence of serious misconduct even if such misconduct falls short of criminal wrongdoing.

title: Reforms in Judgeship Selections Urged
description: TRENTONCharging that the appointment of judges in New Jersey frequently involves backroom political deals, State Senator James H. Wallwork, Republican of Essex, has called for major reforms of the selection process.

title: TRANSIT BODY SET FOR CHICAGO AREA
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 1A regional transit authority that would coordinate and help finance subways, buses, and commuter trains in Chicago and five surrounding counties was created today by the Illinois legislature.

title: 3 L. I. Villages Facing Chilly and Dim Winter
description: A chilly winter may also be a dim one for 71,000 residents of three Long Island villages that generate their own electricity. The power plants run on residual oil or natural gas, fuels that are scarce in today's energy crisis.

description: WHERE were you in '62? ask the ads for American Graffiti. In 1962, I was changing the diapers of my yearold son and watching my abdomen expand with the relentless growth of my second child.

title: Martin Kutzin to Wed Patricia S. Dickerman
description: FAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., ?? 1Miss Patricia Sue ?? and Martin How?? ?? plan 10 be mar?? in Temple Ema?? in New York. Mr. and Mrs. William Dickerman have announced their ?? ?? to the son of Mr. and Mrs, George Kutzin of ?? Chester, N. Y.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BOONTON It has been 50 years since player pianos were in their heyday, but the melody lingers on at the Player Piano Headquarters here, And their music is as fine a sound as you'd want to hear on a cheerless winter afternoon.

title: Island Area Purchased By Conservation Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Nature Conservancy announced here that it had purchased 1,840 acres of Cobb Island, which it called a classic ecological example of a barrier island eight miles off the Virginia coast.

title: Laws to Bar Homes in Flood Areas Are Pondered
description: TRENTON  Under the threat of action by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, many New Jersey communities are grappling with the problem of how to enact floodhazard zoning ordinances.

title: MRS. MEIR HOPEFUL ON NEGOTIATIONS
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1Premier Gulch Meir conceded today that the negotiations with Egypt over a disengagement of forces along the Suez Canal had hit a serious snag, but said she remained hopeful that further meetings would he held.

title: City College Names Dean Of Liberal Arts and Science;,
description: Dr. Harry Lustig, associate dean of science at City College, has been named dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Science there, effective immediately, it was announced last week by the City College president, Robert E. Marshak.

title: Medal for Life Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) A 31yearold man from Altamonte Springs, Fla., was awarded a Presidential medal this week for saving the life of a 2yearold child in 1971. Ralph Franks Jr., a construction superintendent, was presented the medal by Secretary of Transportation Claude Brinegar.

title: I Talk to the Plants And They Listen to Me
description: EXPERIMENTS have been conducted for some years to determine the effects of external stimuli on flora. Music has been piped across tulip fields. Matches have been held to philodendron leaves. Attempts have been made to measure plant reaction to human thought waves.

title: From Santa with love By Thomasina Alexander
Yeshiva U. Maps a Drive for $160Million
description: Ye Viva University and its Albert Einstein College of Merlicine have announced a $160million drive ever a period of seven years to strengthen and sustain essential programs of education, community service and health and to insure future financial stability of the institutions.

title: 28 U.S. Officers Joining U.N. Truce Team in Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) The Pentagon said today that 28 United States military officers had left for Middle East duty with the United Nations' truce supervision organization.

title: December
description: December comes, and we can expect enough snow before the year's end to hide the trash heaps of what we call civilization and give the world a deceptive look of innocence. After that first snowfall the countryside seems ready for a new and better transcription of the elusive truth. For a little while, this scene of man's argument and confusion is made immaculate and all things seem possible again, even wisdom, even integrity.

title: This Week in Sports
description: College BasketballMadison Square Garden will host its first college basketball double. header of the season Saturday when Long Island University meets Dayton at 1:30 P.M. followed by Lafayette against Fordham. Ruben Rodriguez, who was one of the nation's top 20 rebounders last season, will lead the L.T.U. squad, which has four returning starters. Lafayette was last season's MidAtlantic Conference Western Division champion. Fordham's young team is led by Darryl Brown, a 6foot7inch junior center. Hal Wissel, beginning his third season as head coach at Fordham, formerly coached Lafayette.

title: Volunteers Will Aid In Probation Cases
description: NEWARKA program designed to help offenders on probation avoid a continuing life in crime will get under way here this month. The project, which relies on the service of volunteers, has been established by the Essex County Probation Department; it is supported by a oneyear, $1.2million grant from the state's LawEnforcement Planning Agency.

title: Anna McCann to Marry
description: ROUND POND, Me., Dec. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Harper McCann of Round Pond, formerly of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Anna Marguerite McCann, to Robert Dorsett Taggart of New York, a vice president of the Bank of New York. The future bride is senior research associate in the Greek and Roman department at the New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. The wedding is planned for Dec. 21 in Wellesley, Mass. Mr. Taggart is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rush Taggart of Rye.

title: COLLUSION STUDIED IN HYDRANT BIDS
description: The city's Department of Investigation is examining complaints concerning three brothers who run three separate contracting companies to determine whether they conspired on bids with the city for contracts to replace and repair fire hydrants, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: POPE TO GET PLEA OVER JERUSALEM
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1African Moslem and Christian leaders are reportedly planning; to visit the Vatican to seek commitment from Pope Paul to work for the return of East:. Jerusalem to Arab control.

title: Church Removes Statue In Dispute Over Visions
description: Roman Catholic authorities last week directed the removal of a statue of the Virgin Mary from a Queens churchyard in which a 50yearold housewife said she has been receiving visions.

title: Most Foreigners Are Undaunted by Latin Violence
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7 (AP1 John A. Swint was driving work in Cordoba, Argentina, on, Thanksgiving Day when a spray of bullets killed him. Anthony Duncan Williams was breakfasting in his home in Guadalajara, Mexico, when terrorists burst into his home and kidnapped him.

title: Voters Imperil School Budgets
description: WOODBRIDGE  This town's Board of Education, like hundreds of others in the state, is in the process of drawing up its annual budget, which must be submitted for voter approval early in February.

title: Slow Pace Marks Life in Little Falls
description: LITTLE FALLSAlthough it is situated in the heart of Passaic County's busy commercial and industrial district, Little Falls seems to have skirted the hustle and bustle that mark today's rapid development. In fact, the slow pace at which things move here is reminiscent of many small communities in Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. And there is a touch of the mountain solitude, too, although, once one drives up from neighboring highways, he is surprised by the lack of hills within the town itself.

title: SKYLAB CREW SPOTS LASER BEAM IN TEST
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 1 (AP)The Skylab astronauts photographed a point of intense green light winking at thorn front earth today in a test of laser beams which one day may he used for spacecraft navigation and communication.

title: Ava Ottman Is Betrothed to Luther E. Birdzell 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Ottman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ava Marie Ottman, to Luther Earle Birdzell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdzell Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Patriarch
description: Perhaps what the world least appreciated about David BenGurion was his love of scholarship. Even at the height of his power, a moment to study the conjugation of an irregular Greek verb excited him almost as much as a political success in the struggle for a new Jewish state. The world of his declining years was strange him, the contrived distinction between the man thought and the man of action. To him, abstract thought and concrete action were interdependent qualities mankind, inextricable; both were intoxicating, both were fulfilling.

title: 12 Cases Dismissed In City Loan Scandal
description: Criminal indictments have been dismissed in court against 12 of 14 persons who had been charged in a major scandal two years ago with fraudulently obtaining nearly a million dollars from the city's municipal loan program for rehabilitating slum housing.

title: Reid to Announce Plans For Governorship Race
description: Reid to Announce Plans For Governorship Race

title: Oneline Poems and Longer, but Not Much
description: Reading Irish Literary Portraits by William R. Rodgers (Taplinger Publishing Co.), I came across Something that Yeats said to Maude Gonne's daughter. He was talking about prose rhythm, and singled out his favorite line, Emerson's The stars, the stars everlasting are fugitives also. This reminded me of a line I had copied down from John Barth's The SotWeed Factor, Many a deed smells sweet at night that stinks in the heat of the sun. These lines, I said, aren't prose, they're poems. I'm sure most academics would hoot me out of the halls at the idea, but there is such a thing as a oneline poem.

title: OFF BEAT ON THE UP BEAT! The Changing Classical BestSellers
description: What is a classical bestseller? Until a few years ago, anyone with a little savvy in classics could immediately tell you. It was that simple. The answer, inevitably was, staple warhorses performed by superstar soloists and conductors with virtuoso orchestras. But all that has changed.

title: HIJACKER MISSING AFTER TWO YEARS
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 1 (AP)  Two years after parachuting from a Northwest Airlines jet with $200,000 in ransom money, the hijacker known as D. B. Cooper remains a folk hero and a mystery. ***He is, according to the Department of Transportation, the only person ever to hijack a domestic airliner who has not been killed or brought to justice.

title: PANEL CRITICIZES POSTAL OPERATION,
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) A survey of four postal centers indicates that poor plant design, cost overruns and employe negligence keep the Postal Service from operating as it should.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 13 Died in Mishaps In Bergen County
description: HACKENSACK  During October, members of the Bergen County Police Department patroled 72,303 mileS in 40 police cars, issued 1,271 summonses and made six criminal and quasicriminal arrests, according to Chief Arthur Abrams monthly report.

title: Hermitage Caper Cracked by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1  When embellishments began disapnearing from the antique furniture and rare hooks inside the Hermitage. Museum in Leningrad five years ago, officials thought that thieves were sneaking in with the millions of legitimate visitors.

title: OLDTYPE RAILROAD IS THRIVING IN OHIO
description: SANDUSKY, Ohio (AP) Emile A. Legros and George A. Roose run an old railroad that makes a profit handilybut it's only 1 miles long.

title: Konarak Just May Be the B Minor Mass of India's Art
description: WHEN I was a teenager in an Indian school, the Konarak Sun Temple on the Bay of Bengal was referred to only in hushed sniggers, a reflection of the Victorian attiudes of our teachers. As I grew older I began reading descriptions of the temple by 19thcentury British travelers. None, seemingly, could resist visiting it, yet each felt obliged to express shock at its shameless obscenities and sinister character, terming it filthy or licentious or repulsive to European notions of decency. Some moralized that the 13thcentury temple was abandoned and in ruins the result of some kind of just punishment from God. Westernized Indians of the period parroted their colonial masters, offering abject apologies for the poor taste of their Hindu ancestors.

title: High Water in Great Lakes Called Winter Flood Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) The Commerce Department warned this week that high water levels in most of the Great. Lakes posed a potential flood threat this winter that could force the evacuation of residents from lowlying areas.

title: Navy Routs Army, 510; Aussies Win Davis Cup
description: Navy crushed Army, 510, at Philadelphia yesterday. It was the widest margin in the 84yearold football rivalry. Army did not win this year.

title: Aids to Help DeafBlind People Shown
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Dec. 1A twoday conference aimed at developing communication aids for people with the dual handicaps of deafness and blindness was held here this week for educators and scientists.

title: INSULATION DRIVE BALKED IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Dec. 1.  The power companies' drive here to save fuel by urging people to insulate their homes has hit a snag: Many Detroitarea dealers have run cut of insulation materials.

title: Few Ask the Old Question: Is Space Worth the Trip?
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  A subtle but important change is taking place in the exploration and use of space. It is being taken for granted, and the old, heated debate over whether space was worth the price is, if not over, at least muted.

title: Rural China Told to Shed All Traces of Old System
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 1  A major radical campaign, punctuated by dire warnings against capitalist tendencies and sabotage by the class enemy, appears to be getting under way in the Chinese countryside.

title: I Like Liz Taylor, But ...
description: SEVERAL days before Thanksgiving I was on my way to the office, walking down Broadway, when, without warning. I received a familiar, hearty clap on the shoulder from Stanley, my film industry friend.

title: Ahmad's Oil
description: Thousands of curious Arab youngsters have trooped through the oil exhibits displayed by the Arabian American Oil Company at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Thousands more have seen a traveling exhibition that tours the desert kingdom.

title: Surging Trade With China
description: WASHINGTON  United States trade with China this year is surging tenfold from the 1972 level. Exports to China will reach $840million by year end while imports from China will total $60million, according to officials of the, White House, State Department and Commerce Department.

title: Berton Lewis to Wed Miss Hooley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Hooley of Nottingham, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Ann Hooley, to Berton Bramiette Lewis of New York.

title: HOSPITAL UNION PLANS U.S. DRIVE
description: A new national union for hospital and health care workers held its founding convention here last week and made plans for a nationwide drive to organize workers in the health field throughout the country.

title: Submarine Commander Falls Into Sea, Is Presumed Dead
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (UPI)The search was suspended today for the skipper of la nuclear submarine who tumbled into the Pacific Ocean durling a gale and was presumed drowned.

title: Son to the Jules Levins
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. A son was born Nov. 23 to Dr. and Mrs. Jules S. Levin of Wilmington at the Wilmington Medical Center. Dr. Levin is an ophthalmologist. The child has been named Eric Louis.

title: Thoughts on Detente
description: LONDON  I intend to talk about dtente: what the word means to those who use it, and especially what means to us and other mediumsized countries in Europe, East as well as West.

title: OHIO IN A DISPUTE ON EARLY PAROLES
description: CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 1The state parole authorities expect to appeal an appellate court ruling that prohibits the consideration of parole for crimi nals until they have served their minimum sentences less time off for good behavior.

title: The Flowering of a New England Skier, Or, The Pleasures of Getting High
description: IT was the day before Christmas and the sun was coming through the Theodul Pass, more than 10,000 feet over Zermatt. It was an errant Riviera sun and it was using the Matter. horn as a reflector, bouncing light off its angled, glaring peak and bouncing great swaths of warmth down upon us on the terrace of the little restaurant by the Schwarzsee ski lift. A Frenchman clomped down the restaurant steps in his huge red ski boots, then stopped, shut his eyes and slowly let his mouth drop open. O, mon Dieu, he said softly. Muttering, and with his eyelids still closed to the sun, he fell into a chair at the empty table next to mine, pulling over another chair on which to hoist his feet and released a whistling sigh. Oooo...ahhh...c'est le ski, he said.

title: And Thank You Very Much
description: PRINCETON, N. J.On Nov. 17, 1973, The New York Times carried a story, from a Washington correspondent, based largely on statements of the President, concerning speculation that the Arab oil embargo on shipments to this country might soon end that the Arab governments, or at least certain of them, might soon relent and resume the shipment of oil to this country.

title: Ervin Asks for $500,000 To Continue Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The Senate Watergate Committee chairman, Sam J. Ervin Jr., asked the Senate today for an additional $500,000 to continue his committee's investigation.

title: POPE RECONSIDERS THE BAN ON REDS
description: ROME, Dec. IThe Vaticar is considering requests from the Italian clergy to revoke a 24yearold decree under which all active supporters of Communism are supposed to be automatically excommunicated.

title: Music in Review
description: Ian Shapinsky, a pianist who has played here previously in concerts with his father, Aaron Shapinsky (a cellist), gave a solo recital in the Town Hall Young Artists series on Thursday night. His program contained Scarlatti sonatas, the BachLiszt Fantasy and Fugue in G minor, a Chopin group, Bartok's Sonata (1926) and pieces by Liszt, Rachmaninoff and Liapunoff.

title: ROCKEFELLER PLAN STILL DIFATHOMED
description: If there are hints to be pondered in Governor Rockefeller's speeches lately about whether he will seek a fifth term, Bernard Levine, the Governor's omnipresent, thoughtful senographer, has heard them all.

title: FASHION TALK
description: They want to be the Channel 13 of fashion  to make cloches not for the masses but for the individualists. So Lynne and Stanley Greene formed their own company Iast year with Lynne as the designer and her husband as the worrier,

title: PREMIER AND AIDE DIFFER IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1  Premier Kakuei Tanaka and his top economic adviser offered conflicting assessments today of the economic crisis confronting Japan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: All concerned citizens support the President's call to achieve national selfsufficiency and balance in energy production and usage by the end of this decade. We will turn down our thermostats, drive slower, keep shorter shopping hours, organize car pools and make other minor contributions President Nixon suggested to cope with the nearterm crisis.

title: Photography
description: ONCE upon a time, there was only one sort of photographic book published around Chistmas. It was known generically as a coffeetable hook, since it was of a size which could only be supported by (or, itself, serve as) that particular item of furniture. The photographs contained in this kind of book were almost inevitably in color, and revealed either the wonders of nature or the mysteries of exotic places. Preferably both. Aside from decorating tabletops, the only discernible function of this genre of photo book was to display a lavishness of production which might justify its price, which was always exorbitant and which no one in their right mind would pay except at Christmastime. when Americans traditionally finances.

title: Somerville Acts to Aid Emotionally Disturbed
description: SOMER VILLE  Lafayette School an institution for emotionally disturbed and neurologically impaired children, is being watched by state educators, who regard it as a pilot project that might he emulated on a statewide basis.

title: Consumer Aid for Indians
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. An office to provide consumer education to Indians has been established here by the AllIndian Pueblo Council with grants totaling $205.000 from the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare.

title: France's Special Kind of Banking Giant
description: PARIS  in the heart of the Paris show business district on the Boulevard des Italiens sits the headquarters of the biggest hank in the world outside the United States.

title: News Summary and Index
description: David BenGurion, a founding father of modern Israel and its first Premier died in Sheba Medical Center in Tel Aviv at the age of 87. He succumbed to a brain hemorrhage that struck him two weeks ago. [1:12.] His obituary is on Pages 7677.

title: Pueblo Victim Honored
description: EUGENE, Ore., Dec. 1 (AP). The Silver Star has been awarded posthumously to Duane Hodges, the only person killed in the 1968 North Korean seizure of the Pueblo, a United States intelligence ship. The award was presented to his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Hodges of Creswell, at the Eugene Naval Reserve Center Tuesday night.

title: Chi Cheng, the Sprinter, Has Learned to Walk Now
description: Chi Cheng, the former world recordholder for women in the 100meter and 200meter dashes, says she will rest for a couple of More months hefare deciding whether to resume her track career.

title: The Mexican Charreada Is Brutal, But at Least the Animals Survive
description: UNDAY in Guadalajara means charreada time, and it's easy go. You park free on the street across from the arena, buy tickets at the door from a Mexican boy wearing a white shirt and a smile, and walk in: roughly 80 cents an adult, 40 cents a kid.

title: Is Nixon Good for the Press?
description: Under a smiling portrait of Richard M. Nixon, three journalists faced an audience of law students at Duke University last week. The famous law school alumnus whose picture overlooked the scene would not have liked much of the exchange, but at least it was mostly about him.

title: Miss Pierce to Be Bride
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Forrester W. Pierce Jr. of Upper Brookville and Wolfboro, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Virginia Pierce, to W. David Golden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lathrop Golden of Coral Springs, Fla. The prospective bridegroom's father is retired treasurer of the Bethlehem Steel Export Corporation.

title: Linda S. Solomon Wed to Allen Adler
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 1The marriage of Miss Linda Sue Solomon to Allen Adler of New York took place here this evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Solomon, parents of the bride. Rabbi Morton Levine performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, who is vice presidentcorporate development of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Adler of Merrick, L. I.

title: State May Lose Millions In Fuel Crisis Cutbacks
description: TRENTON  New Jersey's fiscal officials predicted this weekend that the stringent cutbacks and restrictions recommended by President Nixon to deal with the national energy crisis, plus the existing shortages of fuel and other raw materials for industrial production, would drastically reduce state revenues and undermine the current operating budget.

title: Schools Of Paris
description: Unanswerable questions: If young Claude Monet had not been grudgingly won over to painting outofdoors by the aging landscape painter Eugene Boudin, would Impressionism have been born? If Monet, Auguste Renoir, Alfred Sisley, Frederic Bazille had not met, in 1862, in the stultifying art classes of BeauxArts professor Charles Gleyre, would Impressionism have developed into a fullfledged art movement? Yet, the history of modern art, at times, does seem a history of chance encounters which, gathering force, developed into irreversible historic trends.

title: Utilities Seeking Coal Find It Scarce
description: NEWARKThe Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, would like to solve its part of the energy crisis by switching from scarce oil to more plentiful coal. But it cannot find enough coal.

title: War Isn't Over For ThemTheir Son Must Stay in Canada
description: SHARON, Vt.  Very few people here have ?? to say about that small Asian country called Vietnam It does neat seem to ?? much that this ?? will he the first in ?? when American ?? are not fighting there.

title: New and Old Angles to Cooking
description: The abundant 1973 crop has been separated according to subject matter. Tallest pile is that of the socalled general cookbooks, some with rather desperate new angles. Next are the books with natural wild, growing and similar words in their titles, a dispirited lot based on the assumption that a little wheat germ and a few soybean sprouts will rejuvenate dowager recipes. The specialty pile is tall, with good stuff. Among the foreign books, French has given way to exotic and Italian. Interestingly only three books deal with the current food concern for high prices.

title: LUCY LEMMER
description: SOUND BEACH, L. I., Dec. 1Lucy Lemmer, director of the Office for the Aging in the office of the Suffolk County Executive, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson. Her age was 38 and she lived here.

title: STATE YOUTH UNITSCORED AS ERRATIC
Australians Find the Battle Against Rust Quite Costly
description: SYDNEY, Australia (UPI)Australian home owners and industralists are spending $650 million a year combatting rust, a research report says.

title: Jobs: Wichita's SmallAircraft Industry Feeling Pinch
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 1After Mrs. Joyce Creekmore took a $3.77anhour job last summer operating a punch press at the Cessna aircraft plant here, a job involving lots of overtime, she and her husband decided they could afford a $4,000 combination pickup truck and camper.

title: Melanie Garfinkel Bride of Jay A. Grotas
description: Miss Melanie Susan Garfinkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Garfinkel of New York was married here last evening to Jay Alan Grotas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Grouts of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Delmonico's.

title: GEN. GIACOMO CARBONI
description: ROME, Dec. 1Gen. Giacomo Carboni, who was in charge of the forces defending Rome when Italy signed the armistice with the Allies in 1943, died today at his home here. He was 84 years old and had lived in retirement since the end of the war.

title: School Adopts Aerospace Aids
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I.An energy conservation program using techniques stemming from the development of aerospace systems is being adopted throughout the Herricks school district.

title: Bach in Ye Olde Instrument Shoppe
description: I REMEMBER being tickled to life, one sultry summer afternoon, by a peculiarly oblong phrase in a German book about a baroque composer. Musealer Klangmaterialismus. Scarcely believing the translation that sprang to mind, I turned to the glossary and discovered that the term had hen coined in order to describe a special, and in many ways regrettable, attitude towards the performance of precassical music.

title: Many Holiday Jobs
description: ELIZABETHA spot check of state and other nonprofit employment agencies shows that teenagers stand a good chance of finding a job during the holiday season, unless they live in Camden, Gloucester or Burlington Counties.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This is catchup week to finish all the things that haven't been done and need doing.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may he obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: Tinsel Art Reappearing in Gift Shops
description: PLAINFIELD  Tinsel paintings, which were popular in the mid19th century, are reappearing in art and gift shops throughout the metropolitan area. They are the work of Mrs. Betty Ely of Madison Avenue, a grandmother who resurrected the art after prowling through museums to find old samples of it.

title: Pop Paul's Grooves Will Grab You
description: WHAT are Jason Robards, James Coburn, Clement Freud, Paul and Linda McCartney (who is a dead ringer for David Bowie) doing on the cover of Paul McCartney's brand new album, Band On The Run (Apple SO3415)? Apparently they're escaping from prison if I read the title tune correctly, but I don't think it really matters. It's the sound in the grooves that grabs you.

title: The Gasoline Shortage Is Giving the Travel Industry the Chills
description: GOVERNOR Reubin Askew of Florida sounded spooked. A few weeks ago, alarmed by the specter of mandatory rationing of gas, he warned the Florida tourist industry, We are all going to have to tighten our belts far more than we anticipated. About 80 per cent of Florida's annual influx of 25 million tourists drive into the state and, said the Governor, many of these people will be lost to us with gas rationing. A week later, Askew raised yet another specter: an acute shortage of fuel for oilburning heaters might spark a new wave of migration from the North. So the state of Florida could be deprived of a principal means of income and, simultaneously, deluged by new residents.

title: Art in Context: A Fresh Perspective
description: Here is a sign that fresh breezes blow in the field of art history: it is Art in Context, a new series from Viking edited by John Fleming and Hugh Honour, in which each book contains an essay on a single famous painting. It used to be the style among scholarestheticiansRuskin, Fry, Berenson to devise critical yardsticks with which they attempted to compare the incomparable, not only in terms of kind, which may be illiminating, but in terms of merit, which is not. As G. K. Chesterton pointed out, one man cannot overtake another unless both are running in the same direction.

title: 3 Private Schools Will Merge
description: MONTCLAIR  Three private schools here with a total enrollment of 990 have agreed to merge by next September, thus forming what officials describe as one of the largest independent school systems on the East Coast.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: WHY bring a show to Broadway at all?, asks Robert Berkvist (Nov. 4). Why indeed!

title: Miss Kate Buddy To Become Bride
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 1 Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edward Carr Buddy of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kate Gridley Buddy, to Randolph Irving Thornton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton of Naples, Fla., and Quonochontaug, R. I., formerly of Oakland, N. J.

title: A Hunter Now Collects Indian Artifacts
description: PRINCETON  Until three years ago, Tom Brian hunted for deer, first with rifles and then with a bow and arrow. A row of mounted deer antlers on the outside of the Brian barn in nearby Kingston attests to his success as a hunter.

title: SOVIET STRESSING COLLECTIVE RULE
description: MOSCOW, Dec. IAmid the triumphant treatment of Leonid I. Brezhnev's visit to India in the Soviet press, there are signs that other prominent figures have been taking steps to reaffirm the collective nature of the Soviet leadership.

title: SOCIAL ILLS CALLED KEY TO HEALTH CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) National health insurance will not lessen America's death and disease rates unless more basic social ills are addressed, according to the president of the Blue Cross Association.

title: A Family Quarrel Breaks Out in Brooklyn
description: THE Brooklyn Museum reminds one of a large family, wrote Duncan Cameron, the museum's director, not long ago. We an solve our problems over the kitchen table. Little did Cameron realize when he expressed these sentiments, that shortly after the family would he painfully split, the kitchen table would become a public forum and that he, the director, would become the center of controversy, accusation and innuendo.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Five people start businesses on Seventh Avenue, and five years later they have undergone a variety of traumatic experiences.

title: Dave Anderson
description: DENVER, Dec. 1 Shortly after John Ralston opened his first training camp as the coach of the Denver Broncos more than a year ago, one of his players muttered:

title: A. I. Miranda Weds Miss Bayard
description: Miss Josephine Linder Bayard and Alfred I. Miranda, who trace their ancestry to early settlers in the New World, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: Missing: A Lot of Oil, More Tape
description: The tough reality of crossexamination in a Federal courtroom last week caught up with, and may well have overtaken, President Nixon's effort to restore his credibility and popularity through Operation Candor. At the end of a week of testimony before Judge John J. Sirica by Mr. Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, and his special counsel, J. Fred Buzhardt, the record was full of contradiction and equivocation, the courtroom was full of doubt and the question had been clearly raised: Has anybody tampered with the White House tapes?

title: Talking Geopolitics
description: When oil men talk of activity in the Gulf, it's not the Gulf of Mexico they mean but the Persian Gulf, 6,000 miles away. The reason for the ambiguity is politics.

title: CONRAD WILL RETIRE FROM NASA AND NAVY
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 1 (UPI)Capt. Charles Conrad Jr., Skylab I commander who was the third man on the moon, will retire as an astronaut and leave the Navy, effective Feb. 1, to go to a cable television company in Denver, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has announced.

title: Problems of Camping Out
description: Recreational vehicles have enjoyed a boom in recent years, but the fuel shortage is sapping the growth of these gashungry models. The Recreational Vehicle Institute in Chicago reported the other day that shipments declined 8.6 per cent in September to 52,300 units. For the first nine months, shipments were up a scant 1.5 per cent to 611,200 units.

title: Nixon Plan To Cut Back Use of Fuel Assailed
description: TRENTONRepresentatives of fueloil and gasoline dealers in New Jersey are expressing doubts that President Nixon's proposed cutbacks on oil and gasoline consumption will significantly forestall the anticipated shortage of both fuels in the state this winter.

title: Sleek animals bred to run
description: It was the dictum of Admiral Henry Rous, who reorganized English racing in the early 1800's, that all men were equal on the turf and under it. Lester Doctor, Payne Whitney's betting commissioner and court jester, once quipped, Yes, they arebefore 5 o'clock. (Post time for the last race in the old days.) Bernard Livingston's Their Turf is all about what he calls our Horsey Set.

title: Fund of $5Million Is Given To the Phillips Academy
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Dec. 1 (AP)  A $5million bequest has been announced by Phillips Academy, one of the nation's prestigious preparatory schools.

title: L.I. House Built for Giving Parties
description: RINGS POINT, L. I.Mary Ruth and Donald Sheff love to entertain.

title: BAHAMIAN RULING ON VERO IS NEAR
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Dec. 1A ruling is expected early next week on a motion to reject the Unites States Government's efforts to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the financier, on a fraud charge.

title: JESUIT COLLEGE PLANS TRANSFER
description: Woodstock College, the Jesuit theology school being phased out here, will transfer some of its resources and assets to new Jesuit research center to be established in Washington.

title: Governor, Caso, Klein Pressing for Transit Aid
description: Governor Rockefeller went to Washington last week to seek Federal funds for mass transit in the regioninincluding assistance for the Long Island Rail Roadbut he went only after making sure that he had the troops back home lined up in solid support.

title: Art
description: WHEN the AfoAKorn, a sacred statue that vanished about seven years ogo from the mountain kingdom of Kom in the Camerons, was discovered last month in the hands of an American dealer, a series of stories in The New York Times resulted in arrangements for the statue's return, now virtually accomplished.

title: CLERK SLAIN HERE FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: A Bronx supermarket clerk on his way to the bank with a bag containing Government food stamps was shot and killed by two holdup men after he had given them the stamps. The police, said the stamps were probably worthless to the robbers.

title: BenGurion, Symbol of the Tough State of Israel, Achieved a Lifelong Dream
description: David BenGurion symbolized the tough little state of Israel. Short, round, with a nimbus of white hair flaring angrily from a massive head, BG, as he was known to many, attained world leadership by firmly concentrating on the achievement of a dream.

title: Energy Only One Crisis for Baseball
description: Professional baseball will open one of its stormiest business meetings in years this week in Houston surrounded by trouble. And heading the list are the energy crisis, the future of the designated hitter, the future of the San Diego Padres and the flap over who will manage the New York Yankees, Detroit Tigers and Oakland A's.

title: Wines Brilliant to Fruity
description: High wine prices are tearing up the social fabric of America. Most families this year face Christmas without the traditional jereboam of LafiteRothschild. And if Mr. Nixon does not pull us through this crisis, the next generation will grow up not knowing what it is to combine the tastes of fresh foie gras and Chateau Yquem on a Tuesday night.

title: CAIRO ASKS SOVIET AND U.S. TO PRESS ISRAELIS ON TRUCE
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1Egypt has asked the United States and the Soviet Union to break the new deadlock in the Middle East by putting pressure on Israel to withdraw her forces to the ceasefire lines of Oct. 22.

title: Guitarist Likes Playing Live Again
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVERWhen the Johnny Carson television show moved to the West Coast, Bucky Pizzarelli, the guitarist with the N.B.C. orchestra, decided that his roots were too deep in New Jersey for him to make the shift.

title: Mrs. Ambler Cantey Stapleton Rewed
description: Mrs. Ambler Cantey Stapleton was married here yesterday noon to Geoffrey Reed Douglas, a feature writer for newspapers and magazines. The Rev. Thomas Bauer performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Operation Candor
description: President Nixon's counteroffensive on Watergate, billed by the White House as Operation Candor, is visibly collapsing. Only full disclosure could make such an operation convincing, but at crucial turns in each of several Watergate controveries, the evidence is missing or incompleteor Mr. Nixon refuses to disclose it.

title: World
description: A Breakdown at Kilometer 101; On the Road to Geneva as Well?

title: Poll Indicates Mrs. Meir And Dayan Still Favored
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Defense Minister Moshe Davan still remain the most popular choicets for their posts, but have lost a lot of support since the October war, according to a public opinion poll published here.

title: No Longer a Certainty
description: In 1959, the year that jet engines made their appearance on commercial airliners and touched off a revolution in mass air travel, the Port of New York Authority published a somber report warning that New York was racing toward an economically calamitous shortage of runways:

title: Lakewood: Dispute Over School Leader
description: LAKEWOOD  When Dr. William D. Mackolin arrived here two years ago to he Superintendent of Schools, he found that many of the town's high school students were afraid to walk in the institution's corridors.

title: 'Barna Pins 350 Defeat On Auburn
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP)  Wilbur Jackson's running and pass  catching led Alabama to a 350 victory over Auburn tonight, giving the Crimson Tide an 110 wonlost record to take into its Sugar Bowl match with Notre Dame on Dec. 31.

title: Jean C. Rushin, Attended by 5, Married to Jonathan Brown jr.
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 1 Miss Jean Claire Rushin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Rushin, was married this afternoon to Jonathan Allison Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Darien, Conn.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1RANDALL ENOS

title: Benturion Tributes Expressed
description: Government leaders around the world, American political officials and prominent Jewish leaders joined yesterday in tributes to David BenGurion, a founding father of Israel.

title: Carol Witschieben Is Fiancee of W. R. Scholz
description: HAWORTH, N. J., Dec. 1Miss Carol Anne Witschiehen, a soprano studying for a singing career, plans to be married in May to Walter Rosen Scholz, an actor, director and producer.

title: New Lights for Outer Boroughs May Cut Crime and Save Energy
description: More than 86,000 new high intensity sodium street lights will be installed in the outlying boroughs of New York City beginning early next year, city officials announced yesterday, in an attempt to conserve energy and cut down on street crime.

title: The Books Show a Tidy Profit
description: HARTWICK, N.Y.  Four years ago Roger P. Butterfield, eminent historian (The American Past) and journalist (national affairs editor of Life), was a busy 62yearold writer in New York City. Then he had a mild heart attack and decided to shuck the metropolis for a quieter pace of life.

title: Hearing Planned On 2 Queens Areas
description: Public hearings on the proposed designation of two planned communities in QueensFresh Meadow and Sunnyside Gardens for special protection under the city's zoning laws are to be continued at 6 o'clock on Wednesday evening in Queensboro Hall.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation has leased approximately 140,000 square feet of office space at 711 Third Avenue, between 44th and 45th Streets. The 12year lease specifies an aggregate rent of about $12million.

title: Experts
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.Topics ranging from revolution to recreation will he on the agenda this week as a group of experts recently returned from tours of new China share their impressions of life behind the bamboo curtain.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Home Improvement
description: In an effort to catch up on.the backlog of unanswered questions, the entire Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers, whose actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Reader; sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page. BERNARD GLADSTONE

title: POLICE QUOTAS SET IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1United States District Judge Robert Peckham this week or dered the San Francisco Polio Department to stop using ex aminations he said had dis criminated against minority group applicants and minority group officers seeking promo tions. He also ordered the de. partment to start one of the most substantial quota hiring programs in the country.

title: Rutgers: Now the Faculty Competes for Students
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The Rutgers University professor was starting his lecture.

title: Nibbles to go with holiday sips
description: When friends drop in By James Beard

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AT THE very time that the Administration's energy planners and other top officials in Washington are wrestling with various options for coping with the shortage of fuels, other Government aides and private economists are weighing a more fundamental question as well: What changes, if any, ought to be instituted at this time in fiscal and monetary policies and in the whole spectrum of the economiccontrols program?

title: Lindsay Giving Mayoral Papers To the City and Others to Yale
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that his governmental papers and records accumulated over the last eight years at City Hall would be given to the Municipal Archives for use by future city officials, historians, students and other researchers.

title: Music: Prey Brilliantly Sings Ballads of Loewe
description: The ballads of Karl Loewe are virtually unknown to the general music public of this country, but if Hermann Prey, the German baritone, goes around singing them as brilliantly as he did at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, they might he in for a rise on recital popularity charts.

title: Of Art and Artists
description: Definition of a good art book: one that combines a text and copious illustrations in mutual support to enlighten the readerlooker on the book's subject. Poor art book: the support fails on one side or the other. Wretched art book: both fail. And a really evil art book is one in which either the text or the illustrations actually distort the subject, with the illustrations most frequently the offender.

title: News of the Screen
description: The grand old man of French films, Jean Gahin, who will 70 on May 17, and who has made 93 movies since his 1930 debut in Chacun Sa Chance, is planning to retire. But not before he completes his 94th feature. The stocky, whitehaired star of such films as Grand Illusion, Port of Shadows and Pep le Moko, will have his final film fling as costar with Sophia Loren in La Tigresse et L'Elephant. According to his local spokesman, it is essentially a courtroom drama.

title: Bridge
description: In almost all sports and games the future is significant, the present is vital and the past is trivial. Bridge is to some extent an exception, for the players sometimes expend more mental energy on the postmortem than they do on the actual play. For most experts the temptation to tell partner exactly what was wrong with his bidding and play is virtually irresistible.

title: Boychoir School Molds Men
description: PRINCETON  What is probably the most unusual institution in this hub of higher learning is a transplant from the capital of Ohio.

title: Health Course Helps Restaurants Here
description: Restaurants whose personnel took part in a Health Department foodprotection course had 76 per cent fewer serious Health Code violations than other eating places, according to a onemonth field study made public yesterday by Health Commissioner Joseph A. Cimino.

title: Hussein, Weighing Peace Talks, Asks Clarification on Guerrillas
Christmas Lights Dim Across State
description: NEWARK  New Jerseyans had already dimmed their Christmas lighting before President Nixon appealed last week for restraint in holiday illumination to conserve energy.

title: Nixons May Leave Estate in Californa To the Government
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) President Nixon is preparing to disclose that he and his wife will give their San Clemente, Calif., estate to the Government upon their deaths.

title: When the Woods Were Thicker, So Were the Baseball Bats
description: When Henry Aaron breaks Babe Ruth's homerun record, he will hit the ball with a Louisville Slugger bat similar in most dimensions to the one that the Yankee hero swung half a century ago.

title: The Less and Less Friendly Canadians
description: TORONTOIf Alastair Gillespie, the Trade Minister who sponsored the measure passed last week by Canada's House of Commons to control foreign investment, had suggested such a course of action a decade ago, it would almost certainly have been regarded as the route to Canadian economic suicide.

title: Abandonment of Service Stations Accelerates
description: Service stations by the thousands are being closed for good all across the country as the gasoline shortage accelerates an oil company program to weed out marginal operations.

title: Colts Visit Shea
Unlikely Father of Arab Power
description: CARACAS, Venezuela Later this month, in a walled hacienda in the verdant Caracas suburb of Los Chorros, a short, darkeyed, baldpated man with a benign smile named Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso will celebrate his 70th birthday.

title: Worldwide Smallpox Cases At Highest Level Since '67
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 (UPI)An upsurge in the number of worldwide smallpox cases has been reported by the World Health Organization, the National Center for Disease Control says.

title: Wittenberg Gains In Football Playoff
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 1 (UPI)Dean Cavin blocked two firsthalf San Diego punts, running one hack 35 yards for a touchdown, and Wittenberg made a key goalline stand in the last minute of the game today as Wittenberg defeated San Diego, 2114, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's college division III playoffs.

title: The TV Show That Had EverythingAnd Died
description: I WALK down the streets of New York and I think everybody in the world is watching our show. People stop me and tell me how much they love it. You know, if we had gotten reviews like this for a Broadway show, we could run for 12 years. But how do you buck the competition? What do you do?

title: Rail Consolidation Urgedin U.S. Study
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  A Federal study group has recommended that the nation's 38 largest railroads be consolidated into four to seven transcontinental systems as a means of revitalizing what it described as a troubled industry.

title: U.S. Given Possession Of Longfellow House
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. (AP)Ownership of Longfellow House on Brattle Street has been transferred to the Secretary of the Interior as a national historic site.

title: CLERK SLAIN HERE FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: A Bronx supermarket clerk on his way to the bank with a bag containing Government food stamps was shot and killed by two holdup men after he had given them the stamps. The police said the stamps were probably worthless to the robbers.

title: Aaron and Ruth: Louisville Sluggers Both
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec, 1 (UPI)Early in April, Henry Aaron will step up to bat at San Francisco's Candlestick Park to begin the final leg of his celebrated journey to overtake Babe Ruth's career home run mark of 714.

title: Nicklaus Becomes A $2Million Golfer
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Dec. 1Jack Nicklaus, the Golden Bear, became a $2million golfer today. With $30,000 reward for winning the Walt Disney World classic, Big Jack brought his career earnings to $2,012,068. He is the first in the game to reach the $2million category.

title: Trustees at Kean Elect a Chairman
description: UNIONJohn L. Shurtleff, of Mendham, has been elected chairman of the Board of Trustees of Kean College of New Jersey, formerly Newark Slate College at Union.

title: CAMBODIANS LOSE ANOTHER OUTPOST
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 1 (AP)Insurgents overran a second Government outpost in as many days today, inflicting heavy losses in men and equipment, reports from the field said.

title: Fuel Crisis Could Improve Mass Transit
description: PRINCETON  Representative Joseph G. Minish expects the energy crisis to lead to the approval of pending Congressional legislation that could improve mass transportation in New Jersey.

title: College Credits Set at Police Academy
description: SEA GIRTFor the first time in the history of the State Police Academy, officers who have completed one of its training courses can receive college credit for what they have learned.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four slurs to none, based on the writer's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good three as excellent and four as superb.

title: The New Port Newark Is Prospering
description: NEWARK  Every 24 hours, five days a week, an average of 13,600 tractortrailers roll into and out of the $33]million, 2,000acre marine terminal complex that the Port Authority operates at Port Newark and adjacent Port Elizabeth.

title: The Americans' Love Affair With Cars
description: WASHINGTONWhether we like it or not, even whether we admit it or not, we are all victims of this national passion for a fourwheeled machine that eats money and produces traffic jams, air pollution and parking lots.

title: Male Nude in Art Shown
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Studies of the male nude at the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra University is a welcome exhibition. Not only is the display a tour de force in its quality and selection but also it is a rarity.

title: Check on Aid Funds Is Urged
description: TRENTONBrendan T. Byrne, the Democratic Governorelect, has promised the voters that the cornerstone of his administration will be integrity and openness to public scrutiny.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
BenGurion Is Mourned In City Sabbath Services
description: The word of David BenGurion's death was passed in whispers at Sabbath services in synagogues across the metropolitan area yesterday, and it evoked the prayers and tears of people who grieve at the loss of a great man.

title: Blind Musician Is Inventive
description: MONTCLAIROne night, while listening to tape recordings of his own orchestra at home, Phil Bennett decided that something was missing. He wandered around the house, found an ironstone howl in the kitchen that made a perfect E flat, had its sound dubbed into oiie, of the 16 tracks of our recording and was satisfied.

title: Susan B. Stieglitz to Be Wed To Kenneth Sutton on May 11
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 1  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Stieglitz of Bronxville of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Belle Stieglitz, to Kenneth Joseph Sutton, son of Mrs. Frank J. Sutton of New Rochelle and Milford, Conn., and the late Mr. Sutton, who was educational and agency director of Newsweek magazine.

title: Ickx Joins Peterson At Lotus
description: Ronnie Peterson, the 29yearold Swede whose long blond hair once led confused customs officials into believing he was a girl, continues to wind up in the right place at the wrong time.

title: The City's Comings, Goings
description: Everyone knows the first law of urbodynamics: Suburbs expand while the central cities contract. However, recent census report shows that two of New York's suburbs that have flourished most, Nassau County on Long Island and Bergen County in New Jersey, actually declined slightly in population over the last two years. Perhaps conventional wisdom needs amendment.

title: Can Opera Singers Conduct?
