description: DOMINGO Conducts Milnes! Milnes Conducts Domingo! screams the jacket blurb of a new RCA release (ARL 10122). Gimmick, gimmick, mutters the suspicious critic, warily putting the disk on his turntable, trying to think of precedents for opera singers who have taken up the baton. Manuel Garcia? But he was a unique singerconductorcomposerpedagogue  impresario genius. Hans Hotter? He at least started his career as a conductor.

title: Sandra Shaffer to Be Wed Feb. 23
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Dec. 1 Miss Sandra Charlotte Shaffer, assistant curator of textiles for the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, plans to be married Feb. 23 to H. Stetson Tinkham, assistant to the director of the National Marine Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Washington.

title: Bloomfield Leaders Clash on Night Freight Issue
description: BLOOMFIELDBitter feelings arising from a twoyearold mayoralty contest have caused internal dissenion between the Mayor and a segment of the Town Council in this community's attempt to bar night freight traffic on the Greenwood Lake Branch of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad.

title: The Palestinians: Dispersed, Perennial Victims of the War
description: JERUSALEM  The fourth IsraeliArab war in a quarter of a century was fought primarily over the territories conquered by Israeli in the third war of the series.

title: Linking Up the Key Currencies
description: The Bretton Woods international monetary system finally broke down largely because of a failure to work out a political compromise on vital issues. It thus follows that any successor system can be established only if such a compromise can be achieved.

title: Having a ball
description: ACROSS

title: Big Spruce Takes Aqueduct Feature
description: Big Spruce showed an extreme liking for the dirt track at Aqueduct yesterday. The Elmendorf representative, competing in the 1mile Gallant Fox Handicap, took the 35th running of the event easily, finishing 6 lengths in front of the runnerup, Crafty Khale.

title: Best Seller List
description: FICTION

title: Coach Is Rehired
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Dec. 1 (AMMississippi State's head football coach, Bob Tyler, was given a new fouryear contract today after a 4.5.2 wonlosttied record.

title: Criminals At Large
description: If one thing has dominated the mystery field for the last 12 months, it has been the Watergate Syndrome. Some of the books, written before the full impact of the revelations, are actually prescient. And they all combine to give the feeling that America had better watch out. The Fascists are coming.

title: Lord Peter Wimsey Needs His Harriet
description: MY MOTHER'S favorite Lord Peter Wimsey book was Gaudy Night; I remembered that when Alistair Cooke spoke of the enormous popularity of the Dorothy L. Sayers mystery novels as Clouds of Witness began on Channel 13 early In October. Gaudy Night belongs pretty much to Peter's associate detective, Harriet Vane, but you won't even know she exists if you've just been watching Masterpiece Theatre without reading the books, The producers have chosen to dramatize two novels written before Sayers had invented Harriet. Furthermore, they've altered Clouds of Witness in some extraordinary ways, standing Sayers's consistently feminist point of view on its head, to no discernible dramatic purpose. I find I'm taking it very personally.

title: 7 Homes Prepare for Yuletide Walk
description: CALDWELL  From 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Tuesday, the Women's Club of Caldwell will sponsor its seventh annual Christmas Walk, tour of seven homes Specially decorated for the holiday season.

title: PARK BARR TURNER
description: LYME, Conn., Dec. 1Park Barr Turner, an executive in the steel industry and formerly export manager in New York City for the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation, died today at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London. He was 78 years old.

title: Army Weeds Out 7% of Volunteers lino Can't Cope
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) Volunteers who cannot take military life arc being dropped from the Army with honorable discharges at the rate of about 1,000 a month.

title: Miss Mulvey Sets Summer Wedding
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 1  The engagement of Miss Maripat Mulvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Mulvey, to Warren H. Fonda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Fondu of Glenbrook, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Sojourner, Roche Help Nets Win
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 1 Two free throws by Willie Sojourner with 25 seconds remaining in the second overtime tonight carried the New York Nets to a 128127 victory over the Virginia Squires in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Italians, Short of Fuel, Face Pasta Crisis, Too
description: ROME, Dec. 1On top of the fuel emergency, which will bring Italy the first of an indefinite series of carless Sundays, this nation finds itself in the midst of a spaghetti crisis.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Phoebeann Jaeger Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 1  Miss Phoebeann Jaeger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas 1. Jaeger, was married here tis afternoon to Anthony S. Previti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Previti of New Britain. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performed the ceremony in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church. Mrs, David R. Landry was the matron of honor, and Joseph Fioretti the best man.

title: BenGurion Is Dead at 87; Founding Father of Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 1  David BenGurion, a founding father of modern Israel and its first Premier, died today at the age of 87. He succumbed at 11:06 A.M. local time (4:06 A.M. New York time) to a brain hemorrhage that had struck him two weeks ago.

title: Gail Rothenberg Is Engaged
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 1 Mrs. Millard Rothenberg has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gail Rothenberg, to John Feldberg Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Levy of Weston, Mass.

title: Jersey Male Nurse Indicted in Death Of Retarded Youth
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Dec. 1A murder case in Wayne County Court here stemming from the death of a retarded youth in 1970 at a special school for such persons in nearby Hawley has been broadened to include a second defendant.

title: Rockaways Fighting Nursing Homes
description: Residents of the Rockaways who see their crowded peninsula as a dumping ground for infirm elderly persons and discharged mental patients made the long trip to City Hall in Manhattan last week to argue for tightened curbs on construction of nursing homes in the community.

title: John Mason Jr. to Marry Barrie Orr
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., Dec. 1Mr. and Mrs. T. Decker Orr of East Islip and Quogue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barrie Walden Orr of Wayland, Mass., to John Montgomery Mason Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason of Fairfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: State Colleges Spared From Expected Losses in OutofState Tuition Fees
description: State colleges and universities, fearful for several years that they faced huge losses of the extra money they charge outofstate students, are finding that the blow has vet to fall and are doing their best to see that it does not.

title: HAROLD E. MARTIN
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., Dec. 1 Harold Edward Martin, who retired in 1965 as president and chairman of M & T Chemicals, Inc., died here Thursday. He was 73 years old and in recent years had lived in St. Croix, V.I.

title: Frostbite Sailors Beat the Fuel Shortage
description: Warmed by psychic fires only a masochist could understand, more than 100 frostbite sailors easily beat the energy crisis yesterday in New York Maritime College's first St. Nicholas regatta.

title: How To Buy Recording Tape
description: Whether you've just come home with your first tape recorder or are planning to transfer some of your favorite music to tape, the time comes when you have to go shopping for blank tape. If you've never been tape shopping, it can be confusing experienceand even longtime tape hobbyists usually take a few minutes to select just the tape they need for a panicular job.

title: Letter to an Airline:
description: YOU probably don't remember me, dear airline, but I was a passenger on one of your flights from Philadelphia to London last summer. It is perhaps a matter of Himalayan indifference to you that I am bothering to write, but our lives were Interdependent for a few crucial hours at least mine was on yoursand I have since been thinking how I was transformed from an unEuroped sedentary to, in your felicitous phrase, a valueconscious voyager.

title: EXCONVICT HEADS A DATA COMPANY
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1In 1972, Jerry Schneider was indicted and convicted on a felony charge involving grand theft, burglary and receiving stolen property. The charge: that he stole at least $100,000 and perhaps as much as $1million in phone equipment and supplies from Pacific Telephone, the West Coast subsidiary of Bell Telephone.

title: Camera Eye View of Our Life and Times
description: Photography, after 140 years as the possession of scientists, hobbyists and connoisseurs, is becoming institutionalized: the medium is being taken more seriously as an art form now than at any period in its history. Museums are devoting greater space each year to photography shows and many, previously unconcerned, are industriously building representative collections. Photography has been reluctantly, tepidly recognized in the graduate schools as a part of art historya subject fit for seminars and dissertations. And photography galleries have become within the last two years a fixed part of the New York art world; in this new atmosphere owning an original print by Edward Weston is becoming as desirable as owning one by Jasper Johns (though it's still cheaper).

title: Bahamas Bars 2 Americans From Treasure They Found
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Dec. 1 (AP)  Two American treasure hunters who say they have discovered $2million in sunken treasure have been prohibited by the Government from salvaging it.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNITED STATES foreign trade registered a surplus of $527.1million in October. In the first 10 months exports exceeded imports by $680million, in contrast to a deficit of $5.2billion in the corresponding 1972 period.... United States Steel Corporation asks for a 6.5 per cent increase on steel rods, wire, bars,.plate and structural and tubular products. Other steel makers indicate they will follow suit.

title: It's Unsettling, This New Jazz
description: HEIRS to the innovations of jazzmen John Coltrane, Ornette Coleman and Cecil Taylor continue to multiply. The older musicians among them have clung stubbornly to their variously recondite premises and procedures for over a decade now, comprising an identifiable movement which nonetheless remains unnamed and, one suspects, unnameable. The New Black Music, Black Classical Music, Free Jazz and The New Thing are all confused and confusing labels for a body of music which has been so uncompromising in its presentation of raw emotion, and so unsettling in its intimations of ghetto realities, that radio programmers, concert promoters, record business executives, and many jazz fans have feigned ignorance of its very existence.

title: There's Gold in Them There Stills
description: Bogart, said the film historian. Bogie, answered the nostalgia addict.

title: The Region
description: Just when it seemed that New York's subway riders and suburban commuters faced their darkest hour, a small light, as of the A Train humming home, appeared at the end of the tunnel. It was a pledge by the United States Transportation Secretary, Claude S. Brinegar, that the Administration was in fact considering the use of Federal funds for operating subsidies.

title: Courses Planned In Jewish Culture
description: EDISON  Courses in Jewish classical literature, antisemitism in modern times and modern Jewish history, are being planned by Middlesex County College's Division of Continuing Education in cooperation with the College for Judaic Studies of the Raritan Bay area. The courses will he given at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 316 Madison Avenue, Perth Amboy.

title: Stamps
description: LOKING back at the waning year, it has been a year of change, with personalities withdrawing from center stage, two firms among the giants of philately changing hands, and one of the hobby's most picturesque firms concluding four decades with its owner embarked on as active a retirement as any senior citizen ever undertook.

title: Baruch College Hearing Set
description: The City Council's Committee on Health and Education will meet on the relocation of Baruch College at 10 A.M. Wednesday. It is the only open committee hearing scheduled for this week.

title: Caroline Jones Has Nuptials Here
description: Miss Caroline Jones, assistant to the editor of American Heritage magazine, was married here yesterday afternoon to Donald E. Franz Jr., an investment analyst. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Owen Daly, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Abortion Rate in Canada Increases Sharply in '72
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 1 (Canadian Press)Abortions performed on Canadians increased sharply in 1972 to 38,905, from 30,923 in 1971, the Government's Bureau of Statistics reported.

title: The Society of Audio Consultants
description: WHAT IS IT? To be brief, SAC is professional trade association that sets minimum standards for its members in both audio knowledge and practical experience. To become a Certified Audio Consultant an applicant must be professionally employed as a hi fi component salesman in a bona fide audio store for period of not less than one year and pass a rigid examination. To keep his rating he must take periodic exams dealing with the latest technological advances in audio componentry.

title: Leonard Marks Picked To Head Refugee Unit
description: Leonard H. Marks, a Washington lawyer specializing in communications and a former director of the United States Information Agency, has been elected president of the International Rescue Committee, a nonsectarian refugee agency.

title: Was the civilrights struggle worth it?
description: Richard L. Mack is a tall, handsome man whose grandfather could well have been an Ashanti chieftain. He often made dramatic appearances in the doorways of noisy classrooms or in the middle of sullen student crowds; he would stand there grimacing with his arms folded Pharaohlike and then stride off in some unpredictable direction, leaving silence and order in his wake.

title: Lights Are Growing Dim Over Sports in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 1 (UPI)Sport throughout Europe is beginning to feel the energy squeeze, and nowhere is the grip tightening more than on ski resorts.

title: Australia Again Bars Export Of Her Prized Merino Rams
description: SYDNEY, Australia. Dec. 1 The Government has again imposed an official prohibition on the export of Australia's prized Merino rams  an action that is a delicate political issue that once saw Prime Minister Gough Whitiam overruled by his Cabinet when he wanted to sell some of the valuable sheep to China.

title: MRS. PETER JAY
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Dec. 1Mrs. Gertrude Holden Jay, active in national and state garden and conservation activities for 25 years, died of cancer on Thursday at her home near here. She was 58 years old.

title: Flyers Dominate Puck
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Dec. 1 There were no fights tonight despite the fact that the two roughest teams in the National Hockey League, the New York Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers, met headon at Nassau Coliseum. The Flyers won, 21, because they dominated a statistic hardly ever kept by the league: most minutes spent in the opponents zone.

title: Arthur Daley
description: These are tumultuous times and it is painfully obvious that Congress has infinitely more important work to do than to give high priority to a couple of bills relating to the Olympic and amateur sports structure in this country. At the moment they are on the back burners, although cautious efforts are being made to push them forward and something could pop soon. What gives these pieces of legislation extra fascination is the identity of their principal sponsors. One is Senator John Tunney of California, the only lawmaker in recorded history ever to campaign for office with the oratorical assistance of two former heavyweight champions of the world, Jack Dempsey and Gene Tunney, his father. The other is Representative Bob Mathias, also of California, and the only legislator since the first Continental Congress to win two Olympic decathlon championships. Oddly enough, Messrs. Tunney and Mathias may be on a collision course, eventual rivals some day for the same Senate seat.

title: GREECE IS LETTING UNIVERSITIES OPEN
description: ATHENS, Dec. 1The new Government, in a display of selfconfidence, ordered all universities to reopen Monday, barely two weeks after a student revolt in Athens against the rule of President George Papadopoulos.

title: Michael Tilles Fiance Of Sharon Lauterbach
description: YONKERS, Dec. 1  Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Lauterbach have announced that their daughter, Miss Sharon Lauterbach, will be married Dec. 16 to Michael Titles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Titles of the Bronx, New York.

title: Two books for $110
description: Sock it to em?the coffee table and the pocketbook, that is. We must prepare for our own upcoming Bicentennial, and here are two books costing $110. For $85 you can have Himalayas, in 88 full  page color plates, 6 foldouts and many, many blackandwhites, a 12pound book with testimonial scribbled by His Majesty, Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva, the King of Nepal, and Sir Edmund Hillary and Arnold Toynbee. Mount Everest itself, it should be noted, has been booked up by the Nepalese Government through the end of the 1970's with French Chamonix Guides, British Army climbers, Spanish, Austrians, Japanese ladies, and other national groups, so you never get closer. Edited by David Boss. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $25.

title: The Visit Chillsand Keeps Us Listening
description: ATHOUGH Friedrich Duerrenmatt's The Visit seems to be an utterly blunt, brutally straightforward parable about man's inhumanity to manwhen a vindictive woman offers an impoverished community a billion German marks to murder its most beloved citizen, you know that the community will overcome its scruples and do the jobit is actually an extraordinarily ambiguous play, and the ambiguity is what makes it so fascinating.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: EUROPEAN JEWS WATCH OIL POLICY
description: PARIS, Dec. 1Dark forebodings about Israel's future, a heightened sense of being Jewish and a readiness to denounce their own governments if they yield to growing Arab pressure are surfacing among Western European Jews partitularly in France and Britain.

title: U.S.NATO CLASH ON COSTS IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1A high State Department official said today that he belives the United States is heading for a major clash with its North Atlantic allies over sharing the financial burden resulting from the stationing of American troops in Europe.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (ERIC) HODGINS: TROLLEY TO THE MOON  There is not much point in recording my impressions of Mussolini's Italy, except to wonder if Italians still confuse we have done it with we are thinking of doing it  whatever the it may be. This selfdeceit was rampant under Fascism.

title: BLACK REELECTED CINCINNATI MAYOR
description: CINCINNATI, Dec, 1Mayor Theodore M. Berry, the first black to hold that office here, has been reelected for a second oneyear term by the City Council.

title: Cinderella story
description: Once this country cottage in the south of France housed coaches and cars instead of people. Now it is a weekend pleasure house with an ambience of understated elegance. The remake of Philip Wilson's 150yearold stone structure was a family affair. The building is situated on his father's (Peter Wilson who manages Sotheby's of London) estate and it was renovated by his brother, architect Torn Wilson. The interior was completely gutted and reworked, but the classical facade, which was added several decades after the structure was built, was left untouched. The arched window openings on the ground level were inset with sheets of glass to frame the landscape. Contemporary and traditional furnishings are blended in the new interiors. Despite the elegance, the mood is that of a country retreat.

title: Brian D. Fitzgerald Is Fiance Of Miss Nancy B. Brookfield
description: RYE, N. Y., Dec. 1  Miss Nancy B. Brookfield, a granddaughter of the late Reginald %V. Pressprich, founder of the New York investment banking firm which bears his name, has become engaged to Brian D. Fitzgerald, president of the VenCap Group, Inc., a New York financing and corporate development consulting firm.

title: John Clinton McDonough Jr. And Muffy Renz Will Marry
description: Miss Janet Pitchford Renz, a production assistant with the sports department of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and John Clinton McDonough Jr., an associate director with C.B.S. Sports, will be married in June.

title: State's Crop Output Up Sharply in '73
description: TRENTON  Crop production in New Jersey this past year was up sharply over 1972, Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi announced last week.

title: Some Pullout Expected
description: BONN, Nov. 29  The Government of Britain, France and West Germany have become convinced that the United Slates is determined to withdraw some of its military forces from Europe. Conversations with senior officials in the cap itals of the three countries convey a deep sense of insecurity about the future defense of the region.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  A hypothetical Bill and Jim Clark, both married, both with children and both used to good incomes, will be standing next to each other sometime next year at the state unemployment compensation office.

title: Sports News. Briefs
description: Elesnar Wins Trotting Classic

title: GERM OFF HERE TO 170 COMPANIES
description: More than 170 of the largest industrial ndustrial consumers of natural gas in New York and New Jersey were shut off last week by the Long Island Lighting Company and by New Jersey's Public Service Electric and Gas Company, forcing the companies to take emergency measures.

title: What's Doing in ATLANTA
description: THE CITYSeveral years after his troops burned Atlanta to the ground, Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, the first American urban renewalist, returned to tell the city fathers he had really bestowed a favor on them: They could build a modern city. After a lapse of about a century they took his advice, and today Atlanta's growth and prosperity are the envy of every Chamber of Commerce east of the Mississippi and south of Cincinnati. Atlantans, both black and white, are justly proud of their metropolis, and traveling salesmen exhausted from the ennui of Birmingham, Ala., or Raleigh, N. C., look forward to the joys of Atlanta. However, one caveat to travelers who come here seeking a Babylon on the Chattahoochee, as it has been called: Even though Atlanta remains a friendly town, filled with a lot of friendly people, bigness has not yet created the institution of greatness. The rapid growth has been in motion for about two decades, not time enough for the things that men cherish about big cities beyond air pollution and traffic jams to catch up with the economic indexes. That is not to say that Northerners exhausted with urban blight don't, find Atlanta refreshing and revel in the beautiful spring and fall, which are perfect for golf and tennis, or that Southerners drawn here don't find it the greatest thing since sliced bread. Hotlanta, the good ol' boys from the hinterlands cry, and every night you can find people craning their necks at the glass elevators sliding down the middle of the vast Regency Hyatt House lobby, the No. 1 tourist attraction in the city. But if glass elevators don't knock you out, Atlanta's night life can present a challenge. And forget about Sunday, when there is an absolute ban on all alcoholic beverages in bars,FOR CIVIL. WAR BUFFSGrant Park is a kw minutes from downtown (don't lot. a minute think it was named for Ulysses S.), and in the middle of the park is the Cyckrama, which sounds like a Honda dialership but is actually a panoramic painting of the Battle of Atlanta, a sort of circular nineton American Heritage foldout. If you wonder why it is housed in a inausoletilike building, don't forget it was painted by Union artists about a Union victory (adults $125, children 75 cents). Kennesaw Mountain, site of the national battlefield park, is a short drive north of the city on 175. You.can drive or walk to the top to survey the countryside to the north where the Confederate defenders of Atlanta first engaged Sherman's troops. There is no museum, but maps and markers provide a feeling of the sweep and scope of the engagement. Margaret Mitchell, author of Gone With the Wind, ordered that her notes and unfinished writings be destroyed at her death but for hardcore G. W. T. W. buffs there's a Margaret. Mitchell room in the Atlanta Public Library, showing her few surviving personal effects. Bus tours into the Tara plantation country of Jonesboro, southeast of the city, are available during the summer. Stone Mountain, of no historic significance other, than that the modern Ku Klux Klan was revived there in 1915, is the centerpiece for a state park and has a titantic bas relief of Confederate heroes on one side. Admission is $2 but costs inside the park can pile up, including fares for such rides as, the sternwheel riverboat and the cable car to the top of the mountain, which is the world'sARTS AND CULTUREThe city foist from the ashes left from Sherman's torch, but no phoenix survived the 1962 crash in Paris of the airliner carrying the foremost: patrons of the arts in Atlanta. The cultural renaissance that was, under way perished with the victims and was replaced with a Maddoxism that bans plays like Boys in the Band and movies like Last Tango in Paris. The High Museum of Art, 1280 Peachtree. Street Northeast, has a Monet (one of the Houses of Parliament), but the collection is skimpy. The Atlanta Symphony, with Robert Shaw conducting, tends to be circumscribed by pressure to perform old favorites. To find out what attraction is currently at the Civic Center, from opera to bluegrass music, call 5236275.MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.'S GRAVEIt's a simple grave at the Ebenezer Baptist Church, 407 Auburn Avenue Northeast, marked only, by a torch and the Words Free at Last, Free at Last/Thank God Almighty, Free at'Last. One day there may be a grander memorial, but masonry and glass won't change history, and no matter how simple the grave, here lies the man who shook the conscience of a nation.DOGWOOD FESTIVALIn early spring; Atlanta is one of the prettiest cities in the nation, blazing with the glory of blooming dogwoods, azaleas, camellias and jonquils. Festival week next April 614 will offer assorted tours of the countryside, outdoor art shows and craft displays. If you have the time, rent a raft and float down the Chattahoochee. It's not as rugged as the Colorado River, but some swear it's about as pretty.

title: We Won't Be Taking The Old Family Bus For a Spin Anymore
description: THERE'S a special poignance in the air these days, blending with the exhaust fumes on the Long Island Expressway, the Deegan and the Bruckner. Drivers are beginning to look back to the autumn of 1973 as the end of an era, as the last time that it was possible to fill the tank and take the family for a Sunday drive.

title: Allen's Redskins Favored
description: Tied with San Diego and trailing Houston by only game and a half in the race for the No. 1 draft pick next year, the New York Giants don't figure to lose much ground when they face the Redskins in Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Stadium today.

title: News of the Stage
description: Haila Stoddard, the actressproducer, who conceived and cosponsored two Broadway revues based on material by the late humorist James Thurber, is readying a third, The Opposite Sex.

title: NoFault Revision Sought By State Insurance Chief
description: TRENTON  Richard C. McDonough, the State Insurance Commissioner, is seeking to remove what he gallssome of the irritants in New Jersey's nofault insurance law, The irritants, he says, are creating hardships, especially for the elderly.

title: DIAMOND IS COOL TO DELAWARE PLAN.
description: PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Dec. 1  The State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, has labeled Federal plans for management of the Delaware River from Port Jervis to Hancock, N. Y. a disappointment.

title: Joseph R. Collins Sr. Dies; Officer in Society for Deaf
description: Joseph Raymond Collins Sr., a former assistant composing room foreman at The New York Times and grand vice president of the National Fraternal Society of the Deaf, died yesterday in Merrimack, N. H. Mr. Collins, who had lived at 3227 Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx, was 73 years old.

title: Dear Santa:
description: It's getting to be that time of year again. Know how I can tell? No, it's not the calendar, the chill in the air or the store decorations. It's the arrival of books with Christmas themes. Happens every yearbeginning around Junedozens of books celebrating the imminence of Christmas. Not much different this time, pretty much the same old wellroasted chestnuts: the wise guys making their way to Bethlehem, a book that's bark off the old fir tree, another interpretation of the Twelve Days, an arch folk play. Don't you get tired of this stuff, too?

title: Fordham Falls, 6944, To Princeton
description: Princeton ran up a 168 lead in the first nine minutes, then erected a sturdy zone defense to defeat Fordham, 6944, in the basketball opener for both teams before a crowd of 2,500 at Rose Hill gymnasium last night.

title: DAVID LLORENS, 34, WRITER AND EDITOR
description: David Llorens, director of the blackstudies department at the University of Washington in Seattle and former associate editor of Ebony magazine, was killed Monday, when his automobile crashed into the rear of a trailer truck on a highway in College County, Washington. He was 34 years old.

title: Bird Farm Curbed By Import Ruling
description: OLD BRIDGEFor the last 33 years, many zoos and private collectors of exotic and rare species of birds have purchased them from the Canary Bird Farm here, thus often sparing the need for expensive expeditions to the birds' more exotic habitats.

title: Gilliam Rises as a Black Quarterback
description: Because he is the only totally healthy Pittsburgh quarterback, Joe Gilliam likely will be the starter tomorrow night in Miami when the Steelers play the Dolphins. Gilliam has played in four pro games in his 22 years, and this one will be his first startand on national television. He did not sound as if he was nervous. It's a terrific challenge for me, or any other quarterback, he said the other day.

title: Irish Crush Miami, 440, To End Season Unbeaten
description: MIAMI, Dec. 1 (AP)Wayne Bullock and Pete Demmerle each scored two touchdowns tonight as Notre Dame defeated Miami, 440, to finish with its first unbeaten regular season since 1949.

title: Kicks Make Tennessee 2017 Victor
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 1 (AP)  Ricky Townsend kicked field goals of 34 and 37 yards in the last five minutes of the game as Tennessee rallied to beat Vanderbilt, 20.17, in a Southeastern Conference football contest today.

title: FUND FOR NEEDIEST TO OPEN 62D DRIVE
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will open its 62d annual appeal next Sunday. The day, the third Sunday before Christmas, is the appeal's traditional opening date.

title: More Trouble Plaguing Con Ed APlant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's new nuclear generating plant at Indian Point, which was shut down by an accident on Nov. 13, has more problems than those that were publicly announced, the utility's officials have conceded.

title: Christmas Amnesty
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (UPI) Circuit Judge Robert L. Hunter of the Divorce Court said this week that men serving maximum six month sentences for failure to pay alimony or childsupport would be released to spend Christmas with their families.

title: Woman, 23, Slain in Bar
description: A 23yearold Brooklyn woman was shot and killed in Brooklyn bar Friday by an unknown man. The victim, Linda Walker of 290 Blake Avenue, was standing at the bar, at 704 Nostrand Avenue, when she was shot.

title: Winn Kadick Married To Winthrop Redmond
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Bethlehem Chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul (the Washington Cathedral) was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Winn Kadick to Winthrop William Redmond.

title: 2 Delicate Flavors That Complement Each Other
description: Most of the common, N.H. hie shellfish are a greater delight to the palate than the eye. The scallop, however, is as beautiful to coot crania te as it is to consume. An inspiration to Christian Pilgrims, Renaissance artists and corporate executives alike, the symmetrically fluted scallop shell is a masterpiece of design.

title: Princeton Picks Schalch
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1Tom Schalch, a defensive tackle, has.been elected captain of the 1974 Princeton football team. Schalch, a junior from Pasadena, Tex., led the Tiger squad with 94 tackles in 1973.

title: 1973: A Selection Of Noteworthy Titles
description: A. PHILIP RANDOLPH. Jervis Anderson. (Harcourt. $12.50.) Good journalistic account of the union leader and his struggle for racial justice.

title: Pyramiders File For Bankruptcy
description: With two government agencies pressing investigations and a Brooklyn Federal Court order tying up its assets, Galaxy Foods, Inc., a catalogue food service with headquarters in Brooklyn, has filed a petition in bankruptcy.

title: Barbara A. McGrath Wed to R. V. Prezioso
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 1  Miss Barbara Ann McGrath and Richard Victor Prezioso, who have master's degrees from Lehman College, she in history and he in health education, were married here this afternoon at the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Paul Yinger. The couple teach at Lincoln High School in Yonkers.

title: William Casler, Caroline Grace Married on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Dec. 1St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Caroline Erskine Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ralph Grace of Oyster Bay, to William Patrick Michael Casler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Casler of Fort Lee, N. J.

title: Headliners
description: A Man and a Legend Die

title: BLACK FEMINISTS HOLD PARLEY HERE
description: Black women from across the country  professionals, bluecollar workers, mothers, housewives and studentsattended the first black women's liberation conference here yesterday.

title: General Motors in Argentina To Sell 1,500 Vehicles to Cuba
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. I (AP)  General Motors Argentina announced today that it had agreed to sell vehicles to Cuba.

title: The New York Times Bookk Review
description: The year of Walt Disney's death, he was honored by a commemorative stamp, bearing his likeness surrounded by a nimbus of cartoon children. Now, seven years later, he is honored by It stamp of a more auspicious nature; the imprimatur of Abrams's art books. One wonders which honor Disney would have preferred, this man who once told a reporter, I've always had a nightmare. I dream that one of my pictures has ended up in an art theater.

title: HURRICANES IN 1973 DID LITTLE DAMAGE
description: MIAMI, Dec. 1 (AP)The 1973 hurricane season is closing as one of the most damagefree years on record. It also marks the end of Dr. Robert Simpson's sixyear tenure as Mr. Hurricane.

title: Mother's Day Will Be a Little Late This Year
description: JEAN EUSTACHE'S The Mother and the Whore may well be the most important film of 1973, yet it still does not have an American distributor, despite the fact it won the Special Grand Jury Prize at Cannes last spring. And it is very likely that American audiences won't have a chance to judge the film for themselves until late next year, if at all.

title: BUS ANNEX PLANS MIRED IN DEBATE
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey says that a continuing dispute with bus lines over fees for use of its Manhattan bus terminal has prevented the start of construction of a major addition to the terminal.

title: H.U.D. TO CONDUCT HEARINGS ON BIAS;Sessions on Four Areas of Discrimination Planned
description: Dr. Gloria Toote, Assistant Secretary for Equal Opportunity for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has announced that, beginning in February, her office will be conducting for the first time administrative hearings on four specific areas of discrimination.

title: FosterHome Need Grows in Hudson
description: JERSEY CITYThe Hudson County district of the state's Division of Youth and Family Services has an urgent need for foster homes to provide temporary care for children, according to Rose Zeltzer, supervisor of the program at the division's Jersey City office.

title: Ideas&Trends/Continued
description: There is at least one aspect of the news that every reporter and editor agree upon. News is always immediate. Timeliness of publication is its common denominator, and it is most of ten only time that makes the difference between news and history.

title: Kerr on Lotta
description: IT is customary for reviewers to speak of certain bad evenings in the theater as being mercifully short. Lotta is short, but merciless. Although the new lapse with music at the Public last no more than an hour and a half, it succeeds, in that relatively brief time, in making you understand that time is indeed relative. Was it Einstein who said that a minute spent kissing a girl seems shorter, somehow, than the same minute spent sitting on a red hot stove? Well, I guess you get the picture.

title: Hartwick Wins Battle Of Oneonta
description: From first in New York to second in Oneonta and back to first again in New York. This has been the story of Hartwick College's soccer team, which defeated Oneonta State. 20, yesterday before half the population of the upstate town of 13,500.

title: SCIDTISTS PRAISE JUPITER WIRES
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW. Calif., Dec. 1The Pioneer 10 spacecraft, closing in on Jupiter, re turned pictures today showing the planet's brilliantly colored bands with a definition better than the best earthbased telescopic views.

title: J.W. French Weds Linda Neshamkin
description: Miss Linda Christine Neshamkin and John Winfield French, who both hold master's degrees in architecture from the University of Pennsylvania, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Donald Harrington, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. The Rev. Fred Lerro, a Roman Catholic priest, blessed the couple.

title: Truman Tapes Have No Gaps, but Some Will Wish They Had
description: BREWSTER, N.Y.The voice of Harry S. Truman, speaking plainly about his enemies, loyally about his friends and revealingly about his philosophy, sounds forth in Plain Speaking, billed as an oral biography by Merle Miller.

title: TRUCE TEAM GAIN TOASTED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1The champagne was poured, and Polish and Canadian colonels toasted each other and the United Nations peace force taking shape for the Middle East.

title: Fireman Courses Planned in Bergen
description: MAHWAH  Training courses in basic firemanship and for pump operators have been scheduled by the Bergen County Police and Fire Training Academy.

title: THE CD4 CARTRIDGEA NEW TECHNOLOGY IN CARTRIDGE DESIGN
description: Stereo records radically changed phonograph and cartridge design, because the stylus and cartridge had to be responsive to both the horizontal and vertical information in a single record groove. The discrete four channel disc, now produced by many of the world's leading record companies, is once again bringing about radical changes in cartridge and stylus design.

title: CAIRO EMBASSY CLOSED BY LIBYA
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1Col. Muammar elQaddafi of Libya has ordered the Libyan Embassy in Cairo closed at least temporarily, informed Egyptian and Libyan diplomats said today.

title: Miss Claudia Randel Is Affianced
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 1Dr. and Mrs. Victor I. Randel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claudia Ann Randel, to George Frederick Little 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Little of Glen Head, L. I. The couple plan to be married in June.

title: Happy Pooh Year
description: What can I say about a scratchandsniff GOLDEN FRAGRANCE CALENDAR (Golden, $2.95) that leaves my children's fingernails smelling of chili? Or pickles. Or butterscotch candy, or apples, or cinnamon toast. I can say, of course, that it's vulgar. I can say that the drawings by Aurelius Battaglia are corny. I can say it has too many words like yummy and munch. And then, when I've finished objecting to its patronizing tone, I can also say that my 6yearold adores it.

title: What's Woody Allen Doing on the Music Page?
description: NEW ORLEANS THE Preservation Hall Jazz Band is fun just to watch. Big Jim Robinson, 83 years old, plays the trombone as though it were invented for him, getting a wonderful sound by playing it almost out of the right side of his mouth alone, with his left cheek flat and his right one like a balloon. During his breaks, he points to his lips as if to say they aren't that good today and then he laughs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Woman Named to Banking Board Governor Rockefeller yesterday appointed Mrs. Hiram D. Black of New York City, president of the New York Day Care Council, to the State Banking Board. A board spokesman said Mrs. Black would be the first woman to serve on the board since it was formed in 1932. The board, whose members serve without pay, regulates the banking industry. It recently raised the interestrate limit on home mortgages from 7.5 per cent to 8.5 per cent. The spokesman said Mrs. Black can be considered to represent consumer issues.

title: Thistle Bridge Triumphs
description: PAWTUCKET, R. 1., Dec. 1 (AP)Thistle Bridge won the Prudence Island Purse today at Narragansett Park, covering the five furlongs in 1 minute. Thistle Bridge paid $7 Ron Secours was second and Stalwart King finished third.

title: ENERGY ROUNDUP
description: To break the strong hold that Saudi Arabia has on the world's oil supplies, Western oil companies have stepped up their search for alternate sources. Exploration has yielded major deposits in Alaska, the North Sea and Indonesia, among other areas, but none rivals the vast reserves of Arabia, and some oil men complain they're running out of places to look.

title: SOVIET WORKERS SHOW DISCONTENT
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1  Despite considerable pay increases in the last five years, young Soviet industrial workers are becoming harder to satisfy.

title: Nancy Jo Davis Engaged
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 1 miss Nancy Jo Davis. who is with the HoffmanLandlubber Company, plans to he married in June to Steven Hirsch, head of the Noel Export Corporation, a division of Noel Industries. Both organizations make blue jeans. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Davis, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Hirsch of New Rochelle. Miss Davis is a graduate of Syracuse College. Mr. Hirsch is a graduate of Lehigh University.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Fear and panic permeated the stock market last week, a brokeragehouse analyst told his clients, as investors, reacting to widespread publicity over the energy crisis, rushed for the exits en masse, causing deep selling waves.

title: Death Penalty Restoration Is Unlikely
description: TRENTONAfter months of lingering uncertainty, the Legislature has killed a stubborn campaign to restore the death penalty in New Jersey.

title: Ruling on Prison Furloughs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) Commenwealth Court has ruled that prisoners have no automatic right to participate in a program that permits inmates to go home no weekends. The court said that Bureau of Corrections guidelines for selecting such mmates rested on professional evaluations, not simply good behavior.

title: Australia Regains Davis Cup
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 1Who said it took years to produce a championship doubles team in tennis?

title: $12,000 in Quarters Taken From Bank Vault
description: Thieves drove off with $12,000 in quarters, weighing about 600 pounds, that they stole early yesterday morning from a Chase Manhattan Bank warehouse at 7307 74th Street, Maspeth, Queens.

title: Mrs. Danz Has a Son
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 1A son was born on Nov. 11 to Mr. and Mrs. Murray Danz at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. The child has been named Warren B. Mrs. Danz is the former Miss Irene Gelber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris. Gelber of the Bronx. The child's father is divisional sales manager of P.F. Collier Company of East. Orange, educational book publisher.

title: Bonn Shift Opens Way to Prague Pact
description: BONN, Dec. 1The West German Government has decided, after months of unsuccessful negotiations, to skip the difficult question of its right to represent courts and corporations in West Berlin in its future diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia.

title: Nobody Wants To Play Max Reger
description: RUDOLF SERKIN on Tuesday will play in Carnegie Hall, as a labor of love, the Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Bach by Max Reger. I have the music before me as I write. Universal Edition, taken over from Bote and Bock. Fortythree of the densestlooking pages of notation this side of Sorabji. Often a Brahmsian look to the writing, though the sound is net Brahmsian. Consistent chordal writing of the kind that takes a big, strong hand to grasp. Complicated figurations. A monster of a piece, and very seldom played public these days. Among the big international virtuosos, has anybody played it in recent years except Serkin and Gina Bachauer?

title: The Nation
description: The first important corrective action resulting from the Watergate scandal was taken in Congress last week when the Senate voted, and the House leadership agreed, that there should he an end to most private financing of Presidential campaigns. Many of the abuses that have been disclosed in the last year have stemmed directly from the huge sums contributed to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: What's New In the Theater?
description: THE VISIT, the New Phoenix Repertory Company revival of Friedrich Duerrenmatt's play, got 12 favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Lewis, Bergen Record; Glover. AP; (laver, UPI; Holder, WNBCTV; Burke, WPIXTV; Scudder, WINSRadio; Woodruff, WMCARadio; A. Klein. WNYCRadio; Gill, New Yorker), 7 mixed reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Harris, WCBSTV; Kalem, Time; Clurman, Nation; Stasio, Cue; Hewes. Saturday Review/World) and 3 unfavorable reviews (Watt, News; S. Klein, WNEWTV; Simon, New York).

title: E. Brunswick School Unit Battling for Bond Issue
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThis town's residents will go to the polls on Dec, 11 to vote on a $2.9million bond referendum, the proceeds of which would be used to renovate nine elementary schools and purchase a 46acre site for additional high school facilities.

title: Senate's Last Sunday Meeting Occurred in 1861
description: When the Senate meets today to try to resolve its dispute on the campaign spending form plan, it will be the first session to start on a Sunday in 112 years.

title: Byrds of a Feather Act Together
description: A casting call for ostriches? To work at the Byrd Hoffman School of Byrd in a 12hourlong production called The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin to be given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music?

title: Winning
description: LOS ANGELES. In the summer of 1973, as he does every summer, John Wooden, head basketball coach at U.C.L.A. and the most successful coach in America, wrote a letter to his squad.

title: Democrats Split Over Assembly Leader
description: TRENTON  Efforts to avert a fight for the Democratic leadership of the Assembly that convenes here next month apparently have failed, forcing what could be a divisive contest among several contenders.

title: More like the novelists than the painters
description: Alongside the highminded absurdities and vulgar visual euphemisms of Victorian painting there flourished another art of the most exquisite candor and dignity  Victorian photography. Slowly, with a sometimes astonished realization of its true quality, we are beginning to recover a proper appreciation of this remarkable art, which, at the very moment when painting was commencing upon a protracted crisis in its relation to the observable world, triumphantly vindicated the representational function in an entirely visual medium.

title: Husband  Wife Students Increasing
description: NEWARK  When Antonio Principi, a new father, happily accepted congratulations from his Seton Hall University Law School classmates, the handshakes seemed appropriate. After all, married law students are not unusual.

title: Defense Motions Denied In RiotConspiracy Trial
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP)Judge Edward T. Gignoux of United States District Court has denied all defense motions to dismiss contempt of court charges against five of the Chicago conspiracy trial defendants and their attorneys. The judge also set Monday for closing arguments in the case.

title: What's New At the Movies?
description: WESTWORLD, written and directed by Michael Crichton and starring Yul Brynner, Richard Benjamin and James Brolin, got 6 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Ann Guarino, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Richard Natale, Women's Wear; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Judith Crist, New York), 2 mixed (Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Pauline Kael, New Yorker) and 5 negative (Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; William Wolf, Cue; Jay Cocks, Time).

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, S??
description: IXTAPA, MexicoWhy would anyone decide to build a multimilliondollar resort community of several hotels and private homes in a virgin tropical wilderness and how would he go about doing it? Such a project requires, first, a compelling motive, then a great deal of money, then the frenzied eye of a poet to search out such a paradise and evaluate its hidden potentialities, and finally the driving power of a real estate developer to anticipate and solve the problems and make the whole thing jell.

title: SOVIET JEWS SET PEAK EMIGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 State Department officials reported today that, despite the ArabIsraeli war, Soviet authorities permitted a record number of Jews to emigrate to Israel in October and that the number has remained at that high level since then.

title: Letters: Russians At Marks & Sparks
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Sinatra Came Back, And the Rest Was Music
description: WELL, ol' blue eyes did it. Puting a brief retirement behind him, Frank Sinatra took an hour of television and turned it into the best popularmusic special of the year. Presented on the network of the National Broadcasting Company a couple of Sundays ago, the program offered a valuable demonstration of how to succeed in show business without being contemptuous of your audience.

title: Grandparents
description: One summer, I picked up Saturday movie money by renting my grandfather to my Mends. For a dime, they could watch him whittle a chain and a whistle from one piece of birchwood and, as a bonus, he would sometimes talk as he whittled. During those lazy hot afternoons he told stories of Indians and blizzards and how barbed wire ruined the wilderness; he made us hear wolves howl and feel the ground shake as the buffalo stampeded. Week after week, Granddad gave my friends and me the gift of his past. He made the way our elders had lived intelligible and real. It was much more entertaining and exciting than the movies I saw with the money I collected.

title: Work to Begin on Stalled Trenton Mall
description: TRENTON  After more than 12 years of delays caused by lawsuits, riots and the growing disenchantment of businesses with centercity locations, it appears that plans for a Trenton mall are about to be realized.

title: CANDIDATES STIR THE FAR WEST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1Dozens of political candidacies are being honed and polished in 12 of the 13 Western states in preparation for campaigns next year where 10 Governors and 10 Senators are to be elected.

title: TEACHERS ASSAIL PLAN ON TRAINING
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., Dec. 1The State Education Department's plan for fundamentally revising the ways that school teachers throughout New York are trained and certified came under intense criticism at an allday conference at Adelphi University yesterday, sponsored by the department.

title: Maryland Coach Tops
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec 1 (AP) Jerry Claiborne, who guided Maryland's football team to an 83 wonlost record and a Peach Bowl bid in his second season at College Park, has been named coach of the year in the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Dec. 1A Swiss teenager was overpowered at the airport here today on board a Swiss airliner he had seized at gunpoint just before it landed on a flight from Zurich with 145 passengers and a crew of 15.

title: Books: New Style of Corporate Wife
description: CORPORATE WIVESCORPORATE CASUALTIES? By Robert Seidenberg. AMA COM, publishing division of American Management Associations. 177 pages. $10.

title: The Fountain of Youth, updated
description: Opposite page, surrounded by the ingredients of his field: the late Dr. Paul Niehans, father of cell therapy.

title: Weicker and Buckley Clash on Watergate Inquiry
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 1Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, of the Senate's Watergate Committee, and William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative spokesman clashed in a debate for television here this week on the proposition that the Watergate investigation has been vindicated.

title: Boardwalk Baron Wins At Maryland
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 1 (AP) Richard Saszak's Boardwalk Baron took the lead at the top of the stretch today and won the $24,250 Constellation Handicap.

title: Flatbush Town Hall Is Cited
description: At a public meeting last Wednesday, the City Planning Commission approved the recommendation of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Committee, made on Oct. 16, designating the Flatbush Town Hall an historic landmark.

title: South Korea Alerts Forces in Dispute Over Islands
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 1  Tension between North and South Korea rose sharply today as North Korea claimed territorial rights to waters around five Yellow Sea islands held by the South and Seoul placed its ;armed forces on a special alert.

title: Utility Group Gets DirtyOil Permit
description: The Connecticut State Department of Environmental, Protection, after two weeks of: public hearings and negotiadons, has decided to let Northeast Utilities burn highsulphur fuel oil for the next 120 days because of short supplies of lesspolluting fuels.

title: Flood Insurance Is Ignored
description: TRENTONDespite widespread damage and enormous financial losses since 1971, more than half of the floodprone municipalities in New Jersey have failed to provide Federally subsidized floodinsurance protection for their residents.

title: OTHER THEATER OPENINGS
description: THE INTERVIEW and THE EPIC OF BUSTER FRIENDTomorrow, Theater DeLys, 7:30. Plays by Peter Swet and Richard Lenz. Repeated Tuesday at 2.

title: Illegal Market in Pistols Found Flourishing Here
description: Rings of gunrunners are sellling thousands of cheap pistols here in a lucrative black market that, according to a recent study, is flourishing in bars and on street corners of the city.

title: Landlords Balk at Cutting Heat
description: Early signs indicate that the voluntary energyconservation program has been running into snags in the real estate industry.

title: British Superhighways To Have Badger Paths
description: LONDON, Dec. 1 (Reuters) Along with rest areas, overpasses, crash barriers and signposts, planners for Britain's superhighways are to build underpasses  for badgers.

title: Europe Turns Garbage Into Electrical Energy
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 1 (AP) Western Europe is getting a useful lift in the energy crisis from the contents of the garbage pail. Its done by incinerating ordinary household rubbish and using the steam to generate electricity.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwite indicated:

title: Rev. Walter Miller, Astronomer At Fordham and Vatican, Dies
description: The Rev. Walter J. Miller, astronomer in residence at Fordham University and a former assistant papal astronomer at the Vatican Astronomical Observatory near Rome, died Friday night at Union Hospital, the Bronx, a few hours after he had suffered a heart attack on the Bronx campus. He was 69 years old and lived at Fordham's Faber Hall.

title: A Jazz Man Finds a Horne
description: EDISONFor a man who spent his childhood in a bad neighborhood in South Brooklyn, who has worked in Greenwich Village bars since he was 17 and who is now one of the owners of a wellknown jazz club in New York City, the move to suburbia is not as easy as it might be for those who follow less exotic trades.

title: Record Entry of 3,552 For Philadelphia Show
description: The first Philadelphia dog show was held in April, 1879, and drew 684 dogs to the Industrial Arts Building, at the corner of Broad and Vine Streets. It lasted five days. The 89th edition will take only one daySaturdayin the Exhibition hail of the Civic Center. It has a record entry of 3,552, making it one of the year's larger canine events.

title: YearLong Pay Dispute In Paterson Nears End
description: PATERSON  This city's Fire and Police Commission is expected to approve on Tuesday a pay rise for firemen and policemen, and thus end an intense, yearlong salary dispute between the two departments and Mayor Thomas C. Rooney Jr.'s administration.

title: Sports (?) Books (?)
description: The assignment is impossible. Not so much because of the quantity 65 books but there are all those photographs one breezes through  but for definitional reasons: What are sports, what is a book? And for reasons of amourpropre. The addiction to sports, Thorstein Veblen wrote in an essay reprinted in SPORTS AND SOCIETY edited by John T. Talamini and Charles H. Page (Little, Brown, $10)the most serious work of the batchmarks an arrested development of [a] man's moral nature. Do I want case revealed?

title: Insurgent Mine Leaders Face Test of Power at Meeting
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1Insur gent leaders of the United Min?? Workers of America will face here next week the most important test in 12 months of dramatic change since they rose from $12,000ayear jobs in Appalachian coal mines to $30, 000a year positions of power in a union with assets of $80million.

title: British Firm Presses Midtown Building Plan
description: The British investment conglomerate that constructed the 50story General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue will start next month to demolish the west blockfront on the Avenue of the Americas between 55th and 56th Streets to make way for a new structure.

title: L. A. Sanders to Wed Christy Schaffer
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schaeffer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christy Schaeffer, to Lewis A. Sanders. He is the son of Mrs. Leonard Sanders of Roslyn Harbor and the late Mr, Sanders.

title: Miss Lisa Mann Is Married to James Edward Burke
description: Miss Lisa Mann and James Edward Burke were married here last evening in the Cottage Suite at the Hampshire House by Jerome Nathanson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of New York.

title: Foster Wins In S. Africa, Keeps Title
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 1Bob Foster of the United States outpointed Pierre Fourie of South Africa in a 15round bout today and retained the world lightheavyweight championship.

title: HARVARD PORTFOLIO PUT AT $1.35BILLION
description: Endowments and other investments for Harvard University had a market value of $1.35billion on June. 30, 1973, according to a report by the treasurer of the university to its Board of Overseers.

title: Ted Turner Proves a Candid Skipper for America's Cup
description: If all goes well, Ted Turner will be defending the America's Cup next September for the United States and the New York Yacht Club at the helm of the new yacht, Mariner. America's Cup skippers of the recent past, from Briggs Cunningham in 1958 through Bill Ficker in 1970, have been a boring bunch in the context of a sports hero. Should he qualify, Turner will change the mold, adding paprika to a bland enterprise.

title: Here's a Young Sculptor in a Hurry
description: KEN GREENLEAF, it seems, is a young artist in a hurry. Last February, at the Lo Giudice Gallery in SoHo, Greenleaf had a quite remarkable first oneman showing of his welded steel sculptures. There were three large pieces in that exhibitionthe two most impressive being Prester John and Natchez, the former approximately 7 feet high and the latter only slightly smaller. Both works revealed a formal command that one might have expected from a seasoned professional.

title: Christmas Books
description: THOMAS PYNCHON'S Gravity's Rainbow (Viking; cloth, $15; paper, $4.95) is one of the longest, darkest, most difficult and most ambitious novels in years. Its technical and verbal resources bring to Mind Melville, Faulkner and Nabokov and establish Pynchon's imaginative continuity with the great modernist movement of the early years of this century. Gravity's Rainbowis bonecrushingly dense, compulsively elaborate, silly, obscene, funny, tragic, poetic, dull, inspired, horrific, cold and blasted.

title: Water Study Finds Excessive Bacteria In 25% of Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) About a fourth of 466 water systems checked in a survey by the General Accounting Office were found to be delivering water in which the bacteria content exceeded Federal drinking water standards at least one month of the year.

title: Knicks Top Cavaliers by 11999 Here
description: Tradition, a powerful weapon, was all the Knicks needed to end a fivegame losing streak last night at Madison Square Garden as they forgot about their recent past and cut down a familiar victim, the Cleveland Cavaliers, 11999.

title: Users, Pushers Haven't Noticed It So Far
description: From the time it was introduced into the Legislature, New York State's stiff drug law has been the target of a diverse coalition of critics, from law officers to civil libertarians, who maintained that wouldn't work and shouldn't he imposed, Its architect, Governor Rockefeller insisted that it was the only recourse to stein a vicious cycle of drug use. Here is a look at how the law has worked so far.

title: Hawks Inflict 50 Loss on Canadiens
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 1 (UPI) Tony Esposito registered his fifth shutout of the season and the 41st of his career tonight and Darcy Rota, a rookie, scored two firstperiod goals as the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 50.

title: Sunday News Increases Price by 5c, to 30c a Copy
description: The Sunday News raised its newsstand price today to 30 cents a copy, a 5cent increase in the price of the Sunday issue in New York City and its suburbs.

title: B.C. Beats Holy Cross By 4221
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 1 (UPI)Mel Briggs, a wide receiver, ran for two touchdowns today and picked up a third on a 30yard pass and Mike Esposito set a career rushing mark of 192 yards as Boston College subdued Holy Cross, 4221.

title: Population Growth Since '70 Sharpest In South and West
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) Population growth since the 1970 Census has increased significantly in Southern and Western states, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Sakharov Decision Deplored in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1A number of dissidents, artists, and freethinkers within the Soviet establishment are disappointed by the decision of Andrei D. Sakharov, the atomic physicist, to apply for permission to go to America.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: DUTCH TURN DOWN 2 ARABS' DEMANDS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 1Dutch and Arab representatives made no progress toward ending the Arab oil embargo of the Netherlands during a meeting in Brussels today.

title: Place Your Bettes Please
17, Including 2 Colombo Sons, Seized Here on Gaming Charges
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office raided a social club in the Bensonhurst section early yesterday and arrested 17 men, including two sons of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, on gambling charges.

title: Christmas Trees Await the Axmen
description: TRENTON  The rolling hillsides and mountaintop fields lined with pines, spruce and fir trees have been silent throughout the year, but in the next few weeks thousands of families will move among the evergreen bows to select a Christmas tree.

title: SUGARMAN BIDS U.S. REVAMP AID
description: A proposal to remove all employable persons from the welfare system and to set up a new national program for them instead, including the creation of jobs, was made public, yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources, Administrator.

title: LEAKS FROM STAFF DENIED BY JAWORSKI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, denied today a White House aide's charge that members of his staff had leaked information to the press.

title: Behind Barbed Wire, Northern Irish Economy Booms
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 27Barbedwire fencing encircles the Ford Motor Company's automobileparts factory just outside of town, and each of the 1,200 workers is frisked before he is allowed inside. Visitors must pass through a guardhouse with shatterproof windows, and they, too, are searched for weapons by one of the 19 security guards on the payroll.

title: 2,000 Attend Spaceday As Dance Center Opens
description: It was as if the bride did not wear white but everyone was happy to see her married any way. After three years of living in minor sinoperating unofficiallythe Space for Innovative Development, an arts center for experimental groups, was formally opened yesterday.

title: Eased Fuel Curb Sought For Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2The economy and lifestyle of Southern California could be crippled if any national system of gasoline rationing does not take regional differences into account, according to transportation experts here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Biltmore Hotel's long, oval, masculinely paneled bar at 43rd Street and Madison Avenue has been called many things: the cheapest highclass saloon in town, the commuter's oasis, the businessman's retreat and, after 38 years of cascading martinis, something of an institution in midtown Manhattan.

title: Blast in Home Kills 2
description: CHARLESTON, W, Va., Dec, 2 (AP)A woman and her 4. yearold daughter were killed and three other persons were seriously injured today when an explosion ripped apart brick residence at rural Baker's Fork, the authorities' said. The dead were identified as Mrs. Charles McCormick, 26 years old, of Charleston, and her daughter, Lisa.

title: Fox Terrier Captures Top Boardwalk Award
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2A flashy black, tan and white fox terrier, Ch, Sunnybrook Spot On, owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, Va., and handled by Peter Green, was named best of 3,719 dogs today at the Boardwalk Kennel Club show in Convention Hall.

title: District Service Cabinets: Where Red Tape Is Cut and Things Get Done
description: Dr. Nina Kourre, Levander Lilly, Vincent Morris, Larry Personnette, Bill Tracy, Stan Weitrezvchowski and 24 of their fellow city officials sat around a conference table in downtown Brooklyn to discuss a number of problems.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT MELVILLE, L. I.

title: 1,000 Attend the Rededication of St. Ignatius Church
description: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church, whose original Irish parishioners attended their first mass in Yorkville dance hall in 1851, celebrated yesterday the 75th anniversary of its present Italian Renaissance  style building, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: Cowboys Stop Broncos by 2210
description: DENVER, Dec. 2  In critical game for each team's playoff chances, experience was the difference today as the Dallas Cowboys stopped the Denver Broncos, 2210. The Cowboys, in the playoffs for the last seven seasons, kept their poise. The Broncos, never close to the playoffs before, lost theirs.

title: LOUIS J. FELSTINER
description: Louis J. Felstiner, a lawyer who was also general council and a director of Shiman Industries, jewelry manufacturers in Newark, died Friday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 72 years old and lived at 531 East Lincoln Avenue in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Suburbia Threatened
description: The Greenwich, Conn., Planning and Zoning Commission's rejection of the proposed new Xerox plant as antithetical to good, planning practice, suggests that suburbia is having second thoughts about the corporate invasion. Although other communities have moved to jump into the breach with offers of industrially zoned land, the longstanding welcome to emigrating businesses may be coming to an end. What looked like a cornucopia of benefitstax returns, jobs (sometimes) and clean industry in sanitized prestige structureshas turned out to be a mixed blessing, environmentally.

title: Rutgers Says Jersey May Gain 500,000 Jobs at Cities' Cost
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 2New Jersey might gain as many as 500,000 new jobi by 1980, an authoritative Rutgers University study predicts, but the forecast also warns that the growth would be at the expense of the state's already economically troubled cities.

title: Personal Finance: JointProperty Law
description: California has lots going for it but as many a man has discovered in divorce in that state is that half of what was his (theirs) becomes hers.

title: Kababo Bahizi, Richard Allocca Wed in Kinshasa
description: Miss Kabado (MarieJos) Bahizi was married in Kinshasa, the Republic of Zaire, Saturday afternoon to Richard Allocca, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Allocca of Upper Saddle River, N. J. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kirema (Gervais) Bahizi, is commercial assistant at the United States Embassy in Kinshasa. The bridegroom is second secretary of embassy there.

title: CountyJail Hearings Set
description: NEWARK, Dec. 2 (AP)Public hearings on conditions in the state's county jails are tentatively scheduled to begin in February. John F. X. Irving, dean of Seton Hall Law School, is chairman of the state's County Penal System Study Commission, which will hold the hearings. He was appointed in September by Governor Cahill, The commission was created by the Legislature last February.

title: Lower East Side Boy, 17, Slain Near Safe Recreation Facility
description: A 17yearold boy was shot dead Saturday night, not far from a churchsponsored community room in a basement corridor of Knickerbocker Village, the housing complex on the Lower East Side.

title: A Fortress America?
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2A main theme in the rhetoric of the energy crisis is the need for American selfsufficiency. That is the goal of President Nixon's Project Independenceto insure, as he put it, that by 1980 Americans will not have to rely on any source of energy beyond our own.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open its ninth annual display of baroque Christmas ornaments tomorrow. The display, which will be on view in the Medieval Sculpture Hall through Jan. 3, was donated by Mrs. Loretta Hines Howard in 1964. Mrs. Howard will supervise the exhibition of some 180 crche figures and tree ornaments.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: A.B.C. Director Is Cleared Of Any Conflict of Interest
description: TRENTON, Dec. 2 (AP)The State Ethics Commission has found the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Director did not violate any ethics codes or conflictofinterest laws by assigning to a trustee, his stock in corporations that held mortgages on two nightclubs.

title: Vaclovas Sidzikauskas, 80; Sought Liberated Lithuania
description: Vaclovas B. Sidzikauskas, a former Lithuanian diplomat who was chairman of the Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived at 3011 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

title: Food Complaints Grow With Traffic At New Newark Airport Terminals
description: NEWARK, Dec. 2As passenger traffic mounts at Newark International Airport with the approaching holidays, so do complaints about food and food prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the last several years, the Government of the United States has come close to dictatorship. At best, the survival of American democracy, in other than name, is highly uncertain. There is tittle evidence that the men in our national legislature will exertise their constitutional powers. Will the cowardly lions only roar or will they drive the jackal from our din?

title: College Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ford Asserts He Favors Aid for Parochial Schools
description: Representative Gerald R'Ford, President Nixon's designee for Vice President, told a Jewish gathering in Queens last night that he favored giving public support in some form to schools operated by religious bodies.

title: Dowdeswell Takes Tennis Final Here
description: Roger Dowdeswell, a Rhodesian teaching pro at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy, won the third annual Jungle indoor tennis tournament, yesterday with a 62, 63 victory over Randall King, a former player at the University of California, Los Angeles, in the final at the Lexington Tennis Center here.

title: Blast in Copenhagen Fatal
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 2 (AP)  A gas explosion blew up a fourstory apartment building in a Copenhagen suburb today, killing one person and injuring seven, officials said. One person was missing. The police said big concrete slabs of the prefabricated building formed protective caves as the structure collapsed, preventing many more deaths.

title: Theater
Qaddafi Reported to Threaten Expulsion of Egyptian Workers
description: TUNIS, Dec. 2A Tunisian newspaper said today that Muammar elQaddafi is threatening to expel from Libya the approximately 100,000 Egyptians who work there.

title: William E. Umstattd Dies at 79; Led Timken RollerBearing Co.
description: CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 2William E. Umstattd, under whose presidency of the Timken Company from 1934 to 1959 the rollerbearing manufacturer increased its sales from $22million to $262million, died here today. He was 79 years old.

title: DR. JOSEPH MERNICK
description: Dr. Joseph R. Mernick, a chiropractor here for more than half a century, died yesterday at the age of 82. He lived at 114 East 90th Street.

title: Jan Ferraris Wins Golf In Playoff
description: CHIBA, Japan, Dec. 2 (AP)  Jan Ferraris, a 26yearold pro from San Francisco, sank a 10foot putt for a birdie on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff with Japan's Hisako (Chako) Higuchi today, and won the Japan women's golf classic.

title: Jan Ferraris Wins Golf In Playoff
description: CHIBA, Japan, Dec. 2 (AP)  Jan Ferraris, a 26yearold pro from San Francisco, sank a 10foot putt for a birdie on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff with Japan's Hisako (Chako) Higuchi today, and won the Japan women's golf classic.

title: Bridge: Michael and Gail Moss Win Open Pairs Regional Title
description: One of the biggest oneday pair championships ever played here ended Saturday night at the New York Hilton Hotel in a victory for one of the country's leading husbdndandwife partnerships. Michael and Gail Moss of New York headed a field of 470 pairs in taking the open pair title at the winter regionals.

title: Oil Shortage Abroad Puts Stocks in Different Light
description: PARIS, Dec. 27For the first time in the postwar period almost all the world's stock markets have been falling together, heightening fears that a generalized recession may be around the corner.

title: Jurgensen Aerials Rally Redskins in Last 8 Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Redskins did not feel like playing football for the longest time today and the Giants finally forgot how to play. Behind by 213 in the second quarter and by 2413 at the start of the fourth, Washington turned defeat into victory with two touchdowns in the last eight minutes to win, 2724.

title: BLACK FEMINISTS PREPARE POLICIES
description: The National Organization Black Feminists would up its first organizing conference yesterday by preparing an agenda of policy proposals ranging from seeking Government money for the establishment of drug programs run by black feminists for the exclusive treatment of black womenaddicts mounting a campaign of boxoff ice womencotts of racist, sexist films.

title: TV: Channel 13's Nana With Nudity and Ribaldry
description: As part of its current pledge week, an intensive drive to enlist viewer subscriptions, WNETChannel 13 has, put together a special programing package that includes the British Broadcasting Corporation's fivepart production of Emile Zola's novel Nana. The serialized work will be shown, begining at 9:30 P.M. each night, tonight through Friday.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Press Israelis for Concessions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2A firm consensus appears to have been reached within the Nixon Administration that the United States must put pressure on Israel to make significant concessions in the forthcoming Middle East peace talks in Geneva, according to several high American officials.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: PORTLANDPlaced Dennis (Mo) Layton quard, on waivers.

title: Egypt Hints She'll Boycott Talks if Israel Won't Yield
description: CAIRO, Dec. 2Egyptian officials and Governmentcontrolled newspapers strongly hinted today that Egypt might refuse to go to the proposed peace conference in Geneva on Dec. 18 if Israel failed to carry out a first troop withdrawal before then.
