title: City to End Automatic Promotion Of Pupils in New Reading Drive
description: New and tougher school standards that will end the city system's current practice of promoting virtually all pupils are to be issued this week by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: Dismal Start in Greece
description: In his first policy pronouncement, the obscure lawyer chosen by Greece's new military junta to head the Government sounded like an earlier version of the ousted President Papadopoulos. Premier Adamantios Androutsopoulos spoke of the need to cleanse Greek society before it could return to democracy. He said the country would be led to elections only when the regime deemed it ready; meanwhile Greece will be ruled by decree.

title: Sudan Delays Trial of 8
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan, Dec. 2 (Reuters)The trial of eight. Palestinian guerrillas accused of killing three diplomatstwo Americans and a Belgianduring a siege of the Saudi Arabian embassy in the Sudan last March was postponed until Dec. 10 after a court session today.

title: Nuclear Power Dilemma
description: Among the alternative sources of energy for the future, what once seemed the most promising seems to be becoming one of the more problematic.

title: HIRAM HAYDN, 66, AUTHOR, EDITOR
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Dec. 2  Hiram Haydn, editor since 1944 of The American Scholar, the quarterly of Phi Beta Kappa, and a founder of Atheneum Publishers, died here today of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and had, lived on Cape Cod for the last year.

title: BEAR SEEKS END TO CONFRONTATION
description: Abraham D. Beame, in his first formal speech since he Was elected as New York City's 104th Mayor, said yesterday that he hoped in the next four years we can turn from the politics of confrontation to the politics of agreement.

title: Major Bills In Congress
13 Firemen Hurt in SoHo
description: Thirteen firemen suffered smoke inhalation and minor injuries while battling a threealarm fire in a sixstory commercial loft building in the SoHo area yesterday, officials reported. A spokesman said the injured firemen were treated at the scene of the fire, at 57.631 Greene Street, near Grand Street, by department medical units. The blaze broke out in bales of cotton piling in a cellar of the building.

title: Congressman Has Coronary
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 (UPI) Representative William F. Walsh, Republican of Syracuse, has been hospitalized in the coronary care unit of a Syracuse hospital for a series of tests. Mr. Walsh, 61 years old, a freshman Congressman, returned home Friday after becoming ill in Washington. He was admitted to the hospital a few hours later. Hospital authorities said Mr. Walsh had suffered a mild coronary and would remain in the hospital for about three weeks.

title: Dance: Ailey's Streams
description: Streams, which the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater gave this season for the first time Saturday night at the City Center, is a very different dance piece from Mr. Ailey's works drawn from the black heritage, which originally formed the core of his company's repertory.

title: A TOUGH NEW JOB FOR ULSTER CHIEF
description: LONDON, Dec. 2William Whitelaw, whose accomplishments as Minister for Northern Ireland have probably made him the most esteemed politician in Britain, was given an equally difficult job today: managing the Government's price and wage stabilization program as Minister of Employment.

title: ChildRearing: A Return to Discipline, Without Forgetting Love
description: When Dr. Hahn G. Ginott, the psychologist, died last month, he left behind an antidote for what he called overpermissiveness in childreating. Dr. Ginott advocated disciplinediscipline that was not insulting, that was caring and that was firm.

title: Spanish Harrier Wins
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 2 (UPI)Mariano Haro of Spain won the 46th Jean Bouin crosscountry race today over the hilly Montjuich circuit with a time of 24 minutes 33 seconds for the 9.6kilometer course.

title: SENATE VOTE FAILS TO END FILIBUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2The Senate, meeting in its first Sunday session in 112 years, defeated today efforts to break a filibuster that has blocked legislation extending the Government's debt limit and financing Presidential campaigns with public funds.

title: Red Smith
description: In 83 years, the biggest score a Navy football team ever made against Army was 43 points. Saturday in their 74th and sorriest engagement, Navy got 43 points in 32 minutes, 14 seconds. It wasn't a game. It was a rabbit hunt, had for rabbits and no great satisfaction for the; hunters. To effect the 510 shutout, the Midshipmen scored a touchdown in the first period, four touchdowns, 4 extra points and a field goal in the second, two touchdowns and 2 extra points in the third and nothing in the fourth. Save for that lastquarter oversight, they could have exceeded the record total of 55 points for both teams, established by Navy's 4312 victory in 1959.

title: PANEL ASSESSES GRADUATE STAFF
description: A panel of academicians recommended that American graduate education would strengthened by putting emphasis on research and fishing in evaluating faculty members. The proposal is one of 26 a report entitled Scholarship for Society, issued yesterday by the Panel on Alternate proaches to Graduate Education. The 18month study conducted under the auspices of the Graduate Record Examinations Board and the Council of Graduate Schools in United States. The board sets policies under which entrance examinations for graduate schools are written and the council is composed of 307 universities that award 98 per cent of the doctoral grees in this country. In the 20,000word report panel asserts that current yardsticks for measuring faculty performance are irrelevant to many important activities graduate professors. Many professors, according to the panel, are repeatedly distracted by the need to cover themselves professionally through publication  often writing papers less significant to the cause of knowledge than the very project that is interrupted. There has been a continuous dispute in academic circles about the importance of research and publication, critics holding that teaching performance and other factors are not sufficiently considered in hiring, promotion and the granting of tenure. We're not talking about abandoning research and publishing as criteria, Dr. J. Boyd Page, the chairman of the Panel on Alternate Approaches, said in an interview. We just don't want them to be the sole criteria, as they have been so often in the past. Diversity Sought The panel proposes no precise amount of weight that each activity should carry in the evaluation of faculty members. It urges instead that to foster diversity among institutions, each university or graduate school, according to its functions and mission, should determine the relative importance of the various criteria. Other recommendations by the panel include the following: Graduate schools should be receptive to accepting as students and teachers people who do not have the usual academic credentials. Successful achievers in business and government, for instance, are suggested as faculty candidates. Part of a student's program, especially at the doctoral level, should call for those who do not already have such experience to become engaged in disciplinerelated work outside the university walls. Efforts should be intensified to recruit women and minority members as students and professors in graduate schools. As a part of such efforts, regulations regarding course sequences, residency and other requirements should be made more flexible to accommodate the needs of special groups such as parttime, women students with families. Reevaluation of Schools We have emphasized that there are new roles as well as new clientele for graduate education, Dr. Page writes in the preface to the report, and we urge no less than a reevaluation of the basic objectives and organization of each graduate school and the disciplines essential to it. Among the members of the panel, along with Dr. Page, were Dr. Daniel Alpert, director of the Center for Advanced Study at the University Illinois; Dr. Warren G. Bennis, president of the University Cincinnati; Dr. Patricia Albierg Graham, professor at Teachers College of Columbia University, and Dr. Rochus E. Vogt, professor at. California Institute of Technology. Another member of the panel, Benjamin H. DeMott, a professor at Amherst College, was the principal writer of the report. Copies of Scholarship for Society are available for $2 each from Educational Testing Service, which coordinated the study. Orders may be sent to E.T.S. in Princeton, N. J. 08540,

description: The Jets, who led after three quarters, 170, held on yesterday for a 2017 victory over the Baltimore Colts before 51,167 at Shea Stadium. In Washington, the Giants couldn't hold a 2413 fourthquarter lead and lost to the Redskins, 2724. Page 57.

title: Public Trust in Institutions Found to Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2Most, Americans have lost confidence in government and other institutions that affect them day by day, but their sense of dis enchantment is not shared by top officials of their state and local governments, according to a surev released by a Congressional committee today.

title: $1.8Billion City Capital Budget offered, First Drawn by GrassRoots Method
description: In what was described as the first fruit of a new, grassroots budgeting process, the City Planning Commission yesterday proposed a $1.8billion capital budget for construction and related projects in the fiscal year beginning next July 1, a figure 20 per cent below the total being spent in the current fiscal year.

title: Warning on Letter Bombs Sent to Federal Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) Federal agencies across the country have been warned to be on the lookout for letter bombs with a Swiss return address mailed from Toronto to United States Government officials and heads of American oil companies.

title: SENATE VOTE FAILS TO END FILIBUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2The Senate, meeting in its first Sunday session in 112 years, defeated today efforts to break filibuster that has blocked legislation extending the Government's debt limit and financing Presidential campaigns with public funds.

title: About New York
description: King Faisal's man was in New York last week. He comes often on the King's business, and he comes unannounced, consorts quietly with the people he wants to see, and then after visiting his relatives in Brooklyn he leaves. Most of the people he wants to see, however, live in the East 60's of Manhattan, where much of the world's business gets done in unofficial ways, and where he talked this time of oil.

title: CITY AIDES MEET IN PUERTO RICO
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 2More than 5,000 officials of cities and towns throughout the United States gathered in this resort city today for five days of meetings on such topics as the energy crisis and Federal revenue sharing, but not on the crisis facing the Presidency.

title: Rangers Triumph Here, 64
description: The New York Rangers took advantage of the ineptitude of the Toronto Maple Leafs last night to beat them, 64, in a freewheeling game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Boy Found Dead in Shaft
description: The body of a 14yearold boy was found early yesterday at the bottom of an elevator shaft in the Brooklyn apartment building where he had lived, authorities reported.

title: HARDENED ARTERY SHOWN IN PICTURE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2The technology that made possible man's first closeup map of Mars has been coupled with the oldfashioned Xray to give doctors a new and potentially important view of hardening of the arteries.

title: Tractor Plant Strike Ends
description: DECATUR, Ill., Dec. 2 (UPI) Striking members of the United Automobile Workers at the Decatur plant of Caterpillar Tractor Company voted today to accept a new contract and return to work. The union struck Caterpillar Nov. 15 at plants in five states, but central contract was approved a week ago and the strike ended everywhere but Decatur.

title: DOUGLASHOME FLIES TO SOVIET FOR TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (UPI) Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, arrived today for two days of talks with Soviet officials aimed at restoring normal relations; chilled since Britain expelled 105 suspected Soviet secret agents two years ago. Sir Alec, who flew here aboard a special Royal Air Force jet, was met by. Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: SOUTH KOREAN CHIEF RESHUFFLES CABINET
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Dec. 3 (AP)  President Park Chung Hee made a major Cabinet reshuffle today affecting half of the 20 posts. He retained Premier Kim Jong Pil.

title: Amparo Merchan Wed To Alberto Medenilla
description: Miss Amparo B. Merchan, a registered nurse at the FrenchPolyclinic Hospital, was married yesterday afternoon to Alberto A. Medenilla, an incometax consultant. Both are of New York, where the ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Duffell at the Sacred Heart of Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Germanys Make a Fresh Start In Impasse on Improved Ties
description: BERLIN, Dec. 2East and West Germany made a fresh start last week in trying to break a deadlock on normalizing relations that is slowing Chancellor Willy Brandt's attempt to improve relations with the Soviet bloc.

title: BENGURION BIER VIEWED BY 200,000
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2The people of Israel paid mournful homage today to their first Premier, David BenGurion, whose body lay in state throughout the day at the entrance to the Parliament.

title: To Them, Life With Children Isn't DrudgeryIt's a Delight
description: The doors to a free choice between working and staying at home have been opening wide for middleclass women. But numbers of them have walked through those doors and then returned, eager for the experience of being home with their childrenat least in the earlier years.

title: Miami Police Hold Daughter in Slaying Of Mother, a Writer
description: MIAMI, Dec. 3Mrs. Mary Axelson Cropper, who had been sought by the police for questioning about the death Tuesday of her 82yearoldl mother, surrendered this morning to Dade County homicide detectives.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 14yeraold boy was stabbed to death on a Brooklyn subway platfrom during an attempted holdup by two 16yearoldd. The police identified the victim as Mario Corto of 11 Second Place, South Brooklyn. Two suspects were arrested. The police said the boy and an identified companion were trying to reach South Brooklyn when they realized they had boarded the wrong train. They got off at the Utica Avenue IND station, when the stabbing took place.

title: Greek Orthodox Meeting
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (UPI)The 22d biennial clergylaity congress of the Greek Ohodox Church of North and South America will convene here from June 30 to July 6. Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Orthodox primate in the Americas, announced.

title: Nixon's Worth Put at $988,000 in G.O.P. Briefing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) A detailed record of President Nixon's personal finances showing him close to being a millionairewas given to eight Republican leaders of Congress tonight in an effort to back up the President's contention that he had earned every cent he received in public life.

title: 93,000 TV Sets Called Fire and Shock Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that more than 93,000 portable color television sets had been found during the last few months to have fire and shock hazards.

title: Brandt's Prague Trip Now Due Dec. 11
description: BONN, Dec. 3  Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel will fly to Prague on Dec. 11 to sign a treaty establishing relations with Czechoslovakia, the Czechoslovak and West German Governments announced today.

title: BENORION BURIAL AT NEGEV KIBBUTZ
Notes on People
description: Doctors have advised Pope Paul VI to limit severely the number of his public appearances during the Christmas period and generally avoid fatigue, a wellplaced source in the Vatican said yesterday.

title: HIGH COURT BARS APPEAL BY PENNSY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) By a vote of 6 to 3, theii Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by the Penn Central Railroad to overturn a lower court ruling that blocked the sale of four New York City properties owned by the bankrupt railroad.

title: House Votes $60Million For Preventing Child Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) The House approved today Federal aid to help eliminate child abuse. The measure would authorize $60million over three years to help states and private agencies finance research to prevent the estimated 60,000 cases a year in which children are beaten, burned, poisoned or otherwise abused by adults.

title: Senate Group Votes Bill For $738Million Rail Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a bill providing $738million in Federal funds to aid restructuring of bankrupt Northeast railroads but retaining Congressional control over the planning progress.

title: Kashmiri Moslem Leader Tells Pakistanis to Keep Hands Off
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Dec. 3  Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, leader of Kashmir's Moslems, warned Pakistan yesterday against interference in the internal affairs of Kashmir.

title: SIRICA STARTS JOB OF HEARING TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Chief Judge John J. Sirica, with only his law clerk for company, began today the long job of sifting out the White House Watergate tape recordings.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Weiskopf Winner in So. Africa

title: U.S. Drafts Plan to Cut Car Use.
description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency announced a new set of regulations ysterday designed to reduce the use of, automobiles in 14 of New Jersey's 21 counties without reliance on the steep parking charges that touched off a wave of protest in the state earlier last month.

title: Pioneer 10 Passes Jupiter, Will Leave Solar System
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 3  A small American spacecraft, Pioneer 10, sped within 81,000 miles of Jupiter tonight, sailing past the glowing giant ball of primordial gases for man's first closeup exploration of the largest planet in the solar system.

title: RENT WOES AIRED BY WESTCHESTER
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Dec. 3Westchester's crowded southern tier appealed today to a state commission studying living costs for local control of rent stabilization machinery.

title: U.N.Unit Drops Support of Conference on Torture
description: LONDON, Dec. 3Facilities for a conference on the abolition of torture have been withdrawn by the headquarters of UNESCO in Paris.

title: Marotte Debut Pleases Ranger Coach and Fans
description: Although Gilles Marotte's debut as a New York Ranger Sunday night was not a complete artistic success, the fans and Coach Larry Popein liked what they saw. The fans were delighted to see Captain Crunch administer at least half a dozen of his trademarked body jolts against the Toronto Maple Leafs. Marotte was the only Ranger to visit the penalty box, for elbowing Darryl Sittler in the first period and interfering with Borje Salming at the Ranger net in the second. The interference incident had a bit of everything, including the decking of Salming from the rear with a crosscheck

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Robert Stigwood has decided not to open his production of Rachel Lily Rosenbloom and Don't You Ever Forget It, the new musical by Paul Jabara, which had been scheduled to make its Broadway debut tomorrow at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State tax collections are running $355million ahead of the comparable 1972 period, State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday, and he held to a prediction that the state would have a budget surplus of $200million to $300million by next March 31, the end of the 197374 fiscal year. Governor Rockefeller has predicted a surplus of about $100million

title: Pennsylvania Road Is Blocked As Truckers Protest Fuel Cost
description: BLAKESLEE, Pa., Tuesday, Dec. 4Scores of truck drivers, enraged over the high price of fuel and lowered speed limits, staged a protest on Interstate 80 in the Pocono Mountains last night that continued into this morning, blocking all traffic More than 15 miles in each direction, the state police reported.

title: A.M.A. IS DIVIDED ON MONITOR PLAN
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 3American Medical Association members argued, often bitterly, today over whether to support or oppose a new Federal law that is to create a national monitoring system to examine the quality of each doctor's services.

title: BENGURION BURIAL AT NEGEV KIBBUTZ
description: SDE BOKER, Israel, Dec. 3 David BenGurion, Israel's first Premier, was buried here today in a starkly simple 45minute religious service near the Negev Desert kibbutz where he spent the contemplative final years of his life.

title: Relief Client Here Reportedly Put Up $67,000 Cash Bail
description: A 67yearold East Harlem woman on welfare put up $67,500 in bail money several weeks ago after she and her son were arrested on narcotics charges, welfare officials said yesterday.

title: EDWARD KINSELLA, ASSEMBLYMAN, DIES
description: SYRACUSE, Dec, 3  Assemblyman Edawrd M. Kinsella, a twoterm Republican Conservative of nearby Solvay, died this afternoon in Community General Hospital here after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: COLLEGE WEIGHS NEWTERM DELAY
description: MONTCLAIR, Dec. 3  Officials at Montclair State College are considering delaying the opening of the spring term by at least two weeks and perhaps longer in the face of the oil shortage.

title: Wage Earners Are Upset As Inflation Saps Income
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Jim Willis, a union carpenter in Bonner, Mont., (pop. 250), grossed $408.01 on his most recent weekly pay stub and is getting a 6 per cent raise, his second of the year. But Mr. Willis feels squeezed financially and is starting to worry about the future.

title: WALLACE WARNS ON SOVIET ACCORD
description: Sounding like a Presidential candidate again, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama declared last night that he did not trust either the Soviet Union or China despite their current accommodation with the United States.

title: Soviet Presses Amity in Talks With British and French Aides
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3 The Soviet Union, concerned by recent West European moves toward political and military cooperation, sought today to maintain the momentum of reconciliation in Europe in separate talks with the British Foreign Secretary and the French Defense Minister.

title: Dance: Walker Premiere
description: Dennis Wayne Is an exciting dancer who displayed his new company and gave the premiere performance of Norman Walker's Lazarus Sunday evening at the Bronx Community College. His solo was very good and so was the company, but I wonder about designating it the American Ballet Company, which evokes strong memories of Eliot Feld's former company of that same name.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Limousine Renounced By Defense Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger, as a fuel conservation measure, has given up his Cadillac limousine in favor of a smaller sedan furnished by the Pentagon motor pool, a spokesman said today.

title: N.H.L. Lends Support to Sport That Keeps Kids on the Street
description: The wild, scruffy game of street hockey, which began 100 years ago in Canada with youngsters flailing with branches at pucks composed of frozen horse manure, took another step toward respectability yesterday.

title: Rome Court Voids Warrant For Arrest of ExFascist
description: ROME, Dec. 3A Rome court of appeals has revoked an arrest warrant against Prince Junio Valerio Borghese, the wartime Fascist leader who was suspected of heading a rightwing plot to overthrow the Italian Government in December, 1970.

title: Fulton Market Strike Halts Flow of Fresh Seafood
description: Fulton Fish Market employes struck yesterday, halting most deliveries of fresh fish throughout the metropolitan area.

title: 2 EXCITY AIDES GET BRIBE TERMS
description: Charles S. Kee, mayor of Chinatown and former assistant city housing commissioner, was sentenced to six months in jail yesterday for his role in shaking down a provisional city employe.

title: LOVE QUITS POSTS AFTER A SHAKEUP IN ENERGY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3John A. Love, who gave up the governorship of Colorado five months ago to be President Nixon's energy czar, resigned today because he had been shunted aside in a shakeup of energy policymaking.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Senate wound up today a weeklong debate on legislation that would overturn the traditional American system of paying for election campaigns with money collected from private donations. The measure, which has now been put off until next year, would prohibit large private gifts of money to candidates for Federal office and, instead, would finance election campaigns with funds from the Federal Treasury.

title: Adm. Richard Colbert, Who Led Southern Europe Forces, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 Adm. Richard G. Colbert, commander in chief of Allied Forces, Southern Europe, until his retirement last month because of ill health, died today of cancer in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: Reserve Clause Replaced By 1Year N.H.L. Option
description: The National Hockey League announced yesterday it was dropping the reserve clause in future player contracts in favor of a oneyear option system similar to pro football contracts.

title: SENATE GIVES UP ON ELECTION FUND; PASSES DEBT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  A sixdayold effort to force passage of a landmark measure financing Federal election campaigns with public funds collapsed today in the Senate.

title: People and Business
description: Fred L. Turner, president of McDonald's Corporation, the giant fastfood chain with 2,600 franchised and owned stores throughout the world, has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds Ray A. Kroc, 71, who continues as chairman.

title: Sadruddin's Term Extended
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3The General Assembly decided today to extend the term of office of Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The Prince, whose office helps persons displaced by war or political upheaval, has had the post for eight years.

title: Jews in Vienna Demand Soviet Reentry Visas
description: VIENNA, Dec. 3 (AP)About 40. Soviet Jews who were unhappy in Israel and have been trying to return to their homeland forced their way into the Soviet consulate here today and stayed there for three and half hours demanding reentry visas.

title: What Price Ostpolitik?
description: When he first postponed a trip to Prague to sign treaty normalizing West Germany's relations with Czechoslovakia, Chancellor Willy Brandt called Berlin the test bed for EastWest coexistence in Europe. We are not going to be made fools of, Mr. Brandt said, referring to the Czech regime's refusal to specify that Bonn's Embassy in Prague could represent West Berlin citizens and institutions in consular business.

title: City Breaks Garbage Sound Barrier
description: Garbage trucks, which have long jarred the nerves of sleepy New Yorkers, may be quieter soon if a new model dispayed yesterday outside City Hall lives up to advance notices.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CRISIS TRIAD Three panels will dissect National Crisis and the Press in a series that starts at 8 tonight in the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, under the sponsorship of Farleigh Dickinson University. The series, with Lester Markel, former Sunday editor of The New York Times and now visiting professor at Fairleigh Dickinson, as organizer and moderator, gets under way with a discussion of How Deep Is the National Crisis?

title: Chiefs' Lohmeyer Out
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 3 (AP) The rookie defensive lineman, John Lohmeyer, suffered a fractured neck vertebra yesterday and will be sidelined for the remainder of the season, the Kansas City Chiefs said today.

title: Officials Cautiously Back TrashIntoPower Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Government officials and utility company representatives from across the country generally endorsed at a conference here today the idea of burning garbage to generate power but they warned that what appears to be a simple and ideal solution entails problems.

title: People Are Warming Up to Coal
description: Some of the coziest people in town this winter may be in some of the oldest houses and tenements, in firehouses or in classroomsprovided that the 471 public schools heated with coal do not have to close on cold days because of a fueloil shortage in the rest of the school system.

title: 2.4 Million Shares Of Airco Sought By CurtissWright
description: The CurtissWright Corporation announced yesterday that it was seeking to purchase 2.4 million shares, or about 20 per cent, of the common stock of Airco, Inc., for $18 a share. The offer would amount to $43.2million. Airco is a leading producer of industrial gases and ferroalloys.

title: A Former Premier of Greece Joins Critics of the New Regime
description: ATHENS, Dec. 3  One of Greece's principal political leaders, former Premier Panayotis Canellopoulos, joined today in the public criticism of the nation's new military rulers, which was begun last week.

title: People in Sports: Flyers' Clarke Has 20Stitch Brawl Souvenir
description: Bobby Clarke of the Philadelphia Flyers, who was the National Hockey League's most valuable player last season, required 20 stitches to close a gash in his face after a brawl between the Flyers and the California Golden Seals on Sunday night in Philadelphia. The Flyers' captain and center was struck on the head with a stick wielded by Barry Cummins of the Seals.

title: U.S. Expects Resumption Of Mideast Troop Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The United States said today that it expected Egypt and Israel to resume military talks on troop disengagement later this week, leading to a fullscale Middle East peace conference in Geneva on Dec. 18.

title: Chess: When the Going Gets Tough, Bent Larsen, Too, Gets Going
description: An early loss in a tournment is bound to have a chastizing effect, though what will come of that is an open question. The Viennese grandmaster Rudolf Spielmann (18831942) customarily saluted such a misfortune by taking himself off to the nearest bierstube and drowning his sorrows for the rest of the tourney. He would show up in the playing hall every round at the correct time all right, but his notorious skeins of losses thereafter made it clear that his heart was no longer in his work.

title: Steel Production Rose 0,10 in Week To 2,961,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Dec. I totaled 2,961,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 0.1 per cent over the 2.959,000 tons poured in the preceding week. The index of production rose to 121.4 from 121.3 a week earlier.

title: Jersey Assembly Gives Backing To Sports Complex Bond Issue
description: TRENTON, Dec. 3A controversial measure putting the state's moral pledge behind the financing of a $280million sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands cleared the New Jersey Legislature here this evening.

title: The Zeus Ziegle
description: President Nixon's troubles with newsmen are negligible compared with what Zeus had to endure. Some idea of the Olympian's difficulties with the media may be gleaned from a fragment of an ancient press briefing, the text of which is reprinted here in its entirety.

title: Duets Enhance Ailey's Hidden Rites
description: Alvin Ailey's Hidden Rites was performed by the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Company for the first time this season on Sunday afternoon, It is an exotic work and reminiscent of his Streams.

title: Suicide Pact
description: It is hard to know whether Senate Republicans were engaged in a filibuster or a suicide pact. With the help of a few Southern Democrats, they now have successfully blocked a compromise with the House on the campaign finance reform plan.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Local school boards in New Jersey will soon be considering a recommendation made last week by Edward Kilpatrick, acting state commissioner of education, that night and weekend athletic activities be eliminated in an effort to conserve fuel.

title: Mrs. Huxtable Gets City Medal at Fete For Custom House
description: Mayor Lindsay last night presented the Diamond Jubilee Medallion of the City of New York to Ada Louise Huxtable in recognition of her appointment to the editorial hoard of The New York Times, where she had been architecture critic.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: House Votes Study on Show
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) A study to consider setting up a soundandlight show at the nation's Capitol to recount its history was approved today by the House and sent to the Senate. The show would be conducted nightly at the Capitol's east front, where Presidents are inaugurated, and would spotlight different sections of the building as a recording descirbed their history. The study will be financed by the private Capitol Historical Society.

title: GULF OIL TO DIVEST A LIGHTWATER UNIT
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it planned to divest its lightwater reactor fuel fabrication operations of its whollyowned subsidiary, Gulf United Nuclear Fuels, Elmsford, N. Y.

title: Blast Closes Orly Airport; Flights Halted Temporarily
description: PARIS, Dec. 3 (Reuters)An explosion, apparently caused by a short circuit in the aircraft maintenance section, closed Orly Airport today, forcing the evacuation of passengers and the temporary cancellation of all flights.

title: New Man for Ulster
description: William Whitelaw, Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland, achieved something of a miracle last month when he brought hitherto irreconcilable Protestant and Catholic leaders into an agreement to share political power in the province. This was a prodigious accomplishment after five years of bloody sectarian strife, even if it was only a good start, as Mr. Whitelaw said, on the road to lasting peace and political stability in Ulster.

title: Fulton Market Strike Halts Flow of Fresh Seafood
description: Fulton Fish Market employes struck yesterday, halting most deliveries of fresh fish throughout the metropolitan area.

title: Columbia's Latest First
description: Columbia University's first woman trustee said last night that she would be naive not to think that being a woman had something to do with her nomination.

title: JAPANESE TO OBTAIN GAS FROM INDONESIA
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 3 (UPI)Five Japanese companies signed a $3billion contract today with Pertamina guaranteeing a yearly supply of 7.5 million tons of Indonesian liquefied natural gas to Japan over a 20year period. Pertamina, the state oil company, said delivery of the L.N.G. (equal to 180,000 barrels of crude oil a day) would begin in 1977.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SATURDAY NIGHT SPECIAL. By Robert Sherrill. Illustrated by Julio Fernandez. 338 pages. Charterhouse, $8.95.

title: Raid Cuts Saigon Gasoline Stocks a Third
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3  At least one third of South Vietnam's stock of gasoline for civilian use was reported destroyed early today by a rocket attack on a petroleum depot seven miles southeast of here.

title: Two Amex Seats Sold
description: Two seat salesone at $37,000 and the other at $36,000were reported yesterday by the American Stock Exchange. The last sale on Nov. 19 was at $42,000, The new quote is $35,000 bid and $60,000 offered.

title: H.E.W. Says Louisiana Fails To Plan for Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that Mississippi had complied with an order to make plans to desegregate its statesupported colleges and universities, but that Louisiana had failed to comply and might be subject to legal action.

title: TWONAME CHECKS FOR NEEDY TO END
description: Under the new Federal security program for the aged, blind and disabled poor, landlords in the city will find that 20,300 tenants who have been getting welfare rent checks requiring both the landlord's and their own endorsements will no longer get the separate twoparty rent checks.

title: Johnson Plans to Resign F.C.C. Position Tomorrow
description: Nicholas Johnson, the feisty, reformminded member of the. Federal Communications Commission, plans to resign his seat this week but to continue goading the broadcast establishment and the F.C.C. as a private citizen.

title: Hofstra Defeated By Mercer
description: MACON, Ga., Dec. 3Hofstra University concluded its Southern trip by losing to Mercer University tonight, 8974.

title: 4 Trades Made at Meetings
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 3Surrounded by the sights and sounds of winter games, baseball opened the busiest talent market in sports today with a flurry of trades and a steepening of the argument over who will manage the New York Yankees.

title: Leon Hart: No Lineman Will Win Heisman
description: A lineman will never again win the Heisman Trophy, according to Leon Hart, the Notre Dame end and team captain in 1949 who was the second and last lineman to win this annual, award as the outstanding intercollegiate footbal player in the United States. The Downtown Athletic Club of New York City, which conducts the national vote for the Heisman Trophy, will announce the 1973 winner at L. P.M. today. John Hicks, an Ohio State offensive tackle, is considered the leading lineman candidate this fall.

title: Chicago to Review Trading Tax Plans
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 3Mayor Richard J. Daley said today that Chicago was reevaluating its proposal to impose a tax on stock and commodity transactions in the face of vocal opposition from the city's business and investment community.

title: Chiefs' Lohmeyer Out
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 3 (AP) The rookie defensive lineman, John Lohmeyer, suffered a fractured neck vertebra yesterday and will be sidelined for the remainder of the season, the Kansas City Chiefs said today.

title: Momentum for '74 Is Left
description: The Giants have two games to play this season, against the Rams in Los Angeles next Monday night and Dec. 16 against Minnesota in the Yale Bowl.

title: Cuban Embassy Is Bombed
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 (Reuters)  A bomb wrecked the consular section of the Cuban Embassy here today and shattered windows in nearby houses. No one was injured. The bombing followed a series of shooting incidents with leftist guerrillas, in which three policemen were wounded.

title: Philharmonic Picks Up Today On Lost Chords
description: The New York Philharmonic picks up an interrupted melody today, resuming rehearsals at Avery Fisher Hall for the orchestra's first concert there since a strike broke off the season on Sept. 25.

title: House Votes Speed Limit Of 55 M.P.H. for Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The House voted today to require states to establish a uniform 55mileanhour speed limit for automobiles, buses and trucks.

title: Seoul Cabinet Change May Signal Easing of Rule
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3 A sweeping Cabinet shuffle today was being interpreted in political quarters as a signal that President Park Chung Hee might be easing his repressive rule in the face of a growing antiGovernment movement among university students, intellectuals, churchmen and journalists.

title: Ruppert Units May Open in '74
description: Ruppert Towers, one of four publicly assisted apartment buildings now being built or $100million on the site of the old Ruppert Brewery; may be ready for its first tenants in June, it was announced yesterday as Mayor Lindsay toured some nearly completed apartments and cut a symbolic ribbon at the rental office.

title: No More PassAlongs
description: The new rules for promotion of pupils in the city's elementary and junior high schools should be viewed not as a punitive toughening of standards but as humane and honest effort to give meaning to secondary education. Chancellor Irving Anker, who arrived at the change of regulations after consultation with the community school districts, has properly made reading capacity the touchstone by which pupils would be advanced or held back.

title: 9.9% Prime Rate Set By First of Chicago
description: The First National Bank of Chicago announced yesterday a second straight weekly increase in its corporate baselending rate, moving to 9.9 per cent from 9.75 per cent, effective today.

title: Byrne Displays His PreInauguration Power
description: TRENTON, Dec. 3  When does a Governorelect actually become Governor in fact? At the moment on, election night that the returns show that he won, or when he is officially inaugurated two and a half months later? In the opinion of political leaders here, there are no clearcut answers. However, if the public record is any indication, in the four weeks since Brendan T. Byrne was elected in a Democratic landslide, he is, in fact, wielding considerable gubepnatorial power right now and will undoubtedly wield much more before taking office on Jan. 15.

title: LAYOFFS TO AFFECT 137,000 G.M. WORKERS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 3 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation said today that previously announced layoffs to cut production of slowselling big cars would affect 137,000 United States and Canadian auto workers this month.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Umpires Given Power To Determine Spitball
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 3 The major leagues modified their rule against the spitball today in an effort to encourage enforcement of it. They put the issue up to the umpires judgment.

title: Energy and Serendipity
description: CHICAGO  In his energy crisis speech President Nixon called on America's scientific community to develop new sources of energy. The presumption made by the President is that the current crisis is in some way a scientific, technological problem. If that were so, we would be in greater trouble, for the American scientific community is in difficulty at the moment because the Nixon Administration has begun to dismantle this country's strength in basic research.

title: Newcombe, Kodes Will Clash Today
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) John Newcombe of Australia will face Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia in an opening match of the $50,000 Commercial Union Masters tennis tournament tomorrow at Haynes Auditorium.

title: SENATE GIVES UP ON ELECTION FUND; PASSES DEBT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  A sixdayold effort to force passage of a landmark measure financing Federal election campaigns with public funds collapsed today in the Senate.

title: Erving No CureAll for Nets' Box Office 4 Trades
description: When a $4million deal brought Julius Erving to New York from Virginia, the mood was that a knight in shining armor had arrived and, with one touch of his lance, all would be well.

title: Genesco Expects Sales to Slow
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3Retail sales will slow down in the months ahead because of unemployment problems arising from the energy crisis, Franklin M. Jarman, chairman of Genesco, Inc., said today after the company's annual meeting here.

title: Business Briefs
description: The volume of helpwanted ads increased in October, signaling a further dip in the unemployment rate, according to the Conference Board.

title: Customs Service Dog Displays DrugSniffing
description: Dog may be man's best friend most of the time, but with smugglers of narcotics it can be different.

title: Wheat Futures Advance in Price; Beef Cattle Drops
description: Talk of good export buying spurred a rise in wheat futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. As a result, the March contract closed at $4.84 a bushel, up from $4.72 on Friday.

title: Significant Effort Reported In Talks on Panama Treaty
description: PANAMA, Dec, 3 (AP)Foreign Minister Juan Antonio Tack and Ellsworth Bunker, the special United States envoy, said today that their talks in the last week represented a significant effort toward a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Pioneer 10 Passes Jupiter, Will Leave Solar System
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 3  A small American spacecraft, Pioneer 10, sped within 81,000 miles of Jupiter tonight, sailing past the glowing giant ball of primordial gases for man's first closeup exploration of the largest planet in the solar system.

title: Is Gasless Sunday Enough?
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 3Being on the highways during the first gasless Sunday was an odd experience. Virtually everyone seemed to be observing the new gassaving speed limits55 m.p.h. in North Carolinaand service stations were closed as bidden, with few exceptions. But surely these relatively easy measures are not going to be enough, if this crisis is as real as advertised.

title: BayState Leads in Lottery
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP)Massachusetts leads the states in per capita sales of lottery ticklets, William E. Perrault, director of the state lottery, said yesterday. He said that the total sale for the week ending Nov. 22 was $2.1million, which was a rate of 37 cents a person. Michigan was second at 28 cents and Pennsylvania third at 25 cents.

title: 5,000 Workers Furloughed
description: ALIQUIPPA, Pa., Dec. 3 (AP) About 5,000 workers have been furloughed at Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation's Aliquippa works in the wake of an oxygen line explosion Saturday, company officials say.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1973

title: SCHOLARSHIP RULE OF STATE UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Supreme Court upheld today the law that limits New York State Regent Scholarships to award winners who decide to go to college inside the state.

title: Beame Is Said to Favor the Concept Of Moving Baruch College to Brooklyn
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame favors, in concept, the move of the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University to Brooklyn, an aide to Mr. Beanie said yesterday.

title: U.S. Army Division in Korea Combats Racial Flare  UPS
description: TONGDUCKON, South Korea Three outbursts of racial vialence erupted among American troops here on Oct, 7, after a period of relative quiet. The incidents apparently touched off outbreaks among American forces elsewhere in South Korea.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nassau May Restrict Outdoor Lights
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 3A proposed Nassau County law that would require outdoor lighting and display advertising lights to be turned off after the close of the business day got a generally favorable reception today.

title: It's Fill 'er Up Again as Cars Crowd Stations After Drought
description: American motorists went back to the gasoline pumps yesterday, crowding into stations that had been closed Sunday, and traffic returned to normal levels on the highways.

title: Prices on Big Board Continue to Tumble
description: Stock prices tumbled sharply yesterday amid investors' concern over the increasing energy crisis, the possibility of a recession and rising interest rates.

title: House Delays Confirmation of Saxbe By Sending Bill Back to the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The House of Representatives voted today to remove a constitutional impediment to the nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be Attorney General.

title: Hockey Scoring
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Merger Plan Is Voted
description: Shareholders of the Southern National Corporation, at a meeting in Fort Worth, Tex., yesterday, approved an agreement for the company's merger into the Fort Worth National Corporation, the state's sixth largest bank holding company. The plan is subject to approval of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Many Nassau Elderly Find Only Isolation in Suburbia
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 30Winter Is particularly bad time for 84yearold Sebastiano Ferlito, of Freeport. It is too cold for him to meet his friends in the park and there is no public transportation to the nearest senior center. So he sits in his apartment waiting for spring.

title: Christmas Lights Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) Representative William A. Barrett, Democrat of Pennsylvania, asked President Nixon today to suspend energy restrictions so people could turn on lights and otherwise buoy their morale during the four days before Christmas. Mr. Barrett said he made his suggestions in a letter to the President.

title: 34 Food Places Here Are Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The Health Department has released the names of 34 more restaurant and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions on two inspections.

title: JOSEPH MURTAUGH, U.S. HEALTH AIDE, 61
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Joseph Stuart Murtaugh, a health science administrator who helped shape policy of the National Institutes of Health during their period of greatest expansion, died today at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver. Spring, Md. He was 61 years old.

title: Nixon in Reversal, Urges House to Spur Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3President Nixon, in a reversal of position, has decided to ask the House of Representatives to proceed with the big foreign trade bill despite the risk of strong antiSoviet amendments.

title: Knicks Welcome Monroe To Practice Cautiously
description: The lights on the Madison Square Garden basketball court Saturday night were still dimmed as the crowd slowly filtered in for the Knicks' game with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Just as it seemed as though a cure had been found for the mysterious malady that has been besetting the Giants this season, a relapse flattened the patient Washington over the weekend. It struck somewhat unexpectedly in the fourth quarter against the Redskins, and the more learned medical minds are now recommending a long winter of rest and seclusion, provided the ailing Giants can survive the rigors of the next fortnight.

title: Duke to Undertake Big Ten Vote Study
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (UPI)The Big Ten Commissioner, Wayne Duke, was ordered today to investigate allegations by Michigan's coach, Bo Schembechler, that the vote picking Ohio State to play in the Rose Bowl was influenced by Duke.

title: Archdiocese Names Woman To Post of Associate Vicar
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has named a woman for the first time to the post of associate vicar for religious, Cardinal Cooke announced yesterday.

title: Eisenhower College Asks Congress for $10Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) Eisenhower College came to Congress today asking for $10million it says it needs for survival.

title: Women's Groups Here Protest Transfer of RapeSquad Head
description: Fiftyfive chanting, signcarrying women protested the transfer of Lieut. Julia Tucker from commanding officer of the Police Department's sex crime analysis squad to patrol duty in Brooklyn's 88th Precinct, during a onehour demonstration outside Police Headquarters yesterday.

title: DANIEL D. WILLIAMS OF UNION SEMINARY
description: The Rev. Daniel Day Williams, Roosevelt Professor of Systematic Theology at Union Theological Seminary and author of numerous books on religious topics, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 63 and he lived at 99 Claremont Ave.

title: 28 U.S. Officers Arrive In Israel to Join Truce Unit
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 3 (AP)Twentyeight American officers arrived today to join the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization. A United Nations spokesman said that the men would take up positions along the Israeli side of the Suez and Syrian fronts for 90 days.

title: Hughes's Aides Begin Testifying on $100,000 Given to Rebozo
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Employes of Howard R. Hughes, faced with the threat of contempt citations, began testifying today to the staff of the Senate Watergate committee about a $100,000 cash payment made to Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recently, Iran's Shah, appearing on Meet the Press, revealed his grasp of underlying currents of the Arab revolution when he urged reform on Saudi Arabia. King Faisal has, however, elected the cheaper course of a political oil policy, hoping to deflect social pressures threatening Persian Gulf sheikdoms that already have toppled Iraq's monarchy. In view of Saudi Arabia's virtual dependence upon U.S. military and European technological support, the collapse of Europe without even hinting possible reprisals is disgraceful.

title: Gourmet Eating on Turnpike Is Still in the Future
description: WOODBRIDGE, Dec. 3The old Romans said, You can't argue about taste (De gustibus non est disputatidum).

title: Americans Visiting Soviet Gas Fields
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced yesterday that a group of geologists and engineers had left for the Soviet Union to make an onthespot study of natural gas fields that may supply part of United States energy needs in the nineteeneighties.

title: First Pony Express Site Makes Way for Motel
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 3 (UPI)Wrecking crews have destroyed one of the last remaining relics of the old west to make way for a motel.

title: N.H.L. Lends Support to Sport That Keeps Kids on the Street
description: The wild, scruffy game of street hockey, which began 100 years ago in Canada with youngsters flailing with branches at pucks composed of frozen horse manure, took another step toward respectability yesterday.

title: Living With Canada
description: OTTAWAIn the October issue of Foreign Affairs, Prof. Robert M. Dunn Jr. of George Washington University characterizes relations between the Governments of Canada and the United States as probably more strained than at any time in living memory.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company reported yesterday receipt of contracts for the manufacture of nuclear components valued at $64.5million. The awards were made by the Atomic Energy Commission and the work would be performed at the company's facility at Lynchburg, Va.

title: Chain Store Sales Up 10.4% in October
description: Sales volume in leading chains throughout the country in October increased by 10.4 per cent, according to a compilation by The New York Times. The October gain was the lowest so far this year and fell below the previous low figure of 10.9 per cent in March, which resulted from an early Easter.

title: Two Office Buildings Damaged in Explosions
description: Two separate explosions and fires damaged two Manhattan office buildings last night, one blast slightly injuring two staff workers of the United States Committee for Justice for Latin American Political Prisoners at 150 Fifth Avenue.

title: PENTAGON SEEKS FUNDS FOR RADARS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The Defense Department, under the pressure of a Congressional budgetary cut, has reversed itself and decided it does not have an adequate system to warn of an attack by submarinelaunched ballistic missiles.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Prices on Amex Close Sharply Lower as Trading Volume Rises
description: Sliding steadily from the opening bell, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply lower yesterday in slightly higher trading. Prices also fell in the overthecounter market in slackened trading.

title: 503d Golden Gate Suicide
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UPI)  Salpador Acirendondo became the 503d known suicide from the Golden Gate Bridge when he leaped to his death Saturday.

title: Nixon, in Reversal, Urges House to Spur Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3President Nixon, in a reversal of position, has decided to ask the House of Representatives to proceed with the big foreign trade bill despite the risk of strong antiSoviet amendments.

title: Cerebral Victim Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) A cerebral palsy victim who learned to use a typewriter by using motions of his head, the only bodily movement of which he is capable, was honored today by the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy. He is Charles F. Rayburn, 38 years old, of Great Bend, Kan., who writes magazine articles.

title: Argentina Offering Foreign Concerns Armed Protection
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3The Argentine Government has offered armed protection against guerrilla attacks to foreignowned plants that request it.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN TRIAL OF KROGH
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP) A Superior Court judge dismissed charges today against Egil Krogh Jr. in the Ellsberg burglary case. The judge said he had taken into consideration Mr. Krogh's guilty plea to similar charges in Washington, D.C.

title: RIDERS MOURNING AIRSHUTTLE LOSS
description: NEWARK, Dec. 3Disgruntled passengers said today they were disturbed by the news that Eastern Airlines was ending its shuttle service between Newark International Airport and Boston and Washington, as of Jan. 7, to save fuel.

title: For Jets and Giants, Only New Defensive Philosophy at Shea
description: Not long after Walt Michaels had departed the Jets after 10 seasons as their defensive architect, some people suggested his methods had become outmoded and were one of the reasons the Jets had crumbled since their Super Bowl championship.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Governor's transition office announced yesterday that Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne would take the oath of office at an indoor ceremony in Trenton at noon on Jan. 15 in the War Memorial Building near the State House.

title: Pioneer 10
description: Scientific history has been made with the flight of Pioneer 10 within 100,000 miles of Jupiter, the largest and most massive planet of the solar system. To accomplish this historic rendezvous, the Pioneer vehicle had flown more than 600 million miles, a distance so enormous as to make earlier rocket flights to the moon, Mars and Venus seem almost like local excursions.

title: Arabs Said to Link Peace Talks to Israeli Pullback
description: CAIRO, Dec. 3Highly placed Arab diplomats here said today that Egypt and Syria had derided to boycott the proposed Middle East peace conference at Geneva unless Israeli forces carried out at least a limited withdrawal in the Suez city area.

title: Adolfo Ruiz Cortines Dead at 82; Was President of Mexico '52'58
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 (UPI) Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, President of Mexico from 1952 to 1958, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 82.

title: Dolphins Conquer Steelers On FirstHalf Spree, 3026
description: MIAMI, Dec. 3The intercepted pass has been called the best play in football because it shifts a team so swiftly from defense to offense and often advantageously. The Miami Dolphins proved the point here tonight as they beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 3026, thanks to interceptions of six Pittsburgh passes.

title: Virdon Will Manage Denver Club in A.A.
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 3In a postscript to the fiveteam race in the National League's East last September, the Denver Bears of the American Association today signed Bill Virdon, who was dismissed as manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates with three weeks to go in the season.

title: Tumorous Japanese Gets Leg Bone Made of Alloy
description: TOKYO, Dec. 3 (AP)Doctors removed the bones from a patient's upper right leg and replaced them with an artificial set of bones, Jikei Medical University reported today.

title: VICTOR YORAN HEARD IN CELLO DEBUT HERE
description: Victor Yoran made his New York debut Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, but he had played here before. Mr. Voran first attracted attention a couple of years ago as Russian Jew who was playing here to attract attention to his efforts to persuade the Soviet authorities to let his family join him in Israel.

title: Philip Morris Takes Option On Property in Kentucky
description: Philip Morris, Inc., has taken an option to purchase 460 acres of land in Oldham County, Ky., about 20 miles from Louisville.

title: TREASURY ISSUE IS SET FOR TODAY
description: The United States Treasury, blocked yesterday by Congress from borrowing the $4.3billion it normally gets each Monday, scheduled its sale of threemonth and sixmonth bills for 1:30 P.M. today instead.

title: Relief Client Here Reportedly Put Up $67,500 Cash Bail
description: A 67yearold East Harlem woman on welfare put up $67,500 in bail money several weeks ago after she and her son were arrested on narcotics charges, welfare officials said yesterday.

title: Wage Earners Are Upset As Inflation Saps Income
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Jim Willis, a union carpenter in Bonner, Mont., (pop. 250), grossed $408.01 on his most recent weekly pay stub and is getting a 6 per cent raise, his second of the year. But Mr. Willis feels squeezed financially and is starting to worry about the future.

title: Many Nassau Elderly Find Only Isolation in Suburbia
description: MINEOLA, Nov. 30Winter Is particularly bad time for 84yearold Sebastiano Ferlito, of Freeport. It is too cold for him to meet his friends in the park and there is no public transportation to the nearest senior center. So he sits in his apartment waiting for spring.

title: 10,000 AT GARDEN HONOR BENGURION
description: More than 19,000 people last night attended a memorial tribute in Madison Square. Garden to David BenGurion, a founding father of Israel and her first Premier.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY BACKS BOND ISSUE
description: TRENTON, Dec. 3A controversial measure putting the state's moral pledge behind the financing of a $280million sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands cleared the New Jersey Legislature hers this evening.

title: THIRD U.N. PARLEY ON SEA LAW OPENS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3  Secretary General Waldheim today opened the third Law of the Sea Conference here by stressing that it was urgent to reach international agreement on the peaceful development of the ocean's resources.

title: Sunday Senate Session Not Quite So Historic
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The Senate, which thought its meeting yesterday was its first Sunday session in 112 years, found out today that it was not so historic after all.

title: Disputed Nixon Tape With Hum Examined Here in Uptown Loft
description: The tape of the conversation between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman that has been partly obliterated by an 18minute hum is being studied in a nondescript loft on West 131st Street, well within earshot of the elevated Broadway local subway trains.

title: House Panel Blocks Testimony By Matthews in S.B.A. Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The House Subcommittee on Small Business has rejected an attempt by Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, a black businessman from New York convicted of illegally using Medicaid funds, to testify before it in connection with scandals in the Small Business Administration.

title: State of Nixon's Health Is a Dimension of Watergate Affair Constantly Being Gauged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3As long as I am physically able... This seemingly ?? phrase, used by President ?? on recently when insis??ng ?? would stay in office, probab y would not have caused a ripple of interest a year ago. But in the current climate of tension and suspicion brought by the Watergate disclosures, it has aroused a new round of questions and speculation about the President's physical and mental state.

title: LOVE QUITS POSTS AFTER A SHAKEUP IN ENERGY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3John A. Love, who gave up the governorship of Colorado five months ago to be President Nixon's energy czar, resigned today because he had been shunted aside in a shakeup of energy policymaking.

title: 2 Gasoline Cans Explode, Injuring Brooklyn Youth
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn youth trying to allay the gasoline shortage was critically hurt yesterday when two onegalion gasoline containers he was carrying exploded.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1973

title: Sea Conference in Brief
description: TITLEThe Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea. It follows two previous conferences held at Geneva in 1958 and 1960.

title: A.P. Places Dorsett on AllAmerica
description: Tony Dorsett of the University of Pittsburgh, a running back, became the first freshman in 29 years to be named to The Associated Press allAmerica college football team, announced yesterday. The team has three repeaters, Randy Gradishar and John Hicks of Ohio State and Richard Wood of Southern California.

title: Governor Holds Preview Talk With Panel on Choices for U.S.
description: On the eve of the first meeting of his National Commission on Critical Choices for America, Governor Rockefeller was host last night at a private dinner for Vice Presidentdesignate Gerald R. Ford and other members of the commission.

title: Nixon's New Federalism Scored by Ohio Representative at Urban Parley
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec 3President Nixon's New Federalism was harshly criticized today before a large gathering of United States mayors and city officials as a mandate from the White House to accept its definition of a more orderly process of government.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: British Soccer Results
description: SCOTTISH CUP

title: GOVERNOR MEETS WITH PANEL ON U.S.
description: On the eve of the first meeting of his National Commission on Critical Choices for America, Governor Rockefeller was host last night at a private dinner for Vice Presidentdesignate Gerald R. Ford and other members of the commission.

title: Five thinkers who have taken up the challenge to forecast developments in their respective fields
description: PARISAn encyclopedia that makes people uncomfortable? That doesn't pretend to know it all? That raises many more questions than it answers?

title: Miss Lear's Voice And Stewart's Join In Persuasive Song
description: On the operatic stage, both Evelyn Lear and Thomas Stewart show signs of vocal wear. Miss Lear can no longer sing out at the top of the soprano range with ease or purity, and Mr. Stewart's lightness of voice and shortness of range have become more and more troubling when he essays the heavy Wagner baritone parts.

title: Pavers Admit Gifts to Lindsay's Drive
description: The city's Department of Investigation and the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York have conducted inquiries into cash contributions to Mayor Lindsay's Presidential campaign by asphalt and paving contractors who do business with the city, some of the principals of the investigations have disclosed.

title: Pincay's Purses Pass $4Million
description: Laffit Pincay discovered yesterday that he was a millionaire four times over in the matter of purses won for the current season. When he was secure in the knowledge, he decided to take the rest of the year off, starting today.

title: WOMAN IS NAMED COLUMBIA TRUSTEE
description: Columbia University announced yesterday the election of two new members of its board of trustees, including the first woman member in the school's 219year history.

title: Black Militants Accused of Bank Robbery Scuffle With Armed Marshals in Federal Courthouse
description: Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, identified as members of a militant group known as the Black Liberation Army, obtained a oneday delay of their bankrobbery trial yesterday, then scuffled briefly with armed marshals guarding them in the Federal courthouse here.

title: DEATHS ANALYZED IN KIDNEY CASES
description: Patients who have kidney transplants in small American hospitals are twice as likely to die as those who have the same operation at larger medical centers, according to a report published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Advertising: It's a Boy's Life
description: Considering it was a world premiere, the crowd was rather smallbut select. But, then, the film wasn't too long either, just 15 minutes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Theater: Are You Now or Have You Ever Been...
House Votes Speed Limit Of 55 M.P.H. for Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The House voted today to require states to establish a uniform 55mileanhour speed limit for automobiles, buses and trucks.

title: Contract Is Signed
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday signing a contract with the Taiwan Power Company of Taipei, Taiwan, for the manufacture of four electric power plants valued at approximately $20million.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
JAMES A. MULVEY OF DODGERS DEAD
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3James A. Mulvey, a vice president of the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers since 1937 and retired president of Samuel Goldwyn Productions, died here last night. He was 74 years old.

title: 2d Day of Artillery Exchanges Reported by Radio Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3Syria reported heavy exchanges of artillery and tank fire today on the Golan Heights in a second day of serious violations of the ceasefire.

title: New U.M.W. Chief Vows To Enforce Mine Safety
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec, 3  The nation's major coal operators and oil companies were told today that any efforts to increase coal production that lead to shortcuts by management in mine safety procedures would bring walkouts by members of the United Mine Workers of America, and that the union's new leadership would support the walkouts.

title: Levy TicketFixing Trial Told of Officials' Payoffs
description: A state prosecutor charged yesterday that judges, Assemblymen, commissioners, marshals and their deputies had made nighttime trips to an apartment in Brooklyn to get their parking tickets fixed.

title: Sinatra Reported Working Hard Among Friends to Raise Money to Aid Agnew
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 Frank Sinatra is working hard to raise money for his close friend, former Nice President Spiro T. Agnew, according to knowledgeable sources here.

title: Jobs Urged in Energy Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) Senator John V. Tunney proposed today that workers laid off because of the energy crisis he made eligible for public service employment. The California Democrat asked that provision for a $250million Federal subsidy for such public service jobs be provided for the current fiscal year and $500million for the fiscal year 1975 in manpower legislation now pending in a HouseSenate conference committee.

title: CITY SEEKS BLOC WITH 2 COUNTIES
description: A plan to weld the legislators from New York City, Westchester and. Nassau into a political block to present a united front in Washington and Albany on matters of mutual concern was decided upon Yesterday at a meeting of Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame, County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau and Alfred Del Bello, Mayor of Yonkers and County Executiveelect of Westchester.

title: Earl Wild in Uneven Piano Recital
description: Earl Wild is one of those strange pianists who play better as the music gets worse. In his Alice Tully Hall recital on Sunday night, he reached his peak of acceptability in Liszt's Grande tarantelle di bravura sur la tarantelle de La muede de Portici, d'Auber, a depressing piece of trash that must figure low on the quality scale of Lizst arrangements and transcriptions.

title: Policeman Dies After Trip To Coast for a Tranplant
description: Police Officer Harvey Gronwald, who was flown to California by the Patrolmen's Banevolent Association in an attemp to replace his ailing heart with a healthy one, died Sunday night at the Stanford Medical Center.

title: Music
description: The best way to judge the success of a chamber music concert is by how well it focuses one's attention on the works rather than the workers. By that standard, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center added another to its string of successes on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Needlework Experts Turn Their Hand to Writing Books
description: A decade ago, long before needlework became a national mania, embroidery enthusiasts quickly graduated from the limited stock of commercial kits and patterns to designing their own. Many of them also eventually wrote books on the subject and these figure heavily in the approximately 40 new stitchcry volumes to be found in book stores this year.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A.B.C. Technicians, Writers Threaten to Strike Today
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 3 (UPI) Newswriters and technicians of the American Broadcasting Company are scheduled to go on strike tomorrow night if negotiations for higher wages fail.

title: Fernandez Victor In Bout at Forum
description: Chris Fernandez, 30yearold welterweight from the Dominican Republic, scored a decision over Adolphus McClendon of Paterson, N. J. last night in a 10round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: South Vietnamese Planes Fly 124 Bombing Sorties
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 4The Saigon military spokesman announced today that South Vietnamese aircraft had flown 124 bombing sorties yesterday against Communist positions.

title: It's Fill 'er Up A gain as Cars Crowd Stations After Drought
description: American motorists went back to the gasoline pumps yesterday, crowding into stations that had been closed Sunday, and traffic returned to normal levels on the highways.

title: Inventories Rose Moderately in October
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 Manufacturers' inventories continued to rise moderately in October as shipments and new orders boomed, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TV: 90Minute Soaps
description: The 913minute soap opera isn't new. It's a staple on prime time evening television, and has been used experimentally in the afternoon schedule. The experiment seems to be working. This week, the American Broadcasting Company is offering no fewer than five special daytime dramas, Monday through Friday, beginning each day at 1:30 P.M.

title: North Vietnamese Defects Because Life Is Miserable
description: LAI KHE, South VietnamA thin young man in wrinkled green North Vietnamese Army fatigues folded and unfolded his hands as he sat and talked in the South Vietnamese division commander's office.

title: Knicks Welcome Monroe To Practice Cautiously
description: The lights on the Madison Square Garden basketball court. Saturday night were still dimmed as the crowd slowly filtered in for the Knicks' game with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: CARL S. SWISHER
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 3 Carl S. Swisher, former president of the John H. Swisher Cigar Company, died here yes terday at the age of 82. He headed the concern which manufactured. King Edward Cigars, from 1944 until six years ago, when he became chairman. He was a member of the Cigar Hall of Fame.

title: BOY DIES IN KNIFING ON IND PLATFORM
description: A 14yearold boy who spoke no English was stabbed to death on a Brooklyn subway platform yesterday as he and a companion attempted to evade a holdup by two 16yearolds, the police reported.

title: Body Tossed From Car In Shooting in Brooklyn
description: The body of a 41yearold man with three bullet wounds, was tossed from an automobile shortly before midnight last night at the intersection of East 56th Street and Whitty Lane in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, according to the police.

title: Mechanics' Raise Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) The Cost of Living Council said today that it was challenging the size of pay increases for about 5,300 mechanics employed by four airlinesDelta, Braniff, Frontier and North Central. The council said that the scheduled increases for the mechanics for 1973 and 1974 may be inconsistent with the wagesalary guidelines of the Government's wageprice control program.

title: CITY SEEKS BLOC WITH 2 COUNTIES
description: A plan to weld the legislators from New York City, Westchester and Nassau into a political block to present a united front in Washington and Albany on matters of mutual concern was decided Upon yesterday at a meeting of Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame, County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau and Alfred Del Bello, Mayor of Yonkers and County Executiveelect of Westchester.

title: Stage: Miss M. Divine
description: Despite Bette Midler's Honolulu birthplace, New York has always regarded her as homegrown and hometown. Not for nothing does a club where she more or less began her current career as a singer have the piano inscribed with a brass plaque because Miss Midler first leaned there. And not for nothing did that same segment of audience, now much grown, welcome hack the singer to the Palace Theater, Broadway, last night. She is now called the Divine Miss M., has been duly consecrated by the likes of Johnny Carson and terms herself the last of the truly tacky women.

title: ARCHITECT NAMED TO PLANNING BODY
description: Mayor Lindsay filled the only vacancy on the City Planning Commission yesterday, placing in doubt the job of the current commission chairman when Abraham D. Beame takes over as Mayor.

title: PIONEER YANKED AROUND JUPITER
description: Jupiter reached out with its exceptionally strong gravitational field last night and gave to the first manmade intruder into its vicinity a tremendous yank throwing Pioneer 10 into a trajectory that will carry it far beyond the solar system.

title: JOHN A. HILL DIES; AIRCO CHAIRMAN
description: John A. Hill, who retired in 1969 as chairman of Airco, Inc., formerly the Air Reduction Company, died Sunday night (while visiting his daughter's home in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. He was 69 years old and had moved from Armonk, N. Y. to Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Bridge:
description: The tournament trend in recent years has been toward youth, but the veterans make their presence felt from time to time. The Winter Regional Swiss Team Championship, played Sunday at the New York Hilton Hotel, was won by the oldest team in the event. Dr. Kalman Apfel, Phil Goodman, Francis Begley, Dave Halper, all of New York, and Abe Schoenfeld of Hicksville, L. L, whose average age is 62, headed the field of 224 teams, with a score of 119 victory points out of a possible 160.

title: Gulf Western Sets 3Month Profit Record
Truly Independent
description: In reporting out its bill to provide for a courtappointed Watergate prosecutor, the House Judiciary Committee declared that the only way to assure that the American people will have complete trust and confidence in the aggressiveness and independence of the special prosecutor is to make him truly independent of the Executive, give him tenure, and legislate limited grounds, for his removal.

title: People in Sports: Perry's Pitch Doomed?
