description: Mrs. Grace Higby Peck, the widow of F. Hamilton Peck, a longtime newspaper man, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 915 West End Avenue.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: IRONIA, Dec. 5John Tiernan, who spends much of his spare time during the winter dreaming about skitouring trips, is hoping the snow falls with more regularity than last year in this Morris County region.

title: Rutgers Panel Scores Policy on Blacks
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 5. A report by a Rutgers College faculty committee today criticized campus policies affecting black students and urged a sweeping reevaluation and change of admissions, counseling and financial aid policies.

title: HOUSING IS URGED ON BIGLOT TOWN
description: LEWISBORO, N. Y., Dec. 5The microphone went dead at one point last night as Eleanor Steinholtz, an economic consultant, was explaining to hundreds of residents here why they should accept a mixedincome housing project that would double the size of their town in eight years.

title: North and South Koreans Meet To Discuss a Renewal of Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 5Negotiators from South Korea and North Korea met today at the armistice border camp of Panmunjom to discuss the resumption of political talks between the two countries.

title: REBOZO BANK TOLD TO YIELD RECORDS
description: MIAMI, Dec. 5The Key Biscayne bank headed by Charles G. Rebozo was ordered today by a Florida judge to give him the names of those who maintain accounts in the bank's small trust department.

title: Glitter Outshines Show At Blue Angel Opening
description: It was supposed to bring back the glories of nightclub life in New York before muggings and television kept people off the streets.

title: BEAME ASKS 265 OP MAYOR'S AIDES TO RESIGN POSTS
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beanie called yesterday for the resignation of 265 highranking officials in the Lindsay administration.

title: Stock Prices Slump
description: Worries over the energy crisis and the uncertainty of corporate profits continued to batter the stock market yesterday. The DowJones industrial average, dropping 14.90 points to 788.31, has tumbled nearly 200 points in less than six weeks. Page 71.

title: Johnson Quits F.C.C. Post; To Join Law Firm in Iowa
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) Nicholas Johnson announced tonight that he was stepping down as a Federal Communications Commisioner without waiting for the Senate to confirm a succesor.

title: Notes on People
description: Moving to fill a vacancy created more than a year ago, President Nixon announced yesterday his plans to nominate Arthur S. Flemming to succeed the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh as chairman of the Commission on Civil Rights. Father Hesburgh, sharply critical of the Nixon Administration on civil rights, was dismissed in November, 1972, from the commission he had served for 15 years and resumed fully his duties as president of the University of Notre Dame.

title: Dodgers Also Acquire Agee From Cards
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5  Mike Marshall, baseball's top relief pitcher of 1973, was traded by Montreal to Los Angeles today for Willie Davis, the 33yearold center fielder who is one of baseball's biggest everyday stars.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Greyhound Computer Set to Acquire EDP Resources
description: The Greyhound Computes Corporation announced yesterday it intended to acquire EDP Resources, Inc., of White Plains, a computerleasing company.

title: Stock Prices Slump
description: Worries over the energy crisis and the uncertainty of corporate profits continued to batter the stock market yesterday. The DowJones industrial average, dropping 14.90 points to 788.31, has tumbled nearly 200 points in less than six weeks. Page 71.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On behalf of the National Council of Senior Citizens, a nonpartisan, nationwide organization of older people's clubs, I wish to express disagreement with your Nov. 13 editorial on a pending costofliving increase in Social Security cash benefits.

title: Equity Charges Kickbacks at the Children's Theater
description: A longstanding dispute between Actors Equity and the head of the Robert F. Kennedy Theater for Children has broken out into open warfare with both sides charging misrepresentation and intimidation.

title: Fuel a Worry in Car Renting
description: National Car Rental Systern, Inc., the nation's third largest car rental concern, is no longer filling up some of its vehicles' fuel tanks for customers.

title: Soviet Reduction of Heroes Cuts Down Even Olga Korbut
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5This has been had year for Soviet international sports champions. It almost seems someone prefers to have their images somewhat tarnished.

title: Schools Will Extend Holiday by 3 Days To Save Heating Oil
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5  The State Board of Education today ordered all school districts in the state to extend the Christmas recess for three days to save heating oil. The canceled classes will be added to the school year in June.

title: Kom Statue Is Back in Cameroon, and Its Kingdom Plans Biggest Festival of All Time
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Dec. 5 The AfoAKom, the centuryold sacred wood carving( was returned to the Fon of Kom today, seven years after it had mysteriously disappeared from the royal compound in its tiny kingdom and less than two months after It was found on sale in a New York art gallery.

title: Santa Fe Sets $38Million For California Freight Yard
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI)The Santa Fe Railway announced today it would build a $38million freight car classification yard at Barstow, Calif., just west of present yards.

title: CLIFFORD SHIPTON, HISTORIAN, 71, DIES
description: SHIRLEY, Mass., Dec. 5Dr. Clifford K. Shipton, director emeritus of the American Antiquarian Society and an authority On colonial America, died yesterday in Nashoba Community Hospital. He was 71 years old and had lived here for many years.

title: Stock Repurchases Sifted
description: Sliding stock prices have moved scores of corporations to seek their own shares in the stock market but not without some misgivings in Washington.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Blaze Leaves 50 Homeless And Injures 24 Firemen
description: Fifty persons were driven from their homes last night by a fire in a sevenstory tenement at 524 East 12th Street, between Avenues A and B,

title: Suicide Note Left by Morse Says He Considered Taking His Life Many Years Ago
description: United States Attorney Robert A. Morse, who leaned to his death from his Brooklyn apartment Tuesday, left a suicide note saying that he had considered taking his life many years ago and had consulted a psychiatrist, at that time, investigators said yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Western railroads have petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 5 per cent general freight rate increase on traffic in the Western states and between the Western and Eastern states.

title: Democrat Wins Seat
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5 (AP)Charles R. Mansolillo, a 24yearold Democrat, won the special election yesterday as state representative from Providence's 18th district.

title: C.A.B. Seeks a Role In Flight Schedules
description: Robert D. Timm, chairman o the Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that his agenc must take from airline man agement many of its prerog atives for scheduling flights adequate service is to be main tained in the face of massivt projected cutbacks due to fue shortages.

title: Theater: Witty Fashion
description: Fashion, a new musical with a clever idea, a bubbly score and a disarming tone of sly, clean amusement, proves that at least one Off Broadway house is ready with the Christmas spirit. This slender sapling of a show, with a cast of eight women and one man, is though, a honey for all seasons. The Greenwich Mews Theater, at 141 West 13th Street (CH 36800, WA 99868), is presenting it through Dec, 15, with admission by contribution.

title: Byrne and Rockefeller to, er, Cooperate
description: Governor Rockefeller and Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's Governor  elect, exchanged friendly, generalized promises of cooperation here yesterday, then politely disagreed over their rival plans for sports complexes.

title: Southern Conservatives Form National Presbyterian Church
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 5  Conservatives within the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. founded a new denomination today and named in the National Presbyterian Church.

title: Dance: Missa Brevis
description: Alvin Ailey has a particular dream for American modern dance. He wants to form an ecumenical dance company. Not only does he want to create new works, by himself and other choreographers, but he also wants to provide a permanent home for historic moderndance works.

title: RALPH J. CORDINER, EXG.E. HEAD, DIES
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Dec.  Ralph J. Cordiner, whose wideranging philosophies of professional management as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the General Electric Company made him one of the bestknown men in American industry, died of cancer today. He was 73 years old.

title: Chess: Never Have So Many Cared So Little About So Much
description: Nowadays the old emotionally biased attitude toward playing styles and choice of openings has by and large retreated in the face of a sober, pragmatic approach. There is no one around who would declare, as Wilhelm Steinitz did after his 1889 match with Mikhail Tchigorin; The young master of the old school sacrificed pawns and pieces, but the old master did morehe sacrificed whole games to prove what he understands by sound rules.

title: FRANCE STEPS UP INFLATION FIGHT
description: PARIS, Dec. 5On the eve, of a general strike, the French Government disclosed today new moves to check inflation now running at more than 10 per cent annually, and at the same time insure high employment during the energy crisis.

title: White House Silent on Haldeman Files
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The White House would not say today who owns the files that H. R. Haldeman left behind but apparently continued to control after he resigned as President Nixon's chief of staff last April 30.

title: League Meets Today On San Diego Setup
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5  The National League will meet again tomorrow morning to consider the disposition of the San Diego franchise. A fourhour session today ended with no votes taken and no decisions made.

title: New Haven Ordered To Increase Ranks Of Minority Firemen
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5The New Haven Fire Department agreed in Federal Court here today to end allegedly discriminatory hiring and promotion practices and institute compensatory policies preferential to blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: Hungarian Long Hairs Go Far
description: The Hungarian long hairs are doing very well in the Caribbean. The komondor and pull, which for centuries reamed the Magyar puszta while herding sheep and cattle, now lope over the palmcovered hills of Puerto Ri co chasing salamanders and coquis (tiny frogs). Indeed, on that island, renowned for its rum, there is now a sparkling Tokay  a pull, not a winetaken there by Mr. and Mrs. Earl Williamson.

title: Court Says Company Collecting $8Million a Year in Rents Is Too Small to Be Covered by Wage Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Supreme Court ruled today that an apartment management company in Virginia that collected $8million a year in rent was too small to be required to meet Federal minimum wage laws.

title: Coast Guard Brings In 19 From Lost Cypriot Freighter
description: The Coast Guard cutter Unimak arrived here yesterday morning with the 19 crew members of the Cypriot freighter Aegis Duty.

title: DouglasHome Reports Ties With Soviet Back to Normal
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP)Foreign Secretary Sir Alec DouglasHome returned today from two days of talks with Soviet leaders in Moscow and said relations between Britain and the Soviet Union were now back to normal after the coolness of the past two years.

title: Nets Topple Pacers for 5th in Row
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 5 Larry Kenon, the rookie forward of the New York Nets, scored a game high of 25 points and snared 15 rebounds tonight to spark a 108103 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: ExCandidate Fined $1,000
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) A Federal judge fined Jack Insko, an unsuccessful Repute lican candidate for Congress, $1,000 today for violating Federal election laws. Mr. Insko was found guilty Nov. 8 of distributing bogus bumper stickers during his 1972 campaign against Representative William D. Gunter Jr., a Democrat.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Glassboro State College has stopped participating in an educational program for prison inmates following the filing of assault charges against one Leesburg Prison Farm inmate who attended evening classes at the school. The program, sponsored by the Garden State Educational District, allows model prisoners to leave the prison unescorted to attend the college for a few hours a day The school's action was prompted by concern for student and faculty safety after the arrest of William T. Boland Jr., 40 years old, formerly of Newark. He was seized in Woodbury on assault charges.

title: MRS. JEAN AURINGER
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 5. (AP)  Mrs. Jean Tomlinson Auringer, secretary  treasurer of the Morristown Daily Record, Inc., died of cancer yesterday in the Community Medical Center here. She was 42 years old and lived in Madison.

title: CITY BLACKS GET MOST ABORTIONS
description: More black women residents here than white received abortions in the year ended June 30 1973, although the 1970 Census figures indicate that there are twice as many white women of childbearing age as black.

title: A's Refuse to Relax Hold on Williams
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5  The New York Yankees lost big yardage today in baseball's celebrated case of the stolen managers when Charles O. Finley of the Oakland A's refused to relax his legal grip on Dick Williams.

title: Soviet Reduction of Heroes Cuts Down Even Olga Korbut
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5This has been had year for Soviet international sports champions. It almost seems someone prefers to have their images somewhat tarnished.

title: Giants Reinstate Evansto Taxi Squad
description: Charlie Evans, the New York Giants running back suspended last week for conduct detrimental to the club, has been reinstated by coach Alex Webster.

title: Rangers Beat Blues, 51, And Take Second Place
description: The New York Rangers, enjoying a relaxed evening, gave a hockey lesson to the St. Louis Blues last night at Madison Square Garden, beating them, 51. With the victory the Rangers passed Montreal and moved into second place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Energy Crisis May Bring a Rise in Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5A rise in street crime, an expansion of organized crime, and the hampering of law enforcement operations are all distinct possibilities as a result of the nation's energy crisis, the administrator of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration said today.

title: Protest Led by Sakharov Undisturbed by Soviet Police
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5 (AP)The Soviet police showed unusual restraint tonight as Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist, led a silent demonstration of political dissidents in Moscow's Pushkin Square.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH FOOTBALL LEAGUE

title: Poujadism in Denmark
description: Denmark's election has confirmed a strong trend against the oncedominant Social Democrats in Scandinavia, but it has also turned up a disturbing tendency by voters to endorse the quack doctrines once hawked in France by Pierre Poujade. The overall result is a badly fragmented Parliament, which will make effective government exceedingly difficult and prospects for the near future as cloudy as those in Norway and Sweden.

title: Black Muslim Group in Trouble From Financial Problems and Some Crime
description: The enterprise of American Black Muslims has been pointed to as a showcase, an example of industry, competence and selfhelp that the entire black community should emulate.

title: Amish Sect in Iowa Untouched By Rising U.S. Energy Crisis
description: OELWEIN, Iowa, Dec. 5 (AP) The Amish of Iowa are summate savers of energy.

title: Dodgers Also Acquire Agee From Cards
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5  Mike Marshall, baseball's top relief pitcher of 1973, was traded by Montreal to Los Angeles today for Willie Davis, the 33yearold center fielder who is one of baseball's biggest everyday stars.

title: Albany 1974
description: The campaign for Governor has begun nearly a year before Election Day with Representative Ogden Reid's announcement that he wants the Democratic nomination. His solitary position in the field will not last long. On the contrary, the probability is strong that the 1974 gubernatorial race will be the most open in a decadewith harsh primary contests a possibility for both Democrats and Republicans.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: P.S.C. GIVES PLAN TO SAVE FUEL OIL
description: The State Public Public Service Commission announced a sweeping series of proposals yesterday to save fuel, including a statewide 5 per cent voltage reduction by electric utilities, greatly reduced lighting for outdoor displays, windows and signs and the maximum use of coal to fire generating plants.

title: Netherlands Will Increase Bank Rate to 8% From 7%
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 5, (Reuters)The Netherlands will raise its bank rate to 8 per cent from 7 per cent effective tomorrow, the Dutch Central Bank announced today.

title: YUGOSLAVIA TRIES BRITONS AS SPIES
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Dec. 5During the ArabIsraeli war in October, while Soviet military air transports were crossing Yugoslavia with weapons for Syria and Egypt, two young Britons were arrested at an air base near here with a long telescope, powerful binoculars, a shortwave radio capable of monitoring aircraft communications, a tape recorder and notebooks full of data about airfields and planes.

title: Books of The Times
description: Here are some books to give and get for Christmas this yearnovelties, catalogues, picture hooks and reference works that struck me as especially unusualwith the least expensive listed first, and so on.

title: Music: Prime Serkin
description: Most of the Tuesday night recital by Rudolf Serkin in Carnegie Hall was prime Serkin. This great pianist has never been known for infinite variety in program making, and more often than not he is content to concentrate on the things he loves bestMozart, Schubert, Beethoven. But every once in a while he surprises. It may be Chopin. It may be a Bartk concerto. Or it may be the monumental Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Bach by Max Reger, which he played at his New York debut recital in 1937.

title: A's Refuse to Relax Hold on Williams
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5  The New York Yankees lost big yardage today in baseball's celebrated case of the stolen managers when Charles O. Finley of the Oakland A's refused to relax his legal grip on Dick Williams.

title: REID TOURS STATE; SCORES GOVERNOR
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid formally opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday by charging that Governor Rockefeller was out of touch, aging and insensitive and that a likely Democratic opponent for the governorship, Howard J. Samuels, was a threetime loser.

title: Contemplated F.C.C. Rule on Networks Is Scored
description: A rule being contemplated by the Federal Communications Commission to prohibit, the television networks from producing entertainment programs or leasing their facilities to outside producers has been assailed by the National Broadcasting Company. The rule would, according to an N.B.C. statement, weaken the networks capacity to provide news and information services.

title: Giants Reinstate Evansto Taxi Squad
description: Charlie Evans, the New York Giants running back suspended last week for conduct detrimental to the club, has been reinstated by coach Alex Webster.

title: An Unknown Quantity
description: WASHINGTONThe confirmation of Gerald Ford to be Vice President will come to its unsuspenseful conclusion today as the House of Representatives overwhelmingly votes to endorse the nomination. We will be confirming a man whose honesty, integrity and decency are above reproacha welcome change from our recent history. We will be confirming a man whose political philosophy, consistently expressed over 25 years in the House, seems to be in touch with the mainstream of the electorate as expressed in the 1972 election.

title: Nixon Aide Asks Eased Exhaust Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The deputy chief of the onedayold Federal Energy Office told Congress today that a standpat attitude barring any easing of antipollution laws for automobiles was unacceptable to they White House.

title: The Best Way to Solve Any Macaroni Crisis: Flour, Eggs and Care
description: The threatening shortage of macaroni in Italy would not have fazed Marcella Hazan's grandmother. The old woman made pasta every day until her nineties, and when storebought macaroni then began to appear occasionally on the family table, Mrs. Hazan recalls, Grandma couldn't understand why they made it.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
City Drops Debt Collector Because of Tainted Record
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau has decided not to use one of three private debtcollection agencies it had already approved, on the ground that the agency had been found guilty in 1970 of improper billing practices and collection methods.

title: Rockefeller and Byrne to, er, Cooperate
description: Governor Rockefeller and Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's Governor  elect, exchanged friendly, generalized promises of cooperation here yesterday, then politely disagreed over their rival plans for sports complexes.

title: U.S. to Help Drivers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Administration, responding to spreading wildcat blockades of the nation's highways by truck drivers, promised today to take immediate action to alleviate the truckers problems and to give high priority to fuel for trucks in a national energy allocation program.

title: Who's Where in College Coaching Shifts
description: When it comes to football, some coaches quit, others take new jobs and some stay put no matter what. In the first category is Bill Fulcher, who left the head post at Georgia Tech yesterday he cause he said he didn't enjoy the job. Some sources had indicated that Fulcher was disenchanted with Tech's high scholastic requirements, which made recruiting difficult.

title: Black Police Assail Shooting of Officer
description: Groups representing black city, transit and housing policemen angrily contended yesterday that facts had been omitted or covered up in the Police Department's investigation of the wounding Sunday night of a black officer by a white detective in Queens.

title: TIMES ASKS COURT To SHIELD NOTES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The New York Times has filed a motion in United States District Court here to prevent lawyers for John D. Ehrlichman, a former aide to President Nixon, from forcing one of The Times's reporters to testify or turn over his notes about an article written last July. about an article written last July.

title: Lang's 'Testament of Dr. Mabuse,' at Cultural Center Tomorrow:The Cast
description: Although we now live with melodrama on a weekly basis, it's still immensely refreshing on film. Fritz Lang's "Testament of Dr. Mabuse," the sequel to his "Doktor Mabuse" of 1922 (which was shown at this year's New York Film Festival), yields a sensational torrent of images that almost make the early nineteen-seventies seem tame.The second "Mabuse," which can be seen at the New York Cultural Center tomorrow, was made in 1932 and had only a brief run in Germany until Goebbels banned it in 1933. (Evidently, the German original hasn't been shown in this country; only the French version has been exhibited.) Goebbels offered Lang the job of running the German film industry, and the director's response was to leave the country that day.Goebbels at first tried to steer movies toward Brown Shirt propaganda, but these did so poorly at the box office that he soon encouraged lush escapist films instead. Yet Goebbels also cherished the notion of a Nazi "Mrs. Miniver," which was attempted in Hamburg toward the end of the war. It wasn't completed, due to script trouble, actresses who failed to show up on the set because the German submarine fleet had landed, the vast British raid on Hamburg and a director who flipped his lid.In Lang's 1932 classic, Mabuse, the master criminal and hypnotist who wanted to dominate the world, is now a lunatic in an asylum. The muscle-bound sensualist of the first film appears as a ravaged wraith in the second. But he continues to direct his gang of hoods: on his written orders, they kill and steal, set fire to chemical factories and plan to destroy crops and to poison water supplies.Lang wrote in 1943 that he'd designed "an allegory to show Hitler's processes of terrorism. . . . I hoped to expose the masked Nazi theory of the necessity to deliberately destroy everything which is precious to people. . . . Then, when everything collapsed and they were thrown into utter despair, they would try to find 'help' in the new order."Mabuse dies. But he has already hypnotized his psychiatrist, who continues to carry out the dead man's schemes. It's a fine case of mind poisoning and demonic possession, which also evokes the spell that Hitler cast on the German psyche. Pursued by the bulky, ebullient Inspector Lohmann (acted by Otto Wernicke, who played the same part and trailed Peter Lorre in "M"), the psychiatrist comes to look more and more like Mabuse, and finally goes as mad as his own mentor.While this "Mabuse" lacks most of the surrealistic effects and the dazzling hallucinations that gave its predecessor such magic, it's rich in the images and the shocks at which Lang excelled. Mabuse's trained killers arrange a murder in a traffic jam: as the doomed man smiles at the rhythm of the cars' horns honking around him, and then presses his own horn to jibe with the same beat, we realize that he's unwittingly giving the signal for his own execution.Mabuse's death is first announced by a close-up of still, bare feet: hands tie a name card to the stiff ankles. (But his supernatural powers have been stressed so often that it's hard to believe he's really dead.) A curtain  which used to reflect Mabuse's shadow while his voice gave ordersis parted to reveal a dark silhouette painted on a wall and a recording machine: the ruse merely makes him seem more ubiquitous than ever.In "Mabuse," as in some of Lang's other movies, the director most brilliantly conveyed the sense of being trappedthe moment when death or lifelong consequences close in. Here, during a shootout with the police, the criminals panic and turn on one another, fighting savagely about whether to surrender or hold out. Meanwhile, a young couple locked in a basement with a ticking bomb decide to break a water pipe in hopes of diminishing the inevitable explosion; when the woman fears that they'll be drowned if they're not blown up, the man looks at her fondly and shrugs slowly.For most of Lang's characters, there was rarely an escape-hatch. The climax of the first "Mabuse" showed the Doctor frantically trying to fight his way through bolted doors. Lang seemed to specialize in people who were desperate to escape: either from places where they might be killed or from situations that they found intolerable. The Mabuse films remind us again of what Lang himself escaped fromand of our own good fortune in being able to savor the body of work that he achieved after that escape.

title: Moscow Angrily Denying Role in Arab Oil Embargo
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5  The Soviet Union, mindful of the uproar that the Arab embargo has created in the West, has reacted angrily to speculation in the West European press that the Kremlin might have its hand in the cutback of oil from the Middle East.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1973

title: Soviet Said to Use Guinea To Observe U.S. Shipping
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Soviet Union has begun flying military reconnaissance missions from the West African nation of Guinea, apparently to monitor ship movements in the South Atlantic, Pentagon officials reported today.

title: 15 Injured in Israel By Bomb on a Bus
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 5 (Reuters) A bomb exploded today on a bus traveling through the countryside north of here, wounding 15 persons, a police spokesman said.

title: Court May Have Freed Slaying Suspect, 16
description: A 16yearold youth arrested for a murder in a subway statino Monday is believed by officials to be the youngster who was sent home from a state training school last July after a landmark decision by the state's highest court.

title: WARREN S. DAVIDSON
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec, 5 Warren Strasser Davidson, member of the New York law Firm of Silberfeld, Danziger Bangser, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at Old Wagon Road.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In pounds sterling Per metric ton)

title: Opposing Protestant Factions Brawl in New Ulster Assembly
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 5 (UPI)A fistswinging brawl broke out in the newly established Northern Ireland Assembly today between rival Protestant factions, causing the Speaker to adjourn the session and call for police help.

title: Democratic Mayors to Work For a VetoProof Congress
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 5Charging President Nixon with callous disregard of the needs of the nation's cities, 26 Democratic Mayors formed today a caucus within the Democratic National Committee to work for the election of enough additional Democrats to Congress next year to override any Presidential veto.

title: U.S. SALES DOWN FUR CAR IMPORTS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 5Import sales of automobiles in the United States in November totaled 134,000 cars, off 2 per cent from 136,600 last November. The imports' share was 14.7 per cent of total sales versus, 13.2 per cent a year ago. Combined domesticimport sales in November were 911,455, down 11.3 per cent from 1,027,395 a year ago.

title: Transit Police Retain Maye
description: John T. Maye was elected yesterday to his sixth consecutive oneyear term as president of the New York City Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Mr. May received 862 votes out of a total of 2,150 that were cast in a mail poll supervised by the Honest Ballot Association. His nearest opponent was James McKechnie, who received 569 votes.

title: BOY, 10, COMMITTED FOR FIRE AT CHURCH
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 5 (AP)A 10yearold boy has been committed to a children's institution for 18 months. A court ruled he helped start a fire that destroyed a church.

title: Lebanon Jails Editor for Publishing Summit Secrets
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 5The editor and publisher of Lebanon's leading newspaper was imprisoned today for having published the secret resolutions of the recent conference of Arab chiefs of state.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Player representatives yesterday authorized the National Hockey League Players Association to reject an option clause proposed by N.H.L. owners for future contracts. R. Alan Eagleson, the Toronto lawyer who isexecutive director of the association, said the owners were trying unilaterally to achieve something that had been turned down in joint negotiations. The option clause would replace the traditional reserve clause, which the N.H.L. owners have been enjoined from using.

title: SHOP TALK
description: When it comes to buying clothing for her shop Britten Olsson has one ruleofthumb: It must be wearable, she insists.

title: Rangers Beat Blues, 51, And Take Second Place
description: The New York Rangers, enjoying a relaxed evening, gave a hockey lesson to the St. Louis Blues last night at Madison Square Garden, beating them, 51. With the victory the Rangers passed Montreal and moved into second place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Wharton School Forecasts 0.6% Increase in Economy
description: Real growth in the economy next year will be limited to sixtenths of 1 per cent, the University of Pennsylvania predicted yesterday. Gross National Product without the inflationary factor, it was said, will come to a total of $841,6billion for the year. The inflation rate will be 7.20 per cent higher than it is this year.

title: Mayor Wins Recall Vote
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. Dec. 5 (UPI)in this Detroit enclave gave Mayor Robert B. Blackwell a vote of confidence yesterday when they chose by a 3 to 2 margin not to recall him. The vote was 3,167 against recall to 2,172 for.

title: Ohio Protest Goes On
description: Blockades by truck drivers protesting higher fuel prices and lower speed limits ended in Pennsylvania late last night but continued in Ohio despite six arrests and the forcible removal of 300 vehicles.

title: NEW CURBS ON PRESS IMPOSED BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 5 (UPI) Israel today announced new and tougher restrictions on news coverage of military activities. The measures require advance permission for interviews with senior officers, several of whom have been critical of the nation's war strategy.

title: Can a Child With $8 Find Joy in a Store? 800 Gave It a Try
description: Gina Monasco bought a huge, orange, plush fish at Macy's yesterday. It's for my mother, the 10yearold explained. She's going to like it, solemnly agreed Margaret Quinones, who attends P.S. 122 in Brooklyn with Gina.

title: TRUCK GAS SAVING AT 50 M.P.N. FOUND
description: Computer studies by the General Motors Corporation show that large trucks can save about 15 per cent in fuel by driving 50 to 55 miles an hour instead of 70, primarily because of reduced air resistance.

title: HOSPITAL GROUPS SCORE PRICE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Protestant and Roman Catholic hospital groups, representing a large share of the nation's hospitals, have joined in threatening legal action to force changes in proposed Federal price control regulations.

title: High School Sports
description: After a summer of playing basketball against some of the toughest and meanest competition around, Charlie Barker has become a star. Barker, a junior forward, studied at Playground U. and now is refining his numerous skills under Coach Julie Levine at Samuel Gompers High School.

title: MARCOS MEETS MOSLEM REBELS
description: MANILA, Dec. 5President Ferdinand E. Marcos met today with Moslem rebel leaders as part of his martiallaw Government's continuing efforts to make peace with insurgents, but increasing difficulties were reported with youths and militant Roman Catholic clergymen.

title: Haig Says Gap in Tape Disturbed Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 President Nixon was very, very disturbed and almost incredulous when he finally learned of the full extent and import of the 18minute gap on a crucial White House tape recording, his chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., testified today.

title: Stern Named to U.S. Court After Delay Over MixUp
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern, who won a national reputation for his successful prosecution of official corruption on the state and local level, was nominated today by President Nixon to the United States District Court.

title: PHYSICIANS OPPOSE MONITORING PLAN
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 5Bowing to the demands of angry doctors, the American Medical Association voted today to oppose a federally mandated system that will monitor the competence of physicians services to 50million people.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Early one spring many years ago a big league ballplayer with a permanent residence in California set out for training camp. In his station wagon were his wife, his kids and his gear as he began his transcontinental drive to the Yankee base in St. Petersburg, Fla. No sooner had he arrived in St. Pete, though, than he discovered that he had just been traded to a team training on the Pacific Coast. So he merely made a Uturn on Central Avenue and headed back to join his new ball club.

title: U.N. DEFERS ISSUE OF CAMBODIA SEAT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5  The United States succeeded tonight in its effort, to stave off until next year a Chineseled drive to expel from the United Nations the present Government of Cambodia and seat instead the exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Comings and Goings
description: On Feb. 20, 1969, one month after his inauguration, President Nixon announced that he was personally assuming full responsibility for oil import policies. From that day to this he has followed a bewildering series of bureaucratic reshuffles and reorganizations. The substance of the energy problem was forever getting lost amid the managerial confusion; about the only consistent factors in the Administration's record of energy policy have been indecision and procrastination.

title: Scotch on the Rocks
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Dec. 5 (AP)Bad news for Scotch whisky drinkers: the heatingoil shortage has forced Scottish distillers to cut production. The Scotch Whisky Association said today that the situation was severe. Oil is vital in many stages of production. Scotch whisky is Britain's biggest dollar earner.

title: JUSTIN GALATOIRE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. (AP)  Justin Laurent Galatoire, owner of the famous New Orleans French restaurant that bears his family name, died yesterday. He was 87 years old.

title: SPECTER MAY DIRECT NIXON LAWYER TEAM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5District Attorney Arlen Specter of Philadelphia has discussed joining President Nixon's team of lawyers in the Watergate case, the White House said today.

title: Actors Studio Thrives at 25... or 26
description: This evening the Actors Studio officially becomes a venerable institution. It celebrates its 25th anniversary with simultaneous benefit balls in New York and Los Angeles. Actually, the Studio is not 25 years old, but 26 years old. Asked about the discrepancy, Lee Strasberg, the Studio's artistic director, said philosophically, That's how poorly organized we are.

title: Skylab Crew Focuses on Comet That Will Loop the Sun Dec. 28
description: HOUSTON. Dec. 5 (AP)The Skylab 3 astronauts aimed powerful cameras today at Kohoutek, a comet from deep Space that is expected to loop around the sun during the Christmas holidays.

title: Glamour Group Is Off GoldMining Issues Strong
description: Stock prices kept tumbling yesterday as uncertainties aroused by the energy crisis spread fears of recessgiyonplusinflation for 1974.

title: MOVING OF BARUCH ARGUED IN COUNCIL
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of the City University, and other university officials told a skeptical City Council committee yesterday that they favored moving Bernard B. Baruch College to lower Manhattan instead of downtown Brooklyn for two reasons time and money.

title: PHYSICIANS OPPOSE MONITORING PLAN
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 5Bowing to the demands of angry doctors, the American Medical Association voted toiday to oppose a federally mandated system that will monitor the competence of physicians' services to 50million people.

title: Amex and OTC Downturn Continues
description: Prices continued their downward trend on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading yesterday as volume rose.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE ALLOWED TO RISE 2C BY U.S. PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Government decided today to let refiners increase the price of heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, an increase that will be passed on to consumers in January and add about 7 per cent to the average homeheating bill.

title: Penn Beats Manhattan By 91 to 79
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec (UPI)John Engels scored 26 points and grabbed 14 rebounds tonight to pace Pennsylvania to a 9179 victory over Manhattan at the Palestra. In the opener of the twin bill, St. Joseph's College downed Rider, 6546.

title: Finland Promotes Head Of U.N. Mideast Force
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  President Urho K. Kekkonen has romoted Maj. Gen. Ensio Siilasvuo, commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force in the Middle East, to lieutenant general, it was officially announced today.

title: CATTLE FUTURES RISE, THEE SLUMP
description: Snowstorms and icy roads in the Far West curtailed delivery of live cattle at major terminals, with a result that cash and futures prices for the near months rose early yesterday. Later, futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, partly because of the large number of cattle en route and partly because of the decline in the stock market.

title: Stern Measures Set
description: The Governors of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware ordered tough measures yesterday to deal with truck drivers who were blocking traffic to protest fuel costs and low speed limits.

title: Union Carbide Expanding
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced plans yesterday for the construction of a multimilliondollar plant in Alsip, Ill., to make Prestone antifreeze and coolant.

title: Reviving Central Park
description: The city has announced the first step in the desperately needed rehabilitation plan for Central Park, for which initial contracts are to be acted on by the Board of Estimate this week. At the same time, the board will consider the controversial Bloomingdale gift for redesign of the Mall, which, it is hoped and even expected, will quietly get laid over.

title: Thousands Line Up for City Exams
description: Thousands of persons stood in the rain for hours yesterday to apply for examinations for city jobs in the Sanitation and Police Departments.

title: BEANIE ASKS 265 OF MAYOR'S AIDES TO RESIGN POSTS
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame called yesterday for the resignation of 265 highranking officials in the Lindsay administration.

title: 5 Killed in Chicago Blaze
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI)Five persons, including a pregnant woman and three of her children, were killed early today when fire destroyed a basement apartment on Chicago's Northwest Side. A spokesman at St. Mary's Hospital, where the five were pronounced dead on arrival, identified the victims as Flourine Spenser, about 23 years old; her brother, Ronnie, 13, and her three children, Theresa, 6, Shirrell, 3, and Maurice, 1.

title: Energy Crisis May Doom Era of Glass Towers
description: In recent years the sealed glass box has become as much or an architectural symbol of New York as the Empire State Building. The economy and practicality of the simple shaft design has so attracted architects and developers that they have changed the face of Manhattan with it.

title: ABUSES ARE FOUND AT STATE HOSPITAL
description: A State Controller's audit of the Sheltered Workshop at the Central Islip State Hospital charged yesterday that the program had engaged in massive underpayments of patients, improper withholding of wages, illegal employment of minors and violations of the Code of Etics for state employes.

title: Britain Cuts Speed to 50 and Dims Street Lights
description: LONDON, Dec. 5Britain imposed a compulsory national speed limit of 50 miles an hour on all highways today as part of a stringent new program designed to cope with her deepening energy crisis.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Rise in Discontent
description: Fewer Americans are satisfied with their standard of living today than 10 years ago, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: TV: Sifting Big Business
description: C.B.S. Reports takes an hourlong look at The Corporation on the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight at 10. Jay McMullen, the producer  writer  reporter, attempts to explore the corporate mind primarily from the perspective of the executive suite.

title: ExRep. Richard P. Gale Of Minnesota Dies at 73
description: Minneapolis, Dec. 5 (AP)  Former United States Representative Richard Pillsbury Gale died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Byrne Accepts Hudson Plan on Leaders
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5Hudson County Democrats have apparently reestablished their traditional dominance over New Jersey Democratic politics by getting Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne to agree to a political arrangement on the leadership of the overwhelming Democratic majorities in the new Legislature.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Plans Appeal In Memphis School Case
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 5 (UPI)Attorneys for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that they would appeal a Federal appeals court ruling yesterday that refused to grant expanded school desegregation and busing in Memphis.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Advertising: Good N.C.K. News
description: It was enough to make a public agency long to be private once again.

title: Egypt Is Undecided on Resuming Talks
description: CAIRO, Dec. 5The Egyptian Government has informed the United Nations that it has not yet reached a decision on resuming the military talks with Israel that were suspended at its request a week ago.

title: Rutgers Report Scores Campus Policy on Blacks
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 5A report by a Rutgers College faculty committee today criticized campus policies affecting black students and urged sweeping reevaluation and change of admissions, counseling and financial aid policies.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LA LA LA Ron Eliran, the Israeli singer, once described those lilting syllables as an area code and the area to hear both them and Mr. Eliran is at El Avram, one flight down at 80 Grove Street, near Seventh Avenue and Fourth Street (2439661, 2430602). The dcor is moorish, unchanged since El Chico moved out and El Avram, with its stress on Israeli, Greek and Mediterranean, moved in six years ago under the energetic aegis of Avram Grobard, its boss and most tireless and constant performer.

title: NIXON SUPPORTED ON PAPERS VALUE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Ralph Newman, the Chicago rare books expert who appraised President Nixon's VicePresidential papers at $570,000, said today that he valued them conservatively because he knew Mr. Nixon planned to give them to the Government.

title: What Better Forum?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The witness swore to tell the whole truth, and counsel began his examination:

title: Local Builder Buys $800,000 Picasso, A Record, by Phone
description: LONDON, Dec. 5A Picasso painting, Femme Assise, was sold at Sotheby's auction here today for 340,000 (about $800,000)a record price for a Picasso.

title: Trucker Tantrum
description: We're classified as the lowest form of life, an irate truck driver from Iowa complained the other day.

title: House Votes 386 to 23 to Give Congress Stronger Budget Role
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) The House passed a bill today intended to strengthen the hand of Congress in contests with the White House over spending. The vote was 386 to 23.

title: BERNARD S. BERCOVICI
description: Bernard S. Bercovici, a, former political commentator for the Mutual Broadcasting System and more recently editorial director of WNBFTV in Binghamton, N. Y., died Friday at his home near Harpursville, N. Y. He was 78 years old.

title: Cambodian Capital Feidfraid by Boat in Early Morning
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambo?? Dec. 5  A band of abou?? insurgent commandos ?? into the capital early this ?? ing and staged the first ?? Government attack ins?? Phnom Penh in more than ?? year.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Miami BeachElisha Obed, 153 pounds, Miami Beach, knocked out Mike Lankester, 155, Seattle, 8 rounds.

title: SWEDEN NOT NAMING NEW ENVOY TO CHILE
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Sweden announced tonight that she would not replace her Ambassador to Santiago, Harald Edelstam, who was ordered to leave by the Chilean Government yesterday.

title: Times Names Family/Style Editor
description: The appointment of Mrs. Joan Whitman as Family/ Style editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor.

title: 5 Federal Aides Get Rockefeller Service Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Rockefeller Public Service Awards, the highest civilian distinctions awarded to Federal Government employes, were presented here today to five career officials.

title: French Ban Auto Racing Temporarily
description: France has barred all auto racing until further notice and there were indications yesterday that other European governments would follow.

title: U.S. and Rumania Pledge Firmer Links
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5President Nixon and President Nicolae Ceausescu signed a joint statement in the White House today pledging the con tinued development of friendly relations between the two countries.

title: 33 Food Outlets Are Cited for Violating City's Health Code
C.A.B. Seeks a Role In Flight Schedules
description: Robert D. Timm, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said yesterday that his agency must take from airline management many of its prerogatives for scheduling flights if adequate service is to he maintained in the face of massive projected cutbacks due to fuel shortages.

title: Saudi Minister, in Capital, Is Optimistic About Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani the Saudi Arabian Petroleur Minister, met with Secretary of State Kissinger for 9 minutes today and said late that peace in the Middle East was now more feasible that at any time in the past.

title: High School Principal Here Pleads Guilty to Extortion
description: A Bronx highschool principal pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he attempted to extort money from an assistant principal on the ground that he could save his job for him.

title: Governor to Testify On Contract Given To Perot Company
description: Governor Rockefeller will give sworn testimony on Tuesday in an investigation by George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, of circumstances surrounding a controversial computer contract awarded to H. Ross Perot, the Texas millionaire.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE ALLOWED TO RISE 2C BY U.S. PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Government decided today to let refiners increase the price of heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, an increase that will be passed on to consumers in January and add about 7 per cent to the average homeheating bill.

title: Soul Mate Wins Interborough Marked By Disqualification, Dead Heat for 4th
description: The running of the $28,450 Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday seemingly went off without mishap, with Soul Mate carrying the silks of Robert Dodderidge to a clear success in the sixfurlong test for fillies and mares. She preceded Elmendorf's Protest by a length, with Java Moon next in the 52d presentation of the event. This sequence was quite satisfactory to the favorite players in the crowd of 14,762 for they had made the 4yearold Virginiabred daughter of Red God the strong favorite in the field of seven. Those who backed Soul Mate were on the way to the cashiers' windows to collect when this announcement came over the public address system: There is a stewards' inquiry involving the stretch run.

title: Personal Finance
description: Not now, maybe later. Can't afford it. Don't want it. Don't need it. Call me some time. See me next week. I'll think about it.

title: Court May Have Freed Slaying Suspect
description: A 16yearold youth arrested for a murder in a subway station Monday was believed by officials yesterday to be the youngster who was sent home from a state training school last July after a landmark decision by the state's highest court.

title: Mrs. Meir's Party Adopts a New Basis for Arab Talks
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 5  The leadership of the governing Labor party formally adopted a revised election platform tonight that authorizes the Israeli Government to enter peace negotiations with the Arabs in Geneva later this month.

title: Pioneer 10's Manager Charles Frederick Hall
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 5Charles Frederick Hall, the man in charge of building and operating the Pioneer 10 spacecraft, paused the other day to do some historical arithmetic. He figured that we are really only 12 generations away from Galileo and his crude first look at Jupiter in 1610, Twelve generations later, Mr. Hall reflected with a sense of wonder and pride, we are actually there.

title: BUSINESS OUTLAYS TO RISE NEXT YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The first Government survey of business plans to invest in plant and equipment next year generally confirmed today earlier private estimates of strong capital investment in 1974.

title: RULES PROPOSED ON SAYINGS UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank, Board yesterday proposed complex new regulations designed to permit mutual savings and loan associations to convert to stockholderowned companies.

title: CANADIAN JAVELIN CONTESTS CHARGES
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Canadian Javelin, Ltd., has contested charges by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in hearings before the British Columbia Securities Commission and Vancouver Stock Exchange officials.

title: Newcombe Sets Back Gorman
description: BOSTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)John Newcombe of Australia, jealously guarding his position as the world's No. 1 player, defeated Tom Gorman for the second time in four days today to remain the only player with a 100 per cent record in Masters tennis play.

title: Haig Says Gap in Tape Disturbed Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 President Nixon was very, very disturbed and almost incredulous when he finally learned of the full extent and import of the 18minute gap on a crucial White House tape recording, his chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., testified today.

title: Saigon Reinforcing Encircled Provincial Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 6The South Vietnamese Government flew reinforcements yesterday into the encircled capital town of Quang Duc Province, where some of the fiercest fighting since the ??ary ceasefire has occurred.

title: New Outbursts Mark Chesimard Trial
description: For the second day in a row, Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton were escorted out of a Federal courtroom several times yesterday after they repeatedly shouted complaints and epithets at the judge presiding at their trial on bank robbery charges.

title: Transportation Agency Upholds Ford in Recall Dispute on Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Department of Transportation, concluding a threeyear investigation, supported today the Ford Motor Company's refusal to recall more than four million passenger cars for correction of a suspected safety defect.

title: Wright Quits Ocean Hill Board; Aide Named to Fill School Post
description: City Councilmanelect Samuel D. Wright announced yesterday that he had resigned from the community school board of the Ocean HillBrownsville district in Brooklyn, and the board moved quickly to select his personal secretary to serve out the remaining 19 months of his term.

title: A DANCE CONCERT BY ELINA LOONEY
description: It is typical of Elina Mooney's intelligence and sensitivity toward spatial relationships that, in a concert at Theater at St. Clement's on Tuesday, she used a stage already quite specifically prepared for a resident play and made it her own. Dancers in white nuzzled into white niches, pulled themselves up ramps and hopped between different levels. The stage constructions seemed to echo the planes of stretched bodies.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: For Cause, Not Cost
description: LONDONThe hottest theater ticket in London these days is to Saturday, Sunday, Monday, the Old Vic production starring an aging Sir Laurence Olivier, about a family that nearly comes apart because its members took each other's love for granted.

title: Soviet Said to Use Guinea To Observe U.S. Shipping
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Soviet Union has begun flying military reconnaissance missions from the West African nation of Guinea, apparently to monitor ship movements in the South Atlantic, Pentagon officials reported today.

title: A Peking Parley That Isn't, Chou's Modesty and Sundry Errors
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 3More than three months ago, Premier Chou Enlai announced that China's top legislative body, the National People's Congress, was about to hold its first session in nine years. The English translation of the Premier's statement said merely that the congress would open soon, but the Chinesemost near, to be literal made it sound more imminent.

title: ESCANDON PIANISM SHOWS ASSURANCE
description: Teresa Escandn, a Cubanborn pianist now on the Hartt College of Music faculty in Hartford, has studied with some of the best teachers in the countryIsabelle Vengerova, Edward Steuermann, Ward Davennyand it shows, Her recital on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall had the technical polish and assured musicianship that such credentials would indicate.

title: Jimmy Cannon, Columnist, Dies; Sportswriter Ranged Far Afield
description: Jimmy Cannon, the syndicated sports columnist, died yesterday in his home, 440 East 56th Street. He was 63 years old.

title: Celtics Halt Knicks 3d Time, 11997
description: BOSTON, Dec. 5The Boston Celtics merrily chopped the New York Knicks to pieces tonight and then proclaimed  as only superconfident winners can  that their 11997 victory didn't mean a thing. The runaway triumph before a capacity crowd of 15,320 at Boston Garden was Boston's third straight over the Knicks this season and kicked the Celtics' lead in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division to 6 games New York.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey who won a national reputation for his successful prosecution of corruptiod on the state and local level, was nominated yesterday by President Nixon to a Federal judgeship. Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, who submitted Mr. Stern's name to the White House, has recommended Jonathan Goldstein, first assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey to succeed Mr. Stern, according to Washington sources.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Christmas is a major selling season for bicyclesalthough the bicycle business has been booming all year longand this year there is some added information for shoppers.

title: The Screen: Serpico, Disquieting Drama of Police Corruption
description: Early in 1970, two New York City police officers, Detective Frank Serpico and Sgt. David Durk, put their careers and their lives on the line. After getting the runaround for months from their superiors, who preferred not to listen, they called on David Burnham, a reporter for The New York Times, to tell him their story of graft and corruption within the Police Department.

title: BISHOP WALTER GRAY OF CONNECTICUT DIES
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 5 (AP)The Right Rev. Walter H. Gray, Bishop Emeritus of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, died yesterday at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: Musical Troupe in Crash
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 5 (UPI)A bus carrying the musical troupe Jr. Walker and the All Stars overturned about 50 miles southwest of here on interstate 69 yesterday, injuring all those aboard, including the bus driver. No one was critically injured.

title: BENEFITS INCREASE FACES HOUSE DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)The Senate has added so many amendments to a bill increasing Social Security benefits that it would serve no purpose to seek a HouseSenate compromise, the acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today.

title: Pittsburgh Transit Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 (UPI)More than 300,000 commuters drove, hitchhiked, pedaled or walked to work for the third day today as striking bus and trolley workers refused to obey Common Pleas Court Judge Richard T. Wentley's backtowork order until they receive a new contract.

title: Parts of Park to Close
description: BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, Tex., Dec. 5 (UPI)Joe Carithers, superintendent of Big Bend National Park, said today that parts of the Southwest Texas park would be closed to the public beginning next week because of the energy crisis. He said that certain wilderness roads would be closed because we simply do not have enough gasoline to adequately patrol and maintain these roads.

title: JAVITS SEES A NEED TO DECIDE ON NIXON
description: WSHINGTON, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that the impending confirmation of Gerald R. Ford as Vice President brought nearer the possibility that Republican politicians might ask President Nixon to resign.

title: Lizanne Seabrook Married in London
description: Miss Lizanne Seabrook, daughter of John M. Seabrook of Salem. N. J., and Mrs. Anne S. Seabrook of New York, was maried in London y sterday to Jonathan Grant Leatham of London. The ceremony was performed in St. Michael's Anglican Church, Chester Square, by the Rev. E. G. H. Saunders.

title: Swiss Parliament Spurns Tradition In Vote for Cabinet
description: GENEVA, Dec. 5  The two houses of Parliament, which elect the seven ministers who make up the Swiss Federal Government, filled three vacancies today in an untraditional manner. They rejected the three candidates proposed by the coalition parties.

title: P.S.C. GIVES PLAN TO SAVE FUEL OIL
description: The State Public Public Service Commission announced a sweeping series of proposals yesterday to save fuel, including a statewide 5 per cent voltage reduction by electric utilities, greatly reduced lighting for outdoor displays, windows and signs and the maximum use of coal to fire generating plants.

title: MGM Opens 2,100Room Las Vegas Hotel
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 5MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., entered the hotel business here tonight with all the hoopla that attended the premieres of its movies in the nineteenthirties.

title: SEARCH ACQUITS A WOMAN PICKET
description: MIDDLETOWN, Dec. 5A Monmouth County judge, overruling the conviction of a woman who was arrested while picketing a store here, has questioned the practice by the Middletown police of stripping and searching woman prisoners.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: CASHMERE LOVE, a new play by F. V. Hunt. Directed by Shan Covey. Tonight through Dec. 30 at 7:30 at the Fortune Theater, 62 East Fourth Street (5416250).

title: Stern's Chief Aide Among 8 to Receive U.S. Commendation
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6Jonathan J. Goldstein, who reportedly has been recommended to succeed United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern here, will be honored by the Department of Justice next week for distinguished service.

title: McGovern Says President Fails to Restore Confidence
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 6 (AP) President Nixon's attempt to restore lost confidence in his Administration has plainly failed, Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said tonight.

title: Polish City, Once German, Retains Only Trace of Vibrant Jewish Life
description: WROCLAW, Poland, Dec. 3 A handful of bedraggled old men and women, two of, them obviously deranged, eat their daily hot meal in a bare communal dining room. The feeble light of early afternoon, reflecting off the dirty snow in the rear courtyard into the misty groundfloor windows, barely reaches them.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Hialeah Race Course, Inc. pleaded guilty yesterday to covering up a $1,000 contribution to the 1969 campaign of Governor Cahill. United States District Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple, who had rejected an earlier defense request to plead nolo contendere, fined the Florida track $2,500.

title: Former Pakistani Officials Being Freed by Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 6 (Reuters)Dr. A. M. Malik, the last governor of the former province of East Pakistan, which is now Bangladesh, has been released from prison here along with four of his former cabinet colleagues.

title: NixonDean Tape Will Go To Mitchell Trial Judge
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed last night that the White House had agreed to provide the tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and Jahn W. Dean 3d for the trial of two former Cabinet officers.

title: Concert
description: Human ingenuity in making virtues out of necessities is boundless. Lately we have been having a glorification of monotony, as a visitor to Wednesday's Evenings for New Music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall can testify.

title: Haig Says White House Feared Sinister Force Ruined Tape but Now Feels Miss Woods Is to Blame
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Gen, Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's chief of staff testified today that White House aides had suspected briefly that some sinister force had purposely caused the 18minute gap on one of the subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings.

title: CITY SCHOOL AREA SUES U.S FOR AID
description: The City Board of Education and Community School District 19 in Brooklyn have sued the Federal Government in an effort to obtain nearly $1million in grants that have been withheld from the local district.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
AIRCO FILES SUIT IN CURTISS OFFER
description: Airco, Inc., a leading producer of industrial gases and ferroalloys, announced yesterday it had filed a suit in Federal Court in Newark seeking; to enjoin the offer made Monday by the CurtissWright Corporation to purchase 2.4million shares or about 20 per cent of Airco's outstanding common stock at $18 a share. The offer would amount to $43.2million. The suit describes the CurtissWright tender offer as a fraudulent, deceptive and manipulative act. The suit seeks to enjoin CurtissWright permanently from soliciting or accepting the tender of any Airco common shares. The suit says that CurtissWright's ac quisition of Airco shares may constitute working control of Airco and that in such case) CurtissWright intends to exercise such control through; representation on Airco's board of directors.

title: 9 Chileans Flown Here to Face Trial As Smugglers of Cocaine by the Ton
description: Nine Chilean citizens who were extradited and flown to the United States fared Federal charges here yesterday that they had smuggled large quantities of cocaine into the New York metropolitan area.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: For the first time in six sessions, prices rallied and finished higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. They also rose in the overthecounter market.

title: Will The Arabs Go Too Far?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6In his latest news conference, Secretary of State Kissinger appealed to the Arab states to lift their oil embargo and give the Middle East peace talks a chance to. succeed.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)  November sales and redemptions of Government Savings Bonds both declined from October levels, the Treasury Department said today. Sales of E and H bonds totaled $467million last month, compared with $482million in October and $454million November, 1972.

title: Hill School, Hurt by a Fire, Seeks to Notify Applicants
description: The Hill School, a private boarding school for boys in Pottstown, Pa., is trying to reach the parents of prospective students following a fire last Friday in the main administration building that destroyed the school's correspondence with applicants.

title: Measure on Gas Imports Is Approved by House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) In an attempt to increase supplies of natural gas, the House Commerce Committee aproved today legislation which would allow the importation of liquified natural gas without controls of the Federal Power Commission.

title: Excursion Fares Raised For Flights to London
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP)The International Air Transport Association has raised its proposed excursion fares for flights between London and New York to meet objections from the Civil Aeronautics Board, a spokesman said today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Protecting Wetlands
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation have been admirably prompt In putting the new Tidal Wetlands Act to the test. Ten weeks after that law's effective date, the Attorney General took criminal action against a Long Island realty syndicate for allegedly filling in a wetland at Shelter Island without a special hardship permit.

title: Issues Plummet on Report of a Huge Payments Deficit
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  Britain reported her biggest quarterly trade deficit in history today and the stock market absorbed one of its worst declines on record.

title: Clancy Heads RCA Records
description: Kenneth D. Glancy, formerly managing director of RCA Records, United Kingdom, has been named president and chief executive officer of RCA Records here, it was announced yesterday by Howard R. Hawkins, executive vicepresident of the RCA Corporation. Mr. Glancy suceeds Rocco M. Leginestra, who will continue in an executive capacity within the RCA corporate staff. Mr. Glancy began his career in the record industry 20 years ago as midWestern district manager for Columbia Records.

title: Texasgulf to Accept 4 C.D.C. Directors
description: Texasgulf, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it had resolved its differences with the Canada, Development Corporation, an investment company owned by the Canadian Government, and that it would agree to the appointment of four C.D.C. board members to the Texasgulf board of directors.

title: Notre Dame Wins, 9874; Shumate: 30
description: EVANSTON, III., Dec. 6 (UPI)Notre Dame forged a 9point lead late in the first half and went on to an easy victory over Northwestern of the Big Ten Conference tonight, 9874, in college basketball.

title: NEW DATA HINTED ON GIFT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has told associates that he has prepared a detailed analysis that raises significant doubt about whether President Nixon was entitled to the halfmilliondollar tax deduction he claimed for the gift of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives.

title: Air Travel Here Disrupted As 3 Lines Are Picketed
description: Thousands of air travelers were delayed here yesterday as employes of Trans World Airlines, on strike for a month, set up picket lines at the terminals of American Airlines and Pan American World Airways.

title: CON ED POTENTIAL CUT 10% BY A FIRE
description: Ten per cent of the Consolidated Edison Company's electrical generating capacity here was knocked out yesterday by a smoky oil fire that scorched the utility's millionkilowatt Big Allis turbine at the plant in Ravenswood, Queens.

title: Con Ed Announces Dramatic Cut Here In the Use of Power
description: Consolidated Edison yesterday reported a dramatic decrease in the electricity, natural gas and steam used by its customers during November, and a company executive hailed it as strong indication that customers in New York and Westchester County are cooperating in conserving energy.

title: 4 CITY JAIL AIDES INDICTED HERE
description: Four employes of the City Correction Department have been indicted on charges of selling heroin, cocaine and marijuana, it was announced yesterday by the office of the state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: The Republican Spirit
description: HUNTINGTON, N. Y.I have always feared for the party of Abraham Lincoln. I had always imagined that Republicans would someday run out of people to make deals with, and be left with the goods.

title: Nixon Signs Bill Raising Veterans' Pension Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UN) President Nixon signed a bill today giving a 10 per cent costofliving increase in monthly pensions to about 2.4 million military veterans and their survivors, effective Jan. 1.

title: No Dec. 24 Action Taken
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange took no action at its regular monthly meeting yesterday on closing the exchange on Monday, Dec. 24, a spokesman said last night. Because the market is closed on Christmas Day, such a closing would have meant a fourday weekend for employes of the Big Board and its member firms for the first time in history.

title: Ulster Talks Open With Partial Accord
description: LONDON, Dec. 5  Prime Minister Heath met today with the Prime Minister of the independent Irish Republic and the members of the new executive body for British  controlled Northern Ireland. They immediately agreed in principle on the basic structure for a Council of Ireland.

title: Osmond Fraenkel, Patron of Liberties, to Be Honored
description: Osmond K. Fraenkel, who is being honored tonight on his 85th birthday, is a man deeply committed to his pleasures.

title: Ohrbach's Will Close Store in Newark; Cites Drop in Sales and Lack of Lease
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6  Ohrbach's, for 43 years a landmark for city shoppers in search of a bargain and one of the few department stores left in downtown Newark, announced today that it would discontinue operations here Jan. 31, 1974.

title: Advertising: Agency Selection
description: There comes a time in almost every agencyclient relationship when one or the other (usually one) thinks it's time for a change. The industry, however, is devoid of marriage counselors.

title: Ford Expected by Some to Get More Responsibilities Than His Predecessors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Vice President Ford is expected by some members of the Nixon Administration to assume more responsibilities than any of his recent predecessors.

title: Sale Contingent On Conditions of Transfer
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 6The move of the San Diego Padres to Washington, first announced last May, was approved unanimously by the National League todaywith conditions.

title: Antibiotic Skin Ointment Called A Potential Hazard for Infants
description: A leading medical publication has warned about the potential hazards of allergy and deafness among Infants whose skin is smeared with an antibiotic ointment for diaper rash.

title: NATHAN I. CORBIN
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 6  Nathan I. Corbin, founder and board chairman of Corbin, Ltd., which he started in Brooklyn in 1920 as a pantsmanufacturing shop, died Monday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Music: The Tovey Way
description: If you are at all serious about music, you know the lively and acute essays of Sir Donald Francis Tovey, the British critic, pianist, conductor and composer who died in 1940. Yes, composer. Tovey wrote all sorts of works, including a massive opera, The Bride of Dionysus, which he began in 1907 and completed nine years later.

title: TAX OFFICE CHIEF ACCUSED OF THEFT
description: The director of the Brooklyn office of the State Department of Taxation and Finance was indicted yesterday on charges of official misconduct in a continuing investigation that has already implicated 10 of the 15 senior officials in the office.

title: Nuclear Project Blocked By Coast Ecological Unit
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6A $1.3billion atomic power project has been blocked by the California Coastal Zone Conservation Commission on the ground that it would deface some scenic cliffs, obstruct public access to a beach and damage marine life.

title: Level of South Vietnam Fighting Is Fiercest Since Truce Accord
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6In the last month, the fighting in South Vietnam has reached its fiercest levels since the January signing of the agreement for an ostensible ceasefire, which has since been shattered.

title: Ex.U.S. Aide Reportedly Served Simultaneously in a Vesco Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)  A former official of the Small Business Administration served simultaneously as director of a foreign bank controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive New Jersey financier, sources at the Securities and Exchange Commission confirmed yesterday.

title: DRAIN REPORTED IN JOBLESS FUND
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  New Jersey's unemployment insurance fund is slowly being drained by a computerconnected breakdown in an accounting system that is reported to have failed to keep track of $130million in benefit checks paid out since 1970.

title: Death Penalty Bill Opposed
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)Twenty leaders of church and civic groups met quietly today with Gov. Francis W. Sargent to urge him not to sign a death penalty bill that awaits his decision by Monday.

title: City Orders All Restaurants to Use Exterminators
description: Starting Monday, all restaurants here will have to licensed exterminators on regular basis, the Board of Health announced yesterday.

title: Mrs. Everett Bows Gracefully
description: Mrs. Marjorie Lindheimer Everett, leader of the group that tried to keep the Padres in San Diego, expressed disappointment yesterday over the bid's failure.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: OUT OF THE INDIES The Jamaican Restaurant, 432 Avenue of the Americas, near Ninth Street (9823260), is precisely what it announces itself to be. The entrance way is decorated with neatly reproduced pages of The Gleaner, the island's bestknown newspaper. The inside is dark but cheerful with pictures and decorations redolent of the Caribbean. Mostly, it is a restaurant, but come nightfall the Jamaican takes to music.

title: Kaunda, Unopposed, Reelected Zambian President for 3d Term
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda, the only candidate, was reelected for a third term in Zambia's first presidential and general elections since she became a oneparty state, preliminary votes showed today.

title: Coast Guard Ends Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 6 (UPI) President Nixon signed a bill today calling for full integration of women in the United States Coast Guard. The measure eliminates all discriminatory laws and also creates a single Coast Guard Reserve of both male and female members.

title: PRICES OF METALS ALLOWED TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Government announced today that it was permitting the prices of aluminum and copper to rise, although they will remain under controls, and that it was decontrolling completely the prices of about 40 other nonferrous metals, ranging from lead and zinc to gold and uranium.

title: Administration Impounds Funds For Water and Sewer Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Nixon Administration has quietly impounded $550million voted this year for development of water and sewer systems despite a directive from Congress to spend the money.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Nixon's Adviser Says Rationing Could Not Start Before March
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) President Nixon's chief energy adviser said today that if gasoline rationing was imposed as an absolute last resort, March 1 would be the earliest possible date for it to begin.

title: TV WILL BENEFIT FROM FUEL CRISIS
description: Television will undoubtedly be one of the immediate beneficiaries of the present fuel austerities. As people drive less and stay home more, it follows that many of them will spend more time before the set. But a boom in viewing could create a crisis for television.

title: The Pop Life
