description: The king of oldfashioned, traditional bluesB. B. King has just returned from his first tour of Africa with his personal and musical visions renewed.

title: PRESIDENT FILLS DIPLOMATIC POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 President Nixon announced the appointment today of three ambassadors and six high State Department officials.

title: Stock Prices Score Sixth Biggest Rise
description: The stock market bounded ahead yesterday in a dynamic recovery that saw the sixth biggest point advance ever for th? DowJones industrial average. The bluechip indicator soared 25.81 points to 814.12.

title: HANOI URGES FIGHT ON ROT IN SOCIETY
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Ten months after the signing of the Vietnam ceasefire accord, the official party newspaper, Nhan Dan, has called for action to combat the dolce vita that is gradually rotting North Vietnamese society.

title: MISS CHESIMARD ILL; TRIAL HERE DELAYED
description: The trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton on bank robbery charges was put off in Federal District Court yesterday after Miss Chesimard became ill with pleurisy.

title: Prices Turn Mixed in the Corporate Bond Market
description: Prices turned mixed yesterday in the corporate bond market in moderate trading activity. Taxexempt issues were up in price, but the Government market closed lower in quiet trading.

title: Harold Uris Gives Columbia $2 Million For 2 New Facilities
description: Columbia University has received a $2million gift from Harold Uris of the Uris Brothers Foundation, former president of the Uris Building Corporation.

title: Jacobson May Start For Giants
description: Larry Jacobson, who cut his left foot on a piece of glass last June at a swimming pool, may start at his regular defensive tackle post for the New York Giants Monday night in Los Angeles.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 2.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 198.1 from 195.9 last week.

title: M.T.A. TO PROVIDE TWO SUNDAY RIDES FOR PRICE OF ONE
description: In a dramatic experiment to lure people to public transportation on gasless Sundays, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will provide roundtrip transportation for the price of a normal oneway fare on all public transportation in New York City and on all M.T.A. commuter lines for five consecutive Sundays beginning Dec. 16.

title: Cambodia Claims Victory
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 6The Governmentcontrolled radio said tonight that the United Nations' postponement of action on the Cambodian membership issue was a defeat of the enemy.

title: Vizzini Is Indicted In Firemen's Strike
description: Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, and two other top union officials were arrested yesterday on charges stemming from the first strike by the city's 10,900 firemen exactly one month earlier.

title: Air Travelers Delayed
description: Thousands of air travelers were delayed here yesterday as employes of Trans World Airlines, on strike for month, picketed at the terminals of American Airlines and Pan American World Airways. Operations resumed last night after pickets were removed in compliance with a court order, Page 81.

title: Pro Football Is in Full Bloom on TV This Weekend
Sabres End Rangers' Streak, 84
description: BUFFALO, Dec, 6What's become of the New York Rangers' defensive style of hockey?

title: About New York An Administration's Dying Days
description: There is a stillness at City Hall and all its agencies, and the stillness is broken only by the typing of rsums, the murmur of private deals, and the sound of festivities for John Lindsay. It is the dull time, the slack time, and there is no noise from Abe Beame.

title: Walker Helps Bulls Down 76ers, 10196
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI)Chet Walker scored 27 points and Bob Love added 24 as the Chicago Bulls scored a 10398 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Bridge
description: LAS VEGAS, Ney., Dec. 6 For the first time in its 46year history, the American Contract Bridge League is holding a national championship in the gambling capital of the United States.

title: Top Stern Aide Among 8 To Get Federal Awards
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  Jonathan L. Goldstein, who reportedly has been recommended to succeed United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern here, will be honored by the Department of Justice next week for distinguished service.

title: Sergeant at McGuire Admits Espionage
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., Dec. 6 (AP)An Air Force sergeant with a 15year unblemished service record pleaded guilty today to charges that he tried to pass secret documents to a Soviet diplomat.

title: McGuire Airman Pleads Guilty to Charge of Spying
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, Dec. 6 (AP)  An Air Force sergeant with a 15year unblemished service record pleaded guilty today to charges that he tried to pass secret documents to a Soviet diplomat.

title: The Stage: Red Ryder Aims to Stay
description: People keep on asking where are the good American plays? And the curious thing is that season after season, as regular as wheat or clockwork, the good American plays keep turning up. Last night one turned up at the Eastside Playhouse. It is called When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder? but it is my guess that Red Ryder won't he leaving this theater for a long time. It is a fascinating and commanding play.

title: Planning Commitment
description: If the rites of politics occasionally include finding the best man for the job, Mayorelect Beame would be welladvised to keep John Zuccotti as chairman of the City Planning Commission. The fact that the position is considered a comparatively wellpaid political plum makes its disposition a particular temptation and danger.

title: Vice President Ford
description: The expected has duly occurred: Gerald Ford has been confirmed and sworn in as Vice President.

title: Cynthia Driano Leads Skaters
description: AMHERST, N. Y., Dec. 6Cynthia Driano, an 18yearold from Lake Placid, led the field of senior women today after the compulsory, figures event in the North Atlantic figure skating championships at Clearfield Recreation Center.

title: CHRISTOPHER J. WHITE
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 6Christopher J. White, a retired executve of Bowring & Co., steamship agents and brokers, died of a heart attack yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 81 years old and lived at 2 Highland Avenue.

title: Bomb Alarms Cause Traffic Chaos in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 6 (UPI)The Irish Republican Army set off bombs and blocked streets throughout Belfast tonight.

title: Notes on People
description: Observers of the fastchanging political scene in Greece think the new President, Lieut. Gen. Phaidon Gizikis, has, if nothing else, given a boost to paint sales by notifying all Government services that he does not wish to see his portrait displayed in offices or such private places as village cafes, as is customary.

title: Text of Ford's SwearingIn Ceremony and His Address to Congress
description: The following is a transcript of the swearingin ceremony of Vice President Ford in the House of Representatives yesterday, and a brief address by Mr. Ford, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: G.M. PLANS JUMP IN 1974 SPENDING
description: DETROIT, Dec. 6  The General Motors Corporation said today it was planning capital spending in 1974 that could exceed the corporate record of $1.3billion.

title: Gilmour Not in No. 1 Spot, but He's Doing All Right
description: William (Buddy) Gilmour has conceded that he will not overtake Herve Filion in the race for the national earnings and victories title in harness racing, but, as he said at Yonkers Raceway yesterday, I'm doing all right. There is no argument with that calm statement, for Buddy is in a highly comfortable bracket of more than $1,800,000 this year. Maybe next year I'll overtake Herv, but it won't be easy, Gilmour said. He's right in that respect, inasmuch as Filion has attained the winning rhythm, having topped the list of moneyearners for the last three seasons and being virtually certain to carry on this year. Recent tallies show that Filion has won more than 400 times this season, with Gilmour next at more than 300.

title: Waldo Salt Recalls The Day of the Locust
description: LOS ANGELESWriting the screenplay for The Day of the Locust, Nathanael West's novel of Hollywood's lower depths in the nineteenthirties, has been for Waldo Salt a trip into his own past.

title: Washington Opens Arms for Padres
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 6 After a twoyear baseball silence in Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium and a summer of uncertainty, Washington welcomed the announcement of the return of major league baseball today with open arms.

title: Sir Robert WatsonWatt Dies; Developed First Radar System
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 Sir Robert WatsonWatt, developer of the world's first practical radar system, which aided the repulsion of Germany in the Battle of Britain in 1940, died yesterday in a hospital at Inverness, Scotland. He was 81 years old and had been in poor health for some time.

title: Canadiens' Superior Play Overcomes Islanders, 4 to 2
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec.  All the Montreal Canadiens needed tonight was just a little touch of class to defeat the Islanders by 42 and maintain their strange record.

title: New Head of Black Officials
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 6 (AP)Vice Mayor Henry Marsh 3d of Richmond took the helm today of the National Black Caucus of Elected Officials in Puerto Rico, where he is attending the National League of Cities convention.

title: Okker Stays Unbeaten at Stars' Net
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6  Tom Okker, Jimmy Connors, the Nastase and John Newcombe qualified today for the semifinals in the $50,000 Commercial Union Masters tennis tournament.

title: EXTRANSIT OFFICER CHARGED IN SLAYING
description: A former 33yearold transit policeman, released from the force several months ago for what the police described as psychiatric reasons, was arrested last night and charged with homicide in the stabbing death of his 63yearold mother in their home in Rego Park, Queens.

title: The Evolution of a Midwest Republican
description: A presentday novelist would scarcely dare to create Gerald R. Ford. He is square, his wife says. He is sincere, loyal, hardworking and honest, his friends say. He is dull, unimaginative, lacking in flair, his critics say. According to one aide, he is a mixture of Tom Swift and Jack Armstrong, the allAmerican boy.

title: House Panel Votes For a Year's Delay Of Exhaust Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) In a move intended to conserve fuel, the House Commerce Committee voted tonight to defer for at least one year stricter cleanair standards for automobiles that now are set to become effective in late 1975.

title: Jupiter's Atmosphere Found an Efficient Greenhouse
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 6  After a preliminary analysis of Pioneer 10's radioed data, scientists reported today that four of Jupiter's satellites very likely have atmospheres, that Jupiter and its entire family of 12 moons are heavier than predicted and that Jupiter's opaque atmosphere is an efficient greenhouse.

title: Peace Talks a Dilemma for West Bank Palestinians
description: NABLUS, Israeli  Occupied Jordan Dec. 5The war and perhaps even more the prospect of ArabIsraeli negotiations have created a mood of restive uncertainty among the Palestinian Arabs living under Israeli military occupation.

title: Wholesale Index Up 1.8% On Soaring Prices of Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Soaring prices for oil products and other fuels were the main element in another big increase in the Government's wholesale price index in Novem ber, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Ceremonies Yield a Warmth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6In a swell of applause and warm feeling that seemed to give sense of stability to the troubled Administration of Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford became the 40th Vice President tonight.

title: Beame Promises Women And Puerto Ricans Jobs
description: MayorElect Abraham D. Beame promised groups of Puerto Ricans and women yesterday that each would be represented fairly among his appointees to important jobs.

title: Mrs. Meir Wins Vote in Party After Taking Onus for Errors
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 6 (AP) Premier Golda Meir won a 291to33 vote of confidence from the Central Committee of the governing Labor party today.

title: China, in Reported Shift, Said to Borrow Abroad
description: TOKYO, Dec. 6The Bank of China has reportedly, in a major policy shift, begun borrowing hard currency abroad to finance imports into China. The Bank of Japan, in a report from its Hong Kong office, said that the Bank of China recently borrowed $100million, probably from British banks, to finance the import of British Trident passenger aircraft.

title: FRANCIS SHACKELFORD
description: CLEVELAND, Tenn., Dec. 6  Francis Shackelford, who served as Assistant Secretary of the Army in the Truman Administration, died today after openheart surgery. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: Miss Proell Takes Opening Ski Race
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 6 (AP)  Austria's national women's ski team, led by Annemarie Proell, won the top three places today in the first major international race of the season.

title: Firestone Reports Record Earnings
Mets Lose Out in Bid to Get Astros' Star
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 6The New York Yankees, still searching for a manager, settled for a secondstring shortstop today, but the Mets struck out again while baseball's winter trading market went booming along for their rivals.

title: Bermuda Club Golf Led by Canadians
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 6A pair of Canadian teams pulled away from the field today after 54 holes of the 21st annual Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament.

title: Reid's Little Party Attended by 3,500, And Chaos Results
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6The invitation contained visions of a cozy fire, an intimate gathering and tinkling champagne glasses: Mary Louise and would like to have you join with us and a number of friends at a reception at our home....

title: Pop Music: Edith Wilson Joins Blake in Spotlight
description: Nobody ever steals a show from Eubie Blake, that 90yearold bundle of joy and vitality. But Edith Wilson, a singer who made her first records 52 years ago, came delightfully close to it Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, when Mr. Blake brought her up from the audience to join him in three songs. Miss Wilson's voice still had the authority and almost as much power as it had in the nineteentwenties as she punched her way through such period pieces as He May Be Your Man, but He Comes to See Me Sometimes.

title: India Tilts
description: India has moved closer to the Soviet Union, with which it signed a 20year friendship pact two years ago, and further from its professed position of nonalignment in world affairs, as a result of the agreements announced in New Delhi following an effusively friendly visit by Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.

title: Dumplings Made With Beef Liver
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Air Travelers Delayed
description: Thousands of air travelers were delayed here yesterday as employes of Trans World Airlines, on strike for a month, picketed at the terminals of American Airlines and Pan American World Airways. Operations resumed last night after pickets were removed in compliance with a court order. Page 81.

title: 500 Attend Brooklyn Rites For Morse, U.S. Attorney
description: Funeral services for Robert A. Morse, United States Attorney, were attended by about 500 people yesterday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn. Mr. Morse, the Federal prosecutor for the Eastern District of New York, was killed in a fall from his fifthfloor apartment at 57 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights. The death was ruled a suicide.

title: NixonDean Tape Will Go To Mitchell Trial Judge
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed last night that the White House had agreed to provide the tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d for the trial of two former Cabinet officers.

title: FORD SWORN AS VICE PRESIDENT AFTER HOUSE APPROVES, 38735; HE VOWS EQUAL JUSTICE FOR ALL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Gerald R. Ford, pledging equal justice for all Americans, took office just after dusk tonight as the 40th Vice President of the United States.

title: DR. ALAN ANDERSON, TAUGHT PHILOSOPHY
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6  Dr. Alan Ross Anderson, former chairman of the University of Pittsburgh department of Philosophy, died yesterday at his home here. He was 48 years old.

title: MYRA A. SMITH
description: Myra A. Smith, who retired in 1954 as director of publication services of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla., where she lived. Her age was 81.

title: TV: Incidcnt at Vichy
description: This season Hollywood Television Theater, produced for publictelevision station KCET in Los Angeles, has been presenting a series called Conflicts, a collection of short plays obviously confined within even shorter budgets. The results so far have been, at best, uneven. The exception is presented this week in a fine production of Arthur Miller's Incident at Vichy.

title: DUKE SETS ORDER FOR G.E. TURBINES
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that the Duke Power Company had placed an order for six nuclearpowered steam turbine gen erators valued in excess of $250million.

title: Jacobson May Start For Giants
description: Larry Jacobson, who cut his left foot on a piece of glass last June at a swimming pool may start at his regular defensive tackle post for the New York Giants Monday night in Los Angeles.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6The honeymoon is over for Upsala. The East Orange college won its first two games and now goes to Pennsylvania, the state that has given the Vikings nothing to cheer about in football or basketball in recent years.

title: U.S. Calls Arab Embargo No Longer Appropriate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had told Arab states that their oil embargo was no longer appropriate against this country given Washington's energetic efforts to get a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Hirshhorn's Target Date Is Fall of 1974
description: The Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, beset for the last four years by sporadic Congressional opposition and by construction and bidding delays, will open next fall, the man whose name the complex will bear said yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: The National Association of Manufacturers yesterday picked Donald A. Gaudion, a Rochester businessman, as its new board chairman for 1974.

title: ARABS CUT FUNDS AT BANKS OF U.S.
description: PARIS, Dec. 6Arab states are stepping up their economic offensive against the United States by withdrawing funds from American banks.

title: Morton Urges Oil Incentives
description: Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said yesterday that the longrange solution Ito the nation's energy difficulties lies in growth of economic incentives to develop new sources of energy.

title: BANKS' RESERVES SLOW IN GROWTH
description: The Federal Reserve continued to keep a tight grip on money and bank credit during the week ended Wednesday, data released by the central hank yesterday afternoon showed.

title: Hawley, Unhurt in Spill, Shatters Victory Mark
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 6 (AP)  Sandy Hawley, unhurt after being tossed from his mount before the fourth race at Laurel today, came back in the fifth and broke Bill Shoemaker's oneyear record of 485 victories.

title: New Skyrocket
description: The astronomic climb of wholesale fuel costs last month, with the price of refined petroleum products up by more than a third, indicates an alarming breakdown of antiinflation controls even before the real pinch of the energy crisis.

title: Landlords Seeking to Ease 68 Minimum to Save Fuel
description: Landlords of 1.5 million New York City apartments warned yesterday that enforcing the existing statutory minimum heat standard of 68 degrees could leave their tenants with no heat at all by the end of this month.

title: Their Problem: To Find Schools That Aren't Public, or Private
description: David Lavin, a sociologist, grew up in Scarsdale, where he now lives with his wife and three children. Scarsdale, he says, has a fine public school system. But he uses the word fine a little ironically, and goes on to say that the system has not maintained its leadership.

title: MYLES J. GERAGHTY
description: Myles J. Geraghty, a retired linotype operator of The New York Times and a 50year moilher of Local 6 of the International Typographical Union, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 74, and he lived at 3977 50th Street in Woodside, Queens.

title: M.T.A TO PROVIDE TWO SUNDAY RIDES FOR PRICE OF ONE
description: In a dramatic experiment to lure people to public transportation on gasless Sundays, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will provide roundtrip transportation for the price of a normal oneway fare on all public transportation in New York City and on all M.T.A. commuter lines for five consecutive Sundays beginning Dec. 16.

title: QUICK MOVES SAVE LON NOL U.N. SEAT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6Asian delegations friendly to the present administration in Cambodia told today of the months of planning, lobbying and effective footwork that neuver to stave off the expulsion of President Lon Nol's Government from the United Nations.

Mrs. Holzager, the wife of Dr. Theodore G. Holzager, was 66 years old and lived here.

SOYBEAN FUTURES REBOUND IN PRICE

In 1968, the system met one of the most difficult tests of all: peaceful transfer of power after the Social Christian party (COPEI) narrowly upset Democratic Action (A.D.), the base from which Romulo Betancourt restored democracy to Venezuela in 1958.

title: P.U.C. PANEL JOBS MADE FULLTIME
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6As one of his final major actions in his last month and a half in office, Governor Cahill signed into law this afternoon a bill that would require the three members of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to serve full time.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 4.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion tonmiles, 4.6 per cent, above the corresponding week last year.

description: TEXASSold Jim Mason, shortstop, to the New York Yankees and purchased Terry Crowley, first basemanoulfielder, from the Baltimore Orioles.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (AP)  President Juan D. Pern intends to reform the Constitution and the move could bring a general election next September, a key political aide said today.

description: International

title: A Watershed for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Now that Gerald R. Ford has become the nation's 40th Vice President, a number of Republicans in Congtess hope that he will soon become the 38th President.

title: F.B.I. DATA DISCLOSE ATTACK ON NEW LEFT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation marshaled a threeyear nationwide counterintelligence program to expose, disrupt and otherwise neutralize what the late Edgar Hoover called the New Left movement, according to internal agency memos made public today.

title: Screen:' David Holzman Diary' Spoofs Cinema Verite
description: "Life as a work of art"at least once a decade that ancient concept seduces some members of yet another generation, and inspires them to hash up their lives in the name of truth or beauty. Jim McBride's "David Holzman's Diary," a totally delightful satire on "the blubber about cinma vrit," mocks those ghastly reels from the nineteen-sixties, when various film makers immortalized themselves or their friends by trying and failing to be spontaneous. "Diary," which derides directors who scorned imagination or invention while worshiping the camera, opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art.Holzman, an earnest young Godard-hound, decides to film his life in order to understand itand only succeeds in ruining it. As a voyeur, a gentle intruder into other people's lives, he can't understand that the filming makes his subjects feel self-conscious, or that "reality" is altered by the presence of his camera and his tape recorder and his lavalier mike, which he calls his "friends."His girlfriend, who detests his movie-making, finally leaves him because of it. He's already told us in a dry, flat voice that he really loves her, though he can't resist pointing out that she's "dirty, sloppy." Forlornly, he adds, "I don't quite get her sense of privacy." After she's gone, he argues that masturbation is an improvement on the real thing because You can think of anything . . . pigs. Think of trains going in tunnels. Think of bagels. I mean, you're not limited to women."However, his obsession with freezing everything on celluloid rarely allows him any other fantasies. He gives manic attention to every detail of his New York neighborhood, from derelict sofas on the street to the installation of matchstick bamboo blinds in a nearby apartment, and finally gets slugged by a cop for filming people through their windows.Soon, we realize that the camera is his analyst. He tells it everything, and then grows furious because it doesn't answer him with "the right things," and also makes him "do things" that he wouldn't ordinarily do. Accusingly, he asks it, "What do you want?" Then he shouts at the lens that it hasn't helped himjust as a frustrated patient may denounce an all too silent psychiatrist."Diary" was made in 1967, and time has served it very well. We get a pungent flash on the past when a radio announces the numbers killed in the Newark riots, or refers to "the new Israel-Egyptian cease-fire," or quotes the Pentagon on the probable increase of American forces in Vietnam next year. But aside from politics, that period now seems a rather innocent one in retrospect, and the character of David Holzman (admirably played by L. M. Kit Carson) distills the eager naivet that accompanied the zest for technology, deliberate inarticulation and the mistrust of words, the vibes and the hoaxes and all the lighter put-ons of 1967.At the end, Holzman is bitterly disappointed that his movie and his camera have taught him nothing  least of all how to control his life. The picture reminds me of the late A. J. Liebling's recollection of being 23 in Paris, when he felt that his life hinged on an impossible decision. Meanwhile, he was writing a novel about a 23-year-old in Paris whose future hung upon an insoluble choice. When the character caught up with the day of his own life that he was describing, he couldn't finish the book. Jim McBride's movie evokes the spirit of Liebling's enormous laughter when he remarked that few diaries yield conclusions or solutions.

title: In Springlike Connecticut Winter Seems Far Away
description: If you really want to find lots of snow, Frank Ellis, operator of a telephone ski condition bureau, said yesterday, I recommend Timberline in Oregon. They tell me there's 100 inches of it right outside the base lodge.

description: TORONTOThe Senate Armed Services Committee and House Appropriations Committee hearings on the Pentagon budget until July 1974 are now out, and the traditionally diligent censors released alarming new information on the Nixon Administratioh's plans for Indochina.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Robert L. Vesco has been granted permission to live in Argentina, the press office of the Argentine judiciary announced here today.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Holiday candles with metal cores in their wicks contain enough lead to be hazardous when burned, a consumer advocacy group sponsored by Ralph Nader charged today.

title: MRS. CLINTON B. BROWN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Mrs. Erzebet Duma Brown, the widow of Clinton Bleecker Brown, who was a civil engineer in New York, died here today of leukemia, She was 86 years old.

title: France Shutdown Leaves Gaps
description: PARIS, Dec. 6Irne Ribault, a waitress at the Hole in the Wall Restaurant near the Opera, walked to work from her Paris suburb today only to find that the subway was running despite the general strike called by leftist unions and political parties. She was furious, the more so since she could have ridden free: the ticket punchers had stayed home.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the last two win five 50cent tickets for any subsequent weekly drawing when shown to any lottery vender.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Department of Commerce re, ported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.478billion up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $1.348billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.955billion up 7 per cent from last year's $10.222billion.

title: MRS. MAURICE SEILER

description: Osmond K. Fraenkel, who is being honored tonight on his 85th birthday, is a man deeply committed to his pleasures.

description: STONY RIDGE, Ohio, Dec. 6  Don Miller, a truck driver, sat in the Toledo Arco Truck Stop sipping coffee and looking pleased with himself.

title: Red Smith
description: What do you think of my stuff? Jimmy Cannon asked Frank Graham hack in the days when Jimmys column in the New York Post was a cornet in the sportspage firmament and Frank was the bright particular star of the JournalAmerican. Through all his life, Frank Graham managed to combine two qualities that are not always compatibleabsolute honesty and unfailing gentleness. His answer was gentle and honest: Jimmy, you remind me of a young lefthanded pitcher with all the speed in the world and no control. Coming from somebody else, the comment might have affronted Jimmy, for he was not a secure person arid needed frequent assurance that he was one of the very best. He took it with good grace from Frank, however. Overwriting, he Said. Yes, that's my greatest fault.

title: Dining Out: The Bright Side of the Fuel Crisis
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Australia to Poll 60,000 On New National Anthem
description: CANBERRA, Dec. 6 (Reuters)The Australian Government today voted down proposal for a referendum to pick a new national anthem instead it will hold a poll of 60,000 people.

title: Ken Harada Dead at 80; Japanese Envoy, Minister
description: Word has been received here of the death in Tokyo on Sept. 18 of Ken Harada, a Japanese diplomat who was his country's charg d'affaires in Vichy, France, in 1941, and special envoy to the Vatican from 1942 to 1945. He was 80 years old.

title: CHECKS A PROBLEM IN U.S. AID TO POOR
description: Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman disclosed yesterday that the city's banks so far had not agreed to cash checks for 200,000 aged, blind and disabled poor here, starting in January.

title: NELSON E. MINTZ
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 6Nelson E. Mintz, retired president of the Jaxton Clothes Company of Morristown, N. J., and former vice president of the Union National Stores, retail men's shops, died here today at his home. His age was 71, and he lived also in Blairstown, N. J.

title: Federal Judge Retires at 76
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) President Nixon acknowledged the retirement Friday of 76yearold Judge John R. Bartels as a Federal judge for the Eastern District of New York. Judge Bartels, who has served since July 30, 1959, will assume the status of a senior judge and be available for continued assignments.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. PICKS LEADER AMICABLY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7For the first time in recent memory, Republicans in the House of Representatives changed leaders today without a fight and elected Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona as minority leader to succeed Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, who was sworn in yesterday as Vice President.

title: Cambodia Premier Again Offers To Resign, Criticizing Cabinet
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Premier In Tam today offered his resignation to President Lon Nol for the second time in two months, wellinformed sources said tonight.

title: Business Briefs
description: Stocks Recoup Losses in London

title: Kissinger Off for Europe and Middle East Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Secretary of State Kissinger leaves tomorrow on a twoweek trip to Europe and the Middle East to smooth relations with America's traditional allies and to encourage Israel and the Arab states to talk seriously about peace.

title: Fuel Hoarding by Businessmen Deplored by ExOfficial of G. M.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 7Former General Motors vice president John Z. DeLorean, who now head the National Alliance of Businessmen, said today businessmen all over the country are starting to hoard oil and gasoline.

title: Ford Says Nixon Told Him He Won't Quit Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Vice President Ford quoted President Nixon as having told him today that he has no intention of resigning.

title: Notes on People
description: Out in Sasquisili, Ecuador, an hour out of Quito, the honeymoon continued for Princess Anne and Capt. Mark Phillips. A woman called her the Queen of London; the town danced in honor of the Princess and of its patron saint, San Juan the Weaver; Anne was lent a horse, and the couple shopped for blankets, masks and ponchos before driving up the slopes of Mount Cotopaxi for a picnic.

title: West German Girl, 16, Captures Slalom
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 7 (UPI)It was outsiders' day in the women's special slalom ski race for World Cup points today.

title: HERBERT C. SKINNER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) Herbert C. Skinner, first general vice president of the 900,000member United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, died today at the age of 61.

title: Japan Braces for a FullScale Oil Crisis
description: TOKYO, Dec. 7  Japan does not, at first glance, appear to be a nation in trouble.

title: Stocks Score Fresh Gains; Dow Surges 23.93 Points
description: Stock prices soared again yesterday as the DowJones industrial average recorded its best backtoback point gains in his tory. Trading was heavy.

title: China Squares The Circle
description: PARISThe only institutionalized revolution I have ever heard of is Mexico's and that experiment resembles a frozen custard. What Maoist China seeks is to institutionalize the idea of permanent or continuing revolution, which is almost like saying it wants to make dynamism static.

title: New Mail Center Uses Dogs to Sniff Out Illegal Drugs
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 7A fierce dog sniffing out contraband nail and a televised Xray machine that looks for drugs and guns were displayed here today as a Federal postal facility was opened by the United States Customs Service.

title: Forest Hills Is Staying With Grass
description: After a long period of reappraisal, the West Side Tennis Club has decided to defer for the time being the conversion of some of its grass courts to a claylike surface. Accordingly, the 1974 United States Open championships will remain on grass.

title: Scoppetta Reappointed
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame reappointed Nicholas Scoppetta as Commissioner of Investigation yesterday, commenting that it was the first time in the 100 years of the department that its head had been retained by a new Mayor.

title: U.S. PLACES CARRIER OFF NORTH VIETNAM
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 7 (UPI)North Vietnam charged today that the United States had stationed the aircraft carrier Midway off its coast and demanded it be withdrawn, the Chinese news agency Hsinhua reported.

title: Legal Action Is Pondered By Williams
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7 (AP)Dick Williams said today he was taking a waitandsee attitude for the present regarding his managerial status, but noted the possibility of legal action if the American League president, Joe Cronin, and the baseball commissioner, Bowie Kuhn, continue to refuse to rule on the matter.

title: LTV'S DIRECTORS BACK WILSON PLAN
description: The LTV Corporation announced yesterday that after an additional review, its directors had reaffirmed the original plan whereby LTV would acquire 100 per cent ownership of Wilson & Co., Inc., through a distribution of Wilson debentures to holders of Wilson common stock. LTV currently holds 89 per cent of the meat packer through its 100 per cent ownership of LTV Wils o n Industries, Inc. Under terms of the LTV Corporation's proposal to acquire Wilson & Co., shareholders of Wilson would receive for each of their shares $13 principal amount of new Wilson 9 per cent 10year sinkingfund debentures.

title: Export Outlook Sparks Futures Of Wheat to Record Price Level
description: Wheat futures set a record high of $5.55 a bushel yesterlay on the Chicago Board of Trade. The previous high was $5.48 set in September.

title: People and Business
description: New thinking about food production and population control is needed to avert hunger, malnutrition and perhaps even famine in the next 30 years, according to Roy V. Edwards, chairman of Wilson & Co., one of the nation's largest meatpacking and processing companies.

title: Senate Passes Park Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Senate passed without debate and sent to the House today a bill to authorize establshment of the Boston National Historical Park.

title: BIG MAKERS RAISE PRICES OF METALS
description: Major producers of copper and aluminum moved swiftly yesterday to raise prices for these commodities.

title: BENN W. LEVY, 73, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES
description: LONDON, Dec. 7Benn W. Levy, a playwright, stage and motionpicture director and former Labor member of Parliament, died today in Oxford. His age was 73.

title: Musicians Accept City Ballet Contract
description: Members of the New York City Ballet orchestra voted last night to accept a new threeyear contract, thereby paving the way for a possible opening of the seasonearly next week. Richard M. Clurman, chairman of the City Center, the ballet company's parent organization, expressed hope that the season would be resumed by Wednesday or Thursday with The Nutcracker.

title: College Quintets Play at Garden
description: Three teams, with a composite total of 305 previous appearances in its programs, will share the spotlight this afternoon when Madison Square Garden launches its 40th intercollegiate basketball season.

title: HARRY G. SEIDEL
description: Harry G. Seidel, a former Exxon Corporation executive and for the last year and half administrator for the United States Agency for International Development in Morocco, died of a heart attack in Washington on Monday. He was 51 years old.

title: Order in Court
description: The disruptive behavior of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton during their trial on bank robbery charges once again raises the issue of the defense lawyer's responsibility for a client's conduct. Instead of urging Miss Chesimard to desist from her disgusting verbal attacks on United States District Judge Lee P. Gagliardi, Miss Evelyn Williams, the defendant's counsel, exacerbated the situation by trying to walk out of the courtroom in defiance of the judge's order to return to the defense table.

title: Spain Arrests 14 Basques in a Wave of Bombings
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Fourteen persons have been arrested here in connection with a series of bomb attacks in Spain's northern Basque provinces, police sources said today.

title: Jobless Rate Back at 4.7% After Decline for a Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The nation's unemployment rate, after a dip in October, returned in November to the level that had prevailed since last spring, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Fixed Police Term Cited
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that because he had been appointed to a specific term in office, he had declined to subniit the resignation requested of highranking Lindsay administration officials by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame.

title: Book Thrown at Judge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (Reuters)A defendant here threw the book at the judge yesterday. Donald Lakey Reese, 23 years old was in court on a charge of attempted murder of a fellow prison inmate when he became angry and threw a copy of the Pennsylvania Penal Code at District Judge Harry Moles, striking him on the jaw. Judge Moles turned the other cheek. He [Reese] is in enough trouble already, the judge said, adding that he would not charge him with contempt of court.

title: South Africans End Gold Pact; Little Effect on Prices Expected
description: PARIS, Dec. 7South Africa and the International Monetary Fund announced today the termination of a 1969 gold sales agreement that dealers in Europe described as dead as a dodo anyway.

title: CHIEF OF BIG BOARD BACKS CLEARING UNIT
description: The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that he expected to sign shortly a memorandum of understanding with five other stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers designed to set up a national stockclearing system.

title: S. E. C. and General Host Agree to Settle a Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the General Host Corporation have reached an agreement to settle the suit brought against the company early this year charging fraud and other illegal acts in its 1969 attempt to acquire control of Armour & Co.

title: Kilmer Out of Bed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)  Billy Kilmer, the Washington Redskins was released today from a hospital where he has been undergoing treatmen for a stomach ailment since Tuesday. A team spokesman said Kilmer would practice prior to the Redskins' departure tomorrow for their showdown game with Dallas. Kilmer was listed as probable for the Cowboys although Coach George Allen has indicated that Sonny Jurgensen would start.

title: Nancy Gurney Dies at 58; Author of Children's Books
description: Mrs. Nancy Jack Gurney author of children's books and wife of the illustrator Eric Gurney, died Tuesday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital, She was 58 years old and lived in Westport, Conn., and Gay Head, Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Days of Testimony About Tape Gap Leave Questions, Including Big One
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The White House lawyer began walking out of the courtroom He got as far as the hallway, turned around, and hurried back to the cluster of reporters still inside.

title: Nets Take 7th Straight, Routing Tams, 138102
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Dec. 7With two minutes remaining in the first quarter tonight, Butch van Breda Kolff, the Memphis Tams coach, called time out and yelled at his players:

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to cut off debate on debt limit and campaignfinancing bill. The motion required a twothirds vote for passage. Motion defeated, 47 to 33, Dec. 2.

title: Hockey Players Fined
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 7 (UPI) Gary Edwards of the Los Angeles Kings, a goalie, and Bobby Schmautz of the Vancouver Canucks, a forward, were suspended today for one game and fined $200 for a stickswinging incident by the National Hockey League. The slashing occurred during a game in Vancouver last Tuesday night.

title: Jobless Rate Back at 4.7% Alter Decline for a Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The nation's unemployment rate, after a dip in October, returned In November to the level that had prevailed since last spring, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Historic Newark: A Glance at City's Landmarks
description: With the formation of the Newark Preservation and Landmark Committee, the first step has been taken to restore and preserve the city's historical sites. There are about 30 buildings that are considered important enough to save. To this end, the committee plans to organize tours, print guide books and promote special events to focus attention on local history.

title: LAURA VAN SPLINTER
description: ALLENDALE, N.J., Dec. 7Miss Laura Van Splinter, treas. urer of the Advertising Club of New York until her retirement 10 years ago, died last night at the Allendale Nursing Home. She had formerly been a resident of New York City for 45 years and lived at 235 East 22d street.

title: Leon Polk Smith's Maverick Attitude
description: Among the practitioners of the geometric mode of abstraction, the American painter Leon Polk Smith has had a curious career. Mr. Smith, now 67, began his career in the nineteenforties, a followerwith a difference in the Mondrian tradition. He has exhibited widely over the years and has exercised, through his various teaching positions, a certain influence on the development of the geometric mode.

title: Suspect Arraigned in Theft Of Coins From Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 7 (AP)Leonard Piazza, 44 years old, of Lynn, was arraigned in United States District Court here today on charges of armed robbery in connection with a robbery of about $1million in rare coins from a Harvard University museum.

title: Abend Retains Title
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Dec. 7 (UPI)  Lothar Abend of West Germany retained the European junior lightweight boxing title today with a 15round decision over Ugo Poli of Italy.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. PICKS LEADER AMICABLY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7For the first time in recent memory, Republicans in the House of Representatives changed leaders today without a fight and elected Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona as minority leader to succeed Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, who was sworn in yesterday as Vice President.

title: Truck Drivers Plan National Stoppage 2 Days Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Independent truck owneroperators, dissatisfied with Government assurances of special help during the fuel shortage, are moving ahead with plans for a nationwide truck stoppage net Thursday and Friday, according to unofficial spokesmen for the truckers.

title: 3 Libraries Ask City to Increase Operating Funds
description: The New York Public Library asked the city yesterday to in cease its contribution, to the library's operations by nearly. 50 per cent for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.N. AGAIN PUTS OFF ISSUE OF TERRORISM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7The General Assembly today put off until next year its debate on terrorism over protests by Israel that the decision demonstrated United Nations helplessness and a lack of will to take on the issue.

title: ONE DEAD AND 9 HURT IN W. MIDTOWN FIRE
description: An unidentified woman was burned to death and nine other persons injured, one of them critically, in an apartmenthouse fire on West 52d Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues last night, fire officials reported.

title: MRS. MAURICE EPSTEIN
description: Mrs. Stella Friedman Epstein, an illustrator and the wife of Maurice Epstein, a realestate developer, died Thursday in the New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived at 150 East 61st Street.

title: Finders Weepers
description: It was like everyone's dream come truelike manna from heaven, a sack filled with 16,200 $1 bills tumbled from a truck and landed in front of four construction workers.

title: Miss Driano Still Ahead In Skating
description: AMHERST, N.Y., Dec. 7Cynthia Driano of Lake Placid maintained a slim lead in the senior women's event after the short compulsory program tonight at the North Atlantic figure skating championships at the Audubon Center.

title: FRENCH EQUIPMENT ORDERED BY SOVIET
description: PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters)The Soviet Union placed today its largest single order for equipment in this country with the French subsidiary of an American company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Osmond K. Fraenkel, the civilliberties activist who has served for the past 36 years as general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union, was honored by his colleagues at a dinner. More than 450 persons jammed the starlight roof of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel to hear friends and relatives praise the activist lawyer, whose 85th birthday was yesterday.

title: Scoppetta Reappointed
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame reappointed Nicholas Scoppetta as Commissioner of Investigation yesterday, commenting that it was the first time in the 100 years of the department that its head had been retained by a new Mayor.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Power Commission in Washington has posted an order permitting the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation to bring increased supplies of natural gas to the Elizabeth Town Gas Company. A spokesman for the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners said that the move had broken a 16month deadlock on the request for the additional gas.

title: Fed Cuts Reserve Requirement On Big C.D.'s to Ease Money
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Federal Reserve Board took a step today apparently aimed at slightly easier money and lower bank lending rates to business.

title: Hope for U. S. Transit Aid Here Is Brighter, but...
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Excuse me, gentlemen, but I've got to get on to my next crisis, Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said last week in bidding goodby to Governor Rockefeller, Mayor elect Abraham D. Beame and the Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso. They had come in search of Federal funds to the 35cent fare in New York City.

title: Vesco's Extradition Refused by Bahamas
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 7Robert L. Vesco's monthlong fight to stave off extradition to the United States ended successfully today when a Bahamian court ruled that the wire fraud charge on which the financier was indicted in New York was not an extraditable offense.

title: `Balk Line Trial Is Set for Spring
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)The chairman of baseball's Rules Committee. Johnny Johnson, said today that both major leagues would experiment with a balk line during spring training. Johnson said the test was an attempt to help umpires.

title: F.P.C. Approves Gas Move To Help Fill Energy Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Federal Power Commission approved today the backward integration of two local natural gas distributors that decided to get into the production end of the natural gas business to augment supplies available to their customers.

title: Stage
description: James Elward's Hallelujah!, a new drama of a faithhealer's world, is quite a play. And Jim Jensen, the craggyfaced television newscaster, turns out to be quite an actor, heading a fine cast. Even the churchbasement cavern of the Central Arts Theater at 108 East 64th Street (7586327) suits the occasion.

title: PARIS ARRESTS 80 IN CHILE PROTEST
description: PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Policemen used a bulldozer today to break down the door of the Chilean Embassy here after 80 young Communists staged an occupationto publicize their call for the release of political prisoners in Chile. The policemen arrested all the youths without a struggle.

title: Knicks Subdue Braves
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 7  Dave DeBusschere put in 41 points, tying his National Basketball Association career high, as the Knicks rallied from an 8point deficit midway in the final quarter tonight to post a 113108 triumph over the Buffalo Braves at Memorial Auditorium.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, Dec. 7The New Jersey AllSports Hall of Fame, which will stage its annual testimonial dinner Monday night here at the Town and Campus Inn, has leaned heavily upon track and basketball in the selection of its 1973 inductees.

title: Michigan Election Feb. 18 To Fill Ford's House Seat
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 7 (UPI) Gov. William G. Milliken today set next Feb. 18 for an election to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Vice President Ford from his Fifth Congressional District seat.

title: A Report of Vision of Mary Draws Crowd
description: Several hundred people gathered outside St. Robert Bellarmine Roman Catholic Church in Bayside, Queens, last night, to witness what many of them said was another miraculous vision of the Virgin Mary on the eve of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WORLD AND THE 20'S: The Golden Years of New York's Legendary Newspaper. Edited, with an Introduction, by James Boylan. 346 pages. Illustrated. The Dial Press. $10.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Electric Company received a $78.8million contract addition from the Air Force for warheads for Minuteman III missiles.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP)Cold, rainy weather washed out the debut of Tournament Golf International today. Offering an alternative to the Professional Golfers' Association tour, TGI rescheduled the opening the $125,000, 54hole proam event at the Bardmoor Country Club for tomorrow. Most of the field of 80 pros and 80 amateurs had completed at least nine holes in a steady drizzle before the event was called. Five of the P.G.A.'s top 25 moneywinnersBob Murphy, John Mahaffey; J. Snead, Leonard Thompson and Ed Sneedare entered. The P;G.A. tour ended last week.

title: Japan Braces for a FullScale Oil Crisis
description: TOKYO, Dec. 7  Japan does not, at first glance, appear to be a nation in trouble.

title: Michaels Sheds Past With Jets for Eagles' Problems
description: Many people thought he would be the Jets' next head coach, most believed he was a good defensive coach. But he won't be the next coach and, after he left after last season, some instant critics suggested he had not been a defensive mastermind after all.

title: A Japanese Zoo Feels Oil Pinch
description: TOKYO, Dec. 7In Japan polar bears may be the first victims of the fuel shortage this winter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Iona Overcomes Columbia Five, 5551
description: Dave Budd sank two free throws with three seconds remaining to assure Iona a 5551 victory in basketball over Columbia at the loser's University Gym last night.

title: Miss Driano Still Ahead In Skating
description: AMHERST, N.Y., Dec. 7Cynthia Driano of Lake Placid maintained a slim lead in the senior women's event after the short compulsory program tonight at the North Atlantic figure skating championships at the Audubon Center.

title: School Aide, Not Principal, Named in Shakedown Case
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx announced yesterday that a man who pleaded guilty Wednesday to a shakedown charge was, in fact, a guidance counselor at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx, and not the principal, as the prosecution had stated originally.

title: Radnor Valley Club Wins Bermuda Golf
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 7Radnor Valley Country Club of Villanova, Pa., posted a net score of 56 over the Belmont Golf Club course today and won the 21st annual Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament by three strokes. The winners had a 72hole total of 242.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: The Genocide Convention: Time to Sign
description: The Genocide Convention was adopted unanimously by the General Assembly on Dec. 9, 1948. Opposition to ratification in the United States has since been marked by remarkable irony. Extremist critics of ratification have endowed the convention with enormous powers that would somehow be wielded by the international community at the expense of sovereign states.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In his first game for the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden three years ago, Pete Maravich was shooting when a member of the New York Knicks barely grazed his arm. When a whistle blew, Red Holzman jumped off the bench.

title: DEMOCRATS WEIGH ROCKEFELLER PLANS
description: Democratic leaders were divided yesterday on the effect Governor Rockefeller's expected resignation would have on their prospects for winning the office next year.

title: NATO Allies Assure the U.S. Of Aid in Paying Troop Costs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7 The United States received general assurances from its European tallies today that they will increase their efforts to reduce the balanceofpayments burden caused by the American troop commitment to Western Europe.

title: State Urged to Speed Curb On Indirect Air Pollution
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7New Jersey was warned today that it might have to require prior approval for construction that would produce even relatively small sources of indirect air pollution, such as highways, parking lots, shopping centers and sports complexes.

title: Truck Drivers Plan National Stoppage 2 Days Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7independent truck owneroperators, dissatisfied with Government assurances of special help during the fuel shortage, are moving ahead with plans far a nationwide truck stoppage next Thursday and Friday, according to unofficial spokesmen for the truckers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jerseys daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: The Merritt Saved
description: There's light at the end of Connecticut's green tunnel after all.

title: Seoul Frees Jailed Student Protesters
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. President Park Chung Hee ordered today that all the students arrested for recent antiGovernment demonstrations be freed at once and those expelled from their schools be reinstated.

title: Balk Line Trial Is Set for Spring
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)The chairman of baseball's Rules Committee. Johnny Johnson, said today that both major leagues would experiment with a balk line during spring training. Johnson said the test was an attempt to help umpires.

title: U.S.Soviet Hot Line Shifting to Satellites
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 7  The United States and the Soviet Union are transferring the WashingtonMoscow Hot Line to a network of space satellites.

title: People in Sports: A Kicker's Final Boot
description: Dirk Kryt, a soccerstyle kicker who led Michigan State's football team in scoring this season, has returned to his native Netherlands. But he left a verbal kick behind.

title: Markham Named for Award For Articles on Drug Use
description: The annual media award of AVANT, the Association of Voluntary Agencies on Narcotics Treatment, has been won by James M. Markham, a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Art: Oarsman Shows Strength
description: Jon Carsman's paintings at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue at 78th Street, stir a curious double recall of past masters, being remindful at once of Charles Burchfield and Dwight D. Eisenhower, when the latter was painting by the numbers. It is a tribute to Mr. Carsman's strength that the resemblance can be quite apparent while producing neither a yawn nor a giggle.

title: DEMOCRATS WEIGH ROCKEFELLER PLANS
description: Democratic leaders were divided yesterday on the effect Governor Rockefeller's expected resignation would have on their prospects for winning the office next year.

title: MRS. PATRICK J. SCAFURI
description: Mrs. Laure Young Scafuri, fashion model and the wife of Patrick J. Scafuri, an investment banker, died yesterday of a cere bral hemorrhage in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 32 years old and lived at 301 East 69th Street.

title: Meskill Scraps Merritt Parkway Plans
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 7Gov. Thomas J. Meskill announced today that he had ordered a major revision of the controversial plans for redevelopment and modernization of the Merritt Parkway.

title: Music: A Happy Return
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. With Vladimir Ashkenazy, piano. Conducted by Georg Semkow. At Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Oil and the Third World
description: For generations the people of the Middle East have watched Western oil companies invest little and relentlessly pump out enormous quantities of irreplaceable wealth while the region stagnated. For example, while the consortium of Western companies in Iraq put in no more than $50 million in the early 1900's, by the early 1960's they had taken out over $2 billion.

title: Teamsters' Union Sues Ed McMahon on Contract
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) A $6.75million suit has been filed against Ed McMahon, the television personality, for allegedly breaking a contract in a promotion to improve the image of the Teamsters Union.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1973

title: Idols For Mr. Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7As fortieth Vice President of the United States, Gerald Ford will follow in many famous footsteps.

title: Gyro on Skylab Is Erratic; Officials Are Not Alarmed
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7 (AP)One of two surviving gyroscopes aboard the Skylab space station has begun to act erratically, but officials said today that it was cause for concern, but not for alarm.

title: Ceausescu Urges U.S. Business to Invest in Rumania
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania called on American business leaders here yesterday to take advantage of recent Rumanian legislation permitting outright foreign investmeat in the nation's industry.

title: Christmas a Big Businessin East Germany
description: ERFURT, East Germany  The Christmas shopping season was well under way in East Germany by the middle of November, and perhaps even before that.

title: MORE TRADES: Yankees Obtain Piniella for McDaniel; Cleveland to Red Sox, Curtis to Cards
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7  The American League voted today to make the designated hitter a permanent boarder, and the New York Yankees promptly celebrated by trading Lindy McDaniel to the Kansas City Royals for one of the league's established hitters, Lou Piniella.

title: WINE TALK
description: The First Annual Wine and Cheese Festival begins today at the Coliseum. Its promoters say it is the only show around at which you can eat and drink the exhibits.

title: Chile Protests to Paris
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Chile protested to France over the French Government's failure to prevent the Communist occupation of her Paris embassy. A Foreign Ministry statement said the protest had been delivered by the Chilean charg d'affaires in Paris.

title: Bridge: MixedPairs Event Launches Fall National Championships
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 7 The Fall National Championships began here this afternoon with attention focused on the mixedpair championship. A total of 810 pairs are entered in the foursession event, which ends tomorrow night.

title: HOUSING PROPOSAL OFFERED BY BYRNE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 7Governor  elect Brendan T. Byrne said today that he wanted to investigate the possibility of improving the housing market in New Jersey by investing state pension funds in mortgages.

title: First National City Leads Banks Lifting Prime Rates to 10%
description: Several major banksled by the First National City Bank, which is New York's largestannounced increases in the prime rate to 10 per cent yesterday, and just a few hours later the Federal Reserve Board made a move apparently designed to offset the trend.

title: BREAK CONFIRMED BY A NEW CHURCH
description: BIRMINGHAM, Dec. 7The nation's newest religious denomination, the National Presbyterian Church, ended its first general assembly here today after formalizing its separation from the Presbyterian Church in the United States.

title: SENATE APPROVES $20BILLION FUND TO SEEK ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Senate passed 82 to 0 today a bill calling for a massive 10 year research and development program to make the United States selfsufficient in sources of energy.

title: HOUSE CLEARS WAY FOR TEST ON SAXBE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill designed to eliminate a constitutional obstacle to the nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe to be Attorney General.

title: A GYPSY CAB DRIVER IS ACCUSED OF RAPE
description: A 25yearold driver of a gypsy cab was indicted yesterday on charges of abducting and raping a 16yearold girl in the Bronx in the earlymorning hours last Tuesday.

title: BargainPriced Gasoline Still Available
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7Despite sharp increases in the cost of fuel and gasoline reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, motorists in New Jersey can still find bargains at the gas pump.

title: Memphis Policemen Cleared In Beating Death of Black
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 7 (UPI)Eight policemen were acquitted by a jury of 12 white men last night on charges of beating one black youth to death and assaulting another following 1971 traffic chase.

title: Jewish Leaders Are Told Israel Requires Unprecedented Sums
description: American Jewish leaders were told yesterday that their communities would have to raise unprecedented sums to enable Israel to cope with pressing humanitarian problems in the wake of recent hostilities and tensions in the Middle East.

title: Israel Asking Military Talks in Geneva
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 7Israeli officials say their Government plans to propose that Israel and Egypt meet in Geneva immediately after the formal opening of the Middle East peace conference for direct talks on troop pullbacks on the Suez front.

title: Citroen Sets Holiday Closing
description: PARIS, Dec. 7 (AP)  The Citroen Automobile Company said today it would close its assembly lines for 11 days during the holiday season because of a sharp drop in European export orders. The company said orders were down 15 to 20 per cent, particularly for bigger cars.

title: POLISH SCIENTISTS HELPING THE U. S.
description: WARSAW, Dec. 7  The present happy relationship between Poland and the United states expresses itself in many ways.

title: 56 H.U.D OFFICIALS TO BE DISCIPLINED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Department of Housing and Urban Development has authorized disciplinary action against 55 regional employes for continuing to approve housing applications after they were ordered not to, a high ranking department official said today.

title: White House Will Disclose Data On President's Finances Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The White House will make public tomorrow all of the pertinent information regarding President Nixon's personal finances, the President's deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said today.

title: Fuel Phones Set Up Here
description: The Federal Office of Petro leum Allocation yesterday said the public could telephone its offices here regarding fue problems, Three lines will be open from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M weekdays beginning Monday The numbers are 264.1184 1185 and 1186.

title: Mexico Holds 2 From U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Dennis Banks, a leader of the American Indian movement in the United States, was detained here today and faces possible deportation, police sources said. His press secretary, George Roberts, was also detained, both were accused of interfering in Mexican internal affairs.

title: Stocks Continue Surge
description: The stock market extended its strong technical rally yesterday as the DowJones industrials soared 23.93 points to close at 838,05, The upturn followed Thursday's advance of 23.81 points, which began the turnabout after the Dow had plunged nearly 200 points within six weeks, Page 49.

title: Campus Notes
description: There are few traditions at Kirkland College in Clinton, N. Y., a school for women that was opened in 1968. But even before ivy began to grow on the buildings of the $12million college, Kirkland had a bagpipe player, Elyn Cheney.

title: Jules Olitski Succeeds With Circles
description: Four years have passed since the American painter Jules Olitski made his New York debut as a sculptor in an unusual exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (It was only the third time in its entire history that the Met had mounted a oneman show by a living artist.

title: Vesco's Extradition Refused by Bahamas
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 7Robert L. Vesco's monthlong fight to stave off extradition to the United States ended successfully today when a Bahamian court ruled that the wire fraud charge on which the financier was indicted in New York was not an extraditable offense.

title: Saigon Recaptures Key District Capital in Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 8South Vietnamese infantry units last night retook a district capital in the Central Highlands that was overrun by North Vietnamese soldiers and tanks four days ago, the Saigon command announced.

title: Fighting Fire With Fire
description: Ever since the wildcat police strike of 1971, New York City's officialdom has been showing a commendable disposition to enforce strictly the penalties which state law prescribes for illegal strikes by public employespenalties regularly ignored in earlier years.

title: Infanticide in Japan: Sign of the Times?
description: TOKYOThe body of the newborn baby was found in a coin locker at the Ueno railway station here. It was wrapped in a bath towel and stuffed into a paper bag. A note attached to the package read: Gomen nasai, honto ni gomen nasau (I'm sorry, I really am sorry.).

title: U.S. Oil Exports Continue at Low Level
description: While the Arab embargo on oil shipments is reducing United States oil imports, the country continues to export crude and petroleum products. In October, for instance, the United States exported 7,514,754 barrels of crude and products, or 242,000 barrels a day.

title: C.A.B. SETS DEADLINE TO END AIR EXPRESS
description: Termination of air express service by the nation's airlines no later than June 5, 1974, has been ordered by the Civil Aeronautics Board, which said that many of the historical advantages of air express had withered away.

title: U.S.Soviet Trade Rising; Moscow Assails Bill on Oil
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 7The Unit ed States moved within range of becoming the Soviet Union's largest Western trading partner this year with more than $1.2billion in twoway trade during the first 10 months of 1973.

title: NEWARK MURDERS AT RECORD LEVEL
description: NEWARK, Dec.7The murders of two men with long police records have pushed Newark's homicide rate to its highest level in history.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Schools Defy Hartford on Fuel Rules
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 7The Connecticut State Board of Education has run into opposition as a result of its orders to local school authorities to alter their schedules to save fuel.

title: ExChief Immigration Trial Attorney Quits Abruptly
description: Vincent A. Schiano, the chief trial attorney for the Immigration and Naturalization Service here until he was quietly demoted a year ago, abruptly resigned yesterday under controversial circumstances after 20 years of service.

title: Half of Pedestrian Bridge Over the Van Wyck Is Severed by Truck
description: Half of a pedestrian bridge spanning the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens was sheared off by a dump truck yesterday, the police reported.

title: URGE RESIGNING COURT IN NASSAU
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 7 A Nassau County District Court judge, a longtime enoiled Republican who defeatthe county Republican organization in a bid for reection three years ago, announced today that he was resigning his post, saying his political independence had cost him chances for promotion.

title: Britain Orders a 17% Cut In Fuel for the Airlines
description: LONDON, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Britain ordered a 17 per cent cut in fuel for airlines today and banned Sunday flying for small planes.

title: Greek Urges Nation To Drop Illusions About New Rulers
description: ATHENS, Dec. 7The leader of Greece's last Parliament urged the nation today to discard optimism, illusions, and delusions and join forces against a perpetuation of the dictatorship.

title: TV: Efron Conducts Sunday School
description: Frankly, it's a puzzlement. Marshall Efron's Illustrated, Simplified and Painless Sunday School is the latest product to enter the lion's den of children's programing. Carried on the Columbia Broadcasting System network Sunday mornings at 10:30, the program is an attempt, according to Ted Holmes, producer, to teach values and transmit information to kids in a way which is entertaining, informative, sometimes absurd, but always (we hope) inspiring,

title: ROCKEFELLER VISITS ATLANTA PARLEY
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 7With his arrival enlivened by reports of a renewed Presidential quest, Governor Rockefeller visited the Southern Republican Conference tonight, defending President Nixon and repeatedly turning away specific questions on Watergate to the point where he had to grin.

title: Losersand Winnersin Fuel Crisis
description: The energy crisis has bestowed burdens and blessings with a cavalier randomness on those whose livelihood is somehow connected to energy. One man has spent his career manufacturing gasoline cans, another Christmas lights. Suddenly, events that neither was able to foresee and that each is helpless to control allow one to prosper beyond his expectations, while leaving the other with the economic wreckage of a lifetime.

title: T.W.A. Laying Off 350 More Pilots
description: Trans World Airlines, which has been shut down by a strike of attendants since Nov. 5, announced yesterday that 350 additional pilots would be laid off beginning in January because fuel shortages would require fewer flights when the strike ended.

title: Dance: Ritha Devi Excels
description: Ritha Devi is an exceptional performer of Indian dance. In the true Hindu classical dance tradition, she is as superb an actress as she is a dancer. Both aspects were very much in evidence in her solodance concert Thursday night at the Exchange Theater, and it would be folly for anyone interested in either dance or drama to miss her repeat program at the Cubiculo Sunday night at 8 P.M.

title: ALEX HABERSTROH, FILM CREATOR, DIES
description: Alex Haberstroh, producer of educational films on astronomy, and a specialeffects expert on sciencefiction films, died yesterday of a stroke at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 463 West Street.

title: Fixed Police Term Cited
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that because he had been appointed to a specific term in office, he had declined to submit the resignation requested of highranking Lindsay administration officials by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame.

title: Doyle of Canadian Javelin Is Arrested by Mounties
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 7John C. Doyle, the chief executive officer of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., was arrested today in a police raid on the company's head office here.

title: Some Cambodia Refugees
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, In the absence of American bombing, some Cambodian refugees have begun to filter hack into towns and villages controlled by the insurgents.

title: Russians Explain Their Support for Nixon
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 7There is a curious parallel these days between the official Soviet attitude toward President Nixon and the feelings many Americans had toward Nikita S. Khrushchev at the time he was ousted as Premier in 1964.

title: After a Campaign of 2 Years, Venezuela Is Set to Elect Leader
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 7Venezuela's costly twoyear presidential campaign closed today with forecasts of victory in Sunday's vote fairly evenly divided between the candidates of the two major parties.

title: Treasury Seeks to Mint Pennies of Aluminum
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  The Treasury asked Congress today for authority to begin making pennies out of aluminum instead of copper.

title: MORE TRADES:
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 7  The American League voted today to make the designated hitter a permanent boarder, and the New York Yankees promptly celebrated by trading Lindy McDaniel to the Kansas City Royals for one of the league's established hitters, Lou Piniella.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TRAIN OF THOUGHT The 10th Annual AvantGarde Festival, an argosy of unlikely innovation, takes place tomorrow from 1 to midnight in 20 baggage cars on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal. Charlotte Moorman, the director, has done the festival in past years in such ambiances as the Staten Island Ferry, the Central Park lakeside, Ward's Island and an armory.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Bob Dylan Forms Own Record Label

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: BROOKLYN SCHOOL SCENE OF BOYCOTT
description: Parents of children at Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn kept about 40 per cent of the pupils out ofl school for an hour yesterday morning in a renewal of a lingering dispute over the appointment of a principal.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: OmahaDuane Bobick, 210, Bowlus, Minn., knocked out Reco Brooks, 213, Phoenix, Ariz., 2; Morris Jackson, 224, Omaha, knocked out Lou Bailey, 199, Omaha, 2.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: EGYPT REPORTED READY TO ATTEND PARLEY AT GENEVA
description: CAIRO, Dec. 7Egypt has decided to attend the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva Dec. 18 even in the absence of a prior Israeli troop withdrawal from the Suez area, informed diplomats said today.

title: SENATE APPROVES $20BILLION FUND TO SEEK ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Senate passed 82 to 0 today a bill calling for a massive 10year research and development program to make the United States selfsufficient in sources of energy.

title: Defense Funds Travesty
description: Despite new promises yesterday from the NATO defense ministers to do more, major differences persist among the allies over sharing the financial burdens of the American troop presence in Europe. Money may of may not be the source of all evil, but in NATO affairs it threatens a crisis in the coming months that could prove even more serious than the strain in the North Atlantic alliance stemming from October's Mideast war.

title: For Some, Quilting Is a Night Out...
description: The four young mothers, all married to doctors, spend one evening a week together, and their husbands, who stay at home to look after the children, tease the women about their night out.

title: PETER SABBATINO, LAWYER, 82, DEAD
description: Peter L. F. Sabbatino, a noted criminal lawyer and former assistant district attorney here, died yesterday at his home, 235 East 22d Street. His age was 82.

title: Newcombe Defeated By Injury
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7For the second year in a row, a semifinalist in the $50,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix Master Tournament has been forced to retire with match point in his favor. John Newcombe became the victim tonight when he injured his leg following a winning smash against Torn Okker of the Netherlands.

title: House Vote Backing Ford
Klassen Hopes Christmas Mail Will Be Delivered on Schedule
