description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Postmaster General Elmer T. Klassen said today that barring things we have no control over, we will not have extra mail in our post offices when Christmas eve arrives.

title: Prices Score Gains for 2d Day As Volume Rises on the Amex
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday for the second straight day as traders bought up stocks at what they believed to be bargain prices. The same situation prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Ford Says Nixon Told Him He Won't Quit Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Vice President Ford quoted President Nixon as having told him today that he has no intention of resigning.

title: EGYPT REPORTED READY TO ATTEND PARLEY AT GENEVA
description: CAIRO, Dec. 7Egypt has decided to attend the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva Dec. 18 even in the absence of a prior Israeli troop withdrawal from the Suez area, informed diplomats said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut announced that he had viewed plans for the controversial redevelopment and modernization of the Merritt Parkway and ordered them scrapped. They would have changed the basic nature of the parkway, he said, and I can't allow that.

title: Chapin Pleads Not Guilty to Lying to Watergate Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had committed perjury before a grand jury investigating the Watergate scandals.

title: MANAGEMENT SEEN AS KEY TO ENERGY
description: Th chairman of the nation's largest corporation said yesterday that the energy crisis was a management problem that could be solved by matching energy needs to available resources.

title: First National City Leads Banks Lifting Prime Rates to 10%
description: Several major banksled by the First National City Bank, which is New York's largestannounced increases in the prime rate to 10 per cent yesterday, and just a few hours later the Federal Reserve Board made a move apparently designed to offset the trend.

title: Escaped Murderer Shot
description: PINOLE, Calif., Dec. 7 (UPI) A convicted murderer who escaped from San Quentin was shot and captured last night after he commandeered a truck with four persons in it and smashed through a roadblock. The convict, Francisco C. Salas, 41 years old, was hit in the back and neck by a shotgun blast.

title: Gurney FundRaising Expected To Become Key Campaign Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Senator Edward J. Gurney's acknowledgement in Florida last night that a volunteer aide had used his name to collect a $100,000 fund is expected to make fundraising the major issue in the senator's reelection campaign next year.

title: Santiago: A Big Triple And Big Day
description: Angel Santiago will be a proud soninlaw when Seora Sylvia Suida arrives from Balboa, Canal Zone, today. Santiago is married to Seora Suida's daughter, Edita, and it was Seora Suida who urged Santiago to become a jockey.

title: Michaels Sheds Past With Jets for Eagles' Problems
description: Many people thought he would be the Jets' next head coach, most believed he was a good defensive coach. But he won't he the next coach and, after he left after last season, some instant critics suggested he had not been defensive mastermind after all.

title: John Loeb Jr. Eyes Republican Bid for Governor
description: LONDON, Dec. 7John L. Loeb Jr., a former Wall Street investment banker, disclosed here today that he would seriously consider running for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York State if Governor Rockefeller resigned to seek the Presidency.

title: JOHN F. SIERKS DIES; LEVITT ARCHITECT, 59
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Dec. 7 John F. Sierks, chief architect of Levitt & Sons, builders of Levittown, and designer of most of the homes erected by the company in the last 24 years, died yesterday at the Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived here.

title: ARTHUR SINGER
description: Arthur Singer, a retired button manufacturer, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived at 240 Central Park South.

title: BOOK CLUB SALES CURBED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Some clubs and doortodoor sellers win nave to change their ways to comply with two regulations revived today by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: RICHARD RENDELL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP),  Richard Rendell, a former newscaster, magazine corre spondent and Associated Press reporter, died Tuesday at a hospital here after suffering a stroke. He was 67 years old.

title: Trot Twin Bill
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI)Plans for a harness racing doubleheader to open a 60day meet at Balmoral Park in suburban Crete were reinstated today as horsemen agreed to a threeyear contract with Balmoral Trots.

title: Memories Are Made of This
description: WASHINGTON  Merle Miller has written a book which includes tapes and notes of conversations he had with the late President Truman in 196162. Among other things, Mr. Truman gave Mr. Miller an account of his meeting with General MacArthur at Wake Island Oct. 15, 1950, in which he is alleged to have said the planes of the President and the general jockeyed for landing positions: Each refused to land first, preferring that the other be on the ground to meet him.

title: Celtics, Led By Havlicek, Top Hawks
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)John Havlicek and Dave Cowens scored 24 points each and Cowens had 17 rebounds and lead the Boston Celtics to a 116112 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: Stocks Continue Surge
description: The stock market extended its strong technical rally yesterday as the DowJones industrials soared 23.93 points to close at 838.05. The upturn followed Thursday's advance of 25.81 points, which began the turnabout after the Dow had plunged nearly 200 points within six weeks. Page 49.

title: Free Ride
description: All of the Big Three automobile manufacturers have now agreed to pay the full employe share of any payroll tax Congress may levy if it enacts Federal health insurance in the next three years.

title: Policemen to Get Shotguns
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7 (AP)In an effort to put policemen on a firepower par with criminals some police officers will get shotguns as standard equipment for their patrol cars, Police Commissioner Robert diGrazia announced yesterday.

title: FAMILIES HEADED BY WOMEN GROW
description: New York City families headed by women with children under 18 years old have increased by 81 per cent, or 85,000, over the last 10 years, and they tend to live in the poorest areas of the city on belowpoverty incomes, according to a recent study of 1970 census data by the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: Antiques: Art Deco Style
description: Getting to know Art Deco is definitely a sensual experience, as can be seen in two current exhibitions of furniture from the Roaring Twentiesdesigns not quite vintage enough to be legally classified as antiques but collected as if they were. This time the accent is on French designs by artisans who excelled in cabinetmaking techniques that demonstrate how seductive furniture can sometimes be.

title: Agnew to Retain Guards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  Secret Service protection for former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew is continuing at the direction of President Nixon for an indefinite period, the White House said today. The White House deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said the Secret Service would decide when the protection was to end.

title: U. N. Bids the Big 5 Cut Arms Budgets To Aid Poor Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7The General Assembly approved tonight a Soviet proposal calling on the five major powers to cut their miliitary budgets by 10 per cent and to devote 10 per cent of the savings to helping poorer countries.

title: Bill to Aid Car Pools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) Representative Lamar Baker, Republican of Tennessee, introduced legislation today to give tax break to persons who operate car pools to save gasoline. He said that a 20 per cent cutback in auto use, for example, could save 40 million gallons of gasoline daily.

title: Nixon May Use Trains As a Way to Save Fuel
description: WASHINGTON Dec, 7 (AP)  President Nixon may turn from the skies to the rails as a way to conserve fuel while getting away from Washington, sources said today.

title: Wire Keeps Oil Pipelines Warm
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7A professor of chemical engineering at the Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, proposes moving Arctic and other oil through large pipelines that are warmed by an electric skin effect. Donald F. Othmer was granted Patent 3,777,117 this week for the heat generating system. An insulated wire running through a steel pipe serves as one leg of an alternating current circuit.

title: Wings Play To 11 Draw With Blues
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 (UPI) Pierre Jarry scored his first goal as a Detroit player tonight to earn the Red Wings a 11 tie with the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game.

title: Mrs. Robert O'Connor Dies; FlowerFifth Ave. Aide, 54
description: Virginia Miller O'Connor, patientservice representative at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and widow of Dr. Robert A. O'Connor, who was associate dean of New York Medical College until his death in 1969, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home, 340 Godwin Avenue, Ridgewood, N.J. She was 54 years old.

title: Cahill Signs Bill Increasing New Chief Justice's Pension
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7 (AP) Governor Cahill signed into law today a bill increasing the pension for Chief Justicedesignate Richard J. Hughes.

title: Compacts In, Sedans Out In the Official Fleets Here
description: In response to the fuel shortage, the governments of New York City, New York State, Connecticut and New Jersey are phasing out intermediate and large cars from their official fleets and are buying compacts and subcompacts instead.

title: Play It Again, Bud!
description: The names often become a frame of reference for us: Wrong Way Riegels, Mickey Owen, Shoemaker standing in the irons, Roger BannisterJohn Landy. Each was involved in historic sports flubs. Don't mess with these legends, a part of us says. And yet, what If we went back, using modern camera equipment to freeze the moment for us. Would it be the same?

title: BALTIMORE EYES END OF BOOKBAN
description: BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 8The Baltimore School Board is expected to reconsider next week a decision to ban Manchild in the Promised Land. the 1965 bestseller about life in Harlem, from city school libraries.

title: Electric Utilities' Hunting Season
description: BERLIN, Conn.  With the specter of power cutbacks looming ever larger, electric utilities are finding many obstacles in trying to give their customers the service they need. Already New England voltage is being reduced per cent for four hours every day as a fuelsaving measure.

title: FOR THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: In December, 1912, The New York Times published a comprehensive report of conditions among destitute families in New York City. Since then the annual Times Christmas appeal for the needy has become an important part of the holiday season for succeeding generations of New Yorkers.

title: Forego First In Handicap At Aqueduct
description: Forego contributed another succssful weightcarrying performance at Aqueduct yesterday when he won the 1  mile Discovery Handicap by threequarters of a length under the top burden of 127 pounds.

title: A Conductor's Society to the Rescue
description: TOSCANINI conducting Die Zauberflte? Beecham leading the Berlioz Requiem? Adolf and Fritz Busch performing the Beethoven Violin Concerto? Joseph Szigeti and Dmitri Mitropoulos in the Berg Violin Concerto?

title: CAMBODIANS FLEE PROVINCE CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 8Thousands of civilians fled a strategically important town 29 miles west of Phnom Penh today after it was struck by Communist shells:

title: Miss Lisa Todman Will Wed in March
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. William S. Todman of Scarsdale and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Susan Todman, to William. B. Plough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice D. Plough of Memphis, Tenn.

title: EASTERN AIR PLANS FURTHER LAYOFFS
description: MIAMI, Dec. 8 (AP)Up to 5,000 Eastern Airlines employes, including 25 per cent of the carrier's top executives, will be laid off by Christmas, said a spokesman for the International Association of Machinists.

title: Turnpike Devices Will Halt Crashbound Traffic
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe New Jersey Turnpike Authority reported plans this weekend to install a fully automated system of sensors along the eastern and western roads at its northern end. They will immediately shut down traffic that is heading toward the scene of an accident, or divert it when a roadway becomes congested.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Dr. William B. Shockley, a physicist, was awarded the Nobel Prize for his part in the invention of the transistor. But his views on I.Q. and race have not won him equal acclaim.

title: Gail Beam Is Affianced
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 8 The Rev. Paul V. Beam, minister of the Scarsdale Community Baptist Church, and Mrs. Beam of Scarsdale have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Elizabeth Beam, to Kenneth Claude Sharp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude H. Sharp of Madison, N. C. The future bride's father will perform the marriage ceremony June 1 in his church.

title: Kitchen, Good
description: One of the best things about this automobile beat is a restaurant where much valuable research can be done into coquilles St. Jacques, quiche lorraine and the 1930 Grand Prix of Monaco.

title: Epilogue
description: The AfoAKom, the most sacred religious symbol for the people of Kom in West Cameroon, is safe at home again after an absence of seven years. The almostmansized wooden statue was stolen in 1966 but was discovered in New York City recently in an art gallery. It was flown home last week and arrived with only a few of its head beads slightly damaged. The mourning in Korn is now over and preparations are being made to celebrate the joy of the statue's return.

title: New Colors for a State Map
description: NEWARK  A 13foot, oneofakind relief map of New Jersey, known to thousands of youngsters throughout the state in black and white, is currently being transformed into vivid color. As part of the New Jersey Historical Society's $800,000 renovation project, the map will be brightly colored to indicate major points of reference in the Garden State, according to a society spokesman.

title: SPENCER N. ROSE
description: Spencer N. Rose, who retired recently as vice president in charge of the custody department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Wednesday at the age of 58. He lived at 454 Wyoming Avenue, Millburn, N. J.

title: HEARING IS HELD ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Members of the State Assembly's Codes Committee have been given a lengthy preview yesterday of a controversial issue that the Legislature will have to take up in the next session  the possible restoration of New York's limited provision for capital punishment.

title: Abigail Smith Betrothed to John Davies
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. Miss Abigail Hawley Smith, a senior at the University of Pennsylvania, and John Byron Davies, a senior at Lehigh University, plan to be married in March.

title: Israeli Governor
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 8 (Reuters)The Israeli military governor of the occupied city of Nablus, Col. Eliezer Segev, was wounded in a grenade attack on his car today, a military spokesman announced.

title: Al Paul to Head Columbia's Athletics
description: Al Paul was named athletic director of Columbia University yesterday, taking over responsibility for 14 varsity sports, which includes a football team that won one game.

title: The U.S. Oil Refinery Gap
description: LOS ANGELESInsufficient refining capacity is a bottleneck that will leave the nation short of gasoline, home heating fuel and other petroleum products, even if the Arab oil embargo is lifted.

title: Miss Evelyn Fanning Is Engaged
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Fanning of Ridgewood and Spring Lake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Marie Fanning, to Daniel Caso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carmine Caso of Saugus, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: How to Take a Safari without Being Stanley or Livingstone
description: YOU'RE settled in a comfortable chair on the long veranda of an East African game reserve lodge. There is a rock parapet only inches from your knees. Dinner, English style, has been goodsoup and fish and a roast and a trifleand now night has come, black as tar and studded with stars.

title: Letters: How Read Was Tara?
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Warch, Peter Fenton To Be Married
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. George W. Warch have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Warch, to Peter Low Fenton. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Fenton of Brunswick, Me.

title: Love Asserts He Lacked Means to Do Energy Job
description: DENVER, Dec. 8Last June, Gov. John A. Love took a telephone call from the White House asking him to be the Administration's energy czar. This week, forced out of his job, he returned to Denver as an outofwork lawyer, bewildered by five months in Richard M. Nixon's Washington.

title: Joan Stafford Fiancee Of Frederic S. Haynes
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. Mrs. Matthew Stafford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Ann Stafford, to Frederic Storrs Haynes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Storrs Haynes of Pound Ridge, N. Y.

title: NO ADVERSE EFFECTS FOUND IN DAY CARE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dc. 8 (AP) A pilot study by a team of University of Kentucky psychologists shows that children who attend day care centers do not differ mentally or socially from children who stay at home with their mothers.

title: Bologna: A Nothing City With Everything
description: I REMEMBERED Bologna because it it was the first place in Italy where I had ever relaxed. They were active years, the Frantic Fifties. My wife and I were discovering Europe then; we wore out a shelf of guidebooks, and ourselves, making every twokilometertothesoutheast detour, missing no church or ruin. But it seemed that little had been written about Bologna, except that there was a famous restaurant there. So it was something of a party to leave the Autostrada for no motive other than to have lunch.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICT 1 MUST CUT 60 JOBS
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker has ordered officials of the embattled Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side to eliminate about 60 school jobs because the district was exceeding its authorized budget by about $75,000 a month.

title: Coed and Grandparents Stabbed to Death Here
description: in a bedroom off the hallway. The body of Miss Bush was found in the bloodspattered hallway.

title: Bike Patrol in Richmond
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 8 (UPI)The Richmond City Police Department will reinstitute a bicycle patrol Monday for the first time since 1934. One patrolman will pedal his downtown beat of several square blocks on a 10speed bike, hoping to save gallons of fuel.

title: Dispute on Psychology School
description: NEWARKThe state is moving toward a resolution of a dispute between the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and Rutgers University over which should be selected to establish a graduate school of practical psychology.

title: Full Cold Moon
description: On the old lunar calendar that belonged to Indians and outdoorsmen, tonight's full moon was called the Cold Moon. The one last month was the Beaver Moon and the one next month was the Wolf Moon; but the December full moon was simply cold, and no adjective was needed, neither emphasis nor qualification. marked a time to stay home, tend the fire, feed the family and the livestock and prepare for the holidays. The weather couldn't be expected to improve much after Christmas and the New Year, but one could begin think about spring, though January, February and March had to be lived through to get to April.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  An ingenious, though controversial, idea swept through the Senate late last month by a 5721 vote with brief debate and little public attention. It has almost no chance of being accepted by the House and becoming law this year, but it is likely to arise again.

title: Slower Speeds Could Cut Insurance Premiums for Motorists
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8The energy crisis may mean unexpected benefits for the nation's motorists, already plagued by gasoline shortages and demands that they drive slower.

title: Sara Oltarz Is Bride Of Michael Schwartz
description: Miss Sara Oltarz and Michael Alan Schwartz, both of whom are assistant district attorneys in Kings County, were married here yesterday evening by Rabbi Abraham Vrech in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza Hotel.

title: Architecture
description: IN 1871, the Ladies' Pavilion, a 9 by 15 foot cast and wrought iron Victorian confection, was put up at Columbus Circle as a shelter for passengerspresumably ladies  waiting for horse cars. It was built from the design of Calvert Vaux, who was responsible for many of the buildings and small structures of Central Park, working in collaboration with Frederick Law Olinsted, the park's creator.

title: Small Business Finding Help
description: MONTCLAIRThe American smallbusiness owner faces a life of numerous hazardsonly one of 11 avoids financial failure. But that may change as the availability of a counseling program becomes known and small businessmen call for the help of seasoned executives, some who are former vice presidents of industrial and commercial giants.

title: Child to the Oberbecks
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 8A daughter was born on Nov. 9 to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen K. Oberbeck of Englewood at the New York University Medical Center. The child has been named Sally Morgan. Mrs. Oberbeck isthe former Miss Christina Gellhorn of Philadelphia.

title: The Good Word: But Howard Baker Is a Work of Art
description: FOR Watergate freaks there is much good wallowing to be had this season. Sources close to sources have asked us not to wallow, but alas this is like telling the crowd at a burlesque show what to feel. Wallow we must: not from malice anymore (normal spleens were stripminded months ago) or fear for the Republic (a pretty emotion more talked about than experienced) but sheer gibbering curiosity. What happened next? The trivialities of party strife are suspended when human nature goes into such an act as this.

title: Paperbacks
description: For a number of Christmases past, paperback publishers have selected titles from their back lists, put them into packages and offered them as stocking stuffers. Many parcels that were accorded warm welcomes in other years are in the stores once more. Of the new bundles being offered this Yuletide, the following are especially attractive.

title: HAWAII UTILIZES WELFARE TALENT
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 8  A statewide social program utilizing the talents of welfare recipients has proved a resounding success among underprivileged Hawaiians and foreignborn residents.

title: Tax Accountant Fees: $21,857 for 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8During the first three years of his Administration, President Nixon paid accountants $21,957 to prepare his income tax returns.

title: A Religious School Hunts Clue to Past
description: PLAINFIELDThe board of directors of the Plainfield Hebrew Institute is in a quandary of sorts. It is seeking to determine whether or not it should celebrate its 70th anniversary this year and, as a result, is searching for clues to the school's past.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: 24 In Labor Hall of Fame
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UPI)The first 24 persons have been in: ducted into the Labor International Hall of Fame, 18 of them posthumously. Those Installed included Walter Reuther, Samuel Gompers, John L. Lewis, Eleanor Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Sidney Hillman. The six living members are Paul Allen, Edward F. Carlough, M. A. Hutcheson, Joseph Kennan, A Philip Randolph and Edward R. Stahl.

title: Letters
description: Anne Roiphe's essay on The Waltons (Nov. 18) made a good many valid and interesting observations.

title: The Peace Treaty Was Signed, Americans Went Home
description: News items: On Monday, rockets and mortars blew up a third of South Vietnam's gasoline supply in an attack near Saigon. On Wednesday, the North Vietnamese seized a district capital in Quang Duc Province. Friday, the South recaptured it. What happened to peace in Vietnam?

title: TEAMSTER CHIEF MEETS PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the Teamsters Union, emerged from a meeting with President Nixon today urging patience on the part of truckers and expressing confidence that their position relative to the energy crisis will now be given due consideration by the Administration.

title: U.C.L.A. Routs S.M.U. for No. 78
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (UPI)University of California, Los Angeles, behind Bill Walton's 25 points and 16 rebounds, made it 78 victories in a row by coasting to 7760 decision over Southern Methodist tonight.

title: Janet Sheffield Halsey To Be Married Jan. 5
description: SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Dec. 8Miss Janet Sheffield Halsey, a personnel interviewer with the First National City Bank in New York, and Peter M. Sughrue of New York, a vice president of that hank, plan to be married Jan. 5 in St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in North Tarrytown.

title: Youth Sees Challenge In Space Computation
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 8A 17yearold California boy showed up at the Pioneer 10 control center here this week to get some information for a high school project.

title: Michael Avgerinos Will Marry Anne Jones, Teacher, in Greece
description: GERMANTOWN, Tenn., Dec. 8  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wiley Thomas Jones Jr. of Germantown and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne deHaven Jones, to Michael Theodore Avgerinos, son of Theodore Avgerinos of Athens and Glyfada, Greece, and the late Mrs. Avgerinos.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: GOLD MINERS'
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8Pay increases to black workers in South Africa's gold mines this month have increased the total annual African labor costs in the industry by almost $45million. The new wage rates mean that the pay of black miners has risen by about 70 per cent in the last two years.

title: ...And What About the Peeps?
description: IT'S hard to take the Supreme Court's obscenity decision seriously in this city, where peep shows jostle pornographic bookshops and every other movie house seems to be showing films with names like Lecher, XXX Adult Hits and Selected Male Shorts. Georgina Spelvin, star of the hugely popular porn epic, The Devil In Miss Jones, dominates more movie marquees than Garbo ever did.

title: Room at the top
description: Show me the manner in which a nation or a community cares for its dead, and I will measure with mathematical exactness the tender sympathies of its people, their respect for the laws of the land and their loyalty to high ideals. GLADSTONE.

title: the traveler's world
description: IXTAPA, Mexico  Last week we examined the economic and geographic reasons for Mexico's decision to construct two new multimilliondollar resort complexes, one off the Yucatan Caribbean coast called Cancun, the other Ixtapa, 150 miles northwest of Acapulco on the Pacific Coast. The question for today is how Infratur, the Government trust set up to develop and supervise the construction and operation of Cancun and Ixtapa, can lay down these vast resort areas on virgin coastlands without wreaking injury to the environment and the resident natives, and without building an ugly, monstrous resort megalopolis on each coast. The brochures promise Ixtapa will be created in intimate connection with the economic and social development of a previously undeveloped region.

title: Demarest Secession Pressed
description: TRENTON  Although the tradition of home rule is widely acknowledged to prevail in many of the political decisions in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court is considering a case that could erode the control of municipalities over their boundaries.

title: Three Girls Die in Fire
description: BISMARCK, Mo., Dec. 8 (UPI) An explosion in a flue for woodburning stove apparently caused a fire that killed three young girls left alone in a frame house here yesterday, local authorities said.

title: The Cloakroom Consensus
description: WASHINGTONNinety days, said a Congressional Republican in a Capitol Hill cloakroom. Ninety days, Gerry Ford will be President in 90 days. If minds had fingers, the Congressman's would have been crossed.

title: Badminton Skill Called Net Gain
description: MONTCLAIR  Football and basketball are great games, but most high school students would be better off learning to play badminton. That is the view of Dr. Richard W. Tews, professor of physical education at Montclair State College, who would like to see everyone out enjoying some kind of sport.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: CLIVE Barnes describes Chrissy, the gogo girl, in David Rabe's Boom Boom Room, as a neurotic tramp about whom he knows no more at the end of the play than he did at the beginning. Obviously he feels comfortable choosing a category for her, putting a label on herneurotic trampas if that says everything there is to be said about her.

title: Camera News: Collector's Show, Courses
description: COLLECTORS of antique cameras, vintage photographs and other items of photographica, as well as those interested in the technical aspects of our photographic heritage will be gathering today at the eighth semiannual SwapShopSell or Show fair which is being held from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. in the Crystal Room of the Hotel McAlpin, 34th Street and Broadway. Conducted under the auspices of the Photographic Historical Society of New York, Inc., 244 Fifth Avenue, New York 10001, the fair will contain displays from more than 50 exhibitors who have signed up to show their collections of antique cameras, ancient photographs and similar items to photographers and collectors who are interested in the history of photography and its development.

title: Films About China Slated in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRFour color documentaries in Felix Greene's film series One Man's China will have their New Jersey premiere at 8 P.M. Tuesday at the Hillside School, 54 Orange Road, Montclair.

title: President Agrees to Abide By Committee's Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The White House conceded today that there were serious questions about the legality of two separate aspects of President Nixon's recent tax returns and said that he and Mrs. Nixon might owe as much as $267,000 in additional Federal income tax if both of his original contentions were reversed.

title: You Never Heard of a Silent Opera?
description: WHY are Robert Wilson's plays called operas?

title: Cruise Ship Aground
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 8 (UPI)  The 606foot Italian cruise ship Federico C plowed into a sand bar a halfmile off Fort Lauderdale beach during a heavy fog this morning. Coast Guard said the ship's 606 passengers and 230 crewmen were in no danger.

title: A SolarOperated Home Heater For $100 Suggested by Scientists
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 8 (AP) Two scientists contend that people living in sunny areas can build their own solaroperated home heaters in half a day for $100.

title: STOPGAP OIL PLAN IS USED IN STRIKE;Union Delivers Fuel Where Needed in Westchester
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Dec. 8A weekold strike by deliverets of homeheating oil is creating increasing hardship in sections of Westchester County, but a discreetly handled stopgap plan is preventing a real emergency.

title: City Youth Board Chairman to Resign
description: Two years ago, when youthgang activity was rising throughout the city, Stuart Scheftel, chairman of the New York City Youth Board, went to the South Bronx to talk to a group of teenagers who called themselves the Black Spades.

title: Housing Stirs a Rural Town
description: MIDDLETOWN  A proposed master plan revision for this Monmouth County community that would permit multifamily units for the first time has drawn opposition from many residents, who assert it would destroy the rural character of the township.

title: ALEXANDER LEGGETT, LAWYER, BANKER, 65
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Alexander Coventry Liggett, a lawyer, banker and industrialist, died yesterday in Washington Hospital Center. He was 65 years old and lived here and in Litchfield, Conn.

title: EXSTATE PATIENTS UPSET LONG BEACH
description: LONG BEACH, L. I.In hotels and rooming houses once built for the welltodo who came to spend their vacations along the sea, hundreds of former mental patients now sit, heads sunk into their hands, oblivious to grim, often filthy surroundings.

title: Cortright Wetherill Jr. To Wed Janice Nestle
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 8The engagement of Miss Janice S. Nestle to Cortright Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wetherill Jr., of Happy Hill Farm, New Town Square, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Nestle, parents of the future bride.

title: Headliners
description: All's Well That Ends

title: A New Calm Cloaks Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Student activism at Rutgers University used to mean sitins, the seizure of buildings, teachins, fiery rallies and continual confrontations with authorities. Now, activism means community programs, tutoring sessions and volunteer help.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: 1. ON THE NIGHT OF THE SEVENTH MOON. Holt. A Victorian Gothic novel that should go down smoothly with fans of the genre.

title: Acting U.S. Attorney Known as a Tough Prosecutor
description: Edward John Boyd 5th, who was sworn in Wednesday as Acting United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, is a toughminded, unsmiling prosecutor.

title: Music
description: GOLD and FizdaleArthur Gold and Robert Fizdaleare giving a concert of music for two pianos today, and it is almost as if they are the last practitioners of a noble art. They really aren't, of course, and there are several good twopiano teams currently active. But not many. Certainly not as many as there were from the 1930's through the 1950's. Then the New York concert scene would be adorned with the annual appearances of Maier and Pattison, Brodsky and Triggs, Bartlett and Robertson. Appleton and Field, Luboshutz and Nemenoff, Vronsky and Babin, Morley and Gearhart, Whittemore and Lowe. And, naturally, Gold and Fizdale, who have been together professionally for a very long time.

title: The freezing mind behind the cold war
description: John Foster Dulles had a genius for being disliked. He was often enough personally repellent to those who agreed with him. As Eisenhower's Secretary of State he obstinately took the most extreme and provocative coldwar positions. In order to remain Secretary of State, he bravely mowed down all subordinates who angered rightwing Republicans  it was only against Eisenhower that they could make up for their defeats by Roosevelt, Truman and Dewey.

title: Schedule of Labor Talks Will Be Heavy Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) There will be a heavy schedrule of labor contract negotiations next year, covering about 5.25 million workers, up from 4.75 million this year, the Labor Department said this week.

title: Preservation Urged By Parkway Village
description: A delegation of residents from Queens's Parkway Village appeared before a public hearing of the City Planning Commission last Wednesday night in Queemboro Hall to urge the inclusion of their development in the proposal to establish Special Planned Community Preservation Districts.

title: Margaret Duffy to Wed
description: MOUNT LAUREL, N. J., Dec. 8Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Duffy have announced the engagement ?? their daughter, Miss Margaret Graham Duffy, to Edw?? Joseph Guilfoy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guilfoy of Haddenfield. A February wedding is planned.

title: State Notes Increasing Gap Between Need for Foster Care and Facilities
description: An increasing gap between the number of children who need foster care and places in the state for them to get it has been reported by the State Board of Social Welfare.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1973
description: International

title: Alaskan Pipeline Jobs Scarce, Brennan Warns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan has warned job seekers not to go to Alaska looking for work on the new oil pipeline construction project unless they have already been promised employment.

title: Brooklyn Parish Gives Thanks For Return of Gold Monstrance
description: More than 800 parishioners of the St. Peter Claver Church in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn attended special mass of thanksgiving yesterday to celebrate the return of the church's gold monstrance.

title: Gallows Tuesday
description: The last official exeoutions in the United States took place in 1967. On April 12 of that year, California sent Aaron C. Mitchell, a black, to the gas chamber; he had been convicted of killing a policeman in Sacramento in 1963. On June 2, 1967, Colorado executed Luis Jos Monge, also a convicted murderer, in the state prison gas chamber.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Not long ago, David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was shopping in a Brazilian jewelry shop and decided to make a purchase. He introduced himself to the proprietor and asked, Will you take my check?

title: A Coast Surcharge On Parking Space Delayed by E.P.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UPI)  The Federal Goverhment, faced with 60 lawsuits land a storm of criticism, has delayed for a year its plan to impose a surcharge on parking spaces in major California cities.

title: Competition Raises Price Of Coal For Utilities
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Spiraling prices, a shortage of ?? cars and frantic bidding at coal mines by competitors are some of the Droblems electric companies are continuing to encounter in trying to buy coal to fire their boilers this winter.

title: Social Announcements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Keith Hale announce the marriage of their daughter, Bryce Maryam, of San Diego, California to Mr. Warren I. Abbott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Abbott of Beverly Hills, California, formerly of Woodmere, N.Y. on November 21st 1973 at the Stephen S. Wise Temple in Bel.Air, California.

title: Pollution as FuelSaver
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) Mayor Frank Rizzo says automobile owner should be allowed to remove pollution control devices to conserve fuel. He said the devices caused city police department cars to use an extra million gallons of gasoline ah year.

title: Sports Is Slow to React in Energy Crisis
description: Arnold Palmer's private jet is grounded.

title: The Ideal of College for All
description: A college education is no logger regarded as a luxury in this country. It has come to be considered essential to economic and social success, perhaps an inalienable right, on the theory that learning makes a better person and therefore a better citizen. A degree has become not only a passport to the marketplace, hut also a credential of eligibility for participation in the best that life has to offer.

title: News of the Stage
description: Sparing a few moments between rehearsals the other day, Abe Burrows volunteered some remarks about critics in general and about his forthcoming show, Good News, in particular.

title: Queens Man Dies of Gun Wound Suffered in Capturing a Bandit
description: A 50yearold Queens man tackled and helped the police capture an armed robber in a tavern holdup late Friday night, but he suffered a gunshot wound in the struggle and died early yesterday, less than two hours after the incident.

title: Schedule of Meetings By Council This Week
description: City Council committees will hold two open meetings this week in addition to the Council's regular meeting at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow. The committee hearings scheduled are as follows:

title: A U.S.O. Reminder
description: It is the holiday season, and with that season comes memoriesmemories, for instance, of service in the armed forces and the help that used to come from the U.S.O. Times change, but the U.S.O. is still there. Its impact is still widely felt, for there is not a neighborhood in all New York that does not have young men or women in uniform today. So this holiday season, when you remember how it was in the old days, think of how it is for them today. Gifts may he sent to U.S.O., 2 Penn Plaza, New York, N. Y. 10001.

title: MRS. MICHAEL SCHIMMEL
description: Mrs. Lenore Barr Schimmel, wife of Michael Schimmel, president of a philanthropic foundation bearing his name, died yesterday at her home, 145 Central Park West. Her age was 74.

title: Wall St. Worries: Oil and Nixon
description: A Washington executive was so depressed by recent events in the nation's capital that he came to New York last week for a change of scene. During his stay, he visited several friends who are partners in Wall Street investment firms.

title: Shopping Center Planned In Brooklyn
description: The BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation  a private nonprofit organization subsidized by Federal funds, foundation funds and contributions from individuals and corporationsheld four seminars last week to familiarize the BedfordStuyvesant business community vtith details concerning its new $6million commercial shopping center, which is scheduled to open in the late spring of 1974.

title: Pedigree Cats Meet Common Cousins in L.I. Show
description: ALBERTSON, L.I.It was a catty affair. Members of the household variety were struggling for recognition while their pampered pedigree cousins viewed the scene with an aristocratic confidence.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Leave it to Julian Symons. When he writes a mystery, you can be assured that this urbane stylist, this master of the traditional detective story, will have a puzzler that will keep your mind racing. And so it is with THE PLOT AGAINST ROGER RIDER (Harper & Row, $5.95). Even the title is comfortably traditional. But unlike such veterans as Agatha Christie, there is nothing oldfashioned about Symons. His dialogue is crisp and modern. He is capable of wry humor without becoming heavyhanded about it. And his characters have life in them.

title: TroilusPahn Me for Pointing
description: SHAKESPEARE'S Troilus and Cressida is an extraordinarily difficult play, but there is no point in making it impossible.

title: Penn Central to Add Cars
description: The Penn Central said yesterday that it would add an average of one coach per train next Sunday to accommodate travelers who switch to trains to conserve gasoline. Most trains will have four coaches.

title: What we don't know about sex will fill an encyclopedia
description: One reads this elaborate, Freudhaunted apology for patriarchy with a depressing sense of dj vu. Whether men invent a mythology that makes women superior or inferior, the end result is likely to be the samewomen belong in the home.

title: JOHN A. GUIDERA
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 8 John A. Guidera, a principal in Goodman & Guidera, building contractors of Fort Lee, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 350 Lewelyn Circle.

title: Movies
description: HERE is a set of facts that has come out of the Supreme Court decisions on pornography. If a solution is to be found for our current dilemma, we must deal in facts, not fantasy.

title: Chess: Young Players Getting Chance To Be International Masters
description: The Chicago International Tournament going on at the LaSalle Hotel has been sponsored by the United States Chess Federation in cooperation with the Chicago Chess Club to give some of America's promising young players a crack at the international master rank.

title: CITY BALLET ENDS STRIKE OF 25 DAYS
description: The 25dayold strike of dancers of the New York City Ballet ended yesterday after management agreed to a wage increase of 13.3 per cent and fringe benefits of 1 per cent.

title: New Ways to Teach Biology to the Blind
description: BRANCHBURG  It was more than a week after the beginning of classes this fall at Somerset County College that Dr. Jo Anne Whitaker discovered that one of the students in Biology I was blind.

title: Governor Gets Offers in Spirit of '76
description: Governor Rockefeller has for a Presidential campaign, been receiving offers of help but he has politely rejected. them.

title: Cars Barred, Pope Rides In Carriage
description: ROME, Dec. 8Pope Paul VI was driven in an open carriage drawn by a white horse for three miles from the Vatican to the center of Rome and back this afternoon for his devotion to the Virgin Mary in the Spanish Square on the Roman Catholic Feast day of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Mrs. Hocker Is Remarried
description: KATONAH, N. Y., Dec. 8Mrs. Jill Sherwin Hocker of Katonah and Yarmouth, Me., and Millard Hamilton Moore of Bedford were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Lee Fairchild of the Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Everett Edward Sherwin.

title: William Simon: The First Real Energy Czar
description: WASHINGTON  William E. Simon, named by President Nixon last week as the first real boss of the Government's energy program, is one of those individuals born with a need for little sleep. He was also born with a quick mind and he has acquired the ability required of good executives to make decisions rapidly. All these things will help in his new job, but all of them will not solve the oil and energy problem, at least in the short run.

title: 7 ARE APPOINTED NIEMAN SELECTORS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8 (UPI)Three journalists, a former president of Radcliffe College and three officers of Harvard University have been named to a committee to select Nieman Fellows in journalism for the 197475 academic year.

title: Concert: Five Cantors
description: A gala concert by the Cantica Hebraica Chamber Chorus and Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night was both a benefit for the International Jewish Music Library and an impressive testimonial to the fourcentury scope of its archives.

title: Governor of Maine Calls for Reduction In Snowmobile Use
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 8Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis has assured recreational users of snowmobiles that he has no plans to ban their activity in the state.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Rough1y, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Lonely poet, mellow poet
description: Many of the poems in John Logan's The Anonymous Lover attempt to make a fiftyish American man who has been much ravaged by his experience appear blithe, gutsy and free. The lover of the title is still thinking that he is having a glamorous life, after the usual run of disappointments in an early romantic marriage, the divorce, the alienated children, the effort to make it with younger women, the bouts with alcohol, the empty visits to remembered places and the decent of chronic illness over his life. There is a better reason for him to think himself anonymous: the suggestion of no identity expresses a life that appears adrift and meaningless even to the poet, despite all his efforts to glamorize it.

title: U.S. Drops a Plan That Posed Threat to BlackFooted Ferret
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The United States Torest Service decided against implementing program of prairie dog control through the use of poison. The program might have had the effect of eliminating the already critically endangered blackfooted ferret.

title: Always on the Run
description: For those who refused to believe it last year, the Miami Dolphins are proving again that they are an extraordinary football team. They are also an extraordinarily interesting group of young men, who somehow seem to reflect the whole of society around them. Bob Griese, blondhaired and blueeyed, is Mr. Middle America. Norm Evans and Tim Foley are the religionists. Marlin Briscoe and Henry Stuckey are the wayouts. Nick Buoniconti is the tough kid from the wrong side of the tracks who had to fight for everything he ever got. But the freshest, liveliest, most interesting duet in the whole aggregation is the young rebelsLarry Csonka and Klick.

title: Official of S.B.A. Denies Accusations Against His Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) An official of the Small Business Administration said today that contentions that the agency was corrupt and mismanaged were untrue.

title: Detente: Giving in to a Necessary Virtue
description: WASHINGTONDtente was, in a sense, what the world had been waiting for. A slacking of strained relations, as between the nations of the United States and the Soviet Union. In an interview a few weeks ago the Democratic Majority Leader of the Senate, Mike Mansfield, said: In the nuclear age, there no alternative to dtente.

title: Manhattan Wins Indoor Track Meet
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 8 Manhattan College, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, defeated Connecticut and Massachusetts in an indoor track. meet today.

title: Joan Donovan Engaged
description: EXETER, N. H., Dec. 8Mrs. James F. Donovan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Elizabeth Donovan, to John Albert Caldwell, son of Mrs. J. Albert Caldwell of Baltimore and the late Mr. Caldwell. Miss Donovan, daughter also of the late Mr. Donovan, is marketing director with AppletonCenturyCrofts, publishers in New York. Her fiance is president of Bodine & Associates, Inc., publishers in New York.

title: Delay Pays $3.60 to Win At Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 8Delay, a 5  year  old gelding owned by Mrs. William Coxe Wright, and ridden by Javier Canessa, won the $27,475 Congressional Handicap at Laurel race course today. It was the seventh time Canessa rode Delay to victory in 17 starts this year.

title: College Given $500,000
description: A grant of $500,000 for the music department of Smith College has been made by J. Irwin Miller, chairman of the board of the Cummins Engine Company, and Mrs. Robert Tangeman, his sister. The college in Northampton, Mass., said that the granta memorial to the donors' aunt, Elsie I. Sweeney of Columbus, Ind., would underwrite purchases and maintenance of musical instruments.

title: Housing Projects Break Mold
description: The stark, uniform design characteristics of the city's lowincome housing projects have given way to architectural styles and amenities traditionally reserved for middleincome and luxury housing.

title: Best at Philadelphia Goes To West Highland White
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8A saucy West Highland white terrier, Ch. Braidholm White Tornado of Binate, owned by Mr. and Mrs. George Seeman, was named best of 3,566 dogs tonight at the 79th show of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia in the Exhibition Hall of the Civic Center.

title: Cuba Reorganizes Army Ranks In Line With Other Countries'
description: HAVANA, Dec. 8 (Reuters) Premier. Fidel Castro has given new insignias to the Cuban Army's top officers after a reorganization of its rank system along the lines of most other countries' armies.

title: Mine Union Convention Action Lags Behind Schedule as Miller's New Democratic Procedures Slow Work
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8All right, brothers, let's have a little order here, says Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine, Workers, tapping gently with his gavel and leaning down to get a ruling from a parliamentarian, on loan from the United Automobile Workers.

title: Soviet Ship Rescues 39
description: BREST, France, Dec. 8 (AP)A Soviet vessel today took aboard the 39 man crew of a Rumanian freighter that was listing sharply at the mouth of the English Channel in heavy seas and high winds.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Fordham Rams meet the Columbia Lions and the Manhattan Jaspers take on the Rhode Island Rams in a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden Thursday night beginning at 7. The Jaspers, who led the nation in rebounding last season, lost only two lettermen and will make heavy use of Bill Champion, their 6foot10inch, 230pound center.

title: Mrs. Pollack Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael Pollack of Brooklyn on Nov. 21 in the Brooklyn Hospital. Mrs. Pollack is the former Miss Terri Levine of West Hartford, Conn. The child, the couple's second son, is named Judah Avrum. His father is a lawyer.

title: AntiNixon Drive Gaining
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP)Twenty organizations working for the removal of President Nixon have been formed in New York State's 39 Congressional districts, according to Norman Siegal, a New York Civil Liberties Union official. On Thursday, he told a group forming the 28th Congressional District Committee for Impeachment Thursday, that impeachment is a tested American practice.

title: Carol Handelman Bride
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8Miss Carol Handelman, daughter of Mrs. Myer Handelman of Attleboro and the late Mr. Handelman, was married here tonight to Charles Mark Smoler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Smoler of Harrison, N, Y. Rabbi Phillip Kaplan performed the ceremony at the Colonnade Hotel.

title: Aren't 20 Million People a Public?
description: THIS will be a polemic. Not only has ABC canceled my favorite new program, Adam's Rib, but they have given the knife in Dick Cavett's back another, maybe fatal, twist: He will be allowed on the air just twice a month. I am trying to imagine what's inside the heads of the people who make these decisions. How do their brains work? Sir Charles Sherrington, the English physiologist, described the brain as an enchanted loom where million of flashing shuttles weave a dissolving pattern. Not on Sixth Avenue, where the giant networks live, On Sixth Avenue, the brain is more like the answer to a child's riddle. Question: What's yellow, creamy, sweet and very dangerous? Answer: Sharkinfested custard.

title: A matter of watts and volts
description: You can't sit on it, walk on it, sprawl on it. You can't even touch it. It is the most magicaland most neglectedelement in room design. Lighting. Most homes are lighted like offices, says lighting designer Ralph Bisdale. Architects know only two fixturesfluorescent panels and downlights. What does he have to add? Designed light. He believes a room should change color and atmosphere according to the occupant's whim, and the flick of a switch or two, he says, is all that will be needed to switch mood, function and appearance in the room of the future (or even the present, for the daring). A workaday studio can become a dramatic setting for parties. A dingy, sunless room can become a wideopen space full of greenery nourished by grow lights. His lighting concepts promise a new light futureif the current holds out.

title: Home Improvement
description: USING common, readily available tools and simple, easilylearned techniques, any home handyman or handy woman can make many needed repairs to damaged pieces of furniture themselves.

title: EGYPTIAN WARNS ON PEACE PARLEY
description: CAIRO, Dec. 8 (Reuters)Deputy Premier Abdel Kader Hatem told the Parliament today that Egypt would take part in the Geneva peace conference but would continue to watch for any possible Israeli attack.

title: Schooling Mapped For the Gifted Child
description: TRENTON  More than 100 school districts are exploring ways to establish special academic programs for gifted children in elementary schools.

title: Plans to Develop The Astor Estate At Critical Point In Upstate Town
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y.Ferncliff. The name calls up visions of baronial life and unspoiled nature. For the river people here, it identified for more than a century the bucolic estate overlooking the Hudson that the Astor family owned until 1964. Now, however, is the field of a kind of battle new to this quiet town of 5,700 people about a hundred miles north of New York City.

title: InventorTycoon, 76, Still Seeks New Worlds
description: MILLBURNLike countless other toplevel New Jersey business executives, Joseph J. Mascuch devotes 12 or more hours a day to his job. He is president of Breeze Corporations, Inc., whose sales last year were $24.5million from the manufacture and marketing of missilelaunchers, cargopersonnel winches for helicopters and conventional aircraft, giant cranes for the shipping industry and other equipment.

title: Teams in N. F. L. Contention Face Tiebreaker Contortions
description: If you thought the Big Ten had a strange method for picking its Rose Bowl representative, wait until you see how the National Football League may wind up choosing its N.F.C. Eastern Division champion.

title: New Atlas Traces Jerusalem's Cultures
description: Jerusalem, the great and golden city that is holy to three monotheistic religions Christianity, Islam and Judaismhas now been conquered by the cartographers.

title: Kissinger On the Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Secretary of State Kissinger, who lost twelve members of his own family in Nazi concentration camps, now finds himself in the painful position of trying to persuade Israel and friends of Israel in this country that any lasting peace in the Middle East depends on fundamental changes in Jerusalem's policy.

title: ILLINOIS G.O.P. HAS SENATE CANDIDATE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8After a twomonth search, Illinois Republicans finally had a candidate this week to run against Senator Adlal E. Stevenson 3d next fall.

title: Merciful Disguises
description: Mona Van Duyn's poems in Merciful Disguises, a fine gathering of three decades' work, are comedies of definition. Though she often stands before us in her skin of need, she is not a confessional poet fingering her emotional sores, for even when she writes about mental illness, the whole monstrous ferny land of my nerves, she keeps the delicate propriety of distance. Selfexposure rhymes with a ceremonious selfenclosure. A bravura actress, she takes from her verbal trunk the merciful disguises of metaphor and plays a repertoire of roleswife, godmother, recluse, Leda, poet, counseling friend, the outlandish agon of love and loss with a touch of tart malice and the quiet penetration of a Missouri Molire.

title: Folk Art at Show in Newark
description: NEWARK  The folkart exhibition that opened at the Newark Museum last Tuesday is a festive occasion, the kind of event that should delight both museum regulars and others.

title: Bridge
description: Individual reaction to disaster is an area that can be effectively studied within the microcosm of the bridgetable.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Allied Stores Marketing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Allied Stores Corporation, the nation's second largest department store chain, has leased the 13th, 16th and 17th floors and portions of the 14th and 15th floors at 1120 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Crabiel Seeking A Unified Party
description: TRENTON  The Senate Democratic minority leader, J. Edward Crabiel, who was nominated by Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne last week to be Secretary of State, is expected to become an influential leader of the new Democratic administration.

title: Suffolk Seeks Rise In L.I.R.R. Freight
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.If Suffolk County is to continue to grow industrially and if its industries are to continue to generate income and employment, freight service on the Long Island Rail Road must be improved and expanded, according to a study prepared for the county administration.

title: Is O'Neill a Character in Iceman'?
description: ONE of the most subjective playwrights who ever lived, Eugene O'Neill drew his own picture, with varying insight and fidelity, many times in his plays. In nearly all instances his selfportraiture Is easily recognizedthe Poet in Fog, the newspaperman in The Straw, the playwrighthusband in Welded, the failed artist in The Great God Brown, the selftortured skeptic in Days Without End, and of course the younger son in his unsparing family study, Long Day's Journey Into Night. There is, however, an important exception, a revealing portrait that has been universally overlooked, in The Iceman Cometh, which opens in revival Thursday.

title: NYE HALTS PLAN TO AID VETERANS
description: New York University has withdrawn $20,000 in annual scholarship funds for veterans of the war in Vietnam after only four people applied and only two enrolled in the first term that the funds were available.

title: Pentagon Says Employers Back National Guard Duty
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Pentagon says that companies employing 50 per cent of the 82 million working people in the country have now promised that their employes will not lose out on vacation time or promotion opportunities by membership in the National Guard or Reserves.

title: Puerto Rico's Governor Gives His Views on Problems Here
description: Puerto Rico's Gov. Rafael Hernandez Coln last week expressed his administration's concern for problems of the Puerto Rican community here, which he summed up as education, housing, jobs.

title: Back to Cambodia
description: The vote was a little too close to be heralded as triumph of statesmanship, but the outcome saved the United Nations General Assembly from blundering into a destructive and dangerous precedent. By 53 to 50, with 21 abstentions, the Assembly deferred a Chineseled move to unseat the representatives of Cambodian President Lon Nol and substitute the willo'thewisp exile regime of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: JERSEY MAN HOLDS TITLEBRIDGE LEAD
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 8Leading the field into the final session of the American Contract Bridge League's niixedpair championship here tonight were Bernard Chazen of Fort Lee, N. J., and Marilyn Johnson of Houston.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayFour Seasons Farm, Merest Road, Readington, N. J. Maiden, novice and limit open handicap working hunters; special and juvenile jumpers. 8:30 A.M.

title: White Plains Is Tough
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.In certain circles, William H. Bruder is considered unreasonable, inflexible and unfair. As the White Plains Commissioner of Public Works, he enforces what are widely agreed to be the toughest homebuilding standards in Westchester County.

title: Photography
description: EVERYONE knows Dorothea Lange's classic FSA photographs of poverty in rural America. Here now, In To A Cabin (Grossman, $15) is a new book of photographs, mostly hers, with a very different theme.

title: BRITONS AND DANES COOL ON MARKETS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8  A poll published this week by the Common Market confirms a fact already indicated by national opinion surveys: people in Britain and Denmark are much less proCommon Market than those in the other seven Community members.

title: Clemente Plaza Under Way
description: Ground was broken in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last week for a 532family apartment development that neighborhood leaders say they hope Will not only reflect, but will also help to preserve, the area's ethnic and racial diversity.

title: Nixon Paid $12,783 Fee For Appraisal of Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Records released today by the White House show that President. Nixon paid $12,783.24 to a Chicago rare hooks expert to appraise his VicePresidential papers.

title: Islanders Lose to Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 8 (UPI)  Jacques Lemaire scored two secondperiod powerplay goals tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to victory over the New York Islanders, 31.

title: The American University
description: This dense and often difficult volume aims at being both an empirical study of the American universityincluding an explanation of its convulsions in the 1960'sand a theoretical contribution to our understanding of the modern world through analysis of the higher education complex, which Parsons and Platt hold to be the most critical single feature of the developing structure of modern societies. The university is our institutionalization of the third great modern revolution, the educational, following on the industrial and the democratic; it is treated here fundamentally as a social structure specializing in implementing the cultural patterns of cognitive rationality. This entails a massive deployment of the full Parsonian panoply of general system of action

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sid Luckman sent George McAfee in a probing thrust up the middle for a couple of yards on the first play from scrimmage and learned precisely what he wanted to know. The Washington Redskins were using the identical defensive alignment that they had used three weeks earlier in defeating these same Chicago Bears, 73, in a bruising, disputatious game of violent intensity.

title: Manhattan Tops Rutgers For First Victory, 8778
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 8There was no trouble from militant black students tonight in the Rutgers gymnasium, but there was a taut basketball game between Rutgers and Manhattan that was not settled until the final four minutes.

title: Tables in Coast Restaurant Have Rather Unusual Legs
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) Some 180 legs a la Betty Grable hold up tables in a restaurant here.

title: Elyse Foster Fiancee Of Charles Safran 2d
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 8 Miss Elyse Foster, a student at the TuftsNew England Medical Center in Boston, and Charles Safran 2d, a graduate student in mathematics at Tufts, plan to be married in July.

title: LAKE NEAR MANILA IS BEING REVIVED
description: MANILA, Dec. 8Laguna de ray, one of the largest lakes in Southeast Asia, is ailing, and an ambitious program to revive it is getting under way.

title: State Park Aide Appointed
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8 (UPI)William A. White of New York City, deputy regional director of the United States Office of Economic Opportunity, has been named to the State Park and Recreation Commission for New York City, Governor Rockefeller announced. Mr. White succeeds Kenneth N. Sherwood of Queens, whose term expired. The post is unsalaried.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: MANY of the major economic problems that will confront the nation next year are coming into clearer focus with each passing day, but the solutionsor the feasible antidotesare less discernible.

title: Hinterseer Triumphs In Slalom
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 8 (UPI)Hans (Hansi) Hinterseer of Austria won the men's giant slalom today and put his country further ahead at the opening of the new World Cup skiracing season.

title: Supermarkets For Toys Get a Big Play
description: Here's the scene: 250 different games, 200 kinds of dolls, 100 varieties of bicycles and tricycles and thousands of toys are stacked throughout the store, Women push shopping carts down the wide aisles, accompanied by screaming and pointing children, pulling items off the shelves. Harried clerks at central checkout counters tally the prices and wrap the goods.

title: Explanation of Difference in Figures
Maimonides Requiring Doctors To Give $500 to Be Retained
description: In an unprecedented move, the medical staff at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn has voted to require a $500 contribution to the hospital from every member as a prerequisite for reappointment.

title: The good old days
description: Children are naturally immune to nostalgia; the summer of '42 has accumulated no special interest in their private memory banks. And so, any stories about the old wooden ice house of 1908, or snowdrifts as high as the telephone wires during a winter on the prairie in the 1930's, had better be engaging indeed to win favor from an audience as yet unmoved by remembrances of things past.

title: Wallace Is Said to Plan 3dTerm Race
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 8 (A.P.)Gov. George C. Wallace has decided to run for an unprecedented third term as Governor. He has told friends he plans an active campaign next year despite the paralysis caused by a 1972 assassination attempt.

title: Susan Herbert Wed To William H. Kyle
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 8Miss Susan Pembroke Herbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Herbert of North Caldwell and Green Pond, was married at noon today to William Howard Kyle, son of Mrs. Howard 3. Kyle of Saugus, Mass., and the late Mr. Kyle.

title: News Summary and Index
Joel Claster, 82, Headed Luria Brothers, Scrap Iron
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 Joel Claster, retired board chairman of Luria Brothers, dealers in scrap iron and steel, died today at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania here. He was 82 years old.

title: Safer Ski Equipment Becomes a Theme of Industry
description: Aware that injured skiers make poor advertisements for the sport, officials of Ski Industries America are fostering a Safety in Action program. It is designed to keep skiers healthy by making certain their equipment is safe. The trade association's project is muchneeded, particularly since legions of recreational skiers go into ski shops ignorant about the equipment best suited for them. They usually make purchases merely on the shopkeeper's sayso.

title: Alabama Sets Practice
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 8 (AP)Topranked Alabama will begin formal practice Dec. 21 for its New Year's Eve Sugar Bowl date with Notre Dame, Coach Paul Bryant said today. Bryant said the team would fly to New Orleans Dec. 29.

title: To Light a Candle
description: Christmas decorations in this great city are somewhat subdued this year because of the energy crisis. Nevertheless, Fifth Avenue and New York's other principal shopping centers still glitter with allurements for Americans who, in the eyes of most of mankind, already have everything.

title: RESIDENTS ADVISE CITY ON HOUSING
description: The City Planning Commission was told last week that the only way to preserve stillviable residential neighborhoods was to let the residents themselves decide how to do the job and then give them the power and the money to carry out their plans.

title: More than a book about guns
description: Guns kill 20,000 Americans each year. But consider the bright side. That's less than one death per year for every 10,000 guni in private ownershipa small price to pay for such an important privilege. Moreover, as Robert Sherrill says in The Saturday Night Special, we should be candid with ourselves: Gun victims are rarely middleclass folks; they are the refuse (he puts it bluntly) of our trashy society, mostly criminals or people who wouldn't have come to much anyway. Highway accidents, by contrast, cause three times as many fatalities, and wayward automobilesunlike bullets  are wickedly egalitarian. May we not, all things considered, fairly ask ourselves if the typical victim of cannot be spared?

title: POVERTY IS ISSUE IN CARACAS RACE
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 8 The two leading opposition candidates in tomorrow's presidential election charged today that while Venezuela had grown richer from rising oil revenues, most of the people had become poorer.

title: Ultimate Issue Remains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8By releasing his personal financial records today, President Nixon sought, as he himself said, to put to rest most of the questions outstanding in the public mind about his business affairs. But neither the President, nor his battery of lawyers and accountants can answer the ultimate question: Will this latest Presidential iniative head off impeachment or resignation, or will it fall short? The answer to that lies with the American people, and their reis less than certain.

title: Daughter to the Shers
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Roger Evan Sher of Larchmont, N. Y., on Nov. 21 at the New York University Medical Center. Mrs. Sher is the former Miss Joan Lear of New London, Conn. Mr. Sher is a member of Satterlee & Stephens, law firm here. The child, the couple's third, has been named Abigail Judith.

title: The Question Posed by the Shockley Dispute:
description: When Dr. William B. Shockley of Stanford pressed on last week with his controversial contention that the poor showing of black children on intelligence tests is rooted more in heredity than social deprivation, he showed his Princeton audience a chart to demonstrate the asserted gap in intellectual capacity between black and Jewish youngsters. It was based on a decadeold study that traced patterns of mental development in children from various backgrounds in New York City and Boston schools.

title: Twixt Wins Handicap at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8Racing to the lead from the outside at the top of the stretch, Mrs. John M. Franklin's Twixt went on to score a twolength victory in the fifth running of the $28,200 Poquessing Handicap at Liberty Bell Park today.

title: where women Are an Annoyance That Disturbs the Symmetry of Life
description: I HAVE an acquaintance in New York Citya liberated American womanwho recently cut hr hair very short because, she explained, long hair is too attractive to men. The American male is a sexual imperialist, in her view, and she intends to keep him up against the wall from now on. This young woman is very eloquent, along the lines of current feminist dogma, when she explains the kitchenandfamily slavery of American women and speaks of how women are nothing hut sex objects for American men and how, ultimately, male oppression is somehow akin to the bombing of defenseless Vietnamese villages. She has harsh words for any male who refuses to see that American women are de slaves.

title: Contributions for 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) In addition to a writeoff for contributing his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives, President and Mrs. Nixon listed the following other deductible contributions on their tax returns:

title: Cole Porter: His Songs Defined a Decade
description: COLE PORTER is one of those names that, all by itself, can conjure up the flavor of a particular view of life. For one thing, no other major American songwriter fits so neatly into a single time slot. Irving Berlin's music, decade by decade, gave voice to the changing moods of the first half of the 20th century; you could almost devise a social history of America by using his songs as a framework. Jerome Kern covered almost the same period. George Gershwin moved from the age of Swanee to that of Summertime. Richard Rodgers wrote songs that epitomize the lighthearted twenties and also the earnest forties and fifties.

title: A lonely young man
description: The eerie feeling one gets on reading this, sad, selflacerating journal of a lonely young man's cockroach's existence in a New York room, is that if he had not killed himself no publisher would have touched his book with a bargepole. Publication might have saved him. He felt he was a failure. An early entry goes: Today for the first time in my life I smelled gas. For suicide. It does not smell bad. But in a world that hankers for proof of the truly tragic, only death convinces us of sincerity: we are willing to find magic in an obituary while we deny it to a life. That logic is made explicit in Thomas Hardy's story, The Withered Arm, where a hangman's rope is sold in Dorchester the inch.

title: Werblin High on Track Plan
description: There's Mr. Werblin now, the maitre d in the fashionable East Side cafe said, moving forward with a greeting.

title: Two Groups Open Appeal To Assist Chilean Refugees
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters)A $120,000 appeal to help students and other academic refugees from Chile has been started by two Londonbased aid organizations.

title: TRANSIT STRIKE JARS PITTSBURGH
description: PITTSBURGH Dec. 8More than 330,000 daily bus and trolley commuters were without public transportation in Pittsburgh and Alleghany County this week because of a strike of transit operators.

title: Elderly Relive 1913 For Hofstra Students
description: HEMPSTEAD, E. I.  A group of 104 elderly persons from housing developments in Wantagh and Port Washington reminisced about the past recently for the benefit of some 60 art students and faculty members at Hofstra University.

title: New Concrete Barrier Reduces Accidents Along the L.I.E.
description: A moment of drowsiness or a pause to light a cigarette can be fatal distractions for motorists on the Long Island Expressway.

title: The End of the Cowboy Economy
description: The United States has built its prosperity on a foundation of ample and lowcost energy. So when the longsimmering energy crisis finally erupted, many Americans understandably reacted with fear and alarm. But as bad as this winter's fuel crunch may be, the energy crisis may prove something of a blessing, too. For it will force the nation to make some highly desirable changes over the next decade or two.

title: Caroline C. Herrick Betrothed To Prof. Robert R. Glauber
description: SHARON, Conn., Dec. 8Mr. and Mrs. William Worthington Herrick Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Coates Herrick, an editorial assistant with the New Yorker magazine, to Prof. Robert R. Glauher, who teaches investment management at Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Abrams Criticizes Sunday Fare Plan As Only Tiptoeing
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, toting sixfootwide cardboard subway token he said would probably have to be used if fares kept rising and tokens got larger, yesterday termed the experimental halffareonSunday plan inadequate.

title: CANADIAN FINANCIER ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: ST. JOHNS, Nfld., Dec. (AP)John C. Doyle, a Montreal financier, was formally charged in court here today with fraud and breach of trust. Magistrate Hugh O'Neil ordered Mr. Doyle held until Tuesday, when a bail ruling will be issued.

title: Raiders Rout Chiefs, 377
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 8  The Oakland Raiders took a firm grip on their division championship and a playoff berth today by crushing the Kansas City Chiefs, 377, in the nexttolast game of their regular schedule.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Notice on Prisoners Sought
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)Representative Bernard Wilber, Republican of Barnstable, has filed a bill to require prison officials to notify the police at least 24 hours in advance when a prisoner from their area is to be released on furlough.

title: Miss von Bvecklin Wed Here to Bruce Korson
description: Miss Jeanne von Boecklin, daughter of Mrs. John Hall Allen of New York and Glen Cove, L. I., and Rupprecht von Boecklin of Blairstown, N. J., was married here last evening to Bruce Andrew Korson of New York, son of Mrs. Max Korson of New York and Miami and the late Mr. Korson.
