title: Suit Withdrawn On Michigan Plea
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP)A lastditch effort by University of Michigan fans to send the Wolverines football team to the Rose Bowl has failed.

title: Cyrus Peck Home Is Razed in Newark
description: NEWARKThe 119yearold Cyrus Peck Homestead, once the proud residence of a family responsible for the development of railroads in this area and the Essex County park system, has fallen victim to the city's need for housing.

title: County Growth: Boom by '80
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  In the next seven years New Jersey is expected to divorce itself even more from the New York City and Philadelphia spheres of influence and to experience an advanced stage of suburban growth.

title: Firewood Sales Draw Complaints on Measures
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 Increased use of cordwood for fireplaces during the fuel shortage has resulted in complaints from homeowners who have purchased firewood by measurements not considered legal, an official said,

title: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO LIFT SUBPOENAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) A Federal judge has refused to throw out subpoenas requiring President Nixon's former personal attorney Herbert Kalmbach and his close friend C. B. Reborn to give testimony in a civil suit.

title: ARGENTINE FLOOD LASTS 6 MONTHS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 (UPI) Timothy Mulcahy watched his ranch foreman float by on a sailequipped raft over what used to be his pastureland and reminisced about last winter's flood, which looks as if it will never go away.

title: Sharon Zick Plans Bridal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8John W. Zick, partner in charge of the New York office of the certified public accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Co., and Mrs. Zick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Lee Zick, to Brian louis Rieger, son of Louis E. Rieger, board chairman of the Old Orchard Bank in Glenview, Ill., and Mrs. Rieger.

title: KISSINGER URGES NEW NATO VISION
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight for a crucial meeting with America's European allies and said that a new act of vision was needed to preserve the alliance's strength.

title: Down on the Fish Farm
description: For some people, the salmon run in early June rouses the sporting blood of an angler. For others, it's all in the day's work.

title: A Bit of France in Sunnyside, Queens
description: Late last Sunday morning, Marcel Perise sauntered into the corner patisserie for some croissants, those buttery, flaky delights few Frenchmen omit from Sunday breakfast. His eyes skimmed over the neat rows of breads and cakes, and then focused on the display case crammed with napoleons and glazed eclairs.

title: Questions on the Estates Unsettled by Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8President Nixon, in today's statement on his personal finances, said he hoped to dispel the myth that improvements on his private estate at San Clemente, Calif., paid for by the Government, have vastly enriched me personally.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of reports United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Middleclass premier find
description: HOUSTON. On Nov. 7, the moon and the planets of Venus, Pluto and Saturn were at right angles, forming what astrologers call the Grand Cross, with Pluto, representing upheaval, in opposition to Saturn, representing stability. The Grand Cross is like a block of pentup energy, a source of avataric power, astrologer Richard Greer explained. The tailed Kohoutek comet flickered over Houston, announcing, Geer said, ego death and other momentous changes in human consciousness. On Nov. 8, Aquarius rose, which meant the dawn of the Aquarian age in the West. On Nov. 10, Mercury, the planet of the mind, crossed the equator of the sun, which it does every 13 years. This is the very message of Guru Maharaj ji, Geer said, the mind being gobbled up by the basic life force. He couldn't have better time. While these auspicious astrological configurations formed in the heavens, a threeday festival called Millennium '73 and billed as the most significant event in the history of humanity was taking place in the Houston Astrodome. The Astroturf was covered with red carpeting, and the carpeting was covered with thousands of blissedout followers of the perfect master, Guru Maharaj ji, who will be 16 tomorrow. At one end of the Astrodome, where the goal posts are placed for football games, and extending to the 23yard line, stood an enormous white plastic stage lit from the inside and divided into seven fernfringed segments, sprinkled with artificial ponds of cellulose acetate over aluminum foil. One segment was a stage area for plays and dances. Another was a stand for Blue Aquarius, a 56piece band led by the guru's hulking, coweyed brother, 20yearold Bhole ji. On a higher, platform sat 24 of the guru's 2,000 mahatmas, or close disciples, all but one of whom are Indian. On the highest platform sat the holy family. The guru's mother, Mata ji, and his two other brothers, 23yearold Bal Bhagwan ji and 18yearold Raja ji, were on orange thrones. Three steps up, 300 feet off the ground, sat the guru, as motionless as an ivory Buddha, on a blue velveteen throne with a circular blue Plexiglas back framing his head like a halo. A 14foot white Plexiglas flame, symbol of his pure fire, rose behind him, and a cathoderay tube projected rainbows on 60foot curtain that hung saillike over his head.

title: Bullish Baseball Week Closes
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8Baseball survived its encounter with the energy crisis and Charles. O. Finley this week. But the sport's annual business convention closed with strongly mixed feelings about the 55 playersand one franchisethat were traded in the busiest bull market in history.

title: The Eyes of Texas Are Upon `Figaro
description: THE eyes and ears of Texas are upon a brash young man named Figaro who is busily running around the state getting married. Late last month, the peripatetic hero of The Marriage of Figaro simultaneously tied the knot on opera stages in Houston and Dalias. Coming up yet are nuptials in Fort Worth and San Antonio.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gibson Asks Port Authority Seat

title: NEGRO WOMEN ACT ON ENERGY CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Fearing that disadvantaged and poor people will become the greatest victims of the energy crisis, the National Council of Negro Women, Inc., which represents 25 black wornen's groups, has called for the formation of a national monitoring group to protect the interest of such people.

title: Banker Weds Jane C. Leary
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation here yesterday, Miss Jane Cooke Leary, an investment officer with the United States Trust Company of New York, was married to Bruce William Schnitzer, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The Rev. Jan A. Maas performed the Ceremony.

title: Loan to Save Venice Proves Elusive
description: ROME, Dec. 8  The puzzle of an elusive international $500million loan to save Venice is stirring a furor in Italy.

title: NEW JOB WEIGHED FOR NEXT PIONEER
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 8Flushed with the success of Pioneer 10's flyby of Jupiter, space agency officials are now almost sure to aim Pioneer 11 so that it will reach reach beyond Jupiter for the first closeup exploration of Saturn.

title: CITIES ASK FUNDS, ASSAILING CENSUS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 7The National League of Cities, which represents some 15,000 municipalities in the United States, has asked Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz to provide additional Federal revenue sharing funds to cities because of an undercount of blacks in the 1970 census.

title: SISTER MAJELLA, 73, AN EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: Sister Majella O'Brien, the former Margaret O'Brien, Provincial Eastern American Province of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary from 1960 to 1966, died yesterday in the St. Catherine of Alexandria Convent in Brooklyn Her age was 73.

title: The Nation
description: Campaign Reform Comes in Second One More Time

title: Networks, N.F.L. Blaming Congress
description: The National Football League and two television networks, Columbia and National, last week responded to the many complaints each has received regarding the new policies on televised games this season. The complaints have had variety but the responses had a common theme  don't blame us, blame the Congress that effected those changes with its sudden antiblackout legislation just before the season began.

title: Cappelletti, Paterno Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) Penn State's Heisman Trophy winner, John Cappelletti, was named college back of the year and his coach, Joe Paterno, was selected college coach of the year today by the Washington Touchdown Club. They will be honored at the club's 29th annual dinner on Jan, 19.

title: Soviet Widens Its Charges Of Chinese Expansionism
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8The Soviet Union has broadened its campaign to discredit China in the Third World by accusing Peking of new provocations against such smaller neighbors as Bangladesh, Burma, Malaysia, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

title: Nutcracker Due At the Paper Mill
description: MILLBURN  The New Jersey Ballet Company will present Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker for 17 performances here at the Paper Mill Playhouse beginning Wednesday.

title: Borough Culture Center Major Aim of Manes
description: This time, said Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, we don't want to make the mistake of the World's Fair.

title: The World
description: The issues change little from year to year, and so the talks that begin tomorrow in Brussels among the ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will have a strong feeling of ithappenseverywinter. But if the questions of United States troop strength in Europe and the nature of NATO strategy are, for all their seriousness, oldhat, there are at least two issues that are not, and they will be high on the agenda:

title: Gridiron Club Turns Down Move for Women Members
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 8 (UPI)  The Gridiron Club, a private dining group of 50 Washington newmen, rejected today a proposal to admit women to membership.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Milton Friedman talked about the stronger dollar, the hank chairman talked about his twomonth trip around the world and a bundle of bank officers offered views on everything from leveraged leasing to shortages in petrochemical feedstocks.

title: Somerville Lets Pupils Go to School In Hospital
description: SOMRRVILLEBecause of a pilot program at Somerset Hospital here, elementary and junior high and high school students can go to school Without leaving their hospital beds.Labeled the Academic Teaching Program, the threemonthold plan aims to provide continuity of education and to ease the normal catchup scramble that faces hospitalized youngsters when they have recovered.

title: The Doctor Watchers
description: When Dr. X treats Mr. Y in the privacy of his office, no one is involved in this intimate transaction except physician and patient  no one, that is, except for the insurance company, medical society grievance committee, specialty society, Federal government and two sets of lawyers.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Television
description: PROPONENTS of the system have concocted a number of more neutral labels, but the one that sticks is payTV. The basic theory is ingeniously simple. In exchange for such amenities as more flexible schedules, greater programing diversity and no commercial interruptions, some television viewers will be willing to make direct cash payments to willing suppliers. The practice, still severely limited after years of threats and promises, is immensely complicated, generally bogged down around three key questions: How much is paid? To whom? And for what?

title: Actors Don't Retire The may We Retire
description: LONDON. I WAS greatly amused to read in The Times of London Dirk Bogarde's announcement that he had retired. He had decided that acting was no longer a fit job for a grown man, a conclusion that came to him when lying on the floor of the Cinecitta studios with his fly buttons undone and Charlotte Rampling sitting on top of him. Do I, he asked himself, really need this at the age of 53?

title: Dance
Who Was Traded Where In Houston Baseball Deals
description: The Philadelphia Phils traded Barry Lersch, pitcher, and Craig Robinson, shortstop, to the Atlanta Braves for Ron Schueler, pitcher.

title: Rent Control Is Sought for Trailer Lots
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  The County Legislature, when it meets here Tuesday, will weigh a bill favoring the establishment of rent control for lots occupied by mobile homes.

title: VOLUMINOUS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 President Nixon made public today a voluminous amount of information, including his income tax returns for his first four years in office, which he said should lay to rest false rumors about his personal financing.

title: A Weather Expert Helps Fruit Crops
description: NEW BRUNSWICKMost New Jersey food shoppers probably have not given a thought to next year's peach or apple crop, but for the state's big and small growers, these are the crucial months.

title: INDIA LOSES 10% OF STORED GRAINS
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 8 (UPI)In foodshort India, where the Government has had to go shopping in the United States and the Soviet Union, millions of tons of food a year are lost. to pests, poor storage and bad transportationenough to feed 50 million people for one year.

title: 2 MORE KILLINGS HORRIFY DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8In recent years, as this city was acquiring the unofficial title of Mur der Capital, U. S. A., Detroit ers seemed to have become accustomed, if not hardened to routine homicide. But this week, in the face of a new horror, that attitude changed swiftly to one of outrage.

title: Jean Sussman Engaged
description: NORTH BELLMORE, L.I., Dec. 8Mr. and Mrs. Abraham D. Sussman have made known the engagement of their slaughter, Miss Jean N. Sussman, to Howard A. Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Klein of East Meadow, Miss Sussman is a junior at the university of Miami. Her fianc at (ends New York Univtrsity and is with the research and development department of the Phoenix Candy Company, Brooklyn, of which his father is president.

title: COMET DESCRIBED BY SKYLAB CREW
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)The Skylab 3 astronauts got a good look at the comet Kohoutek today and said it was developing a long, glowing tail and was getting easier and easier to see.

title: Zamboni: Newest Broom Sweeping World Hockey Rinks
description: ZAMBONI. A brand of noodle? A voodoo hex? An Italian ice cream, maybe?

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Yount Friars in Italy Protest Circular on Obedience
description: ROME, Dec. 8A circular on strict obedience issued by the Superior of the Franciscan order stirred a group of young friars to protest this week.

title: WALL STREET
description: We are all conservatives about breakfast. Whatever our routine, we are loath to change it ourselves and react with high hostility to changes forced upon us.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES in November rose to 141.8 per cent of the 1967 base period, up 1.8 per cent from the October level and up 17.5 per cent since November, 1972. . . . The First National City Bank of New York and Bankers Trust Company raised the prime rate to 10 per cent. Other banks are expected to follow.

title: What's Doing in MIAMI
description: ORANGE BOWL FESTIVITIES In Miami everything is a special event, including the opening of supermarkets. The blockbuster, however, is the Orange Bowl Festival which began Nov. 30 and ends Jan. 4. The high points are the New Year's Eve parade in downtown Miami (grandstand seats. $5 and $3.50) and the Orange Bowl football game on New Year's Day (seats $7 and $6.50). The theme for the neverrainedupon parade is Broadway Magic. Opponents in the 40th annual Orange Bowl classic are Louisiana State and Penn State. Festival preliminaries include the Orange Bowl International Junior Tennis Tournament, Dec. 2330, at Flamingo Park, Miami Beach, admission free, and the Junior Orange Bowl Parade, with the theme Heroes of a Child's World, Saturday, Dec. 29, on the Miracle Mile, Coral Gables, grandstand seats $2. For ticket information and a full list of events, write: Ticket Manager, Orange Bowl Committee, P.O. Box 748, Miami, Fla. 33125. You can buy tickets at Gate 7 of he Orange Bowl, 1500 Northwest Third in downtown Miami.

title: Music With a Psychic Split
description: NO ARTIST of the 19th century understood the essential manicdepressive nature of Romanticism better than Schumann. In the way artists so often do, he put his emotional problems to work for him, splitting himself into two personalities, a brash extrovert whom he named Florestan and a moody searcher after inner things, Eusbius.

title: Army Passes Enlistment Target First Time Since End of Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) For the first time in 10 months the Army has met and surpassed its monthly recruiting goals, lifting Pentagon hopes that its allvolunteer experiment would work.

title: Art of KnotTying Revived
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I.Neither cowboys nor sailors seem to manage a length of rope with anything like the easy proficiency of their forebears, but if John Hensel has his way, fancy rope work may again be in style. Considered the foremost authority on ornamental knottying, Mr. Hensel has written a book on the subject, The Book of Ornamental Knots, which was published recently by Charles Scribner's Sons ($9.95).

title: WATERGATE SPURS JOURNALISM ON TV
description: Watergate was a fountainhead for the enlivening of television journalism over the last year, restoring the credibility of the medium with much of the public and creating a new atmosphere for investigative reporting.

title: VASSAR CONTINUES OFFICE ON BLACKS
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 8The board of trustees of Vassar College voted unanimously today to continue the office of the assistant to the president for black affairs, thus apparently resolving a contraversy that had stirred student protests and faculty resignations.

title: NEW JOB DECLINE PREDICTED HERE
description: The State Labor Department foresees a further decline of 22,200 jobs in the city by mid1975, led by continued decreases in apparel manufacturing and printing, the city's two largest industries.

title: Pop. The Glitter Is Gold
description: STRIKINGLY and unexpectedly, Lou Reed's Berlin (RCA APLI0207) is one of the strongest, most original rock records in years. Reed was the leading member of the Velvet Underground, the late 1960's band that Andy Warhol took under his wing and that remains the most important precursor of today's ambisexual glitter rock.

title: Weinberger Bars Speeches At Discriminatory Places
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has instructed all department employes to decline invitations to speak before groups or in locations that discriminate.

title: IOWA FUND TO PAY LAWYERS' VICTIMS
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 8 The State Supreme Court, in response to a proposal by the Iowa State Bar Asiociation, has set up a fund for reimbursing clients who loszi money to dishonest lawyers.

title: AllEast Football: Representative Team
description: Since John Cappelletti, Penn State's tailback, ran over and around every defense put against him this season, it is easy to place the first Penn State Heisman Trophy winner at the top of an allEast team for 1973. From that point on, however, the job becomes difficult. Which players should be eliminated from an East allstar team?

title: A DayCare Center for the Lonely Dog
description: EAST RUTHERFORD Does your dog whine when you leave for work? Sulk if he's left alone? Take revenge by ripping up sofa cushions or messing brand new carpets? If he does, Harvey Rubin's School for Dogs at 239 Paterson Avenue here may have the answer.

title: Homes Dim Christmas Lights
description: ESSEX FELLS  For 40 Christmases Sidney Pike has labored early and late putting out an enormous snowman, Santa, reindeer and sleigh, with lights twinkling from every bush and tree. Originally he did it for the Pike children, then for his grandchildren, who now number 10, and, as time went by, for most of the youngsters in the town who came to stare and wonder at the holiday panoply.

title: A.T.&T. Site Dispute Easing
description: BEDMINSTER, Dec. 5 Residents of this affluent community and the neighboring borough of Far Hills in the heart of New Jersey's hunt country are reaching the end of an officeconstruction controversy that experts predict will increasingly confront similar towns in the decade ahead.

title: N.C.A.A. Soccer Regionals on Today
description: St. Louis University and Southern Illinois at Edwardsville will meet at Busch Stadium in St. Louis this afternoon in the National Collegiate Athletic Associations Midwest soccer final, while Clemson and Penn will meet at Clemson. All are striving for the right to play in the semifinals in Miami early in January.

title: Sara L. Cady Married in Summit to William Lipton, Teacher
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 8M iss Sara Lyman Cady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Hutchins Cady of Short Hills, was married here this afternoon to William Harris Lipton, son of Mrs. Abraham Morrison of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and Norman C. Lipton of Jackson Heights, Queens, New York.

title: Early Success: Can It Be Lived Down?
description: SOME artists become so identified with a particular style or historical epoch that they are all but consumed, in public consciousness, by that identification. Such an artist may be young, with a whole career ahead of him, but his mythic status can immure him in the past as effectively as a coffin. His every new show may come as at once a surprise and an almost automatic disappointment; it may seem a superfluous imposition on a body of work already complete, on an idea perfectly formed and assimilated.

title: Greater Local Control Is Sought by Leone
description: Downtown: a coliseum for professional and college basketball and hockey. In the neighborhoods: more control over city housekeeping services and over a proliferation of facilities like methadone centers and halfway houses for returning institutional inmates.

title: GOLD MINERS' WAGES IN SOUTH AFRICA RISE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8Pay increases to black workers in South Africa's gold mines this month have creased the total annual African, labor costs in the industry by almost $45million. The new wage rates mean that the pay of black miners has risen by about 70 per cent in the last two years.

title: Nets Top Colonels, 102 to 87
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 8  The New York Nets routed the Kentucky Colonels, 10287 tonight at the University of Cincinnati's armory field house and established a club record.

title: More Communities Urged To Adopt 911 Phone Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The White House Office of Telecommunications Policy began a campaign this week to get more state and local governments to adopt the emergency telephone number 911.

title: QUESTIONS
description: if you have a question, or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News; The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: Composer of Musical Is 17
description: PRINCETONDuring the coming week a musical group called Aqueous Fowle will, somewhat reluctantly, go into rehearsal for a series of January concerts at the Murray  Dodge Theater at Princeton University.

title: Dr. Russell A. Nixon Dies at 60; Columbia Manpower Economist
description: Dr. Russell Arthur Nixon, a leading manpower economist, died yesterday of a heart attack in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Passaic Wonder Team Cited
description: PASSAICThis city's famous Wonder Team will be enshrined in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., on April 24, the first high school team to be so honored.

title: Saplings Sought to Replace Tree Vandals Cut Down
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)The owner of a recreation camp used by the Rice University football team has asked Texas Agricultural and Mining University for 104 saplings to replace a centuryold tree apparently cut down by students from the rival school.

title: U. of Massachusetts Post
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)Ernest A. Lynton, dean of Livingston College at Rutgers University, has been appointed senior vice president for academic affairs of the University of Massachusetts. Mr. Lynton, dean of Livingston College from 1965 to 1973, will also be Commonwealth Professor and professor of physics at the University of Massachusetts.

title: FIGHT SAID TO GO ON FOR VIETNAM TOWN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec, 8 (UPI)South and North Vietnamese forces battled for control of the Central Highlands district capital of Kien Duc today despite Saigon Government assertions that the town had already been recaptured from the Communists without a fight, field reports said.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Mayflower Descent Traced
description: WESTFIELD  What is a name like Jarulzelski doing On the membership roster of the Society of Mayflower Descendants? Or Wachter, Kitchel or Prodo? Well, for one thing, they all belong to persons descended from the Mayflower passengers who arrived at Plymouth in 1620 and survived that harsh first winter.

title: Letter to Nixon Outlining Result of Audit
World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 8  Leaders from London, Dublin and Belfast today continued their effort to reach agreement on plans for the future of Northern Ireland.

title: COFAET'S FINDER DESCRIBES VIGIL
description: The 38yearold Czechhorn astronomer Dr. Luhos Kohoutek, who discovered the comet that has been named for him, flew yesterday from Hamburg, West V Germany, where he has been working since 1968, to New York, to join a threeday cometwatching cruise aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2. The ship is to sail at 9 P.M. today and return to New York Wednesday.

title: Constance St. John Shrader Is Bride of Robert Richard Rapp
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 8 Miss Constance St. John Schrader and Robert Richard Rapp were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas A. Hughart in a Presbyterian ceremony.

title: DAYAN ADDRESSES U.J.A. DINNER HERE

title: Dayton, Lafayette Triumph at Garden
description: Johnny Davis, remember the name. He was schooled on the playgrounds of Detroit. He watched and learned from Dave Bing and the other Detroit Pistons and yesterday he gave some of his knowledge to Long Island University.

title: Chrysler Issues Warning
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it was notifying 83 owners of 1974model Plymouth Valiant and Dodge Challenger cars of a problem that could lead to bearing failure on the front wheels.

title: Tristate Area Is Found Lagging On U.S. Health Aid for Children
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are lagging far behind the rest of the nation in implementing a vastly underutilized Federal program to provide health examinations and treatment for underprivileged children.

title: WOMAN, 27 IS RAPED IN HER APARTMENT
description: A 27 yearold Manhathan woman was raped by an intruder yesterday afternoon in her apartment in a highrise building at 7 last 14th Street, near Fifth Avenue, the police reported.

title: Utility Eyeing Trash as a Fuel
description: NEWARK  Burning garbage to generate electricty is an idea that is very interesting to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, according to Henry B. Barron, senior engineer of the company's environmental affairs department.

title: Simplicity Is Style of Hamptons Boutique
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Three years ago, Wayne Young and Michel Cantin were riding the crest of the fashion boutique new wave with a clothes manufacturing concern that grossed more than a quarter of a million dollars annually in sales to smart little shops from coast to coast.

title: SWITCHING TO GAS FOR HEAT
description: New York University does not expect to be caught short by the fueloil shortage this winter.

title: Nastase Takes Grand Prix Net Final
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8For the third successive year, Ilie Nastase of Rumania justified the Grand Prix of tennis system by winning the final match of the final tournanient today. He defeated Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 63, 75, 46, 63.

title: Puerto Rican Woman Is Named 1 of 3 New Assistants to Beame
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beanie, who has been under pressure to appoint both Puerto Ricans and women to high positions in his administration, yesterday named Irma Vidal Santaella, a lawyer and founder of the National Federation of Puerto Rican Women, as one of three new assistants to the Mayor.

title: Seoul HighSchool Boys Join AntiGovernment Protests
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. (AP)Highschool students today made their first appearance in the continuing student demonstrations against the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: A Landmark Tavern Burns
description: MOHAWK, N.Y., Dec. 8 (UPI) The Valley Tavern, a preRevolutionary landmark where George Washington is said to have eaten in 1783, was damaged last night by fire. The roof of the tavern, which is on the main street of this Herkimer County community, caved in.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The fine wood objects crafted by Neta and Inge Friberg are being introduced to New Yorkers in an exhibition and sale at AmericanScandinavian Foundation headquarters, 127 East 73d Street, through Wednesday.

title: Mushy squeaker or foxy Speaker of the House?
description: WASHINGTON. The Congressional freshman class of 1947 produced two Presidents, John Kennedy and Richard Nixon. Conceivably, though now less likely, it could produce a third in Carl Albert, Democrat Oklahoma and Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.

title: What Has the Court Saved Us From?
description: A SURPRISING number of intelligent people have defended the June 21 Supreme Court ruling on obscenity by insisting that it was aimed solely at hardcore pornographers, and will have no effect on serious artists. Observers who hold this misguided view obviously know little Or nothing about movies.

title: Wife of a Representativie is Beaten by an Intruder
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Dec. 8 (UPI)The wife of Representative William L. Dickinson, Republican of Alabama, was beaten unconscious by an intruder at her suburban Washington home last night, but not before she had managed to hit her assailant with a piece of firewood.

title: A 125year record of helpfulness
description: EVERY day the letters pour inletters of appreciation and gratitude for all the assistance received, letters asking for aid. More letters are pouring in now than ever before, letters addressed to the oldest and largest, voluntarily supported, nonsectarian socialservice agency in the country, the Community Service Society of New York.

title: AUSTRALIA STUDIES SOLARENERGY USE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 8 Warned that even Australia's rich deposits of mineral fuels have limits, the Government has begun an intensive study of the powerproducing potential of the country's most enduring and plentiful asset and liability combinedsunshine.

title: Tree Key Issue in Park Vote
description: MANHASSET, L. I.They are having an election donnybrook here this week and it all began with a single tree.

title: What's Opened in the Theater?
description: THE GOOD DOCTOR, a comedy by Neil Simon adapted from stories by Chekhov, got 19 favorable reviews (Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Lewis, Bergen Record; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Harris, WCBSTV; Holder, WNBCTV; Scudder, WINSRadio; Stasio, Cue), 9 mixed reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Sanders, WABCTV; Burke, WPIXTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; Novick, Village Voice; Gill, New Yorker; Kroll, Newsweek; Clurman, Nation) and 6 unfavorable reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; S. Klein, WNEWTV; Woodruff, WMCARadio; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Kalem, Time; New York).TROILUS AND CRESSIDA, the New York Shakespeare Festival production of Shakespeare's, play, got 1 mixed review (Lewis) , and 10 negative (Barnes, Watt, Watts, Gottfried, Wallach, Raidy, Glover, A. Klein, Simon, Stasio).

title: Gail Buerger Is Bride of James L. Kerr
description: Miss Gail M. Buerger, director of data processing education with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., certified public accountants, was married yesterday here afternoon to James L. Kerr, manager of money and banking for Nabisco, Inc. The Rev. Robert Weeks performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles.

title: WINS Falsely Reports Governor Was Stabbed
description: An erroneous report that Governor Rockefeller had been stabbed during his visit to Atlanta Friday night was broadcast early yesterday by WINS radio, touching off a flurry of telephone inquiries to local newspapers.

title: Music: 2 Composers for the Theater
description: The adventuresome Composers' Showcase at the Whitney Museum of American Art led off its season Wednesday with an engaging, paradoxical evening devoted to two composers of American theater music. The program was engaging because both Marc Blitzstein and Al Carmines have written innovative works that command unserving loyalty from their admirers; the paraaoxes arise from their differences and their similarly marginal relationship to the mainstream of commercial musical theater in this country.

title: Miss Gardner To Be a Bride
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 8  Miss Jane Kathryn Gardner of Boston, associate director of the grant and contract administration at Boston University, plans to be married in June to Wynne Shepard Carvill of Cambridge, Mass., a thirdyear student at the Harvard Law School.

title: Museums Cut Back in Funds Crisis
description: Since 1966, financial pressures have resulted in cutbacks in facilities, services or staff for 36 per cent of all the country's museums, a justreleased nationwide survey disclosed. And, despite large increases in state and Federal funding of the arts, 63 per cent of the more than $513million received by the art, history and science museums covered in the study came from the private sector.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seems odd that L. J. Davis should cite Joyce Carol Oates's characterization of contemporary experimental writing as deathobsessed, for her own work contains considerably more death than my anthology, Breakthrough Fictioneers. Indeed, to conjecture, she probably portrays more deaths than can be found in all the writings by the book's 101 contributors, Contrary to what DavisOates say, avantgarde literature today tends, by contrast, to be comic and cheery.

title: Congregation EmanuEl Honors Rabbi Perilman on Retirement
description: Congregation EmanuEl honored its retiring spiritual leader, the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, with a special farewell Sabbath service yesterday morning as Mayor Lindsay presented him with the city's 75th anniversary medallion.

title: Pontifex Maximus as a minor character
description: Everyone remembers something about John Pierpont Morgan. He was the man with the ferocious eyes and bulbous nose who bought steel properties from Andrew Carnegie for $447million and formed United States Steel, the world's first billiondollar corporation. He was the man who bailed out the Federal Government in the Panics of 1895 and 1907. He made a good joke about the cost of owning a yacht and shared the favors of beauteous Maxine Elliott with England's King Edward VII. He called Theodore Roosevelt that damned cowboy and on the occasion of T.R.'s trip to hunt big game in Africa hoped the first lion that saw him would do its duty. He formed the greatest collection of art treasures ever assembled by one man, with the possible exception of Napoleon Bonaparte, and divided it between the Morgan Library and the Metropolitan Museum. He was the arrogant Robber Baron who manipulated the American economy solely for personal gain. He was one of the architects of our material growth who made the United States a great industrial power in hardly more than a generation, and did it at a lower human cost than that paid by any other nation.

title: UNIVERSITY GETS FOUNDATION LOAN
description: The Ford Foundation has made a halfmillion dollar, lowinterest loan to Shaw University, a predominantly black institution in Raleigh, N.C., in the first case of a foundation providing a loan instead of an outright grant to an institution of higher learning.

title: Vermont Buys A Railroad
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 8 (UPI)  The state of Vermont has purchased a 99mile railroad line for $1,265,000. Samuel Pinsley, owner of the financially troubled St. Johnsbury and Lamoille County Railroad, signed over all deeds yesterday.

title: Legislators Back Temporary Lifting Of Pollution Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) An organization representing 7,600 state legislators recommended today that environmental quality standards be relaxed if there is no alternative to the energy crisis.

title: Hospital Sought In Montauk
description: MONTAUK, L.I.An intensive campaign for the establishment of a medical facility to meet the rapidly increasing needs of the Montauk area got under way last week under the direction of the Montauk Chamber of commerce.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Yom Kippur War was, at least in one important aspect, a godsend for the Arab oilproducing countries.

title: Wynne Greenfield Plans Nuptials
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 The engagement of Miss Wynne Greenfield to Alan Maxwell Weingarden has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Richard K. Greenfield. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Weingarden of New York. A Dec. 30 wedding is planned.

title: Incumbents Wary Over Redistricting
description: TRENTON  Despite partisan pressure in the new overwhelmingly Democratic majorities in the Legislature to draw new Congressional Districts, 13 of New Jersey's 15 incumbent Democratic and Republican Representatives do not want their districts changed for next year's election.

title: New York Colleges Recruit in State
description: LIVINGSTONA number of private liberal arts colleges in New York State, striving to find students in a day of declining applications, are glad New Jersey exists.

title: FUEL CUTS MAY HIT CITY AREA HARDER
description: Any acrosstheboard cutbacks in energy usage would cause much deeper problems for the New York metropolitan area than for the rest of the country, a study released yesterday indicates, because people who live here are already much more sparing in the use of energy.

title: Nixon's Statement on His Financial Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Following is a statement by President Nixon on the release of documents dealing with his personal finances:

title: Marilyn Aschner to Be Wed Jan. 27
description: Miss Marilyn Jane Aschner, why teaches tennis professionally at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy, and Dr. Alan Rachleff, a member of the anesthesiology staff at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I., will be married Jan. 27.

title: CLYDE H. SPENCER
description: PORTLAND, Ore,, Dec, 8 (AP)  Clyde H. Spencer, a supervisor of some of the West's larger dam construction projects, died Thursday at his home in Tigard. He was 81 years old.

title: Salvaging homes
description: ALL happy families resemble one another: every unhappy family is unhappy in its own fashion. Sidney Herling, executive director of Staten Island Family Service, is fond of this quotation from Tolstoy. No one, Mr. Herling says, is more aware of this fact than the staff of Family Service.

title: West Portal a Crafts Base
description: WEST PORTALThe lives of hundreds of handicraft workers in more than 20 states and Canada are touched by a shopkeeper in this almost forgotten hamlet at the foot of Jugtown Mountain. She is Mary Isham, who operates The Woodpile Shop, situated in an old hotel that was once a stagecoach stop between Somerville and Easton, Pa. Mrs. Isham sells only handmade items, most of them fashioned by craftsmen in depressed areas. She also carries handicrafts made in New Jersey, but not necessarily by craftsmen in need.

title: Soviet Union Is Cleaning Up the Volga but Not Without Setbacks
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8  The Volga River, celebrated for its beauty in Russian story and song, has been the target of a mammoth environmental cleanup campaign that is notwithout its snags.

title: Future Social Events
description: Dec. 12You'll digest a very concentrated history of arts in courses at the benefit dinner in the Metropolitan Museum with the Council of Fashion Designers in America as cohost), which will herald the museum's Costume Institute exhibition, The Tens, the Twenties, the ThirtiesInventive Clothes/19091939. That's a twicetold title. The evening will start off soothingly enough with cocktails in the Medieval Sculpture Hall, then dinner (pt, potage, blanquette de veau, salade and brie) on the balcony of the Great Hall against a background of, but not on, Chinese porcelain. The pace gets feverish in the Costume Institute as the clothes (Vionnets, Callot Soeurs', Chanel's, etc.) come on, raise skirts and save waists from Edwardian strictures, hurried along by abetting media like Fauves, cubists, jazz, blues and LatinAmerican throb. Diana Vreeland organized the exhibition; Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon is chairman, and the edification is $1??0 a person.

title: George Brengle And Anne Blum Set May Bridal
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Halsey Blum of Riverside and Seal Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of Mr. Blum's daughter, Miss Anne Beeckman Blum, to George Munson Brengle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence John Brengle Jr. of Manchester, Mass,

title: Sarah Elizabeth Brush Fiancee Of William Blum Thalhimer 3d
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 8Miss Sarah Elizabeth Brush plans to he married here Dec. 27 to William Blum Thalhimer 3d, a buyer in the men's division of Thalhimer Brothers, a department store chain founded by his family in 1842.

title: Travel Notes: Survey Of Restrictions on Driving in Europe
description: ANYONE who has ever driven on an autostrada in Italy knows how passionately the Italians love speed. Try pulling out of the righthand lane to pass a relatively slowmoving vehicle in front of you and before you've had time to flash your turn signal, a Fiat is beside you, its horn blaring, and behind it an AlfaRomeo is closing the gap and using its horn to get the Fiat out of the way.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The prospect of cold homes this winter has combined with changes in fashion to produce a surge in sweater sales this fall  and the best may be still to come.

title: Nixon Friend Gave Tricia $25,000 Trust Fund in '58
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8When Richard M. Nixon was Vice President, a wealthy friend established a trust fund of more than $25,000 for Mr. Nixon's older daughter, Tricia, according to information released today by the White House.

title: Lie Detector Use
description: TRENTONA drug company that wants to give liedetector tests to all its employes has attacked the constitutionality of a 1966 state statute prohibiting such practices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Point of View article by Barry BruceBriggs [Nixon's Policy on Housing Is Sound, Nov. 11] favors the housing allowance approach as a substitute for subsidized housing, acknowledging that one probable effect will be to accelerate the racial transition of borderline areas.

title: Retired Policeman and Druggist Help Thwart Brooklyn Holdup
description: An attempted robbery in a Brooklyn drugstore was frus trated yesterday through the combined efforts of a former policeman who left the force three days ago because of a serious injury, a pharmacist who kept his wits after a pistol :had been held to his head and two detectives specially trained in negotiating with gunmen holding hostages.

title: Private and Proud and Hepburn
description: HOLLYWOOD. KATHARINE HEPBURN opens the front door herself. You must come and look at my Christmas wreath, she says, as, together with her secretary, a gentle English lady called Phyllis, she ushers me into the livingroom of her West Hollywood cottage. She walks over to the crackling fire, picks up the green wreath, and shows me its intricately woven leaves. I made it myself. I'm as proud of it anything I've done.She so often plays embittered, brokendown old women on the screen it's a relief to find her as alive with enthusiasm as a young girl, cheeks ruddy with sunburn, movements quick and precise, her figure almost as attractively skinny as it was when she played Philadelphia Story more than 30 years ago.

title: Miss Ann R. Peake To Become a Bride
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8  Mr. and Mrs. David Wainwright Peake have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Robinson Peake, to Robert Dunham Nostrand of Denver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Dudley Nostrand of Forest Hills, Queens, N. Y.

title: Pastor Will Explore Another Frontier
description: WESTFIELD  The Rev. George Carruthers Bonnell, for 17 years pastor of Presbyterian churches in Englewood, Brooklyn, N. Y. and Plainfield, has forsaken the pulpit at the age of 48 and forged a new career.

title: Shearwood McClelland to Wed Yvonne Thornton, Gynecologist
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., Dec. 8Dr. Yvonne Shirley Thornton, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Roosevelt Hospital in New York, plans to be married June 8 at New York's Riverside Church to Shearwood Junior McClelland.

title: Stamps
description: THE program of new A United States stamps and postal stationery for the higher rates due early next year, which has been announced in driblets, often in inadequate detail, has now taken on substantial shape.

title: Environmentalists Fear a Shift to Coal
description: Norman Cousins, who as chairman of Mayor Lindsay's task force on environmental pollution helped to bring about the shift from coal to oil and the bannning of highsulphur fuels, voiced the fears of environmentalists last week that the energy shortage would doom the ban on heavily polluting fuels.

title: Arms Parley Splits Nixon Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Significant differences continue to exist within the Nixon Administration on where to go from here in the talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms.

title: A Chamber Panel Aids Energy Drive
description: NEWARK  An Energy Conservation Task Force is being formed by the Chamber of Commerce. Edward R. Eberle has appointed eight businessmen to serve on the task force, which will be headed by Richard Cross, general manager of advertising and community relations for the Public Service Electric and Gas Comany.

title: Eagle Passes Will Keep Jets Flying
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 Charley Winner, the coach who designs the Jet defense, and Ralph Baker, the signalcalling linebacker who implements that defense, agree that the Philadelphia offense reminds them of the Denver offense.

title: Demonstrators Back Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI), About 75 people paraded outside the White House in 40degree temperatures today, waving miniature American. flags and singing God Bless America to show their support for President Nixon.

title: Counterparts
description: ACROSS

title: Martha Gustayson Will Be Wed Dec. 29
description: ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 8Carl Gustayson, professor of history at the University of Ohio, and Mrs. Gustavson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Gustayson, to Dr. Alan B. Marks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Marks of New York.

title: Women Choose Engineering
description: JERSEY CITYThe panelists were women, most of the people in the audience were women and the subject was careers for women. But the profession under discussion was engineering, where men outnumber women 100 to 1 and where a young woman starting out is often greeted with, What's a nice girl like you doing in a job like this?

title: Jennie Toure19101973
description: IT took me a long time to discover the values of a funeral ceremony: I had always abhorred and avoided them as pomposities  pompes funbres and as a poor way to say goodbye, a needlessly public way of paying one's private last respects.

title: Gov. Byrne May Never Get Chance to Ride in Style
description: TRENTON  Being Governor of New Jersey is not as grand as it used to be. For one thing, Governor Cahill has had to give up his shiny, long black limousine for a nondescript black Plymouth, and as for Gov. elect Brendan T. Byrne, he may never get a chance to ride in style.

title: Another Little Flower Is Coming Here
description: Fiorella is a natural for New York, said George Bernard, vice president and general manager of the New York Sets tennis team. Her Latin background, charisma, love for New York and desire to make a lasting mark in World Team Tennis is significant in building a solid team.

title: Queens Village Residents Seek Blockbusting Ban
description: Individual homeowners, legislators and representatives of civic, community and religious groups urged Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo last week to issue a nonsolicitation order to prevent what they termed unscrupulous real estate dealers from using blockbusting tactics in Queens Village.

title: Toy Shop Planned By Salvation Army
description: NEWARKThe Salvation Army will open a Christmas toy shop on Dec. 17 in the gymnasium of its New Jersey divisional headquarters at 80 Washington Street here.

title: Giants Can't Spoil Season for Rams
description: When the New York Giants were booked into Los Angeles the nation's film capital for the final Monday night game of the season, some had visions of the game being a glamorous, Hollywoodtype confrontation between two possible contenders for the Super Bowl.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Numismatics
description: THE Hobby Protection Act is at last a reality. After months of uncertainty during an erratic and prolonged course through Congress, it was signed into law by President (Nixon on Nov. 30. It is officially designated as Public Law 93167.

title: What They Are Saying
description: John Cappelletti of Penn State confesses some doubt the night before he won the Heisman Trophy: All the allAmericans were in New York to tape a television show. I saw John Hicks [Ohio State's mammoth offensive tackle] and I thought someone that size might be big enough to scare some people into voting for him. (Hicks finished second in the balloting).

title: DraftBoard Registering Still Required of Youths
description: The Selective Service System issued a reminder yesterday that although there is no draft now, young men still must register with Selective Service within 30 days before or after their 18th birthday.

title: NAVY SUSPENDING A RACE PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The Navy has suspended pilot race relations program, in part because it was decided that the emotions of the participants had been rubbed too raw to continue.

title: A.K.C. Puts Emphasis on a Diverse Dog Program
description: In an effort to develop more effective communication with the dog show fancier, the American Kennel Club held an allday symposium in Atlantic City last weekend and drew an audience of 1,100.

title: Yacht Racing Union Starts Study of Handicap System
description: The North American Yacht Racing Union, the sport's ultimate authority on a national scale, has announced a research program to cost $280,000 that it hopes will produce the most equitable system of handicapping yachts in sailing history.

title: CALIFORNIA AIDE SEEKS TO TAX NIXON
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. (UPI)A California tax official said today that there was serious question about President Nixon's claim of exemption from state income tax.

title: Music in Review
description: If there was any doubt about Shirley Verrett's current status in the opera world after her sudcess this fall in the Met's Les Troyens, it was dispelled by her Carnegie Hall recital Wednesday night, complete with a herd of hardcore Met fans, a tumultuous reception and numerous tape recorders hidden under folded rain coats (a singer's ultimate accolade these days).

title: The Scrooge Story Becomes a Musical
description: MONTCLAIR  Ebenezer Scrooge will sing and dance here next weekend in The Stingiest Man in Town, a musical version of A Christmas Carol being presented by the Montclair Dramatic Club.

title: Harry Gutmann Is Elected By Reform Judaism Group
description: Harry K. Gutmann of Scarsdale, N. Y., has been elected to his first full twoyear term as chairman of the board of trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, national hods of Reform Judaism in the United States and Canada.

title: In First Term, Nixon's Fortune Grew $150,000 a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec., 8In his first term in office, President Nixonaccording to financial records released today  saw his fortune grow by $150,000 a year and has become a fullfledged millionaire.

title: Jane E. Drew Engaged
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 8 Miss Jane Elizabeth Drew, a sophomore at Wellesley College, plans to be married to Stephen Britton Land, a junior at Harvard College. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Drew, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gay V. Land. Both families are of Westport.

title: Nassau Takes Steps to Ease Impact of the Fuel Shortage
description: MINEOLA, L.I.The Nas sau County government, business organizations and schools are taking immedi ate steps as well as deter mining longrange action in attempts to minimize the effects of the nationwide energy crisis.

title: A Master of the Movable Feast Retiring After 37 Years at Sea
description: LE HAVRE, France (UPI)One of the great chefs of France is about to retire from what gourmets call the greatest restaurant afloat.

title: Art
description: THE sensational exhibition of treasures unearthed since the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, which has already traveled from Peking to Paris to London, is scheduled to go on to Stockholm and should reach this continent in August, 1974, at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto. It might even reach the National Gallery in Washington in 1975 if negotiations now being carried on by the State Department are successful.

title: Nixon Income and Outgo
Gardens
description: IN our house we're solving the energy crisis with a blooming revolution. The crisis is national and the revolution is fast assuming nationwide proportions.

title: 3 Records Fall In School Track
description: Three records were broken yesterday in the Mount St. Michael scholastic track and field meet at the host school's allweather facility in the Bronx.

title: Justices to Rule on Sideburns
description: TRENTONThe first longhair case to reach the State Supreme Court concerns sideburns, and not long hair as such.

title: CALIFORNIA FACES FOOD SHORTAGES
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 Supermarket chains throughoutthe state locked their doors against striking employes this week, curtailing supplies at some outlets and raising the possibility of major food shortages in California by the end of the month.

title: Citizen Gives State Gift of 240 Acres
description: MONTAGUE TOWNSHIPIn a brief ceremony here last week, the state accepted from a 66yearold retired television repairman a gift of 240 acres of unspoiled land this his family had owned since the eighteenforties. The land, valued at $225,000, will be preserved in perpetuity as a natural wilderness area.

title: Three novels
description: Graham Billings's The Slipway is a fine novel, jumpy and sad, and it is a pleasure to read; it demonstrates that the author of Forbush and the Penguins is pushing his talent hard, if perhaps with insufficient risk. The scope of The Slipway is small: an alcoholic named Geoffrey Targett, heir to the nearlydead Targett shipbuilding line, spends two days thinking about trying to save himself and the family business, then watches the Saint Clair, last ship of the tine, shelled and sunk by the New Zealand Navy during gunnery practice. Targett donated the ship in a gesture of despair and in a grasp after style. When the ship is sunk, he is sunk, and that is all; the book ends, though he will go on a little longer, a ghost.

title: Pressures On Mr. Nixon, His Oil Czar
description: The swearingin ceremony over, Gerald R. Ford, the 40th Vice President of the United States, stood in the House chamber, an unassuming figure in a neat blue suit, responding in his flat tones with words that set no pulses racing. Yet inherent in the scene last Thursday was a sense that high drama might be quickening toward culmination.

title: Lottery to Offer Special Yuletide Cash
description: TRENTONThe state lottery will provide dozens of opportunities to win an Instant Christmas Bonus of up to $10,000 in addition to regular cash prizes during the holiday season.

title: A. Coast Surcharge On Parking Space Delayed by E.P.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UPI)  The Federal Government, faced with 60 lawsuits and a storm of criticism, has delayed for a year its plan to impose a surcharge on parking spaces in major California cities.

title: Shift of Padres to Washington a Political Move
description: A desire to keep the goodwill of Congress, which has the power at any time to take away the antitrust exemption baseball prizes so highly, turned out to be a major factor in the National Leagues abrupt decision to move the Padres to Washington even though another buyer was available to keep the team in San Diego.

title: News of the Screen
description: David Rabe's play Boom Boom Room closes its successful limited run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater tonightbut won't stay shuttered forever. Joseph Papp, producerdirector of the New York Shakespeare Festival presentation, discloses that he will make his debut as a movie producer with a film adaptation for Ray Stark's Rastar Productions.

title: Nickel Mountain
description: Tis an old saw, John Lyly wrote way back in, 1591, that children and fooles speake true. That old saw is the informing idea of the pastoral, the genre to which John Gardner's new novel belongs. In pastoral narratives, depending on where and when they are set, children, fools, madmen, women, rustics, proletarians, Indians, blacks or other lowstatus types know what urban smartness or caste eminence has driven out of sight and out of mind. Oliver Mellors, for example, gamekeeper and son of a blacksmith, knows what Sir Clifford Chatterly, intellectual and captain of industry, does not know: how to scratch a itches.

title: Terry Schneider Bride of Denis Bovin
description: Miss Terry Schneider, speechimprovement teacher with the city school system, was married here last evening to Denis Alan Bovin,an associate in the corporatefinance department of Salomon Brothers, investment bankers. Rabbis Seymour Freedman and Steven Riskin performed the ceremony in the Lincoln Square Synagogue.

title: Cynthia Krasnov Fiancee
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Krasnov have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Susan Krasnov, to Neil Kline Rosengarden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rosengarden. Both families are of Great Neck.

title: The immigrs do what the French won't
description: PARIS. We are beneath the grimy glass roof of the Gare de Lyon. A train pulls in from the south, and a Chaplinesque little fellow with a black mustache and gold teeth descends from second class bearing a cardboard suitcase bound with string. He is an Algerian immigrant; we shall call him Abdelkader. He is from the mountains beyond TiziOuzou; he has a wife and half a dozen children, and he has come to France to look for work.

title: Israel Files Slaying Charge
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 8, )Reuters)Israel today formally notified the International Red Cross of her charges that Syria killed 42 Israeli prisoners captured in the October war, senior Foreign Ministry official said here tonight.

title: Others may combine Eichmann and Elmer Fudd, but not
description: Pit a man against a deer, one on one, and I'll take the deer every time, a hunting partner mine likes to say. They can see anything that moves within a mile, hear anything unnatural within five, and smell you, if the wind's right, while you're eating breakfast clear back in town.

title: SOUTHERN G.O.P. MEETS IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 8  The Southern Republican Conference, a thousand hardcore party workers from all over Dixie, gathered here this weekend, insisting that Watergate was not a crucial issue but talking about it endlessly.

title: Pledge on Turnpike Tolls
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 (UPDThe Ohio Turnpike Commission says that tolls on the state's turnpikes will remain the same even if revenues drop because of the gasoline shortage. The commission chairman, James W. Shocknessy, said Wednesday that advance retirement of construction bids would provide a protective cushion against higher rates even if income dropped.

title: In the Wrong Century
description: PARISNapoleon is credited with the remark that China is a sleeping giant and when it awakes the world will tremble. The Chinese giant has now awakened from its long, long slumber although, despite Soviet pretensions to anxiety, there seems no reason for trembling. But one is inclined to wonder whether China didn't wake up too late.

title: Katherine Caldwell Plans February Wedding to Kevin Graham
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Dec. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Caldwell of Allentown, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Edmonston Caldwell, to Kevin Michael Graham. He is the son of Mrs. Edward Lawrence Graham of Southold, L. I., and the late Mr. Graham.

title: Holiday fare
description: In this season of nostalgia, one way to recapture some of the warmth and simplicity of earlier times is to hold an open house for friends and relatives. And serve the kind of homebaked cookies and cakes that hostesses set forth for guests in the early 19th century. The recipes on this page are modified for modern stoves from the receipts followed by Fanny Pierson Crane back in the eighteenhundreds.

title: Southampton Study Of Water Is Set
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. LA study of Southampton's water resources will get under way next month, according to the town board.

title: SEMINAR STUDIES PATIENTS' RIGHTS
description: Recent court rulings in several states have greatly broadened the rights of patients in mental institutions and sharply restricted the ability of state governments to commit people to mental hospitals, a seminar was told here last week.

title: The Energy Shortage in and Around New York
description: The energy gap has produced a reality gap for the 15 million people of the region: For the moment, the widespread fears of heatless homes, stranded cars and shivering schoolchildren are just that, fears. Very few people are going without what they need as the winter begins.

title: A Program For Blind Stands On Its Own
description: FRANKLIN  The Squibb toothbrush in the counter display and the free sample of Revlon's Charlie perfume, are not just commercial ventures; they are examples of what a blind person can produce.

title: Point of View
description: The following article was written by Carter F. Bales, director of the public practice consulting group of McKinsey & Co., management consultants, and Robert C. Alexander, an associate of the company.

title: What's in a Name? Money, if All Goes Wel
description: The Cities Service Oil Company was facing a crisis: Profits were on the skids, and something had better be done. Enter Lippincott & Margulies, Inc., super salesmen of graphic design and corporate identity.

title: GASOLINE SUPPLY DROPS ACROSS U.S.
description: Servicestation owners and their spokesmen throughout the country expressed concern yesterday over a gasoline drought brought on by tight supplies and a run on their pumps.

title: ARAB OIL OFFICIALS CONFER IN KUWAIT
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 8 (UPI)  Oil ministers from 11 Arab states assessed their sevenweekold program of oil cutbacks and embargoes at a meeting of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries today but declined to say whether their policies would be changed.

title: Why was there a shortage before the shortage?
description: In September, 1972, supplies of home heating oil in the United States were dangerously low and stocks of crude oil, from which heating oil refined, had fallen to their lowest level since World War H. A serious fuel shortage seemed inevitable as winter approached. President Nixon authorized the petroleum industry to import more foreign crude oil. It was the second time in five months he had increased the allowable imports of foreign oil, which had been under tight Government restriction since 1959. A few weeks later, in a speech to the National Petroleum Council, Gen. George Lincoln. head of the White House Office of Emergency Preparedness, which had charge of oil imports, strongly urged industry leaders to crank up their refineries to full capacity to head off a heatingfuel crisis. Simultaneously, the Interior Department sent telegrams to the major oil refineries urging them do the same.

title: The Leadership Crisis
description: The nation's leadership crisis continues Unresolved. The inquiry in Judge Sirica's courtroom into the perplexing nonexistence of two of the Watergate tapes and the eighteenminute gap in a third has offset President Nixon's Operation Candor. At best, the President's recent speeches and disclosures, including those he made yesterday on his personal finances, have bought him a little more time.

title: Activist Wins Back Apartment Lease
description: A Bay Ridge tenant won back her decontrolled apartment four months after her landlord refused to renew her twoyear lease because of her active role as a local tenant leader.

title: The Vermont Ski Train: On Time for the Fuel Crisis
The best to date about
description: It has remained to an Englishwoman, Margaret Crosland, to produce the best work to date about Colette. Miss Crosland must have been thoroughly immersed in her subject, for the book seems to have been written by someone thinking in Frenchnot only the occasional turn of phrase, but the turn of mind. She has, however, kept a scholar's detachment and has avoided what Janet Flanner in her introduction calls the patriotic sentimentality of French commentators on Colette.

title: Chekhov Meets Neil Simon, Both Lose
description: CHEKHOV and Neil Simon are flying their flags together in The Good Doctor. Unhapplly, both are at half mast. Mr. Simon has taken nine of Chekhov's early short stories  call them sketches, they are scarcely stories at all  and, with Christopher Plummer serving superbly as narrator, has filtered them onto the stage of the Eugene O'Neill in droplets, a bit of character here, an earcatching epigram there, the ghost of an emotion racing just past us, fragments of farce and snatches of truth and ominous echoes of Broadway formula comedy all going into the same thin potaufeu.

title: Vikings Set Back Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 8 Bobby Bryant intercepted three passes, returning one 46 yards for a touchdown and setting up a field goal with another, to spark the Minnesota Vikings to a 317 National Football League victory over the Green Bay Packers today.

title: MEDICAID REFUND BY CITY IS URGED
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the city should refund, by means of credits, $6.9million to the state and Federal Government that he said it had improperly collected after failure to get Medicaid patients to pay their required shares of hospital costs.

title: College Offers DayCare Aid
description: EDISONOpen the door of the long white building at the edge of the Middlesex County College campus any weekday and you will probably hear the unfamiliar sound of tiny voices. They belong to the youngsters enrolled in the college's new day care center.

title: Argentine Rebels Plan Trial
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 (UPI) Leftist guerrillas in Argentina said they would make a kidnapped American oil executive stand trial in a rebel court, a Buenos Aires newspaper reported today. An armed group identifying itself as the People's Revolutionary Army took Victor E. Samuelson Thursday from the restaurant of the Esso Oil Company of Argentina's refinery at Campana. 50 miles from Buenos Aires.

title: U.S. to Help Maine On Winter proofing Of Homes for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The energy shortage has prompted the Office of Economic Opportunity to fund a $478,715 program in Maine to winterproof more than 3,000 homes of the poor.

title: Energy Inquiry Urged
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Dec. 8 (UPI) The Farmers Union national president, Tony Dechant, called today for an investigation into the causes and solutions of the energy shortage.

title: Strife Divides Tenant Group
description: Last week, after two months of internal dissension, leaders of the major tenants association in Queens and a newly created breakaway organization announced that they had reconciled and would work together. By the next day, the agreement had evaporated.

title: How Oil Allocation Is Working's
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIPThe state is preparing to implement President Nixon's mandatory allocation program for fuel oil, and one of the first obstacles officials at the monthold New Jersey Emergency Fuel and Energy Agency must overcome is public ignorance of how it operates.

title: Brighter Side
description: Some benefits will accrue to American society from the energy shortage, alongside the undoubted hardships. Here, in no particular order, are some of the good results that may be expected in coming months:

title: People and Business
description: Printing is a billiondollar industry in the metropolitan area, and for the last halfcentury the Denburg family of Newark has played an important part in its development. It started in 1922, when Harry M. Denburg bought a threeman printing shop situated above a tobacconist's on Market Street.

title: Roy D. Budd to Wed Miss Lynn Liptak
description: YONKERS, Dec. 8Miss Lynn R. Liptak, assistant. dean of students at Fordham University, and Roy D. Budd, a stockbroker with Reynolds Securities in New York, plan to be married here Jan. 5 in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: RICHARD D. BLANCHARD
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 8 Richard D. Blanchard, director of public relations of the Newark College of Engineering, died yesterday at his home, East Walnut Street. He was 61 years old.

title: Iowa Candidate Withdraws, Seeing Bad Year for G.O.P.
description: KEOKUK, Iowa, Dec. 8.Explaining that he is unwilling to accept campaign contributions from nonresidents and special interest groups, State Representative John Clarke, a Keokuk Republican, has withdrawn as a candidate for Congress in the First District.

title: At Last, The Sound Of Music!
description: The expressive hands of the symbolic maestro above proclaim the resumption of the New York Philharmonic season last Thursday night after a 10week strike, with Vladimir Ashkenazy playing the Scriabin Piano Concerto. The contract settlement will improve wages and pension benefits for the musicians and increase their base pay of $330 a week to $380 over three years. The losses incurred by the strike include a total of $35,000 in salaries for the players and, for the public, 44 canceled concerts. This Thursday Pierre Boulez will lead the orchestra, the Camerata Singers, Hermann Prey and other soloists in Schumann's rarely heard Scenes from Faust.

title: Ballet Strike Ends
description: The 25day strike by dancers of the New York City Ballet ended yesterday, and the company said performances of The Nutcracker would begin Wednesday. Details, Page 41.

title: H.E.W. Names Rights Chief
description: Joel W. Barkan has been named regional civil rights director for the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare, directing a staff of 40 persons enforcing Federal civil rights laws in New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: Your Life Might Make A Goodor BadMovie;
description: THE fever began In Paris with Henri Langlois and his Cinmathque Franoise where, in the 1950s, a generation of cineastes discovered that it was actually possible to survive 12 to 18 hours a day sitting in the dark watching old movies. No bends. No laughing or crying fits. No hallucinations uninvited. One might be a bit dizzy and inarticulate when one emerged, but the traumas were seldom fatal. In the 1960s the fever, not unlike a kind of medieval ecstasy, spread to America, where the effects were initially apparent on the postwar young. They were the most easily susceptible, but the older generations were also touched.

title: A Summary of the More Than 50 Documents Detailing the Presidential Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Following is a summary of the more than 50 documents released by the White detailing the President's finances:

title: Marichal Sold to Red Sox
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP)Juan Marichal, for more than a decade one of the premier righthanders in baseball, was sold to the Boston Red Sox today by the San Francisco Giants. The deal, for an undisclosed amount of cash, was consummated last night in Houston prior to the interleague trading deadline and announced tonight after the Giants had notified Marichal in his native Dominican Republic.

title: VASSAR CONTINUES OFFICE ON BLACKS,
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 8The board of trustees of Vassar College voted unanimously today to continue the office of the assistant to the president for black affairs, thus apparently resolving a controversy that had stirred student protests and faculty resignations.

title: New Job for ExVehicles Head
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP)Governor Rockefeller has appointed Vincent L. Tofany, who resigned recently as State. Motor Vehicles Commissioner, to the state's Public Health Council. He succeeds former State Republican Chairman Charles T. Lanigan in the $2,500ayear post. The Madison County Republican chairman, Arnold Fisher, was named the new Motor Vehicles Commissioner.

title: A Cool Head For Berlioz
description: BERLIOZ'S entry into the Pantheon of Great Composers has been a long, even painful, processlong because there are many perplexing aspects to his music without immediate precedent and not easily grasped; painful because he has never lacked eloquent spokesmen (beginning with the composer himself) to hammer away at our musical consciousness. That Berlioz has arrived at last can hardly be doubted, if for no other reason than that all his major works, and most of the minor ones too, are available on records.

title: Barbara Newman Is Wed
description: Miss Barbara Frances Newman, an assistant district attorney in Kings County, was married here yesterday evening to Bernard Nathan, son of Mrs. Charles Nathan of Albany and the late Mr. Nathan. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. David Newman of Hartford. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony in his study. The bridegroom is president of the Eagle Supply Company. science from Columbia University. He is director of libraries at Elmira College.

title: The Day the Circus Came To Lone Tree
description: Bored with books about the circus? Well, through the eyes of Glen Rounds, who was born in the Badlands of South Dakota and spent his boyhood on a ranch in Montana, the greatest show on earth takes on brand new fun and excitement when it arrives In the small Western town of Lone Tree. Here is Americana as authentic as Oklahoma! and if Rounds has any luck, the Rodgers and Hammersteins, and Meredith Wilisons will come running, for this account of the confrontation between frontiersmen and wildlife they've never laid eyes on before, might conceivably be as hilarious on the stage as it is in a book.

title: The&A Region& In Summary
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller, who has been governor of New York as far back as some people can remember, and who seems to have been seeking an elusive Presidency for almost as long, was reported last week to be ready to vacate the Executive Mansion for good in one final bid for the White House.

title: Woman Suspected In $160,000 Theft Of Gems Is Seized
description: A 55yearold woman who had allegedly talked a jeweler out of $160,000 in diamonds, rubies and sapphires by posing as a buying agent for the United Nations has been arrested in Ossining, N.Y., the police said yesterday.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: As minorities in this country have become more vocal, their feelings and their needs have on the whole been given increasing attention and aid. But according to sociologist Harry H. L. Kitano and psychologist Stanley Sue, one minority group, Asian Americans, who comprise less than 1 per cent of the population of the United States, have generally been considered in a special mannerminorities, yes; but oppressed, no. The two investigators were the editors of the latest issue of The Journal of Social Issues, published by The American Psychological Association.

title: WALLACE DEDUCTION ON PAPERS REPORTED
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec 8 Gov. George C. Wallace claimed a $30,000 tax deduction on his 1968 personal income tax for papers relating to his Presidential campaign that year that had been turned over to the Alabama Archives, a Montgomery newspaper reported this week.

title: Israel Puts Death Toll Since War's Start at 2,412
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 8Israeli deaths attributed to the October war and its aftermath were officially put tonight at 2,412. This is 558 more than the last official count on Nov. 6.

title: Swedes Fighting Bridge to Denmark
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 8 (Reuters)Foes of the Common Market and environmentalists here are protesting plans to link Sweden and Denmark by a mammoth vehicular bridge.

title: Coed and Grandparents Found Knifed to Death in Brooklyn as an ExBoyfriend Confesses to the Police
description: A 22yearold Long Island University coed and her maternal grandparents were found stabbed to death in their Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning shortly after the young woman's former boyfriend walked into a police station with a hunting knife and confessed to the killings.

title: Hearing Is Taught To Deaf Children
description: LIVINGSTON  We've sperd a lot of time teaching hearing  impaired children how to be deaf: now we must spend time teaching them how to hear, said Mrs. Helen Beebe.

title: G. P. Urban 3d Will Wed Jean Enos
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8  Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Trask Enos have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Taylor Enos, to George Pennock Urban 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Urban Jr. of Buffalo and Rosehill, Ontario.
