The wedding is planned for Feb. 9 at Christ Episcopal Church here.

title: The designer who took the garden party out of chiffon
description: WHEN New York first saw her a scant five years agoit was as if some mindboggling apparition had descended from London upon the Fashion Capital of the World. Her eyelids were spangled red, her hair streaked green. And her name was Zandra Rhodes. Her clothes were as remarkable as she was. They were mostly chiffons. Chiffons for daytime. Chiffons for evening. Chiffons in squiggly, different (they were her own) prints. Chiffons slashed into elegant tatters. Outrageous!

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: What goes down must come up. That was the law that Wall Street seemed to be propounding last week in a period of tumultuous markets.

title: The Greatest Duchampian Joke
description: PHILADELPHIA. THE Marcel Duchamp retrospective organized by Anne d'Harnoncourt and Kynaston McShinethe most comprehensive exhibition ever devoted to this Unique and widely influential figurehas been on view at the Philadelphia Museum of Art since late September. It was originally scheduled to open at the Museum of Modem Art in New York on Dec. 3, but the recent strike at the Modern has resulted in what was first announced as a cancellation of the show but now, with the dispute finally settled, turns out to be only a postponement the exhibition closes today in Philadelphia, and is now rescheduled to in New York on Dec. 28.

title: Mundus Artium
description: The function of a literary journal such as Mundus Artium should be to give all poets and critics of poetry a hearing. Fate then decides what will live and who will live. The young poet especially, discouraged over the very few periodicals willing to exhibit his work, tends to believe and to say that there is no place for art in America, that it has become, or has always been, a sheer luxury.

title: New & Novel
description: It is too late to save Nineveh and spare Tyre. There may still be time to keep our effete civilization from becoming a terminal case. This is the nub of Allen Drury's parable in novel form. Its message is as clear as the graffiti on a subway oar.

title: West. Ky. Wins Bowl, Gains Final
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 8 (AP)Western Kentucky rode the passing arm of Dennis Tomek to a 2820 victory over Grambling today and advanced to the Camellia Bowl next week for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I football championship.

title: SENATE TO DEBATE WATERGATE BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The Senate will begin debate next week on three bills almost forgotten in the swirl of events surrounding the Watergate scandals.

title: Seton Hall Students Adopt World View
description: SOUTH ORANGEA former United States Ambassador to two African nations has found on his return to Seton Hall University that student interest in international affairs is quickenng.

title: The President and the Plumbers: A Look at 2 Security Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8For months President Nixon has been citing national security as the reason for authorizing establishment of the secret White House investigation unit known as the plumbers and as justification for restricting some aspects of the Watergate inquiry.

title: Jersey Photo Show Appoints Its Judge
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The judge in the first New Jersey Photography Competition and Exhibition next spring at Rutgers University will be Dr. Peter C. Bunnell of Princeton University.

title: Will We Have Enough Energy to Burn?
description: What I have called Project Independence 1980 a series of plans and, goals set to insure that by the end of this decade Americanswill not have to rely on any source of energy beyond Our ownPresident Nixon in a speech last Nov. 25.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Thirtyfive years ago one of my weekly chores in fall and winter was to walk a mile down the road to cut fire wood with Jimmy Greene, a small, wiry Portuguese farmer.

title: Country  Kitchen Supplies
description: CLIFTON  Oldfashioned countrykitchen cooking is becoming a holiday custom in North Jersey, according to Carmen J. Maggio, owner of the RoweManse Emporium and its fastexpanding Food Department. Most women shoppers, he claims, are bent on cooking everything from scratch, as their mothers or grandmothers did in their childhoods.

title: My Life On the Mississippi
description: In the good old golden days of English Bards and Scotch Reviewers, when authors and editors stalked one another with cudgels and horsewhips, it was the leisurely and genteel fashion to lard a review with generous quotations from the book in question, a fat sandwich between thin slices of asides, laudatory and otherwise, by the reviewer. This will no longer do, but I wonder how else to do justice to Richard Bissell's latest book.

title: C.M. Labor Pact in Canada
description: TORONTO, Dec. 8 (Reuters) A tentative agreement on a new threeyear contract was reached today between General Motors of Canada and the United Auto Workers. The agreement covers 23,000 workers at six plants in Ontario and one in Quebec. Details are being withheld pending a ratification vote next week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Humor is not always a laughing matter
description: Moon Mullins's name is a clever wordplay on mulley, a polled cow, usually hornless, and therefore a subtle reference to Moon's lack of sexuality. Kayo, who sleeps in a drawer, is clearly a Moses figure (the name Moses may derive from mosheh, he who draws out), while the clockstopping Emma has obvious historicoliterary antecedents Jane Austen's Emma.

title: The Chief Executive's Finances
description: WASHINGTONFor months, Richard Nixon has been trying to get the monkey of scandal off his back. He has tried just about everythingsilence, counterattack, small speeches of contrition, staff shakeups, meetings with members of Congress, press conferences, written statements. None has worked.

title: Diana Whittlesey to Wed June 15
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Dec. 8 Miss Diana Whittlesey and John Walton Tomford, thirdyear students at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, plan to be married June 15.

title: Arab Oil Aides Indicate End to Embargo in 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Two Arab oil ministers indicated today that they believed that the embargo on petroleum shipments to the United States and the Netherlands would lifted some time in 1974.

title: AROUND THE
description: Average readers probably would describe wildlife biologists as the men and women who go out into the vast open country to gaze at eagles, study wolf packs and stalk the wily grizzlies to save them from extinction. This they do, but there is more.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The facial resemblance is remarkable, even to the gap between the two front teeth. More important, the flashes of temper are almost identical. So are the sentimental moments, the voice that commanded, the manner that demanded and the ability to transfix an audience. Almost hauntingly, Ernest Borgnine, the actor, will portray the late Vince Lombardi in Legend in Granite on the American Broadcasting Company network Friday evening. The onehour television special concerns two years of decision in Lombardi's lifehis frustration as an assistant coach with the New York Giants, his takeover of the Green Bay Packers in 1959, his stay in Green Bay despite an offer to return to the Giants as, head coach. The future of each franchise was sculptured in those decisions. Eventual success for the Packers, eventual disaster for the Giants.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: White House Refuses To Join Study on News
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The White House said yesterday that it would be unable to join in any cooperative research study regarding the press and news broadcasting as urged by the National News Council.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: Dec. 10, 1973 ENACTED

title: ACCORD ON ULSTER REACHED AT TALKS BY THREE PARTIES
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  Britain, the Irish Republic and the moderate Protestant and Roman Catholic leadership of Northern Ireland agreed tonight on sweeping proposals for the tip ture of Ulster.

title: Job Outlook Good for June Engineering Graduates
description: Those graduating from college next June with engineering degrees will find the most favorable job market in years, according to a report released today on this spring's employnient outlook.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Advertising: Oil Effects Unclear
description: There is general agreement throughout the advertising industry that the petroleum shortage will have its effects on advertising, but complete confusion on what those effects will be.

title: Plant to Test Ore For Aluminum Use Opens in Colorado
description: A $1million pilot plant that may some day revolutionize the rawmaterial base of the United. States aluminum industry was dedicated Saturday at Golden, Colo.

title: Army Will Spend $200Million For Safer Type of Nerve Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The Army plans to spend at least, $200million producing a new type of nerve gas for its larger artillery shells. At the same time it will cost the Army about as much to destroy the munitions that the new nerve gas will replace.

title: To City, Stockbroker Was Only a Pauper
description: George K. Gutterman, a retired Army lieutenant colonel who was a stockbroker here, was nearly buried in a pauper's grave last month because city agencies failed to notify his family of his death, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

title: PASTEUR CENTER SEEKING RESCUE
description: Dr. Jacques Mooed, who won the Nobel Prize for his research in molecular biology, is devoting all his efforts to an attempt to rescue The Pasteur Institute, one of the world's leading centers for biomedical research, from possible bankruptcy.

title: The Rockydoggle
description: WASHINGTONThe way to become President of all the people, Governor Rockefeller has apparently decided, is first to become the candidate of all the people.

title: Student Commons Gives C.W. Post Campus an Uncommon Community Feeling
description: GREENVALE, L. I.It used to be a brownbaggers' school. Even with dormitories and the loveliest campus on Long Island, C. W. Post College was dominated by the blinking tail lights of the commuters, going for a hamburger, going for music, going home, just plain going.

title: Negligence Or Perfidy
description: John W. Davis, great figure of the bar in the first half of this century, once took part in an impeachment proceeding. He was a member of the House of Representatives when it impeached Judge Robert W. Archbald in 1912 and was one of the managers on the part of the House in the trial before the Senate.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Santa's a Big Man In Santa Claus, Ind.
description: SANTA CLAUS, Ind., Dec. 9Santa Claus has a Zip Code. It is 47579.

title: ISRAEL ENLARGES ATROCITY CHARGE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9Israel has charged that at least 42 Israeli soldiers taken prisoner in October were murdared by Syrian, Moroccan and Iraqi soldiers serving in Syria.

title: 2 IN JAMAICAN SECT SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: Two young men were shot to death and two others were wounded during a fight at house party in Brooklyn attended by different factions of the Rastifarians, a Jamaican sect, the police reported.

title: Human Rights Day
description: A quarter of a century ago most of the world's nations were climbing out of the ashes of war. Great dreams could be envisioned without cynicism; the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the U.N. General Assembly on Dec. 10,1948, reached beyond questions of war or peace and into the soul of mankind.

title: Paper Assails Wallace
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 9 (UPI)The Montgomery Advertiser charged today that Gov. George C. Wallace was just another loophole artist. ?? said he claimed a $30,000 tax deduction for giving his personal papers of his 1968 Presidential campaign to the state.

title: 3 LEADING CHINESE APPEAR TOGETHER
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 9Three topranking Chinese Communist officials, Chou Enlai, Chiang Ching and Wang Hungwen, appeared publicly together in Peking over the weekend in a display that may have been staged as a show of unity following speculation of a rift in their relationship.

title: Books of The Times
description: Why is the following a list of children's books for adults? Here's why. One children's book I admired particularly this year was I Do Not Like It When My Friend Comes to Visit, by Ivan Sherman (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich; $4.95). Having just survived an especially disastrous visit when I discovered it, I laughed out loud at its shrewd little commentary on sharing (My mother tells me I must learn how to share. Then my friend plays with all my toys, and I don't have any.), and I was sure that it must be one of the year's beat. But when I put it to the acid test, and the acid test (aged 4) listened grimly and said she hated it, I could see that this was a children's book for adults. And since I have not had a chance to put most of the following books to the acid test, I must assume that they too are chiladults.

title: Israel Said to Have Chosen Site for Golan Heights City
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 (Reuters) The newspaper Maariv reported today that an interministerial committee had decided on the location of the first Israeli city in the occupied Golan Heights of Syria.

title: FORD SUPPORTS NIXON ON TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Vice President Ford brushed aside today any suggestion that President Nixon had paid too little in income taxes during his years in the White House, saying that Mr. Nixon has followed the law.

title: Music
description: The Village Light Opera Group strayed from its regular Gilbert and Sullivan repertory Saturday night with a production of Offenbach's La Belle Hlne at the Fashion Institute Theater (there will be additional performances this weekend).

title: NASHVILLE TO USE WASTE FOR ENERGY
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 10A ma jor experiment In energy conservation, environmental protection and pollution control begins here late this month with the testfiring of the Nashville thermal transfer plant.

title: ACCORD ON ULSTER REACHED AT TALKS BY THREE PARTIES
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  Britain, the Irish Republic and the moderate Protestant and Roman Catholic leadership of Northern Ireland agreed tonight on sweeping proposals for the future of Ulster.

title: F.T.C. Says BristolMyers Made Deceptive Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) A Federal Trade Commission; judge ruled today that BristolMyers Company had falsely advertised Dri Ban antiperspirant spray as dry when in reality, it was wet, watery and runny.

title: Schwanda Is Sung by Opera Theater
description: SCHWANDA THE BAGPIPER, an opera in two acts by Jaromir Weinberger. Libretto by Milos Kares. English version by Ladislas Fiala. Staged by James Lucas. Sets designed by Lloyd Burlingame. Highting by Arthur Grand, costumes by Carol Luiken. Choreography by Diane Adler. Conducted by George Schick. Presented by the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music.

title: Bomb Rips Belfast House
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 9 (UPI)A bomb demolished a Belfast house owned by the Rev. Ian Paisley, a militant Protestant leader, early today. The house, bought recently and undergoing renovation, was vacant. No one was injured.

title: Hatfield Urges Expansion Of Amtrak in Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon said today that expanding the Governmentbacked Amtrak rail passenger system could help ease the energy crisis.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Every once in a while, baseball has its fashion counterpart. The current Tinkers to Evers to Chance play in the world of style is from Cartier to Kenton to Alexanders, and it involves a tank watch, designed more than 50 years ago.

title: Cyclone Hits Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 9 (UPI)A cyclone struck Bangladesh today, causing flooding and forcing people in lowlying areas to leave. There were no immediate reports of casualties.

title: U.A.W. RATIFIES PACT WITH G.M. BY 9 TO 1
description: DETROIT, Dec. 9 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers said today that its nearly 420,000 members at the General Motors Corporation had ratified a new threeyear contract agreement with the auto maker by a better than 9to1 margin.

title: Owners Decry Profit Cuts
description: As bad weather cut already light traffic in the metropolitan area and across the country on America's second gasless Sunday, representatives of gasolinestation owners gathered in Miami yesterday to plan a possible nationwide midweek shutdown next month, protesting the closings and other pressures on their profits.

title: Rev. Ronald Norris Dies; Passionist Missionary, 73
description: The Rev. Ronald Norris, director of the Institute of Chinese Culture in Washington and former director of public relations for the American branch of the Passionist Order, died Friday at Providence Hospital in Washington. He was 73 years old and lived in St. Michael's Monastery, Union City, N. J.

title: Bus Ridership Rises
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 9 (AP)Bus ridership here has increased sharply since President Nixon's energy speech, the publicly operated bus line said today.

title: 4 Million Venezuelans Voting in Presidential Election
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9  Venezuelans turned out in great numbers today to elect the President who will lead this key oilproducing country for the next five years.

title: Italian Newspapers, LittleRead and Unprofitable, Are Riven by Ownership Battles
description: ROME Dec. 9  The Italian press, usually as short on news as it is rich in rhetoric color, is itself in the news these day.

title: Bridge: Impromptu Combination Wins Mixed Par National Title
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 9 An impromptu combination of one of the world's great women players and one of New York's brightest young stars captured the mixed pair championship, the opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, here early today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A general alarm fire believed to have been set by vandals swept through a Salvation Army warehouse Atlantic City, destroying the interior of the onestory brick building and slightly injuring one fireman. Damage was estimated at $250,000. About 200 fire fighters from Atlantic City and neighboring communities fought the blaze.

title: 2 Dead in Malaysian Flood
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 9 (UPI)A state of emergency was declared on the east coast of West Malaysia in flooding from monsoon rains. Two persons were reported dead.

title: Carolina Bus Drivers Strike
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) Union and management representatives broke off negotiations on a new contract today as a strike of bus drivers went into effect against Carolina Trailways in North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, Delaware and Pennsylvania.

title: Film:'Don't Look Now,' a Horror Tale:Donald Sutherland and Julie Christie in Leads The Cast Suspense Yarn Turns Into a Travelogue
description: Nicolas Roeg's "Don't Look Now," which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater, is a fragile soap bubble of a horror film. It has a shiny surface that reflects all sorts of colors and moods, but after watching it for a while, you realize you're looking not into it, but through it and out the other side. The bubble doesn't burst, it slowly collapses, and you may feel, as I did, that you've been had.Not only do you probably have better things to do, but so, I'm sure, do most of the people connected with the film. These include Julie Christie and Donald Sutherland, who play a haunted young English couple, and maybe even Mr. Roeg, the director, who has staged a number of individual sequences with a lot of dash and style, but not enough to disguise the emptiness of the screenplay.This is credited to Alan Scott and Chris Bryant, who have taken a minor short story by Daphne Du Maurier and attempted, unsuccessfully, to elevate it into something on the order of "The Turn of the Screw."It doesn't work. The film takes its supernatural phenomena seriously, but the suspense depends on a twist that comes not at the end but about halfway through. At which point, "Don't Look Now" stops being suspenseful and becomes an elegant travelogue that treats us to second-sightseeing in Venice.For John Baxter, an art historian, (Mr. Sutherland) and his wife, Laura (Miss Christie) Venice is a city filling up with disasters as it sinks back into the sea. Unknown to John, though not to us, he is gifted with second sight. The film opens with an agonizing sequence in England when their five-year-old daughter drowns in a nearby pond, a fact that John senses without questioning why.In Venice, where John is working on the restoration of an ancient church, the Baxters encounter a pair of mysterious English biddies, one of whom has the "power." They cheer up Laura enormously by telling her they've been in touch with her dead daughter. They also warn John that danger awaits him if he stays in town.Actually this plays somewhat better than it tells. Mr. Roeg is able to maintain a sense of menace long after the screenplay has any right to expect it, largely because of the sincerity of his actors and because of the presence of the sinking city itself.Mr. Roeg, who was a cameraman before becoming a director with "Performance" (co-directed with Donald Cammell) and "Walkabout," gets a great performance from Venice, which is all wintery grays, blues and blacks, the color of the pigeons that are always underfoot.The one bit of color that registers on John is that of a brilliant red parka worn by a child who, from the back, looks just like his dead daughter. The figure appears to him at night, at the end of dark alleys or fleeing from something on the other side of the canal. John also has some other hallucinations that I dare not describe without giving away the plot.I can describe a beautifully photographed love scene between John and Laura, which is intercut  for essentially comic resultswith post coital scenes of the couple getting dressed for dinner afterward. The point, I guess, is that if you can see into the future, it's often difficult to keep your mind on the present, no matter what you're doing.One of the problems with "Don't Look Now" is that second sight does not easily translate as a terrifying talent for a film character to possess. It simply looks like a flash-forward, which, along with the flashback, the jumpcut and the fade, are standard story-telling devices in movies.

title: Jets and Redskins Lose
description: The Jets lost a 170 lead and a 2423 decision to the Eagles in a steady rain in Philadelphia yesterday. Joe Namath did not play and 31,333 paying fans did not show. In Irving, Tex., the Dallas Cowboys routed the Redskins, 277, and tied Washington for first place with a game to play. Details on Page 51.

title: Mrs. Mordecai Rochlin, 60, Led Hunter Welfare Fund
description: Mrs. Ruth Kane Rochlin, former president of the Hunter Scholarship and Welfare Fund and wife of Mordecai Rochlin, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. Her age was 60.

title: Yeshiva Lauds Belkin and Cites Senator Kennedy and 2 Others
description: Yeshiva University gave honorary degrees yesterday to three persons and honored Dr. Samuel Belkin on his 30th anniversary as president of the school.

title: Fresh Food for Salefor a Little Less
description: ELIZABETH, Dec. 9The lure of the openair market is as heady to its devoted followers as the scent of the fox to trained hounds. In addition to the hunt for the perfect pear, the unblemished apple and the alabaster cauliflower that nestles naturally in its green leafy basein short, the fresh unpackaged food that titillates the senses is the reward that accrues to the knowledgeable shopper.

title: New Drive by Saigon Troops On Highlands Town Reported
description: GIA NGHIA, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 (AP)South Vietnamese troops, who were reported to have recaptured the strategic Central Highlands district capital of Kien Duc Friday, pulled back today and then made a fresh assault, reports from the field said.

title: Litton Expects to Keep Typewriter Unit
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 9Executives of Litton Industries, Inc., now believe they will be able to retain the company's TriumphAdler typewriter operation, the annual stockholders meeting was told here yesterday.

title: Dickens and Strauss Entertain at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 9The dancers moved clockwise and the clocks moved backwards early this morning as men and women attired in the dress of Victorian England waltzed to the music of Strauss at the Christmas party of Princeton's Ivy Club.

title: Vital Talent Search
description: The start of Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's term office will coincide with the demise of the present Board of Higher Education. The law which Governor Rockefeller steamrollered through the last Legislature requires creation of a new, smaller governing body for the City University. Seven of its ten members are to be named by the Mayor, the remaining three by the Governor. Albany will for the first time be sharing in the City University's governance.

title: SKYLAB SURPRISED BY PARTIAL ECLIPSE
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)A partial eclipse of the moon took the Skylab 3 astronauts and others by surprise tonight.

title: Gunfire in Turkey Kills Five
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 9 (AP)Five persons were killed in exchanges of gunfire among political rivals today as Turks voted in local elections, officials said. More than 60,000 local officials, including mayors of the large cities, were up for election. Results were expected late tomorrow.

title: Rockefeller Shedding His Liberal Image
description: Governor Rockefeller has been using visits to hinterland Republican dinners in the last several months to present the dual message of a happy Republican warrior and a prodigal liberal willing to recant.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: NEW QUARTERLY DUE ON CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: The Civil Liberties Review, a new quarterly magazine de, voted exclusively to civilliberties articles, will publish its first issue next Saturday, according to an announcement yesterday by the publishers.

title: Taking Stock of Wolves
description: LUTSEN, Minn.The facts concerning the endangered timber wolf have become distorted and elusive as the wolf itself.

title: Pope's Carriage Runs Into Criticism
description: ROME, Dec. 9Pope Paul VI told the Romans today how greatly he enjoyed riding in a horsedrawn carriage through their autoless streets yesterday, but some public criticism showed that his austerity gesture, though crowdpleasing, had not been appreciated by everyone.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Report Criticizes
description: The Citizens Budget Commission urged New York City to expand its firefighting technology and sharply criticized the two unions representing firemen and fire officers for allegedly opposing increased productivity. In a 17page report, the commission says unions wield a great deal of power in the department and have all too often been able to veto important management improvements or to exact a high price for allowing such change, to be made. The charges were denied by the head of the Uniformed Fire Officers Union, Deputy Chief David M. McCormack.

title: Redskins, Falcons Still In Running for Playoff
description: Although the Washington Redskins lost to the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, they did not lose their chance to qualify for the playoffs. They can get there as the wildcard entry in the National Conference by defeating the Eagles in Washington next Sunday, assuming that the Cowboys beat the Cardinals in St. Louis,

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MAGYAR REVIVAL The Hungarian Quartet was a chamber group that held together for 38 years. For its last several years, the foursome constantly planned to dissolve the association because after all that time the travel had become something of a strain. In September, the Hungarian Quartet signed off.

title: ExLocal Coaches Not Looking Back
description: Year after year, metropolitan area college coaches bemoan the loss of basketball talent that finds success elsewhere.

title: Rangers Top Seals Here, 63
description: You would think the Rangers, on home ice, could easily dispatch a cellardwelling expansion team. But nothey had to exert themselves last night to beat the California Golden Seals, 63, at Madison Square Garden.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1973

title: Wilkins Urges Effort to Ease JewishBlack Tensions
description: Roy Wilkins, the civil rights leader, called on Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to start programs that would ease tensions between New Yorkers and improve the relationship between Jews and blacks.

title: Western Airlines Increases Passenger Traffic by 10%
description: Western Airlines' passenger traffic last month increased 10 per cent over the yearago period to 478million revenue miles, the company announced over the weekend. Contributing to this increase, it said, were strikes against Trans World Airlines and Pacific Southwest Airlines that reduced the amount of competitors' service on several Western routes.

title: HardPressed State Symphony Is Given Assurance of Support
description: MONTCLAIR, Dec. 9The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, beset by financial problems, received inperson assurantes of support today from an admiring audience here as the organization struggles for survival.

title: Israeli Errors on Eve of War Emerging
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9In the booklined library of the former Justice Ministry in downtown Jerusalem, a fiveman judicial commission has being taking topsecret testimony for the last two weeks from Cabinet ministers, intelligence specialists and Government officials.

title: Tennessee Williams Receives Centennial Medal of Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
description: Tennessee Williams, who merrily declined to he specific about whether he was a practicing Catholic or still an Episcopalian, yesterday receiyed the first centennial medal of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine as the foremost dramatist of our day.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 9 (AP)  Thirteenyearold Jenny Turrall of Sydney set a world women's swimming record in the 1,500meter freestyle tonight with a time of 16 minutes 49.9 seconds.

title: DRILLING ON COAST IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The Department of the Interior is expected to armounce shortly that it will allow the first exploratory oil drilling on Federal leases in the controversial Santa Barbara channel due west of the California city, according to senior Nixon Administration officials.

title: Gas Industry Hopes for Mild Winter as Shortage Grows
description: Midwest factory employes working in overcoats, plants being shut down for lack of fuel, school closings, gasoline and fuel rationing, emergency imports of oil, brownouts and blackouts, relaxation of air pollution standards and restrictions on new sales are all hard evidence of an energy crisis. Still, many are not aware of the sharply increased costs and real hardships ahead if appropriate action is not taken quickly.

title: Army Will Spend $200Million For Safer Type of Nerve Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The Army plans to spend at least $200million producing a new type of nerve gas for its larger artillery shells. At the same time, it will cost the Army about as much to destroy thee munitions that the new nerve gas will replace.

title: Rockefeller Shedding His Liberal Image
description: Governor Rockefeller has been using visits to hinterland Republican dinner's in the last several months to present the dual message of a happy Republican warrior and a prodigal liberal willing to recant.

title: Cowboys Rout Redskins, 277, and Tie Them for First
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 9The Washington Redskins ran out of fuel in Texas today as the Dallas Cowboys routed them, 277, in a game that should have been tense and exciting but fell short.

title: 2 Transit Policemen Wounded In Separate Attacks in Brooklyn
description: One probationary Transit Authority policeman was shot and critically wounded and another suffered a critical stab wound in two separate attacks in Brooklyn late Saturday and early yesterday, the police said.

title: Bruins Tie Flyers, Run Streak to 12
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Boston Bruins scored two goals in the final minute 22 seconds tonight, the last one by Phil Esposito with only 31 seconds left, and salvaged a 33 tie with the Phiadeiphia Flyers in the National Hockey League.

title: Nixon's Active Role on Plumbers: His Talks With Leaders Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 President Nixon played a far more active role in the secret operations of the White House plumbers than either he or witnesses before the Senate Watergate committee have reported.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTCLAIR, Dec. 9Aubrey Lewis's daddy used haul garbage in this town and Aubrey, when he was years old, once picked 71 cents out of the sewer gratings in front of the Bank of Montclair, I was a poor boy, he said by telephone recently, and I was a mischievous, thoughtless kid for a while. Then I got into some trouble at school and I saw my mother cry and I swore I'd never cause her to cry again. I began to realize that God had given me some ability and so I quit messing up and started paying attention.

title: Colts Upset Dolphins by 163; O.J. (219) Nears Rush Record
description: The Miami Dolphins, the defending Super Bowl champions of the National Football League, took a 10game winning streak and some other impressive credentials into yesterday's game against the Colts at Baltimore. They had held the Colts scoreless for 18 straight quarters since 1971 and had run up a 440 triumph earlier this season. The Colts had lost their last six games.

title: New Minority Leader John Jacob Rhodes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9A longtime observer of John Jacob Rhodes was not surprised last Friday when Republicans in the House of Representatives avoided the customary intraparty fight and elected the 11term Arizona Representative to clicceed Gerald R. Ford as minority leader.

title: Christmas Shopping List: A Liner at $12.1Million
description: Anyone with $12.1million to spare and a desire to own and operate the world's fastest passenger liner can become the owner of the 53,329ton superliner United States.

title: Helene Brownstein Wed
description: Miss Helene Brownstein and Alan Desatnick were married yesterday evening. Rabbi Elias Schwartz performed the ceremony in Temple Sholom in Brooklyn. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jack Brownstein of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Herman Desatnick of Rockaway Beach, Queens.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Aussie Girl Sets World Swim Mark

title: WilkesBarre Strike Ends
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Dec. 9 (A13)  Striking members of the International Typographical Union agreed today to return to their jobs at the WilkesBarre Publishing Company, a company spokesman said. The company, which publishes The Times Leader, Evening News Record, is scheduled to resume publication Tuesday morning.

title: Team of Trusted Aides Compiled Report on Nixon's Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9For the last three and a half weeks, two prominent tax lawyers, four White House aides and an accountant have been sealed in a conference room of the Executive Office Building sifting through mountains of the President's financial records.

title: Inflated Bag Tested To Save Jumpers In Building Blazes
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 9 (Ronters)  An airinflated plastic hag that could save the lives of people who leap from burning skyscrapers has been tested here by a film stunt man.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A building contractor was shot dead shortly after midnight, the apparent victim of a gangland executioner, as he sat at the wheel of his 1974 Cadillac on 59th Street near Dahill Road in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. The police said the victim, Luigi Monaco, 39 years old, of 2276 East 73d Street, Brooklyn, a principal in Dyker Homes, 1807 East 78th Street, Brooklyn, had been shot once in the head and three times in the back.

title: To City, Stockbroker Was Only a Pauper
description: George K. Gutterman, a retired Army lieutenant colonel who was a stockbroker here, was nearly buried in a pauper's grave last month because city agencies failed to notify his family of his death, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

title: COALITION FIGHTS LAW ON LOITERING
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 9 newly formed coalition of civil rights and black and Hispanic groups has begun a political and legal campaign to seek repeal of this city's recently enacted antiloitering law.

title: KISSINGER BEGINS BRUSSELS TALKS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 9  Secretary of State Kissinger began series of crucial, highlevel discussions with allied officials today on ways of dealing with disputes that have seriously strained America's ties with its European allies in recent months.

title: Woodcutters Must Call One of 2 State Offices
description: New Yorkers who want to arrange a woodcutting trip to the north can make arrangements at the following offices of the State Department of Environmental Conservation:

title: 38 Hurt on Essen Streetcar
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Dec. 9 (UPI)  The police reported today that 38 persons were injured when a streetcar overturned here. Two of them were injured seriously.

title: Carol Ann Hauptfuhrer Is Wed To Henry Grossman, Opera Tenor
description: The Church Center of the United Nations was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Carol Ann Hauptfuhrer of Philadelphia to Henry M. Grossman, opera tenor and journalistic photographer of New York. The Rev. Clifford Johnson performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Officials to Get Report
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Leading international oil companies have prepared a new, unpublished estimate of this country's expected fuels shortage that is appreciably lower than the Government's estimate.

title: Chicago Fire Kills Seven
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI)Fire broke out in a South Side apartment today, killing a woman along with four of her children and two grandchildren. She was identified as Mrs. Mamie Brown, 43 years old.

title: Theater: The Pajama Game Returns
description: THE PAJAMA GAME, a musical, based on the novel 7 Cents' by Richard Bissell. Book by George Abbott and Richard Bissell; music act lyrics by Richard Adler and Jerry Ross; originally choreographed by Bob Fosse; musical numbers staged by Zoe Leporska; setting by David Guthrie; lighting by John Gleason; musical direction by Joyce Brown; orchestrations by Don Walker; production directed by Mr. Abbott; John Allen, assistant to Mr. Abbott; stage managers, Bert Wood, Bob Bernard and Stan Page. Presented by Richard Adler and Mr. Wood, in association with Nelson Pelts. At the LuntFontanne Theater, West Beth Street.

title: Martha Deane, 65, Dies; WOR News Interviewer
description: Martha Deane, whose weekday news and talk shows on radio station WOR since 1941 had made her a familiar figure to the metropolitan audience, died of cancer yesterday at her home in the Royalton Hotel, 44 West 44th Street. She was 65 years old and in private life Mrs. Marian Young Taylor, wife of William Bolling Taylor, a retired advertising executive.

title: Eagles Overcome Jets, 2423, After Trailing, 170
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9Joe Namath, like many souls before him, spent a lost weekend in Philadelphia today, but the trip wasn't a complete waste for the quarterback who was knocked knocked out of the entire game by a sore right knee.

title: 4 Teams Advance In Soccer
description: After yesterday's turn of events, the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinals in Miami in early January will feature the Billikens, the Bruins, the Tigers and more Bruins.

title: THOMAS A. COFFEY
description: Thomas A. Coffey, a former investment broker with Shields & Co., died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 475 Park Avenue.

title: Jane Abramson Wed to James O'Connor
description: Miss Jane Ann Abramson, an assistant editor at The School Library Journal, was married here yesterday afternoon to James L. O'Connor, a promotional writer for Scholastic Magazines. Jerome Nathanson of the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony at Carlton House.

title: Officials to Get Report
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Leading international oil companies have prepared a new, unpublished estimate of this country's expected fuels shortage that is appreciably lower than the Government's estimate.

title: Debts Dog Mayoral AlsoRans
description: For the losers in an election contest, the campaign lingers on long after the last vote is counted. Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the West Side Democrat, is an example.

title: It's Almost Like Being At a Palace In France
description: That lineup of rooms filled with secondhand furniture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the closest thing to a French palace Fifth Avenue has to offer.

title: Bruins Tie Flyers, Run Streak to 12
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Boston Bruins scored two goals in the final minute 22 seconds tonight, the last one by Phil Esposito with only 31 seconds left, and salvaged a 33 tie with the Phiadelphia Flyers in the National Hockey League.

title: When Festival Is 10, Is It AvantGarde?
description: It all began, sort of, when Charlotte Moorman, a student at Juilliard, back then, deided she was very tired of playing a Kabalevsky cello piece and someone sugested she try John Cage's 26 minutes, 1.499 seconds for a String player, which among other things requires the performer to prepare and eat mushrooms.

title: Architect Ties Loss Of U.S. Contract To Gift Refusal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)The Washington StarNews reported today that a New York City architectural firm lost out on a $507,000 Federal contract shortly after its senior partner declined to make a substantial contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Connally, Seeking G.O.P. Base, May Find It in the South
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 9  John B. Connally's Republican honeymoon ended abruptly last Oct. 10  the day Vice President Agnew resigned  and party leaders as different as Governor Rockefeller of New York and Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona moved with quiet effectiveness to head off Mr. Connally's succession to the VicePresidency.

title: Owners Decry Profit Cuts
description: As bad weather cut already light traffic in the metropolitan area and across the country on America's second gasless Sunday, representatives of gasolinestation owners gathered in Miami yesterday to plan a possible nationwide midweek shutdown next month, protesting the closings and other pressures on their profits.

title: ARMY IS ASSAILED ON TOCKS POLICIES
description: MONTAGUE, Dec. 8About 175 residents of the Delaware River Valley complained to officials of the Army Corps of Engineers here last night about the landacquisition policies of the corps.

title: Laura Nagle Is a Bride
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Dec. 9Miss Laura Greer Nagle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander C. Nagle Jr., was married here today at the home of her parents, to Ensign Marc Burt Wilson, U.S.N.R. He is a son of Mrs. Henry Lewis Wilson of Oceanside, and the late Mr. Wilson. Village Judge Thomas Beasley performed the ceremoney. The couple will live temporarily at the Patuxent Naval Air Station in Maryland until Ensign Wilson reports for flight training in Pensacola, Fla.

title: Des Moines Paper at 40c
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 9 (UPI)The Des Moines Sunday Register announced today that it would increase its newsstand price by a nickel to 40 cents to meet the rising production costs.

title: Sports Today
description: Hedgemon Lewis vs. Johnny Grant, 10round welterweight tight, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street; first bout, 8 P.M.

title: Israeli Errors on Eve of War Emerging
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9In the booklined library of the former Justice Ministry in downtown Jerusalem, a fiveman judicial commission has being taking topsecret testimony for the last two weeks from Cabinet ministers, intelligence specialists and Government officials.

title: THREE IN RAPE CASE SENTENCED TO DEATH
description: TABORO, N.C., Dec. 9 (A)Three men were sentenced today to death in the gas chamber for rape. The sentence was pronounced in an unusual Sunday session in Edgecombe County Superior Court.

title: Athens Radio Cuts Off Speech By Archbishop From Cathedral
description: ATHENS, Dec. 9The voice of Greece's primate, Archbishop Ieronymos, was silenced overt the stateowned Athens radio today in a move that appeared to herald his ouster as head of the Orthodox Church of Greece.

title: TV Review
description: The Perry Como Winter Show, appearing tonight at 9 over the Columbia Broadcasting System, is mildly and reasonably pleasant. It's best when the star unpretentiously warbles some seasonal ballads, amid pretty, snowy settings, and the guest stars Sally Struthers, Burns and Schreiber and the Establishmentchime in without trying to raise the roof.

title: At Home, Ford Sheds Trappings of New Life
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Every morning at 6 o'clock, a White House courier delivers a special news summary to Vice President Ford's suburban Virginia home.

title: SECURITY PARLEY PINPOINTS ISSUES
description: GENEVA, Dec. 9Delegates to the European security conference are beginning to pack their bags as a recess approaches after three months of talks on ways to consolidate the improvements in EastWest relations.

title: A Soviet Western, Wherein the Devil Gets His Due
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9  The saga of the Devil, a lone, heavily armed bandit who plagued the western back country of Soviet Georgia, has ended in a police ambush that would have done justice to Bonnie and Clyde.

title: 10% PRIME RATE EXPECTED TO DROP
description: A Philadelphia banker last Friday characterized the increases to 10 per cent in the prime rate announced during the day as going the wrong way at the wrong time.

title: Deferring Clean Air
description: Neither technological obstacles nor the muchinvoked energy crisis can justify the House Commerce Committee in moving to give the automobile industry an additional year to meet cleanair standards. The committee's action carries indulgence even further than its Senate counterpart, which recently voted merely to extend the 1975 standards an additional year for two noxious emissions.

title: Sargent to End Gun Sales
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent will no longer sell handguns at his Cape Cod sporting goods store. The Massachusetts Governor said the handguns sold at his shop in Orleans were primarily for sportsmen who use them as sidearms while hunting. I just think we ought to get out of it, Mr. Sargent said today.

title: Estate and Trust Checks Aid Neediest Cases Fund
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund started its 62d annual appeal yesterday with $451,311.70 already donated by estates, trust funds and 346 mail contributors.

title: Nixon's Indebtedness in 1969 Put at More Than $1Million, Although He Had Up to $500,000 in Cash
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9President Nixon's financial records, released this weekend by the White House, show that during his first year in office Mr. Nixon's indebtedness ran to more than $1million.

title: Missing Girl Found Slain In a Syracuse Cemetery
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 9 (AP)A fivemonth search for a missing teenager ended here this weekend with the discovery of the decomposed body of Alicia Hauck, 16 years old, the police said.

title: War Is Not Peace
description: There is a truly astonishing projection of 1984 about the Nobel Peace Prize in 1973. Orwell warned us that the dreadful day would come when war would be called peace and peace, war. The Nobel Peace Prize committee's homage to the talents and goodwill of Le Duc Tho and Henry Kissinger for their skillful negotiations lasting more than three years led us at the American Friends Service Committee to wonder if it should be called the Nobel Negotiating Prize. But Peace Prize?

title: Personal Finance
description: One of the most common forms of gifts that husbands make to wives in a neverending quest to avoid taxes is life insurance.

title: Rashomon WellStaged By Equity Library Group
description: Rashomon as literary, theatrical and motionpicture material is proving to be highly durable. The story first came to the attention of Americans in 1952 in the magnificent Japanese movie, now seen fairly often on TV. In 1959 a good stage production, adapted by Fay and Michael Kanon from Ryunosuka Akutagawa's two stories, had one of the most gorgeous sets (by Oliver Messel) ever to steal a Broadway drama. This version, easily scaled down to basic props, has become a littletheater staple, and it is now being presented by the Equity Library Theater at Riverside 15rive and 103d Street.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: About New York
description: The dancers at the New York City Ballet ended their strike on Saturday and there was happiness once again at Lincoln Center. On the day the dancers had struck, there was a pall over the ballet, and it hung like a miasma, and it hung most deeply over Lincoln Kirstein. Even on his best days Mr. Kirstein is lugubrious, hut on the day the strike began he was somewhere beyond even that, and he had sat on a chair, his hands clasped, slightly bent over, the look of infinite sadness on his face.

title: Nixon Studies Proposals For New Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)  President Nixon examined today proposals for a national health insurance plan that would pay most medical bills about $150 a year and all of the costs beyond $1,500.

title: EXCHANGE URGES BROKER RESERVES
description: The New York Stock Exchange has started a drive for new tax legislation designed to encourage stockbrokers and securities dealers to set up reserves to help get through lean times.

title: Jets and Redskins Lose
description: The Jets lost a 170 lead and a 2423 decision to the Eagles in a steady rain in Philadelphia yesterday. Joe Namath did not play and 31,333 paying fans did not show. In Irving, Tex., the Dallas Cowboys routed the Redskins, 277, and tied Washington for first place with a game to play. Details on Page 51.

title: Arabs Set New Oil Cutback
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9 Arab oil ministers today ordered a new cutback in oil production of about 750,000 barrels a day to begin Jan. 1, but promised quick relief from their embargo if Israel agreed to withdraw from occupied Arab lands.

title: 2 AIDES UNDERLINE ARABISRAELI GAP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The Oil Minister of Saudi Arabia and the Defense Minister of Israel, appearing separately in television interviews, today underlined the chasm that separates the Arab states and Israel 10 days before the expected opening of the Geneva peace conference.

title: French Skiing Continues Downhill as Six Stars Are Dismissed
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 9 (AP) The French Alpine ski team, once the most powerful in the world but recently torn by dissension, dismissed six of its stars today to renew and rejuvenate the squad.

title: To Achieve Security
description: Perhaps the biggest danger in the coming season diplomatic maneuver between Israel and its Arab neighbors will be the temptation to view concession as a sign of weakness, instead of a means to achieve a clearly perceived and desired goal.

title: Princeton's Ivy Club Moves Backward To Strauss Tune and Dickens Rhythm
description: PRINCETON, Dec 9The dancers moved clockwise and the clocks moved backwards early this morning as men and women attired in the dress of Victorian England waltzed to the music of Strauss at the Christmas party of Princeton's Ivy Club.

title: GEN. O. F. LASSITER, LED EXECUTIVE JET
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. (AP)Brig. Gen. O. F. Lassiter, U.S.A.F, retired, founder of Executive Jet Aviation, a jettaxi service, died Thursday in Rome of a brain tumor. He was 55 years old.

title: Crash at Moscow Airport, With 13 Deaths, Reported
description: MOSCOW, Dec, 9 (AP)A Soviet jetliner crashed short of the runway on landing at a Moscow airport today, killing 13 persons, unofficial Soviet sources reported.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Vladimir Nabokov has been named the recipient of the National Book Committee's 1973 National Medal for Literature, which is conferred annually to a living American writer for the excellence of his or her total contribution to letters. The award, endowed by the Guinzburg Fund in memory of Harold K. Guinzburg, founder of the Viking Press and an organizer of the National Book Committee, will be increased this year from $5,000 to $10,000. The medal is an inscribed bronze medallion, designed by Leonard Baskin.

title: PRINCE KARL VIKTOR
description: Prince Karl Viktor zu Wied, son of Prince William of Wied who was briefly sovereign prince of Albania before World War I, died Saturday in Munich, where he had been living, according to word received from a spokesman for the family.

title: BUENOS AIRES FIRE SWEEPS 4 BLOCKS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 (AP) Explosions set off a huge and residential district of the Argentine capital tonight. Flames shot hundreds of feet into the air and the blaze swept through at least four city blocks.

title: College Results
description: HOCKEY

title: The Piano Mastery of Alicia de Larrocha
description: The idea of an entire piano recital devoted to the music of Enrique Granados could have been carried off only by Alicia de Larrocha. Yesterday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall, the Spanish pianist showed what a master of the instrument can do to make admittedly limited music constantly absorbing.

title: Panel Urges City Expand FireFighting Techniques
description: The Citizens Budget Commission urged the city yesterday to expand its firefighting technology and sharply criticized the two unions representing firemen and fire officers for allegedly opposing increased productivity.

title: SIDNEY L. CULLEN
description: ROCKLAND, Me., Dec. 9 Sidney L. Cullen, publisher of the triweekly Rockland CourierGazette, died yesterday in Knox County General Hospital here. He was 66 years old.

title: PRESIDENT'S TAX POSES EASY ISSUE, TWO ON PANEL SAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Two Republican members of the Congressional committee that will review President Nixon's tax returns said today that they thought the matter was a relatively simple one that could be 1. It largely to the committee's staff.

title: RIGHTS UNIT BACKS MILK CONSUMERS
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 9The South Carolina Council for Human Rights, whose past reputation was built on its opposition to racial and sexual discrimination, has broadened its role and is fighting for the state's milk consumers.

title: Transit Workers Will End 7Day Strike in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (UPI) Striking trolley and bus operators voted today to return to work tomorrow, ending their sevenday walkout.

title: Eleanor Lawrence, Flutist, Remarries
description: ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Dec. 9 Mrs. Eleanor Baker Lawrence of New York, a flutist, was married here this afternoon to Frank O. Steindler of New York, a stockbroker with Sartorius & Co. The Rev. Dr. Calvert Ellis, a Brethren minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Station to Pay Its Fine With Gasoline Giveaway
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9 (UPI)A gas station owner, ordered by the Internal Revenue Service to refund $1,200 in overcharges to motorists, said today he would give away 3,000 gallons of gasoline tomorrow instead.

title: Record Rainfall in the City Dampens Spirit of Christmas Future
description: A Scrooge of a storm swept through the New York metropolitan area, yesterday, rattling windowpanes, flooding streets, dropping a record amount of rain that washed out noble ventures into preChristmas festivity.

title: Business Is Optimistic on Economy
description: American businessmen are generally looking ahead to a good year for the economy in 1974, despite the problems expected because of the energy shortage. But they are solidly opposed to any form of gasoline rationing and are maintaining their traditional posture against wage and price controls.

title: Riding Meet Is Captured By Hawley
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9Sandy Hawley, who last Thursday broke Willie Shoemaker's record of 485 triumphs in a season, won the first North American Riding Championship today at rainswept Suffolk Downs.

title: Rangers Top Seals Here, 63
description: You would think the Rangers, on home ice, could easily dispatch a cellardwelling expansion team. But nothey had to exert themselves last night to beat the California Golden Seals, 63, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Levitt Scores City On Improper Use Of Official Autos
description: Despite restrictions ordered by Mayor Lindsay in 1966, State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that 65 of 168 city passenger cars were improperly assigned.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Landlord Group Sues City Over Delayed Rent Rises
description: A major landlord group announced yesterday that it had begun court action to force immediate city approval of a large backlog of rentrise applications submitted by owners who had made significant improvements in their rentcontrolled buildings.

title: Party at Kilometer 101 Is International Event
description: TEL AVIV, Dec, 9 (Reuters)Soviet Army officers joined Israeli and Egyptian officers on the CairoSuez road todayfor a party.

title: Planning Controversy in India Intensifies as Economist Quits
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 9  The resignation of a key Government economist has stirred major controversy in New Delhi and brought to light an emerging dispute over India's planning policies in the next five years.

title: PRESIDENT'S TAX POSES EASY ISSUE, TWO ON PANEL SAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Two Republican members of the Congressional committee that will review President Nixon's tax returns said today that they thought the matter was relatively simple one that could be left largely to the committee's staff.

title: Bengals Conquer Browns, 3417
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 9Isaac Curtis, a wide receiver who is now probably the fastest player in the National Football League caught three touchdown passes today as the Cincinnati Bengals moved toward their second Central Division title in the American Conference with a 3417 victory over the Cleveland Browns.

title: 19th Time to Beat Celtics
description: TORONTO, Dec. 9 (UPI) Bob McAdoo established two Buffalo Braves' records by sinking 21 field goals and 49 points but that wasn't enough tonight to keep the Boston Celtics from scoring a 118114 victory.

title: People Give Up Power To Permit Yule Lights
description: RUIDOSO, N.M., Dec. 9This mountain resort will light its Christmas street decorations Friday as scheduled because residents have volunteered to use no electricity, except for heating, for one day to compensate for the energy needed to keep the lights glowing.

title: PRODUCT SAFETY STIRS MANY CALLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Three thousand calls a day stream into the office of the Consumer Product Safety Commission on its tollfree line from worried consumers seeking information on what products are unsafe to have around the home.

title: Hughes Preps for His Job By Attending Court Session
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, sporting a recently grown mustache, sat in the back of the courtroom as the New Jersey Supreme Court began one of its recent biweekly court sessions.

title: BLUE CROSS CITEDON BOOKKEEPING
description: Assemblyman Andrew Stein charged yesterday that Blue Cross had ignored an internal audit that found $3million worth of questionable payments to 24 hospitals in 1971 and had done nothing to monitor payment procedures as recommended by the audit.

title: Red Smith
description: In 20 sinless years as a ballplayer in the majors, Joe Cronin was a good enough shortstop, but it was his bat that got him into the Hall of Fame, not the way he handled hot grounders by Babe Ruth or Al Simmons. Today he can't handle the shots Charley Finley hits his way. How much can an infielder slow down without taking root?

title: Building Boom in Moscow Is for 1980 Olympics
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9  On a gentle knoll on the east flank of Moscow across a manmade lake from the pine groves of Izmailovo Park, there now rises a $42million sports complex that symbolizes Moscow's hopes for hosting the 1980 Olympic Games.

title: Only on Sunday?
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's latest brainstormhalffare round trips on all M.T.A. subways, buses and commuter trains on Sundays, starting next Sundayseems such an obvious good deal for the public, for the metropolis and for the authority itself that the question immediately arises: Why only on Sunday?

title: CITY SCHOOLS CHECK STAFF FOR ARRESTS
description: After a ninemonth delay, the school system's personnel department has recently started reviewing the applications of some 10,000 city teachers for any records of arrests or convictions.

title: DIAMOND RESIGNS TO JOIN GOVERNOR
description: Henry L. Diamond officially resigned as State Environmental Conservation Commissioner yesterday to become executive director of Governor Rockefeller's Commission on Critical Choices for Americans.

title: The Rich Prepare to Get Through the Energy Crisis, Somehow
description: Multimillionaire Charles Revson is not exactly down in the dumps, but what with the fuel shortage he honestly doesn't know what to do about Ultima II, his luxurious 257foot, 1,200ton yacht.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the forthcoming increasedfare structure for the New York City Transit System two significant revisions, for the sake of equity and efficiency, respectively, ought to be incorporated: First, a universal free transfer throughout the system, so no one has to pay more than one fare to reach his destination from any point in the city; second, a reduced fare for nonrush hour use, to spread the load and increase the effective capacity of the system without major additional investment.

title: Many Companies Revising Maternity Leave Policies
description: Ever since the Federal Government decreed that pregnancy was not unlike a broken leg, many corporations have been struggling to revise their maternity leave policies. According to a survey just conducted by PrenticeHall with the American Society for Personnel Administration, sweeping changes are being made though confusion still reigns.

title: Cambodian Opposition Says Government Is Shaky but Won't Fall
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 9Influential leaders in the political opposition inside and outside the Government of President Lon Nol say the Government seems increasingly ineffective in dealing with the worsening military and economic conditions in the country.

title: Harry M. Stevens 2d, Caterer For Sports Events, Dies at 64
description: MIAMI, Dec. 9  Harry M. Stevens 2d, chairman of the board and treasurer of Harry M. Stevens, Inc., caterers at sporting events, died last night at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 64 years old and lived at 25 Indian Creek Island. He also had a home at Cape Cod, Mass.

title: Arabs Set New Oil Cutback
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9 Arab oil ministers today ordered a new cutback in oil production of about 750,000 barrels a day to begin Jan. 1, but promised quick relief from their embargo if Israel agreed to withdraw from occupied Arab Ilands.

title: Broncos Win, Will Face Raiders in Title Contest
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 9In a game overflowing with spectacular plays on both sides, the Denver Broncos today beat the San Diego Chargers, 4228, and set up a showdown at Oakland next Sunday for a National Football League division championship and playoff berth,

title: Shells in Rail Car Explode
description: OXNARD, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) A Southern Pacific freight car loaded with primed shell casings blew up today, scattering debris over several hundred yards, the railroad said. No injuries were reported. The freight car was destroyed, but the train did not derail.

title: Rousseau Enjoys Ranger Role, but ...
description: Whenever the New York Rangers get a power play at Madison Square Garden, thousands of Bobby Rousseau's fans set up a rhythmic chant: RousSEAU! RousSEAU! They want to see the utility man play the right point because they admire his artistry in passing to open men and setting up a score, as he did twice Sunday night in the 63 victory over California. They also like his elusive skating when, on occasion, he carries in the puck for a pass nearer the net.

title: G.O.P. Watergate Woes Typified in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 10If Pennsylvania is still a fair guide to the political balance in the country, the Republican party faces a national Watergate disaster in major elections next year.

title: Treasury Bills Mixed At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Yields on United States Treasury bills rose for threemonth bills and fell for sixmonth bills in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: What Play Will Namath Call: Retire, Sign Again or Jump?
description: Fans who watch the Jets game with Buffalo at Shea Stadium next Sunday will see O. J. Simpson most likely break Jim Brown's rushing record and Weeb Ewbank coach his last game for the Jets. Will they also see Joe Namath play his last game for the Jets?

title: Savings Bonds to Pay 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)The White House announced today that the interest rate on United States Savings Bonds was being increased to 6 per cent to make the bonds more attractive to investors. The increase will be retroactive to Dec. 1. Both old and new bonds will benefit from the higher interest.

title: Ohio Doctor Wounded by Gunman in Hotel Here
description: A 53yearold Ohio anesthesiologist was shot and critically wounded in his 19thfloor room at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday afternoon, apparently during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: Pittsburgh Transit Moving
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP)The city's 1,700 bus and trolley drivers returned to work today.; ending a crippling weeklong mass transit strike. The walkout ended with an agreement between Port Authority Transit and Division 85 of the Amalgamated Transit Workers.

title: Prices Rise Again on Amex and OTC
description: Prices rose again hut trading slackened on both the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three New York detectives were arrested yesterday on charges that they had taken a $3,000 bribe to go easy on a husband and wife they apprehended with more than 100 cartons of smuggled, untaxed cigarettes.

title: High Court Actions
description: CIVIL SERVICE

title: For a Sculptor and His Friends: A Place to Live, a Place to Work
description: BARCELONA, SpainTaxi drivers rarely know the way to the Calle Monserrat in the unfashionable suburb of Esplugas de Llobregat, which climbs a hill just outside of Barcelona.

title: Plans Dismasted
description: Plans to build Courageous, a 12Meter yacht for defense of the America's Cup this summer, were abandoned yesterday because of financial considerations. A second new Twelve, Mariner, will be built.

title: TOURISTS LEAVE GROUNDED LINER
description: FORT LAUDERALE, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP)The party ended today for 606 passengers aboard the grounded luxury liner FedericoC. They were ferried ashore in a flotilla of small boats.

title: Jaworski Receives Tapes, Including Two Cox Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Presidential tape recordings and documents, a point of explosive confrontation between the former Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and President Nixon, have begun to flow to Mr. Cox's successor, Leon Jaworski.

title: LYLE KING, LEADER IN PORT AUTHORITY
description: A. Lyle King, director of marine terminals for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey since 1952, died yesterday of a heart attack in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 67 years old and lived at 1064 Bay Head Drive, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Books of The Times
description: WINTER IN CASTILLE by Honor Tracy. 181 pages. Random House. $5.95. TAJOS by Ronald Fraser, 285 pages. Pantheon. $7.95.

title: Jersey Democrats Name A Black Assembly Speaker
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The overwhelming Democratic majority in the newly elected New Jersey Assembly tonight unanimously chose S. Howard Woodson, a 57yearold black Baptist minister here, to be Assembly Speaker.

title: Ulster Accord Acclaimed But Big Test Is to Come
description: LONDON, Dec. 10  When Prime Minister Heath went before the House of Commons this afternoon to report on the hardwon agreement reached yesterday over Northern Ireland, he was showered with congratulations from both sides of the floor.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BURLINGTON, Ky., Dec. 10 (AP)A driver and a trainer were indicted today by the Boone County grand jury in connection with the alleged fixing of a harness race on Nov. 9 at Latonia Race Course.

title: END TO CURBS ASKED ON GAS AT WELLHEAD
description: The natural gas industry remains convinced that removal Iof price controls at the wellhead would be the single most Important step which can be taken now to ease natural gas supply problems, Herbert D. Clay, chairman of the Amerjean Gas Association, said here yesterday.

title: Rites for Dr. Nixon Friday
description: There will he a memorial service for Dr. Russell A. Nixon on Friday at 1 P.M. at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University, Broadway at 117th Street. Dr. Nixon, who died Saturday, was a protessor at the Columbia School of Social Work and an editor of the quarterly Science and Society.

title: Campaign On to Alter Recruiting
description: The ugly hand of illegal basketball recruiting came under attack yesterday by metropolitan area college coaches, the Eastern College Athletic Conference and black community leaders.

title: 10 REPORTERS NAMED FOR CAPITAL STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)  Ten reporters from around the country have won Washington Journalism Center fellowships for 1974 providing them with five months of public affairs reporting experience in the nation's capital and a $4.200 stipend.

title: Checks to Neediest Replace Yule Gifts
description: A favorite and growing custom of friends of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is to make contributions to the cause in lieu of Christmas cards or gifts.

title: U.S. UNIT TO STUDY PRUNE RATE RISE
description: The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday requested to large commercial banks which have raised their prime or base lending rate to 10 per cent to justify the increases.

title: Michigan Compensatory Education Program Hailed
description: LANSING, Mich.The State of Michigan is claiming exceptional success for an unusual program for helping children who are seriously behind in school.

title: Stocks Again Gain In a Late Rebound
description: The stock market broke its blue Monday jinx of losing sessions yesterday as it extended the strong rally that got under way late last week. Trading activity was moderate.

title: MANILA TO OVERSEE ALL OIL OPERATIONS
description: MANILA, Dec, 10The Govailment announced today it was assuming control and supervision over all crude oil and petroleum products, including those produced by the foreign oil companies here.

title: RIGHTS MANIFESTO IS RAILED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10Diplomats commemorated the 25th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights today with speeches pointing to evidences of continuing religious and racial persecution.

title: Action in SeveredHead Case Defended
description: The Health Services Administration, in a report to Mayor Lindsay, that contradicted previous statements by some persons involved in the case, asserted yesterday that the Medical Examiner's office had acted appropriately when it severed the head of an unidentified woman who was believed to have drowned in the East River in 1971.

title: The New St. John's: A Community Catalyst
description: Worshipers wound through the cavernous Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on a recent Sunday, shaking tambourines, singing plainsong and watching medieval mystery plays.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Retail sales held essentially flat in November at the October level, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures. Last week the original estimate for Octoberwhich had shown a strong increase of 2 per cent in retail sales over Septemberwas revised downward. Now the October figure shows an increase of slightly more than 1 per cent.

title: Hockey Scoring
description: WORLD ASSOCIATION

title: American Federation of Teachers President Is Asked to Quit
description: The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers has formally asked David Selden to resign immediately as president of the 400,000member union.

title: MRS. DAVID H. STEVENS
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 10 Mrs. Ruth Davis Stevens, wife of David H. Stevens, former director of humanities at the Rockefeller Foundation in New York, died here Saturday at the Bellin Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Ephriam.

title: Stocks Continue Gain
description: The stock market extended yesterday the strong rally that began last week. The DowJones industrial average bounded in afternoon trading to finish at 851.14, a gain of 13.09 points. This brought the total advance in the last three sessions to nearly 63 points. Page 63.

title: Medical School Site Picked
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger announced today that the Bethesda Naval Hospital grounds had been selected as the site for a medical school for military doctors. The new university is expected to begin turning out 100 new physicians annually by 1982.

title: OilShort Europe Is Facing Hardest Winter Since War
description: LONDON, Dec. 10The most difficult winter since World War II is in prospect for Westem Europe, and Britain in particular, as the energy crisis intensifies.

title: GEORGE L. SMITH 2D
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP) George L. Smith 2d, speaker of the Georgia House for 11 of the last 15 years, died yesterday of a stroke at a hospital here. His age was 61.

title: Some Eagle Ticket Prices Soar
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Eagles announced today that ticket prices for 28,860 seats at Veterans Stadium would cost more in 1974 while prices on 9,664 would decrease.

title: Nixon Filed $80,000 Deduction In '68 for Congressional Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10President Nixon presented a collection of official papers to the Government shortly before entering the White House, valuing them at $80,000 as a deduction on his 1968 tax return.

title: Checking Up on the Snoopers
description: In the rush of more spectacular news, it escaped public notice that the Senate recently took a small step toward closing a large loophole Congress had opened in the Fourth Amendment rights of American citizens. A nice bit of political footwork by Senator Sam Ervin, chairman of the constitutional rights subcommittee, should at least make the supervisors of Federal narcotics agents keep their men on a tighter rein.

title: CONFEREES BACK DAYLIGHT SAVING NOW LIKELY JAN. 6
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation that could put the nation on yearround daylight saving time as early as Jan. 6 to conserve energy.

title: 186 VENDERS SUED OVER KICKBACKS
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The state filed an antitrust suit today against 186 companies and 24 former Hudson County and Jersey City officials, seeking more than $500million in damages as a result of an alleged kickback system that officials say operated between 1957 and 1971.

title: PUBLIC WILL DECIDE A.B.C. MUSIC AWARDS
description: Public balloting will deter mine the winners of popular music awards for an American Broadcasting Company special on Feb. 19. The special, to originate in Hollywood with Steve Lawrence as host, will run for 90 minutes.

title: Museum Board Hears Cameron Issue Today
description: The cases for and against Duncan F. Cameron, director of the Brooklyn Museum, will be presented today in an extraordinary proceeding that will lead to his dismissal or retention as director of the country's seventh largest museum.

title: $500,000 Pledged For Police Career
description: A Police Department anticorruption team in Brooklyn is handing out an insurance policy that promises all patrolmen a minimum guaranteed income of $500,000.

title: Hockey Transaction
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Fine Musicianship Of Soho Ensemble Starts New Season
description: There is a good deal of music to be heard in Soho (the area south of Houston Street), but most of it is so highly experimental that an average audience might not recognize it as music at all.

title: California Official Disputes White House Tax Report
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI)  A California tax offiical disputed today a White House contention that President Nixon's lawyers had consulted state officials on whether the President was required to pay state income taxes.

title: Corporate Profile
description: What makes Airco, Inc., so attractive?

title: FOOD COMPANIES SCORED ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10An official of the Federal Trade Commission told a Senate subcommittee today that monopolistic practices were a significant cause of recent increases in the costs of the nation's food.

title: Bridge: Adds to His Record For Master Point Totals
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 10 The world's greatest collection of master points seemed likely to get, even bigger at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Barry Crane of Los Angeles, one of the leaders going into the final sessions of the life master men's pair, had gained more than 16,000 points in his career, and was piling them up faster than ever before.

title: Sewage Sludge Nears L.I. Beach
