description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Senator Claiborne Pell introduced legislation today to repeal the 1962 Congressional resolution against Cuba.

title: Locks Bring Back the Key
description: GRINNELL, Iowa, Dec. 12 (UPI)Grinnell College officials replaced 376 locks yesterday on doors in eight student dormitories at a cost of $1,800 of a master key was, stolen last Saturday. A few hours later the missing master key was secretly returned.

title: DURYEA AND G.O.P. LEADER OF ASSEMBLY ARE INDICTED ON VOTESIPHONING COUNT
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and the Assembly Republican Majority leader, John E. Kingston, were indicted yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury investigating an alleged Republican votesiphoning scheme.

title: WITNESS IS NAMED IN KICKBACK SUIT
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12Bernard J. Murphy, former purchasing agent for Jersey City, has been identified by police sources as the key government witness in the multimilliondollar antitrust action filed this week by the state against 186 companies and 24 former Hudson County and Jersey City officials.

title: Anglicans and Catholics Reach Accord on Ministry
description: An international commission of Anglican and Roman Catholic scholars announced yesterday that it had reached basic agreement on the nature of the priesthood and the ministry of laymen.

title: 4th Graders Dream Of Mayoral Power
description: All around the five boroughs, the changeover at City Hall is a current event to school children, many of them so young that four years is a geological age and any time when Mayor was not automatically followed, by Lindsay is beyond conscious memory.

title: Tunisia Approves Pipeline
description: TUNIS, Dec. 12 (UPI)Chedli Ayari, the Tunisian Economics Minister, signed an agreement today with Raffaele Girotti, president of Italy's Enze Nazionale Idrocarburi oil concern, on the construction and exploitation of a natural gas pipeline on Tunisian territory. The pipeline, 1,550 miles long, will link Algeria oil and gas fields with Italy via Sicily.

title: Exxon Is Said to Agree to Pay $10Million Argentine Ransom
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 (Reuters)The Exxon company's affiliate in Argentina has agreed to pay a record $10million ransom demanded by guerrillas for the release of a kidnapped American executive, Victor S. Samuelson, knowledgeable sources said here today.

title: Santa Talks to Deaf With Sign Language
description: ABILENE, Tex., Dec. 12 (AP)  Santa's fingers moved quickly. No one heard except the two toddlers seated on his knee, but it was the sound of joy for them.

title: Light Quake on Coast
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)  A light earthquake rolled through Sohoma County yesterday but its intensity of 2.2 on the Richter Scale was too low for an epicenter reading. It was the 15th onshore quake of between 2.0 and 4.7 magnitude to shake northern California since May.

title: MOVE HELD UNLIKELY AGAINST OIL GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  A Justice Department spokesman said today that the antitrust division could not support a legislative proposal to require a breakup of the vertically integrated petroleum industry.

title: Realty Company Asks $100Million Bias Damages
description: A $100million damage suit was filed yesterday against the Federal Government by the Trump Management Corporation on the ground that irresponsible and baseless charges had, been made against the realty Company.

title: Vesco's Residence Visa Is Revoked by Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 (UPI) The Argentine Government said today that it had revoked the residence visa granted to the fugitive United States financier, Robert L. Vesco, and had dismissed the Immigration Department official who ordered it issued.

title: Soviet Plan for 1974 Promises Faster Rise in Consumer Sector
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12The Soviet leadership, signaling continuing interest in reduction of EastWest tensions, disclosed today a scaleddown economic plan for 1974 that promises increased growth in the consumer sector and a slight cutback in the formal military budget.

title: CON EDISON SEEKS 22% RATE INCREASE
description: The Consolidated Edison Company the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to raise electric rates by 22.6 per cent over the next two years.

title: ROCKEFELLER MOVE CALLED G.O.P. GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12, Members of New York State's Republican Congressional delegation said today that despite its drawbacks, Governor Rockefeller's resignation would strengthen the state Republican party.

title: Brooklyn Museum Meeting Reaches No Decision on Cameron
description: After a meeting of more than nine hours, lasting from Tuesday afternoon until early yesterday morning, the governing committee of the Brooklyn Museum failed to decide whether Duncan F. Cameron, the museum's director, would be retained or dismissed.

title: C. & N. W. Orders Rail Cars
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (UPI) The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company has placed an $18.6million order. for the construction of 1,000 new 100ton covered hopper cars. The cars, to be built by the PullmanStandard division of Pullman, Inc., of Chicago, will increase the railroad's total of highcapacity covered hopper cars to 2,000. The first 1,000 were delivered earlier this year. Delivery of the new 4,700cubicfoot cars will begin in October. 1974.

title: U.S.O., Friend in Need
description: The U.S.O. provides a wholesome and healthful center for entertainment and relaxation of the more than two million men and women in the armed forces around the world. But it does more than this. It has been, since the outset of World War II, one of this country's best ambassadors of goodwill. It has been recognized by the Department of Defense for its record of no major incidents of any kind, among servicemen in any facility around the world.

title: A Family Portrait: It Takes From Dawn to Dusk
description: If the family is trembling on the brink of extinction, as the doomsayers are predicting, there is no evidence of it in the work of Peter Simon.

title: Sports Today
description: Columbia vs. Fordham and Manhattan vs. Rhode Island, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. First game. 7 P.M.

title: Paratore Brothers Display Virtuosity As 2Piano Team
description: If there is a resurgence of interest in twopiano teams, as there seems to be, the Paratore brothers should find an important place in today's concert world. Anthony, 28 years old, and Joseph, 24, who are from Boston, made their debut in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday night.

title: Harry Vesell, Cardiologist For Nearly 50 Years, Dies
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 12 Dr. Harry Vesell, a cardiologist who retired two years ago after almost 50 years of practice in New York, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 74.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN SUFFER SETBACK
description: After rising sharply in early trading, prices of farm products futures fell back under profit taking yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Dollar Weakens Slightly In European Dealings
description: LONDON, Dec, 12 (UPI)The dollar weakened slightly against the main European currencies in quiet dealings today.

title: International Industries Reports Loss
GOING OUT Guide
description: CAMPUS KICKER The Princeton Triangle Club has made a virtue of constancy; at any rate, its coming up for the 84th time with its annual stage caper. The show, which opened last spring at its home base in Jersey, starts its ninecity tour here in New York with a oneshot at 8 tonight in the Kauffmann Auditorium of the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A., at 1395 Lexington Avenue.

title: MITCHELL LINKED TO A MILK INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Federal investigators have received reports that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell blocked a criminal antitrust Investigation of a giant dairy cooperative that donated $202,000 to President Nion's campaign.

title: Bridgeport Is Dropping ZincAlloy Shipments
description: The Bridgeport Brass Company announced yesterday it was discontinuing the shipment of zincbearing alloys immediately.

title: Ramblin Robyn and Robyn Smith a RipRoaring Combination
description: Diamonds may be a lazy girl's best friend, but give Robyn Smith a horse who can finish fast.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP)Dick Vermeil, offensive coordinator for the Los Angeles Rams, was named today as head football coach at University of California, Los Angeles. Vermeil, 37 years old, was with the Rams for four years under three head coaches, George Allen, Tommy Prothro and Chuck Knox. At U.C.L.A., he replaces Pepper Rodgers, head man the last three years, who left last week to take a similar post at Georgia Tech.

title: 38 More Food Places Listed As City Health Code Violators
description: The Health Services Administration has announced the names of 38 more restaurants and food stores that have violated the health code.

title: Treasury Bills Fell In $1.8Billion Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The average rate on one year Treasury bills fell today to 6.881 per cent from 7.708 per cent a month ago as the Federal Government sold $1.8billion of these securities in its usual monthly sale.

title: KISSINGER URGES POOLED EFFORTS IN ENERGY CRISIS
description: LONDON, Dec. 12Secretary of State Kissinger proposed tonight that the United States, Europe, Canada and Japan join in a united effort to attack the world energy problem for the long term and transform the current energy crisis into the economic equivalent of the Sputnick challenge of 1957.

title: Nippon Steel Expects to Cut December Output 5% to 6%
description: TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP)The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that it expected a 5 per cent to 6 per cent reduction in crude steel output during December and an even deeper production cut in January as a result of reduced supplies of petroleum products and electricity.

title: RALPH STACKPOLE, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (AP)  Ralph Stackpole, sculptor and painter whose works are at the sites of numerous landmarks here, died Monday in France. He was 88 years old.

title: STATE RELIEF AIDE HOLDS CITY IS LAX
description: George F. Berlinger, the State Welfare Inspector General, contended yesterday that the city was able to locate most absentee fathers of welfare famiflies and collect most of they estimated arrears in their Family Court support cases.

title: Alex Acknowledges He Has Had Enough
description: When Wellington Mara yielded to intense pressure from the fans five seasons ago and ousted Allie Sherman as coach of the New York Giants, he did it with considerable reluctance because he knew Allie had one of the brightest minds in the football industry. But the respect that little Allie had once elicited from the hulking brutes under his command had slipped away as the losing record sent team morale spinning downhill with it.

title: French Auto Production Cut
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Alpine Renault and Automobiles, Peugeot, S.A., the French auto makers, said today they had decided to cut production because of an expected decline in auto sales due to the energy crisis. Peugeot had canceled Saturday overtime at its 37,000employe Sochaux plant.

title: Needham Chides Senate
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, warned yesterday that legislative proposals in the Senate could, if enacted into law, threaten the viability of the nation's stock exchanges.

title: Recital: Splendid Debut
description: Entirely successful recitals are rare enough; entirely successful debut recitals are as Scarce as gas on Sunday. But Nancy Evers, a Colorado soprano who appeared on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, came as close to giving total satisfaction as any unheralded recitalist can be expected to do.

title: Books of The Times
description: PARADISE LOST: THE DECLINE OF THE AUTOINDUSTRIAL AGE. By Emma Rothschild. 264 pages. Random House. $6.95.

title: Cause of Clash Sought as Madison High Stays Closed
description: Brooklyn's James Madison High School will remain closed today as students, teachers and parents continue to try to learn why an apparently harmonious racial situation was disrupted Monday and Tuesday by fights between black and white youths.

title: KISSINGER'S PLAN STIRS EUROPEANS
description: PARIS, Dec. 12Industrial countries have been discussing the possibility of international cooperation on energy problems for much of the postwar period, but the discussions lacked the high political content that Secretary of State Kissinger brought to the subject tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Final TransitBond Vote Reported

title: Stemkowski Goal Evens Count
description: At long last, the New York Rangers and the Buffalo Sabres played last night the kind of hockey they are expected totight defense, hard checking and good skating. The result was a 11 tie and one of the best games seen this season in Madison Square Garden.

title: Prices on the Amex and OTC Decline for Second Straight Dar
description: Prices continued downward for the second straight day on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market as economic uncertainties generated by the energy crisis and the Middle East peace talks persisted.

title: Adelphi to Test Mixing Water and Oil To Heat Garden City College Buildings
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 12An ultrasonic fuel reactor that uses a mixture of 25 per cent water and 75 per cent oil for use in oil burners will undergo a threeyear test at the 15 buildings of Adelphi University's 32acre campus. As of yesterday, four reactors were operating and within three weeks the four others on campus will be operating.

title: Ada Comstock Notestein Dies; President of Radcliffe, 192343
description: Mrs. Ada L. Comstock Notestein, who as president of Radcliffe College persuaded Harvard University in 1943 to accept classroom coeducation, died yesterday at her home in New Haven. She was the widow of Prof. Wallace Notestein, Yale historian, to whom she was married in 1943, the year she retired after 20 years as Radcliffe's first fulltime president.

title: State Begins Grants for American Music
description: A commissioning program for American music, described by its planners as unprecedented in scope and likely to result in a massive infusion of new works by native composers, was set in motion yesterday by the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Senator Urges F.T.C. Be Told To Scrutinize the Food Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Senator James Abourezk recommended today that the Federal Trade Commission be ordered to scrutinize the food industry annually and urged that certain large corporations be prohibited from farming.

title: Firms Exploring Merger
description: The Advest Company and Sartorius & Co. are negotiating for a possible merger, officials of the two New York Stock Exchange member firms confirmed yesterday. If the merger is completed, plans call for Sartorius to operate as a division of Advest. The combined firm would have an estimated total of 30 offices and total capital in excess of $10million.

title: H.E.W. Ordered by Judge To Free Impounded Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12, (UPI)  United States District Judge Aubrey E. Robinson ordered the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to release impounded funds of $20million for state educational programs.

title: Answers by Soviet To West's Questions
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8Conversations are in progress between the Russians and West European leaders who are skeptical about Soviet talk of improved relations and who do not share Secretary of State Kissinger's more hopeful assessment of the prospects. The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, and the French Minister of the Armed Forces, Robert Galley, listened to Soviet overtures for EastWest accommodation in Moscow this week and went home unconvinced.

title: Codd to Head Police Here; Cawley Planning to Resign
description: Michael J. Codd, a former Chief Inspector, was recalled from retirement yesterday by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame, who named him Police Commissioner to succeed Donald. F. Cawley.

title: Gasoline Cutback to Mean Less Money for Highways
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Funds for Federal and state highway programs could be cut by more than 10 per cent in 1974 if gasoline usage is cut by 30 per cent, the Federal Highway. Administration said today.

title: Namath Still Undecided A bout Playing Next Year
description: Everybody's talking about Joe Namath's future these days and yesterday the only person who can do, anything about it didn't.

title: ARTIFICIAL BONES IN FARMER'S THIGH
description: TOKYO, Dec. 12  A 48yearold farmer whose cancerous leg bones were replaced with manmade bones has returned to his home, where he is able to walk but not yet farm his land.

title: 800 Gallons of Gas' Stolen
description: SALINAS, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)Thieves using a tanker truck drew 800 gallorrs of gasoline yesterday from an underground tank at Raleigh Alston's service station. No one would give a second thought to seeling a as tanker at a service station in the middle of thel night, would they? a police officer said.

title: Searching for Energy ...
description: By an impressive 82 to 0 vote, the Senate has signaled the wide consensus suddenly achieved on major efforts to develop new sources of energy for America's future.

title: Venezuela Keeps Faith
description: On a continent where democracy is in pitifully short supply, four million Venezuelan voters have met the test of a hardfought Presidential election with a discipline and responsibility that provide a shining example for all the Americas. Democratic Action (A.D.), the party that led the country back to democratic rule in 1958, is justifiably elated at its return to power after five years in opposition, with the spectacular victory of its Presidential candidate, Carlos Andres Perez.

title: Noblesse Oblige
description: It wasn't because of the deductions for, shall we say, a cattle ranch or interest or all of these gimmicks ...

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: London  Danny McAlinden, 193 pounds, England, knocked out Vern Macintosh, 182, Eustis, Fla., 10 rounds.

title: $222Million Fund Is Voted by Senate For Energy Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Senate voted today to appropriate $222million to handle the national energy emergency over the next six and a half months.

title: No Charge Is Made as Inquiry Goes On to Santo Domingo
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 12 Cesar Cedeno was questioned more than two hours today by tan investigating judge on the fatal shooting of a 19yearold woman in a motel early yesterday morning.

title: Baruch Downs Hunter
description: Luis Blas, a 5foot11inch freshman, scored 16 points last night to lead Baruch College to a 7156 victory over Hunter College at the 69th Regiment Armory. Baruch now has a 32 wonlost record. Hunter is 22.

title: $300Million Utility Issue Sells Quickly
description: The Illinois Bell Telephone Company's $30million offering of new 31year debentures, priced at par with 8 per cent coupons, sold out quickly yesterday.

title: Convicted Mass Murderer Guilty in Slaying of Priest
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.,iDec. 12 (UPI)Herbert W. Mullin, a convicted mass murderer, was found guilty yesterday on charges of seconddegree mur, der in the death bf a Roman Catholic priest on Nov. 2, 1972.

title: Senate, After Long Delay, Begins Hearings on Equal Employment Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Senate began consideration today of the fourmonthold nomination of a new chairman for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission after assurances from the White House that the nomination did not reflect dissatisfaction with the commission's enforcement policies.

title: Word Spreads Among Truckers To Park Their Rigs for 2 Days
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12  Richand Robb, a truck driver who had dropped off a load of steel here, was heading back home today to New Castle, Pa., where he planned to park his truck and relax for two days.

title: The Way of the 25th
description: There has been much discussion about the President resigning from office, being impeached, or continuing to serve as President for the rest of the term without being able to govern effectively. His resignation from office would be viewed as an admission of guilt of wrongdoing, produce a reaction that he unfairly was forced from office, and establish a dangerous precedent for the office of President.

title: Speed Limit Reduced
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)  Gov. Ronald Reagan signed a bill today to reduce the California speed limit from 65 to 55 miles an hour, effective New Year's Day.

title: Six Buffalo Children Killed In Fire That Destroys House
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 12 (AP) Six children were killed today in a house fire on Buffalo's east side, officials reported.

title: STEEL PRICE REIN HELD NECESSARY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 12 (UPI) The director of the Cost of Living Council expressed doubt today that wageprice restraints would be lifted quickly in the steel industry.

title: Watchers of Skies Are Disappointed In Comet Kohoutek
description: The muchpublicized Comet Kohoutek is proving a disappointment to skywatchers, if not a fizzle. However, there is hope that, after an encounter with the sun Dec. 28, it will become more spectacular.

title: New Yorkers Halt Cougars, 10797
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 12 The New York Nets raised their winning streak to nine tonight with an easy 10797 victory over the divisionleading Carolina Cougars. The Nets not only drew closer to their primary goal of first place, but also realized a secondary goal: They drew their largest crowd of the season to Nassau Coliseum, 10,149 fans.

title: 4 Soviet Aides Meet State Officials To Discuss Problems of Air Pollution
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12 (AP)Four Soviet officials met here today with representatives of the New Jersey state government to discuss means of reducing air pollution from energy production, particularly from nuclear power stations.

title: Contributor Composes an Official Song for the Neediest Cases Fund
description: The New York: Times Needlest Cases Fund now has its official song.

title: Astros' Outfielder, 22, Is Called Proad and Dedicated Player
description: Once, when asked how he enjoyed the limelight while still a teenager, Cesar Cedeno replied, It's so much so soon.

title: Congressional Investigators Suspect U.S. Has Only Skimmed Surface in Uncovering Major Housing Frauds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Congressional investigators suspect that Government prosecutors have only skimmed the surface in uncovering massive schemes to cheat the poor in Federal housing programs. And this despite about 300 recent indictments in 20 cities across the country.

title: Brown Defeats Yale Five, 6356
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12Eddie Morris scored 15 points and had six assists tonight to lead Brown to a 6356 Ivy League basketball victory over Yale. It was the first league contest for each team as Brown evened its overall wonlost record at 22 and Yale dropped to a 13 mark.

title: St. Francis Loses To Bonnies, 9584
description: St. Bonaventure University turned back St. Francis College of Brooklyn last night, 9584, at the Terriers' gym. Glenn Price's 24 points and 18 rebounds led the Sonnies.

title: Nixon Attends Party, Then Goes to Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) President Nixon left the White House unannounced tonight to pay tribute to an old friend and to meet with business leaders.

title: Anthony Antoville, Internist, Long With U.S. Plywood, 68
description: Dr. Anthony A. Antoville, an internist for more than 40 years, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: U.S. FOREIGN POLICY SCORED BY BENTSEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a moderate Democrat from Texas with avowed Presidential ambitions, assailed today the foreign policy of the Nixon Administration, charging it was substituting sloganeering for policy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today

title: CAMPAIGN FLIGHT LINKED TO VESCO
description: A helicopter chartered by Robert L. Vesco's company carried former White House aid Harry S. Dent to campaign appearances for President Nixon in New Jersey last year, according to records collected for a Federal investigation.

title: MORROW'S NEW BAND IMPROVISES SOLIDLY
description: Charlie Morrow, the chanting composer, has a new project called the New Wilderness Preservation Band, and it is an interesting assemblage indeed. The group performed Tuesday at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, and will be on display occasional Tuesday nights throughout the season.

title: TakeOver Planned By First Chicago Of Finance Unit
description: A definitive agreement for the acquisition of American Finance System, Inc., by the First Chicago Corporation was reached yesterday. The transaction involves an excess of $90million.

title: Codd to Head Police Here; Cawley Planning to Resign
description: Michael J. Codd, a former Chief Inspector, was recalled from retirement yesterday by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame, who named him Police Commissioner to succeed Donald F. Cawley.

title: Black and Puerto Rican Men and Women Take Cram Course for Police Exam
description: In the large unheated auditorium of St. Ambrose Church in Bedford Stuyvesant, fluorescent lights cast a glare over the 100 black and Puerto Rican men and women who sat in six long rows. In an almost reverent silence the other evening, they watched Norman Kirkland, a black police officer sketch a diagram of a street corner on the small blackboard.

title: Notes on People
description: Whether President Nixon travels by train to set an energysaving example or not, his big jet, The Spirit of '76, will still spend at least three hours weekly in flight, according to his pilot. Col. Ralph D. Albertazzle, pilot of Air Force One, said the weekly flying was essential to maintain crew proficiency and to detect potential mechanical problems. The colonel characterized himself as a doctor of flying, a professional who must fly regularly, whether the president is aboard his plane or not, to maintain his skills.

title: Bonn and Sofia Sign an Agreement to Establish Ties
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 12 (UPI)Representatives of Bulgaria and West Germany signed preliminary documents today establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries, Government sources said.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: W. S. Merwin, the New Yorkborn poet and translator, has been awarded the 1973 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets by its board of chancellors. The fellowship, given annually since 1946, honors distinguished poetic achievement and carries a $10,000 stipend.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In certifying the results of the Nov. 6 election, the New York Department of State said there were 2,210,907 negative votes and 1,593,531 affirmative votes on Governor Rockefeller's $3.5billion transitbond proposal.

title: Regional Good Sense
description: The Mayorelect of New York, the County Executive of Nassau and the County Executiveelect of Westchester have taken a hopeful if tentative step in regional cooperation. The plan announced by Messrs. Beame, Caso and Del Bello is to form a united bloc of the area's legislators both in Washington and in Albany. They recognize that on certain issues the common needs of the metropolitan area transcend the differences between city and suburb, Republican and Democrat.

title: Slowdowns Cripple British Rail Lines
description: LONDON, Dec. 12Rail service all over Britain was crippled today as 29,000 railroad engineers and firemen staged slowdowns over a wage dispute, and the Government reacted immediately by extending the national state of emergency for a second month.

title: Country's Last Wooden Whaling Ship Found Fit After Years Out of Sea
description: MYSTIC, Conn., Dec. 12America's last remaining wooden whaling ship, the 132yearold Charles W. Morgan, went into dry dock at Mystic Seaport today.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN SUFFER SETBACK
description: After rising sharply in early trading, prices of farm products futures fell back under profit taking yesterday.

title: Rutgers President Scores College Policy on Blacks
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 12  Rutgers University's president, Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, today attacked programs for educationally disadvantaged college students that offered false hopes of immediate educational success.

title: Bank Robbers Steal Car And Its Driver as Well
description: Raymond Sotero attended a bank robbery in the Bronx yesterday  unwillingly and in the trunk of his own car.

title: CHESIMARD TRIAL GOES TO THE JURY
description: The bankrobbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton ended yesterday with the lawyers for both defendants still refusing to participate.

title: Arabs Set Commodity Plan
description: CAIRO, Dec. 12 (AP)  A joint Arab investment company to specialize in the production of strategic commodities will be formed with a capital of $230million, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today, indicating that the project would be the first to be financed from the huge assets of Arab countries in Western banks.

title: WNBCTV Plans Longer News Shows, From 5 to 7:30 P.M.
description: WNBCTV, Channel 4, is proceeding with plans to expand its early evening newscast to two hours a night and is negotiating for new personnel to serve in some of the principal oncamera roles.

title: House Votes to Retain Control Over Energy Conservation Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The House voted tonight to require approval by Congress of any energy conservation plans that the Nixon Administration devises to head off gasoline rationing.

title: Venezuelan Says Oil Flow Won't Be Cut
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 12Carlos Andrs Prez, a Social Democrat, emerged today as Presidentelect of Venezuela, and he promised that international commitments on oil deliveries would be met during his administration.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters)The aftertax profits of United States manufacturing corporations fell $1.4billion, to $11.6billion, in the third quarter of this year from the secondquarter level, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: Vietcong Chief Sees No Peace Gain Since Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 (UPI)The political leader of the Vietcong believes there has been no progress toward peace in Vietnam since the ceasefire agreement was signed nearly 11 months ago and he blames the United States.

title: Borrowing Planned to Save 35c Fare Pending U.S. Aid
description: City and state officials discussed a plan yesterday to save the city's 35cent transit fare by borrowing enough money to tide over the Transit Authority until Federal legislation to aid mass transit is passed.

title: Unbending Police Chief Michael Joseph Codd
description: Michael Joseph Codd, the city's next Police Commissioner, is known in station houses around the city as Chief Straight Arrow, a nickname with a double derivation.

title: Baruch in Brooklyn Backed
description: The Regional Plan Association yesterday urged the State Board of Regents to deny a proposal to build Baruch College in a vacant office building in lower Manhattan at 2 New York Plaza and instead to build it at the Atlantic Terminal in downtown Brooklyn. The association said that the college would be an important component of downtown Brooklyn's development program, which will spark renewal of the Atlantic Terminal area.

title: SOVIET TROUBLED BY VOTE ON TRADE
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12  The Soviet Union, reacting to the vote yesterday by the House of Representatives linking trade concessions to freer Soviet emigration, contended today that the move contradicted the trend toward relaxation of tensions.

title: SAXBE PROMISES TO BACK JAWORSKI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Senator William B. Saxbe, President Nixon's nominee as Attorney General, promised the Senate today that he would vigorously support the special Watergate prosecution in its investigation to determine if any high crimes and misdemeanors were committed by the White House.

title: Rockefeller to Keep 4 of His Top Aides
description: Four of Governor Rockefeller's top state aides will remain with him to work on the National Commission on Critical Choices for Americans and to form the nucleus of a Presidential campaign staff.

title: White House Tree Lighting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) President anti Mrs. Nixon will participate Friday in the traditional lighting of the national Christmas tree on the Ellipse, south of the White House. Announcing this today, the deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said the tree would not carry lights this year, as an energy conservation move, but would be spotlighted.

title: MRS. CHAIM SCHNEIER
description: Mrs. Gisela Bergman Schneier, a leader in the resurgence of the Jewish community of Vienna after World War II, died yesterday in a convalescent home at the age of 71.

title: Gasoline Cutback to Mean Less Money for Highways
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12,Funds for Federal and state highway programs could be cut by more than 10 per cent in 1974 if gasoline usage is cut by 30 per cent, the Federal Highway Administration said today.

title: WILFRID L. HUSBAND
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Dec. 12Wilfrid Laurier Husband, world traveler and lecturer, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 73.

title: Perspective Is Retained By U. C. L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12And how does the University of California, Los Angeles, approach its much ballyhooed meeting with North Carolina State on a St. Louis basketball court this Saturday?

title: KISSINGER URGES POOLED EFFORTS IN ENERGY CRISIS
description: LONDON, Dec, 12Secretary of State Kissinger proposed tonight that the United States, Europe, Canada and Japan join in a united effort to attack the world energy problem for the long term and transform the current energy crisis into the economic equivalent of the Sputnick challenge of 1957.

title: Venezuela's New Chief Carlos Andres Perez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13Carlos Andrs Prez has done what no one else has been able to domake carbound people of Caracas walk for 10 miles and like it, says a close friend of the man who has been elected President of this oilproducing country for the next five years.

title: Marshall Largesse Will Aid Amateurs
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (AP) A Montreal amateur baseball group is $5,000 richer today because Mike Marshall earlier refused the $5,000 cash award that accompanied his selection as the Expos' 1973 player of the year.

title: New Manager to Allow Blomberg to Hit Lefties
description: In one of his first pronouncements yesterday as the New York Yankees' new manager, Dick Williams promised to give Ron Blomberg every opportunity to determine if the lefthanded swinging first baseman can hit lefthanded pitchers.

title: Yankees Hire Williams, Risking Legal Struggle
Nixon's Oil Aides Accused Of Ignoring Shortage Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13A Senate subcommittee investigating causes of the oil and gasoline shortages was told today that the Administration officials responsible for setting petroleum import quotas ignored for more than two years warnings that crude oil supplies were insufficient to meet rising demand.

title: C. Russell Feldmann, 75, Dies; National Union Electric Head
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 13 C. Russell Feldmann, board chairman and president of the National Union Electric Corporation, died today at his home, Horse Island, Mead Point. He was 75 years old.

title: Thousands of Truck Drivers Stay Off the Road to Protest Effects of Fuel Shortage
description: Thousands of truck drivers around the country either stayed home yesterday or pulled into truck stops or off the side of the road to protest the effects of the fuel shortage.

title: With Williams in Darkest Flushing
description: The meeting came to order, more or less, several stories above the old World's Fair grounds in a restaurant called Feathers in the Park, and a fellow couldn't help wondering, had it really come to this with the Yankeeschicken yesterday, feathers today? But Bob Fishel, vice president, quickly laid doubts to rest. There are four phones just outside, he said, and I have a lot of dimes if anybody needs some. Even in the days when they won world championships by just showing up, the Yankees never displayed a nicer touch of class.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the last two win five 50cent tickets for any subsequent weekly drawing when shown to any lottery vender.

title: Con Ed: a Step to Coal
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday gave Consolidated Edison approval to burn coal in its Arthur Kill generating plant on Staten Island and city officials said they were prepared to approve the change quickly. Con Edison was denied its request to be allowed to use coal in its Ravenswood plant in Queens. Page 23.

title: Money Rates Rose In the Latest Week, Reserve Data Show
description: If the Federal Reserve last Friday took a tentative step toward making it easier to borrow money  as Wall Street quickly concluded  the central bank's data released yesterday did not include much evidence of such a subtle shift in monetary policy.

title: Ehrlichman and 2 Others Lose Plea on Coast BreakIn
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (Reuters)John D. Ehrlichman, former White House domestic affairs aide, and two of his assistants lost their appeal today to get burglary and conspiracy charges against them dismissed on the ground they were acting in the interests of national security.

title: Lee Quits F.C.C., 2d Democrat to Do So in 10 Days
description: Tr. Rex Lee resigned yesterday from the Federal Communications Commission in what he described as a desire to retire from career service to try something new. He is the second Democrat to quit the F.C.C. within the last 10 days.

title: 3 U.S. EXECUTIVES LEAVE ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec, 13 (Reuters)  An Americanowned oil company today evacuated three executives and their 13 dependents from Argentina because of fears of kidnapping or assassination, according to United States Embassy sources.

title: Notre Dame Bailed Out.
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 13 (UPI)  The University of Notre Dame finally got confirmation of a return flight from New Orleans following the Irish's football team's New Year's Eve appearance in the Sugar Bowl against Alabama. For several weeks Notre Dame had assurances of a chartered jetliner to New Orleans, but it was not until yesterday that the school was guaranteed a return flight.

title: Hanrahan Seeks Houseseat
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (UPI)Edward V. Hanrahan, the former Cook County State's Attorney, announced today as a candidate for Congress from the Illinois Sixth District in Chicago's western suburbs. Mr. Hanrahan said he would run as an independent for the Democratic nomination in the March 19 primary against Robert Miller, the candidate slated by the regular party organization.

title: Leone Is Named by Byrne As New State Treasurer
description: TRENTON, Dec. 13Richard C. Leone, the chief campaign strategist for Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne, was named State Treasurer today by the incoming Governor at a news conference.

title: Relatives Sue City for 1Million For Not Notifying Them of Death
description: Relatives of the late George K. Gutterman, a stockbroker who was almost buried in pauper's grave last month, filed suit yesterday against the city and two hospitals for $1million in damages for psychic injuries.

title: Con Ed: a Step to Coal
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday gave Consolidated Edison approval to burn coal in its Arthur Kill generating plant on Staten Island and city officials said they were prepared to approve the change quickly. Con Edison was denied its request to be allowed to use coal in its Ravenswood plant in Queens. Page 23.

title: SAXBE SUPPORTED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 15 to 1 today to approve the nomination of Senator WilHain B. Saxbe of Ohio as Attorney General.

title: DR. CLARA K. LAX
description: Dr. Clara Kornfeld Lax, a pediatrician who was the wife of Dr. Henry Lax with whom she shared offices at 160 East 72d Street, died Tuesday. She was 68 years old and lived at 300 Central Park West.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: VOLUME There's musical activity on a downtown scale bursting: out these days at Queens College, Kisseha Parkway and Long Wand Expressway (5207340). First, the music and theater departments have teamed up to sponsor four performances of modern opera in the Queens College Theater on campus. The program, already halfway through its run, consists of three short, oneact 20thcentury operas, each fully staged and done in toto.

title: Banks' Father Image Is Giving Way to Pop
description: It was not all that long ago that banks were solid, limestonefronted buildings, perhaps with a Corinthian column or two to give a sense of dignity, history and the security of one's deposits.

title: Questions, Questions
description: As a result of the numerous financial statements  all billed as complete  that Richard Nixon has made public during the past year:

title: Mrs. King Is Rated No. 1 In U.S. Women's Tennis
description: For the fourth straight year, Mrs. Billie Jean King has been designated the top woman tennis player in the United States. Mrs. King was listed at the top of the women's rankings issued yesterday by the. United States Lawn Tennis Association.

title: Newark Officials to Map Fuel Tactics
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson will meet with top city officials, all department and agency heads and civildefense authorities tomorrow morning to start work on an emergency plan for meeting heatingoil shortages.He said the discussion would include other aspects of energy problem, such as the reduction of lighting and ways to cut fuel consumption.

title: Manhattan, Fordham Victors in Garden Twin Bill
Court Postpones Trial Over Dempsey's Lease
description: The eviction trial against Jack Dempsey's Restaurant was postponed until Jan. 7 yesterday when Judge Harry W. Davis instructed the restaurant and its landlord to try to negotiate a new lease.

title: Contract Awards
description: Pullman, Inc., said yesterday that its M. W. Kellogg Company division of Houston had been awarded a contract for a significant portion of the Amoco Oil Company's recently announced $88million crude replacement program at Texas City, Texas. Industry sources estimated the value of the contract at about $20million. A second award for expansion of an aromatics recovery unit is valued at about $5million.

title: Regan on the Right Track For a MillionDollar Year
description: When he was a boy in Newcastle, New Brunswick, George (Buddy) Regan, like most of his friends, wanted to be a hockey player. I was pretty good, too, said the 31yearold Regan at Yonkers Raceway last night, and with the way expansion has turned out, I might have made it with one of the new National Hockey League teams.

title: McCarthy to Leave Police Post After 26 Years in Department
description: First Deputy Police Commissioner William P. McCarthy, who for two years has headed the city's Organized Crime Control Bureau, said yesterday he would retire next month.

title: Fons' Power Died in Last 20 Years and With It, Much Respect
description: LAIKOM, Cameroon  Listen to the old man from Kom:

title: Appeal Halts Sudan Inquiry Into Slaying of 3 Diplomats
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Dec. 13 (AP)The court of inquiry into the killing of three foreign diplomats here in March was adjourned indefinitely today following an appeal by the defendants.

title: Islanders Lose, 32, To Kings
400 Podell Friends Pay $125 At Party to Aid Legal Defense
description: Friends of Representative Bertram L. Podell rallied to his support yesterday evening at $125aperson cocktail reception at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The Brooklyn Democrat is accused of conspiracy, bribery and conflict of interest.

title: Bridge: Washington Pair Holds Lead In Bule Ribbon Championship
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 13 Two young players from Washington, D.C., held the lead going into the final session of the Blue Ribbon pair championship here tonight.

title: ADMISSION MADE ON TICKETFIXING
description: John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of the City Purchase Department, implicated himself and named three Brooklyn Assemblymen as among those who had tried to have almost 2,000 parking tickets fixed, a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn was told yesterday.

title: This Show Will Have the Most Shattering Effect on Fashion
description: The new fashion show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a dazzler, You don't have to be a fashion buff to enjoy it. It spans 30 years before World War II, when the century was young, the arts were in ferment, and much of the excitement was reflected in clothes. It focuses on five designers who invented new ways to dress the modern woman who was struggling towards emancipation. Naturally, their work was Paris, the center of all culture. No upstart New York was yet calling itself the fashion capital of the world. Oriental opulence, the brilliant colors of the artists known as the Fauves and of Diaghilev's Ballet Russe are all influences on the clothes, but the marvels are the clothes themselves. They recall the time when was not absurd to call fashion an art. The splendor of the fabrics is rivaled only by the imaginative designs.

title: Three Workmen Killed by Gases While Cleaning Newark Sewer
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13  Three workmen cleaning a sewer north of Newark International Airport were killed today after they were apparently felled by sewer gases and slipped into four feet of water and sludge.

title: The Pop Life
description: Dick Clark, now heavily into rock nostalgia through his television show, The Rock'n Roll Years, has secured something of a coupThe T.A.M.I. Show from the early nineteensixties, still remembered as a standout rockperformance film. Mr. Clark will reshow it in February, with Jan and Dean (who also appear in the vintage clips) acting as hosts.

title: 3 Window Workers Killed on East Side In Freak Accidents
description: A defective harness sent a window repair man plunging 30 stories from an East Side building yesterday in a freakish accident that claimed two lives when the repairman landed atop a colleague.

title: District Attorney's Plea Keeps Cedeno in Jail
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominlean Republic, Dec. 13District Attorney Maximo Hendriquez Saladin recommended today that Cesar Cedeno, a center fielder for the Houston Astros, be held in jail. The athlete is being detained in connection with the death of a young woman last Tuesday.

title: Bettor Wins $27,137
description: MIAMI, Dec. 13 (AP)  A lucky ticket holder cashed in a $27,137.60 trifecta today in the fifth race at Calder Race Course. The only winner correctly picked the race's win, place and show finishers. The payoff came within $3,000 of the track's record.

title: Atlantic Dialogue
description: Secretary Kissinger's effort in Brussels and London to ease the strains between the United. States and its NATO allies appears to have improved the tone of the relationship. But the shift on both sides from recrimination over the Mideast war toward a more constructive dialogue is, like taking one step forward after two backward, only the beginning of what needs to be done.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Steady, TaxExempts Change Little
description: Trading was quiet and price, showed little change yesterday in the corporate, taxexempt and Government bond markets.

title: Bette Midler Show Picketed Over Use of Nonunion Man
description: A picket line has been posted at the Palace Theater to protest the use of a nonunion lighting man working with the Bette Midler show, which was sold out in advance for its threeweek run ending Dec, 22.

title: Europeans May Discuss Atom Force at Parley Today
description: PARIS, Dec. 13The Common Market Governments have agreed on a declaration of European identity.

title: KISSINGER AND THO TO MEET IN PARIS AS FIGHTING RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Secretary of State Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, who negotiated the Vietnam ceasefire, will meet in Paris next Thursday, the White House announced today.

title: Kissinger Arrives in Cairo After 2Hour Algeria Tall
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13  Secretary Pf State Kissinger arrived here tonight for talks with President Anwar elSadat on the forthcoming Middle East peace conference only hours after achieving an apparent agreement in Algeria on moving toward a reestablishment of diplomatic relations.

title: Political Audits Were Resisted By I.R.S., Congress Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Congressional investigators have concluded that the Internal Revenue Service resisted White House pressures to conduct politically motivated audits, but they are not yet sure whether the agency deserves to be cleared of another charge of politicization.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE CURBS GAS IN SCHOOL BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The House of Representatives voted today to ban the use of fuel to transport children beyond their neighborhood schools. The antibusing amendment, justified by its supporters as an essential fuel saver, was attached to an emergency energy bill during an emotionally charged session that extended into the night.

title: Miss Abigail Brosius Angell Married to Cass Canfield Jr.
description: Miss Abigail Brosius Angell, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Angell of New York and Newtown, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Cass Canfield Jr., son of Mr. Canfield of New York and the late Mrs. John D. W. Churchill of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Harold Eads, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Curtis Angell, brother and sisterinlaw of the bride.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man who allegedly led the police on a stolencar chase that led to the accidental shooting of an offduty officer in Queens Dec. 1 has given himself up. The police yesterday identified the suspect as Karl Cross, 24 years old, of 12907 Liverpool Street, Jamaica, Queens, and said had been charged with grand larceny of a car.

title: Nixon Is Said to Plan Rail Travel to Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13President Nixon has decided to travel by train to his Key Biscayne home in Florida after Christmas, according to White House sources.

title: Laos to End State of Emergency and Lift Curfew
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 13The Government announced today that it would end the official state of emergency and the curfew in the country on Jan. I.

title: Athens Says It Will Free All Seized in Protests
description: ATHENS, Dec. 13The new armybacked Greek Government announced today that it would release at once all those who had been arrested during the student disturbances last month in the closing days of the rule of President George Papadopoulos.

title: CHESIMARD VERDICT STILL AWAITED HERE
description: The jury in the bank robbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton reported it was still deadlocked after its second day of deliberations yesterday and was ordered by Federal Judge Lee P. Gagliardi to return to court at 9:30 A.M. today.

title: Royals Get Hunter
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)The Boston Red Sox sold Buddy Hunter, a second baseman, to the Kansas City Royals today to make room on their 40man roster for Juan Marichal, a righthanded pitcher whom the acquired last Friday from the San Francisco Giants.

title: Powder Puff Derby Off
description: SANTA ANA Calif., Dec. 13 (AP)  The 1974 Powder Puff Derby, a crosscountry air race for women, has been canceled because of the fuel shortage. The AllWomen Transcontinental Air Race, Inc., said yesterday that it had called off the event at the request of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Bulls' Rally Ends Bucks' Streak at 10
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 13 (AP); The Chicago Bulls, down by 9 points early in the fourth quarter, rallied tonight behind Jerry Sloan and Dennis Awtrey to beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 9794, in the season's first matchup of the National Basketball Association's Midwest Division contenders.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Upham, 2 Other Firms and Aides
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered yesterday that hearings be held on charges of stock fraud against officers or employes of three New York City brokerage firms. The charges revolve around the manipulation of two offerings of stock in 1972.

title: Senate Votes $73Billion Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Senate routinely approved today a $73.7billion defense appropriations bill that reduces aid to South Vietnam but leaves the Pentagon's weapons program virtually intact.

title: NORMAN ASH
description: NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 13Norman Ash, presiden.t of the Ash Steel Corporation of Brookline, died yesterday in Rocky Mountain, N.C., while on his way to Florida. He was 55 years old and lived here.

title: Soviet Is Reconciling Its Quest for Modernization With Communist Ideology
description: Ever since the Bolshevik Revolution, the Soviet Unionnow a superpower with great enterprises and a higher living standard to point tohas focused on science and technology as prime levers for rational development of a Communist society.

title: Bridgeport Brass Co. Adds Surcharge on Zinc Alloys
description: The Bridgeport Brass Company announced yesterday that it was adding a surcharge of 22.65 cents per pound of zinc on all alloys containing zinc, effective with yesterday's shipments. This will be tacked onto the previous quoted price of 21.35 cents a pound.

title: Miners Battle Heath And the Nation Loses
description: LONDON, Dec. 13  The first steps toward the power crisis that led Prime Minister Heath today to order the British economy onto a threeday work week were taken two winters ago in a bitter battle with the nation's 260,000 coal miners.

title: Organist Dies at 90, Leaving Fortune in Rare Sheet Music
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)A former ragtime piano player and moviehouse organist of the silentfilm era died today at the age of 90, leaving in his rundown home a collection of sheet music and rare books valued by experts at up to $2million.

title: Auto Industry Facing Lasting Changes
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13  The energy crisis is expected to have a more profound and lasting effect on the future of the auto industry than the challenges of the environmental and safety movements of the last decade. It has created what one top auto executive described as a whole new ball game.

title: Sirica Says Experts Find Miss Woods's Lamp and Typewriter Are Unlikely to Have Caused Tape Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Neither the highintensity lamp nor the electric typewriter used by President Nixon's secretary, Rose Mary Woods, was the likely cause of a gap with 18 minutes of buzzing on key Watergate tape recording, Judge John J. Sirica said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GUNMAN KILLS MAN, WOUNDS 2 OTHERS
description: An unknown gunman last night shot and killed a Queens man, critically wounded his wife and seriously injured his son in their home at 14703 10th Avenue in the Whitestone section, the police reported.

title: Automatic Rises in Rates Granted to Phone Company
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13  The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company became today the first subsidiary of the American Telephone & Telegraph system to get the right to pass on automatically to consumers a portion of its increased fuel, labor and other costs without going through formal rate proceedings.

title: Memorial for Vishniac
description: McMURDO, Antarctica, Dec. 13 (UPI)A memorial serivce was held yesterday at McMurdo Chapel for the American biologist Wolf Vishniac, killed Tuesday in a 500foot fall from an Antarctic ice shelf. Dr. Vishniac came to Antarctica under a National Science Foundation project five weeks ago and was scheduled to return home next month.

title: Roadblocks Remain for Padres Move to Washington
description: The transfer of the San Diego Padres to Washington, approved unanimously by the National League eight days ago, has not yet been completed, and the possibility remains that the team will, wind up in San Diego, at least for a while under league stewardship.

title: BRITISH WORK WEEK CUT TO 3 DAYS FOR MOST INDUSTRIES TO COUNTER DISRUPTIONS IN SUPPLY OF ENERGY
description: LONDON, Dec. 13Prime Minister Heath announced today that a threeday work week would be imposed on most of British industry starting Jan, 1 in response to sweeping disruptions in the nation's energy supply.

title: Skylab Crew Sees Comet Tail Clearly
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)The tail of Kohoutek, the comet blazing through space toward a to around the sun during the Christmas holidays, was clearly visible today to the unaided eyes of the Skylab 3 crew for the first time.

title: BRITISH WORK WEEK CUT TO 3 DAYS FOR MOST INDUSTRIES TO COUNTER DISRUPTIONS IN SUPPLY OF ENERGY
description: LONDON, Dec. 13Prime Minister Heath announced today that a threeday work week would be imposed on most of British industry starting Jan. 1 in response to sweeping disruptions in the nation's energy supply.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Detroit Gets W.F.L. Franchise

title: City Reports Fuel Spurs $24.5Million Budget Rise
description: The city's chief housekeeper estimates that, largely because of high outlays for fuel for heat, light and power, it will cost nearly $25million more to operate cityowned buildings and other facilities in the next fiscal year than in the present one.

title: U.S. Approves Con Ed Request for Burning of Coal on Staten Island, and City May Go Along
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency gave the Consolidated Edison Company its approval yesterday for coalburning at the company's Arthur Kill plant on Staten Island.

title: PresidentElect's Party Gains Strength in Venezuela Congress
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13When Presidentelect Carlos Andrs Prez takes office in March, he will have strong backing in Congress, latest returns from the Congressional elections of last Sunday indicated today.

title: Madison High to Reopen With Additional Guards
description: James Madison High School in Brooklyn is to reopen this morning with additional security forces on hand to prevent any recurrence of the racial violence that closed the school last Tuesday.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the last two win five 50cent tickets for any subsequent weekly drawing when shown to any lottery vender.

title: Duryea and Kingston Plead Not Guilty in Election Case
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and Assembly Majority Leader John E. Kingston, the two top leaders of the State Assembly, were arraigned and pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of Election Law violations, while both Democrats and Republicansin an unusual display of bipartisan support rallied around the two accused Republicans.

title: TV: Miracle on 34th St.
description: With a perfectly good Hollywood comedy like Miracle on 34th Street as a Christmas perennial on television, it's reasonable to wonder why a network would try to top it with a remake. The answer is, it hasn't. But it has matched the Hollywood film very nicely. There's for both.

title: 14 STUDENTS HURT IN BUS COLLISION
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 13A school bus turned over after colliding with a car at a rural intersection today, injuring 14 pupils and the driver of the car, who was charged with driving while under the influence of alcohol.

title: AIRLINES PROTEST FUEL ALLOCATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The nation's airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association strongly protested today against what they called inequitable fuel allocations, and scattered pilot groups posed the threat of holiday travel shutdown.

title: Death Penalty Asked
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  A bill that would establish the death penalty for murder of law enforcement and correctional officers and for rape was introduced by four state Democratic legislators today.

title: COPPER NEGOTIATOR IS NAMED BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 13 (AP)Chile's military Government has named a former finance minister to negotiate with United States copper companies over compensation for property nationalized by the previous Marxist Government, a high official said.

title: Cardinal Beltrami Dies
description: ROME, Dec. 13Giuseppe Cardinal Beltrami, a former Vatican diplomat, died here today after suffering a cerebral thrombosis a week ago. He was 84 years old. His death reduced the Sacred College of Cardinals to 136 members. Cardinal Beltrami served in various diplomatic posts, including Beirut and The Hague. He was named a Cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1967.

title: Veal Riblets for Weekend Chefs
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on U. S. railroads during the week totaled an estimated 17.1 billion ton miles, 10.7 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The A.A.R. also announced carloadings for the same week: totaled 553,210 cars, 7.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was an estimated 8.2 per cent above last year.

title: LEONARD RAIDER, LED BLUE SHIELD
description: MILFORD, Pa., Dec. 13 Dr. Leonard J. Raider, former president of United Medical Service (Blue Shield of Greater New York) was found dead last night, apparently of carbon monoxide poisoning, in the garage of his brotherinlaw, Raymond Ruby, in Dingman Township. He was 49 years old and lived at 435 East 57th Street in New York and also in this area.

title: CeaseFire Unit in Vietnam Resumes Monitoring Duties
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 (Reuters)The International Commission for Control and Supervision resumed its peacemonitoring function in South Vietnam today aftor nearly five months of inactivity.

title: Ed Emshwiller Retrospective on View
description: Of the legion of avantgarde, experimental or, if you will, independent underground movie makers, Ed Emshwiller, who has been industriously filming since 1959, deserves the retrospective show that started, last night at the Film Forum. If the collection of seven of his shorts, running a total of more than two hours, tends to be slightly repetitive and occasionally a strain on the eye and ear, it also forcefully illustrates the work of a creative professional who towers above many of his competitors.

title: AIR FORCE LAUNCHES SWITCHBOARD OF SKY
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 13 (UPI)An Air Force Titan 3C rocket boosted into excellent first orbit today twin switchboard satellites that will transit secret messages around the world.

title: Screen: Oft-Wed King:New 'Henry VIII' Stars Michell as Monarch The Cast
description: It's always intriguing to watch the development of an actor: Keith Michell has come a very long way since I heard him bellowing "If mew-HOO-sic be the food of love . . ." at Stratford, England, a good many years ago. It wasn't then foreseeable that he would become such a fine character actor, as is now clear In "Henry VIII and His Six Wives," which opened yesterday at the 86th Street East and is opening at neighborhood theaters. The movie production was shot afresh after the success of the British Broadcasting Corporation's television series, shown here on the Columbia Broadcasting System.Mr. Michell vaults the decades with agility. After the boisterousness of his young Henry, he grows to look more and more like the Holbein portrait, and then as though that portrait itself had aged. Lurching from side to side on gouty limbs, waxing wider and bulkier with every scene, he excels at random rages and also in changes of moodas he hurtles suddenly from fury to self-doubt. Tears are usually a test of talent, and his are touching when he weeps unwillingly at the death of one wife and the infidelity of another. He storms and lumbers through the period with gusto, hands laden with heavy rings land with a crash in a dish of succulent food, and it's pleasing to hear his scornful pronunciation of "imp't'nt" (impotent) and "Papissst". Throughout, the Tudor grunts are well orchestrated, whether inspired by feeding or love-making or dying.Frances Cuka has a moving dignity as the rejected Catherine of Aragon, and Jane Asher manages to be both appealing and austere as Jane Seymour. However, Charlotte Rampling (Anne Boleyn) unleashes too many peals of carefree laughter, and Donald Pleasence overdoes his meaching rodent act as Thomas Cromwell: the twanging Northern accent that issues from his pleated lips seems more appropriate for Dickens or even Pinter.This is a fairly sophisticated performance of a very simple-minded scenario  hence it's a bit hard to be certain whom this movie was designed for. Perhaps it should be ranked as healthy popular entertainment for those who enjoy the lusher style of English classical acting (I do), even when the script hardly threathens Shakespeare. For this "Henry," you need a soft spot for jousting, masques and mummeries, lutes and trumpets, pageantry rampant, hunting scenes and limpid evocations of the English countryside. Otherwise, the movie might make you yearn for urban grit and the most sarcastic jokes that our meanest streets can provide.

title: Oil Price Rise Shelters Algeria Economy
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 13Algerian officials are showing confidence that they can maintain and even increase oil cuts without hurting their economy.

title: For 56 Years, a $100 Gift to Neediest
description: Fiftysix years ago on Dec.. 12, John Walter Hirsch died at the age of 3. Ever since then, his mother, Mrs. Walter A. Hirsch of 2 East 61st Street, has sent a donation of $100 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in his memory.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.753billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier of $1.587billion. Total retail store sales were about $11,189billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $10.511billion.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1973
description: Prime Minister Heath announced that the Government would impose a threeday work week on most British industries beginning Jan. 1 in response to sweeping disruptions of the nation's energy supply. The action will mean sharp pay cuts for some 13 million workers, higher unemployment and a possible jolting halt to growth in the overheated British economy. [1:8.]

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: Regents Expected to Reject a Request To Keep Baruch College in Manhattan
description: The State Board of Regents is expected to announce today that it has turned down a request by officials of the City University to allow the Bernard M. Baruch College to remain in Manhattan rather than move to Brooklyn.

title: STATES LOWERING SPEED OF TRUCKS
description: Twenty states have lowered daytime speed limits for trucks on major roads to 55 miles an hour or less in an effort to cope with the energy crunch, an Associated Press survey shows.

title: Pageantry vs. Vision
description: A funny thing almost happened on the way to the bicentennial of the American Revolution. Washington (the Government, not the General) lost the way, focusing on the pageantry and the politics instead of the historical vision of the Founding Fathers. The organization created by Congress and guided by the White House seemed to have forgotten the significance of the Revolution.

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI) Alderman Roman Pucinski, former Democratic Congressman from Chicago's Northwest Side, said, Bah, humbug to the Administration's urging to turn off outdoor Christmas lighting.

description: GENEVA, Dec. 13  The European Economic Community today offered to the United States and other trade partners a list of tariff concessions to offset their losses as a result of its expansion to include Britain, Denmark and Ireland.

title: Magic Rocks and Writhes at Festival
description: The World Festival of Magic and Occult, which opened Wednesday at the Felt Forum and continues through Dec. 30, is a show with something for everybody but maybe just a little too much for some. Most of the publicity seems to suggest groovy, rockoriented occultism, and that is indeed one part of the proceedings. But there is also a good deal of oldfashioned magic, plus a dollop of Grand Guignol violence that may make some parents a little squeamishif not their children, who love it.

title: Ed Emshwiller Retrospective on View
description: Of the legion of avant-garde, experimental or, if you will, independent "underground" movie makers, Ed Emshwiller, who has been industriously filming since 1959, deserves the retrospective show that started last night at the Film Forum. If the collection of seven of his shorts, running a total of more than two hours, tends to be slightly repetitive and occasionally a strain on the eye and ear, it also forcefully illustrates the work of a creative professional who towers above many of his competitors.Oddly enough, the sole new offering, the 22-minute "Chrysalis," made this year with the Alwin Nikolais modern-dance troupe, is only fitfully effective. In tracing and dissecting his choreography through simultaneous, split-screen, slow and accelerated motion, one often gets the impression of expert technique rather than drama or emotion.And, his rarely seen 20-minute "Film With Three Dancers" (1970) is notable mostly for complex camera work that utilizes superimposed and double images (in addition to introspective dialogue) to stress the movement of its three principals.List as the most striking and thoughtful, if not completely comprehensible, subjects in the lot, the 38-minute "Relativity" (1966) and last year's 29-minute "Scape-Mates." In "Relativity," Mr. Emshwiller explores his personal concepts of man and his universe through complicated graphics, animations, several human figures and an electronic musical score. He conveys vaguely similar ideas through humans, animations and drawings in the five-minute "Thanatopsis" (1962)."Scape-Mates," shown early this year on Channel 13, is a versatile videotape mix of computer-aided filming, the Moog synthesizer, animation and arms and legs and human forms to achieve swiftly moving, often arresting patterns from geometric shapes and lunarlike landscapes.The earliest work, the 7-minute "Lifelines" (1960), seems to be merely experimental in its involvement with placental-like drawings and the nude woman seemingly evolving from them. And "George Dumpson's Place" (1964), is an 8-minute exercise concerned simply with affectionately examining dolls and other bric-a-brac strewn about an old black man's garden. The selection may be a special package for special tastes, but it vividly projects the talent and imagination of an artistic film maker.

title: Soviet Links U.S. Oil Shortage To Subversive Zionist Lobby
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13The Soviet press declared today that Americans were going without oil because their country had been subverted by proIsraeli interests.

title: People and Business
description: John M. Henske, a senior vice president of the Olin Corporation, has been named president. He succeeds James F. Towey, 57, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: MARKET DECLINES THIRD DAY IN ROW
KISSINGER AND TM TO MEET IN PARIS AS FIGHTING RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Secretary of State Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, who negotiated the Vietnam ceasefire, will meet in Paris next Thursday, the White House announced today.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13You can hardly take a casual look at today's headlines without wondering where the world is going. Look at its common problems and its narrow divisions. Listen to its leadersand see what happens when men, institutions and nations put their selfish interests ahead of everything else.

title: Nixon's Oil Aides Accused Of Ignoring Shortage Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13A Senate subcommittee investigating causes of the oil and gasoline shortages was told today that the Administration officials responsible for setting petroleum import quotas ignored for more than two years warnings that crude oil supplies were insufficient to meet rising demand.

description: Dr. Austin Vincent Hughes, who retired in 1966 after 55 years of dental practice here, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived at 142 West End Avenue.

Kingston, the two top leaders of the State Assembly, were arraigned and pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of Election Law violations, while both Democrats and Republicansin an unusual display of bipartisan supportrallied around the two accused Republicans.

description: Irving S. Shapiro, the son of a Lithuanianborn Jewish immigrant, is expected to be elected as chairman and chief executive officer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., the nation's largest chemical producer.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Senate narrowly blocked an effort today to stop United States chrome imports from Rhodesia. It was the second time in three days that Senate conservatives defeated a motion to close debate on the issue.

title: Glorified TV Dinners?
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (UN)  Prepackaged frozen entrees in some of San Francisco's worldfamed restaurants? Absolutely, says Supervisor Dianne Feinstein who wants ta do something about it.

description: Mrs. Beverly Becher, fashion director for the Lane Bryant stores, was married here yesterday afternoon to G. Thomas Rainone of New York, who with his father, Raffaele Rainone, owns and operates the Gem Oil Company of Brooklyn.

title: Jets Love O.J. but Will Try to Stop Him
description: Listening to the Jets talk, to know O. J. Simpson is to love himand to know how impossible it will be to prevent him from breaking Jim Brown's rushing record Sunday at Shea Stadium.
