description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: U.S. Holiday Closings
description: Most Federal offices here and elsewhere around the country will be closed the next two MondaysChristmas Eve and New Year's Eveas awell as on the holidays themselves, under an order issued in Washington yesterday by President Nixon. The Executive order declared Dec. 24 and Dec. 31 as additional holidays for nonessential operations.

title: Hook of F.C.C. Tells Blacks To Act on Broadcast Jobs
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, the first black member of the Federal Communications Commission, told a Harlem audience last night that if blacks got together they could change the dismal picture in minority ownership. and employment in broadcasting.

title: Holders Approve Sale of GAC Unit To BankAmerica
description: Stockholders of the GAC Corporation at a meeting in Allentown, Pa., approved yesterday the sale of GAC Finance, Inc., to the BankAmerica Corporation and the sale of GAC's Stuyvesant Insurance Group to H. F. Ahmanson & Co. Proceeds of the two transactions total approximately $113million cash.

title: TV: Williams's Haunting Menagerie
description: This weekend's television event, being presented Sunday evening at 8:30, is the new production of Tennessee Williams's The Glass Menagerie, starring Katharine Hepburn. Taking no chances, the American Broadcasting Company has been assiduously grinding the publicity mills for several months. Members of the press have been rushing, and occasionally stumbling, to get there first with the exclusive interview or breathless review. One film critic managed to review the TV production a month ago.

title: Conable of Rochester Will Head G.O.P. Policy Panel in House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Rochester Republican who is a strong supporter of president Nixon and a close ally of Governor Rockefeller, today becathe the first New Yorker in 35 years to be elected to the House Republican leadership.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13He doesn't look like a basketball player, but Paul Reid has been a menace to a lot of New Jersey college teams this season. The 6foot2inch Reid thin and shy but, as a coach would say, he does it all.

title: Blood Reduces Fine
description: MUSKEGON, Mich., Dec. 13 (AP)District Court Judge Frederic Grimm Jr. says any traffic violator appearing before him can have his fine and court costs reduced $20 if he donates blood to the Red Cross land proves he did so by Dec. 30.

title: Reserve Is Urged to Ban ClosedEnd Investing Units
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) A mutual fund organization asked the Federal Reserve Board today to prohibit the operation of closedend investment companies. These are funds that operate with a fixed amount of capital in which investors receive shares whose value is determined by supply and demand on the securities market.

title: TroopCut Talks Adjourn With Polish Attack on West
description: VIENNA, Dec. 13Negotiators at the EastWest conference on troop reductions in Central Europe recessed today for the holidays, and Poland's delegate publicly attacked Western proposals made in the first six weeks of discussions.

title: California Convicts Locked in Cells Around the Clock to Curtail Prison Violence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13Inmates in California's major prisons are being held in their cells around the clock in what officials say is an effort to end an increase in violence in the institutions.

title: Snapshots' Clicks as Film About a Film
description: Experimental films of a movie in production, with impromptu soul-baring by the contributors, are an avant-garde staple by now. Most of them are pretentious bores. But "Snapshots," which the Whitney Museum of American Art is presenting through Wednesday in its New American Filmmakers series, is an exception.Produced by Kenneth E. Schwartz and directed by Mel Howard, the co-writers, the picture is apparently a truthful production diary involving on-camera embraces by some young Greenwich Villagers and off-camera bickering by one and all. This is not a movie for everybody. The sex is explicit and the language is fierce.Yet the whole thing has a fresh, spontaneous flow and thoughtful texture. Mr. Howard's sideline use of his own family background is original and amusing, almost a movie in itself (with some haunting camera shots of the Ellis Island shell). Wryly amusing, too, and revealing, is the bleak confusion after the director steps aside as leading man and hands over his heroine-mistress, Turid Aarsted, to his handsome photographer, Paul Goldsmith, the new hero.Add to this some beautiful color photography, effective use of Mahler music and the pervading determination of Mr. Schwartz (heard but not seen) and his partner to get it all on camera, as something different. And it iseven touching, ultimately. The only catch is a redundant finale that suggests Hitchcock's "Psycho."Let's ignore that candid postscript, with the two movie makers, who express their discouragement with the project. We need them around.

title: DECLINES POSTED FOR COMMODITIES
description: Most commodities futures prices were lower yesterday for the second session on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Auto Industry Facing Lasting Changes
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13  The energy crisis is expected to have a more profound and lasting effect on the future of the auto industry than the challenges of the environmental and safety movements of the last decade. It has created what one top auto executive described as a whole new bail game.

title: West Point Dismisses Coach Cahill
description: Tom Cahill, the man who worked miracles with Army's football teams in the late nineteen sixties, was dismissed as West Point's head football coach yesterday just 12 days after Army concluded its worst season by losing to Navy, 510.

title: RULES ON OPTIONS REVISED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission issued revised regulations today for exempting trading in options from its registration requirements.

title: Maximum Income Is Raised For School Lunch Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced an increase today in the maximum income a family can have and still qualify for their children to get reducedprice school lunches.

title: Heart Recipient Dies
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 13 (AP)Gladys Manis of Kingsport, Tenn., who received a new heart in transplant surgery at the Medical College of Virginia here Oct. 5, died today. A spokesman said Mrs. Manis, 39yearold mother of three children, had died of complications arising from pneumonia, a brain abscess and rejection of the tissue of the transplanted heart.

title: Investigations Into Small Business Administration Could Change Way It Is Run
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The first round of public hearings on the Small Business Administration, which ended Tuesday, indicated that the agency was, in the words of a television car salesman, in a heap of trouble.

title: Simon Offers New Plans To Reduce Use of Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Government proposed new energysaving measures today as President Nixon guardedly expressed hope that voluntary conservation by the American people would make gasoline rationing unnecessary.

title: BIDRIGGING LAID TO CAMDEN MAYOR
description: TRENTON, Dec. 13Mayor Angelo Errichetti of Camden was indicted by a state grand jury here today on charges involving a bribery conspiracy, perjury, forgery and misconduct while he was the city's Director of Public Works.

title: 15 Seoul Leaders Demand Restoration of Full Democracy to Avert a Crisis
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 13A group of 15 senior South Korean politicians, educators and religious leaders, including the only living former president of the country, called today for the restoration of full democracy before a grave national crisis occurs.

title: 5 N.F.L. Playoff Berths At Stakein Weekend Play
description: Three division titles and five of the eight playoff berths will be decided on the final weekend of pro football's regular season. Twelve teams are, eligible for the playoffs although the qualifying chances of three, Atlanta, Buffalo and Cleveland, are remote indeed, Five of the 12Dolphins, Steelers, Vikings, Broncos and Raiderswill be seen on television here. Tomorrow's games are Detroit at Miami, Channel 2 at 1 P.M., and Pittsburgh at San Francisco, Channel 4 at 4 P.M. On Sunday it will be Minnesota and the Giants at New Haven, Channel 2 at 1 P.M., followed by Denver at Oakland, Channel 4 at 4 P.M. Here is a preview of all the games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

description: GRAPHIC DESIGN. By Milton Glaser. Preface by Jean Michel Folon. 239 pages. Illustrated. Overlook Press/Viking. $30.

description: From Jerusalem, London, Paris, Antwerp, Amsterdam, Melbourne and all over the country Hasidic Jews converged last night on 770 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, the international headquarters of the Lubavitcher movement.

title: 100,000 Pensioned Members Of U.M.W Lose Voting Rights
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (AP) The United Mine Workers convention stripped its more than 100,000 pensioned members of most of their voting privileges today and resolved to disband locals with fewer than 10 active rnembers.

title: Advertising: Needham Changes
description: The relationship between S. C. Johnson & Son and Needham, Harper & Steers, which waxed strong for 43 years is now on the wane and ends completely March 15.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon will undergo his annual twohour medical checkup at the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., tomorrow. This year, the checkup has political as well as medical overtones.

title: School's In for Students Of Swiss Ski Directors
description: FLIMS, Switze??land, Dec. 10  This is backtoschool week for hundreds of Swiss Ski School directors, and today 91 of them were teaching 847 students from all parts of Europe and the United States the finer phases of the downhill sport. What we are doing here in Flims, however, ist a kleinen Teil von dem Bild [is a small part of the picture], said Karl Gamma, director of Switzerland's Ski School Association. There are now at least 5,000 pupils  about onethird of them Americanstaking lessons all over Switzerland. Where else? At such other resorts as St. Moritz, Zermatt, Arosa, Davos, CransMontana and Verbier, to mention a few.

title: Ocean Hill Faction Calls for Election On Board Vacancy
description: The new chairman of the community school board in the Ocean HillBrownsville district of Brooklyn called yesterday for a special election to fill a vacahcy on the board, because, he said, he and his fellow board members could not agree on a choice.

title: City Gasoline Crisis Turns Out To Be Just a Minor Cutback
description: An anticipated crisis in gasoline supplies available to the citywith shortages so acute that city officials were warning of serious cutbacks in police and fire protection and other vital serviceswas apparently never a crisis at all. It now appears to have been a misunderstanding.

title: EGYPTIANS CHARGE A U.S. SPY FLIGHT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13Egypt protested to the United States today, a few hours before Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival, against what she called a violation of Egyptian airspace by an American spy plane last Monday.

title: Automatic Rate Rises Granted To Phone Company in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13  The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company became today the first subsidiary of the American Telephone & Telegraph system to get the right to pass on automatically to consumers a portion of its increased fuel, labor and other costs without going through formal rate proceedings.

title: Reed Waits For Verdict On Surgery
description: I'm feeling a lot of pain, said Willis Reed of the Knicks in his hospital bed in Oklahoma City yesterday. You know, the postoperative kind of pain. I sure don't feel like seeing anyone.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey Blue Cross has agreed, because of a $27million surplus in reserves, not to seek a rate increase next year, according to the State Insurance Commissioner, Richard C. McDonough. A Blue Cross spokesman confirmed that the nonprofit hospitalization plan would abide the Commissioner's recommendation.

title: Commerce Report Notes a Rise In Business Sales in October
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Total business inventories rose by $2.1billion in October, a little more than the averag monthly increase in 1973 but still less than the rise in sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: Albert ChristJaner, artist, educator and author, died Wednesday near Como, Italy, when his car went down a cliff. He was 63 years old and lived in Athens, Ga.

title: Getting High in Mountainside
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J.  Everyone laughed when the boy walked into the door. I didn't. They were high. I wasn't.

description: FOXBORO, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP)John Hannah, the New England Patriots' rookie offensive guard from Alabama, suffered a fractured fibula in his right leg today in a punt protection drill. Hannah was injured when he was accidentally kicked by Greg Boyd, a defensive back.

title: Cloud Over Albany
description: The damage already done to public confidence in the political process by the Watergate scandals is inevitably heightened by the indictment of New York State Assembly Speaker Duryea and two other Republican Assemblymen on charges of illegally conspiring to elect G.O.P. candidates through use of misrepresentation to siphon off Democratic votes into the Liberal column.

title: Stage: Iceman Cometh to Broadway
description: Pace was always a prime concern with America's greatest dramatist, Eugene O'Neill. He dared time. He wrote long plays, but never carelessly. His plays were long because the best of them are essentially plays of theme rather than exposition. They are markers to a drowned life, autobiographical, intense, and acquiring their dramatic flavor from an atmosphere that seduces its audience into the very past of a time experienced.

title: Former Bear Is Stabbed
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)Wayne Mass, 27 years old, a former offensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, was stabbed early today by two men who attacked him from the rear after he stopped to assist a driver involved in a hitandrun accident. Mass, 6 feet 4 inches tall and 250 pounds, fought off the men and was walking toward his car when he realized he had been stabbed. He was taken to a hospital, where his condition was reported as fair.

description: John Doar, who for the last six years has headed the technicalassistance arm of the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation, has resigned from that position, effective today.

title: About New York Getting a Baby for $710
description: He was a mechanic, and she was a secretary, and they had been married nine years. For seven of those years they had wanted to have children, but nothing had worked, and so they had long talks and old longings and consulted with doctors. That hadn't worked, either.

title: City Boys' Home Depicted As Base for Criminal Raids
description: The city's Jennings Hall temporary shelter for boys was depicted in a state report yesterday as a place from which youngsters easily sortie to commit muggings and return bedecked in stolen finery and from which youths once left to perpetrate a rape and a murder.

title: G.M. and Ford Win An Antitrust Round
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13Federal District Judge John Feikens today dismissed a Government charge that the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company conspired in 196970 to monopolize the market for automotive fleet sales.

title: Toyota Won't Provide Spare Tires in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP)The Toyota Motor Company said today that it had ceased equiping new motor vehicles for sale in the domestic market with spare tires.

title: Starlings Find Few Friends In Waterbury
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 13Well, what would you do with 250,000 starlings perched outside your window?

title: TENANTS WARNED ABOUT RENT RISES
description: Tenants of the 1.1 million rentcontrolled apartments here were told by the city yesterday that they would not be required to pay any new rent increases in 1974 until officially notified by the city.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Another Job Open At Giants?
description: Bob Broadhead, Upton Bell, Vic Schwenk, Al Ward, Jack Teel, John Thompson and Tim Mara are hardly household words in the world of pro football. But for the esoteric Giant fan, concerned and curious about the future of his team, each one means something.

title: Loan Snag Fails to Deter Soviet Energy Projects
description: The Soviet Union, which has been looking to American investment in its Siberian oil and gas resources, has apparently not been deterred by the prospect of a cutoff of large credits from the United States and has been moving forward on several fronts through its own efforts.

title: Former Bear Is Stabbed
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)Wayne Mass, 27 years old, a former offensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, was stabbed early today by two men who attacked him from the rear after he stopped to assist a driver involved in a hitandrun accident. Mass, 6 feet 4 inches tall and 250 pounds, fought off the men and was walking toward his car when he realized he had been stabbed. He was taken to a hospital, where his condition was reported as fair.

title: British Crisis Poses Key Question for Common Market
description: PARIS, Dec. 13Britain is expected to seek help from her Common Market partners in dealing with her worst economic crisis of many in the postwar period.

title: ACCOUNTANTS GET CRRENCY RULING
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the new organization established earlier this year to set down the rules for writing financial reports, issued yesterday its first statement, a set of regulations governing the translation of foreign currency into dollars.

title: Operator of Bronx Store Is Wounded by a Robber
description: The operator of a variety store in the Highbridge section of the Bronx was shot last night by a rubber who took an undetermined amount of money from the store's cash register, the police reported.

title: Screen: OftWed King
description: It's always intriguing to watch the development of an actor: Keith Michell has come a very long way since I heard him bellowing If mewHODsic be the food of love ... at Stratford, England, a good many years ago. It wasn't then foreseeable that he would become such a fine character actor, as is now clear in Henry VIII and His Six Wives, which opened yesterday at the 86th Street East and is opening at neighborhood theaters. The movie production was shot afresh after the success of the British Broadcasting Corporation's television series, shown here on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Cambodia Forming A New Government As In Tam Resigns
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 13 (Reuters)President Lon Nol of Cambodia has announced that a new government will be formed shortly with the emphasis on foreign policy and internal security, following the resignation of Premier In lam.

title: The Name Isn't Southern But the Food Certainly Is
description: ?? restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated lour stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the pric'e of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: AfoAKom Joyously Greeted on Its Return Home
description: LAIKOM, Cameroon, Dec. 11 Men in brightly colored tribal dress punched at the air with spears, joyously, reliving the triumphs of old wars. Ancient flintlock rifles barked in salute. Women waved raffia fronds in welcome and they swayed and chanted in unison, The AfoAKom is with us once more. There is peace. There is joy.

title: Excerpts From Heath's Address on the Energy Crisis
description: LONDON, Dec. 13  Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Heath's statement to Parliament today:

title: Mayor of Camden Indicted In BidRigging Conspiracy
description: TRENTON, Dec. 13Mayor Angelo Errichetti of Camden was indicted by a state grand jury here today on charges involving a bribery conspiracy, perjury, forgery and misconduct while he was the city's Director of Public Works.

title: The New Commissioner
description: Mayorelect Beame's choice as Police Commissioner, Michael J. Codd, has the same kind of reputation for integrity and efficiency as his two talented predecessors, Patrick V. Murphy and the incumbent, Donald F. Cawley.

title: A New Book Links President Kennedy To Marilyn Monroe
description: Marilyn Monroe had been having a romance with President John F. Kennedy for almost a year when she died, and among her last words were, Say goodby to the President, Earl Wilson, a syndicated columnist, reports in a new book.

title: Simon Offers New Plans TO Reduce Use of Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Government proposed new energysaving measures today as President Nixon guardedly expressed hope that voluntary coritervation, by the American people would make gasoline rationing unnecessary.

title: Crampton Winner Of Vardon Trophy
description: LAKE PARK, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)  Bruce Crampton of Australia won the 1973 Vardon Trophy today, becoming the first foreign golfer to be so honored since Harry Cooper of England in 1937. The award is based on the best scoring average for 80 rounds.

title: Quarry Favored Over Shavers
description: In what is anticipated to be a spectacular heavyweight bout between two 28yearold knockout punchers, Jerry Quarry will oppose Earme Shavers tonight at Madison Square Garden with the winner perhaps advancing to a title bout with George Foreman next year.

title: AfoAKom Joyously Greeted on Its Return Home
description: LAIKOM, Cameroon, Dec. 11 Men in brightly colored tribal dress punched at the air with spears, joyously reliving the triumphs of old wars. Ancient flintlock rifles barked in salute. Women waved raffia fronds in welcome and they swayed and chanted in unison, The AfoAKom is with us once more. There is peace. There is joy.

title: RapidAmerican Sets Records In Quarterly Profits and Sales
Judge Denies Squatters' Plea to Stay Eviction From Delaware Gap Area
description: SHAWNEE, Pa., Dec. 13Federal Judge Michael J. Sheridan today denied a plea by squatters for a delay of eviction from the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area here.

title: Loss to the Caribbean
description: It is as difficult to imagine a Government of Trinidad and Tobago headed by someone other than Eric Williams as to picture Kenya without Kenyatta. That is why his People's National Movement has implored him to reconsider his decision to retire as party leader and Prime Minister. Dr. Williams reluctantly agreed to delay his departurebut only until elections expected next year.

title: Firefly Designation Urged
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 13 (UPI)A bill designating the firefly as Pennsylvania's official insect was introduced yesterday in the legislature.

title: UPJOHN STOCK HIT BY DRUG REPORT
description: The Upjohn Company, whose shares plunged 15 points on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to a 1973 low of 69, issued a statement after the close of the market that said that the reaction to a report of drugrelated deaths in New Zealand had been exaggerated.

title: Regan on the Right Track For a MillionDollar Year
Business Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (UPI)  A classaction suit has been filed against the nation's biggest stock brokerage house for allegedly charging illegal rates of interest on margin loans to tens of thousands of California investors.

title: What a Crazy Brain!
description: We are sitting in front of the TV set, the brain and me, the way we do sometimes in the evening, and the brain is complaining again. You know what a brain is like. Always complaining.

title: U. S. ART PRICES DROP IN AUCTION
description: It was a mixed bag from which dealers and collectors plucked their choices yesterday and Wednesday evening at the Sotheby Parke Bernet auction of American paintings, many from the first few decades of this century. And the results were mixed, too.

title: BRITAIN SUFFERS WIDE BLACKOUTS
description: LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 15 The first blackouts of Britain's energy crisis darkened large areas of London and the rest of the nation last night.

title: Quilts: As They Appear in a Festival and Between the Covers of Books
description: Grandma's quilts never looked as grand as in the Great American Quilt Festival that opened yesterday for a twoweek run in a rented East Side townhouse, a minimansion embellished with Italianate moldings, arched doorways and sweeping staircases.

title: DEMOCRAT IN LINE FOR SAXBE'S SEAT
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 14Howard M. Metzenbaum, a millionaire lawyer  businessman from Cleveland and a Democrat, is expected to be named by Gov. John J. Gilligan next week to succeed Attorney Generaldesignate William B. Saxbe, an Ohio Republican, in the United States Senate.

title: F.A.A. Asks Sunday Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration today asked aviation gasoline and jet fuel dealers to limn voluntarily Sunday sales to pleasure fliers. The F.A.A. administrator, Alexander Butterfield, said the voluntary ban would not apply to commercial carriers or to the high priority general aviation user.

title: People and Business
description: Restaurant Associates Industries, Inc. whose 145 units throughout the country include such well  known names as Mamma Leone's, Brasserie, Trattoria and Zum Zumhas named Richard A. Blumenthal as president. He succeeds Martin Brody, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: No Recession Expected By the Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)President Nixon and his economic advisers do not believe there is going to be a recession as a result of the energy crisis, a White House spokesman said today.

title: 18 Chicago Police Get Prison Terms In Extortion Case
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14, (Reuters)Eighteen Chicago policemen received today prison sentences ranging from six years to 18 months for extorting money from bar owners.

title: Mrs. Peck Wed to Lars Potter Jr.
description: Mrs. Victoria Tyner Peck and Lars Sellstedt Potter Jr., both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon. State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Ruth Dubonnet, a friend of the couple.

title: Mass Slayer Given Life
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)William Ray Bonner was sentenced to life imprisonment today for an Easter Sunday shooting spree that left seven persons dead. He pleaded guilty to three countsfirst and second degree murder and assault with a deadly weapon on Nov. 13, the day he was scheduled to go on trial on 18 charges.

title: Double Pays $7,907
description: MIAMI, Dec. 14 (UPI)A 79 combination paid $7,907.80 today at Calder race course, the biggest daily double in the 43year history of the track. The first race was won by Pretty Chipper, who paid $93.60 for $2 to win. Royal Powder won the second race and paid $103.80. The previous double record of $7,205.40 was set March 18, 1935.

title: Condemned To Success
description: BRUSSELSThree, major problems were defined for Western statesmen at this week's conference of NATO foreign ministers:

title: Infant's Body Is Cremated in an Error Laid to the Medical Examiner's Office
description: The City Medical Examiner's office mistakenly gave the body of a 15dayold boy who died at Mount Sinai Hospital last week to a Queens funeral home, which cremated it, the boy's parents said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AU Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Text of Declaration by European Common Market
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Following is the text of the declaration of policy issued here today by the European Economic Community:

title: KISSINGER URGES SAUDI KING TO END U.S. OIL EMBARGO
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14Secretary of State Kissinger met for 90 minutes tonight with King Faisal to inform him of American efforts to move the Middle East crisis to the peace table and to try to convince him that the oil embargo against the United States should now be lifted.

title: 76ers Win No. 10, Top, Last Season
description: DETROITS, Dec. 14 (UN) Fred Carter scored 23 points and Leroy Ellis pumped in 18 tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers broke a fivegame losing streak and snapped the Detroit Pistons' sevengame winning streak with a 9693 National Basketball Association victory.

title: Saving the Fare
description: Prospects for saving the 35cent transit fare have been significantly enhanced but by no means guaranteed a result of the agreement announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller and Mayorelect Beame.

title: LOMENZO RESIGNS SECRETARY'S POST
description: Governor Rockefeller anpounced the resignation of Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo yesterday, six months after the cabinet member had been embroiled in controversy, then cleared of contractinterference charges.

title: 4 Arab Ministers Confront Common Market Meeting
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Saturday, Dec. 15Four Arab foreign ministers arrived here yesterday and brought the European Common Market the message that before the oil embargo can be ended Europe must do more to influence a Middle East political settlement favorable to the Arab cause.

title: Trucks Are Damaged in Protest on Fuel Situation
description: Blockades at truck stops and scattered incidents of violence yesterday marked the second day of a wildcat work stoppage by thousands of independent truck drivers protesting higher fuel prices and lower speed limits.

title: 2 Fees Are Raised For 100th Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 14 (AP)The entry and starting fees for next year's 100th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs has been raised to keep out some horses that might not belong.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: An afternoon rally on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market on reports of an easing of the Arab oil embargo sent prices higher on both markets yesterday.

title: LOCKHEED FACING FINANCIAL CRISIS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, saved from bankruptcy in 1971 by a Government guarantee of up to $250million in loans, sought urgent help yesterday to save itself from a new financial crisis.

title: MASON SEARS DEAD; EXU.S. AIDE AT U.N.
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Mason Sears of Dedham, who served as United States representative to the United Nations Trusteeship Council from 1953 to 1960, died yesterday at Faulkner Hospital. His age was 73.

title: Widower Awarded A Widow's Benefits On Social Security
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  A threejudge Federal Court ruled today that a widower was entitled to the same monthly Social Security death benefits that a widow collects in payments that are called mother's insurance benefits.

title: 3 Robbers in Bronx Bind Wife in House, Get $290,000 Loot
description: Three men forced their way into a private home in the Bronx yesterday, bound a woman with tape and carted off heavy safe containing $250,000 in negotiable bonds, $20,000 in cash and $20,000 in Jewelry.

title: Price Increases Announced By Chrysler and American
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UPI)Chrysler Corporation and American Motors announced price increases on their cars and trucks today, ending the second round of price increases on 1974 models.

title: People in Sports: Davis Signs
description: Willie Davis, the center fielder obtained last week by Montreal from the Los Angeles Dodgers in a trade for Mike Marshall, ace relief pitcher, signed a twoyear contract with the Expos yesterday. Although the terms were not announced, it was reported Davis would receive more than $200,000 for the next two seasons. Davis, who bats and throws lefthanded, hit .285 last season, with 16 homers and 77 runs batted in. I'm still the fastest 33yearold in baseball and can cover a lot of outfield, he said. I'm not a homerun hitter, but I expect to hit a lot of triples and wait for somebody to bring me home. I'm friendly with both Ron Fairly and Bob Bailey and I'm happy to be on the same team with them again. They played with me on the Dodgers.

title: Pan Am Warns of Halt In U.S.London Service
description: LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Pan American Airways warned tonight it might have to halt its transatlantic flights from London after Christmas unless the British Government gave it more fuel.

title: Donahue's 8:56.6 Wins 2Mile Run
description: Tom Donahue of the North Jersey Striders won the featured twomile race in an Amateur Athletic Union development meet at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight.

title: After 11 Months of Battles Since Truce, Saigon Troop Morale Is Sagging Badly
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13  In almost a year since the signing of the Paris ceasefire agreement, the morale of many South Vietnamese fighting units appears to have sagged seriously.

title: Student's Marijuana Story Stuns Jersey High School
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Dec. 14  Jonathan Dayton Regional High School here boiled with indignation today as a result of an article by a student who reported the widespread smoking of marijuana at the school.

title: Comecon Indicates Concern On Fuel in Eastern Europe
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP) The Sovietled economic union, Comecon, today indicated concern over fuel supplies within the Communist bloc.

title: Patents Aide Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) President Nixon today nominated Curtis Marshall Dann, an executive of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., in Wilmington, Del., to be United States Commissioner of Patents. Mr. Dann, 58 years old, would succeed Robert Gottschalk, who resigned the post last June. His nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: Two Forgotten Rangers May Be in Picture Tonight
description: Perhaps if televisionwatchers are lucky, they may get a glimpse (in living color) tonight of those two forgotten men on the Rangers  Gene Carr and Jack Egers. In recent games these youngsters, who have been termed promising for several years, have been on the ice sporadically. Maybe tonight against Toronto, if the New Yorkers establish a big early lead, the pair will see more duty.

title: Article 4  No Title
Stage: The Multigravitational Group
description: Conceptual theater is a fascinating, dangerous and, very occasionally, valuable thing. Let me define. Conceptual theater happens when some creative mind mikes a hop and says, in effect: Wouldn't it be interesting if ...

title: Bucks County Playhouse Is Closing
description: The Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., one of the country's oldest and best known strawhat theaters, will close its doors permanently Dec. 22 because of continuing and unmanageable deficits.

title: Grounded Tanker Refloated Here
description: A 572foot tanker carrying gasoline and oil ran aground yesterday at about 3 P.M., on the Ways Reef near the Hell Gate Bridge in the East River. It was finally freed by tugboats at 8:15 last night.

title: British Town Hopes to Muddle Through
description: LUTON, England, Dec. 14 Nineteen businessmen have just returned from a monthlong trade mission to Australia, New Zealand and Singapore with orders worth $2.3  million for the ball bearings, electronic components, machine tools, hats, paper tapes and other goods produced in this industrial town 30 miles north of London.

title: Erich Fromm on the Nation: I Am Not an Optimist
description: American society has turned sour for Dr. Erich Fromm, the social philosopher and psychoanalyst. He came to this country from Berlin in the early nineteenthirties, an exile from. Hitler's Germany and full of hope to live and work in a vibrant democratic nation.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Wilson's Prospects
description: After 15 years of relative obscurity as Lieutenant Governor, Malcolm Wilson has gotten off to a strong start toward the pinnacle of power in this state in one of the most amazing weeks in New York politics, which saw the Governor announce his resignation and the state's most powerful legislator indicted. Even foes of the 59yearold News Mr. Wilsonof the Analysis narrow necktie, the closecropped hair and the Ciceronian sentencesadmitted yesterday that Mr. Wilson had moved long way toward winning the Republican nomination for Governor next year.

title: British Town Hopes to Muddle Through
description: LUTON, England, Dec. 14 Nineteen businessmen have just returned from a monthlong trade mission to Australia, New Zealand and Singapore with orders worth $2.3  million for the ball bearings, electronic components, machine tools, hats, paper tapes and other goods produced in this industrial town 30 miles north of London.

title: US. FUND DENIED ROCKEFELLER UNIT BY SENATE GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The prospects of Congressional financing of Governor Rockefeller's $20million Commission on Critical Choices for America dimmed today amid criticism that the commission was Rockefeller vehicle for a 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: ERVIN, WEICKER REVEAL TAX DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) At the prodding of the White House, Senators Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, and Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, made public, their 1972 income tax returns today.

title: Unitas Goes to Court
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) Johnny Unitas's $750,000 suit against his old team, the Baltimore Colts, will have to he settled in court, rather than in arhitration by the National Football League, Superior Court Judge Joseph C. Howard ruled today. The Colts had asked that the case be arbitrated. The suit charges malicious breach of a 10year personal services contract.

title: COLLEGES WARNED ON SEGREGATION
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14The Board of Regents directed the State Education Commissioner today to move against the small number of institutions of higher education in the state that, it said, permit minoritygroup students to segregate themselves in racially separate living arrangements on campus.

title: N.C. State Takes Aim At U.C.L.A.
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14The University of California, Los Angeles, with a record, 78 straight basketball victories, and North Carolina State, with 29 consecutive triumphs, meet tomorrow in a glamorous earlyseason match made possible and attractive because North Carolina State was placed on probation last season.

title: Sadat Rules Out Direct Negotiations With Israelis at Geneva Peace Parley
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14President Anwar elSadat today ruled out direct negotiations with Israel at the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva on Tuesday.

title: Jersey Man Wins a Widow's Social Security Benefits
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14A threejudge Federal Court ruled today that a widower was entitled to the same monthly Social Security death benefits that a widow collects in payments that are called mother's insurance benefits.

title: Howard Seibert, Authority On Infant Nutrition, Dies
description: MALVERN, Pa., Dec. 14Howard F. Seibert, senior vice president of Wyeth Laboratories in Radnor and an authority on infant nutritional formulas, died last evening in Jefferson Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. Funds Denied Rockefeller's Panel By a Senate Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The prospects of Congressional financing of Governor Rockefeller's $20million Commission on Critical Choices for America dimmed today amid criticism that the commission was Rockefeller vehicle for a 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: Private Woodcutters Now Welcome On State LandIf They Follow Rules
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y.Joseph Labonte Jr. drove over a rutted dirt road into a stateowned forest near here the other day, started his chain saw, and cut down a towering hickory tree. He cut the felled tree into 18inch lengths, loaded the wood onto his pickup truck, and drove out again.

title: Athens Frees Some Prisoners Seized in Riots Before the Coup
description: ATHENS, Dec. 14Some of the several hundred political prisoners held by the military police since last month's student riots were released today. They included a dozen professors, journalists, actors and Ilawyers.

title: WALTER H. KNORR
description: CLARK, N. J., Dec. 14Walter H. Knorr, president of the Safeguard Electrical Products Corporation of Linden and vice president of Continental Copper and Steel Industries of New York, died today at the Perth Amboy General Hospital, He was 64 years old.

title: Student's Marijuana Account Stuns School
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Dec. 14  Jonathan Dayton Regional High School here boiled with indignation today as a result of an article by a student who reported the widespread smoking of marijuana, at the school.

title: I. B. M. IS TARGET IN 1BILLION SUITS
description: The Memorex Corporation, manufacturer of peripheral equipment for computers, and several of its subsidiaries yesterday filed antitrust suits in Federal Court in San Francisco against the International Business Machines Corporation. The suits ask damages of just over $1billion, and if successful could bring an award of $3billion.

title: Foreign Trade Bill: Nixon Accepted Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14President Nixon knowingly took two major risks when, overt the opposition of Secretary of State Kissinger, he decided last week to ask the House to proceed with the sweeping foreign trade bill that eventually was approved Tuesday.

title: M.T.A. Ready for 2for1 Fare Test Tomorrow
description: As the Metropolitan Transportation Authority prepared for the start tomorrow of its experiment in charging oneway fares for round trips on subways and buses on Sundays, a study was issued urging that the plan be extended to Saturdays and offpeak weekday hours.

title: KISSINGER URGES SAUDI KING TO END U.S. OIL EMBARGO
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14Secretary of State Kissinger met for 90 minutes tonight with King Faisal to inform him of American efforts to move the Middle East crisis to the peace table and to try to convince him that the oil embargo against the United States should now be lifted.

title: Los Angeles Acts on Crisis
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (Reuter)The Los Angeles City Council, faced with a fuel sheitage described by officials here as the worst for any major city in the nation, today ordered mandatory power cutbacks, including a ban on swimming pool heaters. From Dec. 21, residential users and industry must reduce last year's power usage by 10 per cent and commercial users by 20 per cent.

title: LOMENZO RESIGNS SECRETARY'S POST
description: Governor Rockefeller anbounced the resignation of Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo yesterday, six months after the cabinet member had been embroiled in controversy, then cleared of contractinterference charges.

title: Antiques: Revival in Victorian Jewelry
description: Fashion leaders ignore it and caratconscious gem enthusiasts deplore it. Yet, for several understandable reasons, there is a definite revival of interest in Georgian and Victorian jewelry.

title: HOUSE VOTE BARS GIVING INDOCHINA OIL FOR MILITARY
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 15The House passed an emergency energy bill early this morning after attaching to it a ban on petroleum shipments for military use in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.

title: Gun Permit Is Issue in Cedeno Case
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 14 (UPI)A prosecutor questioned today whether the weapon with which a 19yearold woman was fatally shot while in a motel room with Cesar Cedeno was registered to the baseball player.

title: New Theater Unveiled At Brooklyn Academy
description: A new theater, the Lepercq Space, named in honor of Paul A. Lepercq, board chairman of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was dedicated Thursday. Attending the ceremonies were Richard Clurman, the city's Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs; Peter Brook, a British director, and Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's executive director.

title: PHILL NIBLOCK MUSIC HAS A PIQUANT MOOD
description: Phill Niblock is a composer an film maker who lives in loft at 224 Centre Street in the lower Village. For the last week Mr. Niblock has been inviting some of the more lively experimental composers of this city over to his place for public performances of their music.

title: RECAPITALIZATION IS SET BY MOPAC
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday a recapitalization plan under which the Mississippi River Corporation would become the majority stockholder of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

title: Music: Schumann Faust
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. With Judith Blegen and Phyllis BrynJulson, sopranos; Hilda Harris and Gwendolyn Killebrew, mezzosopranos; Louise Parker, contralto; Stuart Burrows, tenor; Hermann Prey, baritone; John ShirleyQuirk, bassbaritone; Camerate singers. Conducted by Pierre Boulez. At Avery Fisher Hall. Scenes from Goethe's Faust ...Schumann

title: On the Anniversary of a Party in Boston
description: WASHINGTON  Tomorrow is the bicentennial of the Boston Tea Party. It is an occasion to consider the consequences of bigness in eighteenthcentury America. As every school child knows, the tax on tea was enacted by Parliament to bail out the East. India Company. What every school child does not know so well is that the East India was one of the giant business ventures in history, a corporate monster which pillaged a continent in one of the classic ripoffs of all time. The company collected its own taxes for Indian principalities, maintained its own army, fought its own warsall for the benefit of its investors and directors, among whom were, not unnaturally, members of Parliament.

title: LOCKHEED FACING FINANCIAL CRISIS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, saved from bankruptcy in 1971 by a Government guarantee of up to $250million in loans, sought urgent help yesterday to save itself from a new financial crisis.

title: College Fives Take Over Court at Garden Tonight
description: In an effort to bolster sagging attendance at its college basketball doubleheaders, Madison Square Garden today will initiate an experiment in which the colleges and the Knicks switch their normal Saturday playing times. In recent years, the Knicks have played at night and the colleges in the afternoon.

title: Madison High Calm as It Reopens Under a Heavy Police Guard
description: James Madison High School in Brooklyn reopened without incident yesterday after two days of discussions on the roots of the apparently racially motivated violence that erupted there Monday and Tuesday.

title: TURNER SENTENCED TO 169 DAMS IN JAIL
description: Glenn W. Turner, a target of civil and criminal prosecutions for promoting pyramid sales of business franchies, was sentenced yesterday to 169 days in jail. Two of his companies were fined a total of $65,000.

title: 35C TRANSIT FARE SAFE UNTIL MAY IN CITYSTATE DEAL
description: City and state officials announced agreement yesterday on a plan to save the 35cent subway and bus fare in New York City until May 1, 1974, and beyond that date if Federal funds for masstransit subsidies become available.

title: Canada Bid to Hold Addicts And Make Them Seek Help
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14 (UPI)A Canadian commission on nonmedical drug use today recommended new laws to permit the arrest and confinement of heroin addicts for up to three months so they would at least consider treatment.

title: Lieut. Donald J. Blane Marries Karen Clark
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec, 14  Miss Karen Joy Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Clark, was married here this evening to Second Lieut, Donald Joseph Blanc, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Robert N. Blane of Clarendon Hills, Ill., and the late Mr. Blanc.

title: Earthquake Jolts Hawaii
description: HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 14 (AP)A predawn earthquake shook, most parts of the big island of Hawaii yesterday, but no damae or injuries were reported.

title: Pulp Mill Reopening
description: TORONTO, Dec. 14 (AP)AngloCanadian Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd. announced today that it was reopening it pulp mill at Quebec City. The mill has been closed since midJanuary.

title: State Says Welfare Tally Rose Although City Reported It Fell
description: While the city was announcing a reduction of 3,281 persons on welfare rolls for October, it was filing an unpublicized report to the state that showed an actual increase of 88 relief recipients during the month.

title: Fuel Share Assured For Boats
description: Boat owners who have feared their status in the current energy crisis were assured yesterday by the Federal Energy Office that they would receive fair and equal treatment under the gasoline allocation regulations announced on Wednesday.

title: Quarry Stops Shavers at 2:21 of First Despite a Possible Broken Left Wrist
description: In only 2 minutes and 21 seconds, Jerry Quarry battered Earnie Shavers into a helpless knockout victim at Madison Square Garden last night in a brutal heavyweight bout that attracted 14,962 spectators, including George Foreman, Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON LORENZ'S PRIZE
description: Because of what Dr. Konrad Lorenz wrote on racial purity, as a professor in wartime Germany, the propriety of awarding him a Nobel Prize has been questioned in the December issue of The Sciences, organ of the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Bunker to Head U.S. Team at Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 President Nixon today appointed Ellsworth Bunker, the experienced diplomatic troubleshooter, as chief of the United States delegation at the Middle East peace talks scheduled to begin Tuesday in Geneva.

title: Pollack Is Expected to Be a Member
description: Irving M. Pollack, a career official with the Securities and, Exchange Commission, has been selected to fill a vacant seal on the five  member commission, according to sources close to the S.E.C.

title: S.E.C. CURBS TRADING OF OPTIONS ON STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Securities and Exchange Commission put into effect today a rule prohibiting trading on exchanges in options to buy stocksputs, calls, straddles or other such optionsunless approved in advance by the commission.

title: Du Pont Aide to Be Named as Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14President Nixon announced today his intention to nominate C. Marshall Dann of Wilmington, Del., as Commissioner of Patents. Mr. Dann, who is 58 years old and chief patent counsel of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., will succeed Robert Gottschalk, whose resignation as head of the Patent Office was effective June 29.

title: Art: Joy of Drawings at Morgan
description: The exhibition of 16thcentury Italian drawings from the collection of Janos Scholz, which opened Wednesday at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, turned out unexpectedly to be a doubleheader. Originally organized by the National Gallery in Washington, it was first shown there, but on its second goround at the Morgan Library it took on a very special character when Mr. Scholz announced, at the private opening Tuesday night, that he was giving his collection to the library very, very soon, following the immediate transfer of a group of the finest drawings.

title: Leasco to Change Its Name
description: Shareholders of the Leasco Corporation have approved change in the company's name to Reliance Group, Inc., effective Monday. Security holders, it was said, would not be required to exchange their securities as a result of the change.

title: Utah State Bows, 7061, To Temple
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14 (AP)Temple University, led by the secondhalf shooting of Joe Anderson, defeated Utah State, 7061, in opening game of the Volunteer basketball classic tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1973

title: Triplicate Filing Abandoned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) To conserve energy and paper, the Federal Maritime Commission has abandoned triplicate filing requirements for tariffs. Two copies will suffice.

title: 4 Arab Ministers Confront Common Market Meeting
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Saturday, Dec. 15Four Arab foreign ministers arrived here yesterday and brought the European Common Market the message that before the oil embargo can be ended Europe must do more to influence a Middle East political settlement favorable to the Arab cause.

title: Postal Service Planning Work on Holiday Eves
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Postal Service employes are not among the Federal employes who will enjoy Christmas eve and New Year's eve holidays, it was announced today. The Postal Service will be operating on a businessasusual basis, with its employes being given compensatory time off, a spokesman said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City, in a Federal court suit, sought to prevent the Federal and state governments from holding up grants for the Red Hook sewagedisposal project in a dispute over minoritygroup employment.

title: Bauxite Venture Is Set
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday it had joined with companies from six other nations for participation in the development of bauxite reserves in Brazil. Principal sponsors of the project are Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., of Canada and a Brazilian company, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce. Alcan established the reserve in 1963 in the Amazon River basin.

title: CITY SUES STATE AND U.S. ON HIRING
description: New York City has filed a suit in Federal court here in an effort to prevent the Federal and state governments from holding up grants on millions of dollars worth of federally assisted construction projects. The dispute is over the hiring of minoritygroup employes.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: T. W. A. Strike Negotiators Announce Tentative Pact
description: Negotiators for Trans World Airlines and its striking cabin attendants reached a tentative contract agreement last night to end a 41 dayold walkout that has gorunded the airline's 550 daily flights since Nov. 4.

title: JOHN M. BOOKER
description: RED BANK, N. J., Dec. 14John Marshall Booker, who retired several years ago as a partner in the New York brokerage firm of Wagner, Scott & Co. Inc., died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Coal for Power Held Blow to City's Air
description: Federal approval of the state's decision to permit Consolidated Edison to burn coal in its plant at Arthur Kill on Staten Island is an example of the type of environmental decisions we should try to avoid, Dr. Harold Gershinowitz of Rockefeller University said yesterday.

title: The G.O.P.'s Duty ...
description: The accession of Gerald Ford to the Vice Presidency underscores the need for the next step to restore to the White House the credibility and public confidence that indispensable for the nation. This next step is the departure of Richard M. Nixon from the Presidency, and it is evident that the initiative for this next step must now be taken by the Republican leadership.

title: Ski Problem: Getting There and Back
description: New Yorkers, looking for places to ski without using a tank of gasoline for the round trip, lost another slope yesterday on the eve of the unofficial opening of the ski season.

title: 9 Market Countries Define Their European Identity
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 14  The nine member countries of the European Common Market today issued their policy statement on European identity, noting their close ties with the United States but stressing their independence.

title: CURB ON DRIVING UNDER U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Federal energy planners disclosed today that the alternatives to gasoline rationing that were under consideration included a mandatory onedaya week driving ban and the closing of filing stations on Saturdays as well as Sundays to limit longdistance weekend driving.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SCATTERSHOT The 65year old National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has never before sponsored a concert series, but that's what it is doing now, starting with two at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 63d Street (TR 42424). Tomorrow at 3 P.M. Roberta Peters and William Lewis will do a program of operatic arias, duet and solo, while on March 31, Andre Watts will give a piano concert with the Symphony of the New World. The series benefits the group's community programs. Admission: $4 to $10 for each concert; $8 to $20 for both. ... Radio station WBAI's second annual holiday crafts fair takes place today from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. and tomorrow from 11 to 7 at Barnard College's MacIntosh Center at Broadway and 118th Street (8260880). It will benefit the publicly supported station, and you can buy quilts, jewelry, candles, pottery, musical instruments and food from fore than 80 artsycraftsy creative types. Tonight, you can join in a singalong, too. Admission is free, but money is needed. ... The New York Jazz Museum, 125 West 55th Street (7652150) gives free Sunday concerts from 3 P.M. to 6, and they're always overattended; you may have to stand in line to get in. Tomorrow's may be worth a wait. The show is jazz tap dance, done by John T. McPhee, Chuck Green, Buster Brown, dancing away to show that their pedal percussion is an art form at least as much music as dance. ... Tomorrow at noon, there's a threehour concert at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street (4256677), to benefit the personalspending accounts of people detained in the city's houses of detention. You'll hear Bach played on organ, the church choir, the Sidhartha Rock Ensemble, Gary Steigerwalt on piano and the New American Trio. Admission consists of whatever donation you care to make. ... St. Paul the Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street, is being menaced by destruction and is badly in need of any benefits available. One will be forthcoming at 8 P.M. today and at 6 tomorrow, in the shape of a program in the church. Fordham University's dance department is presenting a cast of 25 in GianCarlo Menotti's Medieval fable, The Unicorn, the Gorgon and the Manticore, first done by the New York City Ballet in 1956. It has been restaged by Marian Horosko, and it features two professional dancers in lead parts. The work will be followed by carols sung by children of Lincoln Square Community Center's Double Image Theater. Admission, $2; students, $1. Information: 9564774. ...The Sunday Brunch Company is giving a concert reading, with elements of dance and other movement incorporated, of W. H. Auden's dramatic poem For the Time Being, a Christmas Oratorio, at 4:30 tomorrow at the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 88th Street (AT 98128). Admission to this second in churchsponsored arts events is $2.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Glenn W. Turner, the Florida promoter who convinced 1,604 New Yorkers that they could dare to be great and then allegedly bilked them of $3.8million, was found guilty of criminal and civil contempt of court and fined $65,850 by a State Supreme Court judge here yesterday. He was convicted of failing to abide by the terms of a consent order more than three years ago in which he promised stop using his pyramid sales technique.

title: FELIX M. ERLANGER
description: Felix M. Erlanger, a retired executive of the B.V.D. Company, a manufacturing and licensing organization for various ous types of apparel, died qestypes of apparel, died yesterday at his home, 156 West 86th Street, He was 84 years old.

title: Jack Corbett, 85, Who Fought Baseball's Reserve Clause, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) Jack Corbett, a former minorleague baseballteam owner who challenged the reserve clause and lost, died today after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Coast Volunteers to Check Gas Stations on Sundays
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Volunteers will be patrolling area roads on Sundays to find open gas stations and to flash the word to motorists stranded without fuel.

title: T.W.A. Pact Reached
description: A tentative agreement to end the 41dayold strike by Trans World Airlines' 5,000 stewardesses and stewards was announced by Federal mediators in Washington. Page 62.

title: Nixon's Plane to Be Used Less for Training Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) President Nixon's special plane will be used less for training flights, and the pilot and crew will keep in practice by flying other aircraft to conserve fuel, the White House said today.

title: FASHION TALK
description: In the beginning, there were the sweater sets, the pants suits, the caftans and the shirtwaist dresses, especially the ones in Ultrasuede, the fake leather that you could throw into your washing machine. Not to mention the suit with the box jacket and wrapped skirt that has become practically the only suit in town.

title: Congress Votes Daylight Saving; For Two Years to Save Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Congress passed today and sent to President Nixon emergency legislation he had sought to put the nation on yearround daylight saving time for the first time since World War II to help conserve energy.

title: Market Place: Suits Are Drain On I.B.M. Stock
description: While the stock market as a whole gathered steam and moved upward yesterday afternoon on a report that there was about a 5050 chance that the Arabs would lift their oil embargo in January, International Business Machines, one of Wall Street's bellwether stocks, went the other way.

title: Bethlehem Steel Expanding
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday it planned to open a new underground coal mine just east of Windber, Pa., near Johnstown. Development work on the mine, which would be known as Cambria No. 9, is expected to cost $9million and begin after the first of the year. Coal production is scheduled for sometime in 1975 and will provide employment for about 250 persons.

title: Regents Act to Ban College Segregation A Minority Imposes
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14The Board of Regents directed the State Education Commissioner today to move against the small number of institutions of higher education in the state that, it said, permit minoritygroup students to segregate themselves in racially separate living arrangements on campus.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Dave Anderson
description: On a basketball court against U.C.L.A. for the first time, the tendency is to be awed. Almost to be transfixed.

title: Music
description: Something new in the way of Bach transcriptions turned up in the Dorian Wind Quintet concert at Tully Hall on Thursday night. It was Henry Brant's version (he calls it translation) of the Goldberg Variations for flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon and French horn.

title: WESTGATE DEFAULTS ON 1978 DEBENTURES
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec, 14 (AP)The WestgateCalifornia Corporation, citing a cash shortage, announced yesterday it would not pay the 6 per cent interest due today on convertible subordinated debentures due in 1987.

title: Air Force Aide Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of James W. Plummer of Los Altos, Calif., to be Under Secretary of the Air Force.

title: Trucks Are Damaged in Protest on Fuel Situation
description: Blockades at truck stops and scattered incidents of violence yesterday marked the second day of a wildcat work stoppage by thousands of independent truck drivers protesting higher fuel prices and lower speed limits.

title: Cahill and Byrne Light Capitol Christmas Tree
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)Governor Cahill, accompanied by his good friend Brendan Byrne, today switched on the lights on the traditional State House Christmas tree.

title: JOSEPH WALSH DIES; AT HARVARD 50 YEARS
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 14Dr. Joseph Leonard Walsh, who had been a member of the mathematics faculty at Harvard for half a century before his retirement in 1965, died Monday at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: Mistrial Declared in Chesimard Case as Jury Splits 111
description: The bankrobbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton ended in a mistrial here yesterday in Federal Court as a single juror held out against the other 11 jurors' verdict of guilty.

title: VOLKSWAGEN SEES 7% RISE FOR SALES
description: Volkswagen of America, Inc., which raised prices several times this year to offset currency changes, forecast yesterday that its sales in 1974 would rise about 7 per cent over 1973 levels.

title: BILL ENIS
description: HOUSTON (AP)  Bill Enis, television sportscaster, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. His age was 39.

title: Johnson Asks 11 P.M. TV Shutdown to Save Energy
description: Nicholat Johnson, who resigned as a memter of the Federal Comfnunications Commission last week, has called for a shutdown of television service at 11 P.M, and a ban on advertising of large automobiles and other products that are excessively inefficient users of energy.

title: Q's Halt Net String By 112104
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 14  The New York Nets' ninegame winning streak, longest in the club's American Basketball Association history, was halted tonight by the San Diego Conquistadors, 112104, before a crowd of 8,223 in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: 9 Market Countries Define Their European Identity
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 14  The nine member countries of the European Common Market today issued their policy statement on European identity, noting their close ties with the United States but stressing their independence.

title: GEORGE SCATCHARD, M.I.T. CHEMIST, 81
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14Dr. George Scatchard, professor emeritus of chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Monday at Mount Auburn Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Nixon Delays Checkup To See Energy Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)President Nixon postponed plans to undergo thorough physical examination tomorrow morning so he could meet with his two top energy policy advisers.

title: BOYS' HOME AIDES CITE DEFICIENCIES
description: Representatives of Jennings Hall, a temporary city shelter for boys, told State Assembly investigators yesterday that the great majority of the approximately 100 children there  not just 5 to 10 per, cent as state and, city officials had suggested  had special problems that the shelter could not handle.

title: Romanticism Marks Landscape Show
description: A fullblown romanticism characterizes the large selection of paintings in the exhibition American Landscape Artists of the 19th Century, now on view at the Hirschl and Adler Galleries, 21 East 67th Street.

title: WINE TALK
description: If they like wine, for goodness sake give them some. You don't know what wine they like? So what. If they don't like your choice, they can always serve it to relatives. If you buy a case of 1973 Beaujolais, it's pretty certain they will drink it themselves and thank you for it. The Beaujolais primeur, which is bottled after the first fermentation and is good only for a couple of months, is already available and runs around $36 a case. The Beaujolais nouveau won't be here until January and will cost $24 a case.

title: T.W.A. Pact Reached
description: A tentative agreement to end the 41dayold strike by Trans World Airlines' 5,000 stewardesses and stewards was announced by Federal mediators in Washington. Page 62.

title: Garrett Requests Exchanges to Try Competitive Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission told the nation's stock exchanges today to start experimenting with competitive commission rates by next April.

title: Temple Defeats Stubborn Utah State Five, 7061
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14 (AP)Temple University, led by the secondhalf shooting of Joe Anderson, defeated Utah State, 7061, in opening game of the Volunteer basketball classic tonight.

title: Saudis Keep Old Ways but Adapt to New
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia After 13 centuries of virtual seclusion from all but the Moslem world, the people of Saudi Arabia are being drawn into a relationship with the world of modern technology, high finance and the power struggles of the 20th century.

title: Borrowers Whimsey Fits Holiday Mood
description: As might have been expected, care and taste pervaded The Borrowers, Hallmark's 90minute Christmas special shown last night over the National Broadcasting Company network. As seasonal fare, Mary Norton's children's classicthe tale of a small, inquisitive boy who discovers and protects a happy family trio of tiny beings cozily living under the floorboards of a Victorian mansioncame off well.

title: Allie Wrubel, 68, Composer Of Popular Songs, Is Dead
description: Allie Wrubel, a composer of popular songs during the nineteenthirties and forties, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Twentynine Palms, Calif. His body was cremated yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: 45 Tunisia Students Drown
description: TUNIS, Dec. 14 (UPI)Fortyfive college students drowned yesterday when floodwaters swept away a military truck attempting to rescue them from their school in Gafsa, southwest Tunisia. Government offidais said today.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: LOS ANGELESJimmy Heair, 136 pounds, Glendale, Calif., knocked out Nacho Castenada, 136, Mexico, 9 rounds.

title: About the Jets
description: Joe Namath has been working out and barring an unforeseer development will start tomorrow against Buffalo. He missed last Sunday's game because of a sore and swollen right knee. NaMath says the leg is stronger and he has had no problem bending it as he did a week ago.... John Riggins was listed as probable for tomorrow after having reinjured his shoulder on his lirst play against the Eagles. ... Mark Lomas enters the final game leading the Jets in quarterback sacks with 10. That's two more than last season, when he also led the team... The Jets will announce at their 1st and..10 club limcheon. Monday the capacity in which Weeb Ewbank will remain with the club. He most likely will be involved in the daily operation of the club but not necessarily as general manager.

title: Senate Banking Panel Puts Off Vote on the Casey Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Senate Banking Committee decided today to postpone action on President Nixon's nomination of William J. Casey, to be president of the ExportImport Bank.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAY VICEPRESIDENCY
description: RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 14 (AP) An appeals court has blocked further action temporarily in a suit in which H. R. Haldeman is charged with conspiring to encourage political dissent against President Nixon.

title: 35C TRANSIT FARE SAFE UNTIL MAY 1 IN CITYSTATE DEAL
description: City and state officials announced agreement yesterday on a plan to save the 35cent subway and bus fare in New York City until May 1, 1974, and beyond that date if Federal funds for masstransit subsidies become available.

title: CURB ON DRIVING UNDER U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Federal energy planners disclosed today that the alternatives to gasoline rationing that were under consideration included a mandatory onedaya week driving ban and the closing of filing stations on Saturdays as well as Sundays to limit longdistance weekend driving.

title: Notes on People
description: Traditionally, the men who have headed the Immigration and Naturalization Service have avoided taking a position on the issue of whether immigration should be curtailed, expanded or allowed to stay as is, preferring to act strictly as administrators. The new immigration commissioner, Leonard F. Chapman Jr., who has been on duty only two weeks, plans to change all that. He intends to tell Congress what he thinks immigration policy should be, the former commandant of the Marine Corps said, because I think it is one of my duties. The question, he said, has two sidesthe open door tradition of admitting almost anyone who wants to live here, and what General Chapman called the other end of the spectrumhaul up the gangplank. He hasn't formed his own position, he said.

title: Gromyko Reasserts Plan for 10% Arms Budget Cut
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today reasserted a Soviet proposal that the five major powers of the United Nations Security Council cut their military budgets by 10 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although much has been written about the energy crisis, little is said about the major resultunemployment. While we are driving at slower speeds, buying smaller cars, using less gasoline, cutting down heat and electricity and staying home on Sundays, many people are losing their jobs.

title: Edgar Koerner Weds Eileen McIlvaine
description: In St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University yesterday afternoon, Miss Eileen McIlvaine, a reference librarian at Columbia, was married to Edgar Koerner, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers. The Rev. Paul Coleman, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Cougars' Cunningham Out at Least 8 Weeks
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Dec. 14 (UPI)Billy Cunningham, the Carolina Cougars' forward who was voted the American Basketball Association's most valuable player last season, will undergo surgery next week for removal of a kidney blockage and will be sidelined for at least eight weeks, the team announced today.

title: CITY BOND RATING UPGRADED AGAIN
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised its rating of New York City's bonds to A from BBB  a shift that means it now regards the city's securities as good investment instead of mediumgrade.

title: Peter B. Gordon, Engineer, Worked on ABomb Project
description: Peter B. Gordon, heating engineer and vice president of the engineering concern of Wolf & Munier, Inc., died yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 325 East 72d Street.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: A NIXONDEAN TAPE IS GIVEN TO COURT
description: A tape of a conversation in the White House between President Nixon and his forme?? counsel, John W. Dean 3d about a $200,000 gift to the Nixon campaign fund from Robert L. Vesco, an international financier who is now a fugitive has been turned over to the United States District Courl?? here.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (UPI)A spokesman for the allblack ad hoc committee on the Sugar Bowl announced today that street demonstrations would be staged next week to protest what is called the Racist policies of the organization operating the annual football game. The committee also is trying to block the broadcast of the game between Alabama and Notre Dame.

title: QUEENS MAN SEIZED IN A DOUBLE SLAYING
description: A 57yearold man with a record of arrests for bookmaking, policy and narcotics offenses was charged yesterday with killing his sisterinlaw and her husband and wounding his nephew in their home at 114703 10th Avenue, in the Whitestone section of Queens, at about 6:30 P.M. Thursday.

title: Labor Urges a MortgageRate Rollback
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 14The State A.F.L.C.I.O. adopted a legislative program today that gave top priority to a rollback of mortgage interest rates to 6 per cent, from their new ceiling of 9.5 per cent.

title: American Killed and 4 Wounded In a Search for Dead in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Saturday, Dec. 15One American soldier was killed and four were wounded this morning when Communist forces shot down a helicopter that was carrying them on a search for the remains of an American missing in South Vietnam since 1966.

title: Senate Bars New Move to Halt Debate on Legal Help for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Legislation to create an independent government corporation to finance legal services for the poor continued to run into trouble in the Senate today.

title: Recession in Economy Of Japan Held Possible
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14A senior Japanese economic official warned today that the international oil crisis and internal inflation could bring the vaunted Japanese economy to a complete collapse.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Striking workers at the Helene Fuld Hospital in Trenton agreed yesterday to return to work for $1 more week than the hospital offered them 12 weeks ago when the strike began. Although the 225 strikers had demanded a $20aweek raise over a twoyear period, they settled for an increase of $7.50, bringing the salary level to $140 a week, effective September, 1974. In addition to the $7.50 raise, the employes will receive one more paid holiday a year and one day of paternal leave. The vote to end the strike was unanimous.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAY VICEPRESIDENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  Spurred by memories of the 1972 Eagleton case, a Democratic party commission has proposed creation of a screening committee to check the background of future VicePresidential possibilities.

title: FUTURES PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bearish Government reports and continuing concern over the energy crisis sent futures prices of farm products down sharply yesterday in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, but there was some small recovery at the close.

title: Wilson's Prospects
description: After 15 years of relative obscurity as Lieutenant Governor, Malcolm Wilson has gotten off to a strong start toward the pinnacle of power in this state in one of the most, amazing weeks in New York politics, which saw the Governor announce his resignation and the estate's most powerful legislator indicted. Even foes of the 59yearold Mr. Wilsonof the narrow necktie, the closecropped hair and the Ciceronian sentencesadmitted yesterday that Mr. Wilson had moved a long way toward winning the Republican nomination for Governor next year.

title: 76ers Win No. 10, Top Last Season
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UPI) Fred Carter scored 23 points and Leroy Ellis pumped in 18 tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers broke a fivegame losing streak and snapped the Detroit Pistons' sevengame winning streak with a 9693 National Basketball Association victory.

title: Simon to New England: Extinguish Gas Lamps
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 14William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, proposed to the gas companies of New England today that they extinguish the quaint gas lamps in front of private homes and save a bit more fuel for the nation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was.

title: Senate Unit Backs Ingersoll For State Department Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 14 (UPI) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Robert S. Ingersoll, U.S. Ambassador to Japan, to be Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs.

title: Sweet Victory Soured by Wrist Injury
description: Jerry Quarry had good reason to be jubilant in his dressing room last night after he had demolished Earnie Shavers in the first round.

title: Concert
description: Unlike the now legendary politician who was said to be so dumb he couldn't walk and chew gum at the same time, Michael Tilson Thomas is so multitalented that he can both conduct and lecture at the same concert.
