Mr. Thorrias is not yet the Ronald Colman smoothie that Leonard Bernstein is in such situations, nor as witty as the late Sir Thomas Beecham, another famous talker/ conductor, but the young man shows a compensatory flair for picking fascinating programs.

title: Knicks Will Meet Kings In Matinee Here Today
description: Fans of the Knicks, who so far this season have had to put up with the complete absence of Earl Monroe and infrequent appearances by Willis Reed, now will have to make another adjustment.

title: Business Community Given a Welcoming By the MayorElect
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame delivered a welcome imessage to the city's business community, yesterday, reaffirming a campaign pledge to give top priority to improving the business climate in New York.

title: Nixon Lights Christmas Tree, Its Electricity Slashed by 80%
description: WASHINGTON, Dee. 14 President Nixon, assisted by a Campfire Girl and a Boy Scout, pressed the button today to light the national Christmas tree.

title: Skylab 3's Officials Pleased With Crew After First 28 Days
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Skylab 3 is onethird of the way through its 84day mission, and officials say they are pleased with its accomplishments so far.

title: BRITAIN SUFFERS WIDE BLACKOUTS
description: LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 15 The first blackouts of Britain's energy crisis darkened large areas of London and the rest of the nation last night.

title: COST COUNCIL PLANS REFINERS' INCENTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Cost of Living Council published today a tentative plan for increasing the priceincentive to refiners to produce more heating oil and other distillates and less gasoline.

title: High School Notes
description: There are 12 graduates of the old Commerce High School now better known by its new name, Louis D. Brandeis High School who never fail to show up for the annual reunions.

title: ParkviewGem Plans Filing
description: ParkviewGem, Inc., announced in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday that it was preparing to file a petition under either Chapter X or Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company, which operates discount department stores in the Middle West is reported to have lost $2.4million in the first half of its 1973 fiscal year. Since the end of fiscal 1972, ParkviewGem has liquidated 35 of its stores.

title: Scheel Will Seek the Bonn Presidency
description: BONN, Dec. 14The West German Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, today told his party, the Free Democrats, that he would resign and be a candidate for the ceremonial but prestigious office of president next May.

title: 4 Women's Groups Hail An Advocate, Mrs. Mery
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Dec. 14 Mrs. Dorothy B. Mery, former director of the State Office on Women, was honored tonight it a dinner given by four statewide women's organizations.

title: Canadian Javelin Chairman Is to Go On Trial Jan. 30
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press)The case of John C. Doyle, chairman of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., was remanded today to Jan. 30, when Mr. Doyle will be tried on charges of fraud and breach of trust.

title: TV Programer Allows Automatic Station Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14An automatic television programer that was patented this week enables a set owner to schedule in advance just what the family will see and hear all evening. By pressing buttons, the operator can cause the set to switch stations at specific times for specific periods. Robert L. Moran of Franklin, Mass., an electronics engineer, was granted Patent 3,778,721. The equipment includes a clock, so that channels can be changed on the hour and half hour.

title: Women at Rutgers Label Alma Mater Sexist Song
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 14  The Rutgers College alma mater, 100 years old this week, is running into a little flak. The song, one woman student said in a letter to the student newspaper, is an influencing factor in hindering the progress of the school.

title: AvantGarde Art to Fade in Beame's City Hall
description: Nonobjective art, which was welcomed into City Hall by Mayor Lindsay and his youthful advisers, will have trouble finding wall space when Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's traditionconscious troupe takes over on Jan. 1.

title: Tho Stops in Peking on Way To Meet Kissinger in Paris
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Le Due Tho of North Vietnam arrived in Peking today on his way to Paris for talks Thursday with Secretary, of State Kissinger, the Peking radio reported.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Two Editors Are Elected To Pulitzer Prizes Board
description: Thomas Winship, editor of The Boston Globe, and Eugene C. Patterson, editor of The St. Petersburg Times in. Florida, have been elected members of the Advisory Board on the Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title: Austrian Ring Victor
description: VIENNA, Dec. 14 (AP) Hans Arsolics of Austria scored an impressive 10round decision over Manuel Gonzales of Odessa, Tex, in a middleweight bout tonight.

title: Fists Fly on Court and Rink
Senate Votes Walking Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House today a resolution to make the last Sunday in May Walk a Mile for your Health Day. Action came on a voice vote after Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, who jogs to and from work most days, said he hopes to encourage more physical exercise by Americans.

title: Late Rally Raises, Dow Index by 15.22
description: After three days of declining prices, the stock market registered a sizable advance yesterday in more active trading.

title: Federal Energy Panel Orders Diversion of Crude Oil to Guam
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The new Federal Energy Administration, acting on a request by the Department of Defense, has ordered the diversion of 500,000 barrels of crude oil to a refinery on Guam whose crude oil supplies have been depleted.

title: Whalers Outscore Knights, 31
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)Tom Earl and Larry Pleau had a goal and an assist apiece tonight to lead the New England Whalers to a 31 triumph over the Jersey Knights in the World, Hockey Association,

title: COURT UPHOLDS PLAN ON AMAX LITIGATION
description: American Metal Climax, Inc., said yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia had upheld settlement of the pending litigation against Amax arising out of the reorganization in 1970 of Roan Selection Trust, Ltd. Under the agreement, Amax will pay $6.5million to the court for benefit of former stockholders of ??an as of June 30, 1970.

title: Dance: Jamison Vehicle
description: How Long Have It Been, choreographed by Merleane Furtick, is another one of those minor solos that dot the repertory of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater and that are saved from failure by their interpreters.

title: Photography in Italy Recalls 19th Century
description: In the exhibition entitled Photography in Italy in the Nineteenth Century, currently on view at the Robert Schoelkopf Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street, picturesque images of ancient monuments and heroic works of art abound. Here are the original prints of all those views of St. Peter's in Rome, the Leaning Tower in Pisa, the Doge's Palace in Venice, etc., that once adorned our textbooks and travel guides, together with the closeup details of Renaissance masterworks that earlier generations of tourists carried home as asthetic mementos of their cultural pilgrimages abroad.

title: Trial of Three Arabs Seized In El Al Case Opens in Rome
description: ROME, Dec. 14  Three Arabs, charged with having plotted to shoot down an El Al airliner with missiles on Sept. 5, went on trial here today.

title: Getty's Grandson Is Found A live After $3Million Ransom Is Paid
description: ROME, Saturday, Dec. 15 (UPI)J. Paul Getty 3d, an ear severed by his alleged kidnappers and in frail health, was freed today after a fivemonth abduction and payment of nearly $3million ransom.

title: A Counterclaim on Airco Filed by CurtissWright
description: The CurtissWright Corporation, which has made a tender offer for 20 per cent of the stock of Airco, Inc., said yesterday that it had filed a counterclaim against a suit brought by Airco.

title: Council Power
description: Knowledge is power, members of the new enlarged City Council were told this week at the start of a pioneering orientation program conducted by the City University in cooperation with the Council leadership. To the extent that this is true, the power and effectiveness of the 43member Council to be sworn next month could be significantly enhanced as a result of the freewheeling discussions at the twoday seminar of such subjects as intergovernmental relations, civil service, labor relations, discrimination and municipal finances.

title: EXNIXON AIDE GOT BIG S. B.A. SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) A California campaign official for President Nixon received a large Small Business Administration contract subsidy despite objections from a review panel, Government documents disclosed today.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOW I TURN ORDINARY COMPLAINTS INTO THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS: The Diary a Tough Customer. By Ralph Charell. 192 pages. Stein & Day. $6.95.

title: Blast Hits Algerian Consulate In Tense Marseilles, Killing
description: MARSEILLES, France, Dec. 14 (UPI)A plastic bomb exploded today at the Algerian Consulate in this racially tense port city, killing four persons and injuring 23, many of them seriously, the police said.

title: L.I. Teacher Accused of Karate Death of Girl
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 4A 25yearold substitute physical education teacher was indicted by a Nassau County grand jury for allegedly contributing to the death of a 2yearold girl by using her to demonstrate karate blows.

title: Bridge: Championship at Las Vegas Brings 3Way Photo Finish
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 14 In one of the most dramatic finishes in recent tournament history, the Blue Ribbon pair championship ended here this morning in a threeway photo finish, which could be resolved only after a committee issued its verdict on a disputed ruling and the directors calculated the scores to two places of decimals.

title: Growth Slower in Industrial Production
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Growth of industrial production has slowed markedly in the last three months but there is still growth, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Veto for Congress On Gas Rationing Is Voted by House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The House voted today to allow Congress to override the President in the event he ordered gasoline rationing.

title: RUTGERS U. URGED TO COMBINE UNITS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 14 A Rutgers University committee report released today urges widespread mergers of various university academic units and a reduction in tenured faculty members to meet the financial needs of the future.

title: Slowdown in Britain
description: Well before the declaration of emergency one month ago, it was clear that Britain was facing a rough economic passage. But it still comes as a shock that Prime Minister Heath has been forced to invoke such drastic measures as a three  day week for most industries  meaning pay cuts for millions, rising unemployment and widespread hardship  and to warn the British people of a harder Christmas than we have known since the war.

title: Cruguet Returns the Continental Touch to Aqueduct
description: Jean Cruguet has been back on the local racing scene for the last week or so, and in that time has been able to find his way to the winner's circle a few times. The 33yearold Frenchman built up a good reputation in New York over the halfdozen years he had been riding here before returning to Paris in 1971.

title: Fists Fly on Court and Rink
description: Trail Blazers' Rick Roberson swinging at Suns' Neal Walk in the third period Thursday Phoenix. Dick van Arsdale (5) is trying to hold back Roberson, who was ejected. Walk had a bloody nose but returned to play. Trail Blazers won, 119108. Below: Kings' Mike Murphy landing a left on the neck of the Islanders' Gary Howett (8) in the first period Thursday at Inglewood, Calif. Ron Finn is the linesman. the bottom is Ed Westfall. Both pugilists were given major penalties. Kings won, 32.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Deal, N.J., Dec. 14Mrs. Marie Lombardi, the widow of the famed football coach, was the honored guest this week at a luncheon given by the Deal Golf and Country Club, to announce the winner's of the second annual Vince Lombardi Awards.

title: FOOD FAIR STORES STEPS UP PROFITS
description: Food Fair Stores, Inc., a large supermarket chain operating on the East Coast, which also runs a chain of discount department stores known as J. M. Fields, showed a sharp rebound in profits in its first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 17, according to results announced yesterday.

title: NEW INQUIRY URGED ON CAMBODIAN RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Senator Harpid E. Hughes called on the Senate Armed Services Committee today to reopen its inquiry into the 1969 B52 bombing of Cambodia, declaring that the Pentagon has yet to supply the documents that started this secret war.

title: John J. Turin, 60, Headed U. of Toledo Graduate School
description: TOLEDO, OhioDr. John J. Turin, dean of the University of Toledo Graduate School since 1969, and a nuclear physicist, died Thursday, shortly after collapsing in his home. He was 60 years old.

title: Lieut. Donald J. Blane Marries Karen Clark
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 14  Miss Karen Joy Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Clark, was married here this evening to Second lieut. Donald Joseph Blanc, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Robert N. Blanc of Clarendon Hills, Ill., and the late Mr. Blanc.

title: TV: Returning Open Mind Looks at Presidency
description: The Open Mind had a respectable TV run of roundtable discussions, with Richard D. Heffner as chairman, in the nineteenfifties. The subject of its first edition was the American Presidency. Tomorrow night at 9, the program and format are being revived for an hour on WPIX/Channel 11. The subject is once again the American Presidency. Time, however, has radically shifted the focus.

title: Edgar Koerner Weds Eileen McIlvaine
description: In St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University yesterday afternoon, Miss Eileen McIlvaine, a reference librarian at Columbia, was married to Edgar Koerner, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers. The Rev. Paul Coleman, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: When Peace Comes to the Middle East
description: JERUSALEMI believe that peace willcome to Israel and her Arab neighbors in the present generation.

title: Notes on People
description: Traditionally, the men who have headed the Immigration and Naturalization Service have avoided taking a position on the issue of whether immigration should be curtailed, expanded or allowed to stay as is, preferring to act strictly as administrators. The new immigration commissioner, Leonard F. Chapman Jr., who has been on duty only two weeks, plans to change all that. He intends to tell Congress what he thinks immigration policy should be, the former commandant of the Marine Corps said, because I think it is one of my duties. The question, he said, has two sidesthe open door tradition of admitting almost anyone who wants to live here,, and what General Chapman called the other end of the spectrumhaul up the gangplank. He hasn't formed his own position, he said.

title: Picasso Art Collection Is Accepted for Louvre
description: PARIS, Dec. 14 (AP)Valery Giscard d'Estaing, France's Finance Minister, announced today that the Government had decided to accept the late Pablo Picasso's priceless collection of paintings by other artists, some of which helped inspire his own genius. The acceptance automatically freed Picasso's principal heirs, his widow, Jacqueline, and his son, Paulo, from payment of inheritance taxes on the value of the pictures collected by Picasso throughout his life.

title: Lebanon Releases an Editor Jailed for Printing Secrets
description: EDRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14The editor and publisher of Lebanon's leading newspaper was released today after being jailed 10 days ago on charges of publishing socalled secret resolutions of the conference of Arab chiefs of state in Algeria Iast month.

title: The Three Sisters Return
description: Mary Joan Negro, Patti LuPone and Mary Lou Rosato act Chekhov's troublebeset trio when the City Center Acting Company begins a monthlong repertory engagement at the Billy Rose on Wednesday. John Gay's The Beggar's Opera joins the company's schedule next Saturday, followed by Shakespeare's Measure for Measure on Dec. 26 and James Saunders's Next Time I'll Sing to You on Jan. 2. With the Phoenix Company also on Broadway, theatergoers have the rare choice of two repertories.

title: College Cuts Hours of Library and Gallery
description: CRANFORD  Union College will close its library and the Tomasulo Art Gallery on the Cranford campus one hour earlier each day and will be shut all day on Saturdays until the energy situation is eased.

title: L.I. Park Election
description: MANHASSET, L. I.John J. Murphy was decisively reelected as park district commissioner here last week, defeating the man who had challenged the district's plan to cut down a tree at the proposed entrance to a railroad parking lot. Mr. Murphy defeated John P. Brady, 678 to 347. The district has postponed a decision on the fate of the tree until next spring.

title: MAN IS FOUND SLAIN ON UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The superintendent of a fivestory brownstone on the Upper East Side was found shot dead yesterday afternoon in the lobby of the building, at 109 East 89th Street, near Park Avenue, the police reported last night.

title: MITCHELL IS LINKED TO DISPUTED MERGER
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (UPI),The St. Louis PostDispatch said in its Sunday edition that after meeting with executives of the Granite City Illinois Steel Company and the National Steel Corporation in July, 1971, Attorney General John N. Mitchell overruled the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department and allowed the two concerns to merge.

title: Mantle, Maris Head Hall of Fame Ballot
description: Mickey Mantle, three times the American League's most valuable player, and Roger Maris, who eclipsed Babe Ruth's season homerun record, head the list of candidates eligible for election to the Hall of Fame in 1974 by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Studies Stir An Interest In Antiquity
description: Women in flowing velvet gowns and men resplendent in red and gold brocade capes listen intently to medieval music in a dimly lighted chamber Others discuss, practice and eat the results of 15th century recipes for pastries, meat pies, bread and mead.

title: ANNULMENT FEES ANGERING VATICAN
description: ROME, Dec, 15  A longsmoldering conflict between the Vatican and lawyers who plead marriage annulment cases before church tribunals flared up this week.

title: Nassau Study Shows That Higher Education Means Higher Salary
description: What happens to students who take high school vocational and technical programs? A new study has followed up 4,460 young people who attended such programs in Nassau County, and some of its findings are these:

title: Buddy Brown Wins Award
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 15 (UPI)Buddy Brown, an Alabama tackle, was named today as the winner of the Jacobs Award, which goes to the outstanding blocker in the Southeastern Conference. He will receive the award, Jan. 24, at a meeting of the Columbia (S.C.) Quarterback Club.

title: Through a poet's private voice into her life
description: Women have no wilderness in them, They are provident instead, Content in the tight hot cell of their hearts To eat dusty bread. from Women

title: Medical Program Elects a President
description: EAST ORANGE  John F. X. Irving of Basking Ridge, dean of the Seton Hall University School of Law, Newark, has been elected president of the board of trustees of the newly reorganized New Jersey Regicnal Medical Program.

title: 3 Factions in Greek Leadership Believed Vying for Ascendancy
description: ATHENS, Dec. 15  Three weeks after the quiet military coup that ended the sixyearlong rule of George Papadopoulos, most Greeks cannot tell for sure who really holds the reins of power in their country.

title: 4 Winners Makes 503 For Hawley
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 15 Sandy Hawley, the recordsmashing Canadian jockey, rode his 500th winner of the year at Laurel Race Course today to reach a goal he had set for himself last January.

title: Men and battles of the Revolution
description: An infrequently mentioned and often misunderstood victory of the Revolution was the American repulse of a power ful British invasion of New Jersey in June of 1780. The large scale raid was conceived by in fluential loyalists who convinced the British command in New York that New Jersey was ready to surrender and that Washington's Continenta Army, rent with mutiny in Its encampment in the Jersey hills would fall easy prey to a surprise attack. The operation spanned 17 harrowing days be fore swarming American regu lars and militia drove the British out of Jersey for the last time.

title: Sherry Reiff Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Reiff of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Lynn Reiff, to Marc Gary Stromberg, son of Mrs. Muriel Stromberg of the Bronx, where his mother is Councilwoman of the 10th District and Alexander Stromberg. Mr. Reiff is vice president of the Jones Tool Company of New York. The couple plan to be married on May 12.

title: Byrne's Regime Is Taking Shape
description: TRENTON  Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne's Democratic state administration is beginning to take shape and a vanguard of some of its prospective members are already at work.

title: Flow of U.S. Oil Products To Mexico Is On After Halt
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) United States and Mexican Wicials took steps today to ??estune the movement of United States petroleum products to Mexico halted by confusion over an American exportcontrol order.

title: The Aging Are Afraid and Lonely in New Brunswick Project
description: NEW BRUNSWICKYou can put, the location of this place down as one of the biggest mistakes New Brunswick ever made, a 74yearold tenant of the Hoffman Pavilion this city's only apartment house for the elderly  said last week.

title: Texas Legislature Is Called To Act on Auto Speed Limit
description: AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 15 Gov. Dolph Briscoe has called the Texas legislature into special session Tuesday to enact legislation on highway speed limits.

title: Necessary Trade Bill
description: The House of Representatives has approved a trade bill that would grant President Nixon the broad negotiating authority he needs to strengthen United States economic relations with Western Europe, Japan and the underdeveloped countries. But the House has also defied the Presidentand the threat of a Presidential vetoby attaching to the bill an amendment prohibiting mostfavorednation tariffs and United States credits to the Soviet Union unless the Russians allow free emigration of Jews and other citizens.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: To management people who have been struggling these past few years to successfully juggle their available supplies of energy, the energy crisis is hardly new. But, with the politics of the Middle East and Washington as a current backdrop, what was a slowbrewing problem has suddenly erupted in the public press and public consciousness as a fullblown emergency.

title: Joy of Christmas at Museums
description: Many New Jersey museums will reflect the special mood of Christmas in exhibitions of toys and gifts and special programs to entertain children out of school for the holiday.

title: Auction Handles 1,500 Cars a Week
description: BORDENTOWN  Dealers call it the stock exchange of the usedcar industry. Each Wednesday, more than 2,500 buyers and sellers gather here at the National Auto Dealer's Exchange, which is said to be the world's largest automobile auction.

title: GamebyGame Rushing
description: Simpson's Records

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One of the reasons that the consumer may not be fully aware that price competition exists for property insurance [Insurance Rates on Home Policies Now Vary Widely, Buyers Informed, Nov. 18] is that the Insurance Department has refused to support the Marino Bill, S138. The bill passed the New York State Senate, but not the Assembly.

title: A Joining of Immigrants, Quarrelsome Yet United
description: JERUSALEMOn the eve of the war, our society was characterized, more than at any other time, by an indescribable complacency, an impatient covetousness and a pursuit of material advantage.

title: Westenburg Gets Out Of Church
description: WHEN Richard Westenburg was thinking about becoming a concert organist, Virgil Fox told him to avoid the conducting bug that plagued so many church musicians. Look what happened to Stokowski, Fox said, referring to the fact that Stokowski started out his American career as organist at St. Bartholomew's here. Westenburg didn't think that what had happened to the great conductor was so bad, but it still never occurred to him at the time that conducting would become his major concern and that one day he would be leading a performance of Handel's Messiah in Carnegie Hall, as he will be doing next Wednesday. Westenburg is, of course, the founder and director of Musica Sacra, the distinguished series of concerts given at Central Presbyterian Church, where he is organist and choirmaster. But except for one excursion into Brooklyn with his forces, he has never conducted outside a church before.

title: Home Improvement
description: A PORTABLE electric drill is undoubtedly the first power tool every doityourselfer acquires, and It is certainly one of the most useful and versatile (which is why it will make an excellent Christmas gift for any home handyman or handy woman).

title: Focus on the Old South
description: CLARENCE JOHN LAUGHLIN is an obsessed romantic. A Southerner to the marrow, he makes photographs which exude that peculiarly southern aura: nostalgia amplified to a level of metaphor, guilt as a fetish object, decay as a perfume.

title: Estate May become a Park
description: Special to The New York Times OYSTER BAY, L. I, Another of Long Island's fast dwindling estates may become a public park. A proposal by the Town of Oyster Bay to acquire the 121Bruce estate in Woodbury was praised by four speakers and opposed by only one at a public hearing last week at the Town Hall.

title: Soviet Paper Charges Abuse of Labor Laws
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  A Soviet newspaper has charged that pregnant women are being made to work at nights and on overtime and that children are being forced to lift dangerously heavy weights, causing death in at least one case.

title: Churches Oppose South Africa Ban On Black Cleric
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec, 15South Africa's Council of Churches plans to send a delegation to meet with Prime Minister John Vorster to protest among other things the recent ban ordered against a leading black Lutheran clergyman, the Rev. Manas Buthelezi.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHT FOR '74 GRADUATE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15Despite the uncertanties of the energy shortage, many American companies still expect to hire more college graduates in 1974 than they did this year, and many of them hope to increase the number of women they will hire.

title: Pyramid Scheme Under Fire
description: Two government agencies are pressing suits against Galaxy Foods, a catalogue food service with headquarters in, Brooklyn, that are intended to establish the principle that pyramiding franchisers must conserve the investments made in them and, if they are convicted of fraud, return the investments.vestigators that they had entered into no contracts for the equipment such an operation would require.

title: Veterinary Class Goes Out of State
description: TRENTON  New Jersey education officials are trying to overcome a shortage of veterinarians in the state without building a costly staterun school.

title: Kerr on Creeps
description: THERE is a steady enough ring of truth to David E. Freeman's Creeps, not simply because the author has himself spent time in a workshop for cerebral palsy victims but because he has been able to stand back and extract from the experience the little bits of selfknowledge that hurt most.

title: Opera: Bartered Bride at Juilliard
description: Bedrich Smetana's The Bartered Bride was composed in 1864, but it remains just about the happiest and most innocent opera in the repertory. It has not been staged in New York in many a year, and its neglect is simply incredible. The opera has everythingan unending fund of melody, and charm and humor and folk dancing and even a circus. The two New York opera companies are simply derelict in their duties in not keeping The Bartered Bride as a permanent repertory piece.

title: A Full & Accurate Account Of the Largest, Highest and Longest Singles Party in the History of Western Civilization  With Some Reflections On the Predatory Nature tyre of Meeting People
description: THE customs people at Toronto's Malton International Airport are usually a friendly yet brisk and efficient lot, so I Can't helpnoticing the sly smiles on their faces as they watch the departing passengers. What their smiles mean, I suppose, is that they, along with a goodly portion of the rest of the residents of Toronto, have been reading the breathy newspaper advertisements that drew our crowd together. My sensing their amusement may be a defensive fantasy, but I really don't think so. Everyone in the departure lounge looks faintly uncomfortable, not at all like sybarites setting out (one Friday last month) on what is being billed as the World's Largest, Highest and Longest Singles Party.

title: Housing Needs
description: The New Jersey Office on Aging estimates that the state will need a total of 101,103 lowincome and moderateincome units for people over 60 years of age during the next seven years. Counting units in construction and planning stages, the office now has a total of 27,382 subsidized housing units for the elderly, of which only 15,619 are finished and occupied. This leaves a projected shortage of 73,721 units.

title: Creating a Nixon Court
description: Is a judicial counterrevolution under way, a fullscale retreat from the liberal landmarks of the Warren Court? The question has been in many minds since Chief Justice Warren E. Burger was joined by three other Nixon appointees on the Supreme Court, and it was raised again last week. The occasion was two 6to3 decisions of the Court that took a broad view of police power to search any person placed under arrest.

title: Brokerage Firms' 3 Big Challenges
description: It's really pretty grim down on Wall Street these days.

title: Man Slain in Apparent Spat With Fellow Drinker Here
description: A 49yearold man was stabbed to death in his tenement apartment on the Lower East Side yesterday afternoon in what the police believed might have been an argument between drinking companions.

title: Cargo Plane Hits Homes on TakeOff In Miami, 9 Killed
description: MIAMI, Sunday Dec. 16A fourengine cargo plane crashed into a residential neighborhood about a mile east of the Miami International Airport early today, killing at least nine persons including two crewmen.

title: School Principal Awarded $356,000 in Libel Suit
description: FREDERICK, Md., Dec. 15 (UPI)A circuit court jury awarded $356,000 in damages this week, in a libel suit brought by a high school principal against a newspaper that had called him unsuitable for his post.

title: A Report From Ireland, 800 Years After the British Arrived
description: LONDONThe reasons why Britain is involved in Ireland at all are in origin strategic. Henry II took an army across the Irish Sea in 1171 to prevent his dissident barons from setting up independent Irish princedoms. Oliver Cromwell, after Charles I's execution in 1649, added a few thousand Irish lives to the tally mainly to demolish a royalist refuge. English rulers saw Ireland as a country which might threaten their regime if it was allowed the freedom to fall into unfriendly hands.

title: VideoTape Helps Judges Pick Dressage Champion
description: John Winnett of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., riding Mario, won the national intermediare dressage championship after competing under a new system that involved videotaping at three locations around the country.

title: 5 WOMEN DEACONS PROTEST AT RITE
description: Five women deacons tried unsuccessfully yesterday to become the first women priests of the Episcopal Church in an emotional ordination ceremony at the Cathedral Church of St John the Divine.

title: Brown Got a Tax Break
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 15 (UPI)Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown received a $105,000 Federal tax break for the donation of his papers to the University of California at Berkeley. A student tax group first reported the tax break. It was confirmed by a spokesman for Mr. Brown.

title: Cezanne Unseen
description: destine amours, and by the ways in which the gaff might be blown on such entanglements. Two drawings at the Hayward illustrate the frenzy of terror and excitement with which he would pencil, for himself alone, the likely look of such scenes: the naked bodies sprawled akimbo, the tophatted avenger breaking down the door, the supporting evidence of strewn clothes and empty bottles.

title: To save a way of life
description: FIFTYONE years ago, the City of New York persuaded a group of representatives from Protestant and nondenominational socialservice agencies to form an organization that would serve to coordinate their diverse interests. This was the origin of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. Today it represents more than 300 member agencies which together spend over $200million each year to help hundreds of thousands of needy men, women and children. The federation is also an organization, its officials point out, whose socialservice methods embrace the latest in computer technology and management techniques and whose institutional operations are periodically reexamined and overhauled so as to adapt to the changing and growing needs of the people its agencies serve.

title: Miss Joan Killiam Gallagher Engaged to John S. Warden
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 15  The engagement of Miss Joan Killiam Gallagher to John Sheppard Warden, son of Dr. and Mrs. David E. Warden of Laurel Hollow, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Gallagher of Armonk.

title: Mikita Sparks Chicago
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 15 In a game punctuated by brief, brutal fights and a startling control of one of hockey's superior teams, the Islanders held the Chicago Black Hawks to a 33 tie tonight.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The pro football season in New York ends today, officially and gratefully. Not that it ever really began. What was available was more of a semipro season. Again. Without even an apology, the Jets and the Giants continued to be an embarrassment to their followers. As they have so often in recent years, they shortchanged their seasonticket subscribers. If the Jets and Giants were department stores, the Better Business Bureau would investigate them. Instead, each is a family, which seems to exempt them. The decline in the last decade of the Giants, operated by the Maras ever since the club began in 1925, is typical of what has happened in the National Football League to the old family organizations. As for the Jets, with Weeb Ewbank importing his soninlaw, Charley Winner, to be his successor as coach next season, a similar family looms. Ominously.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Xerox Corporation has given further details on its relocation plans in Connecticut, which involve the decisions to build the company's new headquarters in Stamford and to rent a total of 240,000 square feet of space in downtown Greenwich.

title: Beame Retains O'Hagan
description: John T. O'Hagan, who was promoted to Fire Commissioner by Mayor Lindsay a month before Election Day, will be retained by Mayorelect, Abraham D. Beame as head of the 12,000man Fire Department.

title: INJURER'S TRIP TO TALKS DELAYED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15  The Security Council, moving today to reinforce the links between the United Nations and the forthcoming Geneva Conference on the Middle East, approved a resolution affirming that Secretary General Waldheim would play a full and effective role at the conclave, and that it would he held under the auspices of the United Nations.

title: Fashions for the Very Young
description: Ask a 5yearold fashion plate where she got her seethrough vinyl smock or her paisley party dress with matching pants and she will tell you Ingrid of Copenhagen. But ask her mother who Ingrid is and where one can buy her clothes and she will probably mumble some vague Ijustcan'tremember reply.

title: All the honest deceivers
description: Consider this: Horace Goldin, illusionist, rushed onto the stage of the Brooklyn Music Hall in October, 1900, and pulled a bowl of fire from scarf. He then blasted a handkerchief from the end of a rifle and found it tucked under his collar. From a cone of paper came a live, kicking rabbit from a waterfilled tub, into which eggs were thrown, four ducks emerged.

title: Hooded Pushers May Talk in State's Drug Inquiry
description: TRENTONHooded drugpushers may testify about organized crime's international dopepeddling operations in the New Jersey Senate chamber this week.

title: LaborSaving Aids Viewed as Threat To Eskimos' Health
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP)Eskimos are enjoying the easy life and may be paying for it with their health, two Medical researchers say.

title: Brodie Bids Farewell
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 The Pittsburgh Steelers assured themselves of a National Football League playoff berth by beating the San Francisco 49ers, 3714, today, and kept alive their chance to win the championship of the Central Division of the American Conference.

title: A Hanukkah Gilt Is Sent to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Bernard Herald's Hanukkah gift came early this year.

title: The great old movie days recalled in two pop histories
description: These twin books share more similarities than differences. Both are published by the same house. Both deal with two of D. W. Griffith's four leading cameramen. Both are tailored to the same literary and editorial policy: like official handouts that hew to a fixed authoritarian cultural line, rather than to authoritative but freewheeling interpretation. Both follow the nowfamiliar pattern of pop histories of the movies contradictory reminiscences; dubious anecdotes; labored, often painful, attempts at apparent humor; undocumented incidents; unverified quotations or dialogue, and unsubstantiated credits, or claims of credit. Yet, despite the similarities of treatment, there are a few differences between them. Easily the better of the two is Karl Brown's Adventures With D. W. Griffith, as compiled and edited by Kevin Brownlow.

title: WILLIAM J. McINTOSH
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Dec. 15William J. McIntosh, a retired chemical consultant, died at Stamford Hospital yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived at Westover Park.

title: FemaleDominated Jury Legal, Italian Court Says
description: GENOA, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP)An Italian court has declared that a jury with a female majority is just as legitimate as one with a male predominance.

title: Syria Reports a New Clash With Israel on Golan Heights
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 15 (ReuterslSyrian and Israeli forces clashed on the Golan Heights today for the second successive day, a Syrian military spokesman said.

title: What's Doing in Palm Springs
description: SHANGRILA IN THE SANDAt the close of World War II, wealthy sunseekers and Hollywood celebrities discovered Palm Springs and transformed it from a village whose mineral baths were it main attraction into what is probably the world's most sumptuous sandpile. Milliondollar homes are almost commonplace and, casispluperfect, there's a swimming pool for every five residents. So famous has Palm Springs become that its name is now actually a generic term for a skein of winterresort communities stretching 50 miles down the Coachella Valley from towering San Gorgonio peak on the northwest to the salty Salton Sea on the southeast. Palm Springs it self, occupying a 10mile stretch of the upper valley, draws a million visitors annually and, heginning in November, its permanent population of 23,100 swells to 70,000 or more. Palm Springs and the eight other main communities in the Coachella Valley resort complex together attract 3million visitors a year. So overlapping are these communities that the tourist is hardly aware of leaving Palm Springs as he travels 12 miles north to Desert Hot Springs or south to Cathedral City, Rancho Mirage, Palm Desert, Indian Wells, La Quinta, Indio, Coachella and on to the Salton Sea.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: RCA Sign to Be Put Out
description: The orangered RCA sign atop the 70story RCA Building will go dark Monday night, for the fist time since World War II, to conserve energy. The RCA sign letters, each 24 feet high and 22 feet wide, are on the north and south side of the building and are about 850 feet above the ground.

title: Young Students Find History at Source
description: NEWARK  In the last 10 years, more than 15,000 of the state's junior and senior high school students have explored history through such varied activities as researching landmarks, rediscovering lost handicrafts and arts, reenacting historical scenes and digging for artifacts.

title: Ali Sued on Taxes
description: SACRAMENTO, Dec. 15 (AP)The California Attorney General has filed a tax suit against Mohammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, for $60,298 in taxes allegedly owed for 1973. The suit alleges Ali paid only about onethird of the taxes owed this year in California.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Ron Waller, interim coach of the San Diego Chargers, when asked how he would select a new coach for next season: If I were the owner, I would get the individual best suited for the job. Of course, if Ron Waller was available, I'd probably hire him.

title: Nature and Brueghel at Rutgers Show
description: NEW BRUNSWICKLovers of nature and its wild animals, both modern and prehistorlc, can enjoy themselves at the Rutgers University Art Gallery. Until Jan. 25, the gallery is exhibiting more than 90 paintings, prints and drawings by Robert Bruce Horsfall, the distinguished American natural science illustrator, who died in 1948.

title: MESKILL SCORES PLAN FOR SEAPORT
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 15 A Rhode Island study commission's report calling for a major new Atlantic Coast seaport, on Navy land soon to be vacated at Quonset Point, has been denounced by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut as attempted hijacking of his state's industry.

title: Movies
description: MARTIN SCORSESE said goodbye to God a long time ago. But you'd have a devil of a time selling that story to the stewardesses on the plane that recently carried him here from his home in Hollywood.

title: BRONX GIRL IS KILLED BY CAR ON SIDEWALK
description: A 7yearold girl was fatally injured yesterday afternoon when an allegedly intoxicated man lost control of his car, which mounted the sidewalk at a busy Bronx intersection, striking the girl, her 12yearold sister and their 18yearold aunt.

title: A Coach Looks Back on 20 Years
description: In my 20 years as a coach in pro football, I was fortunate in having two great quarterbacks in John Unitas and Joe Namath. John's records, of course, speak for themselves. Joe never has gotten the records because of his bad legs. But I wouldn't say one is better than the other. I think they're both great.

title: Ruckus on Columbus Circle
description: IT'S at least the sixth time around for Red Grooms's The Discount Store, a supermultisculpture first shown in 1970 in Minneapolis as part of a Walker Art Center exhibition, Figures /Environments, where it had plenty of room to spread out as a lifesize satirical complex. It was disassembled and rebuilt when the exhibition traveled to Cincinnati and Dallas. New York saw it in its fourth reorganization in 1971, when it was adjusted, including new backgrounds, for compression into a narrow gallery on Madison Avenue. Last month at the Rutgers University Art Gallery in New Brunswick, N. J., it again had room to breathe as part of a big oneman retrospective assembled there, The Ruckus World of Red Grooms, which has now been stuffed into acutely inadequate quarters, with the sacrifice of much material, at the Cultural Center on Columbus Circle.

title: Suffolk County Democrats Pick Nominees for the District Court
description: The Democrats of Suffolk County chose their nominees last week to fill three District Court vacancies, among them the first woman to be a Suffolk judge.

title: In Pursuit
description: With their bitterness and everlasting distrust scarcely diminished, with their armies once more equipped and facing each other across narrow strips of sand and water, and their negotiating positions in neartotal conflict, the Israelis, the Arabs and their superpower sponsors were scheduled to meet in Geneva this week to try to find a lasting peace after four wars and 25 years of hatred.

title: Colleges Aid Comet Watchers
description: CRANFORD  Two New Jersey colleges are making their facilities available to astronomy enthusiasts at a time when the Comet Kohoutek is expected to come into closer view.

title: Office Mall Is Filling a Need
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  Abbey Ripley is the owner of a small but growing business, Travelscope, Inc. Until recently, she ran her business from her home in South River, but several months ago she realized that her home was no longer adequate for her business needs.

title: Consortium Fosters Joint School Efforts
description: MADISON  When a group of highschool seniors gathers at the WarnerLambert Company headquarters in Morris Plains on Jan. 7 for a threeday seminar on the American business system, it will be meeting a basic goal of the School Consortium of New Jersey: better communication between education and business.

title: Dtente: What's left of it?
description: Dftente has taken some knocks as the result of the recent war in the Middle Eastdespite assurances from President Nixon and Dr. Kissinger, from Mr. Brezhnev and Pravda, that without dtente the crisis might have had far more dangerous consequences. Seen from that viewpoint, the crisis was a sudden and inexplicable breakdown in communication, a temporary obstacle on the main road toward closer cooperation. But this, of course, is not the only possible interpretation. Now that the worst of the immediate conflict seems to be over, a new look at dtente is called for. Are Nixon's and Brezhnev's claims justified, or are they merely hiding the fact that the cracks in the edifice have been papered over?

title: Many in Legislature Champion Reforms
description: TRENTON  More than half the newly elected memberg of the Legislature have gone on record in support of a number of governmental reforms, including measures to strengthen conflictofinterest laws and to insure that more governmental business will be conducted in the open.

title: Alone or Together?

Only a few short weeks ago, it was talking in isolationist tones about the goal of national selfsufficiency. Now, while maintaining this goal, it is asking Canada, Europe, Japan and the oilproducing countries to join together in a longrange effort to assure adequate fuel supplies for all.

They are now ready to house doctors, lawyers, decorators, dentists and other professional people in twotosixroom offices.

title: CHICAGO PASSES $1BILLION BUDGET
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15The Chicago Council passed its first $1billion municipal budget last night but deferred action on the most controversial item in a $50million package of new taxes sought by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: The Wasted Resource
description: In every major crisis in recent American history, the nation's leadership has regularly turned to the universities for help. More than one hundred years ago, it was largely through the landgrant colleges that the demands of the agricultural and industrial revolutions were met. Franklin D. Roosevelt reached into the universities when he assembled his Brain Trust. The universities unlocked the secret of atomic power, and they became a key factor in the World War II defense effort.

title: Sputtering Western Economies
description: PARIS  The industrial machine of the West, despite pockets of poverty, has produced an unrivaled period of general prosperity for the world. But the machine is starting to clank and cough and sputter because it is running out of fuel. The embargoes and cutbacks by Arab oil producers have caused severe dislocations.

title: Serving neighborhoods
description: GIVE Thomas A. De Stefano five minutes of your time and he will convince you that about the best thing to do these days is to work in social service. A minute more and he may even persuade you to contribute to the agency he works for, the Brooklyn Catholic Charities. Mr. De Stefano is not a fundraiser. A young man, he is director of operations of the agency at 191 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn, and his job is to plan and coordinate communityservice programs that, all in all, help more than 40,000 men, women and children each year. Our basic question, Mr. De Stefano said the other day, can be simply stated as: How can this agency relate more meaningfully to communities?

title: The Junta Urges Austerity, and The Poor Get It
description: SANTIAGOAusterity, largely at the expense of President Allende's most fervent supporters, the poor, has been the watchword of Chile's new military Government. In an effort to revive the chaotic economy, the fourman junta led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, has instituted severe measures designed to assure that Chileans produce more than they consume, in marked contrast to the years under the previous regime.

title: Did Marx come over on the Mayflower?
description: Studies of our cultural and literary past usually avoid bodies of thought which have a large interpretive purpose. American Studies tags along after the historians and is less adventurous than they are. We persistently duck such bodies of thought as are examined, contrasted and employed by the late George Lichtheim in his Collected Essays, and make no efforts to domesticate a body of thought comparable to Raymond Williams's in The City and the Country in which English literature is illuminated by shifts in class perspectives, and the social attitudes of these classes are documented by literature. Our piety about Tocqueville, who also had a body of ideas, is rather uncomprehending; few have taken him as seriously as did Marvin Myers in The Jacksonian Persuasion.

title: MILK EXECUTIVES LINKED TO FRAUD
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15.  The Dairylea Cooperative, Inc., admitted at a state hearing here this week that about a dozen of its middlelevel executives knew that some milk and milk products were being adulterated at six of its eight plants in New York State but took no action to stop the illegal processing.

title: William Astor Drayton, 85, Gold Mining Expert, Dies
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Dec. 15  William Astor Drayton, who organized and managed extensive gold exploration and mining operations, chiefly in British Columbia, died last night at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington. He was 85 years old and lived here.

title: Donald Ford Fiance of Louise Levy
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Dec. 15 Miss Louise Redfield Levy, a director of the Association for Children with Retarded Mental Development in New York, and Donald Craig Ford, president of Hamilton Publishing Company of Santa Barbara, Calif., a division of John Wiley & Sons of New York, will be married here Dec. 31.

title: LETTER FROM LONDON
description: Nothing seemed more timeless or less ominous than the park at Blenheim Palace that Sunday. This year, the oaks and beeches, yellow, gold and red, possessed the brilliance of a New England fall. The great house threw a dramatic silhouette against the serene, pale blue November sky. A few Americans, like late swallows, drifted about the park, amazed, overwhelmed by its beauty, yet scarcely one realized that every tree, every stretch of water, even every hill, had been carefully planned; indeed, was manmade: a construction like the house itself. The park and house were created with a deliberate grandeur to celebrate Blenheim, that famous victory in 1704 which launched Britain into imperial greatness. And it was there (how appropriately) that Winston Churchill was born; and now, a mile or two away, lies his grave. In the distance, on that Sunday, the church bells tolled for Remembrance, remembrance of those men who had died in two world wars, died to save an empire that was irretrievably lost; winning the wars, yet losing the peace. Serene and beautiful as it was, Blenheim and its park symbolized so many of Britain's problems, so many of the specters of history that still haunt its days and nights. All countries are entangled the thickets of the past, no matter how young or how old they may be. The past broods just as much over the White House today as it does over Blenheim: At the heart of the American crisis are the Founding Fathers and their Constitution.

title: News of the Screen

Like Ulysses, it will have a cast selected largely from the Abbey Theater.
