title: Letters: The Paris Hemingway Knew
description: To the Editor: In Justine DeLacy's article on the Clobbering of Paris (Travel Section, Nov. 25), it is stated that Mine. Dupont had been selling sewing oddments, just off the Place de la Contrescarpe for about 35 years. That magic Parisian place name reminded me that exactly 51 years ago, Ernest Hemingway and his first wife, Hadley, set up housekeeping just off that same square in a fourthfloor apartment on 74 rue du Cardinal Lemoine. Nearby was a hotel in which Paul Verlaine had died 25 years before and in which Hemingway took a room exclusively to write. It was at the Verlaine hotel and the Lemoine place that be wrote the famed vignettes for his early In Our Time. Hemingway worked mornings because of the street noise and the music from the Bal Musette downstairs. It was this very dance hall that Ford Madox Ford used for his weekly little evenings of drinking and dancing, and which served as a small scene in The Sun Also Rises.

title: Housing for the Old: Problems and Plans
description: New Jersey is confronting a projected shortage of 73,721 lowincome and moderateincome housing units for the aged during the next seven years. The problems of the elderly, their discontent with some of the housing that has already been provided and state statistics on future needs are examined in articles that appear on Pages 90 and 91.

title: Jeremy Nichols, Ronald Pierce To Be Married
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 15Miss Jeremy Jane Nichols, who is studying for a master's degree in learning disabilities at the University of Virginia, and Ronald Jules Pierce, assistant fish biologist with the State Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries in Charlottesville, Va., have made plans to be married next April.

title: U.S. Soldier Kills 3 Others
description: ELZTALDALLAU, West Germany (AP)An American soldier shot and killed three other American soldiers and wounded another in the barracks of Nike antimissile base here today, West German police officials said. The United States Army confirmed that the incident had taken place and said it was investigating, but provided no details.

title: Precinct's Party Amazes Both Police and Visitors
description: Santa Claus sat under the F.B.I.'s posters of its most wanted persons, handing out bags of candy. Hot cider was given out beneath the missingpersons photographs. And Officer Frank Toscano, surveying the crowd that had come to the Sixth Precinct's first Christmas party, was amazed.

title: 64 Nations Charged in Report as Users of Torture
description: PARIS, Dec. 15Amnesty International, the organization dedicated to assisting political prisoners, has charged that torture as a systematic weapon of control is being used by almost half the world's governments and is spreading rapidly.

title: Text of Common Market Statement on Energy Issue
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Following is the text of the Common Market statement on energy:

title: McCarthy Winner Of Loughlin Mile
description: Two established runners, one without his competitor's ticket and the other without any sleep, were victorious yesterday in the Bishop Loughlin scholastic indoor track games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: The Greens
description: In the summer we call them conifers, and in the winter we call them greens. Sometimes we even specify and call them pine, spruce, hemlock, and cedar, fir, juniper. They are of the ancients, old in geologic time, old in the memory of man. They have stood in the cold and snow and darkness since they first lifted a branch. To man they are reminders that all winters come to an end, that life endures.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The multibillion dollar American fashion market has become a focal point for the increasingly active Italian and French readytowear industries. Both the Italians and French are engaged in coordinated promotion efforts to get more American retailers interested in the foreign label.

title: Ecumenical Chord Struck
description: We're doing it for God and Bruschi, explains Thomas Doyle as he leans back in a chair waiting to be made up.

title: Television
description: WHEN it comes to battling payTV, the networks and their hired friends can offer some convincing arguments for the prosecution. The key line is being prominently delivered in this month's fullpage Television Information Office ad, which appears in magazines and newspapers. The TIO is an arm of the National Association of Broadcasters.

title: Can Two Really Live as Cheaply as One?
description: Marriages may still be made in heaven, but the equations have now been worked out by Gary S. Becker, professor of economics at the University of Chicago.

title: 20% FOUND OPPOSED TO PRESS IN SURVEY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)A preWatergate survey found that onefifth of Americans aged 26 to 35 either denied or were undecided about the right of a newspaper to criticize an elected Government official.

title: Paraje Captures Display For Third Straight Year
description: Paraje was in the right place all the way in the 2mile Display Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Moved into the lead just after the start by Jorge Velasquez, the 7yearold campaigner owned by Sigmund Sommer contributed a wonderful demonstration of courage and ability by taking the $56,400 event by three lengths over Everton II, with Rule by Reason next in the field of eight.

title: The Region
description: New York's straphangers geined a reprieve Friday from a threatened increase in the cost of their subway tokens when the state's outgoing Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller, and the city's incoming Mayor, Abraham D. Beame, negotiated an agreement that is expected to hold the 35cent fare steady, until at least May 1.

title: Giants to End Lost Season
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15With little motivation, the Giants conclude their season tomorrow by playing the Minnesota Vikings here in the Yale Bowl, The game, which will be televised by Channel 2 in New York, starts at 1 P.M. and they had better hurry it along because there are no lights at the Bowl and it can be quite dark by 4 oclock.

title: Headliners
description: On Nov. 16, after driving relatives to La Guardia Airport, George K. Gutterman was returning to his Manhattan home when he had a flat tire. While changing it, he had a heart attack and was found lying next to his disabled car by two Port Authority detectives. They called city police but Mr. Gutterman was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst Hospital. Although the dead man's wallet contained six credit cards, a dozen business cards, much other clear identification and indications he was a man of substance, his family claimed last week that neither police nor the Medical Examiner's office notified them of his death. It was only when the family, worried by the 56yearold bachelor's sixday disappearance, began a search for him that his body was discovered on Nov. 23 at Queens General Hospital's morgue, being prepared for a pauper's burial. The family arranged a funeral, took care of a parking ticket placed on Mr. Gutterman's abandoned car and launched a suit for $1million against the city and the two hospitals.

title: News of the Camera World
description: IN tune with what seems to be a definite trend toward the introduction of 35mm cameras which are much more compact and lighter in weight than older models, the Konica Camera Company has recently introduced a new pocketsize rangefinder model that weighs less than one pound (12.3 ounces, to be exact), yet has features to match those of most other top quality rangefinder cameras without interchangeable lenses. Called the Konica Auto S3, and measuring about 4x 3x2 inches, this new model is priced at $185, including case and battery, and a 38mm f/1.8 lens.

title: Mayor Bids Backers Adieu With Songs, Dances, Quips
description: With songs, dances, quips, the skirling of bagpipesand some tearsMayor Lindsay said farewell to his troops early yesterday morning in a fourhour party that roused in many of them the expectation that they would soon be reforming for other political wars.

title: A Successful Escape Into Night
description: IN its exhibition, George Ault: Nocturnes, running through Jan. 6, the Whitney Museum of American Art has aptly and very happily chosen to illuminate a particular aspect of the work of an American artist who, all too often in the past, has been classified merely as a minor American Precisionist. While the Precisionist label is applicable to a degree, it has tended to obscure the real gifts of a painter who brought to that ordinarily cool and detached style a poetry that was altogether personal anti, in its insistent, analytical, fashion, quite unique. Ault's essays on the subject of darknessranging from: the tremulous light of early evening to the inky blacknes's of midnight, picturing hard urban realities or nostalgic glimpses of rural Americaformed, as it were, a continuous visual theme throughout all the stylistic phase of his career.

title: Israeli Town Cuts Heat To Identify With Dutch
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15 (AP)The Dutch are being denied Arab oil because of their support of Israel. So the people of the little Israeli town of Hatzor have turned off the heaters in their homes and offices.

title: Deer Herd in Millburn 68 Years Old
description: MILLBURNSanta Claus's reindeer, as they have been known to three generations of children in Essex County, will have their 68th Christmas Eve next week in the deer paddock at South Mountain Reservation here.

title: SEOUL CUTS 17% OF INDUSTRY'S OIL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 15  The South Korean Government has imposed a publicly unannounced 17 per cent cut on oil to almost all industries, transportation and the state electric power company, wellinformed official sources said today.

title: KIDNAPPERS FREE GETTY, 17, IN ITALY
description: ROME, Dec. 15J. Paul Getty 3d, 17yearold grandson of the American oil billionaire, was found at a deserted service station in Italy's South early today, more than five months after he disappeared from Rome.

title: M. B. Bernstein Fiance Of Diane L. Friedman
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Dec. 15 Miss Diane Linda Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Friedman, and Marc B. Bernstein, son of Mrs. Herbert Bernstein, also of Wantagh, and the late Mr. Bernstein, plan to be married in July.

title: CHICAGO PASSES $1BILLION BUDGE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15The Chicago Council passed its first $1billion municipal budget last night but deferred action on the most controversial item in a $50million package of new taxes sought by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: Guitar Workshop Stresses Tradition
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.There are no coal mines in the hills of Long Island. But the perils of that industry seemed immediate one recent afternoon when a young woman from Appalachia taught mining songs to a class of Yankees.

title: Election Law Involved in Duryea Case Has Been Struck Down Twice by courts and Faces New Challenge
description: The State Election Law under which Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Assembly Majority Leader John E. Kingston and four aides have been indicted has been struck down twice by the courts and seems certain to face a new challenge when the Republican votesiphoning cases moves into court.

title: Arthur Daley
description: For most of the season, Orenthal James Simpson of the Buffalo Bills has been singularly successful in escaping the clutching hands of the tacklers and the tightening grasp of the statistics. Of recent weeks, however, he has been able to duck the tacklers much more nimbly than he has been able to avoid the growing pressures from his yardage totals. At long last, though, he has even made a surrender of sorts to his personal numbers game.

title: L.I.U. Loses; Seton Hall Wins, 8983
description: Long Island University revived the cry last night for a 30second clock in college basketball.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market finished lower last week in moderate trading.

title: Miss Emery Norweb Is Betrothed
description: WILLOUGHBY, Ohio, Dec. 15Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R. Henry Norweb Jr. of Kirtland and Boothbay Harbor, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emery May Norweb, to Jeffrey Robert McManus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil C. McManus of Washington and Austin, Tex.

title: Watch That Guarantee
description: Cautious optimism is trickling back from Secretary Kissinger's traveling party in the Middle East. But this seems primarily to reflect the hope that once the Geneva peace conference gets down to business after its opening on Tuesday, some Arab oil might start flowing again to the United States and other (Western nations.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: At 4 A.M. one recent Monday, William P. Orr, president of the Lummus Company, arrived in his office in Bloomfield, N.J., to begin a new week.

title: Cornelia Ladd Sets Wedding
description: Miss Cornelia Masters Ladd and Lord Baillieu are planning a spring wedding in London.

title: Edward Melcarth, Artist Taught at Schools Here
description: Edward Melcarth, an American artist, whose romantic pictures showed the influence of Renaissance painters, died Friday in Venice, where he lived. His age was 59.

title: Fuel Shortage Threatens To Curtail Holiday Travel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Moskowitz of Washington have made reservations on five jets to Europe this week to be sure at least one will have enough fuel to get there.

title: Record Oil Prices in Iran Are Expected to Affect Arabs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 15Iranian officials and Western experts are stunned at the record prices offered here last week for oil, and predict that they will have a major impact on the looming decisions by Arab countries on setting new petroleum costs.

title: A.D.A. Asserts Incumbents Have Big Edge for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) An incumbent Congressman has a better than $375,000 advantage in salaries and privileges over a challenger for election, according to a survey by Americans for Democratic Action.

title: Margaret Court Is Upset, 75, 64
description: PERTH, Australia, Dec. 15 (AP)  Kerry Harris upset Mrs. Margaret Court, the world's No. 1 player, 75, 64, and advanced to the final of the West Australian open tenni3 championship today.

title: Henry Bradley, Publisher Of St. Joseph Newspapers
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 15 (AP)  Henry D. Bradley, president and retired publisher of The St. Joseph News Press and Gazette and a former director of The Associated Press, died yesterday at a, hospital here. He was 80 years old and had been hospitalized since suffering a paralytic stroke in 1971.

title: Miss Davy Is Bride Of Rupert Fennell
description: Miss Charlotte Jane Davy was married here yesterday morning to Rupert Winters Fennell, an English furniture expert at Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Philip Culbertson, an Episcopal priest.

title: Leafs Lose Lead Twice
description: TORONTO, Dec. 15Bruce MacGregor pulled a game out of the fire for the New York Rangers tonight by scoring a goal at 17 minutes 25 seconds of the third period, gaining a hardfought 22 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Judge Orders Lutheran Jailed For Silence on Wounded Knee
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 15An official of the American Lutheran Church has been ordered jailed for refusing to testify about what he saw and heard during the confrontation at Wounded Knee, S, D., last spring.

title: Numismatics
description: INTEREST in fractional currency has kept pace with the overall rise of paper money collecting. Ample evidence of the growth of both was produced at the Nov. 1617 Matt Rothert Collection auction conducted by the American Auction Association (Bowers & Ruddy Galleries) in Hollywood. The feature of the nearly 2,000lot sale was the notable collection of largesize and fractional notes consigned by Matt H. Rothert, a former president of the American Numismatic Association.

title: Laura B. Leake, Charles Brown To Be Married
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 15Mr. and Mrs. Frank Beveridge Leake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Blanton Leake, to Charles James Gatewood Brown of New York where he is a district assistant in the national division of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Home Seekers Feel the Tug of Varied Forces
description: The energy shortage has added a negative note to the residential real estate market in the metropolitan area.

title: Information Service Is Set Up Here
description: Where in this city could one go to find a stuffed gorilla, an African sympathy card, an ostrich egg or glass slippers to fit a corpse?

title: STUDENTS' SCORES AGAIN SHOW DROP
description: thorities indicate, however, that increasing attention may be given to the possibility that the lower scores stem not from more youngsters taking the testas has been believedbut from an education that does not equip them as well for the test, which measures developer abilities.

title: B'NAI B'RITH BARS A LONDON PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The 500,000  member B'nai B'rith, reacting to what many American Jews regard as Britain's proArab stance during the Middle East war, today canceled London as the scheduled site of its international convention next year.

title: Rutgers Acts, to Conserve
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Rutgers University will shut down for 11 days, starting this week, as part of an energysaving campaign projected to save one million gallons of heating oil this school year.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENEEvery Man for Himself?
description: FROM the perspective of a manufacturer of Christmas tree lights whose business has suddenly collapsed, President Nixon's exhortations that everyone make sacrifices to help the country through the energy shortage may seem to have set off a virtual stampede of compliance. Even the President himself set an example. He dimmed the national tree.

title: Toys That Can Hurt Are Sought by Teams In Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  A flaxenhaired doll whose head comes off to expose a wire spike, a toy rifle that can deafen a child, a plastic rattle readily breakable into sharpedged weapon  a Christmas Eve's visions of sugar plums can dissolve into such realities as these.

title: Japan Developing a Nuclear Project
description: TOKYO, Dec. 15Japanese nuclear researchers believe that Japan can generate nuclear power through the fusion process by the year 2000.

title: Man Picks Bad Place To Refuel a Stolen Bus
description: A 23yearold Brooklyn man who the police said went for a spin Friday night in a stolen bus came to the end of the line when he tried to fill up at the wrong garage.

title: French AutoRacing Ban Perils Le Mans Event
description: Le Mans is 130 miles southwest of Paris and in deep trouble.

title: Princeton School Is Helping Orphans
description: PRINCETONStudents at the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart here have sent paintings they completed to orphanages in South Vietnam to be displayed there.

title: TWA Sees Strike's End
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it should be back to full schedule by late this week if flight attendants approve an agreement to end strike that began 42 days ago, United Press International reported. Tentative accord to end the strike by 5,000 stewards and stewardesses was reached in Washington Friday. Details were withheld until union members vote on it.

title: Music
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. HOW many public speakers can you think of who could get applause by announcing that tonight's lecture would be exceptionally long and who could hold an audience of 1,650 from 7:30 until 11:20? Even after you discount a 15minute delay in starting, a 15minute intermission, and a 50minute film of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex, it leaves you two and a half hours of lecture. Who would even try?

title: Friends and Enemies
description: PARISThe war of Yom Kippur has revealed the fragility of existing Atlantic arrangements. Europe's policy on the Mideast was tantamount to a declaration of diplomatic independence, however fainthearted.

title: PRESIDENT URGES CONGRESS TO ACT ON ENERGY BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15President Nixon urged Congress today to complete action before Christmas on legislation providing emergency powers to conserve energy as he signed a bill putting the nation on yearround daylight saving time starting Jan. 6.

title: Montauk Backs Our Perry
description: MONTAUK, L. I.  Here in Perry Duryea country no one really believes that it happened.

title: MRS. LE BOUTILLIER
description: Mrs. Cornelia Geer Le Boutillier, educator and author, and the widow of Martin Le Boutillier, a lawyer, died yesterday in Stamford, Conn,, where she lived. She was 79 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Church's Hotel Going Coop After Fight
description: The church should not be in business, commented the Rev. Donald S. Harrington, and therein lies the tale of the residential hotel at 10 Park Avenue.

title: They Call It Monster Fishing and Thereby Hangs a Tail
description: MONSTER FISHING, some of them call it. They have even devised a special flag to hoist when they've caught one. The flag is a squareshaped yellow burgee with a green, firebelching dragon rampant, meanlooking but sort of foolishlooking, too, like the wolf in Roadrunner cartoons. When they've caught a really huge Specimen, a mako, a maneater or a great hammerhead, say, they'll fly the monster burgee high on the mast, but if the monster is less spectacular the burgee usually flies at half staff.

title: Point of View
description: The writer of the following article is president of Metropolitan Structures, Inc., a building and management concern based in Chicago.

title: A dreamer caught in the reality of smalltown mediocrity
description: Each chapter of Heartbreak Tango is headed by a quotation from a tango lyric, a movie or a radio commercial. The quotations deploy a simple, captivating ethos. A radio commercial for toothpaste puts it in a nutshell: As long as you can smile, success can be yours. The tango lyrics are more realistic, for their devotion to passion and success is frequently undermined by an act of callous fickleness. Yet the tangos also leave no doubt about one thing: the pursuit of passion and glamour is man's most natural and valid activity. As one tango says:

title: A Skyscraper Goes Up
description: Carter Harman's handbook takes a very literal approach and leaves no Ibeam or Manitiwoc crane unaccounted for. We rise with New York's Exxon Building from its 1968 plans through the terse toppingoff ceremony of August, 1970, to the 1972 arrival of the first tenants and the maintenance crew of people and robots who will keep it going.

title: ANCIENT FRESCO FOUND IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, Dec. 15A fresco of six nymphs bearing gifts of flowers to a barebreasted goddess, fashioned some 3,500 years ago, has been rescued by Greek archeologists from the wreckage of Thera, the Aegean island destroyed by one of the most powerful volcanic eruptions ever recorded by man.

title: Ellyn Miller Is Fiancee of Daniel Cohen
description: HEWLETT, L. I., Dec. 15Mr. and Mrs. E. Edward Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellyn Miller, to Daniel H. Cohen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward I. Cohen of Syracuse, N. Y. The couple plan to be married here on Feb. 2.

title: Prelate Discusses Mixed Marriages
description: CARTERET  Roman Catholic leaders who oppose interfaith marriages only on the ground that their communicants may be lost to the Catholic church are on the wrong track, according to Msgr. Victor J. Pospishil, pastor of St. Mary's Ukrainian Catholic Church here and an associate professor of religious studies at Manhattan College in New York.

title: For richer, fuller lives
description: AT the offices of the Children's Aid Society in downtown Manhattan they talk about cutting the suit to fit the cloth. They talk that way because the size and the scope of present programs to help the needy are such that the society, which has been in existence for 120 years, simply cannot take on new ventures unless new donors are found.

title: New Plant to Start Purifying of Clams
description: HIGHLANDS  After almost 18 months of preparation, the Sandy Hook Lobster Company here plans to begin New Jersey's first commercial clampurifying operation soon.

title: Howe & Sons
description: He's grayhaired, now, and paunchy. They say he's only two pounds over his old 206pound playing weight with the Detroit Red Wings; if so, the anatomical priorities have been reordered. The jersey is different, too; after two years of retirement, he's wearing his old number 9 for the Houston Aeros. But the essential Gordie Howethe man who shattered virtually every scoring record in hockey's history, who revolutionized the gameremains. There is that familiar casual grace as he whispers over the ice in long, almost loping strides. At the advanced age of 45, he is still the unhesitating brawler. And his stick handling is still subtle and controlled: He shoots goals the way Hank Aaron hits home with his wrists.

title: Auditions Are Set For King and I
description: The Theatre Workshop for the Performing Arts is holding auditions for The King and I, the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, on Tuesday and Wednesday, Dec. 1819, the United Methodist Church on Parish Drive in Wayne, at 8 P.M.

title: Diagramless, 16 by 23
description: ACROSS

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Archbishop Ieronymos, primate of Greece, offered to resign today because of repeated attacks against him.

title: Notes: Bear Facts About Gerald Ford
description: WHEN Vice President Gerald R. Ford used to tell bedtime stories to his four children, one of his favorite sources of material was his experience as a ranger at Yellowstone National Park. That's right. A ranger. In fact, Gerald Ford is the first National Park Service ranger to become the Vice President of the United States.

title: J.L. LOEB JR. DENIES GOVERNORSHIP BID
description: John L. Loeb Jr., the former Wall Street investment banker who is now chairman of the New York State Council of Environmental Advisers, said last night that he had no plans to run for Governor or any other office at this time.

title: Robert Carr to Marry Nancy Leigh Malkin
description: WAYLAND, Mass., Dec. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Malkin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Leigh Malkin, to Robert Oliver Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver T. Carr Jr. of Washington and Easton, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: Nancy Grant Sets Nuptials
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Dec. 15Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Grant have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Virginia Grant, to Martin Lian, son of Dr. and Mrs. Caspar A. Lian of Scarsdale, N. Y. A wedding in February is planned.

title: Architecture
description: THE BUILDINGS in our cities today have been designed by competitive economics and cheap energy. They are fiscal and mechanical marvels. Yes, they have been designed by architects too, but forget any Fountainhead idea of genius fighting business and the mobocracy for art.

title: O.C.S. Graduates Married
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Dec. 15 (AP)Two members of the Navy's first coed officer candidate class have married and will, be assigned to the Naval Communications Station in Honolulu. They are Ensigns Andrew Siter and his Nov. 21 bride, the former Della Gibson.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF REPORTS MOST TRYING YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (Reu ters)The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation Clarence M. Kelley, said in an annual report issued yesterday that the last year had been one of the most trying eras lin the F.B.I.'s history.

title: Opera? It's Sheer Porn
description: FIRST, let me get a correction out of the way. In my review of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Tales of Hoffmann a few weeks ago, I wrote that obviously the voice of Cynthia Munzer, singing the role of Antonia's mother, was amplified. The voice certainly did not come from the stage, and I took it for granted that this was one of the special effects that the Metropolitan sometimes uses. Several readers have pointed out that Munzer's voice was not amplified. She was singing from the orchestra pit. Writes Francis Robinson, assistant manager of the Metropolitan, The only productions so far this season to use amplification are Salome (the voice of Jochanaan from the cistern) and Les Troyens for the offstage instruments and certain effects in the dream sequence.

title: Child to Mrs. Blacker
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Blacker on Monday at Doctors Hospital. The child, the couple's second, has been named Lauren. Mrs. Blacker, an interior designer, is the former Miss Jean Valente. Her husband is president of Stanley Blacker, Inc., men's sportswear manufacturer.

title: Mrs. Marie Coudert Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Marie Moore Coudert and James B. Rosenwald Jr. of New York and Ossining, N. Y., were married here today at the home of Mr. Rosenwald's brother  in  law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Ben Heller, by Judge Leonard Cohen of the New York Civil Court.

title: Stage: Red Ryder Aims to Stay
description: People keep on asking where are the good American plays? And the curious thing is that season after season, as regular as wheat or clockwork, the good American plays keep turning up. Last night one turned up at the Eastside Playhouse. It is called When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder? but it is my guess that Red Ryder won't he leaving this theater for a long time. It is a fascinating and commanding play.

title: Harassment of Opponents Called Impeachment Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations says that President Nixon committed an impeachable offense by using Government agencies to harass his political opponents.

title: Art in London
description: LONDON. CEZANNE in life was the most secret of men. From first youth onward he found it difficult to verbalize his inmost feelings and painful, if not impossible, to argue. To prove something to Paul Czanne, said his friend the novelist Emile Zola, is like asking the towers of Notre Dame to dance a quadrille. As he grew older, gratuitous human contacts became so abhorrent to him that if someone brushed against him in the street he wouldscream aloud with rage and horror. Conversely, to be recognized, in no matter how conventional a way, would bring tears to his eyes; in 1894, as a man of 55, he went on his knees to Rodin to thank him for shaking him by the hand.

title: Duryea Proposes Stronger Code Of Ethics for the Legislature
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea today proposed a stronger code of ethics for the State Legislature, the closer supervision of lobbyists and a number of other reforms he said would further open the legislative process to the people.

title: Astor Estate Proposal Fails
description: The town board in Rhinebeck, N.Y., voted unanimously last week against zoning changes that would have permitted a developer to build a residential community on part of the former Astor estate.

title: Barbara Batzes Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Batzes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Batzes, to Stuart Homer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Bentley Homer. Both families are of Brooklyn, where the wedding is planned for Jan. 26. Miss Batzes is a magna cum laude graduate of Brooklyn College. Her fianc, an alumnus of Hunter College, is a sales representative for Ohio with the Vanity Fair Corporation in Columbus.

title: Town Adopts Plan Drafted by Students
description: BERNARDSVILLE  The Borough Council here is in the process of adopting a series of farreaching governmental changes drawn from a comprehensive study drafted by an unlikely sourcean undergraduate seminar at nearby Drew University In Madison.

title: Dolphins Triumph, 347
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15  Bob Griese and Paul Warfield, tuning up for their American Conference playoff test on Dec. 23, hooked up on four touchdown passes in the first half today and the Miami Dolphins posted a 347 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: SaltNoody, Dujo, Lee, Jill, Snooky, Mumps, Shaft and Dee Dee
description: There is a building in upper Harlem on a shabby side street with several other buildings that resemble it in both appearance and condition. This building is in an advanced state of deterioration; only cold water runs through the water pipes, the rats here are as large as cats. The saving grace of this building might very well be the erratic patterns of the varied and brilliant colors of the graffiti which adorn it internally and externally from basement to roof. This building has no electricity in the apartments, but the electricity in the hallway lamp fixtures is still on. Some of the apartments have garbage piled up in them five feet high and that makes opening the door a very difficult task for those whose nasal passages are sufficiently insensitive to permit entry. In some of the apartments and on the rooftop, the garbage and assorted debris are piled only one or two feet high, and the trash has been there so long that plant life has generated. The most rapid tour possible through this building will necessitate boiling oneself in a hot tub of strong disinfectant for a couple of hours, and even then this astonishingly formidable breed of lice will continue to make its presence felt throughout a long itchy night. This building adjacent to a fully occupied tenement whose inhabitants are families, some of which include several children. This building has a few steps missing from the staircase above the second floor and there are no lightbulbs in the hallway; it's a very unsafe place for trespassers, even during the day. This building's last family of tenants was emancipated several weeks ago; they hit the numbers and moved to the Bronx, shouting, Free at last; free at last; thank God for the number man. Prior to their liberation, the last family had lived a most unusual existence. Somebody had to be at home at all times to protect the familys secondhandhot television from becoming a thirdhandhot television; there were too many junkies in and out who used the vacant apartments to stash their loot until they could down it and who also used some of the apartments for sleeping and as shooting galleries. For protection, the last family had a large, vicious German shepherd. This dog was needed for the rats as well as the junkies. A cat would be no help at all. The sight of the rats in this building would give any cat smaller than a mountain lion instant heart failure. The last family considered itself fortunate, despite the many unpleasant, unhealthy and unsafe aspects of its residence. We ain't paid no rent in two years. I guess the city just forgot that we was here or they was just too embarrassed to ask for it, said the head of the last family. This building has holes in the walls large enough for a man to walk through two adjacent apartments. This building has holes in the ceilings on the fourth and fifth floors, and when it rains, the rain settles on the floor of a fourthstory apartment. This building is not unique, there are many others like in the ghettos of New York City; and like many others . . . this building is owned by the City of New York.

title: Even in 1942, Berlin Tent to the Opera
description: BACK in those darkest of years of the midWorld War Two period and shadowed by the mounting horror of holocaust, Berlin, Munich and Dresden still thought about music, Bombs and gas chambers for one compartment of the mind, opera and concerts for the other. If one is capable of overlooking this dismaying dichotomy  or perhaps if one finds seasoning in its very gruesomeness  recent releases on the imported BASF label will prove not only undisturbing but quite fascinating.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1973

title: People and Business
description: New Jersey's business community is gearing for the observance of the 200th anniversary of the nation's founding, according to Milford A. Vieser, chairman of the New Jersey American Revolution Bicentennial Celebration Commission.

title: Energy:Physicists Suggest SuperCleanAtomic System
description: Physicists in California have proposed a superclean method for extracting nuclear energy that combines both fusion and fission.

title: A Small Town: Arkansas Area Pulls Itself Up From Stagnation
description: HARRISON, Ark., Dec. 4  One of the most striking things about this little Southern town in the northwest corner of Arkansas is that almost everything in it seems new  the homes, the schools, the sparkling new shopping centers and the industrial plants clustered in a row outside town.

title: Miss Schroeder Wed
description: FEDERAL WAY, Wash., Dec. 15Miss Kathleen Ann Schroeder was married here this noon to James Durward Emerson of Seattle. The Rev. Michael Batterberry performed the ceremony in the St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church. The bride is the daughter of Maj. Julius T. Schroeder, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Schroeder of Goldbar. The bridegroom's parents are Mrs. A. Grinstead Emerson of Old Lyme, Conn., and Fred Light Emerson Jr. of Lyme, Conn.

title: NEW RESTRICTIONS FACED BY BRITONS
description: LONDON, Dec. 15Britons began the weekend today facing renewed power cuts and complete suspension of Sunday train service.

title: Dance: Impish Wagoner
description: As a dancer, Dan Wagoner has always looked like a cross between a friendly leprechaun and a high school track star. His face positively glows with friendly good nature, but in all of his dancing there is a lurking touch of mischief.

title: The Eight Years of the Lindsay Era
description: The eight years of John V. Lindsay fall into three periods, each a chapter to be read against his ambitions for higher political office.

title: City Council Schedules Meeting and 2 Hearings
description: The City Council's regular weekly meeting will be at 1:30 P.M. next Thursday, and the Council has scheduled the following two public hearings this week:

title: AROUND THE
description: One good thing about 68 degree room temperature in the home, the Christmas tree will probably last longer. The cooler the room, the slower the drying out of the needles.

title: NIXON LEGAL AIDE HAS FEW REGRETS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 15 (UPI) Charles Alan Wright, the lawyer who labored to keep President Nixon's Watergate tapes secret, said today that he hoped there were adequate answers why two of them did not exist and one was marred.

title: Suckered
description: The sermon for this morning is about the fallibility of editors and the ethics of reviewers.

title: Squeeze on I.R.S.
description: The same joint Congressional committee that is about to review President Nixon's income tax returns has been conducting a quiet inquiry into White House attempts to influence the Internal Revenue Service to act against individuals and organizations on its enemies lists. No public hearings have been held or any report issued. Although some members of the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation have said that the inquiry shows the I.R.S. resisted political pressure, this question is too grave to be treated in a hushhush manner. A full public examination is imperative.

title: Several Thousand at Wedding of Wallace's Daughter in Alabama;
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 15It was, as one observer of Southern society noted, probably the most lavish social affair in the Cradle of the Confederacy in its long and illustrious history of colorful social events.

title: Patricia Rand, Aide of Javits, Fiancee of Alexander Ellis 3d
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 15  The engagement of Miss Patricia Robin Rand, an aide in the Washington office of Senator Jacob K. Javits, to Alexander Ellis 3d, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Calvin G. Rand, parents of the future bride. Her fianc, who is a legislative assistant to Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., and a grandson of the late Senator Prescott S. Bush of Connecticut.

title: Good manners for liberated persons
description: The whole relation of men to women, as far as etiquette is concerned, is based on the assumption that woman is a delicate, serfsitive creature, easily tired, who must be feted, amused and protected, and to whom the bright and gay side of the picture must always be turned.

title: TITLE BRIDGE LED BY CALIFORNIANS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 15A California foursome led the field into the semifinal stage of the Reisinger open team championship here today in the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: STUDENTS' SCORES AGAIN SHOW DROP
description: A steady 10year decline in high school students' scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, underlined by a drop reported yesterday for this year's graduates, puzzles educators who thought students had been getting smarter.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: U.C.L.A. Wins 79th
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, rated number one, defeated secondranked North Carolina State, 8466, in St. Louis yesterday, extending its record basketball streak to 79 victories, and ending its opponent's at 29. Details in Section 5.

title: Cathedral
description: The Middle Ages were a time of faithfaith in God and faith in man under the guidance of God. Evidence of this faith and justification for it can be seen in the great cathedrals of Eng. land and the Continent, monuments to the spiritual insights and material achievements of mankind over the centuries.

title: Turkey's Caretaker Premier Seeks Governing Coalition
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 15President Fahri Koruturli today asked the caretaker Premier, Naim Talu, to form a national coalition Government to end Turkey's twomonth political crisis, the President's office said.

title: America the not always beautiful
description: A Play of American Politics, War, and Protest Taken from the Historical Record. By Elinor Fuchs and Joyce Antler. 233 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $3.95.

title: Show's Star: L.I. in 2600 B.C.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I.Artifacts from Long Island settlements that existed more than 2,600 years before the birth of Christthe earliest datable traces ever found of permanent human settlement on the Islandgo on display today at the Garvies Point Museum here.

title: The Root of the Matter
description: PARISNATO has always been hampered by flabby consultation procedures, above all when problems affecting the allies arise outside the North Atlantic Treaty area. The worst instance was the 1956 Suez war when the United States joined Russia to oppose a BritishFrenchIsraeli attack on Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In addition to the voluntary measures suggested to reduce fuel consumption, three alternative solutions are being considered to meet with the present fuel shortage: Rationing, higher taxes and/or price increases.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Daniel Berrigan's Speech to Arabs Stirs a Furor Over Award
description: Plans to honor the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan with a peace award here have run into opposition following the report of a speech he gave recently to an Arab audience describing Israel as a criminal Jewish community and a nightmare that manufactures human waste,

title: Mrs. Staples Wed To Marketing Aide
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Dec. 15Mrs. Joan Woodbridge Staples was married at her home here today to Raymond Poelvoorde Jr., executive vice president of Lippincott & Margulies, Inc., international communications, marketing and design consultants in New York.

title: Grant by Schering Aids Medical Study
description: HOBOKENA medicalresearch program designed to bring together doctors, research scientists and engineers has been instituted by the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry at Newark and the Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: Dinkins Asks campaignspend Law
description: Deputy Mayor  designate David N. Dinkins urged the State Legislature yesterday to enact reforms of the election laws on campaign contributions and spending while the memory of Watergate is fresh in our minds.

title: Legislative Posts for Losers
description: TRENTON  The Democratic leadership elections in the new Legislature last week produced enough consolation prizes to massage a few deflated egos and pay off a number of political debts.

title: Crown roast
description: If you're bored with turkey and can't look another chicken in the eye, if you don't like goose and think duck is for the birds, but you still yearn for stuffingwell, think crown roast. A crown roast of lamb is festive enough for Christmas dinner and while it's expensive, it's not necessarily outofquestion expensive. (One of Manhattan's best butchers says a six pound crown roast of lamb with a pound of ground lamb should run about $10; another says that he would have to charge $20 to $24. The difference is not so much in the grade of the meat as in the butcher's competence as a buyer and the store's markup policy.) It takes less time to cook than the average turkey or goose, it's easier to carveand there shouldn't be any leftovers.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated our stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Manhattan Wins Three Relay Races
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15  Manhattan College won three relays and two team field events today at the third annual Princeton Relays. But Columbia scored an upset in the distance medley that prevented the Jaspers from sweeping the four team events.

title: Something on Every Page To Pain the Republicans
description: WASHINGTONOnly a pundit with an independent income would risk predicting the outcome of a Congressional election one year in advance, but there is nothing to stop politicians from worrying. And the arithmetic of the 1974 elections gives them plenty to worry about.

title: Investors Find Bottom of the Pyramid Is Barren
description: Mrs, Edith Soicher, who is 55 years old, wanted to make some money to pay for a condominium in Florida, where she is retiring next year. She persuaded her husband, Sam, to use $2,000 of their savings to buy a franchise from Galaxy Foods to sell their products. She was told that she would make $5,000 in a year's time, but today she does not even have her initial investment back, and last month Galaxy filed for bankruptcy.

title: ARABS AND DUTCH CORDIAL AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 15 A Saudi Arabian representative told the Netherlands Ambassador during a recent meeting here that the Dutch Government must be burdened by distracting difficulties these days.

title: O.J. in Jet Spotlight
description: If O. J. Simpson doesn't severely stub his big toe getting off the team bus and if Weeb Ewbank doesn't have a lastminute change of heart, this could be a noteworthy day at Shea Stadium.

title: Lisa Christine Kingsley Betrothed
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 15 Donald E. Kingsley, a first vice president of Harris Upham & Co., investment brokers, and Mrs. Kingsley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Christine Kingsley, to Roland A. Baroni Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Baroni. Dr. Baroni is a dentist who practices in New York.

title: U.S. SEEN NAMING ENVOY TO SWEDEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Unless President Nixon changes his mind at the last minute, the United States will end a yearlong diplomatic freeze against Sweden next month and name a new ambassador to Stockholm, American officials report.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The dependable Michael Collins, creator of Dan Fortune, is back with the latest in the saga of the onearmed private eye. THE SILENT SCREAM (Dodd, Mead, $4.95) may or may not be the best in the seriesall are goodbut it is in the best Collins vein. This means it is a novel of action in a big city, full of the tugs and tensions of people operating on the other side of the law. It also means that this is a novel full of insights and, in its way, compassion.

title: Nets Top Cougars By 9995
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 15 A jump shot by Julius Erving with one minute 4 seconds remaining broke a 9595 deadlock and helped the New York Nets to a 9995 American Basketball Association victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: The Nation
description: There may have been times last week when America's new energy czar, William E. Simon  by a majority opinion a toughminded and talented administrator  must have wondered why he had not chosen instead to resolve the border dispute between the Soviet Union and China. Nobody could yet begin blaming him, but last week he presided over a situation that was compounded of confusion, inadequate information, political ploys and simple error. These things happened:

title: John Marston Fiance Of Elizabeth Barlow
description: State Supreme Court Justice Theodore G. Barlow and Mrs. Barlow of New Brighton, Staten Island have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Troy Barlow, to John Robert Marston, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Marston of Silver Spring, Md. The wedding is planned for Jan. 26.

title: Yiddish Theater LivesIs That an Illusion?
description: A SIMPLE enough matter, going to the Yiddish theater. You take a trip down to the shabby old Eden at Second Avenue and 12th Street, watch some crafty old actors in a wellworn old play, and release some old memories. . . . But the evening I went to see Joseph Buloff in Sholom Aleichem's Hard to Be a Jew I found myself entangled with feelings far more troublesome and complex.

title: U.C.L.A. Captures 79th, 84 to 66
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15Forced to play without its leader for 21 minutes 7 seconds today, the Walton Gang from the University of California, Los Angeles, stuck to its guns in his absence.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: Better Arbitor, 72, Triumphs in $100,000 Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15Put $100,000 on the line, and top trainers will send top horses after it, even at a northern track 10 days before Christmas.

title: Newport, RI, Is Betting on Jai Alai
description: Yankee bluebloods shouting Chula! as Jose and Julio scramble to victory in a long shot daily double at Newport, R. I.?

title: Flames Top Flyers, 32; End Streak
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (UPI)Goals by, Larry Romanchych, Tom Lysiak and Curt Bennett and 33 blocked shots by Phil Myre, the goalie, enabled the Atlanta Flames to score a 32 victory today and break the sevengame unbeaten streak of the Philadelphia Flyers, leaders of the National Hockey League's West Division.

title: Music in Review
description: Although the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center generally busies itself with the classic and romantic repertories, it occasionally ventures outside them, and that is what it did, briefly, at Tully Hall on Friday night.

title: ACADEMY CODES TERMED ILLEGAL
description: A twoyear study of legal practices at the nation's five service academies has found what are alleged to be extensive violations of constitutional guarantees in maintaining conduct, honor and ethics codes.

title: Antitrust Group Takes Action
description: TRENTONThe fledgling antitrust section of the State Attorney General's Office, created as part of a package of anticrime bills three years ago, moved again last week.

title: U.S. AIDE EXPECTS THREEDAY DELAY IN GENEVA PARLEY
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 15A senior American official traveling with Secretary of State Kissinger's party said tonight that the Middle East peace conference in Geneva would. probably be delayed until Friday.

title: They Won't Bach Around the Clock
description: WITH Emerson, Lake and Palmer, apparently nothing succeeds like excess. The successful British rock trio, which is known for its appearances with symphony orchestras, is due at Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Tuesday with over 200 separate items of equipment, valued by Customs at just over $100,000.

title: Arizona Women Win
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI) Eastern Arizona Junior College defeated Miami Dade South today to win the national junior college women's volleyball championship.

Richardson, who was among the victims of the Saturday Night Massacre of Oct. 20, when he resigned as Attorney General rather than carry out President Nixon's order that he fire Archibald Cox as Watergate special prosecutor:

title: Bike Rentals Up In Energy Crisis
description: MONTCLAIRThe bicycle business in this welltodo suburban town is a silver lining in the dark cloud of the energy crisis.

title: Swiss Take To Forests With Skis
description: BEVERS, Switzerland, Dec. 14The gray smoke curled above the railroad station's chimney, and drifted lazily to the south as more than 50 students, ranging in ages from 30 to 55, gathered for a skitouring safari into the woods.

title: Major Collection of Drawings Shown in Brooklyn Museum
description: One of the drawings collections in New York that merits considerably more recognition than it has won in the past is the CooperHewitt collection. Opening next Tuesday at the Brooklyn Museum, the collection constitutes one of the leading groups of Italian and American drawings in the United States. It contains outstanding examples from the 15th century to the 20th century with a notable concentration on the baroque and rococo in France and Italy.

title: Regan Alford Wed to W. R. Forrester Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Miss Regan Anne Alford was married here today to William Ray Forrester Jr. in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity in Georgetown by the Rev. Cornell Bradley.

description: MORRISTOWN  A proposed parkandride station for the Erie Lackawanna Railway took a major step forward last week after State Department of Transportation officials reached agreement with officials from Morris County and ParsippanyTroy Hills on the site for the project.

title: Broker Weds Mrs. Morton
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Dec. 15Mrs. Elizabeth Nickerson Morton, widow of Charles Ingalls Morton, who was vice president of the CurtissWright Corporation, was married here at noon today to Charles Hamilton Sabin, retired investment banker, also of Stonington.

description: Despite Watergate, the energy crisis and shortages of numerous productsperhaps partly because of them many Americans seem determined to have a jolly Christmas this year.

description: WASHINGTON  Our problem, said a very senior officer of one of the world's largest oil companies, is that we don't have the money to do a lot of things.

title: Jeffrey E. Fleuren to Wed Daryl Byrne
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 15Miss Daryl Elizabeth Byrne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Byrne of Greenwich and Grande Princesse, St. Croix, Virgin Islands, plans to be married Jan. 12 to Jeffrey Edward Fleuren, son of Mrs. Main Sanseigne of New York and the late John Praett Fleuren.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE American Express Company and The Ely Landau Company, which have been presenting The American Film Theatre movies in New York City and other cities around the country, are responsible for ripping off many, many people. Not because of the quality of the presentations, but because they have oversold most of the local Manhattan theaters and subscribers' tickets are not being honored at the box office.

title: Independent Oil Distributors Feel Caught in the Middle of Energy Crisis
description: How's it going? Do you really want to know? It's going ridiculous! said Samuel Fisher, juggling phone calls in the office of what he calls an averagesized independent heatingoil retailer in Brooklyn, with a clientele that is 95 per cent residential.

title: Miss Carstens Plans Nuptials
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 15Mrs. Samuel Ferdinand Carstens has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Wilkinson Carstens, to Paul Martin Tymniak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Tymniak of Fairfield. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Psychiatrists, in a Shift, Declare Homosexuality No Mental Illness
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The American Psychiatric Association, altering a position it has held for nearly a century, decided today that homosexuality is not a mental disorder.

title: J.W. Vandeveer to Wed Jeanette Jenkins
description: GLENSIDE, Pa., Dec. 15Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jenkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanette Atlee Jenkins, to Jay Wellington Vandeveer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington Vandeveer of Bernardsville, N. J.
