description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (UPI) Gov. Daniel Walker's campaign records have been subpoenaed by a Cook County grand jury investigating possible official misconduct, the state's attorney's office said today.

title: The Coups Haven't Given Peace a Chance
description: Syria: An Ancient Nation, a New Nation

title: Day of Decision for N.F.L. Playoffs: Scramble for 2 Wildcard Positions
description: The National Football League's threeyearold system of playoff qualification, which includes a wildcard team from each of the two conferences, has proven its efficacy again. Twelve of the league's 26 teams were still in contention for a postseason playoff berth prior to their final games. Only three of six division titles have been resolved and five of eight playoff positions settled going into today's final 11 games.

title: HANUKKAH FETE OPENS WEDNESDAY
description: The eightday observance of Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights marking the Maccabean victory over Syrian tyranny more than 2,000 years ago, and a holiday symbolizing religious freedom, begins at sundown Wednesday.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: A 21member international commission of Anglican and Roman Catholic scholars last week announced their basic agreement on the second of three theological disputes that have been barriers to the reconcilation of the two Christian faiths separated for store than four centuries.

title: Hospital Gains in Fight for More Beds
description: TRENTON  After a 23month wait, Point Pleasant Hospital seems certain to receive state permission to complete a 38bed addition on the top floor of a new wing.

title: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: IN one way or another, the activities of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York touched the lives of nearly half a million men, women and children last year. Half a million is a sizable number, and officials of the agency emphasize that the agency does its work in cooperation with more than 200 member organizations, with the support of the priesthood and vast numbers of laymen.

title: The Nation
description: Four worried men, the President and three of his top aides, are in a helicopter flying from Los Angeles to San Clemente. The New York Times has just printed a secret Pentagon history of the Vietnam war, and the fear in the White House is that Daniel Ellsberg, the former Defense official who says he turned the documents over to the press, may give still more vital secrets, such as the American nuclear targeting plan, to the Russians. The four leaders discuss setting up an undercover operation, bypassing the F.B.I., to find out all about Mr. Ellsberg and stop all leaks.

title: Coast Paper Is Purchased By The Tribune Company
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) The Tribune Company has purchased the Van Nuys Publiqhing Company and News Building Corporation of California, publishers of The Valley News and Green Sheet.

title: L.I. Ferry Service Assailed
description: GREENPORT, L. I.Does Eastern Long Island need another ferry line linking it to Connecticut?

title: As Controls End, Prices Take Off
description: To the delight of almost everyone in the business community, the Nixon Administration has begun the widely anticipated final phase of its economic stabilization program, which began in mid1971.

title: Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR: Darrow Wood's letter in your Dec. 2 issues served only to point out the ignorance of the many New Yorkers with regard to Big Ten football. I would like to take this opportunity to provide Wood and everyone else with some straight facts on the Michigan controversy.

title: Richard Westenburg in Debut As Collegiate Chorale Conductor
description: In its 32 years, the Collegiate Chorale of this city has had only four conductors: Robert Shaw, its founder; Ralph Hunter. Abraham Kaplan and, now. Richard Westenburg. The last, who is well known for his Musica Sacra concerts at the Central Presbyterian Church, made his debut with the Chorale on Friday night. It was a relatively modest affair, with a program of two Christmas works performed in St. Thomas Church.

title: Students Will Meet On Transport Issue
description: WEST LONG BRANCHStudents from high schools and colleges throughout New Jersey and the metropolitan area will meet at Monmouth College on March 22 to discuss The Transportation Crisis: How It Effects States, Counties and Local Municipalities.

title: Kenya, 10 Years Independent, Emerges as a Model of Stability
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 15Kenya celebrated 10 years of independence this week, a decade that has seen the East African republic emerge as a model of a pragmatic, conservative stategy of development.

title: Big SixYear Tax Deduction for Nixons Foreseen in San Clemente Gift to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15President Nixon's intended gift to the American people of his house and grounds in San Clemente could give him another big tax deduction at about the time that one he claimed for the donation of his prePresidential papers runs out.

title: Our Lord Don Quixote
description: The inventor of splendid arguments with death

title: India Children to Eat Leaf Protein in a Diet Test
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Protein extracted from leaves is to be fed children in South India in a twoyear trial to determine if this is the answer to the developing world's undernourishment problem.

title: Food Stamp Diet Called Nutritious by U.S. Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) A Federal judge rejected this week the contention of a group of welfare recipients that the food stamp program did not provide a nutritious diet.

title: Witnesses Tell Jury of Hughes Airline Deal
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 15A Federal grand jury has completed an intensive week of taking testimony on possible irregularities involving the purchase of Air West by Howard Hughes in 1970. Indictments are expected to be handed up within two weeks, sources close to the investigation Indicate.

title: A Pause for Reflection in Irvington
description: IRVINGTONAs this Essex County community prepares to mark its centennial beginning in April, the 64,000 residents have become aware of the fact that there no longer is room for expansion in town, and they are zealous in seeking to guard what they have. The Town Council has has to declare a oneyear moratorium on construction of garden apartments for lack of adequate sewerage, a problem described in an ordinance as serious in certain areas of town. The action was taken at a time when Irvington appeared to be expanding rapidly and the business district thrived as a result.

title: A Lesson in Holiday Fun
description: MORRISTOWN  All the elements of the traditional Christmas party were three the holly and the mistletoe, the decorated tree, the festive foods, the carol singing and the exchange of gifts.

title: Dolly Bostwick Prefers To Be a Jockey Than Deb
description: Dolly Bostwick would like to make one thing perfectly clear: she is a jockey, not a debutante.

title: Emil (Six Yards) Sitko Dead; Irish Grid Star in the Forties
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 15 (AP)Emil (Six Yards) Sitko, a stubby, explosive runner who starred on four undefeated football teams for the University of Notre Dame, died today at his home here. He was 50 years old.

title: 51,665 TAKE TEST FOR POLICE POST
description: A total of 51,665 young men and women lined up in the cold at high schools around the city yesterday to take, the Police Department's first Civil Service qualifying examination since 1970.

title: Pop
description: LONG before the energy crisis hit the record industry in the form of a vinyl shortage, another kind of energy dilemma affected the business. That was the failure of disks to convey the energy of certain groups who gave high voltage performances but did not create very distinctive music. Bands without the clearcut musical identities that often come from hit records must work twice as hard as bands which hit home runs up the charts immediately. But the staying power of the former type is usually longer because they have built up a faithful following based their live shows.Pursuing a grueling string of onenighters, groups like the J. Geils Band and Black Oak Arkansas have become top moneymakers in the concert field because they have this solid block of kid power behind them. Yet, though each has just released its fifth album, only Geils has achieved even one gold album (signifying milliondollar sales) because they need to be seen as well as heard. Even Alice Cooper, who by now has had five albums out of seven certified gold, is in a similar spot because his records reveal how much his fame ultimately rests on the insanity of his image.

title: Miss Gretchen Anita Johnsen Is Fiancee of David G. Bryant
description: RUMSON, N. J., Dec. 15Mr. and Mrs. Niels Winchester Johnsen of Rumson, New York and Vail, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gretchen Anita Johnsen, to David Grant Bryant, son of Mrs. Ruth G. Bryant of Washington and Thomas V. Bryant Jr. of Bend, Ore.

title: 20% FOUND OPPOSED TO PRESS IN SURVEY.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)A preWatergate survey found that onefifth of Americans aged 26 to 35 either denied or were undecided about the right of a newspaper to criticize an elected Government official.

title: The Notebooks Of Martha Graham
description: Martha Graham has been as responsible as anyone for the priestessaura that surrounds her today. She shared with most choreographers an utter disregard for posterity and an unwillingness to use any energy to preserve dances once completed. Graham clung almost fanatically to the moment of performance. She hated passing on her roles to other dancers; hence, when she no longer danced in a work, it stopped being done. To Graham, repertory meant the work she was creating, plus whatever else was necessary to complete a program. Dances were dropped, lost, revived with great difficulty, dropped again. She never used notation, and until recently she refused to let other companies do her works. The number of her dances that have been officially filmed is pitifully small, and the informal work films are guarded within the Graham company, in peril of obliteration by fire, flood, or destructive impulse. It's as if not only her choreography but she herself could be alive only at that moment when she assumed a character and faced her audience.

title: Stores Seek More Bus Runs
description: PARAMUS  Shopping centers throughout the state say their customers accustomed to driving to and parking at the stores will have to rely more on public transportation if the gasoline shortage worsens. The centers are making every effort to persuade transportation concerns to offer increased and more widespread service.

title: Martin Mortensen Weds Mrs. Ashley
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 15Mrs. Julianna Morrison Ashley of Darien and Martin August Mortensen of Stamford were married here today. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speer Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: SLAIN U.S. OFFICER HAD HIS HANDS UP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15The operations officer of the United States search team that came under attack in an area southwest of Saigon this morning said that the one American killed was murdered in cold blood as he held up his hands in surrender.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (UPI)The Leeds United soccer club, English First Division leader, reached a landmark today with a 21 victory over Chelsea to become the only division team since World War II to remain undefeated after the first 20 league games.

title: Test Called BiasFree
description: The Police Department described the specially designed Civil Service examination given yesterday as unisex and free of cultural bias.

title: PERRIDE SUBSIDY URGED FOR STATE
description: A statewide program to sub??dize mass transit on a perride basis has been drafted by en Assembly task force with the backing of several key legislative leaders.

title: Scientist Creates Electronic Violin
description: MURRAY HILLThe violinist places the instrument under her chin and bows the strings, and out comes the brassy sound of a bugle reveille. As she continues to play, a slim man wearing metalrimmed glasses twiddles the dials on a small, gray box and the bugle sound takes on a wahwah effect.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New: Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Logs Made of Dried Leaves
description: WEST ORANGE  Chilly homeowners, caught with their thermostats down and a dwindling supply of firewood, may find some unexpected relief this winter through logs made of dead leaves.

title: Report Says Storm King Plant May Peril 75% of Bass in River
description: A new preliminary report by an Atomic Energy Commission laboratory has estimated that the controversial Storm King hydroelectric power project might destroy as much as 75 per cent of the annual hatch of striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Artis Gilmore, the Kentucky Colonels' 7foot2inch center and leading rebounder in the American Basketball Association, will have a chance to compete for another top statistic when he meets Julius Erving and the New York Nets Wednesday in Nassau Coliseum, 7:35 P.M. The two players lead the league in blocked shots.

title: 35% IN POLL ASK OUSTER OF NIXON
description: A Gallup Poll early ?? month found the public agains compelling President Nixon ?? leave office by 54 per cent ?? 35 per cent. This compare with a Gallup finding a ?? earlier of 54 per cent to 37 per cent.

title: FRANCIS VON KAHLER
description: Francis von Kahler, who had peen president for 35 years of the Allied Brokerage Corporation, an insurance concern in this city, died in Roosevelt Hospital on Friday. He had undergone openheart surgery a month ago. His age was 78 and he lived at 6 East 65th Street.

title: Legality Of Abortion In Clinics Is Uncertain
description: TRENTON  Despite efforts by the State Attorney General's office to clarify New Jersey's tangled abortion regulations here last week, the legality of performing abortions outside of hospitals in the state is still uncertain. Such abortions are therefore continuing, but on a small scale.

title: Bicentennial: Where the Action Was
description: NEWARKTo bring home to our residents that here was where the action was, New Jersey's newly formed bicentennial commission plans to recreate in the next several years a significant number of historical events that took place in the state during the American Revolution.

title: Tennessee Overcomes Temple's Stall, 11 to 6
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15 (AP)Tennessee withstood a long stall by Temple tonight and wan its invitation tournament, the Volunteer Classic, 116, in the lowest scoring basketball game on record here.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Dear Santa Claus: I write to you tonight, my fellow American, about a major list of gift requests of absolutely vital importance to the national security of the United States.

title: Sewaren Seeks Park Aid
description: SEWAREN  Environmentalists in this onetime resort town  now part of the most heavily industrialized area in the stateare hopeful that the new year will finally see a start on a 39.5acre park on the only open land left on the Arthur Kill. The park, a goal of three generations of residents, will arise on a triangular piece of land between Smith Creek and Arthur Kill.

title: Controls Go Into Their Final Phase
description: WASHINGTONConsumer and wholesale prices are rising at the fastest rate for peacetime in the modern era, and the Government is slowly dismantling price controls. Good thing or bad thing?

title: Upstairs at The White House
description: They came with their dogs, cribs, stuffed toys and trunks of clothes just after noon on Inauguration Day. Some moved their relatives in. Others a piano or a rocking chair. One even clutched a picture of Sam Rayburn. They came with the apprehensions and concerns of any wife who is stuck with a house her husband had picked out. The women had married their spouses for better or worse, but not necessarily for a term at the White House.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE IS LOSER IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15In the latest episode of a longstanding dispute over State Department personnel policies, a Federal judge ruled this week that members of the Foreign Service can no longer be dismissed without a full hearing.

title: 3 Refineries In State Push Plans To Expand
description: PERTH AMBOYDespite the Arab embargo on crudeoil shipments from the Middle East, three major refinerdes in New Jersey that had announced major expansion programs earlier this year are proceeding with their plans.

title: Noahs' Arks
description: Suddenly we are deluged with children's books on Noah's Ark. Since the name Noyes stems from the French noyer, to drown, derived from Noah, we embark on this review with a certain proprietary interest.

title: Ches: The Overprotection Pitfall Applies to More Than Pawns
description: Svetozar Gligoric, the leader of Yugoslav chess for more than a quartercentury, had every reason to be satisfied with his result in the 1967 Interzonal in Sousse, Tunisia, in which he took one of the qualifying places for the 1968 candidates' matches. Nevertheless, the genial grandmaster believes the way he won his place was more than dubious.

title: Europeans Agree on Unity in Oil Crisis; Issue New Statement Favorable to Arabs
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 16The heads of the nine Common Market countries managed after a long and bitter argument tonight, to agree to face the oil crisis together, but only at the price of a new statement on the Miclille East that they hived please the Arabs.

title: Truck and Car Fall as West Side Highway Collapses
description: A section of the West Side Highway collapsed yesterday under the weight of a clump truck and a passenger car, both of which fell to the street below.

title: Blue Cross Will Seek an 8% Rise in 1974 Reimbursement Rates
description: Blue Cross of Greater New York plans to propose to the State Health Commissioner next week that its 1974 reimbursement rates to hospitals be increased by an average of about 8 per cent, a Blue Cross official disclosed yesterday.

title: Miss Nina Congdon Is Married To Nicholas Thayer in Bedford
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Dec. 15 Miss Eleanor Hurd Congdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Buffum Congdon of Cross River, was married here this afternoon to Nicholas Thayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Otis Thayer of Katonah and Ipswich, Mass. The Rev, Arthur Hargate performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Belgrade Party Gains in Struggle to Oust Eight Professors
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 15After more than a year of bitter and emotional struggle at Belgrade University, Yugoslaiia's League of Communists was reported today to be on the verge of achieving the ouster of eight members of the philosophy faculty accused of resistance to party policies and control.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: Thailand Increases Tax On Luxury Items Again
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 15 (AP)The Government has increased taxes on luxury items for the second time in three weeks.

title: Mrs. Laurie Salvatori Wed to E.R.O'Connell
description: Mrs. Laurie Salvatori, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Salvatori of Los Angeles, was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward Richard O'Connell of Glen Cove, L. I. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Suozzi performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Art
description: WITH the paintings of Alex Katz, we are never in any doubt about the kind of world the artist has chosen to portray. It is very explicitly our worldthe observable world of contemporary manners and styles, very young and uptodate in its easy sophistication, its movieculture look, and its air of untroubled sociability. It is a world in which the darker shades of feeling are, for the most part, unacknowledged. Friends and family abound, but each participant is given a mask designed to conceal his interior life. Like figures in a dance, we know them by theif gestures, their costumes, and their carefully rehearsed expressions. We are not invited to penetrate beyond an amiable and appealing surface.

title: The Best Christmas Present of All Is a Trip Out of Town
description: HERE is a subversive thought for the holiday season, You will be much, much merrier this Christmas if you take a trip instead of staving at home with your family, ??ecking the halls with boughs of holly, bestowing gifts on loved ones and doing all the traditional things that are supposed to make for family bliss.

title: Her Millions Support Arts in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Dec, 15 (AP) Her greatuncle, Edmond, was the financial father of Palestine. Her brother, Guy, and her cousins are among Israel's greatest benefactors. But Baroness Batsheva de Rothchild is the first member of the Jewish banking dynasty to make her home in Israel.

title: bear BBC, Leave the Russians Alone
description: THE BBC has marched into Tolstoy's War and Peace and made itself comfortable, rather as though the novel were a manor house. Every once in a while someone opens a window to let out the talk, and there is the Yugoslav army in the garden, knocking over hedges and retreating through flowerbeds. Pierre wears aviator goggles. Natasha wears kneesocks. My head harts. I don't know whether I am comparing what I see on public television with the novelhow many years ago did one read the novel?or with Audrey Hepburn.

title: Dr. F. G. Pettengill Weds Mrs. Parvin
description: In the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at noon yesterday, Mrs. Jessie McKenzie Parvin of New York, widow of William Rodman Parvin, became the bride of Dr. Frank Gordon Pettengill, an internist, of New York and New Castle, N. H.

title: Artistic Hands Design From Weeds to Wonder
description: NATURE has infinite shapes, forms and lines but so few of us take time to see them. Mrs. Faith Warner sees them. Her keen eye and appreciation transform autumn's seed pods, capsules, cones, pods and leaves into lovely design which are shown here. Her Connecticut home in Litchfield County is surrounded by open fields and woods which provide endless sources for material.

title: Adelphi Embroiled In Judicial Dispute
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  A controversy over student voice in the censure of facility members at Adelphi University appears to be dying down as slowly as it grew.

title: Hey There, What Happened?
description: NOT all of my thoughts during the genial, spirited but eventually thinnish revival of The Pajama Game were specifically about The Pajama Game, but they certainly stemmed from what was going on up on stage as well as in the auditorium. I pass them along as they come back to me now:

title: the traveler's world
description: CHAOS is come again, to borrow a phrase from Othello, but our chaos arises from an energy crisis about which no two people, even the best authorities, seem to agree, and this disagreement ??ncompasses the legitimacy of the crisis, its extent, and what to do, and how and when. The Great American MoTorist, blood kin of the Great American purist, is being assaulted from all sides with advice on how to comport himself and his car during the gasoline shortage. In an effort to sift chaff and wheat into separate heaps, I turned to my best source of automotive and engineering information, George J. Huebner Jr., direc??or of research for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: I Love the Theater, Man, But Those Prices
description: IT is a few minutes before 3 any afternoon of the week. The windows of the Times Square Theatre Centre, on Broadway opposite the Palace Theater, open on the hour and already there are 25 persons in line waiting to purchase tickets at half price for shows that night. The list of available attractions is posted on the orange signboard facing the windows and as the day wanes some titles come down, their supply of tickets exhausted, while others may be added as boxoffice treasurers around town gauge the scope of demand at their respective theaters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Knicks Topple Kings, 116107
description: Considering the strange contest yesterday afternoon in which the Knicks ran their winning streak to four games with a 116107 triumph over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, Dave DeBusschere observed:

title: Miss Schneider Is Bride of John Sanden
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Read Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Z. Schneider of Crisfield, Md., formerly of Summit, N. J., became the bride of John Howard Sanden, a widower. He Is a son of the late Rev. Dr. and Mrs. O. E. Sanden of Minneapolis.

title: MINE UNION HEADS SUFFER SETBACKS
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15The leadership of the United Mine Workers won support here this week for its contract proposals, but it suffered two important setbacks on issues that might shave strengthened union bargaining power.

title: New & Novel
description: I see Ernest Raymond as C. Aubrey Smith in the role of a retired vicar, narrating those milliondollar heart tuggers that MGM used to make before it went into the hotel business. This one was published in England in 1966, but its heart, bless it, belongs to 1931 and the age of lost innocence. Imagine Norry Kingharber (played by Ralph Forbes), scion of the nobility who comes to the Cumberland for a spot of mountain climbing. At Old Sledden Farm, where Norry bunks, he falls in love with the farmer's daughter, Greta Whinlake (early Loretta Young). The young man is no nambypam by. The Hayes office has not yet been born, but his attitude toward sex (the gift of Life) is exemplary: The joy of it for me but the even greater happiness of giving joy to her.

title: Liberated women's pet peeves
description: (1) Complimenting grown women by calling them girls (or gals).

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fifth Avenue will be closed to vehicular traffic between 34th and 57th Streets today from noon until 4 P.M. for a holiday promenade that will feature musical entertainment and sports demonstrations. Mayor Lindsay, in a walking tour, will visit the events to be staged along the avenue.

title: International Paper: A Reluctant Giant
description: A few days ago The Pickens County Progress, a weekly newspaper in Jasper, Ga., called the International Paper Company with a plea for help because it had been cut off from normal paper suppliers.

title: Ideas & Trends Law, Education, Religion
description: The Catholic Church in New York City recently turned to Madison Avenue with $100,000 for an advertising campaign to recruit priests, and the Trinitarian Fathers have put ads in Playboy magazine for the same purpose (and received 700 bona fide inquiries). The following story examines some of the church's problems.

title: Rube Goldberg
description: A generation (mine) was brought up with the conviction that Rube Goldberg, not necessity, was the mother of invention. Necessity as the inspiration for ingenious devices must have vanished in the 19th century at about the time an acute shortage of laundresses inspired the creation of the handcranked washing machine. Almost everything that has been created since then, including Goldberg himself, has been unnecessary, though some thingslike galoshes and comic strips and Goldberg have tended to make life more pleasant. The rest has been an attempt to gild the tarnished lily of civilization or little by little to destroy it.

title: Robert Walter Owen Will Wed Miss Margaret Ann Cheeseman
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 15  Richard Lewis Cheeseman, former chairman of the Virginia State Port Authority, and Mrs. Cheeseman of Alexandria and St. Mary's County, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Cheeseman, to Robert Walter Owen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter John Owen of Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Quiet joy
description: There was a time when electricity played no part in sparking Christmas excitementan era that merits a backward glance. To the earliest settlers in this country, Christmas was a day of religious observance, of churchgoing, even of business as usual. This aura of austerity persisted well into the early 19th century. Not until Queen Victoria and her Germanborn consort celebrated their royal Christmases with a tree bedecked with baubles in the German manner (and the custom was soon widely adopted here) did Christmas assume the major festive proportions it has today with trees trimmed, homes decorated and presents exchanged among family and friendsand business associates. For those who are interested in experiencing the quiet charm of older, less hectic Christmases, the little town of Odessa (population 500), Del., decorates its superb historic houses (two are properties of Winterthur Museum) as they might have been decorated in the 17th and 18th centuries and opens them to the public for one day in December. The two Winterthur houses and two private homes are shown here.

title: Dance
description: WE are delighted that the New York City Ballet is again performing that absolutely fabulous Christmas ballet called The Nutcracker after the strike by its dancers.

title: Queens Playhouse Is to Get $124,000
description: The odyssey of the Queens Playhouse moved into a new phase last week with the announcement that the city's Board of Estimate had approved a total of $124,000 in funding for the theater.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Striped Bass Endangered
description: When Al Reinfelder, the president of the Striped Bass Fund, drowned in a canoeing accident on the Delaware River last May some felt that without his leadership the organization would fail.

title: Reduction of Supervisors At Farah Plants Disclosed
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 15 (AP) A onethird cutback of supervisory personnel at the remaining five Farah Manufacturing Company plants here was an nounced yesterday. This was the latest in a series of moves related to reductions in sales brought about by a nationwide boycott of Farah products, the company said.

title: The Extraordinary I.T.T. Affair
description: WASHINGTONIt was April, 1971. Richard G. Kleindienst was Deputy Attorney General. The Government had three antitrust suits going against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. And President Nixon ordered Mr. Kleindienst not to appeal one of the suits to the Supreme Court. Why?

title: Officers Chosen to Guide U.N. Sea Conference in '74
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP)The United Nations Law of the Sea Conference has chosen officers to guide it next year in writing uptodate rules on navigation, territorial limits, fisheries, mining of the seabed and marine pollution.

title: Look for CopOuts on Prime Time, Not on Soaps
description: WHEN the soap operas were interrupted for coverage of the Watergate hearings, there was a great deal of hilarious TV commentmuch of it distinctly antifeminineabout all the poor souls who called the stations to complain. On NBC's 6 o'clock news, Jim Hartz smirked, Hundreds of calls of complaint were received, many apparently from women. There are a great many unemployed and underemployed people watching soap operas in this country, and by no means are all of them women. Further, interest in soap operas does not constitute proof of mental torpor.

title: Ferryboats for Sale as Bridge Goes Up
description: Want to buy a ferryboat? Early next month the Port Authority Ferry Corporation of Camden will put three 177foot Delaware River craft up for sale.

title: TEXAS JURY REARS OF BRIBE SCHEME
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 15A scheme to skim money from executives' salaries, to use in bribing elected officials to buy voting machines, was outlined yesterday to a trial jury in United States District Court here.

title: Fresh Air Fund Elects President
description: Frank S. Streeter, vice president and finance chairman of The Fresh Air Fund, has been elected president of the nonprofit youthservice organization, effective Jan. 8. He will succeed Blancke Noyes, president since 1968.

title: The World
description: In terms of comfort we shall have a harder Christmas than we have known since the war.

title: Miss Palacci Wed To Edward Bleier
description: Miss Magda Palacci was married here last evening to Edward Bleier, vice president in charge of network sales and programing for Warner Television, a division of Warner Communications. Rabbi Saul Teplitz performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom.

title: Bridge, Brooklyn
description: Most tournament players are accustomed to being approached by some total stranger and asked to listen to a hand. Sometimes the stranger genuinely wants advice on how he should have bid or played. More often he wants to unburden sad story or get support for his opinion that his partner was to blame for a disaster. And occasionally he is a con man, claiming credit for a winning line of play discovered in subsequent cerebration. He may even offer a famous coup or a doubledummy problem, the equivalent of selling the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Note the prevailing diction in The Guest Word of Nov. 18: carnage, wake, killing, flay, lurching to its grave, debloating, hideously, made a stab at, fat, doomed bailed out, rampant, toxic gruel, digest, jostled. Such gashes and guts, you would think the subject was not the end of Book World but the end of the world. Richard Kluger's lingo  currently in fashion and no worse than many other Times reviewers'  is lurid, tasteless and insane, like Batman. It is like that cavemantalk of the Daily News it pretends to be above. And Kluger wants us to be a civilized people!

title: Upsala FM Station Converts to Stereo
description: EAST ORANGEUpsala College's FM radio station, WFMU, has gone stereo as a result of a 10day appeal that produced $6,000 in cash contributions last spring.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1CHESTER HIGGINS

title: Cruising Is Very Much Alive
description: TO THE EDITOR: IAGREE generally with Stephen Farber and Estelle Changas who, in the Dec. 9 issue of the Arts and Leisure section, reported on the effects on Hollywood of the June 21, 1973 Supreme Court decision endorsing community standards for pornography, and who urged the movie industry to resist in various ways.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Iowa Picks Commings As Coach
description: IOWA CITY, Dec. 15 (AP)  Bob Commings, a high school coach at Massillon, Ohio, was given yesterday the task of reviving Iowa's lagging football fortunes.

title: Head of Store Chain Dies After Getting Award at Hotel Here
description: Mortimer L. Janis, the president of the Franklin Simon chain of readytowear apparel stores, collapsed at an award dinner in his behalf last night and died shortly thereafter, apparently of a heart attack. He was about 57 years old.

title: Collegiate Title Is Won By La. Tech.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif, Dec. 15 (AP)Wenford Wilborn, a cornerback, set up two Louisiana Tech touchdowns and the Bulldogs shut off Western Kentucky's offense today as Tech won the first national smallcollege championship with a 340 victory in the Camellia Bowl.

title: Yule Cheer Aided By Mickey Rooney
description: NEWARKMickey Rooney will he chairman of the Salvation Army's 1973 Christmas cheer program in New Jersey. He has taped spot announcements to be used by more than 25 radio stations throughout the state from now until Christmas Day.

title: Serpico, the Saint Francis Of Copdom
description: SIDNEY LUMET'S Serpico, the first in what threatens to be an avalanche of movies about policemen, picks up the old cop film and brings it with lights flashing and sirens blaring into the middle of the Watergate era. It is Lumet's toughest, most provocative film in years, the story of the New York City detective, Frank Serpico, who in 1970 blew the whistle on graft and corruption within the New York Police Department, leading to the Knapp Commission hearings and the biggest shakeup in the department's history.

title: Planners Are Asked For More Schools
description: When I was a kid, we got moved around every time a new school was built. My own three children went to three different elementary schools. Why is it that today everyone seems to insist that there's only one school they'll allow their children to attend?

title: GEN. COCHET, 85, LED FREE FRENCH STAFF
description: PERPIGNAN, France, Dec. 15 (AP)  Gen. Gabriel Cochet, chief of the general staff of the Londonbased Free French forces during World War II, died yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: Ill Children Aided By Tiny Tim Fund
description: VINELANDThree thousand carolers will make their annual Christmas appeal in this community Tuesday.

title: South Africa Clinches Zone Davis Cup Match
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 15 (AP)Frew McMillan and Bob Hewitt trounced Tom Koch and Edison Mandarino, 60, 60, 61, today to give South Africa an insurmountable lead over Brazil in a South American Zone Davis Cup tennis pairing.

title: Springsteen Celebrates Street Life
description: WHEN Bruce Springsteen's first Columbia album, Greetings From Asbury Park, came out almost a year ago, it was met with the most extravagant and outrageous praise I've ever encountered in the Rock Press. Reviewers compared him to Bob Dylan, The Band, Van Morrison, Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac, El Topo, Webster's New World Dictionary. If superlatives were a dime a dozen, Springsteen could have retired then and there.

title: The poetry of ropeskipping
description: One wouldn't suppose that so scholarly an activity as the collection of ropeskipping rhymes could be a lifeendangering occupation, but on a recent trip to Belfast, in a predominantly I.R.A. section, I learned that even children's chants can become a matter of life and death.

title: TV Review
description: The British television version of the stage musical Pickwick is infinitely better suited to hearth viewing than to Broadway, where that imported hit misfired here eight years ago. Tonight at 7, the 90minute British Broadcasting Corporation production, distributed by Time & Life Films, is being repeated here (after Saturday's debut) over Channel 5.

title: Cairo Feels Geneva Conference Is Now Under Auspices of U.N.
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16Egyptian officials today expressed satisfaction with the progress of preparations for the Middle East peace conference in Genieva.

title: Soccer Results
description: KNICKERBOCKER CUP

title: It's Going to Last
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16Professor Carroli L. Wilson of M.I.T. is a former general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission and a man with strong connections in the Government, business and academic communities. Last July he published in the magazine Foreign Affairs an article predicting a national energy emergency and suggesting ways to deal with it; some of the ideas and even the language turned up in President Nixon's energy speeches.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH MRS. MEIR ON GENEVA TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, Dec. 17Secretary of State Kissinger met into the early morning with Premier Golda Meir and other Israeli officials today to ease Israel's concern about the projected Middle East peace conference and to try to insure that the conference begins in Geneva next Friday.

title: Hackensack's Building Boom Slowing As New Luxury Units Remain Vacant
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 16Three more apartment houses are under construction here and at least three more are on the drawing boards, but some of the momentum seems to be going out of a building boom that has given Hackensack a new skyline.

title: G. D. Crain Jr. Dies at 88; Published Advertising Age
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16  G.D. Crain Jr., publisher of Advertising Age, which he founded in 1930, and other business journals, died yesterday in Evanston Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Del Bello Terms Waste Disposal a Major Westchester Problem
description: What does an incoming County Executive worry about on the eve of his inauguration? Well, garbage, for one thing, at least in Westchester.

title: Brezhnev's Visit to Cuba Postponed, Diplomats Say
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (Reuters) The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, has postponed his planned visit to Cuba, apparently to avoid damaging the improved relations between Moscow and Washington, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: OIL CRISIS CALLED OUTRAGE BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay last night called the world oil shortage an outrage caused by a handful of international conglomerates and sheiks and said that fears that it had created would hurt human freedom.

title: The Detente  Firsters
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16For about 5,000 years, Jews have been confronting each other and the rest of mankind with irritating moral questions. In that tradition, the two moral dilemmas of today's international affairs center on Jews:

title: Republican Strategists See Major 1974 Election Losses for G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Republican campaign planners are beginning to compare 1974 with 1958, when the G.O.P. suffered losses of 13 Senate seats, 47 House seats and five governorships.

title: Slow Time for Schools
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Superintendent Julius Truelson says Fort Worth public schools will not observe daylight saving time. He said classes would start one hour later, by the clock, when the new time takes effect Jan. 6. He said the decision was made so children would not have to wait in the dark for school buses.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Beatrice M. Judge told the police her chambers had been looted of $5,000 worth of antique jewelry, a .32caliber revolver, a desk radio, $12 worth of eightcent stamps and $2 in pennies. Justice Judge told the police that the burglary had occurred sometime between 1 P.M. Thursday and 5 P.M. Friday in her chambers on the 11th floor of the Supreme Court Building at 360 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn. The intruder also opened all of the filing cabinets in her offices.

title: Broncos Lose Passer and Western Title in Oakland, 2117
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 16 After dominating the first half and surviving some anxious moments in the second, the Oakland Raiders wrapped up their fifth division championship in six years by beating the Denver Broncos, 2117, today.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Films

title: Simpson Breaks Mark as Bills Rout Jets, 34 to 14
description: On a day that combined the happiest moments of O. J. Simpson's career and the most emotional of Weeb Ewbank's, the Buffalo Bills defeated the Jets yesterday, 3414, at Shea Stadium.

title: For Youngsters, It's Time Again to Dress Up and Be Taken to The Nutcracker
description: At least a couple of them were only two years old and a lot of them were three, four or five. They were clinging to mothers, grandmothers, aunts, sisters, fathers, or sometimes to both parents as they entered New York State Theater Saturday afternoon for that great childhood adventure of every Christmas seasonNew York City Ballet's production of The Nutcrackerand their little scrubbed faces were a study in expressions.

title: Washington Turns Back Eagles, 3820, for Wildcard Berth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16With his best game coming on the lastigame of the regular season, Larry Brown pulled the Washington Redskins into the National Football League playoffs today as he scored tour touchdowns in a 3820 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles on a slick, snowcovered field.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rangers Crushed By Hawks
description: The Chicago Black Hawks, riding a record unbeaten streak on the road, gave the New York Rangers a 61 mauling last night at Madison Square Garden. Extending their road string to 11 games (eight victories and three ties), the Black Hawks played good, sound hockey while the Rangers had a poor night.

title: Japan Sets Measures to Stern Deteriorating Payment Balance
description: TOKYO, Dec. 16 (Reuters)Japan announced today a series of measures designed to prevent a rapid deterioration of her balance of payments.

title: Half Fares: Glee Mixed With Gloom
description: It wasn't quite like hitting your number, but for the men, women and children who took advantage of yesterday's half fares on subways, buses and trains, the windfall was nice. For cab drivers, competing with the cutrate fares, it was not so nice.

title: Soviet Gives Partial Lunokhod Report
description: The Soviet Union has made public its first scientific report on the findings of its remotely controlled moon vehicle earlier this year, but without disclosing what caused the sudden end of its mission in May after four months of exploration.

title: Holiday Road Toll Estimate Reduced by Safety Council
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI)The National Safety Council said today that it had reduced by 50 its estimate on the number of people who will die from traffic accidents over the Christmas holiday. It attributed the reduction to lower speeds and the gasoline shortage.

title: Gifts to Neediest Aid the HelplessDisabled Children
description: New York's neediest poor are also its most helpless. They are the city's neglected, abused, homeless, handicapped and underprivileged children.

title: Knicks Take Streak of 4 On the Road
description: I'm in trouble, said Phil Jackson before the Knicks left yesterday on a sixday road trip. The center was talking about his Christmas shopping, not any problems on the basketball floor, a good indication of why the New Yorkers had a fourgame winning streak with Jackson handling the pivot duties.

title: Syria Delays Decision on Peace Parley
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 16Syria is holding off a final decision on taking part in the Middle East peace conference until she obtains clarification of Israeli intentions on several issues raised with Secretary of State Kissinger during his visit here yesterday.

title: Doar a Prospect for Impeachment Job
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16John M. Doar, who led the Government's drive against racial discrimination in the nineteensixties, is a leading candidate to direct the Congressional inquiry into President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: Hearing on Medical Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, will conduct a hearing tomorrow into what he described as seriout allegations by drug industry representatives who feel that lives could be lost or endangered by shortages of drugs and medical supplies due to the fuel crisis.

title: Books of The Times
description: A CROWN OF FEATHERS. By Isaac Busheyla Singer. 342 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $8.95.

title: Detroit Judge Bars Strike Of Markets by Teamsters,
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UPI)A Federal court injunction three hours before a strike deadline forced the Teamsters to postpone a strike against Detroit area supermarkets that had been scheduled for midnight.

title: Kidnapping Wave in Italy Spurs Bodyguard Business
description: ROME, Dec. 16 The bodyguard business is suddenly thriving in the wake of recent kidnappings here.

title: Theater: 12Hour Stalin
description: Twelve hours is a long time for a play to play, and at 7 A.M. yesterday morning there were many bleary eyes and perhaps a few bleary hearts when Robert Wilson's The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin ended precisely on schedule. It had started a brief lifetime at 7 P.M. Saturday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Football Riot in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 (Reuters)A girl was shot dead and 100 people were injured when rioting flared after a football game here last night, according to reports by emergency services. An official statement, however, said the trouble was only a fight between students, with four young people slightly injured.

title: Common Market for Energy Shaping
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec, 16Reacting once again to a foreign threat, the countries of the European Economic Community havejust drawn closer together and decided that only through unity can they ensure the survival of the civilization which they have in common.

title: WEEKLY LOTTERY WILL ADD PRIZES
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP)New Jersey's weekly lottery will be revamped in the new year to provide more chances for winning and more cash.

title: Audrey de Jonge Wed
description: TEANECK, N. J., Dec. 16Miss Audrey Frances de Jonge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curt E. de Jonge of Tenafly, was married here this afternoon to Mark Andrew Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Greene of New York. Rabbi Louis Sigel performed the ceremony at Temple Emeth. Cantor Kurt Silbermann assisted.

title: Bronx Man Found Dead on the Street, Shot by a Mugger
description: A Post Office custodian who had been on his way to work overtime during the Christmas rush was found dead in the Melrose section of the Bronx yesterday, apparently of a gunshot wound in the head.

title: Red Smith
description: When you have walked into a buzzsaw it's hard to tell which tooth bit you first. Earnie Shavers didn't use those words, but that's what he was saying after being stuck back together again Friday night. He knew Jerry Quarry had taken him apart in the first round, but there was no way he could tell which punch started him on his wobbly way down Queer Street. It was just one of those things, he said. The mistakes you make.

title: RENTS TO GO UP AT STUYVESANT
description: The 20,000 tenants of Stuyvesant Town have received notice from the owner of the Manhattan housing project that rents will be increased by $45 to $100 a month when a 25yearold taxrelief agreement with the city expires next June 30.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MERCERVILLE, Dec. 14There's an old joke college coaches like to tell on themselves at the start of the season. Question: Coach, of all your returnees, who are you happiest to have back? Answer: Me.

title: ARMS UNIT FIGHTS ANEW NERVE GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is challenging the Army's plan for production of a new type of nerve gas on the ground that it is militarily unnecessary and would complicate international attempts to control chemical warfare.

title: CLAUDE ALEXANDER OF ESSO FOUNDATION
description: Claude L. Alexander, who retired in 1959 as executive secretary of the Esso Foundation after 20 years as secretary of the corporate contributions and memberships committee of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died Friday in Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been living. He was 75 years old.

title: Oilers Top Knights on Rally, 76
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Dec. 16 (AP)Thirdperiod goals by Jim Harrison and Ross Perkins capped an Edmonton rally today as the Oilers edged the Jersey Knights, 76, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Berchtold Is Victor in Cup Skiing
description: VIENNA, Dec. 16 (AP)Hubert Berchtold, a 23yearold mechanic, raced to his first victory in a World Cup ski event today, leading an Austrian sweep of the first four places in the giant slalom.

title: Youths at Jennings Hall Are Given a Free Concert
description: A twohour free concert was presented yesterday at Jennings Hall, a temporary city shelter for boys, because the producer of the concert wanted to do something for the kids.

title: The Freedom to Leave
description: MOSCOWAbout two months have passed since the Soviet Union ratified the International Covenants of Human Rights guaranteeing the right of citizens to freely leave any country, including their own, and return. All powers, large and small, ought to implement these covenants.

title: Beame Will Name Lazar And Elinor Guggenheimer
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame will announce the appointment today of Elinor C. Guggenheimer, former member of the City Planning Commission, as his consumer affairs commissioner, and Michael J. Lazar, who is chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, as Transportation Administrator, it was learned last night.

title: Personal Finance
description: Thousands of labor union members in various parts of the country today get legal care benefits on the jobprepaid legal aid serices packaged somewhat like Blue Cross. Now, under a bill expected to be introduced in Albany by State Senator John R. Dunne, Republican of Nassau, New Yorkers may soon be able to get similar legal help.

title: TRUCKERS CALL OFF PROTEST IN 2 STATES
description: Truckers in Ohio and West Virginia ended their blockade A truck stop fuel pumps yesterday, and one of the drivers said the protest had just about lost all its steam.

title: Helpern Accuses Aide of Trying To Discredit Him by Deception
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, accused one of his deputies yesterday of giving misleading information about morgue cases in an attempt to discredit Dr. Helpern and obtain his job.

title: Unity Against Aggression
description: The Copenhagen summit meeting of the nine nations of the European Community was designed primarily to advance West European integration, but its effects on Soviet policy may ultimately prove of equal importance.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Carlo Bonomi, a 32yearold Italian banker, has been named winner of the Sam Griffith Memorial Trophy, embelmatic of the world offshore powerboat racing championship. The Milan racer amassed a total of 62 points in eight of the 21 races on the 1973 offshore schedule approved by the Union of International Motorboating. His closest competition came from Don Shead of England, with 39 points.

title: If the Lights Are Out You Have to Be Bright
description: A Christmas tree without lights?Not so unthinkable when you think about it. There are multitudes of ways you can do an appealing tree without strings of bulbs, say floral designers, decorators, artists and display people. After all, on a goodsized tree all those bulbs can add up to about 500 watts.

title: Power of the Purse
description: Congress in its collective wisdom decided last year and again this year to appropriate funds for the construction of needed water and sewer systems in rural areas. The executive branch decided that the program was unnecessary and impounded the money.

title: Stage: Aimee, a Musical
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 16 With her flamboyant theatricality and her tremendous emotional conflictsshe apparently had the same passion for sex as for evangelism Aimee Semple McPherson is a terrific subject for a musical.

title: Paper Urges Nixon to Quit
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Dec, 16 (AP)The San Antonio Express and News, which supported President Nixon in his reelection bid, said In an editorial today that President Nixon should resign. The paper said that if Mr. Nixon does not resign, then he must be impeached.

title: Major Bills in Congress
CHRYSLER PREDICTS 10% CARSALE DROP
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16Lynn A. Townsend, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, forcastled a drop of 10 per cent in United States car sales in 1974.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE
description: To forecast or not to forecast. That is the question that divides companies, industries and business thinkers around the nation, and never has the division been deeper.

title: $111,700 Stakes To Money Lender
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) Hazel Longden's Money Lender held off a closing charge by Printo today to win the $111,700 California Juvenile Stakes at Bay Meadows by a length.

title: CITY AIDES WORRIED ABOUT FUEL DELIVERY
description: City officials have expressed concern about the city's ability to make emergency fuel, deliveries to apartment buildings on a widescale basis beyond the middle of January.

title: Skiers in Car Pools Welcome First Snow
description: Skiers and skiresort operators welcomed the season's first snowfall yesterday, and the longdelayed skiing season got under way.

title: India's Journalists Worry They Have Become Timid and Dependent on the Government
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14  The Indian press, one of the liveliest and freest in Asia, is undertaking a somber appraisal of its role, methods and future.

title: RALPH W. GUILD
description: RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Dec. 16Ralph W. Guild, a senior vice president of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter & Hamilton, Inc., a New York real estate firm, and a specialist in the management of luxury cooperative apartment houses, died yesterday at his home here, after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In New York City, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's transition committee told him that he could expect projected $1.3billion gap in the city's expense budget for the fiscal year that begins next July 1.

title: Prospect for Britons Is Most Uncertain Since Early Years of War
description: LONDON, Dec. 16  Britons begin this week in a more wretched state of uncertainty about their immediate futurelet alone their longterm prospepts  than at any time since the Germans seemed to be winping the war back in 1940.

title: OTHERS ACCOSTED AT SLAYING SCENE
description: In the wake of a slaying on East 89th Street in the Yorkville sectionthe result of an apparent mugging at gunpoint police detectives said yesterday that they knew of at least three other armed robberies of residents of the same block, between Park and Lexington Avenues, in the last two months.

title: Tho Gets Soviet Assurance
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (Reuters) The Soviet Union assured Le Duc Tho of invariable support for Hanoi's policies here today, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. Mr. Tho, a member of Hanoi's Politburo, arrived Pelting on his way to Paris for talks Thursday with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: TAX DEDUCTION AID IN NIXON GIFT DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)Gerald L. Warren, the deputy White House press secretary, denied today that President Nixon had any plans to take advantage of a potential tax deduction on the gift of his home in San Clemente, Calif., to the Government.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: CAPETOWN, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Josephus Olivier, 46 years old, died here yesterday, 13 days after receiving a transplanted heart, the Groote Sebum Hospital announced today. Mr. Olivier had been given the heart in a sixhour operation led by the heart transplant pioneer, Dr. Christiaan an Barnard.

title: FORD SAID TO PLAN 2 NEW SMALL CARS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) The Ford Motor Company plans to introduce two new compact auto models next fall in an attempt to widen its lead in domestic small car sales. The Detroit News reported today.

title: Bridge: Rubin's Team Leads Way Into Reisinger Play Finals
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 16 A foursome headed by Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J., led the field of 15 teams into the final session of the Reisinger open teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: New Consumer Peril: Abandoned Supermarket Shopping Carts
description: PLAINFIELD, Dec. 16The shopping cart is increasingly becoming a nuisance to consumers, supermarkets and municipal officials alike.

title: Queens Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 38yearold woman was killed yesterday and four persons were slightly injured in a onealarm blaze in Queens Village, the Fire Department reported. Officials said firemen found the woman, Lucille Moore, dead in her 1story home at 20521 113th Road. Four tenants, including a 4yearold girl, were treated at Queens General Hospital for smoke inhalation and minor injuries.

title: Indefinite Closing Is Set For West Side Highway
description: The West Side Highway will be closed indefinitely in both directions below 18th Street as a result of the collapse of a portion of the northbound section near Little West 12th Street on Saturday.

title: The Screen: 'Papillon':Escapist Film Stars McQueen, Hoffman
description: "Papillon," Franklin J. Schaffner's film version of the late Henri Charrire's book about his adventures in various penal colonies in French Guiana, is a big, brave, stouthearted, sometimes romantic, sometimes silly melodrama with the kind of visual sweep you don't often find in movies anymore.Mr. Schaffner, the director of "Patton" and "Nicholas and Alexandra," looks to be the last of the big-time spenders. When he decides to show us a cargo ship steaming into a Caribbean port, that's what we see, in one magnificent long shot that includes the ship, the quay, the river, the jungles on the other side of the river and the sea in the distance."Papillon," which opened yesterday at Loews State I, the Cine and the Tower East Theaters, is full of such long shots, some of great beauty and all of obvious expense.Though they aren't always necessary and though they give you the feeling the film was shot mostly from a Goodyear blimp, they recall an old-fashioned narrative style to which I'm partial, the kind that seeks to authenticate character and event by telling us a lot more about geography, climate weather, plant life and architecture than we absolutely need know.The movie equivalent is the long shot. It fills the screen with information designed to convince us that because the setting is real, so must be the people in it. "Papillon" desperately needs this sort of support because the Dalton Trumbo and Lorenzo Semple Jr. screenplay, like the book, defines its characters less in terms of what they feel or think than in terms of extravagant incidents and superhuman heroics."Papillon," the French word for butterfly, which was Charrire's nickname in the Paris underworld, is presented as an honorable safecracker dishonorably framed for the murder of a smalltime pimp and thus sentenced to life in the penal colony in 1931. As played by Steve McQueen, Papillon is as all-American as a Rover Boy. He is manly, alert, self-reliant, deeply imbued with a sense of fair play. His love of freedom is so great that he must attempt the impossible, that is, to escape from Devil's Island.His best friend is Louis Dega (Dustin Hoffman), convicted for counterfeiting government bonds, a fastidious, fussy man with bad eyesight and enough money to buy Papillon as his prison bodyguard. Hoffman is not especially convincing as a French counterfeiter, but he is fun to watch as an intelligent character as written.There are dozens of other characters in the story, all more or less obligatory to a Devil's Island adventurethe cruel guard, the doomed prisoner (he prefers death to incarceration), the philosophical doctor, the perverted trustee (in other films he's sometimes presented as a male nurse). The horrors of prison life are graphically shown (including a decapitation that results in blood spurting onto the lens of the camera), cockroaches eaten to supplement the prison diet, storms at sea and a hand-to-hand encounter with a crocodile.My tolerance for this kind of make-believe is fairly high. I like hairbreadth escapes and survivals against all odds, but I must admit that about three-quarters of the way through the two and a half hour of "Papillon" my tolerance was sorely tested.It happened when Papillon is befriended by a tribe of Central American Indians presided over by Chief Victor Jory. They inhabit what looks to be the West Indies' newest and most chic island resort and cabana colony and, to be hospitable, present him with his very own Dorothy Lamour, a maiden named Zoraima who is played by Ratna Assan.This finally establishes "Papillon" as the sort of movie Hollywood supposedly doesn't make any more. Though its native girls go topless and the production budget was huge, "Papillon" is the escapist movie we used to go see on Saturday night without even bothering to read the marquee.

description: The West Side Highway will be closed indefinitely in both directions below 18th Street as a result of the collapse of a portion of the northbound section near Little West 12th Street on Saturday.

title: Judith Pilchik Bride Of Richard Zucker
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Dec. 16The marriage of Miss Judith Pilchik, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Ely E. Pilchik of West Orange, to Richard L. Zucker, son of Saul J. Zucker of South Orange and the late Mrs. Zucker, took place here this afternoon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun.

title: Photographer Dies in Crash
description: BREWSTER, N. Y., Dec. 16Mrs. Marian Stephenson Patmore, 77 years old, a fashion photographer of 200 East 62d Street in New York, died last night in an auto collision near here. Her husband, Graham Patmore, 81, a lumberman, and Thomas Forkin, 52, of New York were injured and were taken to the Putnam Community Hospital in Carmel.

title: SECURITY TAPPING MAY BE EXAMINED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16A new national commission that was created to review Federal and state wiretapping practices is expected to begin looking into the Nixon Administration's use of socalled national security wiretaps, some of which have become a focal point of the Watergate scandals.

description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that public response to its first halffare Sunday on buses, subways and commuter railroads yesterday was encouraging despite the snowy weather.

description: MOUNT POSPECT, Ill., Dec. 16  For Bunny Orkin, the President's recent plea to keep automobile speeds down to 50 miles an hour is one of the year's larger chuckles.

description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1973

title: MinorityOwned Banks Up 3Fold in 10 Years
description: The number of minorityowned banks in the United States has more than tripled in the last 10 years, and it is expected to continue to rise rapidly, the Conference Board reported in an analysis published today.

description: A member of the 1972 United States Olympic basketball team and a staff member of Governor Rockefeller's Commission on Critical Choices were among 32 winners of Rhodes Scholarships, disclosed yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Only 27 per cent of New York City residents who hold jobs drive cars to work, a far smaller percentage than in any other major metropolitan area, according to a Census Bureau study of commuting habits.

description: The first snow of the season, more bluster than substance, fell across the metropolitan area yesterday, leaving a light white glaze on city streets and highways.

description: MADRID, Dec. 16 (AP)The Soviet grandmaster Anatoly Karpov has been chosen world's best chess player of 1973, organizers of the Eighth International Madrid Chess Tournament announced today.

description: Unsold magazines, or returns, have always meant an income loss to publishers. But with development of the paper shortage, the paper waste alone has become as important as the lack of sales.

description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 16with national elections only 15 days away, Israelis appear too preoccupied with the lifeanddeath issues of national policy to pay much heed to politics.

title: London: New Role for Olivier: Center of a Theater Dispute
description: LONDONThe Party, a new play by Trevor Griffiths, will open next week at the National Theater. It deals with the notion of revolution in Britain. A miserable Christmas is coming up here with strikes, meager coal, meager gasoline, meager electricity, abysmal economic forecasts and a lot of political shouting. So the subject is popular, if only wishfully. Even now, without much advance publicity, the play is sold out. When it does open and the reviews appear, they will be like those securities announcements that bear a notice at the bottom to the effect that the big banks have already brought up all the shares.

title: U.S. Adding to Safeguards In Tactical Nuclear Arms
description: The United States has begun a program to equip its tens of thousands of tactical nuclear weapons, maintained in many foreign countries, with advanced electronic controls designed to prevent their misuse even if terrorists or hostile armies overrun an overseas base.

title: The Administration vs. How the Tide Turned
description: The Nixon Administration's Campaign to subdue the television networks, dating from the early part of the President's first term, effectively came to an end late in October, observers in both Washington and New York believe, when secret memorandums on communications strategy surfaced among the Watergate documents.

title: About New York
description: Some people who once worked for The Herald Tribune held a reunion in their old bar on West 40th Street the other night. They drank whisky and carried on, and sometimes they argued. Mostly they argued about when it was that their paper had actually died.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Rockefeller Warnings on Oil Recalled
description: At least a year ago, Governor Rockefeller was warning at private luncheons that there could come a day when the Arab states might subject the West to a disastrous oil embargo. One of those listening recalls having a doubting, puzzled feeling, and the thought that perhaps Mr. Rockefeller was speaking from exaggerated self  interest because the Rockefeller fortune is based in part on oil. But the embargo came to pass.

title: City Police Get in the Spirit In Operation Santa Claus
description: Two tourists from Argentina spotted a sidewalk Santa outside Macy's at the corner of Broadway and 34th Street the other day and asked him to pose for a photograph with them.

title: PROGRESS IS SEEN IN HEALTH REFORM
description: The agreement by House and Senate conferees on a bill to finance health maintenance organizations as an alternative form of health services is seen by the concept's originators as a first step in reforming the health delivery system, although no such overall reform; has been legislated.

title: DAVID LAINE
description: David Laine, secretary of the American Die Casting Institute since 1944, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home, 116 Central Park South. He was 67 years old.

title: Explorer Satellite Orbited To Study Theromosphere
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP)A satellite tough enough to withstand atmospheric friction has been plaed in orbit to make the first thorough study of the thermospherethe atmospheric layer from 72 to 120 miles above the earth.

description: The New York Stock Exchange, in breaking new ground on public disclosure, wants some of its listed companies to include market information about their securities in annual reports.

description: The college basketball scene had something for everybody Saturday:

title: Impeachment of Nixon Urged at Reenactment of Boston Tea Party
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16Thousands rallied here today for the impeachment of President Nixon at an official Bicentennial reenactment of the Boston Tea Party.

title: 27 PER CENT HERE DRIVE TO WORK, STUDY DISCLOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Only 27 per cent of workers who live in the metropolitan area comprising New York City, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties drove to and from work in 1970, a far smaller percentage than in any other metropolitan area, according to a Census Bureau study of commuting habits.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH MRS. MEIR ON GENEVA TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, Dec. 17Secretary of State Kissinger met into the early morning with Premier Golda Meir and other Israeli officials to day to ease Israel's concern about the projected Middle East peace conference and to try to insure that the conference be gins in Geneva next Friday.

title: 400 Catholics Demonstrate For Democracy in Seoul
description: SEAUL, South Korea, Dec. 16 (AP)Some 400 Roman Catholics who had just attended mass demonstrated today in Seoul's downtown shopping district, demending democratic reforms and denouncing what they called economic subjugation by Japan.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, praised today the public's response to the Administration's energy programs, but he said Americans must still change their wasteful ways.

title: The Nixon Haters
description: Suppose Mr. Nixon were guilty of everything he is accused of Money was collected illegally from corporatons that expected favors in return. He encouraged assistants to find out who leaked Government secrets, or to improve his electoral fortunes, by committing burglaries, tapping wires, preparing silly enemy lists or trying to get the I.R.S. to audit the tax returns of enemies. Suppose that Mr. Nixon tried afterwards to sweep these things under the rug. And that, contrary to promises, he fired a prosecutor who became too inconvenient and that some foughtover tapes disappeared. Finally, suppose he borrowed money to buy residences in California and Florida, made profits and found ways to reduce his tax liability, and to have excessive public funds spent for his residences.Some of these accusations involve no wrongdoing; others seem trivial; many seem plausible; none have been proven. But suppose they were true. Should they determine our judgment of his Presidency?

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Thirtyone members of a group demonstrating in Elizabeth for the impeachment of President Nixon were arrested after a clash with the police. They are scheduled to be arraigned today in Municipal Court on disorderlyperson charges. Seven persons, including three policemen, were injured in the clash, none seriously.

title: Looming Food Shortages Increase Britain's Woes
description: LONDON, Dec. 16Food shortages are now expected in Britain in the new year because of the threeday work week the Government has ordered to cope with the energy crisis.

title: BONUS DAY PRECEDES AUTO PLANT LAYOFFS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UPI)More than 200,000 automobile workers got a bonus holiday today before being laid off as a result of declining sales of large model cars.

title: Services for Navy Crewmen
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 16 (UPI)Memorial services were held today at Sand Point Naval Air Station in Seattle and at Whidbey Island Naval Air Station north of here for 10 crewmen killed recently in an airplane crash on Alaska's Great Sitkin Island.

title: Soviet Farm Reform Could Eliminate Collectives
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16  The Soviet Union, after a record grain harvest, indicated today that it was ready to push ahead with agricultural consolidation that could, in time, bring an end to that classic Soviet institutionthe collective farm.

title: Fire Kills Five Children
description: MAXTON, N.C., Dec. 16 (AP) Five children died early today when fire destroyed three houses on the outskirts of this town of 1,800. The victims, children and granchildren of Lewbertha Jones, were Jaamar L. Jones, 3 years old; Checo S. Jones, 2; Tywana Y. Jones, 2; Carla Denise Malloy, 6; and Mark Terell Malloy, 4.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GREETINGS The name of this new midday production is Star, and although it is show business, it's not about show business. It's about Christmas, and it's an unusual, oddly moving short work with some sophisticated music and some simple philosophy, a spaceage version of the Nativity story.

title: Mateer Wins U.S. Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16Gil Mateer of Penn defeated Tom Page of Episcopal Academy of Philadelphia, 1716, 1115, 1015, 1514, 1715, today for the national junior squash racquets title. In the boys final, Mario Sanchez of Mexico beat Todd Bins of Toronto, 1512, 158, 158.

title: 3 in Crew and 5 Residents Killed as Cargo Plane Crashes Into Homes Near Miami Airport
description: MIAMI, Dec. 16 (AP) cargo plane carrying Christmas trees has brought tragedy to a Miami neighborhood, leaving eight persons dead, including three members of a family that fled from Cuba four years ago.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
Nets Win by 129109 as Paultz Stars
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 16  Billy Paultz tallied 26 points, 19 in the second half, and picked up a game high of 16 rebounds, 13 off the defensive boards, to lead the New York Nets to a 129109 victory over the Utah Stars before a crowd of 6,043 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Nets Beat Stars,129.109, As Paultz Sparks Attack
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 16  Billy Paultz tallied 26 points, 19 in the second half, and picked up, a game high of 16 rebounds, 13 off the defensive boards, to lead the New York Nets to a 129109 victory over the Utah Stars before a crowd of 6,043 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Unlocked Treasury Door
description: The Senate, following the lead of the House, has approved legislation to preserve essential railroad transportation in the Northeast. This rescue mission for the bankrupt rail systems that now serve the region will almost certainly forestall judicial orders for dismantlement of the systems a disaster the country could not contemplate even if the energy crisis had not made freight and passenger service more vital than ever.

title: Garrison Is Defeated in Democratic Primary for New Orleans District Attorney
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16Jim Garrison's luck ran out yesterday. He was defeated for a fourth term as district attorney in the Democratic primary. It was one of the closest election contests in the city's history.

title: Bengals and Cowboys Clinch Titles
description: Ken Anderson hit his star wide receiver, Isaac Curtis, for touchdowns twice yesterday as the Cincinnati Bengals defeated the Houston Oilers, 2724, in the Astodome and wrapped up the American Football Conference Central Division title. For their efforts, the Bengals gained the dubious honor of meeting the National Football League's defending champion, the Miami Dolphins, next Sunday at Miami.

title: JERSEY LOTTERY WILL ADD PRIZES
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP)New Jersey's weekly lottery will be revamped in the new year to provide more chances for winning and more cash.

title: Levitt Charges City Paid $5.2Million To Relief Ineligibles
description: The state estimated yesterday that the city had overpaid $5.2million in 11,125 cases in the last fiscal year to persons who should have been removed from welfare family rolls on reaching the age of 18.

title: Light on Kent State
description: The judicial actions in the wake of the disorders at Kent State University in 1970 had the appearance of a coverup rather than an effort to get to the bottom of the events that culminated in the death of four students and the wounding of nine others. The doubts and suspicions and, most important, the outrage and anxieties of the victims' aggrieved familiesare at long last to be given a credible hearing when the issues of that American tragedy go to a Federal grand jury in Cleveland.

title: VIETNAM SLAYING PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16For the first time since the Vietnam ceasefire accord was signed last January, the United States today protested to the International Commission of Control and Supervision.

title: Berchtold Takes Cup Ski Event
description: VIENNA, Dec. 16 (AP) Hubert Berchtold, a 23yearold mechanic, raced to his first victory in a World Cup ski event today, leading an Austrian sweep of the first four places in the giant slalom.

title: Panel Urges Improvement Of TroubledChild Care
