description: The children's policy committee of the State Judicial Conference yesterday decried the myth that any program operated by a private agency is automatically better than one run by a government agency.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: $1.3Billion Budget Deficit Foreseen by Beanie's Staff
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's advisers told him yesterday that there was a projected $1.3billion gap in the city's basic operating budget in the fiscal year that will begin next July 1.

title: Kings Win On Basket By Walker
description: KANSAS CITYS, Dec. 16 (UPI)A baseline jump shot by Jimmy Walker at the buzzer gave the Kansas CityOmaha Kings a 105104 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Increases in Rates and Volume Cited in Turnaround
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, in what represents a striking turnabout in their fortunes from a large deficit earlier this year, are expected to show a slight aggregate profit for 1973.

title: Susan Rockoff Married to Fredric Bear
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Dec. 16Miss Susan Lynn Rockoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin J. Rockoff of North Brunswick, was married here this afternoon to Frederic S. Bear, publicrelations director of the Fresh Air Fund of New York City, His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Moses Bear of Los Angeles. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Yaacov Hilsenrath at the Highland Park Conservative Temple.

title: U.S. Adding to Safeguards Tactical Nuclear Arms
description: The United States has begun a program to equip its tens of thousands of tactical nuclear weapons, maintained in many foreign countries, with advanced electronic controls designed to prevent their misuse even if terrorists or hostile armies overrun an overseas base.

title: Dr. Thomas Morrissey, 73, Urological Surgeon, Is Dead
description: Dr. Thomas A. Morrissey, former chief of urological surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery and St. John's Queens Hospital, died here Saturday at the age of 73. He lived at 176 East 64th Street.

title: Mortimer L. Janis Is Dead at 57; Headed Franklin Simon Stores
description: Mortimer L. Janis, president of the Franklin Simon chain of apparel stores, a division of the City Stores Company, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack, in Bellevue Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

title: Kidnapping Wave in Italy Spurs Bodyguard Business
description: ROME, Dec. 16  The bodyguard business is suddenly thriving in the wake of recent kidnappings here,

title: Season's First Snow Puts A Snarly Frosting on City
description: The first snow of the season, more bluster than substance, fell across the metropolitan area yesterday, leaving a light white laze on city streets and highways.

title: Miss Dugdale Is Wed on L.I.
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Dec. 16  Miss Elizabeth Anne Dugdale, a teacher at the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School in New York, was married here this afternoon to Mark Robert Murray, general manager of M. C. Murray Interiors, Inc., New York furniture distributors, of which his grandfather, M. C. Murray, is president.

title: Panov Fate Imperiling Kirov Tour
description: The unwillingness of the Soviet Union to allow Valery Panov, former principal dancer with the Kirov Ballet Company, and his wife, Gaiina, to leave the Soviet Union has placed the entire 1974 American tour of the group in jeopardy, according to officials of New York's City Center.

title: Thomas Conducts Bostonians in BrahmsSchoenberg
description: Michael Tilson Thomas came up with an attractive program Idea for the Boston Symphony Orchestra concert he conducted at Carnegie Hall on Saturday. It consisted of Arnold Schoenberg's orchestral arrangement of Brahms's Piano Quartet in G minor and Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 2.

title: Agriculture Nears Collapse in Newly Industrial Italy
description: ROME, Dec. 16In the span of only a generation Italy has changed from a predominantly rural society into one of the world's 10 most industrialized countriesand now the nation fears a collapse of its agriculture.

title: The Tumult in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16 When President Park Chung Hee announced early this month he was replacing the widely feared head of his Central Intelligence Agency and relaxing its surveillance of schools, churches and the press, the South Korean Government hoped this would mollify criticism that it had become too authoritarian.

title: The Gentleman Jolter
description: O. J. Simpson didn't run alone and in his finest hour yesterday he didn't take a bow alone. When he arrived among the notebooks, cameras and taperecorders underneath Shea Stadium, after having set a National Football League season record of 2,003 yards, he had the 10 other members of the Buffalo Bills' offensive unit with him. I want to introduce, he said, the cats who did the job all year. One by one, he identified each with a personal touch. When he was asked later if someone would eventually surpass his record, he smiled.

title: Fire Destroys Bus Garages
description: HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., Dec. 16Fire destroyed garages of the Haverstraw Transit Lines on lower West Street tonight. The line provides local transportation in a large part of Rockland County. Apparatus and men were called in from the villages of West Haverstraw, Stony Point, Garnerville, Thields, Congers, New City and Rockland Lake to fight the blaze.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Among the various feminist viewpoints reported in The Woman Cooks, the Man Carves . . . Right? Wrong! [news article Nov. 22] was one (churches and synagogues could have potluck suppers for Thanksgiving) which typifies the sad slide toward viewing the family as unimportant in society. As I see it, a loving family and a warm, secure home is vital for human happiness.

title: MAXWELL ALEXANDER
description: Maxwell M. Alexander, executive director of the Association of Private Camps since 1956, died Saturday night at his home, 245 East 63d Street. His age was 67.

title: Scuttling Land Reform
description: The Bureau of Land Management is littleknown to the general public but it supervises far more of the public lands than do the better known Park. Service and Forest Service. This obscurity has helped to keep the B.L.M., an Interior Department agency, underfinanced, inadequately staffed and slow to adopt modern management practices. From year to year, it goes on renting large tracts to sheepmen and cattlemen for grazing purposes and ignoring many of its other responsibilities.

title: No One Laughs Now at French Bugging Scandal
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  It began, like Watergate, as a caperthe entire country laughing at a botched breakin, bugging, the miscreants caught in the act on the enemy's turf. Now it is not so silly.

title: Energy Woes Curb Detroit Retail Gains
description: DETROIT  If Detroiters are taking the energy pinch seriously, it is not evident from the bumpertobumper traffic. But when it comes to retail sales, it is another matter, for business at most of the city's big store's has slipped since the news of the energy crisis worsened.

title: Islanders Lose, 40, To Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP)Bernie Parent turned away 25 shots and picked un his seventh shutout of the season as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the New York Islanders, 40, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: 2 Dead in a Fire Laid To the Use of Candles
description: KEYPORT, Dec. 16Two persons in an apartment lighted by candles in what officials said might have been an effort to conserve electricity, were killed yesterday when a candle fell from table and started a fire.

title: Ilene Sharon Tanner Is Married
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 16 Miss Ilene Sharon Tanner, daughter of Mrs. Al M. Gordon of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Lester W. Tanner, was married here at noon to James Landau Rothernberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rothenberg of New York.

title: Gas in a Can Proves Death Trap for Driver
description: A Connecticut drivel who stored a threegallon can of gasoline in the front of his car to counter GaslessSunday restrictions was burned to death in minutes yesterday when the car crashed into a guard rail on the Merritt Parkway and the can exploded.

title: Miss Costello Is Bride Of Bernard Rostanski
description: Miss Marjorie Ann Costello and Bernard J. Rostanski were married yesterday afternoon at the International Synagogue at John F. Kennedy International Airport in Jamaica, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Eugene J. Cohen.

title: Students' Latest Support for Israel Buoys B'nai B'rith
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The reaction of American Jewish college students during the latest Mideast waran outpouring of activist support for Israel that astonished Jewish communal leaders by its intensityhas demolished the myth of a generation lost to Judaism, the B'nai B'rith Hiller Foundations said today.

title: Israel to Rename Airport
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Government said today that it would rename Israel's sole international airport after the country's first Premier, David. BenGurion, who died this month. No date was given for the redesignation of Lydda International Airport.

title: Thai Assembly Is Dissolved To Allow a New Parliament
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 16 (AP)  King Phumiphol Aduldet dissolved the National Assembly today to pave the way for the election of a new Parliament by a national convention.

title: Looming Food Shortages Increase Britain's Woes
description: LONDON, Dec. 16Food shortages are now expected in Britain in the new year because of the threeday workweek the Government has ordered to cope with the energy crisis.

title: ProArab Spain Learns With Distress She Won't Escape Oil Crisis
description: MADRID, Dec. 16  A few weeks ago the Spanish were patting themselves on the back because they were such good friends of the Arabs and were therefore sheltered from oil restrictions and all their consequences.

title: Between Jew and Arab
description: Following is an excerpt from an open letter that Martin Buber in 1939 wrote to Mohandas K. Gandhi, who had questioned the validity of the Jewish claim to Palestine.

title: Jewish Group Lauds Meany At WaldorfAstoria Dinner
description: George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, received the American Jewish Committee Democratic Heritage Award at a dinner last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Kissinger at Memorial To Victims of Germans
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17Secretary of State Kissinger ended his visit here on a poignant note today in a driving, cold rain. At a ceremony at the hillside memorial to the six million Jews killed by the Germans, he listened with bowed head while a cantor standing by the eternal flame sang a chant of mourning.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Dec. 18, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Usual Business (for 5,724) at Aqueduct
description: Who showed up at Aqueduct racetrack yesterday?

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Pan Am List Of Survivors
description: Following is a list of survivors of the explosion of the Pan American World Airways jetliner attacked at Rome's international airport by Arab guerrillas yesterday. The airline, which issued the list in New York, said it would not identify the dead until today.

title: Danskin Campaigning to Head G.O.P.
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17Benjamin H. Danskin, the Monmouth County Republican chairman, who is considered a moderate, said yesterday that he would be in touch with members of the state committee this week to round up support for his bid to be state chairman.

title: Storm Falls Hard on Businesses in City and Suburbs in Middle of Busiest Weeks
description: The season's first major snowstorm dealt a heavy blow to the city's economy yesterday, cutting business at retail stores, restaurants, theaters, movie houses and hotels at the outset of what normally is one of their busiest weeks of the year.

title: Republican Assemblymen Affirm Support for Duryea and Kingston
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17Republican members of the Assembly late this evening ratified their previous election of Perry B. Duryea as Speaker and expressed their confidence in Majority Leader John E. Kingston and Assemblyman Alfred A. Delli Bovi, all three of whom have been indicted on charges of violating the Election Law.

title: Rockefeller Is Absolved On State Pact With Perot
description: A state report held yesterday that baseless outcries over welfare and Medicaid computerstudy contracts to a corn pany headed by H. Ross Perot had grown, in part, from sloppy administration by the State Department of Social Services under Commissioner Abe Lovine.

title: City Street Crews Busy Clearing Queens Roads
description: Give any good New Yorker who has lived here for the last five years the word snowstorm on a freeassociation test and the chances are that he will reply, Queens.

title: Yale Names Captain
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17 (AP)  Henry Sherrill, a highscoring forward from Rio De Janeiro, has been elected captain of next year's soccer team at Yale University.

title: Honor for Volpe Reported
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Logan Airport's new $39million terminal will be named in honor of former Massachusetts Gov. John A. Volpe, The Boston HeraldAmerican reported today.

title: City, in Shift, Is Expected To Let Con Ed Use Coal
description: City environmental officials are expected to remove today the last obstacle to the burning of coal here by the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Byrne's Opposition Blocks Jersey Turnpike Extension
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne tonight effectively killed plans for the New Jersey Turnpike Extension through the center of the state, declaring that it represented a danger to the environment and that the fuel shortage had reduced the need for the road.

title: TV: I Heard the Owl Is Moving Drama on C.B.S.
description: Tonight at 9:30, the Columbia Broadcasting System is, almost surreptitiously, easing into its schedule a auminute drama that gently and movingly turns out to be one of the most effective television presentations of the holiday season. Adapted by Gerald Di Pego from a book by Margaret Craven, it is called I Heard the Owl Call My Name.

title: U.N. IS CONFIDENT OF GENEVA ROLE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.., Dec. 17Diplomats and officials here voiced confidence today that the Middle East peace conference would start Friday and that the United Nations and Secretary General Waldheim would have an assured role in the proceedings.

title: FED VOTED EASING IN MONEY POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The sharp decline in money market interest rates in late September and early October posed a dilemma for the Federal Reserve's Open Market Cornmittee, it was disclosed today.

title: 2 New Stewardesses On Lufthansa Airliner
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Two stewardesses with less than 12 months of service were among the crew members of the hijacked Lufthansa Boeing 737 airliner, a Lufthansa spokesman said tonight.

title: Knicks Victors, 10997
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 The New York, Knicks, again playing unselfish team basketball, demonstrated that a fiveman was more effective than a threeman offense as they subdued the Houston Rockets, 10997, before a gathering of 5,341 at Hofheinz Pavilion tonight.

title: Chess: Be Prepared, of Course, But the Question Is How?
description: There are two schools of thought regarding preparation for a match. One, represented by the current world champion, Bobby Fischer, and by a former world champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, favors intensive theoretical studies; the other, represented by Lajos Portisch and Anatoly Karpov, both finalists in the coming candidates' matches to determine Fischer's challenger, favors practical play.

title: Coastal States in Coal Deal
description: The Coastal States Gas Corporation has signed an agreement under which its subsidiary, the Coastal States Energy Company, is acquiring the coal mining assets of the Southern Utah Fuel Company.

title: Wrong People
description: The world has got itself into another of its customary tangles this winter, and it won't help for Professor Kissinger just to fly around it smiling like an agreeable floorwalker. The world needs solutions, not highlevel air travel.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In. Eastern Standard Time

title: Mayor Gives Leonard Lyons Medallion and Scroll
description: Surrounded by friends from the world of art and theater, Leonard Lyons, an elder statesman of Broadway syndicated columnists, received from Mayor Lindsay yesterday the city's bronze medallion and a special scroll for distinguished and exceptional service.

title: Senate Votes $2.2Billion Aid for Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate approved today a foreign aid appropriations bill that provides $2.2billion in emergency aid to Israel, but drastically reduces military aid to other countries.

title: Oregonians Faced Crises in Fall
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Two months ago when the entire Pacific Northwest was caught in the squeeze of a great power shortage, Tom L. Sawyer and his wife closed their 19room house and moved, with their three children, into a small apartment in their attic.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on the Exclusion of Maternity Benefits From a Disability Insurance Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Supreme Court agreed today to determine whether a disability benefits insurance program that does not include maternity benefits discriminates unconstitutionally against women.

title: ARAB THREATENS ATHENS MASSACRE
description: ATHENS, Tuesday, Dec. 18 (AP)We are going to conduct a slaughter at Athens airport, an Arab guerrilla leader reportedly said here early today aboard the West German airliner he and his followers had hijacked in Rome yesterday.

title: Shapiro Confirmed as du Pont Chief
description: Irving S. Shapiro was named yesterday, as expected, as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., succeeding Charles B. McCoy, who will retire at the end of the month.

title: COURT FINES ANCORP IN NEWSPAPER CASE
description: A leading newstand concern, now in bankruptcy proceedings, has been fined $204,200 for exacting special payments from three New York newspapers, the Federal Trade Commission disclosed yesterday.

title: Bond Prices Steady in Dull Trading
description: Prices showed little change yesterday in the corporate and taxexempt bond market in quiet trading. Dealers said many of their colleagues did not get to their desks because of sleet and freezing rain.

title: Children Are Among Best Friends of the Neediest
description: Some of the best friends of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are children.

title: LAST SESSION HELD BY C.U.N.Y. BOARD
description: The City University's 21member Board of Higher Education, which has been appointed solely by the Mayor since 1926, met in its present form for the last time last night. Next month it will be replaced by a 10member board appointed by the Mayor and the Governor.

title: Turnpike to Ask Bids on ParkRide Run
description: RIDGEFIELD, Dec. 17The New Jersey Turnpike Authority hopes to take bids in two or three weeks for a bus company to operate an express bus service between a 950automobile parkandride lot under construction here and midtown Manhattan.

title: E.E.C. Trade Offer Poses U.S. Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The recent European Common Market offer of minor trade concessions to compensate the United States for the impact of adding three new members is regarded as unacceptable, informed Administration officials said today, but the Government is in a dilemma over what to do about it.

title: JOSEPH W. BINGHAM
description: Joseph W. Bingham, a retired professor of law at Stanford University, died Saturday in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 95 years old.

title: Foreman Bout Is Reported Set
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17 (AP) George Foreman, the world heavyweight champion, has agreed to defend his title against Ken Norton, Norton's manager said today.

title: Pan Am to Reduce Flights From London for Holidays
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) Pan American World Airways will sharply reduce the number of its flights between London and United States cities from Christmas to New Years, a spokesman for the airline said here today. He, said that the present eight flights a day would be cut to three.

title: Bids for Airco Amended By Curtiss and Britons
description: The battle to take over Airco, Inc., became more intense yesterday as both contenders for Airco changed the terms of their tender offers for its stock.

title: 2 Companies Are Accused of Homicide In Collapse of a Cofferdam Killing
description: Two engineering companies and three of their officials were indicted in Queens yesterday on charges of criminally negligent homicide in connection with the collapse of cofferdam at a Consolidated Edison plant in August. Two workmen died in the collapse.

title: Notes on People
description: Never mind what his fellow Connecticut Republicans say, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has nothing but the highest regard for Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, a Democrat. Mr. Weicker criticized members of his own party, among them the Republican state chairman, J. Brian Gaffney, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill and Representative Robert H. Steele, for saying that Mr. Ribicoff, at the age 63, is too old for his job.

title: Political Tie
description: The new National Commission on Critical Choices for America seems to be up against a critical choice of its own. The obvious link between the work of the commission and the Presidential aspirations of its chairman, Governor Rockefeller, are creating troublesome legal and policy questions over financing of the group's mission.

title: Glenn in Fresh Start for Senate Seat
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17John H. Glenn, the former astronaut, whose two previous tries for the United States Senate were marked by accident and amateurism, surrounded himself last week with political professionals and embarked on a fresh start.

title: Diarmuid Russell Dies at 71; Founder of Literary Agency
description: Diarmuld Russell, a founder and recently retired president of Russell & Volkening, Inc., a leading literary agency, died Sunday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N, Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Crotona, N. Y.

title: Books of The Times
description: To explore the image of women in the American filmit would seem to be an essential task that the film critic Marjorie Rosen has undertaken in her Popcorn Venus: Women, Movies & The American Dream. Indeed, it seems at first glance remarkable that no one has ever tried to do it before. For as Miss Rosen herself

title: Last Day in Governor's Office Is a Routine One for Rockefeller
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller spent his final full day as Governor of New York yesterday without ceremony and immersed in office routine built of 15 years experience.

title: Home Loan Panel Upholds Women's Mortgage Right
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board made it a matter of policy today that savings and loan institutions, may no longer discriminate against women or families dependent on a working wife's income in making mortgage loans.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL MEDICAL SCHOOLS
description: A committee of four Democratic State Senators yesterday outlined a legislative program designed to end discrimination by medical schools against students living in New York State and other parts of the Northeast, and to halt an unconscionable drain of statefinanced manpower.

title: Bolivian Oil Rights Set
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17, (AP)The Bolivian Government has granted petroleum exploration production rights to subsidiaries of the Amerada Hess corporation and the Standard Oil company (Indiana). Indiana Standard said the Bolivian Government oil company would share in any production that resulted from the companies' exploratory drilling.

title: 16 G.M. Plants Shat For OneWeek Closing
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (UPI)Sixteen of the General Motors Corporation's 24 North American car assembly plants were closed today in the start of a oneweek shutdown that some observers fear may he a common occurrence In 1974.

title: PUBLIC JOB PLAN BACKED IN CAPITOL AND WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 House and Senate conferees, after reaching a compromise with the Administration, approved today a multibilliondollar comprehensive manpower act that includes an emergency public employment program.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In defense of sugar, a reader in New Brunswick, N. J., notes its use in many Chinese dishes and comments:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of the State Supreme Court, suspended after his conviction last year in a bankruptcy fraud case, was denied a new trial yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals here. Justice Pfingst contended that the prosecutor had concealed a deal to grant leniency to a codefendant, the key witness against him.

title: 41 FOOD OUTLETS FAIL INSPECTIONS
description: The Health Department has released the names of 41 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted two inspections.

title: TEXAS TO FREE SOME IN MARIJUANA CASES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 17 Some of the 1,371 Texans who are in prison for marijuana offenses will be freed under executive clemency, a spokesman for Gov. Dolph Briscoe said today, but how many depends on a casebycase review by the State Board of Pardons and Paroles.

title: Widower Expects U.S. Widow Benefits in March
description: EDISON, Dec. 17  Stephen C. Wiesenfeld, who sued for and won his widow's rights in Federal court, said today that he expected to begin collecting his monthly Social Security payments of $248.30 next March.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, said in a report that sloppy administration by the State Department of Social Services under Commissioner Abe Lavine was responsible, in part, for baseless outcries over contracts to a company headed by H. Ross Perot. The contracts were for a study of computerization of welfare and Medicaid programs.

title: Kent State Inquiry to Open
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 (UPI) Impaneling of a Federal grand jury to investigate the 1970 Kent State University by Ohio National Guardsmen begins tomorrow. Robert Murphy, a Justice Department official from Washington who has been acthe in the recent investigation of the case, will make the Government's presentation at the Federal courthouse here.

title: LEONARD F. BLACK SR.
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 17  Leonard F. Black Sr., who retired in 1961 as director of book and mail order advertising for Puck, the comic weekly, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He lived at 294 Bronxville Road.

title: Dance: Perez Premiere
description: In the surreal sunshine world of Rudy Perez there lurks a darker side that emerges occasionally, most often in the form of solos. One thinks of his beautiful Countdown, and now Running Board for a Narrative, which received its premiere performance at Marymount Manhattan College Sunday evening.

title: CURBS ARE ASKED ON SCHOOL POSTS
description: The Board of Education will ask the State Legislature to prohibit teachers and other school employes here from serving as elected members of the decentralized community school boards.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PEOPLE PIX The photo gallery at the EmanuEl Midtown Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 344 East 14th Street (6747200), is a long, narrow reach of room on the second floor where the shows may be on any conceivable topic. The current one should be of particular interest to many New Yorkers. It is called The Jew in New York, 157 photos by 38 living artists, including shots from the past years loaned by various institutions. They cover the years since 1933 and are designed to show the wide scope and presence of the Jewish community

title: WILLIAM SMITH
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 17  William Smith, a retired construction worker and former chief of the Caledonian Club of Newark, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 62 Maple Avenue.

title: Legal Aid Bill Put Off Till Next Year by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Unable to prevent a threatened filibuster by amendment, the Senate decided today to postpone until next year a bill to set up a Government corporation that would provide free legal services for the poor.

title: Dairy Executive Testifies Mills's Campaign Got Aid
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 17 (AP)A dairy industry executive testified today he was told that corporate funds paid rents for two Washington apartments used by company employes to help the Presidential campaign of Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas.

title: Faye and Payne Reunited In Nostalgic Good News
description: Alice Faye and John Payne together again!

title: Cairo Aide Flies to Damascus, Apparently on Geneva Parley
description: Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, flew to Damascus today, apparently to urge a reluctant Syria to participate in the proposed Geneva peace conference, according to informed diplomatic sources.

title: Bonn Coalition Strains
description: Foreign Minister Walter Scheel is eminently qualified to be President of the Federal Republic of Germany. His election next spring, with the backing of his Free Democratic party (F.D.P.) and Chancellor Brandt's Social Democrats (S.P.D.) now seems assured. What is far less certain is the impact on the coalition Government and on the West German political scene of Mr. Scheel's departure from the Cabinet and his party's leadership.

title: Amid the Snow, Some Found Profit or Even Humor
description: Yesterday's snowstorm was the kind that sorts people into two groupsthose who take it as a personal plot against them and those who take it in stride and even find a little humor and camaraderie in coping with it.

title: PRESIDENT YIELDS IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate Watergate committee won statutory authority today to seek help from the Federal courts in obtaining some of President Nixon's tape recordings and documents.

title: Amid Discontent, Tour of Europe Is Planned by Graham Dancers
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will embark on its first European tour is seven years, appearing at the summer Spoleto and Avignon Festivals and London following a threeweek season here in March.

title: Tom Hammer, Developer Of Metalizing Equipment
description: Tom Hammer, a mechanical engineer who developed highvacuum metalizing equipment and was product director of John Dusenbery Company, Inc., in Clifton, N.J., died Saturday of lung cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 171 Montclair Avenue, Montclair, N.J.

title: Guerrilla Attack Assailed By Palestinians' Leaders
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17The Palestinian commando leadership today condemned the guerrilla action that began with an armed attack on the Rome airport, describing it as an operation that was against the interests of our people.

title: Coast Tunnel Builder Fined
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (UPI) The Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company was fined $205,000 today as a result of its conviction on negligence charges in the 1971 Sylmar Tunnel explosion in which 17 men were killed. Judge George W. Trammel 3d also handed down jail sentences for the Sylmar project manager Loren Savage, and its safety engineer, Otha G. Ree Jr., but ordered the sentences stayed until 1976 so the men could redeem themselves.

title: PUBLIC JOB PLAN BACKED IN CAPITOL AND WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 House and Senate conferees, after reaching a compromise with the Administration, approved today a multibilliondollar comprehensive manpower act that includes an emergency public employment program.

title: The Theater: Prodigal
description: The Circle Theaterwith one of those juggles of nomenclature that strangers find puzzling about our theateris an Off Off Broadway Theater on Broadway. Oh well, these names are to do with union contracts not geography, and the Circle Theater at Broadway and 83d Street has been racking up a considerable tally of success.

title: ARAB GUERRILLAS KILL 31 IN ROME DURING ATTACK ON U.S. AIRLINER, TAKE HOSTAGES TO ATHENS, FLY ON
description: ATHENS, Tuesday, Dec. 18A hijacked Lufthansa jet took off from Athens today at the end of a night of negotiating between Arab hijackers and the Greek Government over the release of two guerrilla prisoners during which the hijackers reportedly killed five of 14 hostages.

title: Wright Brothers Day
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP)The 70th anniversary of man's first successful flight in an enginepowered aircraft was celebrated today at the Wright Memorial. It was in 1903 at Kitty Hawk, about six miles north of here, that Orville and Wilbur Wright sent their fragile aircraft airborne for over 120 feet. President Nixon has proclaimed today Wright Brothers Day.

title: Duke Ellington Is Given City's Handel Medallion
description: Duke Ellington received the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award, from Mayor Lindsay at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel Sunday night.

title: Yale Names Captain
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17 (AP)  Henry Sherrill, a highscoring forward from Rio De Janeiro, has been elected captain of next year's soccer team at Yale University.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: New Jersey schoolboy basketball suffered a major setback in Middlesex County because of the energy crisis with the announcements that the Perth Amboy Christmas Tournament and the Colonia Classic have been canceled.

title: Gulf Oil's Directors Approve Record 1974 Capital Budget
description: Directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation approved yesterday a record capital budget for 1974 of almost $2billion, or 34 per cent higher than the $1.5billion expected to be spent this year.

title: Beame Names 2 Women And Lazar to High Posts
description: Two women were among the three persons named to important posts yesterday by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame. They were the first women named so far by Mr. Beame, who said there would be others.

title: 18 SUE L.I. POLICE, CHARGING ABUSE
description: A group of blacks and Puerto Ricans, led by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, filed a ?? in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday charging the Suffolk County Police with systematic physical brutality, verbal abuse and harassment of minority group members.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT U.S. ASSURANCES
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17  Israeli officials said today that their country's agreement to participate in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva had been given in exchange for assurances from Secretary of State Kissinger that American support in the talks would he firm.

title: Early 10:05 Jersey Bus Is Only Late 8 : 30 One
description: In Upper Montclair, N.J., a commuter who normally takes the 10:08 A.M. bus to the city was amazed to see it pull up at his stop at 10:05 despite the weather.

title: Kings Promote Milford
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP)  John (Jake) Milford moved up today to general manager of the Los Angeles Kings of the National Hockey League. He succeeds Larry Regan.

title: State and L.I. Aides Ask Further Tests on Sludge
description: MINEOLA, Dec. 17State and local offices have been unable to substantiate reports that sewage sludge has moved closer to the South Shore beaches, and state, country and town environmental agencies have called for further samplings to attempt to substantiate the reports.

title: Mayor of Jerusalem Still Has Big Plans
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 7The war and the queasy ceasefire have brought building and beautifying to a temporary halt here, but Terusalem's ebullient Mayor, Teddy Kollek, is still full of plans and hopes.

title: Filling Stations in Vietnam Reduce 19Hour Day to 9
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  Filling stations in South Vietnam will operate only nine instead of 19 hours day to conserve dwindling fuel supplies.

title: Advertising: Why Go Public?
description: Account losses generally don't affect the price of publicly held ad agency stock. And they don't automatically affect earnings results, either, Paul C. Harper Jr., chairman of Needham, Harper & Steers, pointed out last week.

title: Watts Beats Rosa On Split Decision
description: Bobby (Boogaloo) Watts counterpunched well against Mario Rosa's southpaw style last night at Felt Forum and won a split decision in a 10round middleweight bout.

title: REICH'S DRUMMING IS TONAL TAPESTRY
description: Drumming (1971) remains Steve Reich's most extensive composition, at least in terms of time. It lasts an hour and a half, but is built around a single rhythmic cell, which the players alter by phasing, pitch, timbre and subdivision. The interest in the piece is both structuralthe way Mr. Reich develops his themeand visceral: this is a score with direct and obvious antecedents in both African drumming and Indonesian gamelan, and it can appeal to lovers of both ethnic forms.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 17 (Reuters)The Senate approved today an $80million appropriation for the reorganization of six bankrupt Eastern railroads, including the Penn Central.

title: Flash Fire Kills Surgeon's Wife And MotherinLaw in Queens
description: The 47yearold wife of a Queens surgeon and her 87yearold mother were killed last night when a flash fire enveloped their threestory brick home in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Jewish Seminary May Leave the City
description: Dr. Gerson D. Cohen's biggest problem is framed by the window next to his desk at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Screen: Dustin Hoffman as an Italian:Germi 'Alfredo, Alfredo' Starts Run at Plaza The Cast Star Is a Bank Clerk Pursued by His Wife
description: Passive as a potato, timid as a fawn, Dustin Hoffman is cast as a victim once again in "Alfredo, Alfredo," which opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater. Here, he has almost returned to his role in "The Graduate": the innocent manchild overwhelmed by a devouring woman. As an Italian bank clerk who's pursued, married and mangled by a beautiful hysteric, (Stefania Sandrelli), Mr. Hoffman plays the kind of character who can't even kick a stone in the road without injuring himself. Of course his marriage is a martyrdom, and divorce is as difficult as a Presidential impeachment.The main problem with this picture is that Pietro Germi, the director, has made it (brilliantly) twice before. His "DivorceItalian Style" and "Seduced and Abandoned" superbly satirized the cruelty of the Italian marital laws, before divorce became legal in that country. "Alfredo" is a rather diluted version of its predecessors: clearly, Mr. Germi has gone over the same material too often. The other problem is that Dustin Hoffman isn't Italian. Despite his efforts to tear into his food with a Latin gusto, or the slicked-down hair above the urban American face, he simply can't appear to be a native of a provincial Italian townany more than Dwight Eisenhower could have convinced us that he was a sleek Roman count.However, there are beguiling details throughout. Mr. Hoffman's small, cautious smiles, the way his mouth and nostrils quiver when he smells his detested wife's perfume, and her scalp-chilling screams at the moment of orgasmwhich alarm the neighbors and terrify the dog into fits of barkingall make for moments of fine farce. And it was a happy thought to have the couple's doctor prescribe sex two or three times a day, during the wife's most fertile hours; as Alfredo runs to and fro between his office and his home, he gets billows of guffaws from his colleagues. There's also a devastating scene when the wife's imaginary pregnancy is suddenly deflated.Stefania Sandrelli has a gift for sulking. But she overacts much of the time, and hence doesn't match her marvelous performances in Mr. Germi's earlier movies and in Bernard Bertolucci's "The Conformist." Also, "Alfredo" is weakened by some mossy male fantasies: the hero unfailingly inspires a tender sympathy in desirable women when they see him for the first time, and they always take the initiative in this picture. But that just isn't believable, since Mr. Hoffman is made to be too pathetic to rouse such attractions.So "Alfredo" hasn't the wit or the bitterness of Mr. Germi's best films; for this director, savagery seems essential to comedy. If he's mellowed, it's our loss. But this isn't a bad movie  it's merely a disappointment because of the immense talent involved.

title: People in Sports: Ralston Is Serving
description: Dennis Ralston, who has coached or played for every Davis Cup team since 1960, except in 1967, was reappointed nonplaying captain and coach yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. It is the third consecutive year in the post for the 31yearold resident of Palm Springs, Calif. In 1972 the team coached by Ralston retained the cup by defeating Rumania. Last month Australia took the cup with a 50 victory over the United States. The 1974 United States team, not yet named, meets Colombia in Bogota Jan. 11.

title: NATIONAL SYMPHONY PLAYS SPLENDIDLY
description: The National Symphony Orchestra owed New York one concert, canceled last month because of the Philharmonic strike, and Sunday night the debt was paid. This could explain why the program seemed a bit patchy, but the performances were superb, reflecting the orchestra's new quality and the talents of Its associate conductor, James DePreist.

title: Woody Allen Sleeps Late in NewFilm
description: Miles Monroe (Woody Allen), the partowner of the Happy Carrot Health Pood Restaurant in Greenwich Village, has a major problem. He had gone into St. Vincent's Hospital in 1973 for a minor ulcer operation, only to wake up 200 years later, defrosted, having been wrapped in aluminum foil and frozen as hard as a South African lobster tail when the minor ulcer operation went somehow wrong.

title: Britain Slashes Budget, Abandons Growth Policy
description: LONDON, Dec. 17The British Government abandoned its goal of economic growth today and chose instead a policy aimed solely at economic survival.

title: A Stalled Train Traps Commuters 10 Hours
description: Several thousand commuters hoarded a 12car Long Island Rail Road train yesterday morning and were forced to remain aboard at least 10 hours, trapped by stalled brakes and frozen doors because of a loss of electrical power.

title: PRESIDENT YIELDS IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate Watergate committee won statutory authority today to seek help from the Federal courts in obtaining some of President Nixon's tape recordings and documents.

title: Thomas Considers Fate of Colt Coach
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (UPI) Joe Thomas, general manager of the Baltimore Colts, said today he would announce a decision after the first of the year whether Coach Howard Schnellenberger would be dismissed or get a new contract.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Wally Butts, ExGeorgia Coach, Dies
description: ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 17 (AP)Wally Butts, the former University of Georgia football coach, recognized as a pioneer of the passing game in the South, died today, apparently of a heart attack, shortly after he had returned home from morning walk. His age was 68.

title: JURY INDICTS BOYLE IN YABLONSK! CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Dec. 17 (AP)W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, was indicted today on murder charges in the 1969 killings of Joseph A. Yablonski, a union, reformist, his wife and daughter.

title: Gros of Italy Captures Slalom Race
description: VIPITENO, Italy, Dec. 17 (AP)Italy's Piero Gros won the first special slalom race of the season's World Cup ski competition today and took the lead in the overall standings.

title: Soviet Says NATO Blocks Gains in TroopCut Parley
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17The Soviet Union charged today that the countries of the Atlantic alliance had impeded the first phase of the troopreduction talks in Vienna by advancing proposals calculated to alter the balance of power in Central Europe.

title: Senate Confirms Saxbe
description: The Senate, by a vote of 75 to 10, confirmed President Nixon's nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be Attorney General. He succeeds Elliot L. Richardson, Who resigned. Page 35.

title: Aide to Queen Loses Hand By Letter Bomb in London
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) One of Queen Elizabeth's aides lost a hand today when a letter bomb exploded as he opened it, Scotland Yard said.

title: UTILITY ASKS TO USE EVEN DIRTIER FUEL
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 17 (UPI)Northeast utilities, which supplies electricity to most of Connecticut and to part of Massachusetts, today asked for permission to burn even dirtier fuel than has already been allowed because of shortages.

title: Steel Production Up 0.7% in Week To 2,926,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Dec. 15 rose by 0.7 per cent to 2,926,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 119.9 from 119.2 in the preceding week when production totaled 2,907,000 tons.

title: Durable Chancellor
description: LONDON, Dec. 17Chancellors of Britain's Exchequer do not last long in office.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: ISRAELIS REPORT U.S. ASSURANCES
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17  Israeli officials said today that their country's agreement to participate in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva had been given in exchange for assurances from Secretary of State Kissinger that American support in the talks would be firm.

title: HOUSE VOTES RISE IN FUNDS TO HI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The House voted 339 to 21 today to give the Small Business Administration more money to lend, rejecting arguments that it is too scandal. ridden to handle the money wisely.

title: McAdoo Still Sets N.B.A. Point Pace
description: The Buffalo Braves' center, Bob McAdoo, raised his scoring average to 29.4 points last week to maintain his National Basketball Association lead. He has hit on 372 of 693 fieldgoal attempts for a .537 percentage, second to Milwaukee's Kareem AbdulJabar with .546.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Maggie Morgan spent year getting ready: sewing tablecloths and place mats, painting trays and tables, mixing potpourri and searching out unusual decorative object's.

title: Amleto Cardinal Cicognani, 90, Dean of Sacred College, Dead
description: ROME, Dec. 17  Amleto Giovanni Cardinal Cicognani, dean of the Sacred College of Cardinals who for 25 years served as Apostolic Delegate in Washington, died today in the Vatican. He was 90 years old.

title: Tourel Memorial Today
description: A memorial program for Jennie Tourel will be held at 2 P.M. today in the University Church at Fordham University's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. The mezzosoprano, who was 63 years old, died Nov. 23.

title: News Officials Oppose Any Links of Correspondents to the C.I.A.
description: Many of the major news gathering organizations say that they would discharge immediately any correspondent who was also found to be working for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Donald Ian Nesbitt McKenzie Weds Mary Lurline McCain
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C., Dec. 17The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Mary Lurline McCain to Donald Ian Nesbitt McKenzie. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William McLeod Frampton.

title: PilotAthens Tower Talk
description: ATHENS, Dec. 17 (AP)Following is a conversation between the captain of the hijacked West German airliner and the Athens airport control tower as monitored tonight by Greek and other sources:

title: Oregon Has Not Become a Haven for Pushers Despite Nation's Most Liberal Drug Law
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 15 (AP)About nine weeks ago, Oregon abolished jail terms and heavy fines for possession of an ounce or less of marijuana, making the state's drug law the nation's most lenient.

title: Merger Plans Dropped
description: Ryder Systems, Inc., a leaser and renter of trucks disclosed yesterday that negotiations to purchase the Toro Petroleum Corporation, Houston, had been discontinued by mutual consent.

title: Providence Turns Back Niagara
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 17 (AP)Marvin Barnes scored 20 points and made the gameclinching play for Providence tonight as the eighthranked Friars handed Niagara its first defeat of the college basketball season, 7874.

title: Fire Jobs Opened to Women
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 17 KUPI) Puerto Rican women may now join the fire department, the director of the Government Personnel Office, Mrs. Milagros Guzman, announced today.

title: People and Business
description: Farnham Lefferts, president of Tiffany & Co. and a relative by marriage of one of the founding families, has resigned after 25 years with the world famous jewelry stores. The company's board is scheduled to meet today to accept his resignation and elect a new president.

title: L.I.R.R. All but Shut Down by Weather
description: Plagued by stalled trains, frozen power rails and myriad equipment problems, the Long Island Rail Road first threw out its schedule and then threw in the sponge yesterday and shut clown virtually its entire operation.

title: Storm Brings Some Hidden Benefits
description: NEW CANAAN. Conn., Dec. 17There are hidden benefits to a storm like this, Robert W. Ker Jr. said., Everyone gets friendly. Your neighbors stop in to see whether you're okay. You talk to people that you hardly ever see the rest of the year.

title: House Plan on Reconvening
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The House, which hopes to adjourn for the year at the end of this week, adopted a resolution today setting Jan. 21 for the convening of the second session of Congress.

title: Senate Confirms Saxbe
description: The Senate, by a vote of 75 to 10, confirmed President Nixon's nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be Attorney General. He succeeds Elliot L. Richardson, who resigned. Page 35.

title: 18 SUE L.I. POLICE, CHARGING ABUSES
description: A group of blacks and Puerto Ricans, led by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, filed a suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday charging the Suffolk County Police with systematic physical brutality, verbal abuse and harassment of minoritygroup members.

title: Churches Have a Christmas List  on Preparations
description: One dozen pines, 300 mailings, somebody's cape, six altar boys, an extra priest and at least 14 choir rehearsals.

title: CostofLiving Raises Voted For Two Retired Generals
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Two retired generals who held high commands during World War II should get costofliving increases matching those of the active forces, the House decided today.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Saxbe Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Following is the 75to10 rollcall vote today confirming the nomination of Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be Attorney Gerteral:

title: Successor Glad Ewbank Is Around for Advice
description: With a swipe at city, officials and a kiss from a wellendowed brunette, Weeb Ewbank began his new duties as vice president of the Jets, yesterday. At the same time, Charlie Winner assumed his new job as coach and didn't knock anyone, especially the football team.

title: Saigon Says Reds Lost 97 Soldiers In Fighting in Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17 (UPI)A South Vietnamese military spokesman said today that 97 Communist soldiers had been killed by Government soldiers, backed lby artillery and planes, in heavy fighting in the Mekong Delta southwest of Saigon.

title: F. BEVERLEY EYRE JR.
description: F. Beverley Eyre Jr., a limited partner in the brokerage firm of C. B. Richard, Ellis & Co., which he represented on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for 36 years, died yesterday at his home on Underhill Road in Locust Valley, L. I. He was 81 years old.

title: Canada and the U.S. Reach Accord on Charter Flights
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 17 (Reuters) Canadian and American negotiators have worked out an agreement on charter flights that wraps up air negotiations lasting four years, Michel Dupuy, head of the Canadian team, said today.

title: Fuel Allocation Formulas: Long Line Forming in the Capital to Demand Fair Share
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The ink was barely dry Wednesday on the Government's proposed formulas for allocating fuels when the complaining started.

title: A Shipyard Worker Gets Up to 10 Years In '71 Slaying Here
description: Willie Mora, a shipyard worker, was sentenced yesterday to up to 10 years in prison after pleading guilty to stabbing a man to death during a $2 holdup in East Harlem two years ago and assaulting a prosecution witness in the case.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The energy crisis is a moral crisis that will ultimately force a reconceptualization of our place within the cosmic order. For too long we have sanctioned the compulsive acquisitiveness of the Protestant ethic, which encouraged a consumptive and exploitive attitude toward nature.

title: Foreign Stocks for Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (AP)Trading in several United States and European stocks begins today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, marking ete opening of the Japanese exchange to foreign securities. The six stocks to be listed include: Dow Chemical Company, the First Chicago Corporation, the First National City Corporation, the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and the IU International Corporation, all of the United States, and Banque de Parts et des PaysBas of France.

title: Three Inmates Arraigned In Boston Strangler Death
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Three inmates at Walpole State Prison were arraigned today on charges of conspiracy in the Nov. 25 stabbing death of Albert DeSalvo, the selfproclaimed Boston strangler.

title: Recreation Complex Burns
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla. Dec. 17 (UPI)A fire destroyed, a $2million recreational  shopping complex today at the Inverrary development 10 miles northwest of Fort Lauderdile. The recreational complex housed swimming pools, shops, indoor driving ranges and saunas. There were no injuries.

title: Arthur Daley
description: At times his method of operations seemed uncanny, almost as if he preferred a slightly preposterous script. The beleaguered Giants would go into the closing stages of a vitally important gamein those days all Giant games were vitally importantand the pressures on the field would keep mounting. Invariably the Giant lead would be so slim that their fervent loyalists in the stands would be biting their nails in suspense as the enemy team moved inexorably downfield. Even the hands on the clock would seem to advance with agonizing slowness. Everything appeared to conspire against them. Suddenly a bulky figure in blue would come flashing in from right end position to sack the opposition quarterback. Andy Robustelli was up to his old tricks. They were tricks, too. Sometimes he'd bolt straight through the protective screen, infiltrating in some impossible fashion. Sometimes he would twist and turn and pirouette to achieve the same result.

title: Poll Shows 45% in Favor Of Resignation by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  A public opinion poll showed today that 45 per cent of Americans surveyed said they would respect President Nixon more if he resigned to let Vice President Ford take office in an act of national unity.

title: SISTER HEDDERTON
description: Sister Berenice Hedderton, a retired teacher of English at St. Vincent Ferrer School, 152 East 66th Street, and for 56 years a member of the Roman Catholic Order of St. Mary of the Springs, Dominicans, of Columbus, Ohio, died yesterday at the school convent, where she lived. Her age was 76.

title: Insurer Unit Name Change
description: C.L. Financial, a holding company for the California Life Insurance Company, plans to change its name to the California Life Corporation, Harry H. Mitchell, chairman, said yesterday.

title: Women's Enlistment Age
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) The House passed a bill today to allow women to enlist in the military at the same age as men. Both men and women would be allowed to enlist at age 17 with parental consent, and at 18 without consent.

title: ICE AND SNOW STRIKE CITY AND SURROUNDING REGION; L.I.R.R. SERVICE CRIPPLED
description: Rain, sleet and snow, propelled by the subfreezing winds of an 800milewide storm, spread destruction and caused massive disruption of normal life yesterday throughout the metropolitan region. At least four deaths were reported.

title: WILLIAM A. SESSIONS, A RETIRED ADMIRAL
description: OAKDALE, L.I., Dec. 17Rear Adm. William A. Sessions, a Naval Reserve officer who was promoted to flag rank on his retirement in 1957, died Saturday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, Northport. He was 76 years old and lived on Chateau Drive.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)Joe Cronin, president of the American League, is expected to approve tomorrow the Detroit Tigers' signing of Ralph Houk as their manager, moving baseball's hierarchy one step closer to another confrontation with Charlie Finley. Houk resigned on Sept. 30 as manager of the New York Yankees.

title: Chile Drops PanAm Games
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 17 (AP)Chile is unable sponsor the 1975 PanAmerican Games because of the political turmoil troubling that nation, and Brazil has offered to be the host of the competition, the president of the Brazilian Olympic Committee said today. Silvio Magalhaes Padilha labeled as absurd Chile's proposal to postpone the games until 1977.

title: CLURMAN PRESENTS ARTS FUNDING PLAN
description: In the television program With Mayor Lindsay, broadcast Sunday night over Channel 11, both the Mayor and Richard Clurman, parks, recreation and cultural affairs administrator, recommended the creation of an independent, quasipublic body that would double the utility of the $25million the city now contributes toward culture and the arts.

title: 63% More NoShows In N.F.L.
description: Over a million football fans bought tickets to the pro games for the season that ended on Sunday and then failed to show up. This was a 63 per cent increase over last year. The big jump was attributable to the fact that home games sold out three or more days in advance were televised locally for the first time this year in compliance with a new law hastily passed by Congress just before the season..

title: Bonn Plans to Ease Curbs on Investing
description: BONN, Dec. 17The West German government will shortly lift restrictions on corporate investment, reflecting fears that the energy crisis will cause mounting unemployment and social unrest unless deflationary policies are eased, according to responsible officials.

title: Home Loan Panel Upholds Women's Mortgage Right
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Federal Home Loan Bank Board made it a matter of policy today that savings and loan institutions may no longer against women or families dependent on a working wife's income in making mortgage loans.

title: PANEL ON CHOICES SEEKS H.E.W. AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Governor Rockefeller's National. Commission on Critical Choices for Americans has requested funds appropriated by Congress for, but not yet spent by, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: ALABAMA OFFICIAL INDICTED IN FRAUD
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 17Three persons, including the state purchasing agent, were indicted today on charges of defrauding the Alabama Highway Department. The scandal has become a major political issue for Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Inquiry Planned on Gangland Killings
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17Prosecutor Joseph P, Lordi of Essex County said today he was considering the empaneling of a special grand jury to investigate a number of what are believed to have been gangland murders in recent months.

title: Glass Menagerie Ratings Trail Columbo in 2 Cities
description: Katharine Hepburn's television acting debut in Tennessee Williams's The Glass Menagerie on the American Broadcasting Company received impressive ratings in New York and Los Angeles, although more viewers in both cities watched an episode of Columbo on the National Broadcasting Company.

title: LIMTED SELFRULE BACKED FOR CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Washington, D. C., for which Congress acts, in effect, as city council, could have a limited serfgovernment under compromise legislation passed by the House today.

title: Tho in Paris for Talks With Kissinger
description: PARIS, Dec. 17Le Duc Tho arrived here today for another round of Vietnam negotiations with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: SECOND STAGE SET BY COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 17  The Finance Ministers of the nine Common Market members agreed today on a package of monetary and economic measures that advanced their threeyearold economic and monetary union into a second stage of development.

title: Music: Chamber Series
description: The American Symphony Orchestra has not only returned, phoenixlike, to the New York scene, but also spawned a fine new Chamber Music Society, which on Sunday evening gave the first in a series of six Carnegie Recital Hall concerts. The freezing rain held down the inaugural audience, and the illness of Anthony Miranda, horn player, forced a change of program and personnel, yet even in adversity, the society made an auspicious debut.

title: Bonds Fined $360
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP)  Bobby Bonds, San Francisco Giants outfielder, pleaded no contest today to a drunkdriving charge and was fined $360 in municipal court. Bonds was arrested Aug. 13 on a freeway south of here.

title: Big Oil Exporters Meet to Draft Plan For Price Increases
description: VIENNA, Dec. 17 (Reuters)Finance officials from major oilexporting nations met under tight security today to draft proposals for new and higher petroleum prices.

title: G.S.A. Lists Many in 5 Administrations Who Donated Their Personal Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and many prominent and middleechelon officials in the five previous national Administrations donated their papers as gifts on which they presumably claimed tax deductions, the ScrippsHoward News Service reported today.

title: It's 7:30 A.M., and the Doctor's Phone is Ringing
description: If a pediatrician wanted to, he could make a cogent argument against the traditional earlymorning telephone hour. He could argue, as some do, that telling a parent he will be available every morning from 7:30 to 8:30 to answer questions encourages too much dependence.

title: College Game Still a Headache to Garden
description: Bigtime college basketball, born 40 years ago in Madison Square Garden, is dead there now, but remains unburied. The fiveyearold, 19,500seat arena, has become a dismal place for college doubleheaders. It's doubtful that as many as 5,000 paying customers have attended the first three programs this season. A college basketball ticket in the previous Garden was once the toughest ticket in town and a haven for scalpers.

title: Customers Pick and Chop Their Own At the ChristmasTree Farms Upstate
description: PLEASANT VALLEY, N.Y., Dec. 17  It was a week before Christmas and all through the woods, not a creature was stirring except Joanne and Walter Lott of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Skylab 3 Crew Reported to Grow Longer and Slimmer in Space
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Skylab 3's astronauts have grown up to an inch or more in height and lost some inches around the waist since they left earth, a space doctor sair today.

title: Moral Profiteering ...
description: It would be unrealisticeven irresponsibleto argue that the nation's energy problems can be met without some setbacks to the cause of environmental protection and other socially oriented policies. Compromises between what is ultimately desirable and what is momentarily necessary must be accepted.

title: Teamsters Continue Wildcat Strike Against Detroit Food Stores
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP)Teamsters defied a court injunction and their own union leaders today and continued a wildcat strike against five supermarket warehouses in the Detroit area.

title: Storm Brightens Christmas Picture for Operators
description: The season's first snowstorm has blanketed much of the Northeast's ski country with sizable depths, setting the stage for what many area operators believe is going to be a happy Christmas season. Benefiting in particular from the precipitation were ski centers in Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. As of dusk yesterday, however, New Hampshire had received little more than a dusting.

title: Seoul Christians Press Park for Reform
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17 About 250 South Korean Christian students, holding a prayer service for national salvation here tonight, urged the Government to amend the Constitution to restore democracy.HONG KONG, Dec. 17Students in China have suddenly begun to hold rallies, ostensibly in support of South Korean demonstrations against the Seoul Government. It was the first mass student activity reported, since the Cultural Revolution and may have domestic political significance.

title: Campus Adrift
description: In its final report on the state of the nation's colleges and universities, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education has painted a gloomy picture of grave trouble on the entire education front. The dominant mood in academia is one of not being appreciated, wanted, supported. In the commission's words, a traumatic loss of a sense of assured progress, of the inevitability of a better future, has occurred.

title: MILTON PILALAS
description: Milton Pilalas, retired president of the Commerce Tankers Corporation of New York, died here Saturday. He was 77 years old and lived in New York and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Issel Stays Ahead In A.B.A. Scoring
description: Kentucky's Dan Issel continues to lead New York's Julius Erving in the American Basketball Association scoring race, averaging 28.4 points to 27.5 for Erving. Kentucky's Artis Gilmore is the top rebounder with a 17.8 average.

title: NET AT DEAN WITTER UP 20% IN QUARTER
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., brokers, reported yesterday that net income for the quarter ended Nov. 30 had risen 20 per cent from yearearlier levels.

title: PENTAGON WEIGHS A CUTBACK IN JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Defense Department said today that it was considering the elimination of as many as 160,000 noncombat jobs around the world.

title: Byrne's Opposition Blocks Jersey Turnpike Extension
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne tonight effectively killed plans for the New Jersey Turnpike Extension through the center of the state, declaring that it represented a danger to the environment and that the fuel shortage had reduced the need for the road.

title: N.C. State Tops Kansas In Liberty Bowl, 3118
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 17 (AP)Stan Fritts, a fullback, ran for two touchdowns to overcome the sparkling passing of David Jaynes and pace North Carolina State to a 3118 victory over Kansas tonight in the Liberty Bowl football game.

title: Kidde Shares Are Bought
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to buy all the 496,900 common shares of Walter Kidde Co., Inc., that are owned by the Loews Corporation and 46,000 shares from another unidentified company. Sun said it was purchasing the shares, representing about 5.7 per cent of Kidde outstanding stock, as an investment.

title: Ford Motor Plans To Redeem Stock Foundation Holds
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that ?? had reached an agreement wall the Ford Foundation to issti:?? notes and debentures to the foundation early in 1974 in exchange for about 5.9 million shares of the nonvoting Class A stock of the automobile manufacturing company.

title: Robustelli Named Giants' Director of Operations
description: Andy Robustelli, the captain of the New York Giants' defensive unit in their glory seasons but not involved with the team for the last nine years, was named director of operations yesterday with what he described as full authority over the selection of the new head coach, trades, signing of players and scouting.

title: High Levels of Lead In Texans Is Linked To El Paso Smelter
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 17 (UPI)Discharges from an El Paso, Tex., smelter are responsible for abnormally high lead levels in residents of a foursquare mile area, according to the National Center for Disease Control.

title: Senate Health Panel Told Of Peril in Fuel Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Shortages that could endanger the ill and injured throughout the United States are developing because of the national energy crisis, spokesmen for doctors, hospitals and makers of drugs and medical supplies told a Senate subcommittee today.

title: Cost of Stadium Up Again, To Nearly $300Million
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority estimated today that the cost of the proposed Meadowlands stadium and race track had increased by another $10million to $15million, and said it hoped to market by Jan. 15 the $290millionplus bond issue required to finance the project.

title: Senate, 75 to 10, Votes to Confirm Saxbe as Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17In a quick and friendly proceeding, the Senate voted tonight to confirm Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, as Attorney General.

title: Treasury Bills Fell At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities:

title: Roberta Peters and Lewis Join in Duets
description: William Lewis has substituted for a number of indisposed tenors at the Metropolitan Opera, and Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall he deputized in concert for George Shirley. The benefit program, celebrating the 65th anniversary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was a joint recital with another Met star, Roberta Peters.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Cahill said yesterday that John F. McCarthy Jr. had asked not to be reappointed as chairman of the State Commission of Investigation. Mr. McCarthy, whose term expired Sunday, was appointed to the commission on July 30, 1970.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: A Chance For Mr. Wilson
description: Malcolm Wilson replaces Nelson Rockefeller as Governor of New York today and the changeover is no doubt being viewed with more than ordinary interest by Nick Donald Bagley, aged 30, a valued employe in a Long Island printing firm. For if, as Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz has said, the new Governor is a political conservative but also a man with a good heart, who believes in helping those genuinely in need, he will have a chance to show it in Nick Bagley's case.

title: Cost of Jersey Stadium Rises by $10Million More
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority estimated today that the cost of the proposed Meadowlands stadium and race track had increased by another $10million to $15million, and said it hoped to market by Jan. 15 the $290millionplus bond issue required to finance the project.

title: Stock Prices on Amex Decline In Session Curtailed by Storm
description: After trading opened an hour late because of the storm in New York, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell on a broad front in quiet activity yesterday. The same conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: AUTO FUME DELAY VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate voted today to extend for one year the 1975 interim standards for pollution controls on automobiles.

title: Frances Witherspoon, 87, Of War Resisters League
description: Frances Witherspoon, a cofounder with the late Tracy D. Mygatt of the War Resisters League in 1923, died Sunday in Philadelphia. She was 87 years old.

title: G.A.O. Lists $100,000 Agnew Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) The General Accounting Office disclosed today that at least $100,000 had been spent to provide offices, aides and other privileges for Spiro T. Agnew since he resigned as Vice President.

title: 22,000 1974 Cars Recalled By G.M. for Safety Defects
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation said today that it was notifying nearly 22,000 owners of 1974 model cars of safety defects that could cause the rear wheels to lock or result in the loss of rear wheel braking.

title: CHARLES G. ABBOT OF SMITHSONIAN
description: RIVERDALE, Md., Dec. 17Dr. Charles Greeley Abbot, former secretary (chief executive officer) of the Smithsonian Institution and a noted astrophysicist, died today in Leland Memorial Hospital. He was 101 years old and lived in Hyattsville.

title: CONTEMPT RULING ON I.B.M UPHELL
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here upheld a civil contempt citation yesterday that threatens the giant International Business Machines Corporation with a 8150,000aday fine for refusing to hand over some of its files to the Justice Department. The court, however, did not impose a fine.

title: Iran Keeps Oil Flowing Despite Reported Pressure From Arabs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 Iran, the secondlargest producer of oil in the Persian Gulf, reportedly has come under oressure from Arab states to limit oil shipments abroad, but has steadily refused to do so.

title: Brooklyn Businessman Named to Head Staff of U.S. Product Safety Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Federal Government's newest regulatory agency chose black businessman from Brooklyn today as its chief of staff.

title: Varied Temperatures in Storm Pose Problems for Forecasters
description: An extreme contrast in temperatures on either side of the storm made it very difficult to predict, Thomas Morgan of the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Reinhold Team Is the Victor In Reisinger Team Contest
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 17Three experts capped a remarkable tournament year here last night by capturing the Reisinger open team title, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals.

title: Britain Slashes Budget, Abandons Growth Policy
description: LONDON, Dec. 17The British Government abandoned its goal of economic growth today and chose instead a policy aimed solely at economic survival.

title: Stocks Decline Slightly; Storm Delays Opening
description: Stock prices closed modestly lower yesterday after a snow and ice storm delayed the market opening by one hour to 11 A.M. Trading volume, reflect. ing the storm and the absence of many brokers from their desks, skidded to 12.93 million shares from Friday's turnover of 20 million shares.

title: Wings Shuffle Goalies
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings farmed out a rookie goaltender, Terry Richardson, and called up Bill Mckenzie today from Virginia of the American League.

title: Goldwater Says Doubt Lingers Over How Honest President Is
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17  Senator Barry Goldwater said in a newspaper article published here today that President Nixon had failed to heed his call of eight months ago to clear up the Watergate scandal.

title: L.I.R.R. All but Shut Down by Weather
description: Plagued by stalled trains, frozen power rails and myriad equipment problems, the Long Island Rail Road first threw out its schedule and then threw in the sponge yesterday and shut down virtually its entire operation.

title: The Whatsis Cap Gets a Workout
description: They saw the snow yesterday and remembered that perfectly forgettable knit cap that was charged at a Fifth Avenue store, picked off a pushcart, snapped up at a discount counter, bought on a whim one night in a bar where they stopped for a little something to take away the chill.

title: FUTURES ADVANCE IN LIGHT ACTIVITY
description: The storm that gripped the New York area, as well as snow in the Middle West discouraged some of the trading activity yesterday in commodity futures. However, there were enough buyers on hand to send prices sharply higher in some instances.

title: Iconoclastic Jain Leader Is Likened to Pope John
description: Some followers of Muni Sri Chitrabhanu call him the Pope John of Jainism because they say that he, like the late John XXIII, opened the windows of his faith to let the fresh air in.

title: People in Sports: Ralston Serves Again
description: Dennis Ralston, who has coached or played for every Davis Cup team since 1960, except in 1967, was reappointed nonplaying captain and coach yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, It is the third consecutive year in the post for the 31yearold resident of Palm Springs, Calif. In 1972 the team coached by Ralston retained the cup by defeating Rumania. Last month Australia took the cup with a 50 victory over the United States. The 1974 United States team, not yet named, meets Colombia in Bogota Jan. 11.

title: 16 Injured as Jet Crashes on Landing At Boston Airport
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)An Iberian Airlines jumbo jet carrying 167 persons clipped a landing light pier and crashed on landing in fog and rain at Logan International Airport today. At least 16 persons were injured, officials said. No fatalities were reported, the police said.

title: The Arab Terrorists
description: The fanaticism that has perverted the Palestinian Arab cause for so long has once again taken a bloody, mindless toll in innocent human life. No civilized person or government can stand aloof from the tragedies perpetrated in Rome and Athens yesterday; no political cause can justify the murderous acts..

title: Vandalism Is on the Increase in City's Cemeteries
description: After repeated forays by night marauders who overturned tombstones and smashed mausoleums, Bayside Cemetery, a centuryandahalf old Jewish cemetery in a quiet neighborhood in Ozone Park, Queens, not long ago installed a sixfoot barbedwire fence, at a cost of $6,000.

title: Bonds Fined $360
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP)  Bobby Bonds, San Francisco Giants outfielder, pleaded no contest today to a drunkdriving charge and was fined $360 in municipal court. Bonds was arrested Aug. 13 on a freeway south of here.

title: ExForeign Minister to Form Danish Government
