description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 17 (AP)Poul Hartling, a former Foreign Minister, was named today to form a minority government with the slimmest parliamentary base in Danish political history.

title: British Unions Pessimistic on Measures
description: LONDON, Dec. 17Efforts to get negotiations going in the labor disputes that threaten to paralyze Britain made uneven progress today.

title: Nightmare for Villemure: Hawks, Storm, Railroad
description: It was bad enough that Gilles Villemure, the New York Rangers goaltender, was injured in that 61 battering the team took from the Chicago Black Hawks Sunday night at Madison Square Garden. Getting home was worse. Leaning on crutches, Villemure planned to go home on the Long Island Rail Road rather than by car. What with the heavy snow and other vicissitudes to which the L.LR.R. is susceptible, it took Villemure's train five hours to get from Penn Station to Jamaica, Queens, and the train had no light or heat. The train got no farther than Jamaica. From there Villemure had to take a taxicab the rest of the way, and he did not reach his home in Nassau County until 4:15 A.M. yesterday.

title: B'NAI B'RITH URGES ACTION ON EMBARGO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 B'nai B'rith called on the Nixon Administration today to initiate a policy of economic selfdefense that would include selective control of exports, tourism and technology to any nation cooperating with the Arab oil embargo.

title: GRAND JURY BEGINS KENT STATE INQUIRY
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18A 23member Federal grand jury was sworn here today and immediately began hearing evidence in the killing of four students May 4, 1970, at Kent State University, 35 miles southeast of here.

title: 200 State Auditors in Welfare Offices Will Seek to Reduce Payment Errors
description: The State Department of Social Services announced yesterday that 200 state auditors would visit local welfare departments, incuding 150 in New York City, to set up procedures to reduce errors.

title: Mrs. Alan Schumacher, 56, Headed the Colonial Dames
description: Mrs. Phyllis Gillespie Schumacher, the wife of Alan Schumacher, a retired vice president of the Empire Trust Company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived on Bellevue Avenue in Newport, R.I., and at 1140 Fifth Avenue.

title: Hughes Takes Oath as Fourth Modern Chief Justice
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18 (AP)Richard J. Hughes, the 45th Governor of New Jersey, took the oath of office today as the fourth chief justice of the modern State Supreme Court, which came into being 25 years ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PARADISE REVIVED John Milton died in 1674, and the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th. Street (TE 86690), is jumping the anniversary gun by a week or so to be the first to commemorate the occasion. Today it opens a new exhibition in its cavernous, almost buckrambound mainfloor hall: John Milton: The Poet Illustrated. The idea, carried out with the usual thoroughness and taste of this bibliophile cadre, is to show illustrations in editions of Milton's works.

title: Breeder Reactor Plan Facing Delays
description: The nation's most costly energyresearch project  aimed at developing a commercial version of a breeder nuclear power plant by the midnineteeneighties  is suffering delays and large cost overruns that have forced reexamination of the effort's pace and scope.

title: 5 BOROUGH CHIEFS BACKED ON RAISES
description: Backed by a good government group and a businessmen's organization, the Borough Presidents told a City Council committee yesterday that they sorely needed $10,000 increases to their $35,000 salaries to keep pace with the rising cost of living.

title: Breeder Reactor Plan Facing Delays
description: The nation's most costly energyresearch project  aimed at developing a commercial version of a breeder nuclear power plant by the midnineteeneighties  is suffering delays and large cost overruns that have forced reexamination of the effort's pace and scope.

title: Music
description: The Group for Contemporary Music, the newmusic ensemble directed by Charles Wuorinen and Harvey Sollberger, unleashed something of a spectacular at its concert Mondy night at the Manhattan School of Music. The spectacle included not only some largish forces, butunusually enough in this rigorously intellectual contextalso some demonstrative wit and charm.

title: Conferees Vote President Free Rein to Allot Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Senate and House negotiators agreed today to give President Nixon unrestricted authority to implement gasoline rationing, without approval of Congress. The negotiators also agreed to allow the President to order other energy conservation measures until June 30, subject only to veto by either house of Congress.

title: Governor Wilson
description: The transfer of the governorship from Nelson A. Rockefeller to Malcolm Wilson was accomplished efficiently and without ostentationin a style characteristic of the two men. Mr. Rockefeller's unsentimentally matteroffact last day as Governor in office was matched in understatement by yesterday's brief and simple swearingin ceremony of the new Governor in the Capitol's Red Room.

title: Suit Charges Grizzlies Program In Yellowstone Is Mismanaged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The chiefs of the Department of the Interior, the National Park Service and Yellowstone National Park were charged in a lawsuit today with conducting a management program that threatens the survival of the grizzly bear within the Yellowstone ecosystem.

title: Curran Says Coverage of a Raid Didn't Hinder FreeTrial Rights
description: News coverage of a massive narcotics raid did not deprive the defendants of their right to a fair trial, acording to documents filed in Federal Court here yesterday by Paul J. Curran, the United States Attorney for the Southern District.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Meadow Stable's Secretariat, the first Triple Crown winner in 25 years, was voted horse of the year yesterday in the Eclipse Award balloting as well as the top 3yearold and grass champion.

title: Red Smith
description: Reporting on the recent death of Count Fleet, that admirable periodical, The BloodHorse, told a tale that brought back to mind another story involving the late, great horseman, Max Hirsch. Count Fleet, everyone remembers, won the Kentucky Derby, Preakness, Belmont Stakes and everything else he attempted in 1943, went home to Stoner Creek Farm, Paris, Ky., and transmitted his own great quality down through the generations, even unto Kelso, five times horse of the year.

title: POTATO FUTURES CLIMB TO PEAKS
description: Potato futures set another record high price at 10.04 cents a pound on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The price was up from the former high of 9.93 cents on Monday. These records, both set for the May contract, are the highest levels for any delivery in the history of the exchange.

title: Dita Beard Dropped as Witness After Two Psychiatric Reports
description: The Watergate special prosecutor has decided not to call Mrs. Dita D. Beard as a witness before the Watergate grand jury, following two psychiatric examinations of the former lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Shortages and Higher Fares Thwart Homing Students
description: BOULDER, Colo.Fred Mills and Carol Bashore of Norwalk, Conn., are going through a curious ritual these days at the University of Colorado: They are auditioning before other students in hope of finding a ride home for Christmas.

title: Surgery for Christenson
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (UPI)  Larry Christenson will undergo surgery for the removal of bone chips from his right elbow, the Philadelphia Phillies announced today. Christenson was examined yesterday by team physician. Dr. Philip J. Marine, after a swelling developed while the righthander was pitching for Caguas in the Puerto Rican Winter League. The operation will be performed Friday.

title: Canada Trade Totals Revised
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Statistics Canada said yesterday that it had revised its October import and export figures, resulting in an increased trade surplus of $67.8million from $24.1million.

title: DAVID BECKER
description: CONWAY, Mass., Dec. 18David Becker, past president of the Westchester Pharmaceutical Association, died today at the home of his son, Stephen Becker. He was 81 years old.

title: New Sanitationmen's Pact Is Foreseen by Year's End
description: A spokesman for the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association said yesterday that he was optimistic about prospects for completing a new agreement with the city prior to the end of the year.

title: President Welcomes Saxbe to the Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)President Nixon welcomed his new Attorney General, William B, Saxbe, to the Cabinet to lay.

title: Bridge: 4 From Metropolitan Area Win Fall National Titles
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended Sunday night in Las Vegas, Nev., were a considerable success in terms of organization and sizeit was the biggest fall tournament ever played, with 13,464 tables in play during 10 days.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A New York City sculptor who allegedly had $40,000 in the bank and lived in a luxury cooperative apartment at 30 Fifth Avenue was charged yesterday with swindling New York City and New York State out of $6,256 in undeserved welfare payments.

title: Democrats, Too, Afiaid Of Watergate Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 18Democratic officials preparing for Congressional elections of 1974 are fearful that if the Republican elephant stumbles over Watergate, it may fall on top of some Democrats.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Finland to Help Develop Big IronOre Deposit in Soviet
description: Finland has agreed to the Russians develop a large ironore deposit to bolster the rawmaterial supply for the Soviet Union's expanding steel Industry.

title: ITALY LINKS RAID TO LYE DEATHS
description: ROME, Dec. 18The Italian Interior Minister told Parliament tonight that the murderous Arab guerrilla raid at Fiumicino Airport near here yesterday might have been carried out by members of the same faction that was responsible for the killings at Lydda Airport in Israel in May, 1972.

title: Fire on Ship Controlled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (UPI)A Norwegian freighter caught fire in the. Pacific 950 miles northeast of Hawaii today. The Coast Guard said it received a distress call from the Wilmara, a 609foot bulk carrier, reporting the vessel ablaze and the crew ready to abandon her. However, two hours later the ship radioed that the fire was under control.

title: White Sox Finish Trade for Santo
description: CHICAGO, Dec: 18 (UPI)The Chicago White Sox sent a lefthanded pitcher, Jim Kremmel, to the Chicago Cubs today as the fourth and final player in the deal that moved Ron Santo, the third baseman, to the White Sox.

title: Prices for Bonds Close Mixed in a Quiet Session
description: Trading remained quiet and prices closed mixed yesterday in the corporate and, taxexempt bond markets.

title: Unreasonable Search
description: By substantially extending the power of police officers to search arrested persons without a warrant, the Supreme Court has taken a long step backward in its role as protector of personal liberties. Under the Court's 6to3 ruling, once the police have taken an individual lawfully into custody, even on a minor offense such as a traffic violation, they may search him for evidence of more serious, unrelated crimes.

title: CONSUMER PANEL CHARGES POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The chairman and three members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission accused the Nixon Administration today of hampering the agency's effectiveness by insisting on political clearance for toplevel staff appointees.

title: ExLoan Chief Guilty
description: Louis A. Reiter, former head of the Municipal Loan Program for slum rehabilitation, was found guilty in State Supreme Court on larceny charges stemming from the scandal that shook the program two years ago. Details on Page 60.

title: Byrne Is Opposed to a Further Delay Of Feb. 1 Car Exhaust Inspection Plan
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18  Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne announced this evening that he was opposed to any further delay of mandatory automobile exhaust inspections in New Jersey.

title: Marovich Gets 34 as Hawks Win
description: LARGO, Md., Dec. 18 (AP) Pete Maravich bounced back from a 2point performance in his last game to score 34 points tonight and Iead the Atlanta Hawks to a 9891 victory over the Capital Bullets in the National Basketball Association.

title: UNFAIRNESS LAID TO CREDIT AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)  The largest credit reporting company in the country has been using unfair and deceptive tactics to gather its information, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Agnew Asks Suspension, Not Disbarring
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 18Spiro T. Agnew asked Maryland's judiciary today to suspend rather than disbar him, giving him a second chance at the practice of lawa chance, he said, to resume a useful place and, perhaps, attempt to bring credit on his state and his profession.

title: Group Says 15 Stores Sell Potentially Perilous Toys
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18 Potentially dangerous toys can be purchased in toy departments in 15 northern New Jersey stores, according to a surIvey conducted this month by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit student corporation affiliated with Ralph Nader.

title: WILSON SWORN IN; PUTS TOP PRIORITY ON HUMAN NEEDS
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18Malcolm Wilson was sworn in today as New York's 50th Governor and immediately promised he would be no caretaker, but rather show himself to be progressive in meeting human needs and conservative in handling the people's tax dollars.

title: Books of The Times
description: WOMEN WRITERS IN FRANCE. By Germaine Bree. 90 pages. Rutgers University Press. $5.

title: Advertising: Magazine Markets
description: Traditionally editors have started magazines that attracted readers who were then used to attract advertisers. The more successful new magazines are still following this method. New York is one example. Ms. is another.

title: Planner for City Focuses on People
description: To most New Yorkers, city planning and zoning are intricate, abstruse subjects shrouded in such seemingly bloodless exotica as floorarea ratios and joint interest districts.

title: People and Business
description: Charles J. Pilliod Jr., president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds Russell DeYoung, who will continue as chairman and who plans to retire next April at the mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: Cubans Identified As Main Supplier Of Cocaine Here
description: TRENTON Dec. 18  A Cuban narcotics ring, operating between the Miami area and northern New Jersey, was identified by law enforcement officials today as the prime source of cocaine for the New York metropolitan area.

title: A Cuban Ring Is Identified As Main Cocaine Supplier
description: TRENTON Dec. 18  A Cuban narcotics ring, operating between the Miami area and northern New Jersey, was identified by law enforcement officials today as the prime source of cocaine for the New York metropolitan area.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Senate judiciary subcommittee approved the nomination of Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, to a Federal judgeship. The nomination was sent to the full committee, where swift action was expected. Confirmation could occur before Congress adjourns at the end of the week.

title: A.T.&T. Advanced in Quarter and Year
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in all phases of its operations for the three months and year ended Nov. 30.

title: Nixon Signs Bill Authorizing $2.39Billion in Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) President Nixon has signed the $2.39billion foreign aid authorization bill, the White House said today.

title: Curb on Portable Toilets
description: WAKE FOREST, N.C., Dec. 18 (AP)The portable toilets at ponstruction sites and public events have been added to the list of casualties of the energy crisis. George. Mackie Jr., president of Industrial Plastics of Louisburg, Inc., said today that his company had discontinued the manufacture of Fiberglas portable toilets because the price of petroleum based styrene used in their manufacture has risen so high.

title: U.S. Aides Walk Out Of Vietnam Meeting To Protest Slaying
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The United States and South Vietnamese delegations walked out of a meeting today of the joint military team looking for missing soldiers after flinging onto the conference table the bloodstained jacket of an American officer killed during a search last Saturday.

title: Ballet: Sunny Mexicans
description: New York can do with little warmth and sunshine right now, and it is right at hand at the City Center 55 Street Theater where last night the amiable Ballet Folklorico of Mexico began a threeweek season. If you can't get to Mexico this Christmas, let Mexico come to you.

title: Canadiens Score, 41, Over Seals
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 18 (UPI) Firstperiod goals by Claude Larose and Frank Mahovlich led the Montreal Canadiens to a 41 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.It was the seventh game in a row without a defeat for the Canadiens, who hold second place in the National Hockey Leaguers East Division.Montreal picked up secondperiod goals by Serge Savard and Larry Robinson while Stan Weir prevented the Canadien's rookie goalie, Bunny Larocque, from gaining his first shutout when he scored midway in the final period.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Rev. Theodore Pitcairn, 80 , Dies; Art Collector and Philanthropist
description: The Rev. Theodore Pitcairn, a clergyman and multimillionaire art collector and philanthropist, died Monday at his home in. Bryn Athyn, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: British Labor's Abolition Plan Scraping Raw Nerve of Class
description: LONDON, Dec. 18With a passion they usually reserve for discussions of football and the high cost of maintaining the Queen's pomp, Britons have been debating a Laber party plan to abolish Eton, Harrow and all the other private, freechanging schools.

title: 2 Children Die in Blaze
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 (UPI)Two young children burned to death and four other members of their family were injured in a fire at their home last night when a match was dropped at the base of a kerosene stove on the first floor of the twostory brick residence. The police said Craig Wilson, 3 years old, and Lilton Wilson, 7, had died in the blaze, which extensively damaged the home of Katie Wilson.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1973

title: Manhattan Sets Back Hofstra Five
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 18 George Bucci had 21 points and Bill Campion. 18 tonight as Manhattan defeated Hofstra, 7751.

title: Mattel Plans Sale of Ringling Bros.
description: Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toy producer, annoutaced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent to sell its wholly owned subsidiary, Ringling Bros.Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., to a major United States industrial corporation, which it did not identify. The sale would also include Ringling Bros. Circus World Theme Park, which is now under development near Disneyland in Orlando, Fla.

title: 5 in Bronx Street Gang Indicted as Extortioners
description: Five members of a Bronx street gang were indicted yesterday for the extortion of money and food from two South Bronx grocers.

title: COLLEGE ENJOYS WINDFALL IN ART
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 18An unexpected legacy came to Salve Regina, a small liberal arts college here, when two old paintings that for many years had hung above a stair landing in the school, a former mansion, brought $376,650 in a London auction last week. Just recently they had been identified as the work of the great Renaissance painter Paolo Veronese.

title: Senate Votes Lobster Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Senate passed today a measure designed to protect New England's $35millionayear lobster catch from foreign fisherman. Senator Edmund S, Muskie, Democrat of Maine, who noted that from 16 million to 22 million pounds of lobster are caught off the coast each year by foreign fleets, said, This measure should insure that foreign fleets would be subject to at least the same restrictions as American lobstermen.

title: PAPERS, UNION SLATE AUTOMATION PARLEY
description: Discussions on the automation issues between Typographical Union No. 6 and the city's major daily newspapers are scheduled to begin on Jan. 7, Theodore W. Kheel, mediator, said yesterday.

title: The Youngsters Love Outrageous Socks: Why Have Drab Feet?
description: When the stockings are hung by the chimney with care, there are some that will simply not hang there. They kick up such a fuss, these socks.

title: 300 Extra Lilco Workmen Toil to Repair Storm Damage
description: MINEOLA, L. L, Dec. 18Three hundred extra crewmen of the Long Island Lighting Company worked today to clear up the mess created by Sunday night's snow storm.

title: TEAMSTERS SEEK NEW WAGE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The teamsters' union demanded today that its national contract with the trucking industry be reopened to increase the wages of overtheroad truckers whose earnings are being eroded by the fuel shortage.

title: WILSON SWORN IN; PUTS TOP PRIORITY ON HUMAN NEEDS
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18Malcolm Wilson was sworn in today as New York's 50th Governor and immediately promised he would be no caretaker, but rather show himself to be progressive in meeting human needs and conservative in handling the people's tax dollars.

title: Cordin First In Downhill; Collombin 2d
description: ZELL AM SEE, Austria, Dec. 18 (AP)Karl Cordin of Austria, who hadn't won a World Cup race since 1971, recorded a convincing victory today in a downhil race.

title: Soviet Fears Terrorist Attack Will Jeopardize Peace Parley
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18The SoViet Union today indicated concern that yesterday's massacre by Arab terrorists at Rome's international airport might jeopardize the Middle East peace conference slated to begin later this week in Geneva.

title: ARAB HIJACKERS LAND IN KUWAIT; HOSTAGES FREED
description: Arab terrorists who attacked Rome's international airport Monday and hijacked a West German airliner to Athens flew to Kuwait yesterday and released their hostages in exchange for free passage to an unknown destination.

title: Survey Shows That Athletes Also Have a Credibility Gap
description: Would a sports fan in Iowa buy a used plow from Howard Cosell? Would he admire Ted Williams more than O. J. Simpson as an athlete? Or like Jackie Stewart more than Johnny Bench as an individual? Or, if he is young, trust George Allen more than Arnold Palmer? Should the Government take more control of sports to eliminate monopolies, drugs and fixing?

title: Turnpike Agency Contests Byrne's Rejection of Spur
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 18 The New Jersey Turnpike Authority refused today to accept as final Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne's rejection of a planned expressway link between the turnpike and East Brunswick and the Garden State Parkway and Toms River on the shore.

title: TOMCOMPERE,EDITOR ON HERALD TRIBUNE
description: Tom Compere, who was day city editor of The New York Herald Tribune in the nineteenthirties and forties, died Monday at Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 170 West 73d Street and in Rosendale, N.Y.

title: Levy Denies Any Involvement In Traffic TicketFixing Plan
description: Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, denied from the witness stand yesterday that he had ever been involved in a scheme to fix 2,000 parking tickets. He attributed the scheme to a man who had turned state's evidence to testify against him.

title: Dita Beard Dropped as Witness After Two Psychiatric Reports
description: The Watergate special prosecutor has decided not to call Mrs. Dita D. Beard as a witness before the Watergate grand jury, following two psychiatric examinations of the former lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: About New York Welcome Mat Was Seldom Out
description: A black executive of 35 came to the city from Washington two years ago, and left behind him a divorced wife and a house of three floors for which he had made mortgage payments of $181 a month. In the beginning, he did not know which he missed most, his wife or his house, but since his company was putting him up here in a comfortable suite at the Warwick Hotel, it was probably his wife.

title: G.A.O. Critical of Outlays On Nixon'ss Private Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The General Accounting Office, reporting on its review of Federal spending on President Nixon's private residences, called today for Congressional action to provide closer control over and greater public disclosure of such expenditures in the future.

title: Congress Approves Curb On Naming Budget Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Congress has passed and sent to the White House a bill to make future budget directors subject to Senate confirmation.

title: List of Dead on Pan Am Jet
description: ROME, Dec. 18Following a list, made public today by Pan American World Airways, of names of 30 people presumed killed in yesterday's attack by Palestinian guerrillas at the international airport here. In addition to the 30 passengers and Pan Am employes, an Italian policeman was killed near the Lufthansa jet that was commandeered.

title: Girls in Junior R.O.T.C.
description: JESUP, Ga., Dec. 18 (UPI)The girls have just about taken over the Air Force Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps program at Wayne County High School, The new commander of cadets is Karen Jackson and the cadet executive officer is Loretta Rogers, Boys now hold only three of the 11 staff positions in the unit.

title: Secretariat Is Voted Horse of Year
description: Meadow Stable's Secretariat, the first Triple Crown winner in 25 years, was voted horse of the year yesterday in the Eclipse Award balloting as well as the top 3yearold and grass champion.

title: Plea by 4 in Chicago 7 Case
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UPI)Appeals have been filed by four persons convicted Dec. 4 of contempt of court in connection with the conspiracy trial of the Chicago Seven in 196970. The appeals were filed yesterday by David Dellinger, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin, three of the original defendants, and William M. Kunstler, a defense attorney.

title: People in Sports: Mrs. Court Pregnant, Hangs Up Racquet
description: Mrs. Margaret Court is pregnant with her second child and has withdrawn from the Australian team in the $30,000 Bonne Bell Cup tennis competition against the United States starting Friday at Sydney. The 31yearold star also withdrew from the Australian open championship to be played in Melbourne. She has won 23 of 26 tournaments and $205,000 this year. She and her husband, Barry, have a 21monthold son, Danny.

title: Hearing Set on Oil Leases
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 18 (UPI) Federal District Judge W. Terrell Hodges today set a hearing for 1:30 P.M. tomorrow in a suit in which the Sierra Club, an environmental organization, seeks to block the letting of offshore oil drilling leases in the Gulf of Mexico. Bids are scheduled to be opened by the Federal Government in New Orleans on Thursday.

title: THOUSANDS AWAIT UTILITY SERVICES
description: Numbed thousands of residents of the tristate region awaited an end to their ordeal by ice yesterday despite dogged efforts to restore power and heat, telephone service and transportation to normal in the frigid aftermath of the storm that enveloped the area.

title: Syrians Refuse to Attend Peace Parley at Geneva
description: MADRID, Dec. 18  Syria, accusing the United States and Israel of maneuvers that would lead us into an endless wilderness, declared today that she would not attend the Middle East peace conference that is about to open in Geneva.

title: City Lets Con Ed Use Coal at One Plant
description: Consolidated Edison began making final arrangements yesterday to burn coal for the first time in more than two years after the city, as expected, gave its formal approval for the burning of the dirtier, but more plentiful, fuel during the energy crisis.

title: Rodino Hopes to Finish Inquiry On Impeachment by the Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Representative Peter W. Rodino, New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he expected the inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon to be completed this spring.

title: Soyuz 13 Orbits Earth
description: The Soviet Union launched Soyuz 13 into earth orbit, its second manned space mission in three months in a new demonstration of confidence in its modified craft. Page 85.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jury selection in the second bank robbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, reputed members of the Black Liberation Army, began yesterday in Federal Court here. The proceedings were disrupted by frequent attempts by Evelyn Williams, Mrs. Chesimard's attorney, to be relieved of her duties in the case. Miss Williams said she disagreed with her client and with the attorney for Mr. Hilton, Robert Bloom, over the nature of the defense.

title: Inaugural Address of Governor Wilson
description: Following is a transcript of Gov. Malcolm Wilson's inaugural address in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Duncan R. Cameron Resigns As Brooklyn Museum Director
description: Duncan F. Cameron, director of the Brooklyn Museum, resigned late last night from the job he has held for 30 months. His resignation was accepted with reluctance by the museum's governing committee, by an 18 to 7 vote early this morning.

title: Soyuz 13 Orbits Earth
description: The Soviet Union launched Soyuz 13 into earth orbit, its second manned space mission in three months in a new demonstration of confidence in its modified craft. Page 85.

title: Soviet Dancer Gets Exit Visa but Wife Must Stay
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) Valery Panov, one of the Soviet Union's bestknown ballet dancers, was told today that he could finally emigrate to Israel, but that his wife would have to stay in the Soviet Union. Mr'Panov said he refused the offer.

title: Text of Note To Waldheim
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.Following is the text of a letter presented in identical versions to Secretary General Waldheim today by the United States and the Soviet Union, concerning the scheduled Middle East peace conference:

title: ExLoan Chief Guilty
description: Louis A. Reiter, former head of the Municipal Loan Program for slum rehabilitation, was found guilty in State Supreme Court on larceny charges stemming from the scandal that shook the program two years ago. Details on Page 60.

title: TEAMSTERS SEEK NEW WAGE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The teamsters' union demanded today that its national contract with the trucking industry be reopened to increase the wages of overtheroad truckers whose earnings are being eroded by the fuel shortage.

title: Agnew Asks Suspension, Not Disbarring
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 18Spiro T. Agnew asked Maryland's judiciary today to suspend rather than disbar him, giving him a second chance at the practice of lawa chance, he said, to resume a useful place and, perhaps, attempt to bring credit on his state and his profession.

title: Token Job Program . . .
description: The energy crisis and the threat of recession confront national economic policy with a doubleedged problem. On one side, the fuel shortage is causing production cutbacks and manpower layoffs. The unemployment rate, which was 4.7 per cent last month, could reach 6.5 per cent or higher by next summer. The jobless rolls would then swell from four million to six million.

title: Wall Street Attractions Still Felt by Europeans
description: PARIS, Dec 17Despite the recent steep decline in American stock values, many European portfolio managers still see Wall Street as the best place to invest, and some have been accelerating purchases in recent days.

title: TURNPIKE AGENCY CONTESTING BYRNE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 18  The New Jersey Turnpike Authority refused today to accept as final Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne's rejection of a planned expressway link between the turnpike and East Brunswick and the Garden State Parkway and Toms River on the shore.

title: As F.C.C. Members Leave, Nixon's Influence Grows
description: When President Nixon names a successor on the Federal Communications Commission to H. Rex Lee, who resigned last week, he will have appointed six of the seven members of that regulatory agency. His appointees will number a full seven in June, when the term of Robert E. Lee expires. Not since the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt has the composition of the F.C.C. so borne the stamp of a single President. Since the appointments are for seven years, the effect will be to extend Mr. Nixon's influence upon American communications policy well beyond his own term of office.

title: Skylab Crew, Mission Control Have Settled Their Differences
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 18 (AP)After a ragged start, the Skylab 3 astronauts and Mission Control have patched up their differences and are learning to live with each other.

title: Records
description: Bach's Christmas Oratorio may not be so often performed as Handel's Messiah, but it is worthy of Handel's Christmas perennial, and more specifically appropriate to the season. The piece consists of six cantatas, one for each of the six key days of the Christmas season, and all of them full of Bach's music at its most joyful and devotional.

title: Watergate Panel Votes to Subpoena 200 Tapes and Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 18The Senate Watergate Committee voted unanimously today to subpoena over 200 White House tapes and documents related to its investigation.

title: Waldheim Sends Word To Parley Participants
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18Secretary General Waldheim informed the representatives of Israel, Egypt, Syria and Jordan today that he would convene the Middle East peace conference in Geneva at 10:30 A.M. Friday at the United Nations' European headquarters.

title: Beame Retains Planning Chief
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday reappointed John E. Zuccotti chairman of the City Planning Commission and named a new Commissioner of the Addiction Services Agency.

title: Reiter Guilty on All Counts In City Slum Loan Scandal
description: Louis A. Reiter, a central figure in the scandal that shook the city's loan program for slum rehabilitation two years ago, was found guilty of grand larceny late yesterday by a grand jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Parley of SovietBloc Party Leaders On in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18The Soviet Union, which has privately been pressing for a world gathBring of Communist parties, to day opened a conference of ranking party officials from its inner circle of allies in the Communist movement.

title: Oil and the Economy
description: With varying degrees of sophistication, every American corporation is struggling right now to find the answer to the question: What will the energy crisis do to our company?

title: Nader Staff Lawyer Plays a Nixon Tape At a Cocktail Party
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) A White House tape turned over to a lawyer for Ralph Nader last week was played at a cocktail party last night, the lawyer has confirmed.

title: THAIS MAKE GAINS ON A PARLIAMENT
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 Thailand's twomonthold civilian Government is moving, more or less on schedule, toward turning the country over to a parliamentary system of government after four decades of rarely interrupted military rule.

title: MARCO ON CLARINET :
description: It took only a few moments for John Marco to establish himself as a brilliantly gifted young clarinetist at his Carnegie Recital Hall concert Monday night. The few moments were supplied by Charles Whittenberg's Three Puces for Clarinet Alone (1963), a testing virtuoso exercise that Mr. Marco tossed off with acrobatic agility, precise intonation and satinsmooth tone.

title: NIXON CAN'T RECALL DATA ON STATE TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) An official spokesman said today that President Nixon cant remember if he paid any state income taxes when he served as Vice President and as a member of Congress from California.

title: Class War Rears Up in British Crisis, With Unions the Weapons of Workers
description: LONDON, Dec. 18Whenever a major labor dispute hits Britain, one that affects the national life and economy in some significant way, a mild political tremor passes through this normally placid country.

title: Islanders, Canucks In 22 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 18  One might say the 22 tie the New York Islanders and the Vancouver Canucks played tonight in the Nassau Coliseum was poetic justice.

title: U.N. Rings Down Curtain on Assembly Session to Mixed Reviews
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18The United Nations General Assembly last night recessed a session that was marked by the admission of the two Germanys to membership.

title: House Authorizes Sale Of Some Stockpiled Items
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The House authorized today the sale of materials ranging from opium to copper from the Government's strategic stockpiles.

title: Fuel Crisis Has Ignited Drastic Shifts in Athletics
description: Hundreds of intercollegiate sports events that were originally scheduled for the next six weeks throughout the Northeast are being postponed or canceled because of the fuel crisis.

title: City Accuses 646 As Welfare Cheats Who Got $250,000
description: A sculptor who allegedly had $40,000 in the bank and lived in a luxury cooperative apartment at 30 Fifth Avenue was charged yesterday with swindling the city and state out of $6,256 in undeserved welfare payments.

title: Lindsay Leads T our of Port To Show Its Development
description: By helicopter, bus and on foot, Mayor Lindsay led a tour of citywide port developments yesterday to show how the city, during his two terms, had made a comeback in the utilization of waterfront facilities to increase jobs, revenue and recreation.

title: Pound Makes Small Gains
description: LONDON, Dec. 18The British pound held firm today and managed to eke out small gains in the foreignexchange markets following the British Government's latest proposals to narrow the nation's trade deficit.

title: 2 Rembrandts Stolen By Cincinnati Gunmen
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 18 (UPI)  Two 300yearold Rembrandt paintings, valued at $330,000, were stolen from the Taft Museum today by two masked gunmen.

title: 58 Taxi Drivers, 1 a Woman, Win City Hall Awards
description: Bella Freeman, one of the city's 700 women cab drivers, was honored at City Hall yesterday for outstanding service to the riding publichelping the police to capture a man who had stolen a taxi.

title: Cedeno Slated to Stay In Jail During Holidays
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 18 (AP)Cesar Cedeno will spend Christmas in jail, according to the district attorney who charged him with voluntary homicide in the shooting death of 19yearold Altagracia de la Cruz.

title: 17 Marshals Are Named By Mayor, but Reluctantly
description: Mayor Lindsay appointed 15 new city marshals yesterday and reappointed two existing marshals to sixyear terms.

title: T.W.A. PACT VOTED, ENDING LONG STRIKE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 18 (UPI)Trans World Airlines cabin attendants ratified today a new threeyear labor contract, ending a 45day strike and paving the way for resumption of T.W.A. flights in the morning.

title: TurcotteCordero Race Is Going Down to the Wire
description: To Ron Turcotte and Angel Cordero, the New York racing season is like a basketball gamethe outcome frequently is not decided until the last minute. The local thoroughbred campaign is in its figurative last minute, but to Turcotte and Cordero the current activities are of more importance than at any other time during the long campaign, which ends on Dec. 29.

title: Ford Meets Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Vice President Ford met today with Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger for what was described as a general discussion of defense matters. The Peentagon spokesman, Jerry N, Freidhiem, said the meeting had marked the first time the two men had gotten together since Mr. Ford became Vice President nearly two weeks ago.

title: Israelis Report Exchanges Of Fire With the Egyptians
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Egyptian and Israeli forces exchanged fire on the Suez Canal front today, but there were no Israeli casualties, an Artny communiqu said.

title: Heath Cancels China Trip, Strengthening Talk of Early Election
description: LONDON, Dec. 18  Prime Minister Heath today canceled a scheduled trip to China next month because of the difficult and grave situation arising from Britain's industrial strife and the energy crisis.

title: JAPAN PRODUCERS SET SPENDING CUTS
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18 (AP)Japan's largest producer of heavy electrical equipment announced today plans to trim capital spending and the nation's largest manufacturer of electric home appliances said it was considering a similar move.

title: Wilson Hails Duryea In G.O.P. Unity Scene
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18 Faced with a party split over the indictment of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Governor Wilson, former Gov, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Mr. Duryea and other top Republicans joined in an oftenemotional display of party unity yesterday.

title: Britain's Crisis Budget
description: In presenting his antiInflation budget to Parliament, Chancellor of the Exchequer Anthony Barber echoed Prime Minister Heath's warning of last week that Britain faces its gravest economic situation since the war. But even though it imposed a record cut of $2.76 billion Government spending for the next fiscal year and clamped new curbs on consumer credit, Mr. Barber's budget was much less drastic than anticipated and will not directly affect ordinary Britons in the short run.

title: Reed Will Leave Hospital Today
description: The Knicks announced last night that Willis Reed, their firststring center and captain, would be discharged today from St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City.

title: The Limits Of Power
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18One clear lesson of this extraordinary year is that strong nations and strong institutions within nations have more power than they dare use, but some people still haven't learned the lesson.

title: ARAB HIJACKERS LAND IN KUWAIT; HOSTAGES FREED
description: Arab terrorists who attacked Rome's international airport Monday and hijacked a West German airliner to Athens flew to Kuwait yesterday and released their hostages in exchange for free passage to an unknown destination.

title: Sanitation Unit Greets Storm as Job Training
description: For two years, the legions of city sanitationmen have waited patiently for snow. Their supervisors were even looking forward to it, for they have learned that their men must have the experience of coping with a major storm to be tough and effective.

title: Dinkins Tells of Beame Plan To Plug Gaps in Crime Fight
description: David N. Dinkins, Deputy Mayordesignate for Planning, told members of the Alliance for a Safer New York yesterday that Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame had set an immediate goal of remedying some of the most obvious gaps in the city's ability to deter crime.

title: SenateHouse Unit Votes $73.7Billion In Defense Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  SenateHouse conferees agreed today on a $73.75billion defense appropriation bill. The total is $3.5billion below President Nixon's military budget for the year.

title: Syrians Refuse to Attend Peace Parley at Geneva
description: MADRID, Dec. 18  Syria, accusing the United States and Israel of maneuvers that would lead us into an endless wilderness, declared today that she would not attend the Middle East peace conference that is about to open in Geneva.

title: Finley Files Suit Against Williams
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, sought a court order today to prevent Dick Williams from managing any team other than the A's, as a coasttocoast tangle involving three American League teams became more tangled.

title: House Votes for Group Health Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  A compromise fiveyear, $375million bill to encourage group health plans was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

title: Blue Beats Gray, 2014, With Pair of Field Goals
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 18 (UPI)  John Phillips of Xavier booted field goals of 29 and 33 yards tonight to lead the Blues to a 2014 victory over the Grays in the 36th annual BlueGray football game.

title: Stamford Policeman Slays Second in Holdup Accident
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 18 (UPI)  A police officer was shot to death by another officer here today when the two tried to halt a robber they surprised at a local hotel. The suspect, who was not immediately identified, was wounded and taken into custody.

title: Plan for Mined Lands Set
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced plans today to require that miners and prospectors who use public lands restore them after they are finished. At present, persons seeking minerals on land administered by the Forest Service can bulldoze an area to explore for deposits and leave mine wastes, or tailings, in piles.

title: Choate Takes Problems of Transition in Stride
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Dec. 18Chaplain Edward O. Miller, class of '66, leaned forward in the pulpit of the Choate School chapel to inform the congregation that the temperature inside was 55 degrees.

title: 4 New Keuter Dances
description: The Cliff Keuter Dance Company presented four new works by Mr. Keuter Sunday night at the Broome Street Theater, 330 Broome Street, to open a threeweekend series this month.,

title: Four Blasts in London Linked to I.R.A.
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 Four bombs exploded here today in what police officers believed were reprisal attacks for the jalling of Irish Republican Army terrorists who bombed the Old Bailey last March.

title: Rev. Theodore Pitcairn, 80, Dies; Art Collector and Philanthropist
description: The Rev. Theodore Pitcairn, a clergyman and multimillionaire art collector and philanthropist, died Monday at his home in Bryn Athyn, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: Tanker Runs Aground
description: BUZZARIS BAY, Mass., Dec. 18 (AP)  An empty Greek, tanker ran aground today midway through the Cape Cod Canal but was pulled free about four hours later by two commercial tugs and an Army Corps of Engineers tug. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: G.A.O. Sees Election Law Violations by Nixon Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)An investigation by the General Accounting Office disclosed today three apparent legal violations in the handling of funds to hire two reporters to spy on George McGovern's 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: Bausch & Lomb Expands
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 18 (UPI) Bausch & Lomb, Inc., is expanding its Ferson optics division at Ocean Springs, Miss., at a cost of $4.1million and also has bought a 32,000squarefoot factory on 20 acres for $587,000 as an addition to its Austoin, Tex., plant.

title: Islanders, Canucks In 22 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 18  One might say the 22 tie the New York Islanders and the Vancouver Canucks played tonight in the Nassau Coliseum was poetic justice.

title: Pharmaceuticals Said to Kill 100 Daily
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)More than 100 Americans die daily because of adverse reactions to prescription and legal nonprescription drugs, Ralph Nader told a Senate health subcommittee today.

title: Fighting the Terrorists
description: What additional security, steps can the aviation world take to head off tragedies like the terrorist attack that left at least 32 dead on Monday?

title: JAPAN OFFERING A LOAN TO EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 18Reacting to Arab oil power, Deputy Premier Takeo Miki of Japan said here today, after a meeting with President Anwar elSadat, that Tokyo was eager to extend to Cairo a 25year loan of $140million to assist in widening and deepening the Suez Canal.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MANAGE A RALLY
description: After spending most of the day on the downside, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rallied and closed higher yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Business Briefs
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 18 (AP)The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has laid off about 1,000 workers at one plant here for a week, saying it would reevaluate car makers' needs next week.

title: 2 Passersby Killed In Grenade Attack On Cambodian Aide
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 18 (UPI)The Cambodian Transportation Minister, Thappana Nginn, narrowly escaped assassination today when a man tossed a grenade at his car.

title: Dow Index Up 18.37 In a Technical Rally
description: Stock prices made a brisk technical bounce yesterday as Wall Street entered its holiday phase. Only eight trading days remain in 1973.

title: When the Last Trump Sounds
description: GENEVA  The first time Henry Kissinger, whirling dervish of American diplomacy, became personally involved in the Palestine problem was 1967 when, with no official position, he visited Israel. He suggested to the Israelis, who had recently won their slashing SixDay War, that they should make a precise peace offer yielding at least half the conquered Sinai peninsula. Nothing was done.

title: To Elinor Guggenheimer, Affluence Is No Excuse to Take It Easy
description: At this time of year, Elinor Guggenheimer's bible is somewhat battered and forlorn looking, The blackcovered dimestore appointment book, stuffed into handbags, totes and shopping bags throughout the year, is ready for replacement.

title: Democrats, Too, Afraid Of Watergate Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Democratic officials preparing for Congressional elections of 1974 are fearful that if the Republican elephant stumbles over Watergate, it may fall on top of some Democrats.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Canadiens Score, 41, Over Seals
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 18 (UPI) Firstperiod goals by Claude Larose and Frank Mahovlich led the Montreal Canadiens to a 41 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FAIR LAWN, Dec. 18The Grand Prix of junior tennis came to this town the other day and it was hard to tell who was more excited, the 12yearold racquet swingers competing in the tournament or their parents.

title: The Most Successful American
description: WASHINGTON  The impeachment of Richard Nixon would be the impeachment of us all. Mr. Nixon's chief offense is that so mortal a man, so representative of the flaws of this country, should be President. And the fact that he could become President, and by a record plurality, is itself meaningful in terms of what we have become as a people.

title: Senate Votes to Restore Boycott of Rhodesia Ore
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Senate voted 54 to 37 today in favor of restoring a United States boycott of chrome from Rhodesia after a lapse of two years.

title: General Mills Lists Peak Net and Sales In Second Quarter
description: General Mills, Inc., a leading producer of packaged foods and other consumer products, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter ended Nov. 25. Net profit reached $25million, or $1.06 a share, a 15.2 per cent inerase over the $21.7million, or 92 cents a share, reported in the corresponding quarter last year. Sales were up 20.7 per cent to $555.8million from the $460.5million reported in the 1972 quarter.

title: Books, Records for Children
description: A potpourri of poems, puns, planets and people from around the world in new books and recordings can be found among the 800 titles in the 63d edition of The New York Public Library's Children's Books and Recordings.

title: Redskins May Start Jurgensen
description: If Bill Kilmer cannot attend practice today, the Washington Redskins will turn to Sonny Jurgensen as their quarterback for Saturday's playoff game against the Vikings at Bloomington, Minn. Since Sunday night, Kilmer has been in a hospital at Arlington, Va., with a recurrence of stomach cramps that have bothered him from time to time for years. The 39  year  old Jurgenson limps noticeably because of torn cartilage in his left knee, but he played with distinction in Washington's nexttolast game, a loss to Dallas. Kilmer was the quarterback in the finale, the victory over Philadelphia.

title: AUTO CONSPIRACY IS CHARGED BY U.S.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) General Motors Corporation an the Ford Motor Company used third parties in an alleged plot to end discounts in selling fleets of automobiles, the Governmen contended today.

title: Newsman's Widow Wins Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The widow of a newsman killed covering the East Los Angeles riots in the in August, 1970, today was awarded $700,000 damages. Mrs. Sally Salazar, widow of Ruben Salazar, had originally sued for $1.3million. Mr, Salazar had been covering the riot for the Spanishspeaking television station KMEX. He was hit in the head by a teargas casing.

title: Notes on People
description: Sir Rudolf Bing has been appointed director of collegecommunity cultural affairs at Brooklyn College, where he has been serving as Distinguished Professor. The former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera will be a key element in drawing together the cultural life of the college and the cultural life of the community, strengthening both, according to Dr. John W. Kneller, president of Brooklyn College.

title: Grocers' Supplies Dwindle in Detroit As Strike Goes On
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) Gaps began appearing today on the shelves or grocery stores in the Detroit area as negotiations continued in an effort to end an unauthorized strike by drivers and warehousemen in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Shapiro: du Pont Chief of a New Mold
description: Irving S. Shapiro, who will take over the reins of the du Pont Company on Jan. 1, is a du Pont leader of a different mold. And it does not bother him, he says.

title: StarGazing, and Some Other Fun Things to Do
Saudi Oil Embargo Ii Termed Breach of '33 Treaty With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Specialists in international law in and out of the Government have concluded that the oil embargo against the United States imposed by Saudi Arabia violates a littleknown 1933 treaty between the two countries.

title: 3 FIRMS THREATEN TO QUIT EXCHANGE
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith and two other major Wall Street securities house's said yesterday they would have to consider dropping their membership on the New York Stock Exchange if a controversial reform bill now pending in the Senate became law.

title: Russians Orbit 2 in Modified Soyuz Craft
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18The Sonet Union launched today Soyuz 13, its second manned space mission in three months in a new demonstration of confidence in the modified Soyuz spacecraft to be used for a rendezvous with American astronauts in 1975.

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP)Leonid Zhabotinsky of the Soviet Union set a a world weightlifting record of 407.3 pounds in the snatch today in the superweight class, exceeding by 1.1 pounds the mark of Rudolf Mang of West Germany, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: PLANE FOR PRESS OPPOSED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18President Nixon plans a postChristmas trip to Florida by whatever mode of transportation uses less energy but, because of the fuel shortage, he has ordered that no press plane be chartered by the White House for the trip.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Memorial Gifts Key Part Of Neediest Cases Fund
description: Memorial gifts have long been a major mainstay of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Most often they are sent in memory of a deceased relative, friend, coworker or teacher.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Screen: Family Trouble
description: Mark Rydell's "Cinderella Liberty" is a nicely acted but aggressively false and sentimental comedy about a middleaged sailor, a Seattle whore, and the whore's 11-year-old son who, being pre-pubescent, illegitimate and mulatto, has more problems going for him than anyone connected with the film seems to have recognized. The movie opened yesterday at the Columbia I and Embassy Theaters.James Caan is fine as the dopey sailor who makes the right decision (to settle down) at the wrong time (with the whore). The role is well-written by Darryl Ponicsan, who adapted his novel for the screen. Mr. Ponicsan can write funny dialogue but he has no head for events. Almost everything that happens in the film is unbelievable, designed for short-term audience effect of easy laughter or tears.Mr. Caan ("Brian's Song," "The Godfather") seems to be shaping up as the Paul Newman of the nineteen-seventies, an intelligent, versatile actor with a low-key but unmistakable public personality. Marcia Mason is also good as the wayward woman he marries, so good that you wish the script were equal to the complicated feelings that the actors every now and then manage to project.Mr. Rydell, the director and himself a good actor ("The Long Goodbye"), photographed the movie entirely in Seattle with lots of contrasts between obvious prettiness and dismal squalor, the kind of thing usually fancied by budding film makers. Kirk Calloway underplays the little boy, which is okay, and Eli Wallach overplays Mr. Caan's cashiered sailor-pal as if he were doing an impersonation in someone's living room.

title: F.T.C. Charges Credit Agency With Deception in Its Reporting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 18 (UPI)  The largest credit reporting company in the country has been using unfair and deceptive tactics to gather its information, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: War Slows, Cambodians See Fights
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 18When the war subsides in Cambodia on weekends, as it often does, 10,000 or more people pack themselves into the Olympic Stadium and become for a few hours the Phnom Penh fight crowd.

title: G.A.O. Critical of Outlays On Nixon's Private Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The General Accounting Office, reporting on its review of Federal spending on President Nixon's private residences, called today for Congressional action to provide closer control over and greater public disclosure of such expenditures in the future.

title: 2,437 Applicants, a Record Number, Pass Written Test for Admission to the Bar
In Geneva, U.N. Prepares for Parley
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18It's like a scene from Alice in Wonderland, a United Nations official observed here today. They are all gathering for a conference that has yet to be called in response to invitations that have yet to be issued.

title: Music: Lively AllAmerican Evening
description: Morton Gould, one of our leading experts in musical Americana both as composer and conductor, stuck to his last in his concert with the American Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Monday night. In a lively allAmerican program of works by himself, George Gershwin, Charles Ives and Aaron Copland, the most curious and interesting item (but not the best) was Ives's First Symphony.

title: THOUSANDS Mt AIT UTILITY SERVICES
description: Numbed thousands of residents of the tristate region awaited an end to their ordeal by ice yesterday despite dogged efforts to restore power and heat, telephone service and transportation to normal in the frigid aftermath of the storm that enveloped the area.

title: Head of E.P.A. Warns on a Sellout
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that an environmental sellout would not ease the energy crisis but would only jeopardize public health.

title: HOUSING STARTS STEADY IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Housing starts leveled off, at least temporarily, in November after a steep decline that began last spring, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Fantastic Planet' Is Animated Feature
description: Peace in outer space may be fine for Christmas but as a plot resolution it dampens and flattens "Fantastic Planet." Except for this curiously tame windupwhen things should have been poppingthis is highly engrossing science-fiction, a French-Czechoslovak co-production in animation.The technique itself is fascinating. Instead of using the traditional method of drawing on acetate, the ingenious producers have sketched on cut-out and hinged paper. This comparative stiffness of movement, instead of the usual animated flash, gives a dignity and eerie depth to an adaptation by directors Rene Laloux and Roland Topor of Stefan Wul's novel, "Ome En Serie."The story itself is a sci-fi honey, with tiny earthlings "from a destroyed planet" dominated as pets or outcasts by huge, robot-like rulers. This is somber, dead-earnest stuff. And when a Lilliputian revolution explodes, brilliantly evoked, the planet Ygam rocks.The settings and deep panorama, while Deliesque in form, are colored in subdued pastels. Even the English titles, to spoken French, provide an outer-space flavor.There is some inoffensive nudity and not one smidgen of humor, not even for Christmas. As for that ending, it simply seemed too tidy too soon. But for original, thoughtful, often strong (but tasteful) animation, I recommend "Fantastic Planet" for family viewing.The Roger Corman presentation, for New World Pictures, is at the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: IRAQIS INCREASING OIL PRODUCTION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 (AP)Iraq is increasing her oil production because she does not believe that the indiscriminate use of the Arabs' socalled oil weapon is a sound policy, the Iraqi Minister of Oil and Minerals, Dr. Saadun Hammadi, said today.

title: Man, 77, Burned to Death While His Family Is Out
description: A 77yearold Queens man burned to death last night apparently after he fell asleep, while smoking in an armchair in the basement kitchen of his son's home at 7244 Cooped Avenue, in the Ridgewood section, the police reported.

title: Common Market Solidarity Slips On Funds to Aid Ailing Regions
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18Foreign Ministers of the nine European Common Market countries be came deadlocked today over effotts to establish a fund to, aid economically ailing regions of their community.

title: New Killing on St. Croix Brings Toll for Year to 12
description: CHRISTIANSTED, V.I., Dec. 18 (UPI)  A 21yearold man was shot to death by a gunman who fired from a speeding car last night. It was the 12th slaying on the island of St. Croix this year.

title: DAVID BECKER
description: CONWAY, Mass., Dec. 18David Becker, past president of the Westchester Pharmaceutical Association, died today at the home of his son, Stephen Becker. He was 81 years old.

title: Conferees Vote President Free Rein to Allot Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Senate and House negotiators agreed today to give President Nixon unrestricted authority to implement gasoline rationing, without approval of Congress. The negotiators also agreed to allow the President to order other energy conservation measures until. June 30, subject only to veto by either house of Congress.

title: Nixon Signs Franking Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)  President Nixon signed into law today the Congressional franking reform bill that prohibits mass mailings by any member of Congress within 28 clays before a primary or general election in which he is a candidate.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Prison Life
description: TERMINAL ISLAND, Calif.It is difficult, nudging the edge of the impossible, for me to digest my thoughts about my jail and prison experience. can only skim the surface in a limited way that, at times, becomes emotional due to my nature and the way this experience has interacted with my own beliefs and expectations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the face of the current shortfall between U.S. energy demand and supply, the seeming prejudgment in The Times editorial pages against the generation of power from the heat of nuclear fissioning is disturbing.

title: Editor's Slayer Sentenced
description: CHICAGO, Dec, 18 (UPI)Charles McAdams, 25 years old, was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for the fatal beating of a Chicago Daily. NewsSun Times wire service editor, John Dudley Chamberlain, 56, with whom he shared an apartment.

title: Animal Disease Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) A $45million animal health research bill was approved by the House Agricuture Committee today. It is designed to help prevent disease, that would be disastrous to the livestock and poultry industries.

title: Serpico Film Draws Fire From Cast
description: The popular new movie Serpico has been generally praised for its authenticity, for its feel of truth, Yet many of the reallife characters who took part in the events upon which the movie is based are openly angry about what they consider to be distortions, misplaced emphasis and outright inventions.

title: GARRISON IS LOSER IN OFFICIAL COUNT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 (UPI)Official tabulations today showed that Jim Garrison lost to former United States Attorney Harry F. Connick by 2,221 votes in the controversial district attorney's bid for a fourth consecutive term in the Democratic primary.

title: FORTUNE DONATED TO HELP STUDENTS
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 18 (UPI)  Vartakes Migrdichian, an Armenian immigrant, has added still another chapter to his ragstoriches life story by donating his fortune to the education of needy Armenian students.

title: U.S. AIDE FORECASTS RISE IN FOOD PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Retail food prices may rise over the next three months as beef and pork supplies shrink again, an Agriculture Department food economist said today.

title: Curran Says Coverage of a Raid Didn't Hinder FreeTrial Rights
description: News coverage of a massive narcotics raid did not deprive the defendants of their right to a fair trial, acording to documents filed in Federal Court here yesterday by Paul J. Curran, the United States Attorney for the Southern District.

title: 2 Army Deserters of Vietnam War Plan to Invite Arrests Today
description: Somewhere in New York City today, two deserters are expected publicly to invite arrest, both facing possible threeyear prison sentences.

title: SINGLE ENERGY UNIT IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) The House voted today to consolidate all energy research and development programs under a single agency, the Energy Research and Development Administration.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 19Attorney General Kingsley Cheney of Vermont said today he believed that any refusal by gasoline station operators to sell fuel to outofstaters was illegal. He said he had learned of isolated cases where skiers from other states were denied gasoline. Cheney said Vermont's Consumer Protection Law and Federal regulations specify equitable distribution of all petroleum products.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Basketball is a strange sport. No matter what happens in the earliest stages of a game or the season, virtually all of the excitement, intensity and suspense is jammed into the closing stages. Rallies and counterrallies add the turmoil of tumultuous, tempestuous finishes and give the dribble diversion its extra emotion appeal.

title: Snow Shortage Slows Ski Plans of Italian Resort
description: LEVICO, ItalyJust when resort owners in this scenic southern Dolomite region of the Alps were ready to launch a major drive for American skiers, along came early December weather that has defied belief. Through the first half of the month, most of the crests on the towering ranges in this province of Trentino were brown. Those that weren't brown had about enough white powder for a goodsized snowball fight.

title: 2 Deserters Give In Here to Stress Plea for Amnesty
description: One tall agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation darted out of a crowd and wordlessly yanked Eddie McNally, a 23yearold Army deserter, into an awaiting Government car.

title: Atlanta Seeking Sugarman For CityManager Position
description: The Mayorelect of Atlanta has discussed appointing Jule M. Sugarman, New York City's Human Resources Administrator, as Atlanta's chief administrative officera citymanager type of post scheduled to be strengthened next year.

title: Accused Killers in Court
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Dec. 19 (UPI)Two young drifters who are charged with killing nine persons in the small community of Victor, Calif., were manacled and brought into court yesterday but delayed entering pleas. The cases of Douglas Gretzler, 22 years old, of New York, and William L. Steelman, 28, of nearby Lodi, were continued until Jan. 3 in San Joaquin County Superior Court.

title: Prison Study Plea Fails
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Dec. 19 (AP)Dan Wilson told the judge he could study a lot better in prison than out so he wanted a fiveyear instead of a threeyear term in order to complete work on his degree. But United State, District Judge D. W. Suttle gave him only three years on an illegal weapons charge. Mr. Wilson, 27 years old, says he hat, already completed 27 hours of credit from two separate prison terms.

title: Pope, Horrified by Rome Attack, Fears Effect on Geneva Parley
description: ROME, Dec. 19Pope Paul VI expressed fears today that the murderous guerrilla attack on Rome's international airport this week might adversely affect the Middle East peace conference opening in Geneva on Friday.

title: $1.8Billion in 1974
description: Texaco, Inc., the nation's third largest oil company, now estimates that investment for capital improvements and exploration will reach $1.6billion in 1973 and next year will go to $1.8billion.

title: Nets Top Colonels, 8382, in Cold Gym
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 19 Nassau Coliseum was the toughest place in pro basketball tonight to make a basket. Luckily for the New York Nets, it was a point tougher for their opponent, the Kentucky Colonels, who dropped an 8382 verdict and fell into a virtual tie with the Nets, though they lead them by 16 percentage points for second place.

title: Exit Mr. Laird
description: Even though Melvin R. Laird combined his resignation as President Nixon's chief domestic counselor with denial that he had been disappointed over his relations with the President, it is no secret that Mr. Laird's influence could never match that of the diminished inner circle of the White House palace guard. The marginal nature of the Laird role was accurately summed up Senator Goldwater's observation that Mr. Nixon sits by himself and tells himself what he's going to do.

title: Files Are Said to Cast Doubt on I.T.T. Deal;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The Securities and Exchange] Commission has material in its files casting doubt on the legality of a key transaction in 1969 that made possible the takeover of the Hartford Fire. Insurance Company by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according; to informed sources.

description: United by the fear that the energy crisis will jeopardize the very existence of the performing arts in this country, 85 representatives of dance and concert organizations, arts associations, managers and unions formed an emergency coalition yesterday to present their plight to the Federal Energy Office and to fight for their collective lives.

description: Reports that the Administration would impose an excise tax on crude oil products eroded a stockmarket rally yesterday.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 The energy crisis has spawned a new regional selfinterest in the major oil and natural gas producing states where, for the first time since World War II, fuel for local industry, homes and farms is running short and getting expensive.

title: Brooklyn Museum's CommitteeLauds Cameron, Accepts Blame
description: A dispute has arisen over the text of a resolution adopted by the governing committee of the Brooklyn Museum yesterday concerning the resignation of Duncan F. Cameron as the museum's director.

title: Bus Service Sought To Carry Workers To Middlesex Jobs
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 19  The Southern Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce has begun a campaign to provide public transportation for workers and employers in the area because of the prospect of an almostcertain sharp curtailment of the use of private automobiles during the energy crisis.

title: Dontzin, Lindsay's Counsel, To Be Criminal Court Judge
description: Michael J. Dontzin, counsel to Mayor Lindsay, will be appointed a Criminal Court judge by the Mayor, City Hall sources said yesterday. The judgeship has an annual salary of $30,750.

title: BANKRUPT ROADS TO BE REVAMPED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  A HouseSenate conference committee agreed today on legislation to restructure bankrupt railroads east of the Mississippi under a new Government rail corporation.

title: Dublin Court Lifts Ban on Importing Of Contraceptives
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 19  The Irish Republic's ban on importing contraceptives was held unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court, the highest of Irish courts.

description: Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau appealed yesterday to President Nixon for emergency action to help ease the impact of the ice storm that has spread hazard and hardship through the tristate region.

title: U.S. Energy Crisis Stirs SelfInterest of Regions
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 the energy crisis has spawned a new regional selfinterest in the major oil and natural gas producing states where, for the first time since World War II, ??uel for local industry, homes and farms is running short and getting expensive.

title: Livestock Futures Up as Bad Weather Hits Chicago Area
description: Bad weather in the Middles West and the imminence of a Government report or hogs, due after the close of trading Friday, had an impact on both hog and cattle futures prices yesterday.

title: New ProfitReducing Plan Would Keep Oil Incentive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The emergency windfall profits tax on producers of crude oil proposed by President Nixon today is unlike any tax used before in the United States.

title: Williams and Finley Awaiting a Decision by Cronin
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)Joe Cronin, president of the American League, took under advisement today the dispute between the Oakland A's and New York over the Yankees' hiring of Manager Dick Williams.

title: Aide to Levitt Is Indicted in Bribery Case
description: An administrative assistant to the State Controller has been indicted on charge's of attempted bribery, conspiracy and grand larceny.

title: Physicians Throughout the World Are Studying New, Simple Technique for Terminating Pregnancies
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 19  A new method of ending an unwanted pregnancy, developed by a psychologist, promoted by women's groups and surrounded by intense medical controversy, is now being studied carefully by physicians throughout the world.

title: Happy 40th Birthday
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Planned obsolescence is as old as man. Nature built into us a few thinwalled shock absorbers and a finite number of matted cushions, useful, for a predictable period, against the mad sorties of fortune. And of all man's absorber warpers, the most damaging is a wife's fortieth birthday.

title: Beame Names a Lawyer as Parks Chief
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beanie yesterday appointed a new Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, who said he would demand that any museums receiving money from the city make detailed financial reports.

title: COMPETITOR BUYING EXECUTIVE AIRLINES
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)Executive Airlines, once the biggest commuter airline in New England, was sold today to Air New England, its major competitor.

title: KAWAIDA BACKERS, ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19Legal arguments on Newark's controversial Kawaida Towers housing project were heard in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court today as the lawyer for the Newark City Count cil tried to make a point that the development's backers had defrauded the city on applying for a tax abatement.

title: Film: Underwater Talkie:Scott Stars in Nichols's 'Day of the Dolphin' The Cast
description: In the superb opening shot of Mike Nichols's "The Day of the Dolphin," a large, sleek, blue dolphin suddenly leaps from the surface of the sea straight into the sky as if to break through all barriers of space, time and intelligence. The motion is slow. Drops of water change shape in airy suspension. The soundtrack heralds the event with the kind of aural splendor that accompanied the Dawn of Man sequence in Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey."Then you notice something oddly, purposely deflating: the dolphin has an orange ball in its mouth.The leap that seemed to announce the dawn of the dolphin prompts, instead, memories of last winter's visit to Marineland. Performances every hour. Popcorn, peanuts, postcards and souvenirs."The Day of the Dolphin," which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld Theater, is no dawn-of-a-new-era fiction, nor was the original Robert Merle novel, though it was inspired to a large extent by the research of American scientists, including Dr. John C. Lilly, who spent years trying to teach dolphins how to speak English.Working (sometimes desperately) in several genres that are not their own, Mr. Nichols, one of America's most elegant directors of high comedy and low, and Buck Henry, his screenwriter, whose gift is for tumultuous satire ("Catch-22," "Is There Sex After Death?"), have made a Flipper film for adults, a "Day of the Jackal" for kids and a Lassie film for scuba divers of all ages.There also are reminders of "Born Free," "Black Beauty," "Frankenstein," and at least one of the sequels to "Planet of the Apes." "The Day of the Dolphin" is not a movie with much personality of its own.Unlike Dr. Lilly, who finally gave up his work on the grounds that it was cruel to take away the dolphins' freedom in the interests of research, the hero of "The Day of the Dolphin" pursues his experiments to their successful conclusion.Dr. Jake Teller (George C. Scott), the head of a privately funded research center near Miami, scores his breakthrough when he separates his 4-year-old male dolphin, nicknamed Fa, from Fa's mate, Bi.
