title: Weekly Truck Tonnoge Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported today intercity truck tonnage was an estimated 10.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

title: Paine, Webber to Submit Plan for Holding Company
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis will submit to its stockholders on Jan. 14 a plan to restructure its organization through the formation of a holding company, to be known as Paine Webber, Inc., the firm announced yesterday.

title: New Columbia Coach Wins One
description: Columbia University gave Bill Campbell a threeyear contract and a onemonth extension on this winter's application date for athletes yesterday when it signed him as head football coach.

title: Senate Backs Women In Military Academies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)The Senate voted today to permit the admission of women candidates to the nation's military service academies.

title: HEATLESS TENANTS PRESS CALLS HERE
description: The city was swamped with tenant complaints about inadequate heat during the last week as many apartment buildings ran out of fuel and others curtailed heating periods to conserve existing oil reserves.

title: Slippery Oil Tax
description: In its package of moves to deal with the oil shortage, the Administration is loading enormous burdens on consumers, seeking to abandon the idea of an equitable rationing system, and providing huge profits to the oil companies. In presenting a program of such design, President Nixon has resorted to rhetoric that suggests he is serving consumer interests and guarding against windfall profits. What he is doing is the opposite.

title: STATE TRANSIT AID IS CUT $76MILLION IN CONFEREES' BILL
description: A SenateHouse conference committee has agreed on an $800million masstransit bill that would give New York State $76million less in Federal operating subsidies than it would have received under the House version.

title: Jews at ChristmastimeIs It Proper to Join in the Holiday?
description: To many Jewish parents, it's the December dilemmathe question of what to do about Christmas in a land that reveres the holiday not only at the altar, but in the marketplace, the office, the classroom, in every lobby, on every street corner.

title: MRS. MEIR BACKED ON GENEVA POLICY
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20In a turbulent special session of Parliament, Premier Golda Meir today explained and defended Israel's decision to participate in the Geneva peace conference opening tomorrow.

title: Gas Restriction and Rain Dampen Weekend Outlook
description: Operators of ski areas throughout the Northeast received two new rebuffs yesterday. One was that William E. Simon, the nation's new energy chief, had asked Americans to reduce gasoline consumption to 10 gallons a week. The other bad news came with the weather report. Rain, perhaps heavy at times, was forecast for this morning and afternoon for almost all of the ski country. Even Canada's Laurentians were expected to receive a drenching.

title: Snowstorms Batter Eastern Midwest And Leave 21 Dead
description: A great eveofwinter storm battered the eastern Midwest yesterday with record snows and marooned thousands of travelers, all but paralyzing many cities and hamlets between the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes. At least 21 deaths were attributed to the storm.

title: Miss Wenzel Captures World Cup Giant Slalom
description: ZELL AM SEE, Austria, Dec. 20 (AP)Hanni Wenzel, a 19yearold German skiing for Liechtenstein, won her first World Cup ski race today, the giant slalom.

title: Cold Damages Sugar Crop
description: CLEWISTON, Fla., Dec. 20 (UPI)Sugar mills are working around the clock to harvest frostdamaged sugar cane, but industry officials fear the efforts will not be able to prevent the loss of about 10 per cent of the state's cane. J. Nelson Fairbanks, general manager of the Florida Sugar Cane League, said yesterday that the state (would probably lose 10 to 20 per centa minmum of $20millionof its sugar crop because of this week's freezing temperatures.

title: Selected Short Subjects at the Whitney
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has a generally good roundup of 14 short film subjects titled Animation, a new program opening yesterday for two weeks. A couple of them are duds. Some of the better pictures are simply too short. Fittingly, the program closes with a dazzling tour de force, Philip Jones's Secrets (eight minutes).

title: Compliance With the City's EnergySaving Plan Is Found Spotty
description: A city inspector who was sent yesterday to check on compliance by city agencies with Mayor Lindsay's energysaving directives found the results spotty.

title: Spanish Premier, Closest Friend of Franco, Stood Devotedly in His Shadow
description: Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, the Premier of Spain, who died yesterday in an explosion that shattered his car, had stood for years in the shadow of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, firmly attentive and unfailingly devoted.

title: The Focal U.N. Resolution on Mideast
description: A focal issue in the negotiations on Middle East peace will be Resolution 242, adopted by the United Nations Security Council on Nov. 22, 1967, after the sixday war that June. Following is the text of that resolution.

title: Russian Says U.S. Was Warned of Mideast War
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 A Soviet diplomat said yesterday that Moscow had repeatedly warned Washington from June until September that war was imminent in the Middle East.

title: Cahill Signs Bill Raising Mortgage Rate
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20A controversial measure that will enable the state to raise its ceiling on interest rates on conventional homemortgage loans in New Jersey was signed with great reluctance today by Governor Cahill.

title: Carroll of H.R.A. Named a City College Vice President
description: Robert F. Carroll, deputy administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration, was appointed yesterday a vice president of the City College of New York.

title: Bullets, Led By Riordan, Beat Kings
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 20 (UPI)Mike. Riordan hit a pair of fastbreak layups within a 30second span in the last 1 minutes tonight, insuring the Capital Bullets a 9892 victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings in the National Basketball Association.

title: Japanese Retains Title
description: OSAKA, Japan, Dec. 20 (AP)Hideo Kanazawa of Japan, junior middleweight champion of the Orient, retained his title today by winning a unanimous 12round decision from Dommy Cotacte of the Philippines.

title: Pop Music: 4 Top Groups Reflect Bluegrass History
description: The bluegrass was high as an elephant's eye at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, when four top bluegrass groups got together to pick and sing what was called a Strictly Bluegrass XMas. The lineup cut straight through bluegrass historyone of the founders, Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain Boys; an early follower, Jimmy Martin and the Sunny Mountain Boys; a middleperiod group, Jim and Jesse and the Virginia Boys, and a modern bluegrass troupe, the Country Gentlemen. There was also David Bromberg as master of ceremonies and guitarpicker in a country jam finale.

title: Gas Restriction and Rain Dampen Weekend Outlook
description: Operators of ski areas throughout the Northeast received two new rebuffs yesterday. One was that William E. Simon, the nation's new energy chief, had asked Americans to reduce gasoline consumption to 10 gallons a week. The other bad news came with the weather report. Rain, perhaps heavy at times, was forecast for this morning and afternoon for almost all of the ski country. Even Canada's Laurentians were expected to receive a drenching.

title: Lebanese Riot in Main Cities; U.N. Supply Truck Set Afire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20 (AP)A bomb exploded and wounded three persons in downtown Beirut today, the police said. The blast was the second in 12 hours as antiGovernment riots took place in Lebanon's main cities.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Decline As Portfolio Shifts Are Seen
description: Corporate bond prices declined yesterday, reflecting what several dealers suggested were yearend portfolio adjustments by institutional investors. Among the newer issues in the secondary market, prices were off from one quarter to as much as three quarters of a point. Tax selling also showed up in some older issues in the secondary market. Two recently marketed corporate issues were freed from syndicate yesterday and declined in subsequent trading in the secondary market.

title: Turnpike Accidents Halved in November
description: There were only half as many accidents on the New Jersey Turnpike in November, when slower speed restrictions went into effect, as in October.

title: A HardWorking Legal Adviser
description: By the close of the normal business day yesterday, or what would have been the close to most people, John M. Doar, the new legal adviser to the House committee inquiring into the possible impeachment of President Nixon, was forging ahead in a rigorous, selfimposed schedule of interviewing potential members for his staff. In an apparently characteristic move for him, he attacked the task fresh but of the Capitol Hill news conference at which his appointment had been an nounced and worked right into the night.

title: SHORT INTEREST UP AT BIG BOARD
description: Short Short interest increased to 17,621,538 shares at the close of business on the settlement date of Dec. 14 the New York Stock Exchange reported yes terday.

title: Policeman Working As a Teller Shoots Suspect in Robbery
description: A suspected bank robber was shot and seriously wounded yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with an offduty policeman who was working as a bank teller.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the first two numbers or the last two become eligible for the millionaire semifinal drawing to be held later.

title: Firehouse Hit by Blaze As Firemen Go on Job
description: A fire that officials termed suspicious destroyed two floors of a threestory firehouse on West 161st Street in Washington Heights last night while the firemen normally stationed there were responding to an alarm a block away.

title: A Day of Humiliation Is Urged by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)The Senate adopted a resolution today calling for the observance next April 30 of a national day of humiliation, fasting and prayer.

title: PolicyOperation Suspect Kidnapped and Shot Here
description: A man suspected of running a $1.35millionayear policy scheme was kidnapped outside his Brooklyn home yesterday morning, driven in his own car to a deserted street and robbed and shot four times by two gunmen.

title: Bridge: New Yorker Comes Close To Reaching Record Score
description: The biggest score ever recorded in a national championship was 78 per cent, by Eric Murray of Toronto and the late Agnes Gordon of Buffalo, in 1963.

title: Court to Decide HighRise Controversy
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, Dec. 20  A proposal for highrise apartment buildings that has divided this onesquare mile municipality that fronts on the Atlantic Ocean will 1)4 decided in court.

title: East Bloc's Truce Units Said Help Free American
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec, 20Diplomatic sources said tolday that the Hungarian and Polish delegations to the International Commission of Control and Supervision had played a major role in helping persuade the Vietcong to release an American civilian captured Oct. 6.

title: Advertising: A Magazine Story
description: On the day that John Mack Carter, chairman, submitted his resignation to the board of Downe Communications, Albert S. Traina, president and chief operating officer, did the same with the board of Bartell Media, of which Downe holds 40 per cent of the stock.

title: 2 at Columbia Indicted in Sale of Cocaine
description: Two Columbia College students, both varsity wrestlers and fraternity officers, have been indicted for the sale of cocaine. If convicted, they could be the first campus drug dealers to be sentenced to life imprisonment under the state's new narcotics laws.

title: POLICY ON CREDIT RELAXED BY FED
description: The Federal Reserve added a massive $3.7billion of securities to its holdings of Government securities during the week ended Wednesday, an action that injects reserves into the banking system and makes it easier for banks to lend money.

title: Music: A Light and Stylish Messiah
description: The most stylish Messiah in town in recent years has probably been that by Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra of New York, and their move from their base at the Central Presbyterian Church to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night didn't really alter that ranking. Mr. Westenburg goes about as far as one might reasonably expect in the direction of authenticity. He uses a professional chorus and orchestra of about 30 members each, brings in a countertenor for the solo alto parts, ornaments the vocal and orchestral lines freely and consistently (based on Watkins Shaw's edition), makes the proper rhythmic adjustments and keeps the textures light and fleet. He even opts for the more exotic versions of nearly all the arias that offer alternatives, a decision that is actually less authentic than it is simply interesting. Admittedly, the wind instruments look modern, and the organ makes a disconcertingly anachronistic sound, but those are small matters indeed.

title: Pupils Give Their Coins To Neediest
description: Some of yesterday's contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were good things that could not be hurried. One of them took three months in the making, and another represented the fruits of eight weeks' labor.

title: Simon Asks SelfRationing by Motorists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, asked American motorists today to practice doityourself gasoline rationing so the mandatory, variety will not be necessary.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Officials of the State Department of Health yesterday confirmed the existence of 11 cases of typhoid fever in Burlington County and said one of the victims may have been a carrier who spread it to the others at a church dinner. The suspected carrier, who helped prepare the food for a Nov. 3 dinner at St. Mary's United Methodist Church in Burlington City, exhibited no outward signs of the disease but responded positively to tests for the bacteria causing typhoid. The state declined to identify the person.

title: Job Shift Approved
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 20 (AP)  The appointment of Southeastern Louisiana's football coach, Roland Dale, as athletic director at the University of Southern Mississippi was approved today by the state College Board, effective Feb. 6.

title: At Yonkers: Cynicism And Shock
description: YONKERS, Dec. 20  The reaction of the crowd, such as it was, at Yonkers Raceway tonight was one of almost complete indifference to the indictments. The cynical attitude that many fans have toward the harness sport was voiced by Jim Bednar, a sailor on the U.S.S. Steindaker. I don't care whether they're phony or not, it's someplace to go at night. And anyway I got a ticket on that winner.

title: Soviet Confirms Air Crash
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has officially confirmed that an airliner on a domestic route crashed Sunday, killing all on board. A brief announcement in Sovetskaya Litva, the Lithuani an Communist party daily, said that the TU124 jetliner crashed near Volokolamsk, about 65 miles west of Moscow, en route from Lithuania to Moscow. The number of victims was not digclosed. A TU124 can carry 44 passengers.

title: Mohawk Data Moves Further Into Red
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, an independent producer of dataprocessing peripheral equipment which has had deficit operations for the last year, went further into the red, according to its company report issued yesterday for the six months ended Oct. 31.

title: Cushioned OceanDrilling Ship Sets Out to Explore
description: Equipped with novel cushioning devices to enable the ship to drill smoothly into the bottom while afloat on the heaving sea, the ship Glomar Challenger is to sail from Tahiti today on a voyage beginning a new phase of deepsea exploration.

title: OFFERING IS PLANNED BY BURLINGTON LINE
description: A planned offering by Burlington Northern, Inc., of $60million of consolidated mortgage bonds, due 1999, now is scheduled for marketing next month, according to a preliminary offering circular issued yesterday by the underwriters for the issue, led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: 2 RUSSIANS GROW PROTEIN IN SPACE
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20  In their third day in space, the crew of the Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 13 reaped today the harvest of the first nutritive protein mass ever grown in space, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday formally endorsed the Financial Accounting Standards Board as the organization in the private sector of the economy that will set accounting principles and standards to be followed in writing corporate reports.

title: Geneva Negotiation: The Basic Positions
description: The countries involved in the Middle East conflict have tended, publicly at least, to state their demands in the most sweeping terms. Their real positions are known to be somewhat more flexible. Following are the basic negotiating stances as described by correspondents of The New York Times, of the three main participants in the Geneva conference and of Syria, which has thus far refused to send a delegation to Geneva.

title: Eames Recreates the World of Newton, Born on Christmas Day, 1642, for I.B.M. Exhibit Here
description: One of the world's leading enthusiasts for toy trains is the designer Charles Eames of Venice, Calif. The laws of motion formulated by Sir Isaac Newton, himself a modelbuilder, whom Albert Einstein called an artist, govern toy trains as well as moonrockets.

title: TEXTILE PACT SET FOR WORLD TRADE
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20  An international agreement to regulate world trade in textiles was concluded here today by a 50nation conference.

title: FIVE MORE INDICTED IN SHABAZZ SLAYING
description: Five more members of a Black Muslim splinter group have been added to the list of accused in the murder of James Shabazz, a Newark Black Muslim minister.

title: Frederick Ehrman Dies at 67; Led Lehman Brothers Board
description: Frederick L. Ehrman, former chairman of the board of Lehman Brothers, Inc., died of a heart attack in his sleep early yesterday at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 67 years old and also lived in Armonk, N. Y.

title: Saints Reward Scout
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP)Bob Whitman was promoted today from chief scout to director of player personnel by the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League. He replaces Henry Lee Parker, who was fired yesterday.

title: EgyptianIsraeli Fighting Angers Chief of U.N. Force
description: CAIRO, Dec. 20New outbreaks of heavy shooting erupted last night along the EgyptianIsraeli front, endangering Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force. The fighting brought an angry protest to both Egypt and Israel today from the United Nations commander, Lieut. Gen. Ensio Siilasvuo.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.Vicente Medina, 156 pounds, Tueson, Ariz., knocked out Ernie McMickin, 149, New York, 4 rounds.

title: Madison From 61st to 96th Is Rezoned
description: The Board of Estimate, seeking to wind up a number of matters before the Christmas holidays, voted yesterday to give final approval to a special zoning plan intended to preserve the scale and character of Madison Avenue between 61st and 96th Streets.

title: Lights Are Dimmer on Great White Way
description: The nation's energy crisis is putting a crimp in Broadway theater lighting, but not enough to dim the Great White Way drastically.

title: TV: The Agribusiness
description: Tonight, from 10 to 11, the subject and thesis of the American Broadcasting Company's news Close  Up series is Food: Green Grow the Profits. Under investigation are several aspects of, agribusiness, a system of giant corporations and cooperatives that handles food from seed to supermarket.

title: Robert L. Cizek, 71, Dead; AviationInsurance Expert
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 20Robert L. Cizek, an insurance executive who specialized in aviation, died yesterday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: Film: Effective 'Laughing Policeman':The Cast
description: The continuing love affair between movie makers and a violent and photogenic San Francisco is exposed with fresh ardor by "The Laughing Policeman," which came to the National and Beekman Theaters yesterday.Though an essentially familiar amalgam of murder, manhunt and dogged police work in that scenic city, this "Policeman" stands a good deal taller than the norm because of the expert guidance of Stuart Rosenberg, the producer-director. He is effectively aided by a fine script and a cast as convincing as a live cop or a dead gunman.The plot tends to be convoluted from its lengthy opening sequence, in which all the passengers of a bus, including a detective, are massacred by a mysterious machine-gunner. A confusion of other corpses and a gory shootout help cloud the proceedings.But Walter Matthau, as the veteran plainclothesman whose partner was slain; Bruce Dern, his new partner, and their teammates not only provide meticulous expertise in tracing the killer, but also reveal themselves and their views of rough jobs.Credit much of the film's flavor and insights to Thomas Rickman's adaptation of the novel by the Swedish husband-and-wife team of Per Wahloo and Maj Sjowall. This script captures the character and the earthy, germane vernacular, four-letter and otherwise, of the police, street people, blacks, prostitutes and pimps of San Francisco that substitutes for the book's Stockholm.Mr. Matthau gives an underplayed and forceful portrayal of the taciturn, gum-chewing sleuth frustrated by a lack of motives for the seemingly unrelated slayings, who turns to a previous, unsolved murder to unearth the killer. It is in keeping with his old-timer's dedication to a plodding and dangerous job that makes him a stranger to his wife and kids. Mr. Dern's delineation as his cynical sidekick, who occasionally messes up procedures with hard-nosed tactics, is equally strong and natural.The film juxtaposes police practices and points of view in varied vignettes, from Anthony Zerbe's characterization of the harassed lieutenant yelling for results to Lou Gossett's black detective who realy knows his black suspects and can handle them. And a number of bit performances, including actual police squads and a team of emergency-room doctors, lend vivid local color and authenticity to an engrossing and adult crime caper.

title: 65 Held by British In Ulster Set Free In Holiday Gesture
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20In a goodwill gesture for Christmas, the British today freed 65 of the 662 persons detained without trial near Belfast. Some had been held as long as two and a half years.

title: League Ruling Bars YankWilliams Pact
description: Joe Cronin, the president of the American League, made two rulings yesterday that left the New York Yankees without a manager for 1974 and, in effect, increased pressure on them to pay whatever Chat'les O. Finley of the Oakland A's required to release Dick Williams.

title: St. Paul's Is 65 Winner On Ice Here
description: A longtime observer of hockey in Madison Square Garden said yesterday, One team [Groton] played on guts, the other [St. Paul's] on talent.

title: Doar to Direct Impeachment Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 John M. Doar, after being selected to direct a Congressional inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon, pledged today to see that justice is done, that the Constitution is preserved and fairness occurs.

title: Job Shift Approved
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 20 (AP)The appointment of Southeastern Louisiana's football coach, Roland Dale, as athletic director at the University of Southern Mississippi was approved today by the state College Board, effective Feb. 6.

title: OILTALK STUDY SET BY A SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Senator Phillip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, told the State and Justice Departments today that his antitrust subcommittee would investigate negotiations between major United States oil companies and oilproducing countries.

title: 11 SEIZED IN RAIDS ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Eleven members of what was described as one of the city's largest heroin operations were arrested in predawn raids in, the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Congressional Unit Says Dean Gave I.R.S. 2d Enemies List
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The former White House Counsel John W. Dean 3d turned over a second list of 575 White House enemies to the Internal Revenue Service in September, 1972, with a request that the I.R.S. see what type of information could be developed about those named, a Congressional committee disclosed today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Britain should withdraw from international sports competitions where opponents persist in drug taking. That was one of the suggestions made by the British Association of National Coaches after a conference in which the whole question of doping in sports was discussed by 40 coaches, representing a variety of British sports.

title: Harness Leaders React With Disbelief and Relief
description: Most of these drivers are earning more than $100,000 a year, said George Morton Levy yesterday in the president's office at Roosevelt Raceway. Is it possible they'd fix races for a few thousand dollars? The probabilities weigh so heavily against it.

title: Ford Defends Plan to Fly To West on Military Jet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Vice President Ford defended today his plan to use an Air Force jet to take him and his family to Colorado for Christmas, a trip that the Air Force estimates will use 22,000 gallons of jet fuel.

title: Officials Dominate Thai Voting; Many of OldTimers Lose Seats
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 20 (AP)  Citybased Government officials dominated the returns today in the election of the new National Assembly, sinking the hopes of rural delegates for a strong voice.

title: Minority Hiring Plan Is Imposed On Chicago's Building Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Department of Labor, citing the failure of two voluntary programs, announced today that it had imposed on the Chicago area's construction industry a plan to increase minority employment.

title: CurtissWright to Sell Its Airco Stock to B.O.C.
description: The British Oxygen Corporation has almost won its battle for control of Airco, Inc. The CurtissWright Corporation, British Oxygen's rival in the pursuit, reached an understanding yesterday to turn over its Airco shares to B.O.C.

title: BOYLE'S HEALTH PUTS OFF JAILING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20W. A. Boyle, the 72yearold former president of the United Mine Workers, suffered a mild fainting spell today, delaying his departure from a Washington hospital to begin a threeyear Federal prison sentence for embezzling union funds.

title: Tornado Hits Florida
description: FLORIDA CITY, Dec. 20 (UPI) A tornado raked southern Dade County today, injuring 14 persons, destroying 17 mobile homes, ripping the roof off one house and damaging another.

title: LASTTANGO CLEARED BY ITALY HIGH COURT
description: ROME, Dec. 20The Court of Cassation, Italy's highest tribunal in all cases not involving constitutional questions, today annulled a sentence by a lower court that had found Bernardo Bertolucci's film Last Tango in Paris obscene.

title: $1ABARREL RISE FOR SHELL OIL SET
description: The Shell Oil Company yesterday raised crude oil prices by $1 a barrel.

title: St. Paul's Is 65 Winner On Ice Here
description: A longtime observer of hockey in Madison Square Garden said yesterday, One team [Groton] played on guts, the other [St. Paul's] on talent.

title: Souvanna Hopeful on Impact of KissingerTho Talks
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 20Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that the current meeting between Secretary of State Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam could lead to the imminent formation of a coalition government in Laos by the Royal Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao.

title: Notes on People
description: The fivemonth sitin of Mrs. Barbara Mandel, the estranged wife of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, came to an end yesterday at the Governor's Mansion in Annapolis. Mrs. Mandel had refused to move out even though the Governor had left her with the announced intention of getting a divorce and marrying Mrs. Jean Dorsey. Because his wife refused to budge from the mansion, Governor Mandel moved into a hotel and later an apartment.. But now Mrs. Mandel has apparently given up hope for the 32yearold marriage, and Mr. Mandel will be free to reoccupy the mansion.

title: Bettors Not Surprised At Scandal
description: I know I'm batting my head against a brick wall trying to beat those trotters, said a baker who lives in Brooklyn. So what? If you're a gambler, you've got to take chances even if the wheel is crooked.

title: About New York City Tales in Search of a Moral
description: On 40th Street the other day, a man who was on his way to work was stopped by a bulky man, who called out, Say, you went to Hotchkiss, didn't you?

title: Prices of Stocks Decline; Dow Is Off 1.46 at 828.11
description: American Telephone and Telegraph and numerous oil stocks moved up yesterday, but the general market eased slightly in moderate trading. Volume slipped to 17.43 million shares from the previous day's 20.67 million shares.

title: Denmark Raises Bank Rate
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Denmark raised its bank rate to 9 per cent from 8 per cent, the Central Bank said. The rise is effective tomorrow. The bank rate had held at 8 per cent since last July 11, when it was raised by one percentage point.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: Wheat futures prices declined a little in dull trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders apparently wanted to even out their positions before the holiday weekend and they were wary about the crop report due after the close of trading today.

title: CITY TAX OFFICIAL CALLED TAX CHEAT
description: The city's tax collector, Frederic S. Rice, was formally accused yesterday of filing false and fraudulent state incometax returns that understated by more than $20,000 his true income for 1970 and 1971.

title: ELECTIONS IN 1975 PLEDGED IN BOLIVIA
description: LA PAX, Bolivia, Dec. 20 (AP) President Hugo Banzer Surez announced today that he would hold elections and restore constitutional civilian government in Bolivia on Aug. 6, 1975, when the nation celebrates the 150th anniversary of her independence.

title: POLITICIANS' YIELD FROM GIFTS TAXABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Political parties and candidates will have to start paying income tax on money they make from contributions, but not on the contributions themselves, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Car Pools Get Lower Toll
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP)The Delaware River Port Authority wll establish a bridge toll of 25 cents for cars carrying three or more persons. The authority also announced that the commuter rate would go from 35 to 40 cents. The 60cent rate for noncommuters will remain in effect.

title: STATE TRANSIT AID IS CUT $76MILLION IN CONFEREES' SILL
description: A SenateHouse conference committee has agreed on an $800million masstransit bill that would give New York State $76million less in Federal operating subsidies than it would have received under the House version.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Nov. 30 editorial Energy Revolution is most timely. We have become a nation of energy hogs because energy has always been cheap and unlimited, and the construction industry has contributed more than its share to energy waste.

title: AllStar, Playoff Games Of A.B.A. Going on TV
description: Mike Storen, commissioner of the American Basketball Association, announced yesterday that the Hughes Sports Network had bought the exclusive television rights to this season's A.B.A. AllStar glime, divisional finals and championship series.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN AMERICAN VERDICT. By Michael J. Arlen. 196 pages. Doubleday. $6.95. Does anyone remember the Black Panthers now? Yes, there was Huey P. Newton (last heard from rapping with Erik H. Erickson in In Search of Common Ground) and Eldridge Cleaver (Algiers?) and Stokely Carmichael (Guinea?) and, of course, Bobby Seale (aspiring politician). But now? Certain they are no longer the bugbears they were in the nineteensixties, when they created pandemonium in the California legislature in Sacramento (and throughout the nation) by marching into the State Assembly openly toting an assortment of shotguns, rifles and pistols. Gone. Now there are other bugbearsde Mau Maus and the Black Liberation Army specters to fuel a society's ongoing paranoia.

title: Kissinger and Tho in Paris Discuss Vietnam Fighting
description: PARIS, Dec. 20Secretary of State Kissinger arid North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, met for four and a half hours today and exchanged complaints about the ineffective Vietnam ceasefire. They also agreed to keep in touch for possible future meetings.

title: Japan's Auto Output Off
description: TOKYO, Dec. 20 (UPI)Japan produced a total of 626,197 motor vehicles in November, down 2.8 per cent from October, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. The association attributed the decrease to a tight supply of materials and auto parts, such as tires because of the oil crisis. The November output was up 10.4 per cent from the corresponding month last year, the association said.

title: RAISES FOR BOARD VOTED BY COUNCIL
description: The City Council voted yesterday, 33 to 3, to raise the pay of the eight members of the Board of Estimate by $10,000 each.

title: Mideast Parley Begins Today; Early Accord Is Held Unlikely
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20Israel and the Arabs open a conference here tomorrow designed to bring peace to the Middle East after four wars and 25 years of hostility.

title: M.T. A. PublicAffairs Director To Be Beame's Press Secretary
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday named as his press secretary Sidrey J. Frigand, publicaffairs director of the Metropolitan Transportatior Authority.

title: She Smiled Warmly Through a Cold Day
description: It was 19 degrees outside the other day, and the shoppers who trudged through the slush in front of Macy's looked frozen and grim. But Diane Chesney was smiling. She smiles a lot this time of year.

title: Cappelletti, Simpson Win Awards of Maxwell Club
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (UPI)John Cappelletti and O. J. Simpson, this year's premier running backs in the college and professional ranks, were named today as recipients of the Maxwell Football Club's PlayersoftheYear Awards.

title: No Real Harm to U.S. Seen in Oil Cuts
description: PARIS, Dec. 20The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted today that the Arab oil embargo would not seriously impair American industrial output next year because Arab sources fill only 6 per cent of American energy consumption and the nation's use of oil for nonproductive purposes is extremely high.

title: People and Business
description: Eli Goldston, who once identified himself as a kosher dill pickle at a Yankee pot roast, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of one of the nation's most prestigious research and consulting concerns, Arthur D. Little, Inc., effective May 1, 1974. He will succeed a former American military leader, Gen. James M. Gavin, 66, who has been Little's chief executive since 1960 and who will become chairman of the executive committee.

title: Cambodians Hire 20 Pilots From Taiwan
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 20 (Agence FrancePresse) A team of 20 Chinese Nationalist pilots, recruited recently by the Cambodian Air Force, began active service this week, according to informed sources here.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $2.037billion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $1.781billion. Total retail store sales were about $12.103billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $10.964billion.

title: Kuwait Considers Giving Hijackers to Guerrilla Group for Trial
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 20 (AP)A Kuwaiti official said today that his Government was considering allowing the Palestine Liberation Organization to try the five Arab hijackers who killed 32 people this week at the Rome and Athens airports.

title: JOHN D. BAKER
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Dec. 20 (UPI)John D. Baker, who was named general manager of General Motor's Oldsmobile division on Nov. 5, died yesterday at the Methodist Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: 28 ARE INDICTED BY FEDERAL JURY IN RACING FIXES
description: Three of The nation's four top moneywinning harness drivers were among 28 persons indicted by Federal authorities yesterday on charges of fixing superfecta races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways.

title: Red Smith
description: As manager of the Chicago White Sort and a utility man who played when and where the manager dictated, Jimmie Dykes batted .306 in 1937 and 303 the, next season. It took me 20 years to learn to hit, he said, and then it was too late. Trouble was, he turned 41 years old in 1937 and in spite `of his drag with the manager he could play in only 30 games. Even so, making 26 hits that year, he batted in 23, runs. Meaning he really had learned to hit. With men on the bases, he knew how to get the pitch he wanted and place it where he wanted.

title: Assassination in Spain
description: The assassins' blast in Madrid that killed Premier Luis Carrero Blanco also exploded Generalissimo Franco's carefully drawn plans for peaceful transition and continuity of policy in Spain after his own death or retirement. Those plans always rested on a shaky foundation; and the shocking murder of Admiral Carrero, the real power in the Government for much longer than the six months he served as its official head, is certain to intensify the infighting among various factions for leadership of the postFranco era.

title: Japanese Retains Title
description: OSAKA, Japan, Dec. 20 (AP)Hideo Kanazawa of Japan, junior middleweight champion of the Orient, retained his title today by winning a unanimous 12round decision from Dommy Cotacte of the Philippines. Kanazawa weighed 154 pounds and Cotacte 148.

title: TRIBUNE WILL PRINT PARTLY IN ENGLAND
description: The International Herald Tribune is planning to divide printing between England and France, rather than continue printing solely in Paris.

title: Energy and Ecology
description: At first glance, the energy crisis looks like an ecological disaster. It is not uncommon these days to hear hardnosed, practical men of business say knowingly, as it vindicated, that now the ecologists will have to show a little common sense.

title: U.S. Action Adds 3 States For Offshore Fuel Drilling
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20Over strenuous opposition from Florida, the Interior Department opened bids here today on underwater leases that would extend the offshore oil and gas industry to the costal waters of Florida, Alabama and Mississippi.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: With great reluctance, Governor Cahill of New Jersey signed a controversial measure yesterday allowing the State Banking Department to raise the existing 8 per cent ceiling on conventional homemortgage loans. The new rate, to be announced today, is expected to be near 9 per cent.

title: Mrs. Chesimard Is Ousted Again As 2d Trial for Robbery Begins
description: Joanne D. Chesimard, the suspetted Black Liberation Army member who was ousted several times for courtroom outbursts during her first trial for bank robbery, was ousted again yesterda:y for her outbursts.

title: LESTER RICER
description: Lester Riger, an employe of the Veterans Administration, was electrocuted Monday when he stepped on a stormdowned wire outside his home in Albertson, L. I. He was 60 Years old.

title: Hunt Said to Tell Investigators He Spied on Goldwater in 1964
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20E. Howard Hunt Jr., now in jail for coordinating the Watergate burglary, has told Senate Republican investigators that he gathered material on Senator Barry Goldwater's 1964 Presidential campaign and passed it on to an official of the Johnson Administration, according to sources in the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 2 at Columbia Indicted in Sale Of Cocaine to Undercover Man
description: Two Columbia College students, both varsity wrestlers and fraternity officers, have been indicted for the sale of cocaine. If convicted, they could be the first campus drug dealers to be sentenced to life imprisonment under the state's new narcotics laws.

title: SUNDAY'S STORM LEAVES ITS MART
description: Work and utility crews labored for a fourth day yesterday to restore full electrical power and clear the remaining debrisclogged roads in areas of the tristate region crippled by Sunday night's storm.

title: FERTILIZER MAKERS FACE NEW CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)The director of the Cost of Living Council, John T. Dunlop, held out today the possibility that price controls might be reimposed on the fertilizer industry.

title: EXXON ANNOUNCES $6BILLION BUDGET
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday a record $6.1billion capital budget for the company and its affiliates for 1974. The total represents a 73 per cent increase over the 1973 capital budget of about $3.5billion, the company's previous record.

title: ACQUISITION SET BY HUGHES TOOL
description: The Hughes Tool Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Byron Jackson, Inc., a producer of specialized tools for oildrilling rigs that also provides oilwell cementing and wellstimulation services.

title: CONGRESS PASSES AID AND JOB BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Congress passed major defense and foreign aid appropriations bills and a compromise manpower bill today as it struggled to adjourn tomorrow.

title: Sketches of Chief Negotiators
description: Stocky man of 51 years with fondness for cigars and habit of neat attire...In diplomatic service since 1946 and known as skilled negotiator...Protg of Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, longtime Foreign Minister, now Vice President...Studied law and economics at Cairo University...Has held diplomatic posts at United Nations, Paris, Vienna and Geneva ... Served as nation's representative on various international agencies and commissions, including the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Disarmament Commission ... Career dimmed in 1972 when he was too outspoken on need for Egypt to prod Soviet Union into taking more active role against Israel...After sideline duty as Minister of Tourism, was abruptly named Foreign Minister while in Washington after October war ... Reported to have made a favorable impression on Secretary of State Kissinger ... He and wife, Afaf, have three children, one a United Nations employe.

title: Harness Racing Vulnerable To Strategy, Human Factor
description: Ever since the Mesopotamians argued the merits of one skincovered chariot over another, some three thousand years B.C., the horseandwagon sport probably has courted some degree of suspicion.

title: Ice and Salt Producing New Potholes
description: The city's streets  hit hard by severe icing conditions followed by quick thawing and sprinkled with 60,000 tons of corrosive salt during the week  have experienced a plaque of potholes counted in the hundreds on main arteries.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed after holding steady throughout most of the session yesterday. Prices in the overthecounter market, however, closed markedly lower.

title: D'Antoni's 'Seven-Ups' Is Police Drama:The Cast
description: "The Seven-Ups," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, is about a team of four New York City detectives assigned to trap hoods whose crimes are punishable by jail terms of seven years or more.Off duty these four detectives are all-American boys. They take their kids to the dentist. They play basketball. They probably drink beer as they sit in front of their TV sets watching the Sunday afternoon games. On duty they are the kind of guys who beat up suspects with short lengths of hose. They break and enter without warrants. They torture a dying gangster in his hospital bed, and they shoot first, usually to kill, so there are no questions to ask afterward."The Seven-Ups," the first film to be directed by Phil D'Antoni, the man who produced "The French Connection," is a vicious, mechanical, clumsy thriller. It mindlessly uses the violence that in "The French Connection" could be seen as a manifestation of general urban rot. "The Seven-Ups" has no such thoughts in its head. It treats its vigilante cops with respect, not because of anything they might feel or believe in, but because of what they can do. The characters have even less individuality than performing bears.The cast includes Roy Scheider, the co-star of "The French Connection," as the head of the Seven-Ups team, and Tony Lo Bianco, who was so good in "The Honeymoon Killers," as a young mortician whose funeral parlor is favored by the mob. The film was photographed entirely in and around New York, but it's just a lot of geography, even when it's flipping by in the obligatory chase sequence.

title: A LARGER HARVEST IN WHEAT IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Winter wheat farmers, encouraged by record high prices this year, are expected to harvest a 19 per cent larger crop in 1974, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Cost of Living Council ordered today a delay in increases of some steel prices, but, in a surprise move, allowed some other steel prices to go up immediately.

title: Melinda Reed Wed To Kennett Love
description: CAIRO, Dec. 21Melinda Reed, actress, and Kennett Love, author and correspondent, both of New York, were married here today beside the Pyramid of Kefren at Giza. The Rev. Dale Comption of St. Andrew's Church here officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Cordero Scores Day Before Ban Begins
description: A heavy fog rolled across Aqueduct during the second race yesterday and even the track announcer had to say, They must be off because the [Teletimer] light is on. Then, out of the mist came Angel Cordero urging Daretobe across the finish line, a $3.60 winner. Fog or no fog, the railbirds will look in vain for Cordero today. The popular Puerto Rican rider will be starting a fiveday suspension that virtually eliminates his chance to overtake Ron Turcotte as the state's leading racerider.

title: JAMES B. L. ORME
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21  James Booth Lockwood Orme, a partner in the former New York patent law firm of Ward, Hazelton, McElhannon, Orme, Brooks, Fitzpatrick, died here Tuesday. His age was 89.

title: Stricker of Italy Wins Cup Slalom
description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, Dec. 21 (AP)Erwin Stricker of Italy won a World Cup special slalom ski race today with two runs of 52.42 seconds each.

title: New Yorker Theater Is Bought By Walter Reade Organization
description: The New Yorker Theater, the revival and artfilm house at Broadway and 88th Street, has been purchased for an undisclosed sum by the Walter Reade Organization, owner and operator of 81 theaters across the country.

title: Soviet Six Wins Cup
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (UPI)Shaking off a poor first period, the Soviet squad went on to crush Czechoslovakia, 71, to day for the title in the annual Izvestia Cup ice hockey tournament. Finland clinched third place.

title: Bloomingdale Mall Gift Will Stay on the Shelf
description: A plan to redesign the Central Park Mall, using a $150,000 gift from Bloomingdale's department store and matching city funds, has been dropped by mutual agreement.

title: Humphrey Reports $199,153 Deduction For Gift of Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Senator Hubert H, Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he had claimed Federal tax deductions of $199,153 on the donation of his VicePresidential papers to the Minnesota State Historical Society.

title: CONGRESS PASSES 11% BENEFITS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Senate and the House gave final approval today to an 11 per cent increase in two steps in Social Security benefits for some 29 million retired persons.

title: Foreign Stocks Are Traded in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21  In a move reflecting Tokyo's emergence as a major international financial center, six foreign companies had their shares listed this week on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the first time foreign concerns have been allowed to have their shares traded in Japan.

title: Rule of Law Upheld
description: A Senate majority has finally acted to restore the United States as a lawabiding member of the world community and an upholder of the United Nations. After breaking a filibuster, the Senateby a margin of 54 to 37voted to repeal the Byrd amendment of 1971, which had placed this country in breach of the sanctions it had voted for in the U.N. Security Council against the white minority regime in Rhodesia. Here was a blow against racism and a victory for the principle of selfdetermination long championed by Americans. Most of all, however, it was an act to honor the rule of law in world affairs and to strengthen the United Nations.

title: FLORIDA REPORTER GETS 2D JAIL TERM
description: DADE CITY, Fla., Dec, 21 Lucy Ware Morgan, a reporter for the St. Petersburg Times, has received a second jail sentence for refusing to identify confidential news sources.

title: MORTGAGE RATES INCREASED TO 8
description: TRENTON, Dec. 21Richard F. Schaub, the State Banking Commissioner, today increased the maximum interest rate lenders can charge on mort gage loans in New Jersey 8 per cent from its prior ceil ing of 8 per cent.

title: Flawed Equation
description: When a lawyer for Ralph Nader and consumer groups who are challenging the Nixon Administration's dealings with the dairy industry played portions of a copy of a subpoenaed White House tape before friends at a cocktail party, he committed what he himself accurately described as a very foolish mistake. Federal District Judge William B. Jones, after reviewing the incident, agreed with that description of the indiscretion while refusing to censure the lawyer, William A. Dobrovir. Central to Judge Jones' conclusion was the fact that the tape itself was not covered by any judicial restrictions or protection, nor had it been turned over to the court for secret inspection.

title: Nets Top Squires, 115100, for 4th in Row
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 21 Streaking in opposite directions in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division, the New York Nets won their fourth game in a row tonight, 115100, from the Virginia Squires, who lost their fourth straight.

title: Music: A Storm No More
description: For Pierre Boulez, it was a conventional concert, and the only problematic piece on his New York Philharmonic program on Thursday night was Aaron Copland's Connotations for Orchestra.

title: Anger in a British Mining Town
description: COALVILLE, England, Dec. 20In this aptly named Midlands town, where four out of five families are headed by coal miners and the fifth family gets its living from the four others, there is little argument over the merits of the miners' demand for a bigger pay envelope.

title: NATO Is Studying Tactical Lessons of the Mideast War
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18  The latest war in the Middle East could stimulate sluggish programs to improve the quality of frontline equipment in Europe, according to officials at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels.

title: Champion Papers Sued By Saxon on Franchise
description: Saxon Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it had commenced a suit in the United States District Court here to restrain the Champion Papers division of the Champion International Corporation from terminating the sale of Champion Paper products to Saxon's distribution outlets.

title: DR. VINCENT H. GILLSON
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., Dec. 21 Dr. Vincent H. Gillson, pathologist and director of clinical laboratories at the Pascack Valley Hospital here and at the Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Washington Township. He was 52 years old.

title: 3% CUT IN VOLTAGE ORDERED IN STATE
description: The Public Service Commission ordered all electric utilities in New York State yesterday to cut voltage 3 per cent around the clock, in a move it said would save 2.5 million to 3 million barrels of oil a year while having only minimal effect on the consumers of the state.

title: Physician to Astronauts Will Head Health Center
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21, (Reuters)Dr. Charles Berry physician to American astronauts for the last two years, will resign to become president of the University of Texas Health and Science Center, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP)Reggie Jackson of the world champion Oakland A's was named officially today the American League's 1973 slugging king. Jackson compiled a slugging percentage of .531. Sal Bando of the A's was second at .497, followed by Frank Robinson of California (.488) and Milwaukee's George Scott and Texas' Jeff Burroughs (.487 each). Jackson, the league's Most Valuable Player, had a .296 batting average with 286 total bases in 539 times at bat. He led the league with 32 homers and had 28 doubles and two triples. Boston led in team slugging with .401, followed by Minnesota (.393), Baltimore and Detroit (.390 each) and Oakland (.389). A designated hitter, Orlando Cepeda, helped the Red Sox to the team title with a mark of .444. Cepeda, barely able to run because of two bad knees, led the league by grounding into 24 double plays.

title: Christmas in the City Intensifies The Happiness and Sadness
description: When Christmas comes, the city is at its most dazzling. Even this year, as the lights have been dimmed and some of the services curtailed, the gaiety has not been extinguished.Street, just off Times Square. It is not an unusual sight there, and the crowds of people who hurry back and forth on 43d Street every day took no notice of him.

title: A DELAY IS SOUGHT ON OIL ALLOCATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Administration asked Congress today for more time to put fuel allocation rules into effect to avoid mistakes in the new regulations.

title: Senate Votes Energy Bill; Oil Profits Curb Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Bowing to intense White House pressure, the Senate approved tonight, 52 to 8, a modified emergency energy bill that was stripped of a section designed to limit windfall profits by the oil industry.

title: Democracy for D.C.
description: For decades, the citizens of Washington, D. C., mockingly calling their city the nation's last colony, have agitated for selfgovernment. Liberal Presidents, notably Lyndon Johnson, have championed their cause. The Senate a halfdozen times has complied by passing various home rule bills.

title: Stocks Drop Again; Dow Declines 9.38
description: Disappointing news on the inflation front and on 1973 earnings prospects for Westinghouse Electrica big Wall Street blue chipcombined to send stock prices lower yesterday. Westinghouse, the volume leader, plunged 7 points to 24 after trading at its lowest price since 1967. Management said that several persistent problems would cause lower earnings for this year.. Profits ran $2.24 a share in 1972.

title: MATHIAS TO CURB HIS OWN CAMPAIGN
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 21Senator Charles McC. Mathias announced today that he would voluntarily impose restrictions on his own reelection campaign, including a $100 limitation on contributions.

title: Howard Samuels Weds; Antoinette Chautemps
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Howard J. Samuels, president and chairman of the New York City Off Track Betting Corporation and unannounced candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in New York next year, and Mrs. Antoinette Chautemps were married in a private civil ceremony at the home of friends here. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Camille Chautemps of Washington and the late Mr. Chautemps, who was Premier of France.

title: Shah of Iran Urges Arabs To End Their Oil Embargo
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21The Shah of Iran has declared that any tightening of the Arab oil embargo would lead to an economic disaster and has urged the Persian Gulf nations to ends the measure.

title: Books of The Times
description: Everything you always wanted to know about the New York City Ballet but were afraid to ask is not what you will find in this beautifully illustrated volume. The New York City Ballet offers little new material on one of the greatest classical ballet companies of all time. One could argue that it is not so much about the City Ballet as it is about its cofounder and general director, Lincoln Kirstein.

title: Chrysler Recalls 179 Cars
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation anflounced today that it was notifying 179 owners of 1974 model Plymouth, Valiant and Dodge Dart automobiles that their vehicles may have been assembled with an incorrect idler arm. The company said that 75 per cent of the vehicles being recalled had been assembled with the incorrect part, which could result in a loss of steering control.

title: Many Possibilities For Yankees' Post
description: The New York Yankees, whose hallmark for the last 55 years has been a manager of exceptional distinction, suddenly find themselves entering 1974 with no manager at all.

title: Votes in Congress This Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area Senate
description: 1. Vote on nomination of William B. Saxbe to be United States Attorney General. Nomination confirmed, 75 to 10, Dec. 17. 2. Vote on bill making appropriations for foreign aid, which passed, 55 to 31, Dec. 17. 3. Vote on motion to close debate on Rhodesian chrome ore bill, which required twothirds vote for passage. Motion passed, 63 to 26, Dec. 18. 4. Vote on conference report on bill banning importation of Rhodesian chrome ore, which passed, 54 to 37, Dec. 18.

title: Fears and Hopes
description: This has been a year of agony for most stockmarket investors. The DowJones industrial average hit a peak early in 1973, reaching 1051.70 on Jan. 11. It then began to fall, dragged down by the sinking dollar and the sinking fortunes of the Nixon Administration. In the early fall, the dollar strengthened and Wall Street brightened, accepting the economists' consensus forecast of a soft landing for the economya moderate business slowdown in 1974 and a gradual tapering of inflationary pressures.

title: Panama Canal Seeking First Rise in Tolls
description: The Panama Canal Company is seeking the first increase in tolls since the waterway was opened in 1914, it was announced yesterday.

title: Beame Team
description: The decision of Mayorelect Beame to reappoint John E. Zuccotti, the imaginative and dedicated chairman of the City Planning Commission, provides encouraging new evidence that high standards are being applied in most cases in selecting the new leadership team at City Hallalthough the strange appointment of Edwin L. Weisl Jr. to the sensitive post of Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, for which he has little discernible qualification, is disappointing.

title: SUBPOENA SCORED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A spokesman for President Nixon said today that the Senate Watergate committee's 60page subpoena asking for hundreds of documents and tape recordings was incredible and raised the possibility that Mr. Nixon might not honor it in full.

title: Doar Doubts Need to Link Criminal Actions to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) John M. Doar, the special House investigator, said today that it might not he necessary to show that President Nixon had committed criminal offenses as a prerequisite to impeaching him.

title: Israel and Soviet End 6Year Silence
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel met tonight with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, in the first highlevel session between Israel and Russian officials since the Soviet Union severed diplomatic relations during the 1967 war.

title: RUDOLF FORST
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 21 Rudolf Forst, musician, composer and teacher, died Wednesday at Grasslands Hospital, Valhalla. His age was 73, and he lived here.

title: Dave Anderson
description: YONKERS, Dec. 21In the mist under Yonkers Raceway's lights, a hard wind slanted cold rain across the puddled brown track. During most of the race, the horseplayers had huddled under the shelter of the grandstand but now, as hoofs slapped along the stretch last night, hurried toward the rail. At the finish, a few bettors whooped. Others turned away, their faces sour with annoyance, their vocabularies punctuated by obscenities. Among them a small man in a worn gray coat turned on two burly track policemen, their hands in the pockets of their blue woolen coats.

title: Art: Seasonal Selections
description: In spite of plastic Christmas trees and similar pollutants, Christmas is still a i9thcentury festival in this country, which explains why Twice as Natural, an exhibition of the 19thcentury American genre painting at the Finch College Museum of Art, persistently takes on a Christmas flavor at this season, although so far as I can recall there isn't a single Christmas scene in it.

title: Orders for Durables Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  New orders for durable goods rose a marginal 0.3 per cent, or $127million, in November to $44.2billion, compared with an upward revised $44.04billion in October.

title: Whitney Uptown: Sculptures in Wood
description: The organic and the geometric: the polarity is almost too pat, yet it very precisely identifies the artistic loyalties of the two sculptors Michael Lekakis and Anne Truittwhose work is being shown in separate exhibitions at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Both are abstract artists who work in wood, yet their respective attitudes toward this venerable medium are totally opposed. Though contemporaries, they scarcely seem to inhabit the same esthetic universe.

title: Tarkenton of Vikings In First Playoff Role
description: Who will be the hero of the National Football League's series of playoff games this season? No one seems better cast for the role than Francis Asbury Tarkenton, the Minnesota quarterback who in his 13th pro season finds himself facing a new experience, playoff games. For the first time he is with a championship outfit, the Vikings, who won the Central Division title in the National Conference and have designs on the Super Bowl.

title: 2 REACTOR ORDERS RECEIVED BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has received two additional orders for boilingwater nuclear reactor electric generating systems, it was learned yesterday. Mexico's Federal Electricity Commission and the National Institute for Nuclear Energy has ordered its second 660megawatt unit with initial fuel and five reload fuel batches.

title: Too Cold for Hockey
description: TROY, N.Y., Dec. 21 (AP) A Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey game scheduled tonight was canceled because its opponent was snowed in, in Canada. A storm prevented the Waterloo (Ontario) University team from making the trip.

title: Record FuelCost Rises Propel Price Index Here to a New High
description: A record 18.5 per cent rise in the costs of fuel oil and coal combined with sharp increases in food prices to drive the regional Consumer Price Index for November to a new high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: W. F. Wheeler Jr. Weds Mrs. Post
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 21Mrs. Nonnye Landers Post of Binghamton was married here yesterday to Wilmot Fitch Wheeler Jr., chairman of the board of the American Chain & Cable Company, Inc. The ceremony was performed in the presence of the immediate families in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Phil Porter Jr., assisted by the Rev. John C. Humphries.

title: HODAS IS CLEARED IN TWO BOMBINGS
description: Martin J. Hodas, the reputed porno king, has been acquitted of charges of firebombing two competitive massage parlors on West 42d Street.

title: BERRIGAN AWARD UNDER NEW FIRE
description: The Rev. Donald S. Harrington said yesterday that he would not present a peace award to the Rev. Daniel Berrigan because of what he called his recent antiIsrael and antiJewish address before an Arab audience.

title: Goodby, Mr. Gitt
description: BOSTONMost of the obituary notices for J. W. Gitt, the combative Pennsylvania publisher who died here Oct. 7 at age 89, reported that such things as population shifts, rising costs and labor problems led him in 1970 to sell The Gazette and Daily of York County, a newspaper he had owned and directed for 55 years. From my experience as active editor of the paper for 20 years I take a different view, although it is true that The Gazette and Daily confronted the external and internal pressures which have brought about the sale, amalgamation or closing of many urban newspapers over the last quarter of a century and more.

title: Prices in November Pace Serious Inflationary Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The nation's most serious peacetime inflation in the modern era continued in November at an unabated pace, Labor Department statistics disclosed today.

title: Chris Evert Advances In Tennis
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP)Peachy Kellemeyer, the captain of the United States team, hoped her players could regroup after they fell behind Australia, 21, in the opening round today of the Bonne Bell Cup women's tennis competition.

title: JAPAN DECLARES EMERGENCY ON OIL
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 22Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan declared a state of emergency this morning to deal with the current oil shortage and inflation. He ordered an immediate 20 per cent cutback in oil and electric power to major industries.

title: For Some, Sun's the Answer
description: What ever happened to those millions of solar homes that the futurists promised us in the nineteenseventies? Have they gone the way of the predicted helicopter in every backyard?

title: Rain Brings Floods, Outages in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21  More than two inches of rain and melting snow and ice caused widespread minor flooding, sporadic power failures, traffic snarls and waterlogged basements throughout New Jertoday.

title: Decline Reported In Christmas Gifts To Child Agencies
description: Administrators of some privote and municipal childcare agencies say that the spirit of giving seems less in evidence this year, and that this may mean a subdued holiday for several thousand underprivileged children in the metropolitan area.

title: POVERTY AID HERE INCREASED BY U.S.
description: An increase of nearly onethird in Federal funds for antipoverty efforts in New York City$6,219,031 to add to an earlier $20millionfor the year started last July 1 was announced yesterday by United States Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: DARTMOUTH CLUB CLOSES ITS SUITE
description: Confronted with financial troubles and the loss of third of its members in the last decade, the 48yearold Dartmouth College Club closed its suite at the Commodore Hotel yesterday and, swallowing its pride, said it would move into the Yale Club on Jan. 1.

title: VIOLATIONS GO ON, U.N. AIDE REPORTS
description: CAIRO, Dec. 21The United Nations Emergency Force today reported continuing outbreaks of shooting along the EgyptianIsraeli front lines, and Cairo commentators asserted that fullscale war would erupt if the peace conference in Geneva failed to bring results.

title: Legislature Urged to Ban The Use of Amphetamines
description: TRENTON, Dec. 21  An Assembly committee recommended today that the State Legislature enact an outright ban on the use of amphetamines for any purpose whatsoever.

title: Profit Pinch for Mobile and MotorHome Makers
Subscribers to Series Of Films to Get Refunds
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness announced Thursday that the American Film Theater had promised to pay refunds to customers whose prepaid subscription tickets never arrived or came too late.

title: City Control of Methadone Urged After Council Study
description: A special City Council committee, asserting that methadone has been oversold both to the addict and the public, yesterday urged legislation allowing the city to regulate all methadone programs here.

title: Sales of  Gas Gulping Recreation Vehicles Lag
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21  Of all the cars and trucks families drive, probably none is a bigger gas hog than a recreational vehicle.

title: The Deadly Trackers'
description: Our sturdiest screen staple, the Western, is made to look viciously senile in "The Deadly Trackers," an unremittingly bloody search-and-destroy chase that pulled up lame yesterday at local theaters. The vengeance sought by a sheriff whose family has been slaughtered by an inept but bestial gang of bank robbers results simply in fireworks and gore and little more.What the producers had in mind is difficult to discern from the foggy and arty, if explosive, action. Samuel Fuller, already adored by his own cult followers, reportedly began directing "The Deadly Trackers" from his story "Riata" and then was replaced by Barry Shear. But despite any credits or disclaimers, the sum total here appears to be, at best, a distressingly chaotic adventure.Richard Harris, who gives the appearance of a Pilgrim ascetic with an unlikely brogue as the once peace-loving but now vengeful lawman, is given to musings, fumblings, gesturing and occasional ranting on his long trek down to Mexico to mow down the slayers of his wife and young son. Rod Taylor, as the outlaw chief, is vague and bland about the bloody business he's in, except for the climactic moments when he suddenly displays unexpected tenderness toward his illegitmate little daughter who is caught up in the final, fatal shootout in a Mexican convent.Al Lettieri is mostly befuddled as the pudgy Mexican sheriff, also tracking the killers and occasionally tangling with our hero, who is dispatched, along with Taylor, in that convent. The outlaws are simply simple-minded assassins who deserve their bloodbaths.In bemoaning his wife's death, Richard Harris dolefully intones, "They've shot the roses from her checks." Unfortunately, neither script, direction nor its shot-up cast look very rosy in "The Deadly Trackers."

title: Shah of Iran Urges Arabs To End Their Oil Embargo
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21The Shah of Iran has declared that any tightening of the Arab oil embargo would lead to an economic disaster and has urged the Persian Gulf nations to end the measure.

title: 4 in Family Killed In Gas Explosion; Blast Levels Home
description: VINELAND, Dec. 21 (UPI)Three children and their mother were killed today when a flash fire and explosion, possibly caused by leaking gas, flattened their home and burned like an inferno, according to the police.

title: CHARLES P. DEMO
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 21 Charles P. Deyo, a retired banker and industrialist, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 82 years old.

title: Poaching Inquiry Began
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) Representative John Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, said today that an investigation had begun into massive poaching of offshore fish supplies by for eign fleets. Mr. Murphy, chairman of the House Coast Guard Committee, said he had called on the staff of his committee to look into the matter and its economic and ecological effects.

title: Egypt and Jordan Take Similar Stands
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21 Egypt and Jordan today laid on the conference table basically identical blueprints for peace in the Middle East based on total withdrawal by Israel from the Arab territories she occupied in 1967.

title: Citizen Asks for Thermostat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) One energyconscious American has asked the Government to send him a thermostat so he can turn it down. He told the energy chief, William E. Simon, in a letter that he did not have a thermostat In his house but would like to cooperate with the Government.

title: Prices in November Pace Serious Inflationary Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The nation's most serious peacetime inflation in the modern era continued in November at an unabated pace, Labor Department statistics disclosed today.

title: JOHN BRISLIN, 62, REPORTER, IS DEAD
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP) John Harold Brislin, Pulitzer Prizewinning reporter for The Scranton Tribune and The Scrantonian, died yesterday after a fivemonth illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: The Golden City Of Jerusalem
description: GENEVASince the 1967 Palestine conflict there has only been one major topic on which all Israelis agree: insistence that Jerusalem, including, the Arab part known as the Old City and captured during the SixDay War, must remain incorporated in the Jewish state.

title: Law Firm Sues Onassis Over PhotographyCase Fee
description: A prestigious Park Avenue law firm has sued Aristotle Onassis to collect legal fees and costs stemming from its defense of his wife, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, in a suit involving Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer.

title: VIETCONG TO GET AID FROM SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21The Soviet Union today disclosed an agreement to provide, a broad range of economic aid to the Communistled Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam.

title: ARTHUR POOLE DIES; LED BUILDING FIRM
description: Arthur E. Poole, president and chief executive officer of the Hallen Construction Company, Inc., Island Park, L.I., died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hospital in Far Rockaway. He was 60 years old and lived at Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: Stelio Salmona, Newsman And Korean War Hero, Dies
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21 (UPI) Stelio Salmona, a Korean war hero and news broadcaster who twice ran as a Republican for the Congress, died of a heart ailment last night at YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 45 years old.

title: Jimi Hendrix, the Man and the Singer, Documented:The Program
description: The producers of "Jimi Hendrix," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and West, have avoided the temptation to turn a hearse into a bandwagon. This documentary, about the rock star who died at 27 from an overdose of barbiturates, combines fragments of interviews with Mr. Hendrix's father, friends and acquaintances, with chunks of his performances at the Monterey Pop Festival, Woodstock, the Isle of Wight and others  without attempting a necrological high.Mr. Hendrix's famous guitar-burning sequenceswhen he beckons the rising flames with encouraging fingers  are interspersed with the moments when he plucked the strings with his teeth or smashed the instrument, glimpses of him in flagrante delicto with an amplifier, the exhalation of "Sssock it to me" and his parody of the national anthem. Throughout, the reminiscences are fond, reflective, rather gentle. His father recalls him strumming a broom as if it were a guitar; Little Richard says, "At times' he used to make my big toe shoot up in my boot," and several pronounce him shy. Early on, his admiration for Bob Dylan is underlined, and he sometimes appears like a black Mick Jagger. Later, he reminds you of no one.Despite every success, he seems to have fallen between stools: An American who depended on England for his first major recognition, a black man who worried about his black friends' opinion of his music. We're told that black radio stations were at first reluctant to play his recordings, stating that his style did not "relate," while white stations thought it too rugged. The conflicts mount steadily. Decked in the ruffled shirts and sequined boleros and jeweled headbands, he said that he didn't care what the public thought. But the friends stress that being conspicuous troubled him. Some think that he wanted to shed his spectacular act and "just get people to listen to the music."While the ravages of promotion and the isolation of stardom are evoked, as well as "the load of leeches" that fed on him, one young woman says that Mr. Hendrix was no more self-destructive than a passenger on a plane that crashes. That image lingers. Yet it's difficult to weigh, since his black friends feel that he had "a fast fuse"a sense shared with many black people that life wouldn't be long, that it was likely to burn out quickly. While this movie doesn't tell us quite enough about Jimi Hendrix the musician, it does convey some of the talent and the anguish and the exuberance that were there.

title: Quarter Horses Get L. I. Dates
description: The first quarterhorse meeting in New York State will run from April 18 through Nov. 30 next year, Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, announced yesterday.

title: 70 Debutantes, Holding Candles, Form Christmas Star at Ball
description: Seventy young women were presented at the 38th annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the WaldorfAstoria last night. Mrs. Jean William Bauer and Mrs. Frederick H. Gilimore were cochairmen for the event, which benefits the New York Infirmary.

title: CAROLINE D. EMERSON
description: HOLLAND, Mass., Dec. 21Caroline D. Emerson, an author of children's books, died at the Harrington Memorial Hospital in Southbridge on Wednesday. She was 82 years old and had lived here for many years.

title: Treasury Bills Mixed At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Yields on United States Treasury hills fell for threemonth bills and rose for sixmonth bills in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Lindsay Appoints Four of His Aides to Judgeships
description: Four Lindsay administration officials, including Simeon Golar, a Liberal party stalwart, were appointed yesterday to fill vacancies in the Family and Criminal Courts.

title: Response to Terrorism
description: The indiscriminate murder of 32 innocent persons by five Arab hijackers at the Rome and Athens airports is a crime that must not be allowed to go unpunisheddespite the miserable history of past attempts to bring terrorists to trial or to penalize their protectors.

title: Film: 'A King in New York' at Last:The Cast
description: He springs to his feet with an incredibly straight back, as though he had swallowed a telescope; in a noisy restaurant, he mimes his order to the waiter who can't hear him: a pop-eyed swimming fish for caviar, a scuttling turtle for turtle soup.
