Discussing dentistry at an elegant dinner party, he ties a napkin over a fat woman's bosom and fills her mouth with knives and sugar tongs. In an elevator, he thoughtfully slides his finger into the nozzle of a fire extinguisher, becomes wonderfully entangled in the loops of hose, runs off with yards of it trailing behind him and ends by soaking the judge who is investigating him as a Communist conspirator. The choicest moments pass very quickly, simply because Chaplin's best jokes were always sudden: it's the pratfall we don't foresee, or the lunge of improvisation, that reveal his genius."A King in New York," which opened yesterday at the Playboy Theater, was an effort to satirize McCarthyism. It was released in Europe in 1957, when Chaplin was 68. In 1952, when he was traveling abroad, the United States Attorney General stated that Chaplin (a British subject) would not be allowed to return to America without a hearing on charges of "moral turpitude and Communist sympathies." Chaplin stayed away, often repeating that he was not a Communist, but "an internationalist, a peacemonger." In 1956, he said that he wasn't interested in offering "A King in New York" for the American market. Now, we're able to see it for the first time.Chaplin plays the ex-king of a nameless country, who lost his throne because he opposed nuclear weapons and planned to use atomic energy for peaceful purposes. Hurtling to Manhattan for sanctuary, he soon discovers that America is insane. Conventional shots of skyscrapers and jostling crowds inform us of our inhumanity. It's revealed that our movies are brutal, our commercials crass and that people have to do humiliating things for money.Clearly, Chaplin loved playing king. Here, as in some of his other pictures, he seems to be in awe of the rich and the class system, even though he has often derided both. But the camera ogles opulence. (As his autobiography shows, it was ironic that a man who loved money and property so deeply should have been accused of communism.) His king has little in common with the legendary tramp, except for the occasional wriggling shrug that accompanies the raised eyebrows and the nervous toothy grin. He tries to make this aristocrat seem angelic, almost saintlywhich makes for some embarrassing moments.The king has a brief skirmish with a young woman in advertising, played with relentless perkiness by Dawn Addams. He then gets involved with a child prodigy whose parents are former Communists; they're jailed for refusing to give names. The boy (acted by Chaplin's son Michael, then 11) has to appear as a tiny demagogue, spouting Marx while the indignant king attempts to argue or interrupt. Meanwhile, the rhetoric rises to a denunciation of all forms of government.Chaplin crammed his own views between the boy's jawsand deliberately made them sound foolish. The result is a failed farce. Caricaturing the child as a semi-monster hardly strikes a blow for liberalism. Actually, the result is oddly reactionary, since the anti-McCarthy mouthpiece is forced to be absurd. And some sticky spurts of pathos increase the political confusion. Finally, the boy turns informer in order to get his parents out of prison, and he becomes a shattered, weeping wreck. The king, like Chaplin, leaves America.Despite Chaplin's denials, this is a very bitter filmand why should it be otherwise? We can applaud his anger, and it's easier than ever to sympathize with characters grown cautious about what they say over the phone, who worry that their rooms are bugged or sense that they're about to be subpenaed. However, the great man botched his own political arguments, and this movie sags below the rest of his work.Yet, it's important to see "A King in New York": it brings back the bad old days. And the fact that even Chaplin couldn't make guilt by association funny is crucial to our past and present history.

title: Miss Kniffin's Bridal
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 21Miss Constance Ross Kniffin, daughter of Ogden Kniffin of New York and the late Mrs. Catherine Swan Castles of Stamford, was married here this evening in the First Presbyterian Church to Carl David Keith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Frederick Keith of Trumansburg, N.Y. The Rev. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony. The bride and her husband teach in the Macon, Ga., school system.

title: The Wind Blows, the Electricity Flowsand the Lights Go On
description: EAST HOLDEN, Me.  If Henry and Retta Clews's handmade house is on the modest side  a cozy space and a tool shop down, an airy, toyscattered nursery up  the 50 rolling acres of meadow, mountain, orchard and trout stream surrounding it are nothing short of dazzling.

title: STORES IN BOSTON SHOW SALES GAIN
description: BOSTONIn what may be an indication of things to come, the giant, downtown Jordan Marsh store here has apparently become the beneficiary of the fuel pinch.

title: NIXON EXPENSE FUND TREATED AS TAXABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Treasury has been treating the annual expense allowance of the President of $50,000 as a form of salary subject to withholding tax at least since 1959 and possibly since 1951, the official in charge of these matters said today.

title: Williamstown Paper Dies
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP)  The Williamstown News, an independent weekly, will suspend publication, the paper said yesterday.

title: Raiders Choice to End Stealers' Spell Today
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21The Pittsburgh Steelers, who have beaten the Oakland Raiders three straight times, were 4 point underdogs today as the wildcard entry for tomorrow's firstround American Football Conference playoff game against the Western Division champions.

title: U.S WITNESS TELLS OF FAKING INSANITY
description: Avon White, a Government witness, testified yesterday in the bankrobbery trial of a black militant, Joanne Chesimard, how he had faked insanity to get himself transferred from a maximumsecurity prison to a minimumsecurity hospital.

title: CurtissWright Payment
description: The CurtissWright Corporation said yesterday that it would receive a payment of $4,454,000 on Dec. 26 from the General Motors Corporation as an installment against its nonexclusive license to manufacture a Wankeltype engine to be used in G. M. cars in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

title: Excerpts From the Opening Statements at the Geneva Conference on the Mideast
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2IFollowing are excerpts from speeches today at the opening session of the ArabIsraeli peace conference here:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: MIDDLE EAST FOES CLASH AT OPENING OF PEACE PARLEY
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21The first ArabIsraeli peace conference opened today with strong pleas by the United States and the Soviet Union for a permanent settlement that would avoid another Middle East war and break what Secretary of State Kissinger called the shackles of the past.

title: Professor Enters Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) Villanova University professor, Dr. John A. Logue, announced today hat he would seek the Pennsylvania Democratic nomination for next year's Senate race. I can beat Dick Schweiker in 1974, he said in a press statement.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1973

title: Bride: The Theme of One Old Deal May Appear New to Many
description: New ideas in card play are hard to come by, but the theme of the diagramed deal will be new to many readers. The contract is four spades by South, reached after East made an accentric opening bid of three hearts, where most would prefer one heart or a weak twobid.

title: Ariz. State's Big Plays Beat Pitt
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 21 (AP) Danny White's 62yard touchdown pass to Greg Hudson and Woody Green's 23yard run for another touchdown a minute later broke open an erratic, Fiesta Bowl game tonight and gave Arizona State a 28.7 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Miami of Ohio, Florida Play Tonight
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP)Defense was expected to dominate the Tangerine Bowl football game tomorrow night between 17thranked Miami of Ohio and the University of Florida. The game is rated a tossup. Miami led the nation's colleges in defense, allowing 177 yards a game in rolling over 10 opponents for a perfect season. Florida was one of the toughest defensive teams in the Southeastern Conference while winning its last five games, including a 490 rout of its traditional rival, Florida State. The Gaters finished with a 7.4 wonlost record.

title: League Is Reconsidering Padres' Shift
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 The proposed move of the Padres' franchise from San Diego to Washington was dealt a setback tonight when the new owners failed to meet a deadline on the provisions for transferring the baseball team.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon is again delaying his annual medical examination, which had been scheduled for last Saturday, so that his personal physician, Dr. Walter R. Tkach, can fly to California to be married. The President is said to have told Dr. Tkach that the medical tests could be arranged after he returns from his honeymoon.

title: Top Yankee Managers
description: * Second tour of duty.

title: S. B. A. DISMISSES 3 REGIONAL AIDD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Three regional officials of the Small Business Administration were dismissed today in apparent reaction to recent Congressional charges of widespread mismanagement in many of the agency's offices.

title: Aluminum Output for 1973 4.5 Million Tons, Up by 9%
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Aluminum Company of America said today that despite droughtinduced hydroelectric curtailments in the Pacific Northwest, domestic aluminum smelters produced a record amount of primary ingot in 1973.

title: Lawman Who Joined Mobsters Is Gunned to Death in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UPI)Richard Cain, a top Chicago lawman before he became chauffeur for the city's most feared mobsters, was gunned to death yesterday in an apparent gangland execution when he walked into a sandwich shop.

title: New Offerings
description: Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering early next year of $150million of debentures. The offering, would be made through underwriters headed by Lehman Bros., to include $100million of debentures maturing in 25 years and $50million to mature in 7 years.

title: JAPAN ATTEMPTS TO CURB INFLATION
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21  Japan raised her official discount rate today to 9 per cent from 7 per cent, a record high, as part of a major effort to curb inflation.

title: Geneva Parley Only a Strained Beginning
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21The absence of pomp, the severe security arrangements and the meticulous protocol observed as the delegates to the Middle East peace conference filed into the meeting room reflected a point on which all could agree.

title: The Ghost of Christmas Endless
description: Christmas almost here again, and I suddenly remember Ebenezer Scrooge. Must visit him. You never think of me until Christmas rolls around, he always complains.

title: Pistons Top Warriors as Bing Excels
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP)Dave Bing led a lastperiod comeback tonight that enabled the Detroit Pistons to beat the Golden State Warriors, 107104, for the 10th victory in their last 12 National Basketball Association games.

title: OTTAWA PARLIAMENT DEFERS ENERGY BILL
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 21 (Canadian, Press)  Canada's Parliament, which is considering Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's proposed Energy Supplies Emergency Act, reached an agreement today to recess until Jan. 3.

title: School Plan Rejected Again
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP)Voters, for the third time in one year, defeated yesterday a proposal to build a new 22room elementary school.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ODD LOTS Every year before Christmas, the Elgin Cinema, Eighth Avenue and 19th Street (6750935), strays from the beaten path of commercial cinema, going even further afield than this usually offbeat house routinely ventures. From tomorrow through Wednesday, it will be showing an avantgarde film series put together by the experimental film virtuoso Jonas Mekas, under the Sponsorship of the FilmMakers Cinemathtque. The 16mm. films are by knowns and unknowns and are shown at 2, 7 and 9 tomorrow; 4, 7 and 9 Monday, 2, 7, 9:30 Christmas Day; 4, 7, 9:30 Wednesday.

title: Anna McCann Robert Taggart Have Nuptials
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 21  Dr. Anna Marguerite McCann, senior research associate in the Greek and Roman department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, was married here today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Preston Jr., her brotherinlaw and sister, to Robert Dorsett Taggart, a vice president of the Bank of New York.

title: SuperSonics Cleared on Dump Charge
description: Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, yesterday cleared the Seattle SuperSonics of charges they had thrown a game in order to get their coach dismissed last season. The accusation was made in an article in the Dec. 10 issue of Sports Illustrated. Bob Briner, who wrote the story, said it took a dumped game on Jan. 7 to get Coach Tom Nissalke dismissed. The Philadelphia 76ers won the game in question, 8582, at Seattle and Nissalke was dismissed two days later.

title: People in Sports: Nice Guys FinishOut
description: Larry Jones is a nice guy, and most sports fans know what that means if they are familiar with Leo Durocher's credo, Nice guys finish last.

title: 30Nation Moslem Talks Set On the Mideast, Bhutto Says
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 21 President Zulfikar All Bhutto announced tonight that a toplevel Islamic conference would consider the Middle East situation.

title: Burning of a Rembrandt Threatened
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 (AP) Thieves threatened today to burn a Rembrandt painting stolen on Tuesday from the Taft Museum if a $200,000 ransom was not paid, said a man negotiating for return of the work. The police said a second painting, found in a barn last night, was returned safely to the museum today.

title: Earthquake in California
description: EUREKA, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI), A moderate earthquake shook the northern coastal area of California today but caused Tic) reported damage or injuries. The quake was felt in an area north and south of this coastal city.

title: Vanderbilt U. Sued By C.B.S. on Sales Of Cronkite Tapes
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System brought suit yesterday against Vanderbilt University for what it termed the unauthorized editing, videotaping and distributing for a fee of copies of the C.B.S. Evening News with Walter Cronkite.

title: MIDDLE EAST FOES CLASH AT OPENING OF PEACE PARLEY
description: GENEVA, Dec. 21The first ArabIsraeli peace conference, opened today with strong pleas by the United States and the Soviet Union for a permanent settlement that would avoid another Middle East war and break what Secretary of State Kissinger called the shackles of the past.

title: Judge Orders Data in Suit to Justify Deletions in Book on C.I.A.
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 21 A Federal judge here ordered the Government today to turn over a number of documents to back up its contention that certain information must be deleted from a book about the Central Intelligence Agency before the book may be published.

title: House Rejects Energy Bill After It Passes the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 22The House killed a modified emergency energy bill early today. The vote was 219 to 34.

title: Wider U.S. Inquiry Is Hinted in Superfecta Fixing
description: While harnessracing spokesmen called for an immediate trial of 13 accused drivers, there were indications yesterday that the Federal investigation of alleged racefixing was continuing.

title: CHILE WILL PAY U.S. $124MILLION DEBTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Chilean Government has agreed to pay $124million in debts to the United States over the next eight years, the Treasury and State Departments said today.

title: P.U.C. STAY SOUGHT ON PHONE CHARGES
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21The Pub lic Utilities Commission rate counsel has asked the regulatory agency to hold off the implementation of an automatic costadjustment formula awarded to the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company last week on the ground that it would inflate the utility's rate of return at customers' expense.

title: Energy Briefs
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  The Federal Government has shelved a plan to call in 250 oilindustry officials to help run the fuelallocation program. Duke R. Ligon, director of the Office of Oil and Gas, said the plan had been postponed indefinitely after the Acting Attorney General, Robert H. Bork, ruled the oilmen might face conflictofinterest charges over decisions they would make involving their own companies.

title: Schedule for Exchanges
description: The major United States stock exchanges will operate on normal schedules Monday, Dec. 24, but will be closed on Tuesday, Christmas day. Canadian stock exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be closed both Monday and Tuesday. Banks in New York State will be open Monday and closed Tuesday.

title: WINE TALK
description: The business of wine predicting becomes rather silly at times, The air is filled with prognostications almost before the grapes are in the vats. There are even people who will tell you all about next year based on the condition of the vines right now.

title: CONGRESS PASSES 11% BENEFITS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Senate and the House gave final approval today to an 11 per cent increase in two steps in Social Security benefits for some 29 million retired persons.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A New Jersey Assembly committee yesterday recommended legislation banning the use of amphetamines in New Jersey for any purpose whatsoever. The committee said that the range of medical uses for the drug was small but that the possibility for its abusive use was very large. The committee conducted several hearings into the use of amphetaminesknown as speed in the drug cultureand said that if an outright ban on the drug could not be passed by the Legislature, the quantity of amphetamines manufactured and distributed should be drastically curtailed. The use of a triplicate prescription procedure for Certain drugs similar to those in use in several states was also recommended.

title: 3% CUT IN VOLTAGE ORDERED IN STATE
description: The Public Service Commission ordered all electric utilities in New York State yesterday to cut voltage 3 per around the clock; in a move it said would save 2.5 million to 3 million barrels of oil a year while having only minimal effect on the consumers of the state.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EDGEWATER, N.J., Dec. 21If Jim Cronin didn't like kids and football, maybe he wouldn't be where he is nowin Englewood Hospital. But there is no trace of bitterness in this determined little man. It all happened late one Saturday afternoon in October.

title: St. John's Posts Upset Over Alabama, 7267
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21With a defense that forced many turnovers, St. John's stunned 10thranked Alabama, 7267, in the opening round of the Connecticut Classic at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum tonight.

title: Record Rain and High Winds Batter City
description: A 24hour downpour dumped redord amounts of rain throughout the Northeast yesterday, flooding many highways and, lowlying areas and wreaking havoc on many New Yorkers' plans to make an early getaway for the long holiday weekend.

title: Spanish Rightists Disrupt Funeral of Slain Premier
description: MADRID, Dec. 21  Spain's assassinated Premier, Luis Carrero Blanco, was buried this afternoon after a tense funeral procession that extreme rightists turned into a political demonstration.

title: Robert T. Jones 3d Dies; Golfer's Son Was Banker
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 21 (AP)Robert T. Jones 3d, son of Bobby Jones, died last night in a hospital here of a heart attack. He was 47 years old.

title: U.S. POLICY CITED IN ROME KILLINGS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21A statement published here today and attributed to the Palestinian guerrilla faction that claimed responsibility for the massacre at Rome airport last Monday said the attack was aimed at Americans because of the airlift of weapons to Israel during the war in October.

title: And Downtown, Three Noted Names
description: All three of the stellar attractions  Louise Nevelson, Alexander Calder and the late David Smith  included in the current sculpture show at the Whitney Museum of American Art's Downtown Museum, 55 Water Street, may be famous and thoroughly familiar, but their works have never looked so distinctly individualnor so compatibleas they do in this particular conjunction.

title: Nixon Fills 2 Legal Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) President Nixon today named two lawyers to the Council of the Administrative Conference of the United States, They were Assistant Attorney General Robert G. Dixon Jr. and Harold Louis Russell of Atlanta. The 10member panel recommends improvements in Federal legal procedures.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: The New York and Connecticut lottery numbers, usually, drawn on Thursday, were postponed until yesterday.

title: Campus Notes
description: Middlebury College officials, in Middlebury, Vt., have found a solution to a budding campus controversy  they hope. The issue involves, two important facilities, the campus library and the Snow Bowl, a wellknown ski resort owned by the school.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: The New York and Connecticut lottery numbers, usually drawn on Thursday, were postponed until yesterday.

title: Braves Conquer Knicks
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 21  The Knicks tried hard to lose tonight and they finally succeeded.

title: Protests Are Halted as WNJR Revises Its Programing
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21  The Committee for a Unified Newark said today that it was calling off its protests against radio station WNJR because of the recent hiring of a black station manager who had been working with community groups on programing.

title: Argentina Sets Economic Plan To Nearly Double Growth Rate
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 (Reuters)President Juan D. Perlin announced an ambitious threeyear economic plan for Argentina today that he said would raise the gross national product by 7.8 per cent a year, the highest rate ever.

title: President Appoints Aide to Help Rally Support
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21President Nixon has assigned Bruce Herschensohn, who was the subject of controversy when he made films for the United States Information Agency, to be a fulltime White House contact for persons wishing to express their support for the President.

title: BECK ACQUITTED IN SECURITY SALES
description: A former official of the state's Democratic party won acquittal yesterday on charges of conspiracy, fraud and transportation of stolen securities worth more than $500,000.

title: Black College Quintets To Play Here Tonight
description: If you are one of those who have never heard of Clarence E. (Big. House) Gaines, the basketball coach at Winston Salem State University, then you want to stop off at C.C.N.Y.'s Mahoney Gymnasium tonight at 8:30 to see Gaines' Rams play Howard University just for the sake of witnessing a little history.

title: People and Business
description: Jerome S. Hyams, who resigned on Oct. 1 as senior executive vice president of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., has been named to the new post of chairman of the executive committee of the Prudential Building Maintenance Corporation.

title: PLANNED RATE RISES IN POSTAGE CUT BACK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council cut back today an increase in postal rates sought by the United States Postal Service, The result will probably be a twomonth delay in raising the price of a firstclass stamp from 8 to 10 cents.

title: Military Appeals Court Upholds Conviction of Calley
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The conviction of Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of at least 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was upheld today by the United States Court of Military Appeals.

title: Regan College Coach
description: ALLENDALE, Mich., Dec. 21 (UPI)Grand Valley State College named today a former major league pitcher, Phil Regan, as its baseball coach.

title: Antiques: Music Makers
description: Harsh sounds, joyous sounds, provocative sounds are giving tonal life to two current exhibitions of handcrafted vintage instruments that are just about as exciting to see as to hear.

title: Busy Europe and Mideast Ports Cast Doubts on Oil Cut's Effects
description: PARIS, Dec. 21The level of activity in the ports of Europe and the Middle East indicates that the oil shortage may not be as acute as many thought it would be at this point  some two months after the Arabs first brandished their oil weapon.

title: BARMAN SEEKING SIGNAL'S OIL UNIT
description: The Signal Companies, Inc., has agreed to sell for $480million its wholly owned subsidiary, the Signal Oil & Gas Company, of Houston, Tex., to Burmah Oil, Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., of Britain.

title: Plane Crash in Peru Kills 6
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 21 (Reuters)A Bolivian military transport plane, crashed at Talara in northern Peru today, killing six people and Injuring three, the air force announced here. The Convair turboprop airliner was flying passengers and toys from Panama to La Paz, air force sources said.

title: Chemist Slain While on Way to Party
description: On the way from his bank to an office Christmas party, Ernst Rothstein a 59yearold chemist for the Union Wire Die Corporation, was shot dead on a Queens street yesterday afternoon in what the police believe was an abortive holdup.

title: Bay State Offers Firewood
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent ordered the state Department of Natural Resources Wednesday to open state parks to those who want to pick up or cut fire wood to help relieve the shortage of home heating fuel. Up to three cords of firewood could be taken by individuals at a charge of $2 a cord.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: If William C. Norris is under the impression that trade with the Soviet Union brings great benefits to the United States [letter Nov. 30], he is sadly mistaken, for the fact is that we have been trading with the Russians for over fifty years and have little to show for it.

title: Pope Voices Hopes For Find Solution Of Mideast Conflict
description: ROME, Dec. 21Pope Paul VI voiced hope today that the ArabIsraeli peace conference in Geneva would lead to a lasting Middle East settlement, and said that he expected to be consulted on the future of Jerusalem.

title: Paul Witt, Professor, Dies; Created Liquid Sulfa Drug,
description: ABILENE, Tex., Dec. 21 (AP) Dr. Paul C. Witt, professor emeritus of chemistry at Abilene Christian College, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: Sakharov Vows He'd Return to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident nuclear physicist, declared today that his place was in the Soviet Union and that he intended to return here if he were allowed to Accept an invitation to lecture in the United States.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Carolyn Minskoff often goes right to the source to get interesting crafts for Reservation Creations, her North American Indian gallery on Madison Avenue.

title: C.B.S. CALLS SUIT ACT OF REPRISAL
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, in its answer to an antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department in April, 1972, asserted yesterday that the legal action by the Government was an act of reprisal against the network for exercising its First Amendment rights in covering news of the Nixon Administration.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state warned yesterday that some of the 200 people who ate a church dinner in Burlington County Nov. 3 could be incubating typhoid fever. They could be in danger, their families could be in danger, and those with whom they associate could be in danger, said Dr. Martin Goldfield, assistant state health commissioner.

title: VIETCONG WALK OUT OF TALKS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Vietcong today walked out of a negotiating session with South Vietnamese representatives in a fresh clash over South Vietmna's political future.

title: Rioting Flares for 4th Day in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 (AP)  Leftist demonstrators machinegunned a government bailding in Tripoli and barricaded highways and tore down traffic lights in Beirut in the fourth day of antiGovernment rioting today.

title: Little Adjustment Needed On Improved TV Cameral
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A new color television camera, patented this week for the Columbia Broadcasting System, is described as a significant advance in the art and as promising high performance. William E. Glenn Jr., vice president and director of research at C.B.S. Laboratories, Stamford, Conn., was granted Patent 3,780,212 for the camera and filter. The camera has a single image pickup tube instead of the three now used in most color cameras to derive separate signals for the three primary colors.

title: Hughes Swears In. Lawyers
description: Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes swore in 779 lawyers today to practice in New Jersey, The new lawyers also were admitted to practice beswearingin ceremony was Justice Hughes's first official function since becoming head of the state court system.

title: The Next Crises: Population and Resources
description: The average citizen, harassed by successive crises in water pollution air pollution, solid waste, noise, dwindling open space and now energy, may well wonder when the next environmental shoe will drop.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: IRVIN WASSON JR.
description: Irvin Wayne Wasson Jr., a publicrelations executive, died Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 47 years old and lived at 145 East 15th Street.

title: A Christmas Down Home Lures Many
description: To many blacks standing in the long ticket lines at the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday, juggling luggage and keeping an eye on restless children, going home for Christmas meant traveling south.

title: JERSEY JONES DIES; BOXING WRITER, 75
description: NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 21 (AP)Willis N. (Jersey) Jones of North Arlington, boxing historian and manager of fighters, died Wednesday at St. Michael's Hospital in Newark after having suffered a series of strokes. His age was 75.

title: Casco Williams, Musician In Jazz Bands Dies at 79
description: Casco Williams, former jazzband player and financial secretary of the New Amsterdam Musical Association, died Wednesday of a heart attack at Harlem Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 2049 Fifth Avenue.

title: 6 Soviet Jews Seeking Exit Hair House Trade Condition
description: MYSCOW, Dec. 21  Six Soviet Jews who have been denied permission to emigrate to Israel expressed hope today that the recent vote by the House of Representatives linking trade concessions to freer Soviet emigration might help prod the Soviet Union to adopt a formal emigration policy.

title: Another Side of Mountainside ...and Springfield
description: Margo Krasnoff's description of the widespread use of marijuana among her contemporaries is an exaggerated portrait of what is, sadly, not isolated behavior.

title: London's Center Is Target Of New Wave of Bombings
description: LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 22 Three bombs exploded in the center of London about midnight last night and the police suspected that others may have been planted in the area.

title: Travel Plans of Nixon Upset the Press
description: The White House's handling of President Nixon's onagain, offagain trip to Florida next week has further complicated the President's already uneasy relationship with the press.

title: A.E.C. Says Dow Chemical Did Not Report Atom Leaks
description: BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 21 (AP)The Atomic Energy Commission says the Dow Chemical Company has failed to report two leaks of radioactive materials in the last five years.

title: French Connection
description: PARIS, Dec. 21 (UPI)A legal inquiry has been opened in France after suspicion that a horse race in which bettors must forecast the first three finishers was fixed. After the Prix Bride Abattue tirc race at Auteuil here Dec. 9, a spokesman for the parimutuel betting organization said, We are withholding payment on about 20 winning tickets.

title: Boyle Pleads Not Guilty to Three Counts of Murder
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Dec. 21  W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, pleaded not guilty today to three counts of murder in connection with the Yablonski family slayings in 1969.

title: For Ensemble, Music of Past Is Pleasure of Present
description: Lips tight against the mouthpiece of his rauschpfeife, Shelley Gruskin pierced the air with a nasal and raucous lament. Wendy Gillespie drew pure, muted sounds from the strings of her gamba with an underhand stroke of the bow.

title: Impeachment View Pressed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) President Nixon should be impeached for interfering with the constitutionally guaranteed freedom of the press by means of wiretaps, F.B.I. investigations and threats of punitive action, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said yesterday in the sixth in a series of weekly statements calling for impeachment.

title: Malpractice Suit Settled for $1Million
description: A young man who entered the United States Public Service Health Hospital on Staten Island more than four years ago for the repair of a minor eye injury and emerged a quadraplegic and unable to see or speak, agreed yesterday to a $1million settlement by the Federal Government.

title: A Modest Plan for the Cities
description: WASHINGTONIn city after city thousands of housing units  abandoned but structurally soundhave been given over to rats and vandals. Yet in those same cities large numbers of people are wretchedly housed. The combination of those two facts has led to the idea of urban homesteading, based on a strategy devised a century ago when we were trying to open up the West and encourage settlement on the frontier.

title: WOMEN TEACHERS ARE SUING CITY U.
description: A City University faculty women's group yesterday filed a sexbias suit against the university in Federal Court here, charging that women are discriminated against in every possible aspect of employment in the university system.

title: Sather and Giroux Help Blues Score
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21. (UPI) Glen Sather and Larry Giroux set up both St. Louis goals tonight to give the Blues a 21 victory over the Atlanta Flames in the National Hockey League.

title: OncePeriled Alligator Is Gaining in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21The alligator, which was considered an endangered species a few years ago, has made so strong a comeback in this region that Louisiana is offering to give some of the reptiles away.

title: Hughes Back in Bahamas; U.S, Indictment Expected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, has gone to the Bahamas and a.penthouse complex in the Xanadu Hotel at Freeport, apparently to prepare a refuge from Federal indictments expected to be returned against him next week in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: MONEY REFORM LAG INDICATED BY SHULTZ
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, indicated today that a July 31, 1974, target for resolving all issues of international monetary reform was unlikely to be achieved.

title: Hughes Back in Bahamas; U.S. Indictment Expected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, has gone to the Bahamas and a penthouse complex in the Xanadu Hotel at Freeport, apparently to prepare a refuge from Federal indictments expected to be returned against him next week in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: 3 Astronauts Study Kohoutek to Learn About Its Icy Core
description: HOUSTON, Dec, 21 (UPI)The Skylab 3 astronauts studied the streaking comet Kohoutek through their solar telescopes today to learn more about the makeup of its icy core, which is slowly melting away as it nears the sun.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: FORD SEES A DROP IN QUARTER'S NET
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21The Ford Motor Company expects a sharp decline in earnings in the last three months of 1973 and also looks for lower sales in 1974 to have an adverse effect on operating results next year.

title: Busy Europe and Mideast Ports Cast Doubts on Oil Cut's Effects
description: PARIS, Dec. 21The level of activity in the ports of Europe and the Middle East indicates that the oil shortage may not be as acute as many thought it would be at this point  some two months after the Arabs first brandished their oil weapon.

title: Weekly Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion tonmiles, 14.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The A.A.R. also announced carloadings for the same week totaled 534,038, 10.8 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

title: WHEAT FUTURES IN MIXED MOVES
description: Oldcrop wheat futures rose a little yesterday and new crop months declined. The divergent trends told the story of traders' thinking about what the Government's latest figures on wheat exports meant and what they guessed the Govenment's first estimate of the winter wheat crop would be.

title: The Enemy Factor In New York and Civilized London
description: IT is a shock to come back to New York City after having lived in London, and a shock helps clear one's vision. Nothis is not another report on the delights of walking through a European city in the middle of the night without fear of muggers. Nor is it a reassurance that the excitements of New York outweigh its horrors. Rather, I shall try to give an impression of a basic New York mood, the feeling of the city, as it struck a returning New Yorker. And I'm not thinking of Watergate or postWatergate or inflation moods; I'm concerned with a deeper and more lasting pattern of behavior. I believe that this pattern has changed much less through the years than we usually believe.

title: Temple Fills Vacancy
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., Dec. 22 (UPI)  Southern Illinois University announced today its football team would meet Temple at Philadelphia on Oct. 12, 1974, filling a vacancy left on the schedule of both teams when Xavier announced it would drop football next year.

title: CON EDISON BUYS COAL FOR 45 DAYS
description: Last Wednesday morning, Bertram Schwartz, a Consolidated Edison vice president emerged from a meeting in Albany and authorized an aide in New York to buy 18,000 tons of coal at $25 a ton.

title: Why Can't the World's Airports Be Secure?
description: To many air travelers, whether they are apprehensive or casual, the answer to terrorists like those who struck in Rome is a simple one: increase the security at all airports until it is so tight that a slingshot could not get through undetected.

title: No Silence And No Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22At this Christmas season, there is still no peace and very little good will in the Middle East, but finally there is some hopejust a chance that the private talks in Geneva will finally lead to a more durable accommodation.

title: MRS. POLLY B. HOWE
description: Mrs. Polly Brooks Howe, who in 1948 leased her estate in Locust Valley, L.I., to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, died yesterday at her home, 20 Sutton. Place South, Her age was 72.

title: The Year in Sports: Ten Men to a Nine
description: A record total of 30,045,788 persons paid close to $100million to watch majorleague baseball last summer. But it's possible they were shortchanged because much of the significant action again took place behind the scenes in another turbulent year of economic warfare, cityhopping and high, hard lawsuits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Marjorie Dubb Bride Of Howard S. Rosing
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Dec. 22Miss Marjorie Dubb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen I. Dubb of East Williston and Cotuit, Mass., was married here this evening to Howard S. Rosing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford L. Rosing of Bethesda, Md., and Altamonte Springs, Fla. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: That Job in Alaska May Be Pipedream
description: TRENTON  The Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of labor and Industry, Ronald M. Heymann, has warned of false and misleading advertising offering highpaying positions in connection with the Alaskan pipeline project.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Golf Prize Increased
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Dec. 22 (UPI)The Ohio KingsIsland open golf tournament will be held at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Center for the second consecutive year in 1974, with a raise of $25,000 in the prize money to $150,000 and new September dates, Charles S. Mechem Jr., chairman of the board of the sponsoring Taft Broadcasting Company, announced today.

title: Crangle Seeks Spending Pledge By Party's Governor Hopefuls
description: The State Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, said yesterday that he hoped to enlist all his party's governorship contenders next month in a public pledge to limit their primarycampaign spending and to attack Republicans rather than engage in a repetition of past fratricidal strife.

title: Couldn't Get Tickets for Bob Dylan? Join the Club
description: ARE you wondering why you could not get tickets to any of the Dylan concerts? On Sunday, Dec. 2, a fullpage advertisement in The Times announced Bob Dylan's first appearances in nearly eight years  three performances at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 30 and 31. Since the Garden holds 20,000 people, that meant 60,000 seats.

title: Safety Council Says Shortages Of Gasoline Will Cut Road Toll
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22  The nation's energy crisis, widely considered the bane of weekend automobile travelers, may be reducing the steady increase in highway deaths in the United States.

title: Holiday Shoppers Still SpendingBut Cautiously
description: In one of the most mixed Christmas shopping seasons in years, millions of Americans have demonstrated their anxieties and pinched wallets by buying cautiously and sparingly. But others in affluent circumstances, ignoring the country's problems, have bought lavishly.

title: Energy: Many Skeptical on Reasons for Crisis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22On a crowded airliner a stewardess stops to chat and fret about her impending layoff. On the same flight a Midwestern sales manager gulps a double Scotch and sadly wonders aloud how he is going to tell three good salesmen that they are to be dropped.

title: S.M.U. Penalizes Football Coach
description: DALLAS, Dec. 22 (AP)Dave Smith, Southern Methodist head football coach, has been stripped of his athletic directorship and placed on probation, the university's president disclosed today in a report to the Southwest Conference.

title: Basques: Ancient Thorn to Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 22If Premier Luis Carrero Blanco stood for the continuity of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime, he also represented for many ques a symbol and instrument of the repression that has kept a tight lid on the centuriesolds nationalism of one of Europe's most ancient peoples.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Silent Night, Holy Night  In a Spanish Prison Camp, 1938
description: Do you have at least one Christmas Eve you remember clearly? I find all of mine form a pleasant blur, except one, 35 years ago.

title: Padres Still Await Word On Just Where Home Is
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 The fate of the San Diego Padres was just as uncertain today as it had been 2 weeks ago, pending another meeting of the National League club owners, a meeting that may not take place until January.

title: Steeler Coach, Players Agree: Raiders Deserved the Victory
description: OAKLAND, Dec. 22 (UPI)  They beat the hell out of us, it's as simple as that.

title: Stamps
description: CHRISTMAS is a dove of peace on the mail Canadians get, a carol on British stamps, palms in a nautilus shell to inhabitants of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands, a family going to church for New Zealanders and to Nicaraguans Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus.

title: Bruins' Unbeaten Streak Ended by Red Wings, 42
description: DETROIT, Dec. 22 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings rode the strength of two powerplay goals in the second period tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 42, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Something of a stir was caused last February with the publication of The Rocksburg Railroad Murders by K. C. Constantine. The book attracted a good deal of attention for its middleclass ambience, its realism and the author's infallible ear for bluecollar patterns of speech and thought. Now comes THE MAN WHO LIKED TO LOOK AT HIMSELF (Saturday Review Press, $5.95), and it turns out to be as good as its predecessor.

title: What's Doing in RIO DE JANEIRO
description: NEW YEAR'S EVEThe Festival of Iemanja (the Goddess of the Waters) is a cross between a pagan rite and a Holy Rollers sessionand it is a very different way to spend New Year's Eve. Adherents of Umbanda (a type of African spiritism), of which there are 20 million in Brazil, flock to Rio's beaches with mirrors, combs, food and flowers for the goddess. Dressed in white and carrying candles, they gather in circles and sway and chant themselves into a trance. At midnight the believers and many spectators make a wish and walk a short way into the sea, casting their offerings to the waves. If the gifts are returned, Iemanja has rejected their request. Regular Umbanda sessions can be attended all year round. A rabbi turned spiritist takes small groups interested in spiritism to nearby centers. He can be reached through Brazil Safaris and Tours, the local representative of American Express.

title: LongTerm Investing: Pitfalls Emerge
description: One of the most persistent ideas on Wall Street is that longterm investing  the purchase of stocks with the idea of holding them for many years  ultimately produces large profits. All that is required is that selection be confined to reasonably high quality stocks and that the investor be patient.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynGroup show by the HeightsHill Artists Cooperative, through Jan. 3, Tuesday, Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 3 P.M., and weekends, noon to 5 P.M., Gallery 91, 91 Atlantic Avenue.

title: What Happened To Swinging London?
description: WHERE Are They Now? asks the title of one of Ray Davies' songs on the Kinks's latest album, Preservation Act 1 (RCA LPL5002). Where have all the Swinging Londoners gone? Ossie Clark and Mary Quant and what of Christine Keeler?

title: Beth Bencini Plans Nuptials
description: HIGH POINT, N. C., Dec. 22  Mayor William Snow Bencini and Mrs. Bencini have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth Constance Bencini, to Gene Frederick Zarcone, son of Mrs. Frederick Zarcone of New Hyde Park, L. I., and the late Mr. Zarcone.

title: Secretariat: Horse of the Year and Horse of the Era
description: Secretariat was the horse of the year, and beyond that, the horse of the era. The Meadow Stable colt with the three white stockings became a sports idol. And even the fact that he was beaten three times in 12 starts failed to dim his brightness. Indeed, it heightened the admiration of the sports public for the 3yearold Virginiabred son of Bold Ruler and Somethingroyal.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Dolphins at Home Today
description: MIAMI, Dec. 22Facing a team many people believe was helped into the American Conference playoffs by an official's erroneous call, the Miami Dolphins begin serious defense of their National Football League championship tomorrow.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I have a suspicion that America is no longer No. 1. It cannot be confirmed, of course, but still. There is evidence everywhere. Evidence that does not fit with the Number Oneness of things American.

title: Air France Aide Cleared On Showing Racy Film
description: PARIS, Dec. 22 (Reuters)An appeals court has reversed a ruling against the inflight entertainment chief of Air France, who had been fined for allowing the screening of an adult film aboard a plane in which a 10yearold girl was a passenger.

title: 1973: The Sports Hero Was a Horse
description: The heavyweight champion of the world hit the floor six times in 4 minutes, Henry Aaron chased Babe Ruth's ghost all summer, Billie Jean King scampered into history as the Amelia Jenks Bloomer of her time, and America's best college basketball team ran its winning streak to infinity. Nevertheless, the biggest thing in sports in 1973 was a horse.

title: Konte Plays His Poignant Kora
description: ALHAJI BAI KONTE (Rounder Records 5001)  the title Alhaji designates his status as a marabout or holy man of Islamperforms African music on the kora, a harp with 21 strings. Konte's music is classical in that it consists of a repertoire of set pieces and stems from a tradition which emphasizes instrumental virtuosity. But it is equally a folk art, since Konte's subject matter recalls the deeds of kings and heroes of the Senegambian Mandinke tribe.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Homosexuals probably have more social freedom in New York than in any other American city, but they have yet to gain official city recognition of their rights against discrimination in housing, employment and public accommodations. Last week they unexpectedly lost another round in their fight. For the fourth time in the past three years, a City Council committee rejected a bill to ban such discrimination.

title: NIXON SEEKS REPORT ON PAY TO VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  President Nixon demanded today a report on why some 5,000 students in southern California had not received veterans' benefit checks, some for as long as four months.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A Fine may for a Director to Act!
description: Why should a movie director do all the work and yet go unrecognized by moviegoers? Well, it doesn't have to work that waynot if the director has an ounce or so of the old ham in him. Through the years, a surprising number of directorial biggiesHitchcock, Welles, Lang, Huston, Renoir, Von Stroheim, Preminger, De Sica, to mention only a fewhave been bitten by the acting bug. And today, when the practice is perhaps hotter than ever before, you can see a whole slew of directors emoting, among them Martin Scorsese, who plays an assassin in his own Mean Streets, and Mark Rydell, who acts a sadistic gangster in Robert Altman's The Long Goodbye. Not to mention Woody Allen, who's done a dandy job of directing Woody Allen in the town's newest hit, Sleeper.

title: Four More Bombs Explode In London, Hurting 5 People
description: LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP)Four bombs exploded in London today, injuring five people. The blasts were the latest in a wave of explosions that has been attributed to Irish Republican guerrillas.

title: N. Hampshire, St. Louis Ready to Join Monopoly
description: The old order may be crumbling a bit in collegiate hockey. Although more than 100 schools field varsity squads, teams like Cornell, Boston University, Denver and Michigan Tech have dominated sectional and national championship play since the late nineteenfifties.

title: Mrs. Barbara Scullin Remarried
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 22 Mrs. Barbara DuBarry Scullin of Rosemont was married here at noon today to Michael Pardee Erdman, a partner in the Philadelphia architectural firm of Ewing, Cole, Erdman & Eubank. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: Fuel Shortage Is Felt in Many Areas Throughout the State
description: OCEAN CITYThis resort city of 11,000 persons is in an enviable position; unlike scores of towns and governmental agencies throughout the state, it has been promised an adequate supply of gasoline and heating oil for 1974.

title: U.N. Assembly Session Produces 150 Resolutions and a Treaty to Protect Diplomats
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22Delegates to the 28th General Assembly headed home this week after a 13week session in which they adopted 150 resolutions and wrote a new international treaty that aims at protecting diplomats from attack.

title: DEFICIT REDUCED BY MAIL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The United States Postal Service says that it has cut its losses from more than $175million in the fiscal year 1972 to slightly less than $13million in the fiscal year 1973, its second full year of operation.

title: Do We Have to Ration Merry Christmas?
description: The custom of wishing one another a simple Merry Christmas seems to be dying out. All of a sudden, perfectly nice people are unwilling to commit themselves wholeheartedly on this point. They will only say: If I don't see you, have a Merry Christmas.

title: U.C.L.A.Goes, On and On And Walton Does Same
description: The Walton Gang was on the rampage again last winter. From the last weekend of November, 1972, until March 26, 1973, Bill Walton led the University of California, Los Angeles, to another battering of 30 opponents. The season began with a 41point victory over Wisconsin and ended with an 8766 rout of Memphis State. That final triumph gave the Bruins their seventh straight national championship and their ninth in 10 seasons.

title: Some Couldnt Come in From the Cold
description: MANHASSET, L. I.The brutal storm that ripped its way through the Long Island area last week left in its wake a tangle of uprooted trees and smashed automobiles, but for most residents the bitter power blackouts will be hardest to forget.

title: Recordings
description: THE question of musical interpretation is a perennial one, and every generation defines its own standards. Musicians blessed with true recreative genius always have the most compelling answers, of course, but not everyone is going to find them equally valid. You play Bach your way, I'll play him his way, Wanda Landowska once remarked sweetly to a colleague, and by her lights she was perfectly right. Without such supreme selfconfidence, Landowska might never have become the incandeseent artist that she was, even if her monster Pleyel harpsichord and many interpretive idiosyncrasies no longer jibe with our current of Bach style.

title: Record Set In Downhill By Austrian
description: SCHLADMING, Austria, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  Franz Klammer of Austria took the lead in the World Cup ski competition today by winning the downhill at the fastest speed ever clocked in a Cup event.

title: Lebanon Quiet After Riots; Tripoli Strike Is Called Off
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22 (AP)Lebanon was quiet today after four days of street rioting that left four persons dead and prompted the Government to pledge to fight soaring food prices.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comprable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Sylvan Lawrence, the builder and real estate investor, has purchased the 23story building at 71 Broadway from the U.S. Steel Corporation for $6,500,000.

title: Bridge
description: Most games of skill have areas of mystery. The professional performs some astounding feat that leaves the amateur openmouthed with astonishment. The billiard champion executes a masse shot, and his ball curves carefully round an obstacle. The golf pro brings off a controlled slice or hook, doing the wrong thing at the right time.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 260 bookstores in 110 communities of thq United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: It's the whole system and the nature of its interactions we should look
description: We know so much about man, and understand so little. I shall be satisfied if the book dces anything to encourage others to understand more. These words, from the author's introduction to An Introduction to the Study of Man, fairly set the stage for an extraordinarily massive and comprehensive treatment, not only of human life and body and mind, but of life in general, and extending even beyond this, to issues of cosmic evolution. The scope of the volume, as well as its character as primarily a survey of an immensely wide terrain, are consonant with the setting and purpose from which the work took its genesis: a series of lectures designed for medical and dental students at the beginning of their studies. In the words of the author, it is intended as an introduction to the possibility of studying man in a scientific manner.

title: Nicklaus Breaks a Record
description: It wasa super year for super golfers. Jack Nicklaus achieved one, goal by winning his 14th major championship. This came with his Professional Golfers' Association victory at Cleveland as he scored 277 to beat Bruce Crampton of Australia by four strokes. It enabled the 33yearold professional to eclipse the record of 13 major titles set by the late Bobby Jones in 1930.

title: The Toy Industry's Game Plan
description: Send Joe Willie Namath on a rollout pass to the right. Or call a draw off left tackle. It's 1965 and you're Bear Bryant, coach of Alabama's national football champions. Or you can pick any of 31 other college football teams of the last decade.

title: 2 IN QUEENS ROBBED EN ROUTE TO BANKS
description: Two Queens businessmen on their way to make bank deposits yesterday afternoon were robbed at gunpoint of a total of $27,500 in cash in two separate incidents, the police reported.

title: James Biggane to Take Diamond's State Position
description: James L. Biggane, a career man with the state who started 26 years ago as a beach patrolman at Jones Beach State Park, is to be appointed this week as Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, a state official said yesterday.

title: Porsche Expected to Quit CanAm Auto Race Series
description: The International Automobile Federation (F.I.A.) announced it will reduce by 25 per cent the amount of fuel used in championship races in 1974 and asks national racing authorities to do the same.

title: Tarkenton Passes Defeat Redskins by 27 to 20
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 22It took Francis Tarkenton 13 years to get himself into a big, key football game. When the moment came today he won contrary to the prediction of a former coach of his, Norm Van Brocklin, who once said that Tarkenton would never win the big ones.

title: BEAME APPOINTS EXWAGNER AIDE
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday chose John T. Carroll, a 63yearold former Highways Commissioner under Mayor Robert F: Wagner, to head the city's Municipal Service Administration.

title: Mrs. Sidney Has Child
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec, 22 A daughter was horn Dec. 2 to Associate Professor Stuart Jay Sidney of the University of Connecticut mathematics department and Mrs. Sidney at the Manchester Memorial Hospital, Mrs. Sidney is the former Miss Joan Adria Seliger of New York, The child has been named Jennifer Ellen.

title: Photography
Art
description: UNIQUE and unprecedented are listed as dangerous words that should be avoided in The New York Times Style Book for Writers and Editors, which, always obedient, I try to follow. But surely we are on safe ground in saying that Janos Scholz is the one and only; single; sole man in the world who could have given a cello recital as he did at the Pierpont Morgan Library the evening of Dec. 11th, and follow it with the announcement that he was giving his collection of Italian drawings to the sponsoring institution. The occasion can't possibly have had a precedent, nor is it likely to serve as one, not because the musiciancollector combination need be all that rare, but because a comparable collection could hardly be formed again even by the most aggressive, perceptive, and luckiest of future cellists.

title: ARABS NEGOTIATE OVER 5 HIJACKERS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22The Palestine Liberation Organization was negotiating today with Kuwait to gain custody of the five Palestinian gunmen who killed 31 people at Rome airport Monday and then flew to Kuwait in a hijacked Lufthansa airliner.

title: On Brooklyn's Waterfront, New Facilities and Jobs
description: In the Brooklyn Navy Yard, steel is becoming a tanker. In the Northeast Terminal huge cranes are symbols of new containerport operations. A revived railroad freight line binds the Brooklyn piers to New England and the West. From a dock, adults and children have been catching fish.

title: The Flight Of Peter Fromm
description: This is a brilliantly illuminating metaphysical novel that employs ideas as adversaries and translates them into human dilemmas. It is not only the primal question of whether to believe or not to believe that is dealt with here. The question is in what to believe and to find the answer (or nonanswer) to this question, Martin Gardner sends his hero searching the spectrum of Protestant doctrine from fundamentalism to humanism. The significantly named Fromm (pious in German) comes from Oral Roberts country to the liberated Divinity School of the University of Chicago, filled with Pentecostal certainty. Peter's progress thereafter is recounted by his friend and teacher, Homer Wilson, a Unitarian clergyman of wide learning, unusual frankness and atheism.

title: Greece Bans Superstar
description: ATHENS, Dec. 22 (AP)Greece's military Government has banned the rock musical film Jesus Christ Superstar after officials of the Greek Orthodox Church complained about plans for showing it in Athens.

title: The pressures and pain of youth
description: Audrey Thomas, Nicholas Delbanco and F. D. Reeve are all experienced writers, and all are Americans, but with a twist Thomas has a touch of Canada in her diction, Delbanco emphasizes his connections with Europe, and Reeve is a poet. Each concerns himself with adolescents and families, with the pressures and pains of the outer world on a child who feels himself, like Stephen Dedalus, a cuckoo hatched in a foreign nest, and whose difference stems partly from an artistic temperament.

title: U.N. GENEVA ROLE ELATES WALDHEIM
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations said today that he was very happy with the opening phase of the Middle East peace conference. It showed that the United Nations is still a useful instrument if it is used in the right way and if we do our share, he said in an interview.

title: Coed's Quest for Rhodes Scholarship Ends on Sex Barrier
description: The Rhodes scholarship application specifies that candidates possess four essential qualities: intellectual attainment, character, leadership and physical vigor.

title: Music in Review
description: Bach's Christmas Oratorio was the seasonal offering of the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra in Carnegie Hall last Sunday afternoon. David Randolph conducted a substantially complete version (only a few de capo repeats were omitted), and soloists were Carolyn ValSchmidt, soprano; Ann Yervanian, mezzo soprano; Melvin Brown, tenor, and Benjamin Matthews, bassbaritone.

title: Troubled HighRise Is Sold
description: One of the city's most controversial highrise apartment buildings, Gracie Plaza, at 1701 York Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets, has been sold.

title: Nixon's Tax: Obscure Panel Will Scrutinize His Returns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The committee with the clumsy name that President Nixon has asked to review his tax returns is hardly a committee at all in the usual Congressional sense.

title: Whither Wheat?
description: Despite record wheat crops in both the United States and the Soviet Union, wheat prices have been exceptionally strong, and relief for the American consumer is still some time away.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: THE 30th President is just a misty memory, but his truth goes marching on in the 37th President's avid attempt to promote subsidized trade with the Soviet Union. The business of America is business, Coolidge declared, and his shade must. approve the Administration doctrine that the primary business of American foreign policy with regard to the most important nation we must deal with, is business. The doctrine means that it is not the business of United States foreign policy to promote human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: What Is Fairness On TV?
description: Suppose that last winter a Federal agency had been able to rule that The Washington Post in its Watergate expos articles was being unfair to Richard Nixon and had required the newspaper to publish a number of stories favorable to him, thus balancing the expos?

title: Letters
description: Gift of love

title: Bullets Set Back Rockets
description: LARGO, Md., Dec. 22 (UPI)Nick Weatherspoon, a rookie, came off the bench in the third quarter to lead the Capital Bullets to a 9889 victory over the Houston Rockets, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: An ExConvict Held In Slaying Is Freed By Judge Wright
description: A former convict with a criminal record dating to 1953, accused of beating a man to death in a Times Squarearea fistfight late last month, was released without bail yesterday by Manhattan Criminal Court Judge Bruce Wright.

title: Sun's Rays Used To Alter Sludge
description: KINGSTON  Can the sun's rays be harnessed to help solve the problem of the growing amount of sewage sludge that must be disposed of every year?

title: Energy Shortage Puts Spotlight on Light at the Task
description: The lights are going off all over New York.

title: For Buffalo Bills, It's O.J. All the Way; For Television Viewers, It's Open House
description: O. J. Simpson was everyone's hero in pro football this season. The talented 26yearold running back for the Buffalo team set a season record by gaining 2,003 yards in 14 games, of which the otherwise unexceptional Bills won nine.They needed 10 victories to gain the playoffs, which began this weekend for eight of the league's most successful squads, and Simpson said his only unattained goal now was to play in a Super Bowl event. So popular was he, everyone hoped a Super Bowl would be in his future.

title: A Different Midnight Mass
description: ALMA de MAJORCA, SpainMidnight mass on Christmas Eve celebrated throughout the Christian world with almost universal conformity to the prescribed ritual. Languages may vary now that the use of Latin is no longer mandatory, but the format remains the same everywhere. Everywhere, that is, except for two separate spots in the Mediterranean.

title: Top Democratic Senators Move to Right on Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Senate Democratic Presidential hopefuls are moving toward the right on a number of defense spending issues and taking an increasingly critical stance on the Nixon Administration's policy of dtente with Moscow.

title: Graham Chides Nixon
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, an old friend and occasional adviser to President Nixon, has accused the President of errors in judgment and of keeping himself in isolation at the White House. Page 24.

title: Nutcracker Ballet Coming to Trenton
description: TRENTONThe Princeton Regional Ballet's Nutcracker, after a sellout run for the 10th consecutive year at Princeton's McCarter Theatre, will move to Trenton's War Memorial Theatre for two performances next Saturday, Dec. 29, at 3 P.M. and 7 P.M.

title: ESKA UNIT ASKS COURT EXPANSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Changes in the structure of the Federal Court system, designed to cope with mounting caseloads, were proposed today by a 16member commission representing the President, Congress and the Supreme Court.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PITTSBURGH  What impels a man who has turned the nation's seventh largest steel producer from a $12millionayear loser into a $48millionayear winner to shuck it all and turn to new fields to conquer? Apparently, it's the challenge.

title: Nancy P. Arny To Be Married
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 22Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Amy of Upper Montclair and Shelter Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Pauline Amy, to Howard Ross Pywell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pywell Jr. of Canton, Mass.

title: North Dakota Tentatively Backs Plan for CoalGasification Plants
description: DETROIT, Dec. 22Part of the answer to the Midwest's shortage of natural gas may lie in the enormous deposits of lignite coal under the rolling prairie lands of western North Dakota, a thousand miles from here.

title: Spain Names 6 Basques In the Slaying of Premier
description: MADRID, Dec. 22The Spanish security police announced tonight that they had indisputable evidence that Basque terrorists assassinated Premier Luis Carrero Blanco.

title: Kessler to Be Cited
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Harry Kessler, one of the top referees during television's boxing heyday, will be honored at the St. Louis Baseball Writers' dinner Jan. 21. Kessler will receive the Ellis Veech Award for excellence in officiating.

title: College Foundation Reelects Officials
description: EDISONLillian Carman of New Brunswick, secretary of the board of trustees of Middlesex County College here was reelected president of the Middlesex County College Foundation at its recent meeting. She has been a member of the board of trustees since its formation in November, 1964.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The day after the baseball season ended, the wreckers moved into the Yankee Stadium and began to tear the joint apart. There is almost something symbolic about it in a sports year that was speckled by alteration, change and transformation, some for better and some for worse. Many were as jarring as if they had been, imposed by the swinging crunch of a wrecking ball.

title: Headliners
description: For the premeditated murder of not less than 22 Vietnamese in the hamlet of My Lai in South Vietnam in 1968, Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. in 1971 was sentenced to life in prison. A few months later the sentence was reduced by the commander of the United States 3d Army to 20 years. Then, as Lieutenant Calley's lawyers appealed that sentence, President Nixon ordered the convicted man removed from the stockade and placed under loose house arrest at Fort Benning, Ga. Mr. Nixon said that when the appeals were exhausted, he personally would review the case. Last week, in answer to the appeal, the nation's highest military court, the United States Court of Military Appeals, upheld Lieutenant Calley's murder conviction and the 20year sentence. The next avenue of appeal is to the Secretary of the Army and then the fate of Lieutenant Calley, the only man convicted for what has become known as the My Lai massacre, will rest with President Nixon.

title: State Utilities Prepare for Cut in Voltage
description: NiagaraMohawk Power Company workers in 37 upstate counties began changing over hundreds of voltage regulators manually yesterday as the state's utilities prepared for the statewide 3 per cent voltage reduction to conserve energy.

title: Graham Says He Gives 10 to 15% Of His Gross Income to Charity
description: The Rev. Billy Graham says that he and his wife contributed to 19 charities this year, almost all of them religious in nature.

title: JAPANESE REDUCE BUDGET INCREASE
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22The Japanese Cabinet today approved what it termed an austerity budget for 1974, calling for the smallest annual increase in spending in four years, as part of the Government's intense new effort to combat inflation and the oil shortage.

title: City Finance Units Move to Jamaica
description: South Jamaica, which over the last decade had sustained rapid and serious deterioration, took another step toward revitalization last week when the City Finance Administration moved its Queens offices into the area.

title: News of the Screen
description: Ralph Bakshi, the writerdirectoranimator, who with Steve Krantz produced the Xrated animated and liveaction features, Fritz the Cat and Heavy Traffic, says he's now working independently on three more movies in that mode. Included, he said, are Hey, Good Looking for Warner Bros., and The American Chronicles and Coonskin, now in production for Paramount.

title: Miss Mary Pidgeon Is Married On L.I. to Philip A. S. Franklin
description: REMSENBURG, L. I., Dec. 22In the Remsenburg Community Church this afternoon, Miss Mary Pidgeon was married to Philip A. S. Franklin by the Rev. Gordon G. Dickson.

title: Future Social Events
description: Dec. 27If you'd like to see Kohoutek at a reasonable hour, ensconced comfortably in a chair, then get yourself a child and go to the special Kohoutek watchin at the Hayden Planetarium, which the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association has arranged for school children as part of its afterschool program of scientific studies. At 5:15 P.M., the kids will have cocoa, cider and doughnuts in the Planetarium rotunda. At 6 the hourlong visual precreation of the midJanuary sky, with the comet and its beard at maximum length, will be shown. Tickets, from beneficiary, are $10. But remember, adults unaccompanied by children are

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival opens Thursday at Madison Square Garden with eight college teams competing. At P.M,. La Salle will play Stanford followed by Manhattan against St. Louis. Another doubleheader at 7 P.M. will pit Princeton against Duquesne and St. John's against Illinois.

title: More must be done'
description: ACCORDING to The Golden Heritage, official history of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the organization was formed in 1917 in an effort to bring some order into a chaotic condition in which 3,637 separate Jewish institutions in New York City  congregations, schools, recreational and cultural agencies, mutualaid societies and philanthropic correctional agencies  were competing against one another for contributions, making out of the New York situation a vast maze of wasted effort, time, money and duplication of services. Today the federation's membership includes six institutions for the care of the aged, 24 country and suburban camps, 30 agencies for child care, 27 familywelfare agencies, 35 community centers and educational facilities and 11 hospitals and medicalcare agencies, all of which render services primarily to the Jewish community but many of which offer help to all corners on a nonsectarian basis. Executive vice president Sanford Solender points out that, as a coordinating body, the federation not only raises money efficiently hut, in distributing it, carefully considers each agency's needs in relation to the overall purposes of the entire group. Gifts to the Neediest Fund are channeled to the federation's component agencies.

title: Israel and Egypt Cautiously Optimistic
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22Spokesmen for Israel and Egypt, in separate news conferences in the same highceilinged conference room here today, offered similar, cautiously optimistic appraisals of the opening round of the Middle East peace conference.

title: Klein Denounces PoliceBrutality Suit in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, last week denounced a police brutality suit that was brought against his administration by a group of blacks and Puerto Ricans as a shotgun approach to everything and everybody.

title: Greetings a la Berlitz
description: ACROSS

title: LincolnDouglas
description: A House Divided Against Itself Cannot Standwhat Alistair Cooke fan has not thought of the Civil War in terms of Lincoln's portentous speech. To be sure, a handy aid for understanding history, but one not quite right; Lincoln's speech was actually delivered three years before the Civil War as his acceptance of the Illinois Republican party's nomination for the Senate. House Divided was, in fact, the opening argument in a Senate contest which threw the Tall Sucker, Abraham Lincoln, against the Little Giant, Stephen A. Douglas. A campaign characterized by The New York Times, in 1858, as the most interesting political battleground in the Union. It is this battleground the Sigelschiffer's 500oddpage book leisurely toursmuch like the candidates, Sigelschiffer needs an editor.

title: In Albany, Duryea. Gets Warm G.O.P. Welcome
description: ALBANYGovernor Rockefeller bolted for the empty chair in the front row of the packed Red Room in the State Capitol here last Tuesday as the photographers clustered around the new Governor, Malcolm Wilson.

title: Graham Criticizes Nixon, Old Friend, on Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Rev. Billy Graham, an old friend and occasional adviser to President Nixon, has accused the President of errors in judgment and of keeping himself in isolation in the White House.

title: Weiskopf Top Golfer
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22 (AP)Tom Weiskopf, who won the British Open title last summer and compiled $243,155 in official earnings for 1973, was named today male golfer of the year by the Golf Writers of America. Kathy Whitworth was named to women's honors and Gay Brewer and Patty Berg were voted recipients of the Ben Hogan Award for comebacks from physical ailments.

title: Mrs. Feldman Has Son
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22A son was born Nov. 25 to Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Feldman of Washington at Sibley Hospital here. Mrs. Feldman is the former Miss Clarice Wagan of Milwaukee, who as Clarice Feldman is an associate counsel of the United Mine Workers of America in Washington. Mr. Feldman is chief counsel to the Senate Permanent Investigating SubCommittee, The child has been named David Lewis.

title: Utterly Lifelike, Yes, But Is It Anything More?
description: STARTLING verisimilitude, conventionally known as trompe l'oeil, has been a controversial feature of much recent realist art. The debate has mostly centered on a variety of painting called PhotoRealism and has questioned or defended the value of paintings that on first glance are practically indistinguishable from photographs. But tlfe last and probablythe untoppable word in visual art imitating life is the sculpture of John De Andrea, currently represented by six new pieces at the O.K. Harris Gallery, 469 West Broadway.

title: Swedish Medicine Is Troubled
description: This is the first of three articles on the Swedish health care system, frequently cited as a model for improving the American approach.
