The writer, staff member of The New York Times, recently spent five months in Sweden as a visiting physician at Serafima Hospital of the Karolinska Institute.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He's in a wheelchair now and he always will be, but Karl Kassulke hasn't surrendered to being a paraplegic.

title: Hearing Scheduled Over Ban on Artist
description: CAMDEN  A threejudge panel is scheduled to hold a hearing Jan. 10 on an application by the National Broadcasting Company to declare unconstitutional New Jersey's ban on courtroom artists.

title: Winter's First Bite Takes Toll on L.I.
description: With memories of the paralyzing ice storm that stunned the metropolitan area last Monday still painfully fresh, residents of Long Island's North Shore began resuming nearly normal routines at the week's end.

title: For Lindenwold, Free Rides?
description: TRENTONIn an effort to save gasoline and to relieve the heavy congestion of traffic leading toward the Benjamin Franklin Bridge to Philadelphia, a bill was filed in the Assembly last week that would allow southern New Jersey riders on the Lindenwold rapid transit line to travel free during nonrush hours.

title: Ens. Jared T. Kieling Marries Nancy Whitehead at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 22 The Princeton University Chapel was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Ann Rhodes Whitehead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Cleve Whitehead Jr. of Princeton and Squam Lake, Holderness, N. H., to Ens. Jared Taylor Kieling, U.S.N.

title: A sendup sent up and other ministrations
description: INTEROFFICE MEMO Dave: We have a problem with the Goldman review. The book is clearly a witty, affectionate sendup of the adventureyarn form, which Goldman (as the screenwriter for Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid) obviously loves and knows how to manipulate with enormous skill. You could say that it's the novelistic equivalent of Sandy Wilson poking fun, in The Boy Friend, at his equally obviously adored twenties musical comedies  except that Goldman goes even further. He has set up the story with an intro telling how as a boy, he loved having his father read him the alleged S. Morgenstern classic, but that when he himself gave the book to his 10  year  old son, the kid stopped reading after an early chapter. Goldman goes on to say that he then actually read the book for the first time and found that his father, in reading aloud to him, had simply and wisely skipped or telescoped the boring parts, hence this good parts version abridged by Goldman. He keeps breaking up the narrative with redinked passages, explaining what he's cut here and why. What this introduces is a kind of comedic extension of Brecht's distancing effect, alienation to provoke not an intellectual response, but an entertained response. And it works.

title: The Iceman Is Absent Too Much
description: JAMES EARL JONES'S first appearance in the Circle in the Square revival of The Iceman Cometh is virtually magical. Actually, director Theodore Mann has merely used an old stage trick  no doubt one Eugene O'Neill would have gleefully approvedto get him on: he has noisily diverted attention to one end of the long horseshoeshaped stage floor so that Mr. Jones can slip in, unnoticed, at the other.

title: Mutual or Balanced?
description: The first sparring round of the EastWest conference on mutual force reductions in Central Europe has ended with silence from the NATO camp but a sharp propaganda campaign from Moscow against Western proposals. The contrast suggests a reversal of positions toward a negotiation that promises to be the most difficult yet undertaken in the twodecade search for a European settlement.

title: Haiti Wins Soccer Final; Mexican Fans Angered
description: The Tournament of the Confederations of North, Central American and Caribbean Federations, to determine the country to represent the region in the World Cup in West Germany in June was completed Tuesday, with Haiti the winner.

title: A Revolution of the Right
description: THE publication of Max Kozloff's new book, Cubism / Futurism (Charterhouse, $9.95) comes at a propitious moment. At the Guggenheim Museum just now, in the selection of works from the Winston Collection that has been given the title Futurism: A Modern Focus, we are offered an unusual opportunity to acquaint ourselves with a significant number of unfamiliar items in the Futurist canon (as well as to reacquaint ourselves with some familiar masterworks). Takenas it should bein conjunction with the basic works already available to us in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art, the show at the Guggenheim provides the most comprehensive survey of the Futurist movement we have had since the 1961 exhibition organized by Jo hua Taylor. And Mr. Kozloff's study has the merit of reexamining some of the basic, unsettled questions concerning the movement's fundamental character and accomplishment.

title: Kerr on When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?
description: ONE of the troubles with Mark Medoff's When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder? is the fact that there is a clock on the wall and you can see what time it is. I use the word time here both literally and metaphorically.

title: A Tiny Metronome Attached to the Ear Is Helping Stutterers
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I.Mr. B. speaks fluently, but take away his hidden device and he is reduced to a helpless stutterer.

title: MAGAZINE STAFF ASSISTS NEEDIEST
description: Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are often deceptive. Sometimes the amount of a donation does not reflect the effort that went into collecting it.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Credit Card Concerns Cut Loss Attributed to Fraud
description: Through the extensive use of computers, credit card companies have been able to reduce sharply the volume of fraudulent use of their cards that has cost them millions of dollars a year, according to industry spokesman.

title: W.H.A. Makes Its Debut And Players Get Windfall
description: It was outrageous, of course. It was bizarre. Butall things consideredthe last hockey year was fun for the fans and a financial windfall for the players.

title: Architecture
description: EARNEST study follows earnest study, in the immortal words of New York Times columnist John Corry, and nowhere are they more earnest than in the housing field. The fact that I find them thoroughly absorbing and would rather read them than dull porn obviously marks me as some kind of a nut. The latest, America's Housing Needs: 19701980, produced by the Joint Center for Urban Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University, while not exactly The Story of O, is required literature for housing study buffs. It is, in its earnest and institutional way, a fascinatdocument.

title: Leslie Saidel Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Saidel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Ellen Saidel, to Robert Alan Faneuil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip F. Faneuil of Brookline, Mass. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Santa Boom
description: The Santa Claus business is booming this year.

title: Olympic Winners Decline
description: Track and field suffered its traditional postOlympic letdown in 1973 despite the usual crop of world records, fresh faces and the emergence of a new professional circuit.

title: the traveIer's worId
description: THERE is a computer over at Eastern Air Lines that is trying to break up my happy marriage. It seems that the Creative Concept Development unit of Eastern's Marketing, Planning and Advertising Department dreamed up the idea of applying psychology and computer technology to the problem of picking the right vacation destination for any applicant. Eastern put together the Perfect Vacation Planning Kit, a 16page booklet containing a 26part questionnaire.

title: Dr. Gradinger To Be Bride
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Dec. 22 Dr. Lynne Gradinger and Dr. Andrew Besen, 1973 graduates of the Boston University Medical School, plan to be married in June. Dr. Samson Gradinger, a dentist, and Mrs. Gradinger of Woodsburgh have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. Lester Besen, a physician, of Yonkers and Mrs. Arthur Silverman of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Leila H. Pile To Be Bride
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 22.  Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Pile Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leila Helene Pile, to John A. deBruyne, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman A. deBruyne of Cambridge, England, and Princeton, N. J.

title: Mary Dann's Nuptials
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 22Miss Mary Lindsay Dann and Jseph Marshall Kearney were married here today in the Westminster Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. John W. Christie, pastor emeritus, and the Rev. C. Frederick Mathias officiated. Dr. Christie, who celebrated his 90th birthday last month, is the bride's grandfather. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. C, Marshall Dann of Greenville and Mrs. Richard Kearney of New York and the late Mr. Kearney.

title: Dr. Walter Durfee, 84, Dies; Of HobartSmith Colleges
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Dec. 22Dr. Walter Hetherington Durfee, former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, died last night. He was 84 years old. 4

title: From Ice to Water to Freezing Again
description: What happened on the ground all last week was clear enoughfrom subfreezing to almost spring, from ice on everything to water gushing everywhere to subfreezing againbut what produced it was less obvious. According to meteorologists, the extraordinary week was the work of several local weather variants, a warm breath from the Atlantic and one large, unfriendly contribution from Canada.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Steelers Crushed 3314
description: OAKLAND, Calif, Dec. 22 The Oakland Raiders, who have been gathering momentum for the last month, powered their way into the American Football Conference championship game today by beating their chief tormentors of the last two years, the Pittsburgh Steelers, 3314.

title: Cup Soccer Date Set
description: MADRID, Dec. 22 (UPI) Ladislao Kubala, the Spanish national soccer coach, said today the Spanish football Federation had been informed that the World Cup playoff between Spain and Yugoslavia would be held Jan. 16 in Paris.

title: 4 Relay Events Won by Molloy
description: Archbishop Molloy, the Catholic High School's Athletic Association champion, posted four victories yesterday in the League's annual indoor relay carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Heidi E. Humphrey to Be a Bride
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 22Miss Heidi E. Humphrey, a member of the class of '75 at Yale College, and Henry Hobart Benedict 3d, a student at the Yale School of Architecture, plan to marry in the spring.

title: Stewart's 3 Goals Win for Islanders
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22Ralph Stewart achieved the first threegoal game of his twoyear career in the National Hockey League tonight to give the New York Islanders a 4:2 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Foes Are Evenly Matched
description: DALLAS, Dec. 22For 10 of the Dallas Cowboys' 22 starting players tomorrow, the contest in Texas Stadium against the Los Angeles Rams will be one more playoff game, their 14th in the last eight seasons.

title: The New Movies
description: SLEEPER, directed and written by Woody Allen and starring Allen and Diane Keaton, got 12 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Rex Reed, News; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Richard Schickel, Time) and 3 mixed (Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Archer Winsten, Post). At the Coronet and the Little Carnegie.

title: LINDSAY ALLIANCES ALL BUT DEFUNCT
description: The John V. Lindsay Associations, which played a major role in the reelection of the Mayor in 1969 and supported his shortlived bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year, have for the most part quietly faded away.

title: Tai G.T. Triumphs At Calder by Nose
description: MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP)Tai G.T. outran Mr. Sad by a nose today in winning the $24,800 Miami Beach Handicap for 2yearolds at Calder.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two correction officers of the Ossining State Correctional Facility were arrested in Brooklyn after a girlfriend of one allegedly shot and wounded him in a tavern in the Greenpoint section. The woman, identified as Esther Davila, 27 years old, of 47 India Street, was charged with shooting Bernard Garcia, 34, in the left buttock with his revolver during an argument. The second officer, Angel Mercado, was arrested for allegedly throwing the revolver in the rear yard of the tavern before the police arrived. ... A checkcashing store at 243 Nostrand Avenue, in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section, was robbed of $18,620 by an unidentified gunman who forced his way in after an employe unlocked the front door. .. . Five men, one with a sawedoff shotgun, took $4,000 and jewelry from 14 men at the G & E Social and Athletic Club in Mastic, L. I., during a card game.

title: Virginia Gerstley Will Be Wed To James Dubin, Law Student
description: RYDAL, Pa., Dec. 22Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Gerstley 2d of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia May Gerstley, to James Michael Dubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Dubin of Hamden, Conn.

title: Soviet to Let Americans Climb Its 3d Tallest Peak
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22  The Soviet Union has agreed to let a dozen American mountain climbers try to scale its third highest mountain, the 23,405foot Lenin Peak.

title: CONGRESS QUITS WITHOUT VOTING ENERGY MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The 93d Congress adjourned its first session today after abandoning efforts to pass major legislation giving President Nixon sweeping powers to impose gasoline rationing and take other emergency steps to conserve energy.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: Despite a small parliamentary base, Poul Hartling, leader of Denmark's Moderate Liberal party, was named last week to form a minority govern ment as the result of the overwhelm ingly antiSocialist vote in national elections Dec. 4. Mr. Hartling, a for mer Foreign Minister, faces a difficult task: His party commands only 22 seats in the 179seat Parliament.

title: Lombardi Award Has 4 Contenders
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) Lucious Salmon of Oklahoma, Bill Wyman of Texas, and Ohio State's Randy Gradishar and John Hicks have been named finalists for the fourth annual Vince Lombardi Award to college football's outstanding lineman.

title: The World
description: An assassins' bomb killed Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco last week, eliminating the man who has been running the country on behalf of the durable but frail Generalissimo Franco and placing unexpected stress on the continuity of leadership.

title: In Cold Print: Unhappy Returns
description: Any book reviewer, writes daily Times book reviewer Anatole Broyard, commenting on the naivet of a character in Dickle's List by Ann Birstein, a recently published novel set in the milieu of commercial publishing, is painfully aware that publishers are always bringing out books that no one could expect to show a profit.

title: Political Reversal...
description: The year now ending has witnessed the most extraordinary reversal in political fortunes in living memory. For President Nixon and Republicans in Congress, the year opened on a note of high triumph as he was inaugurated for a second term and promptly took the offensive in behalf of a markedly conservative legislative program. House and Senate Democrats were politically and psychologically on the defensive. Although nominally in the majority, they well knew that there were enough conservatives in their ranks to give the Administration a working majority on most issues. Any Democratic initiatives could easily be frustrated by Presidential vetoes that were sure to be sustained.

title: U.S. Food Delegate Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Ronters)Secretary of State Kissinger has named Edwin M. Martin, chairman of the Development Assistance Committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, to he the United Slates coordinator of the World Food Conference, scheduled to be held next year.

title: The Region
description: Governor Malcolm Wilson has offered a preview, of how he will run his new administration and his undeclared campaign for a full term: with emphasis on fiscal conservatism, a respect for political pragmatism and a talent for ideological flexibility. His emerging style manifested itself on the following issues during a press conference last week:

title: Maine Investigating Fuel Sales, Credit and Alleged Price Gaps
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 22An assistant attorney general has been assigned to work with the State Consumer Fraud Division in an investigation of charges of discrimination in fuel sales and credit, as well as charges of widespread fuel price differentials.

title: Heraldry in Modern Idiom By ArtistNeedleworker
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I.When Huguette Braverman, an artist here, sets to work on a new composition, her canvas is a huge length of melton cloth, her palette bits of brilliantly colored fabric, and her tools a needle and thread. Mrs. Braverman makes banners, bringing the freshness of modern graphics to the ancient art of heraldry.

title: Nuptials for Jean Wolff, John Stevens Jr.
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 22Miss Jean Sinclair Wolff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Wolff, was married at home here this afternoon to John Taylor Stevens Jr., a civil engineer and son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens of Falls Church, Va.

title: For the host, the hostess, the home
Knicks Beat Lakers for N.B.A. Title As Reed Plays on Two Good Knees
description: A newspaper headline last May 11 told the story:

title: American Told He Can't Raise 2 From Philippine Tribe
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 22The foundation that protects minority tribes in the Philippines has rejected a proposal by a Miami physician that he raise and educate two children from the Tasadays, a Stone Age people discovered three years ago.

title: The Poems of Sextus Propertius
description: There are some people who like Propertius. With this faint praise the Roman critic Quintilian nearly damned a major poet to eternal obscurity. But fortunately some people happened to include Petrarch, Goethe and Pound. The last of these gave the greatest boost to modern Propertian scholarship precisely because his notorious Homage aroused such hostile criticism. To prove Ezra bad, one had to prove Sextus good.

title: The Nation
description: The inquiry into whether the House of Representatives, for the second time in history, should impeach a President of the United States, appears to be accelerating. With senior Republicans like Barry Goldwater and Melvin Laird pressing for a vote as quickly as possible, in the belief it would go against impeachment, the House Judiciary Committee appointed the man who will direct its investigation of the charges against Richard Nixon.

title: Daphne Zoilo Is a Bride
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 22Miss Daphne Rita Zoilo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A, Marc Zoilo of Rockville Centre, was married here this afternoon to Timothy John Kearney, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kearney of Norwalk, Conn. Msgr. Edward J. Melton performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: No Private Numbers In Peking Phone Book
description: PEKING, Dec. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)For the first time since 1967, the public can buy a Peking telephone directory, which contains between its stout, flexible bindings 11,000 numbers. No private numbers are listed.

title: Mafia Chief and 3 Others Convicted of Stock Fraud
description: A reputed Mafia boss and three associates were convicted yesterday of participating in a stockfraud scheme that bilked the investors in a carleasing

title: King Is Queen, Thanks To 55YearOld Hustler
description: The most talkedabout tennis match of the year was played not at Wimbledon or Forest Hills, but on the floor of the Astrodome between a 29yearold woman and a 55yearold man.

title: Six Ways to Take aTrip Without Guzzling Gas
description: NOW exclaimed the Roman poet Horace, anticipating the gasoline shortage by 2,000 years, is the time to beat the earth with unfettered foot. His words were never more appropriate. And so, for those readers game enough to do their traveling on the hoof, we herewith commend and recommend a few guided walking tours right here in New York Cityone of them led by a scholar whose specialty is the history of New

title: Eliot Field Marries Mrs. Catherine Funk
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22Mrs. Catherine Fisher Funk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Fisher, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Eliot Field, a lawyer with the state Attorney General's office in Augusta, Me.

title: 1972 Buffalo Creek Flood Brings a Suit for $1Million
description: LOGAN, W. Va., Dec. 22 (UPI)  A $1million lawsuit attempting to recover property losses in last year's Buffalo Creek flood disaster was filed here yesterday by the Island Creek Coal Company against the Pittston Company of New York.

title: MAGAZINE STAFF ASSISTS NEEDIEST
description: Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are often deceptive. Sometimes the amount of a donation does not reflect the effort that went into collecting it.

title: Door Prize
description: Faced with a sour housing market, builders across the country are offering inducements to prospective buyers to close deals on new houses before the end of the year.

title: Sandra Curtis, Dean Edwards Plan Wedding
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Todd Porter Curtis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Howell Curtis, to Dean Charles Edwards, son of Bert Giles Edwards of Garden City and of Mrs. Edward V. McGoldrick 3d of Locust Valley. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Energy: We'll Use Less, Pay More
description: American consumers were officially asked to buy less gasoline last week but told they were going to pay more for whatever they bought  and for heating their homes with oil as well. The request and the edict were the latest moves in the Administration's effort to conserve fuel and avoid gasoline rationing.

title: Sleeper Woody's Best Yet
description: THE arrival of Woody Allen's Sleeper last week at the Coronet and Little Carnegie Theaters brings to two the total number of firstclass film comedies that have opened in New York this year. The other, is Jacques Tati's Playtime, which was made in 1967 and released here six years late.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Two new $250,000 tournaments  the first Tournament Players' championship and a revival of the national team championshipare features of the 1974 schedule the Professional Golfers' Association tournament players division, Commissioner Joseph C. Dey Jr. announced yesterday. The number of major tournaments scheduled totals 44, three less than last year, within a season of 10 months one month shorter than 1973.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Employment Act of 1946 was the first law that officially committed the Federal Government to actively promote full employment.

title: Pep Talk by Eller Lights Vikings' Fire
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 22 (UPI)  Carl Eller, an offseason actor, put on an emotional performance at halftime today to inspire his Minnesota Viking teammates to a comeback victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Small delights for small socks
As to Violence, This Family Feels That TV Goes Too Far
description: The Howard Ettinger family, a very middle class foursome from Peter Cooper Village, came facetoTube this fall with what has been called television's most permissive season.

title: Ann von Gal Bride Of Richard Bush
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22Miss Ann Carrol von Gal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Vreeland von Gal, was married here this evening to Richard Clare Bush, son of Ivan Paul Bush of Lansing, Mich., and the late Mrs. Bush.

title: Nuptials Jan. 19 For Miss Felt, Michael Bowen
description: Miss Marguerite Whittlesey Felt, an assistant fashion editor with Mademoiselle magazine, plans to be married Jan. 19 to Michael Cary Bowen, a vice president of the Goldman Sachs International Corporation, investment bankers.

title: She Makes Toys Filled With Love
description: ROCKAWAY  The soft, white hair is the same, but the red suit has been replaced by contemporary pantssuits and the North Pole address has been changed to one in Rockaway, a small community in central Morris County.

title: Taking Care of the Children Who Need Help
description: Ellery C., a 16yearold Brooklyn youth, is charged with the stabbing death of a 14yearold boy during a holdup in the Utica Avenue IND station in the BedfordStuyvesant section. Two days later, Ellery C. is identified as a former inmate of a state youth reformatory who was released last summer after the Court of Appeals ruled that youths in need of supervision rather than incarceration, like Ellery C., should not be confined in reformatories with dangerous delinquents because they might become well tutored in the ways of crime.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Frank Lane tells of suing Charles O. Finley when he was dismissed as general manager of the A's, when they were in Kansas City, after working less than nine months on an eightyear contract: It was pretty obvious, in view of all the evidence, the jury was gping to find for me, which it did, but that didn't seem to bother Charlie when we were left alone by the judge in his chambers.

title: Dr. Elaine V. Digrande Betrothed
description: The engagement of Dr. Elaine Virginia Digrande, a dermatologist, to Dr. Manuel Fernandes, a urologist, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sal Digrande of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Antonio Fernandes of Arcos de Valdevez, Portugal, and the late Mr. Fernandes.

title: Museum in Cincinnati Agrees to Pay $100,000 Ransom for Stolen Rembrandt Painting
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (UPI)The Taft Museum agreed today to pay a ransom of $100,000 to get back a Rembrandt painting that some authorities said could be worth millions of dollars.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Helaine Hartman Is Wed
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 22 Miss Helaine Francine Hartman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland D. Hartman of New Rochelle, was married this evening to Alan Barry Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max B. Cohen of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

title: EXCHIEF OF N.M.U. ALLOTTED $419,663
description: Joseph Curran, who retired as president of the National Maritime Union last March, was paid $419,663.79 in salary and severance pay during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1973, according to the union's annual report filed with the office of Labor Management Reports here.

title: Stephanie Sommer Wed to M. A. Mayhew
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 22 The marriage of Miss Stephanie Sommer to Michael Allen Mayhew took place in Grace Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. James H. Clark performed the ceremony.

title: ECLIPSE OF THE SUN AWAITED TOMORROW
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22 (AP)A partial eclipse of the sun may be seen Monday.

title: Condominiums Sought at Tudor City
description: Harry B. Helmsley, one of the largest real estate operators in the country, has moved to introcluce condominium ownership at a second major apartment development he controls hereTudor City, the quiet residential area in the bustling East Side.

title: A Homosexual Temple Holds Rites on West Side
description: The men took seats on wooden folding chairs in a semicircle in a room at a West Side church community center they call their synagogue.

title: Genetic Diversity and Human Equality
description: Give me a dozen healthy infants, well formed, and my own special world to bring them up in, and I'll guarantee to take any one at random and train him to become any type of specialist I might selectdoctor, lawyer, artist, merchantchief, and yes, even beggar and thief, regardless of his talents, penchants, tendencies, abilities, vocations and race of his ancestors.

title: A long nose argued with its owner
description: When in 1931 Gogol published his Ukrainian folk tales, Evenings on a Farm Near Dikanka, Pushkin congratulated the public upon the appearance of a frankly happy book; and about the second volume that came out the following year, Belinsky, soon to become the most influential critic in Russia, exclaimed: What wit, what gaiety, what poetry, what a sense of the people! Thus Gogol, at the age of 22, had scored his first success and also his first deception, for neither Pushkin nor Belinsky, nor anyone else at the time seems to have detected the sinister, nightmarish note beneath the fun, the anxiety masked by realism, the terror drowned in laughter.

title: Ohio State? Or Michigan? Neither Wins the Big One
description: Ohio State and Michigan met Nov. 24 to resolve which of these undefeated and untied teams should be ranked No. 1 in the nation and go to the Rose Bowl. Instead, they struggled to a 1010 tie, a result that brought forth petty jealousies simmering in the Big Ten Conference for two decades.

title: Free Refreshment On State Parkway
description: WOODBRIDGEThe New Jersey Highway Authority will offer free nonalcoholic drinks to its Garedn State Parkway patrons on Christmas and New Year's.

title: Byrne to Limit Election Costs
description: TRENTON  The legislative initiative of Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne and the incoming Democratic majorities in both houses are beginning to take shape. Major emphasis is being placed on several proposals aimed at restoring public confidence in election campaigns and in the integrity of government officials.

title: Ford, Skiing, Gets Stuck on a Lift
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 22 (UPI) Vice President Ford, rested from an official visit to Spain for the funeral of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco, headed for the ski slopes this afternoon and minutes later he was stuck on a gonola halfway up the mountain.

title: News of the Camera world
description: STUDENTS of photographic history  particularly those who are specifically interested in the development of early cameras  will no doubt welcome a new volume recently published: A Century of Cameras, From the Collection of the International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House, by Eaton S. Lothrop Jr., with introduction by Robert J. Doherty. Priced at $12, this 150page hardcover book (11x8 inches) illustrates and describes 130 examples of early cameras from the comprehensive collection at Eastman House.

title: Diet, Kennel Guide Covered by Books on Dogs
description: With the holiday season on hand, it's a good time to add to the fancier's bookshelf. The 1973 publications run the gamut, from a massive encyclopedia covering all 308 breeds registered with the Federation Cynologique Internationale, the 41nation body, to a pithy manual describing how to show a purebred dog. In between, we I have works telling how to raise a dog the natural way, a system followed by a breeder and, naturally, her way; a book of recipes that will appeal both to man as well as his best friend; and a comprehensive guide to kennels.

title: How NOW?
description: Banks have been prohibited by law since 1933 from paying interest on demand deposits (checking accounts) but beginning with the new year consumers in two states will have a chance to get a very close substitute.

title: Light Amid the Gloom
description: THE ChristmasNew Year's holiday season is usually a time of euphoric spirit, when it is quite easy to overlook the problems posed by major issues of the day and find reasons for optimism. Somehow, this year, the ability to override the mammoth problems confronting the nation is much more difficult because the changes that have taken place this year, plus the ones that loom for 1974, appear to be so complex and so overwhelming.

title: T.V.A. Sales Up 10%
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 22 (UPI)  The Tennessee Valley Authority says that combined sales of T.V.A. power during the fiscal year ending last June 30 totaled 60 billion kilowatthours, a 10 per cent increase over the previous year.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Wall Street, still trying to assess the impact of the energy crisis and the profit outlook for 1974, ended last week with gray storm clouds muttering overhead.

title: The Remembering
description: It is one of the simplest of all the great and enduring stories. The Roman governor of Judea ordered everyone to go to his native village and register, so a poor carpenter named Joseph and his young wife, Mary, who was large with child, made the journey to Bethlehem. There was no room for them at the inn so, as humble folk often did, they turned to the stable for shelter. And there, in the stable, the carpenter's wife bore her child.

title: E. EMMET REID, 101, TEARGAS CHEMIST
description: BALTIMORE Dec. 22 APDr. E. Emmet Reid, a chemist credited with developing one of the key ingredients of tear gas for the Government during World War I, died yesterday at the age of 101.

title: Jewelry Buying Develops Some New Facets
description: Jewelry is costing more this Christmas season  with some curious ??plications for Santa Claus, sugar daddies and jewelers.

title: Chile Reports 5 Men Killed In Attack on Power Line
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Five men were killed by soldiers when they tried to blow up an electrical supply line to the Chilean capital, the military authorities announced today.

title: Six Illustrated Biographies
description: The new illustrated biographiesjudging by the half dozen threepounders that landed recently on my deskare a luxurious, sensuous genre. Packed with superb pictures, many in color, they are a joy to touch and smell and look at. The texts themselves, however, are another matter. Like network news, they abound in facts and anecdotes; they entertain but rarely probe.

title: Shrinking income endangers agencies' programs
description: THE names and faces of the directors may change and even the directions of the eight agencies helped in the annual Neediest Cases appeal may change, but a central question remains: How does one raise the kind of money it takes to effectively help the needy?

title: Letters
description: The article Housing Projects Break Mold [Dec. 9] once again demonstrates the world why lowcost citygovernment has for the taxpayers of New York.

title: AT CHRISTMAS REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST
description: LESTER PEDDY, the executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, sat in his sunny, spacious office in downtown Brooklyn the other day and talked about the way things were. He was worried, he said, that tightening funds had strained the 107yearold agency's efforts to provide assistance to families, children and the handicapped. As Mr. Peddy talked in his secondfloor office at 285 Schermerhorn Street, men and women were working at a variety of jobs in the five floors above. For the most part, they were handicapped persons whose disability prevents them from working in the outside world. Nonetheless, to a visitor it seemed that their physical handicapslack of limbs or blindness or some other crippling ailment did not get in the way of production. Women were busily sewing garments, men were applying finishing touches to a variety of plastic goods (airplane earphones, for example), and a general spirit of comredeship pervaded the place.

title: The case of Raymond Chandler
description: LONG before Raymond Chandler died in 1959, his private investigator, Philip Marlowe, was an American folk hero. Chandler became famous in the forties during and immediately after World War II, and Marlowe was a perfect escapist hero for the period, one who took readers away from the war. Nobody is called up for the draft in Chandler's books; the O.S.S. and C.I.A. stay unmentioned; the war might as well not exist. The violence is entirely local, the product of individual weakness and greed, and shabby, incorruptible Marlowe is there to see the crooked record set straight.

title: Movies
description: ENGLISH cinema seems to be enjoying, a sudden burst of creativity. In the last few years, England has produced three extraordinarily talented filmmakersJohn Boorman, Ken Russell and Nicolas Roeg. They have little in common except for their visual flair, their rejection of the literary conventions that still dominate most films, and their desire to experiment with a purely cinematic vocabulary.

title: Sympathy for Israel Rose After Oil Ban, Poll Finds
description: American sympathy for Israel has grown, instead of diminished, following the outbreak of the latest Middle East war on Oct. 6 and the subsequent Arab oil embargo against the United States and other countries, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Rangers Triumph Over Penguins, 41
Home Improvement
description: THE seriousness of the current energy crisis makes it imperative that every homeowner do everything possible to conserve fuel and avoid wasting heatand the most effective weapon in this battle is adequate insulation in all walls and ceilings (under the roof) of the house.

title: Sydney Is Restoring Waterfront Where Colonists First Landed
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 Respectable Sydneyites were relieved in 1900 when the government of New South Wales took over a ratinfested slum quarter known as the Rocks and demolished most of the tumbledown buildings after an outbreak of bubonic plague.

title: Nancy Herzog Plans June Bridal
description: Miss Nancy Herzog and David B. Turret, seniors at the University College of New York University who expect to graduate next month, plan to wed in June. The engagement has been announced by Miss Herzog's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Herzog. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Turret. Both families live in Manhattan.

title: Dance
Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Gardens
description: MANY flowering plants are associated with the celebration of the coming holiday season. Christmas cactus, Christmas begonia, the poinsettia  called Flor de la Buena Noche in its native Mexicoand the Christmas kalanchoe are traditional favorites.

title: Japan for Wake Forest
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP)The Wake Forest University football team will go to Japan Jan. 4 for two goodwill games against Japanese college allstar teams, the Japan American Football Association announced.

title: Miami (O.) Tangerine Victor, 167
description: GAINESVILLE. Fla., Dec. 22 (AP)  Miami of Ohio's defense throttled Florida tonight and the Redskins wrapped up a perfect season with a 167 Tangerine Bowl victory.

title: Gastronomic razzledazzle
description: Caviar's so common. With champagne, that is. And expensive, too. For those generous romantics who want to ravish their taste buds, this smoked salmon mousse wrought by La Caravelle's chef, Roger Fessaguet, would be a smooth accompaniment to the champagne that ushers in the uncertainties of another New Year. And if champagne seems trite, the folks at La Caravelle suggest a chilled HautBrion Blanc. But this is no onceayear dish to be saved for New Year's Eve. At the fourstar restaurant of its birth, a slice, garnished with aspic, is the first course of a $11.25 prix fixe luncheon. We suggest it for late suppers and special friends.

title: The Executive Branch After Watergate
description: WASHINGTONThere was a tinge of sadness at the White House when Melvin R. Laird announced he was leaving after seven months as President Nixon's chief domestic adviser. It had been known for months that he was going, this canny politician who last summer had vainly sought a fuller disclosure of the Watergate tapes and a cleansing of the White House of preWatergate ways. His announcement, however, seemed to place an aura of finality on what he was leaving behind:

title: He Made The Rich Come To Life
description: RICH people have seldom been of much interest to American playwrights. Our most respected dramatists  O'Neill, Williams, Miller, Albee, Inge, Wilder, Saroyanhave for the most part concentrated on the nettoowealthy, or on lowlifers, discovering in barrooms or unremarkable living rooms characters and conflicts that fired their imaginations.

title: The Show Must Go On, But (Brrr) Will It?
description: WHAT Broadway doesn't need is another crisis. But it is clearly stuck with oneand this time, not of its own making. The national energy crisis has forced the legitimate theater, and show business in general, to drastically curtail heat and electricity in ways that are already affecting the very look of the theater district.

title: A team within a team within a team
description: It is said that there are 26 teams in the National Football League. This, of course, is wrong: There are 52. It's just that they share 26 locker rooms. We addicted millions long tended to forget that fact: We cheered the quarterback as he led the offensive squad down the field, and pretty much ignored that other team, the defensive unit. No more. Sunday after Sunday, we've been forced to take our eyes off the ball and watch the evermoresubtle moves of the Front Four.

title: Mrs. Weiner Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weiner of Englewood, N.J., on Nov. 30 in the Englewood Hospital.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A PRICE INCREASE of $1 a barrel for crude oll has been authorized by the Cost of Living Council. It estimates this will add 2.3 cents to the price of a gallon of gasoline and heating oil ... William E. Simon, Federal energy chief, has asked for a voluntary 10gallonaweek limit on consumption of gasoline.

title: Numismatics
description: THE recent request by the United States mint for standby Congressional authority to switch from copper to aluminum in cent production, widely and often sensationally reported in the daily press, could hardly have caught too many members of the numismatic hobby by surprise. Over the past several months the hobby press has been full of speculation about how the Mint might react to the steadily rising price of copper.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Tree Grows in the Sand
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Dec. 22Whipped by winds from every quarter, drenched with salt spray, twisted and gnarled by the constant play of elemental forces, the Cedars of Cape Pogue, deeprooted in infertile sand, somehow survive.

title: Tulane Picks Bartlett
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP)Roy Bartlett was named Tulane tennis coach today, succeeding the late Emmett Pare. Bartlett played under the famed Pare, captaining the Green Wave tennis team from 1940 to 1942.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  About year ago, as the United States balance of foreign trade was winding up its worst year on record following the first devaluation of the dollar, American economists were engaged in a spirited debate: Could an exchangerate change for the dollar really help the American balance of payments significantly?

title: Television
description: DUCKING away from a doctoral dissertation on racially mixed stereotypes in American literature, I take refuge in Star Trek reruns. Captain James T. Kirk of the Starship Enterprise and his faithful companion, Mr. Spock. These days, America's Indians are organized enough to protest new Tontos, so the old Lone Ranger frontier myths are played out by exotic aliens.

title: New Code Drafted on Refrozen Food
description: TRENTONThe threat of food poisoning from refrozen meats and vegetables has prompted new state health regulations.

title: Joan Sutherland Sets Herself a New Task
description: RICHARD BONYNGE is, as he says, very crazy about Massenet. The conductor has just recorded the French opera composer's Thrse. He has explored the songs, which he pinks number between five and six hundred. Now he has found one of the operas that he wants to revive for his wife, Joan Sutherland, and he has persuaded the San Francisco Opera to produce it next fall. It is Esclarmonde, which comes in Massenet's output somewhere between Manon and Werther.

title: Miss Goddard, a Law Student, Affianced to Douglas Gentry
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 22 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Downey Goddard to Douglas Willard Gentry has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. C. Convers Goddard of Princeton and Upper St. Regis, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Willard M. Gentry of Midland, Mich.

title: Wishes, Lies, and Dreams
description: It's not strictly necessary to read both of Kenneth Koch's excellent and enormously important books on children and poetry, though I strongly recommend it, if only for the pleasure both books give. Each stands on its own, implying the whole argument. But they're better together, and to anyone for whom the subject is importantparents, teachers; anyone who has the normal human delight in true poetry, or anyone who wonders how his normal human pleasure was dwarfed and twistedthe pair of books will, I think, be a revelation.

title: Heinrich Heine: Selected Works
description: Heinrich Heine noted the death of God about half a century before Nietzsche made it official. Unlike Nietzsche, he did so with a measure of nostalgic regret and with a sovereign sense of irony that mocked the depth of his despair but also trapped himagain unlike Nietzschein unrelenting sanity to the end, through seven years of a terminal paralysis in which his outer world shrank to the dimensions of a dingy Paris attic and he literally had to force one palsied eyelid open with his fingers in order to see.

title: Giants' Fixture Retiring
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Peter M. Hoffmann, for 40 years ticket manager of the New York and San Francisco Giants baseball club, has announced his retirement, effective Jan. 1. Arthur Schulze, Hoffmann's assistant since 1956, will succeed him.

title: St. John's Five Takes Final, 68 to 60
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 22With its second basketball upset in two nights, St. John's defeated Jacksonville, 6860, to win the first Connecticut Classic at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum tonight. The Redmen had beaten the Dolphins previously in the season's opener for both teams.

title: Anthony Bothwell Weds Miss Chung
description: MIAMI, Dec. 22In the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany here this morning, Miss Nguyen Thi Chung, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nguyen Van Tang of Saigon, was married to Anthony Peirson Xavier Bothwell, a cornmunications coordinator for the Florida Power and Light Company. His parents are Col. Frederick C. Bothwell Jr., U.S.A., retired, of La Jolla, Calif., and Mrs. Catherine Hannon Bothwell of Pittsfield, Mass.

title: Knicks Beat Pistons as DeBusschere Scores 25 Points
description: Dave DeBusschere may not be welcome the next time he tries to spend some vacation time in his home in a suburb of Detroit. He played the leading role last night as the Knicks battered the Detroit Pistons, the hottest team in the National Basketball Association, 9988, at Madison Square Garden.

title: ... Congress Fumbles
description: Unfortunately, Congress has neither the leadership nor the internal procedures to enable it to supplant a weakened executive as the chief policy maker. Thus, Congress last spring renewed the authority for wage and price controls but an effort of the House Democratic leadership to make such controls mandatory had to be abandoned; continuance of controls was left to the discretion of the President. Similarly, in attempting to frame energy legislation, Congress has been all too willing leave to the President the decision on gasoline rationing.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Funny How News Always Turns Out To Be the Scapegoat
description: GIVEN the right set of circumstances, the commercial networks take considerable pride in their news operations. Cronkite, Chancellor, Reasoner and Smith may not contribute as much to the balance sheet bottom line as the popular situation comedy, but they provide a tone that is invaluable for corporate image. The American Broadcasting Company owes much of its recent and relative respectability to the success of Reasoner and Smith on the evening news.

title: Reshaping the Middle East.
description: GENEVAIf the, ArabIsraeli conference is to accomplish its proclaimed goal of peace in the Middle East, there won't be a sign of any positive action for at least a month. Not that Israel's forthcoming elections and subsequent creation of a new Cabinet comprise the stumbling block; simply that complex modern negotiations take ages to progress. Vietnam is an example.

title: Mary T. Seiberg Wed to Professor
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Dec. 22Miss Mary Tait Seiberg, a candidate for a doctoral degree at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, was married here this afternoon to Harvey Jerome Goldschmid, a professor of law at Columbia.

title: Hippie hero? Superpatriot? Superstar?
description: There is good news, we are told, and bad news.

title: Nixon Goes by Car To Spend Weekend At Mountain Home
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) President Nixon went to Camp David, Md., by car today for a weekend at his mountaintop retreat.

title: Counseling Helps State Employes Cope
description: TRENTON  New Jersey is finding that it pays to take an interest in the private lives of its 50,000 state employes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Jumpers, Jenkins Mark Horse Shows
description: The past year provided all kinds of interesting developmentsboth in and out of the ringin the horseshow world.

title: Free Press: A Topic for Economists
description: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.First Amendment to the Constitution

title: Watergate is simply a new code word for the Old Nixon
description: While the men and women who engineered President Nixon's reelection drive run for cover in Washington, the task of producing the flow of inside campaign reminiscences has apparently been left to the architects of the Democratic defeat. Three of Senator George McGovern's top strategistsRichard Dougherty, Gary Hart and Gordon Weilhave written about their experiences with their candidate. But a fourth, Frank Mankiewicz, has now written instead about Nixon.

title: Giving Them a Bite to Eat
description: Harry and David, a fruit business in Medford, Ore., has sent 1 million Christmas presents this year, grossing between $15million and $17million.

title: Assembly Reforms Sought by Leaders
description: TRENTON  The Assembly's new Democratic majority leaders are formulating innovations calculated to eliminate the parliamentary and procedural confusion that has given it a ranking of 37th in a national study of legislative bodies completed three years ago.

title: Battle Over Growth Stirs East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. LIn more than 300 years little has disturbed the calm or ruffled the dignity of this elegant town, not even the coming of the summer people a century ago.

title: Trot Charges Raise Questions
description: Does the Government have the goods on Del Insko and 12 other prominent harness drivers accused of fixing $3million worth of superfecta races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways?

title: LETTERS
description: Helmsley

title: Finn in U.N. Force Wounded In Shooting on Suez Front
description: CAIRO, Dec. 22 A Finnish soldier in the United Nations Emergency Force was Wounded and other United Nations soldiers in two areas were endangered by EgyptianIsraeli firing along the front, the United Nations spokesman reported today.

title: SYSTEM OF MAIL IN ITALY CgAOTIC
description: ROME, Dec. 22If you receive season's greetings from Italy these days, the chances are they were mailed in 1972.

title: The A.P.A. Ruling on Homosexuality
description: Last weekend, the Board of Trustees of the American Psychiatric Association approved a change in its official manual of psychiatric disorders. Homosexuality per se, the trustees voted, should no longer be considered a psychiatric disorder; it should be defined instead as a sexual orientation disturbance. Ideas and Trends asked two psychiatrists, Robert L. Spitzer, M.D., associate professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia, and member of the nomenclature committee of the A.P.A., and Irving Bieber, M.D., clinical professor of psychiatry at the New York Medical College and chairman of the research committee on male homosexuality, to discuss the A.P.A. decision. An edited version of their discussion follows.

title: The strange case of T.W.A. vs. Howard Hughes vs. T.W.A.
description: Incredible. As it happened, under our noses, the core of it a matter of public record, it took so long that it seemed almost routinea tornado funnel over the business landscape evolving so slowly and subtly that it looked like a casual thunderstorm. It was the strange case of T.W.A. v. Hughes, initiated in 1961 and concluded at last in 1973 without ever having come to trial; and it is the subject of this book.

title: The best ways to get and get rid of a hangover
description: In this short guide to the world of drinkexpanded by largely irrelevant illustrations and by a sprinkling of amiable quotations on the subject Kingsley Amis presents a compendium of lore, most of it invented, much of it scurrilous and some of it useful. Writing with suitable gusto, he offers recipes, advice on such sundries as glasses and bottle openers, helpful hints on cheating your guests, the boozing man's diet and a fine discourse on the hangover. Dogma, in the form of Ten General Principles, takes the place of profundity and occasionally disguises ignorance.

title: There Are More Poor in the World than Ever
description: WASHINGTONWhen Congress approvd a $5,5billion foreign aid appropriations bill last week, it enacted what the Nixon Administration had touted as  major shift in United States policy towards programs designed to help the 70 per cent of the world's population who have to survive on incomes of less than $250 a yearor about 65 cents a day.

title: Civil Rights Council Plans Merger of 2 Periodicals
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22  The merging of two of its publications, New South and South Today, into a bimonthly generalinterest magazine to be known as Southern Voices was announced today by the Southern Regional Council.

title: Needed: A Government That Governs
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.The most important thing about the energy crisis is what it tells us about how inadequately we have been governed. Our Government has permitted this whole society to be built upon the assumption of an unlimited supply of gasoline and other fuel. The pattern of suburban living, second homes, shopping centers and industrial parks assumes this. The travel, transportation and recreation industries assume it.

title: Problems: Tragedy at Indy, Low Fuel and High Costs
description: Months before the energy problem had become serious, motor racing was in economic trouble. Astronomical costs overwhelmed competitors, sponsors, tracks and sanction. ing clubs, and some victims vanished. The fuel shortage simply aggravated the sport's malaise, and this will he felt more dramatically in 1974, when racing activity and spectator travel are likely to be curtailed. major adverse factor was the nationwide revulsion at the accidents in the Indianapolis 500. Two drivers and pitcrew man were killed, another driv

title: Music
description: IN A WAY it's also the season a Charles Dickens, for what would Christmas (and American television be without the Christmas Carol Which, by an illogical quanium jum involving an author's prerogative brings me to the subject of British literary men and music.

title: KING DUE TO KEEP VITAL ROLE IN LAOS
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Dec. 19As the Laotian neutralists, rightists and Communistled Pathet Lao struggle toward the formation of a coalition government, it seems clear that whatever structure they produce will still be within the Kingdom of Laos and that the kingdom will have a King.

title: Call at Halftime Tells Nixon of Adjournment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)Senate leaders notified the President by a telephone call to Camp David today that Congress had adjourned without passing broad emergency energy legislation.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: MORE OF HIGHWAY SHUT ON WEST SIDE
description: Another section of the West Side Highwaythe southbound road from 46th Street to the Batterywas closed to drivers yesterday by the Department of Traffic.

title: ERNEST C. BROWN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22  Ernest G. Brown, who retired in 1960 as a vice president of the United States Rubber) Company (now Uniroyal, Inc.), died here yesterday. He was 77 years old and lived in Darien) and Pine Orchard.

title: Lindsay Recalls the Pressures and Pleasures of the Best 8 Years of My Life
description: Even as a lame duck, John V. Lindsay says, he held onto mayoral power by a deliberate show of activitypushing everybody else off the front pages. It was only when Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame and Governor Rockefeller sat down a short while ago to save the 35cent transit fare that he felt control shift. That's the moment that power changed, Mr. Lindsay says.

title: There Have Been Some Setbacks, But the Damage Isn't Permanent
description: Concern has been growing among ecologists and others that the energy emergency might erode the national movement for environmental reform. A canvas last week disclosed that there have indeed been some setbacks, but most experts felt they would only be temporary. And some even expected benefits to accrue from the shortage. What follows is an examination of the effects so far of the emergency on pollution control.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: In Australia 20,000 to 30,000 years ago, there were predators: marsupial lions and Tasmanian wolves. There were rhinocerossized quadrupedal herbivores. There were hopping herbivores: kangaroos and wallabies. Then man, and his dog, the dingo, arrived. And now there is man, his dog, and the kangaroo and the wallabie.

title: Chess: What Can Be More Crucial Than a Crucial Final Round?
description: Entering into the final round of the Leipzig International Tournament, the standing of the leaders was: Vlastimil Hort, Czechoslovakia, 10; Anatoly Lutikov, Soviet Union, 9; Vlastimil Jansa, Czechoslovakia, Burkhard Malich, East Germany and Zoltan Ribli, Hungary, 9.

title: Dancealot, $1 0, Scores By 2 Lengths at Big A
description: Dancealot pranced into the lead at the start and stayed there all the way to win the $57,300 December Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Only business?
description: Fulbright argues that Jackson's proposal constitutes interference in the Soviet Union's internal affairs. He is right, but his fastidiousness about this is not believable because he, like some others opposing Jackson (and like Jackson), has favored denying South Africa a sugar import quota, forbidding chrome imports from Rhodesia, banning aid to Greece. Unless these votes were intended as innocuous gestures, they were designed to influence the internal affairs of those nations. But regardless of how Fulbright has voted, he has talked consistently (if confusedly) against moralism in foreign policy. A decade ago, in an essay called The Strain of Violence, he deplored moral absolutism, the crusading spirit, selfrighteousness, stern moralism, and our Puritan heritage, using these terms interchangeably to make this point:

title: CAMBODIAN OFFICERS OUT IN NEW SCANDAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 22 (UPI)  The Cambodian command said today that a general and two colonels had been suspended and that 20 lowerrank servicemen and civilians had been arrested in connection with the illegal sale of Americanmade brass shell casings.

title: The Free University of West Berlin, Now 25, Is in Disarray
description: BERLIN, Dec. 22The Free University of West Berlin passed its 25th anniversary this month in a state of disarray and conflict.

title: Hospital Lets Public Give Views
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.In what may become a trend for hospitals, the Nassau County Medical Center released its full accreditation report Wednesday and held a public meeting to invite comments.

title: Community Life: Schools Become the Hosts for Public Services
description: PONTIAC, Mich.A concept called community education is rapidly gaining converts across the country.

title: West Side Highway Is Now Closed Down South of 46th Street
description: Another section of the West Side Highway  from 23d to 46th Street  was closed to traffic yesterday evening by the Department of Highways. The action by the Department of Highways followed by one week the closing of the northbound and southbound lanes of the..;road from the BrooklynBattery Tunnel to 23d Street as the result of a collapse of part of the roadway involving a 30tort, trailer truck.

title: Larry Kohlhoff to Wed Miss Jennifer Sherman
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 22Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Sherman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jennifer Sherman, to Larry Francis Kohlhoff, son of Mr, and Mrs. Francis H. Kohlhoff of, Haddonfield, N. J.

title: Elaine McHugh Fiancee Of Luis Emil Rinaldini
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 22The engagement of Miss Elaine Nash McHugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nevin McHugh of Larchmont, to Luis Emil Rinaldini, son of Dr. and Mrs. Luis Maria Rinaldini of Mendoza and Maipu, Argentina, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Goodmans Have a Child
description: A daughter was horn Nov. 17 to Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Goodman of New York at the University Hospital. Mr. Goodman is a sculptor, The child has been named Emily Sunshine.

title: Images of death and loss
description: The very great war photographers the four, maybe five, men who are still alive and working  always seemed to possess a special madness unlike any other. I do not speak of a condition that could be cured by psychoanalysis, or a long rest, or more money. The war photographers, for example, despise wars yet they belong in them. They grieve for the dead yet during wars they come to life. When they are safe, they wither. Not all of them are suicidal men, but they share the belief that their photographs might make a difference. They are our most disturbing historians. I speak of their madness only because of one haunting photograph in Don McCullin's remarkable collection.

title: EXCHIEF OF N.M.U. ALLOTTED $419,663
description: Joseph Curran, who retired as president of the National Maritime Union last March, was paid $419,663.79 in salary and severance pay during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1973, according to the union's annual report filed with the office of Labor Management Reports here.

title: A Scenario for the Mideast Conference
description: GENEVANo matter how the ArabIsraeli peace negotiations at the old League of Nations palace go here, the public statements, the visible parts of the conference will not be what the seasoned diplomats and officials are watching.

title: How Not to Take Snow Shoveling to Heart
description: HACKENSACKHow can you clear your sidewalk or driveway of snow without risking a heart attack? How do you keep steps and walks free of hazardous ice? And how do you get to work safely at least within an hour or so of your usual driving time? These are only a few of the worries that beset suburbanites at this time of year.

title: But Where Is Home?
description: Who was the appealing Texanwas it Larry McMurtry?who went around in a sweatshirt emblazoned with the legend, MINOR REGIONAL NOVELIST? There is, of course, the, resentment of New York City as book capital on the part of writers who have seated themselves, usually in middle age and after a lot of peregrinating, in an outlying Athens such as San Francisco, which they chose in order to escape the crush of competition and to lead the good life, hoping that peace and comfort and the plaudits of the local Athenians will not rule out their remaining cosmopolitan. This isn't what is meant by regional, however; and they would be the last to characterize it so. Regionalism is a prouder banner, a decent lonely business referring back to Hawthorne in New England and Twain in Hannibal, to Yoknapatawpha Country, Sauk Center, Sherwood Anderson in Ohio, Hemingway in Michigan. The suspicion exists that most real writing in America has been regional, and that the remarkable gifts of such a man as John Dos Passos were perhaps defeated by his not being regional.

title: A CLEAR COLD DAY FOLLOWS THE RAIN
description: Five days of ice and rain and, unpleasantness subsided in much of the metropolitan area yesterday, just in time for the holiday weekend.

title: Greece Bans Superstar
description: ATHENS, Dec. 22 (AP)Greece's military Government has banned the rock musical film Jesus Christ Superstar after officials of the Greek Orthodox Church complained about plans for showing it in Athens.

title: Padres Indecision Stalls N.F.L., Too
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22  Uncertainty about the move of the Padres baseball club from San Diego to Washington is holding up the National Football League's preseason schedule for 1974.

title: Apologetic Champion
description: George Foreman arrived, but apologized for it.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: For years, New York lawyers and judges have joined citizens groups and community organizations in deploring the quality of legal services the city provides the poor. To many, the problem seemed virtually insoluble.

title: Class War Without the Decisive Battle
description: LONDONEdward Heath is the son of a carpenter and a maid. A good education and enormous ability carried him up to Balliol, the army, the City and into Tory politics. He is in no sense upper class. Anthony Sampson made the point, writing of his looks:

title: Persian Gulf Oil Ministers Meet in Iran Amid Predictions of Major Price Rise
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 22 Oil ministers from Persian Gulf nations began a crucial conference here today amid predictions of a major rise in the for a barrel of petroleum.

title: C. FRANK NAUMBURG
description: C. Frank Naumburg, who retired several years ago as a partner in the insurance firm of Spero Whitelaw Company, died Thursday at his home here. His age was 80.

title: U.S. Expects Suez Canal To Reopen After Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The United States expects the Suez Canal to open for traffic immediately after Israel and Egypt reach agreement on separating their troops currently confronting each other along the Canal, a senior American official said today.

title: EXPLOSION IS USED TO END OIL WELL FIRE
description: GLENROCK, Wyo., Dec. 22  Firefighters detonated 500 pounds of nitroglycerine today to snuff out an oil well fire that burned for 17 days, consuming as much as 100,000 barrels of oil.

title: Aaron Cahn Fiance Of Renee S. Lowen
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Dec. 22 Miss Renee Susan Lowen, coordinator of news film crews for the National Broadcasting Company in New York, plans to be married in August to Aaron Ronald Cahn, who expects to graduate from the Brooklyn Law School in June.

title: Durst Is Dropping Sites Assembled For Development In Midtown Area
description: Seymour B. Durst, a major assembler of land for new construction in midtown Manhattan, has allowed mortgage holders to foreclose on about a dozen properties just east of Times Square.

title: CONFEREES AGREE TO SPEEDY TALKS ON SUEZ ARMIES
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22  The Middle East peace conference ended its first round today with a quick agreement on moving forthwith toward talks on separating Israeli and Egyptian forces now tangled along a jagged front on both sides of the Suez Canal.

title: A Suffolk Center For Slavic Arts
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.More prestigious theatrical institutions may clamor and yammer and stamp their feet in frustration. But it well could be that the next time the renowned Polish director, Jerzey Grotowski, brings his ensemble to the United States, one of the few places for which he will work will be the relatively unknown, yet extremely vigorous, Slavic Cultural Center here.

title: Netivark: Christmas in the Rectory
description: NEWARKFor Harry and Katie Grace this merry time of year is an especially busy one.

title: Carey Drucker Wed To George Zuckerman
description: Miss Carole Drucker, who is known as Carey, was married here last evening to George D. Zuckerman, an Assistant State Attorney General and chief of the Civil Rights Bureau in the State Attorney General's office. Rabbi Daniel J. Fingerer performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: 2 LATIN NATIONS FAIL IN PEACE BID
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 Another attempt by Honduras and El Salvador to settle their differences arising from the 1969 soccer war has ended in failure after three months of negotiations in Mexico City.

title: Alvin S. Kaufman Is Dead; A Writer of Popular Songs
description: Alvin S. Kaufman, a composer of poular songs and a member of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers since 1938, died here Friday. He lived in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Robert Sinnott Of Navy Weds Rosa Kendall
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Dec. 22Miss Rosa Lee Kendall, daughter of Lieut. Col. Donald John Kendall Jr., Marine Corps, retired, and Mrs. Kendall, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. (jg.) Robert Vose Sinnott of the Naval Reserve. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Sinnott Jr. of Rumson, N. J.

title: Weiskopf Honored As Most Improved
description: Mary Mills and Tom Weiskopf have been named the most improved golfers of the year by Golf Digest magazine.

title: How to fill the cart without emptying the purse
description: At first glance, a book on how to buy in a supermarket may seem about as much needed as one on how to tie your shoelaces. Well, take a peek at your neighbor's shopping cart. Your own, of course, is full of wholesome and economical goodies. (It is safe, though, to predict that nobody who reads The Supermarket Handbook will buy precisely the same things again.) As for your neighborthe one who really needs ithe is a walking proof of H. L. Mencken's dictum that nobody ever went broke by underestimating the intelligence and good taste of the American public. Mencken himself would be astonished at the degree to which commercial exploitation and bad teaching have turned his jape to understatement. He would doubtless have chortled at a handbook that finds it necessary to say: As we all know, fish come from the ocean (deepsea or saltwater fish) and from lakes and streams (freshwater fish).

title: U.S. Gains 33 Tie in Net Series
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP)  Julie Heldman scored a 63, 16, 63 upset victory over Evonne Goolagong of Australia today, sparkling a comeback that moved the United States into a 33 tie with the Aussies in the Bonne Bell Cup tennis series.

title: Mets Shift Director
description: Ed Kneip, a 24yearold native of Winnetka, Ill., has been named general manager of the New York Mets Class A farm club at Visalia, Calif. in the California League. Kneip was assistant general manager of the Mets' Memphis farm club.

title: EDMUND BRUNNER SOCIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Edmund de Schweinitz Brunner, a specialist in American rural sociology, died Friday in the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: Energy Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  The Pentagon has grounded all Air National Guard and Air Reserve training flights as the result of a Federal Energy Office order diverting 1.5 million barrels of military jet fuel to civilian airlines. That amount was reduced yesterday to 900,000 barrels. Military forces said yesterday that the grounding went into effect Friday night and would last indefinitely.

title: Ski Industry Begins a Tough Slalom
description: For a sport whose basic experience is sliding downhill, the ski business has been one big sitzmark so far this winter.

title: Skiing Parallel With Malamud and Waugh
description: TWO of my greatest pleasures in life are reading and skiing. The question is: Would it be possible io combine the two? Preposterous, it seems on the face of it. You can't ski with your nose in a book. But, as all skiers know, every schuss down the mountain is preceded and followed by a 10or 15minute trip up the chairlift. This, my friends, is the time for reading.

title: News of the Stage
description: Eugene O'Neill's All God's Chillun Got Wings, which created a furor here 50 years ago when it cast a black man as the husband of a white woman, will be presented by the Circle in the Square during the 19741975 season.

title: Mrs. Ruth Davey Greenthal Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Ruth Davey Greenthal, widow of Monroe Greenthal, was married here yesterday to Harry Kelley Lowe. The ceremony was performed at Mr. Lowe's home by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Perilman, retired senior rabbi of Temple EmanuEl.

title: Old themes are not abandoned
description: Anyone who lives in the South, who pays more than passing attention to its political, social and culturallife, cannot fail to be impressed by the persistence of a Southern identityindeed, a Southern sensibility. Most of the writers at work in the South these days are trying to figure out how to reconcile the living Southern heritage with the altered South they inhabit. The old themes have not been abandoned; these three books, like most others coming out of the region, provide solid evidence of the continuing distinctiveness of Southern litrature.

title: Leonard Ruskin, 51, a Founder Of TV Guide and Producer Dies
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 22Leonard Ruskin, who organized the Forest Hills Music Festival and was a founder of TV Guide, died today, apparently of a heart attack, while on vacation. He was 51 years old and lived in Sands Point, L. I.

title: Oil Over the Dam
description: As an aid to understanding the energy crisis, one might consider Niagara Falls and the energy that goes over it in barrels.

title: U.S. Oilmen Find Prices Expectable, but Shocking
description: Oil industry spokesmen in this country did not seem surprised at the doubling of prices for Persian Gulf oil that was announced yesterday in Teheran, Iran.

title: Oil Concern Rejecting New Customers
description: MONTCLAIRFor more than 50 years, the Blondel family has gladly heated the homes of thousands of families in this area, first with coal and now primarily with No. 2 heating oil, but because of the current fueloil situation It is not accepting any new customers.

title: Rupp Home From Hospital
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 231 (AP)Adolph Rupp, former University of Kentucky basketball coach, returned to his Lexington home today, after his release from an Orlando, Fla. hospital. Rupp, 72 years old, underwent surgery for 4 perforated ulcer at the hospital Dec. 14. Rupp's wife, Esther, said doctors ordered Rupp to remain in bed for a while.

title: I Veterans May Get Checks
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UPI)Veterans Administration. officials said today that some 5,000 California students may receive tardy G.I. benefit checks] j by Jan. 1 after President Nixon. ordered the V.A. to work through the Christmas holiday on the problem. Some of they checks have been delayed since September.

title: Janet Lynn, Robertson Win in Figure Skating
description: TOKYO, Dec. 23 (AP)Janet Lynn captured the women's honors and Ronnie Robertson took the men's competition today in the $100,000 international figure skating festival giving the United States a sweep.

title: HOCKEY
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Picking Unusual Gifts: Half the Fun
description: Tomorrow, great Christmas presents will be given and received that can qualify as odd, odious or otherwise open to question.

title: Grocery Owner's Brother Is Killed in Holdup of Store
description: The brother of a Brooklyn grocery owner was killed late Saturday night while attempting to help his younger brother resist three holdup men.

title: Freedom of Choice In Graduate Study Backed by Report
description: Doctoral students should continue to have a free choice of fields of study despite the overproduction of Ph.D.s in some disciplines, a report on graduate education urges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Frazier's Wrist Injured
description: Just when Earl Monroe appears well enough to begin contributing to the Knicks' offense, a problem may be developing with Walt Frazier. New York's leading scorer, with a 21point average, is suffering from acute tendonitis at the tip of the left wrist.

title: Three RapeMurders Stir Rochester Area
description: ROCHESTERIn the last two years three young girls have been raped and murdered here, and some people see a bizarre and inexplicable pattern in the crimes.

title: China Says Soviet Uses Ruse to Gain Asian Hold
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 23China said today that the Soviet Union, under the guise of promoting an Asian security system, wanted to move into positions of power vacated by the United States in Asia.

title: ExConvicts Teach Delinquents Crime Doesn't Pay
description: BALTIMOREIn the basement of a musty Victorian mansion in one of Baltimore's changing neighborhoods, there is a school for young criminals.

title: First Round at Geneva Generates an Air of Hope
description: GENEVA, Dec. 23The opening round of the Middle East peace conference has created a hopeful atmosphere, but the first real test will begin when Israeli and Egyptian officers convene here later this week for secret talks on how to separate their military forces on the Suez front.

title: The Mideast
description: In Washington, American officials said that they expected fairly rapid progress in talks between Egypt and Israel on separating their forces along the Suez Canal. Page 3.

title: Marilyn R. Swist Connecticut Bride
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Dec. 23Miss Marilyn R. Swist and Philip M. Isaacs, both of New York, were married here this morning at the Oak Lane Country Club. The bride's brother, the Rev. Martin S. Swist, of the Silent Temple of Peace (Universal Church) in Fairfield, performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Crocodile Coup Valuable As a Defensive Stratagem
description: One of the rarest defensive plays in the game is known as the Crocodile Coup. A defender with two nontouching honors must play secondhand high to swallow his partner's honor and insure himself of the lead. When the opportunity for this arises, as it did on the diagramed deal from a recent Swiss team championship here, it is usually missed.

title: Ghosts
