description: CHICAGO, Dec. 23The nation's supply of beef, pork and poultry was still abundant this week, and if Government allocations of truck fuel are effective, market analysts believe that these supplies will remain adequate throughout the winter.

title: Simon & Schuster Elated Over an Editorial Coup
description: Simon & Schuster will begin its second halfcentury of business on Jan. 2 with two new editors who have been lured away from other influential publishing houses.

title: Holiday Closings Start
description: All savings and loan associations and most commercial banks in New Jersey will be closed today. So will state and Federal offices, Post offices will be open from 8 A.M. to noon.

title: Queens Man Burns to Death
description: James Abruzzo, an 80yearold Glendale, Queens, man, was burned to death yesterday while sitting in a styrofoam and plastic recliner alone in his secondfloor apartment at 7222 67th Place. The police said he might have fallen asleep while smoking a cigar. The fire, which broke out at 11:20 A.M., was confined to the living room, which was decorated for Christmas.

title: MRS. J. OSBORN FULLER
description: Mrs. Marjorie C. Hall Fuller, wife of Dr. J. Osborn Fuller, who resigned as president of Fairleigh, Dickinson University last week because of her illness, died of cancer yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. She was 60 years old and lived at 10 Mill Road, HoHoKus, N.J.

title: Miss Margaret Steckler Marries
description: Miss Margaret Jon Steckler and Robert Thomas Prouse, graduates of the University of Michigan, were married at the Harmonie Club here yesterday afternoon by Melvin Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester.

title: Boost to Inflation
description: The national economy is experiencing the most serious peacetime inflation of the modern eraan inflation that is the result of mistaken domestic policies and unanticipated world pressures. The Administration, having used both fiscal and monetary measures to provide a powerful stimulus to the economy in 1972, began weaken controls at the start of 1973, believing that inflation would taper off. President Nixon's economists forecast that prices would rise by only 3 per cent this year, with the rate of increase coming down to about 2 per cent by now. Instead, consumer prices have risen by 8.4 per cent in the past twelve months, and were climbing at an annual rate of 9.6 per cent last month.

title: Workers Try to Plug Well After 17Day Fire Ends
description: GLENROCK, Wyo. Dec. 23 (UPI)  Oil well fire fighters worked beneath a shower of crude oil today to plug a well that had blazed out of control for 17 days.

title: Philip Rahv, Critic, Dead at 64; English Professor at Brandeis
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23Philip Rahv, the literary critic and editor who was David Schwartz Professor of English at Brandeis University, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge. He was 64 years old. The cause of his death is under investigation.

title: The Christmas of '33
description: It was Christmas Day, 1933. Jobless for many months because of the Depression, my father had just found work out of town. Now, foregoing Christmas, we were leaving our home in Chicago to join him in Minneapolis, driving the family cara 1929 4cylinder Plymouth sedan nicknamed Skeezix.

title: Housing Shortage
description: The Joint Center for Urban Studies estimates that the country now has twice as high a rate of housing deprivation as it did five years ago. Today, that deprivation is increasingly economicmeasured in terms of the high and stillclimbing cost of housing, rather than by the conventional yardstick of substandard physical condition. More people than ever cannot afford a proper place to live, or they endure economic hardships for it.

title: Hell Up in Harlem' Tracks Crime Czar
description: "Hell Up in Harlem" has the right title as a slaughter pile-up, with Fred Williamson as the super-duper "black Caesar of the underworld." He finally adds the most corrupt man in town, a fictional District Attorney of New York County, to his personal pyramid of corpses. The D. A. gets his, along with most of the other whites in the picture who dare to open their mouths.There is a quietly vivid performance by Julius W. Harris, as a kind of unwilling Harlem godfather. Mr. Williamson himself, who also had another movie, "That Man Bolt, opening yesterday, certainly gets around New York in this one murderously trying to "make it a decent place to live for everybody." He must have meant every survivor. The line got a hearty laugh one morning last week at the midtown Cinerama Theater. The film is also showing at the R.K.O. 86th Street Twin 2, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Books of The Times
description: GRANDMASTERS OF CHESS, By Harold C. Schonberg. 317 pages. Illustrated. Lippincott, $10.

title: HOCKEY
Lawrence W. Snell, Cited For Navy Evacuation Plan
description: Lawrence W. Snell, a retired Naval Reserve commander who helped develop a plan for evacuating the wounded that was used in the Normandy in vasion in World War II, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 730 Park Avenue and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Janice Himmel Is Bride
description: Miss Janice Faye Himmel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Himmel, was married here today to Seth Martin Black, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Black. Both families are of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony at Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing was performed by Rabbis Samuel Shaffler and Shalon Himmel, uncle of the bride. The bride is a prekindergarten teacher at Aiphabetland in Jamaica, Queens. The bridegroom is doing graduate work at St. John's College. His father is vice president of the specialproducts division of Willcox & Gibbs, Inc.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Three men suspected killing a Trenton pharmacist with a shotgun have been charged with homicide. Two of the suspects, John W. Hightower, 22 years old, and Henry Taylor, 22, were arrested over the weekend. The third, William Wardlaw, 27, is serving a sentence in the Mercer County Correction Center on an unrelated charge.

title: Fort Lee Apartment House Residents Present Gifts to Children in a Home
description: FORT LEE, Dec. 23Every year when we clean out the storage rooms, said Donald Cooke, general superintendent for Horizon House, we collect bicycles, sleds and other toys that tenants who have moved have left behind. We send what is salvageable to the Christian Home for Children down the street.

title: Miss Bonnie L. Singer Bride of Hans Weltin
description: HEWLETT, L.I. Dec. 23 Miss Bonnie Lynn Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Singer of Hewlett, was married here today to Hans Weltin, son of Dr. Eva Weltin of Wilmington, Del., and Dr. Erhart Weltin of Vienna. The noon ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Rabbi Martin Siegel.

title: N.B.C. to Challenge F.C.C. On Pension Fairness Rule
description: The National Broadcasting Company will challenge in court a Federal Communications Commission finding that the network violated the fairness doctrine, a spokesman said Friday.

title: LOUIS MASLOW
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Dec. 23 Louis Maslow, founder of the Metropolitan Wire Goods Corporation and a past president of the National Association of Food Equipment Manufacturers, died today in General Hospital of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Detente for the Panovs
description: The current issue of Soviet Life, which is distributed here by reciprocal agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union, is devoted to Constitutional Rights and Freedoms. This magazine pictures life as the Soviets would have us believe it exists there, But this particular issue is cruelly ironical when its lofty ideals are measured against just one current episode in Soviet lifethe case of Valery and Galina Panov, the dancers with Leningrad's Kirov Ballet whose feet have been tied by their government ever since they applied for exit visas to Israel.

title: Fundamentalists View Christmas Comet as a Sign
description: The comet Kohoutek, which promises to provide a holiday spectacle, has taken on special significance in conservative religious circles.

title: NearPerfect Miami Gains A.F.C. FinalDefense Excels
description: MIAMI, Dec. 23The Miami Dolphins, slipping out of their customary style of football perfection for only a few minutes late in the second quarter, thrashed the Cincinnati Bengals, 3416, today and methodically moved a step closer to their second consecutive National Football League championship.

title: GEORGE K. SMELSER, ANATOMIST, 65, DIES
description: Prof. George K. Smelser, an anatomist who held the Malcolm P. Aldrich research chair at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Saturday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 53 Knickerbocker Road, Demarest, N.J.

title: 3 Major Fires Damage Buildings in Manhattan
description: Three major fires damaged or destroyed buildings in upper Manhattan last night and forced the Fire Department to deploy men from the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens to man fire stations that were emptied because of the blazes in Manhattan.

title: StaubachPearson 83Yard Scoring Pass Decisive
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 23The Dallas Cowboys beat the Los Angeles Rams, 2716, today in a playoff game that had 114 offensive plays. Three of them made the difference between victory and defeat for two evenly, matched teams.

title: Federal Fare Aid
description: A Congressional conference committee has agreed on a mass transit bill that marks the furthest point Congress has yet gone toward the Federal subsidizing of transit operating costs. While the development has historic aspects, rejoicingat least on the part of New Yorkersis premature. Obstacles still lie ahead and even if they are overcome, the money involved will not in itself insure against a rise in New York subway and commuter fares.

title: Sports Today
description: Aqueduct (Queens) race track, 12:30 P.M.

title: Sales in Wide Variance At Retailers for Holidays
description: Smiles and frowns mingled equally on the faces of New York's merchant's last weekend. Like the temperatures that jumped up and down last week, the Christmas shopping seasonby far the year's most importanthad come down to its last day with widelyvarying results. Based on retailer's expectations, the extremes ranged from below our's to exceeded our best.

title: Pilots Grounded by Layoffs Find a Jobless Life Hard
description: Jay Johnson of East Brunswick, N. J., who until recently looked forward to earning $60,000 a year by the time he was 45, applied for a job paying $2.20 an hour at a New Jersey lumberyard the other day, and was turned down.

title: Bruins Defeat Leafs On Edestrand Goal
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)A defenseman, Darryl Edestrand, scored the winning goal in the third period tonight in the Boston Bruins' 43 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. It kept Boston's National Hockey League home record spotless this season with 19 victories and a tie.

title: Frazier's Wrist Injured
description: Just when Earl Monroe appears well enough to begin contributing to the Knicks' offense, a problem may be developing with Walt Frazier. New York's leading scorer, with a 21point average, is suffering from acute tendonitis at the tip of the left wrist.

title: AU.S. Force Is Planned to Fight Potential Black Market in Oil
description: ASBURY PARK, Dec. 23The Federal office in charge of allocating fuel oil in the New YorkNew Jersey area will soon have a 1,000member investigating team to control a possible black market, a Federal official said today.

title: Beame to Split Housing Agency; Names 3 of Its 4 Division Chiefs
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday took the first formal step toward breaking up the city's Housing and Development Administration, the superagency assembled by Mayor Lindsay six years ago to coordinate city programs in urban renewal and public housing.

title: ORT BEGINS DRIVE ON SCHOOLING GAP
description: Women's American ORT has opened a nationwide series of programs aimed at narrowing the gap between vocational and academic schooling.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: An Unofficial Breath, by Marie Buchanan (St. Martin's Press, $5.95). A story dealing with extrasensory perception.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Nixon Role in Foreign Policy Is Altered; Some Assert Kissinger Is Now in Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Profound changes have taken place in the way foreign policy is made in the Nixon Administration in the wake of the Watergate scandals and the appointment of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State.

title: Syria Assails Geneva Results And Repeats Basic Demands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23Syria, which has boycotted the Middle East peace conference at Geneva, today criticized the results of the first phase of the talks.

title: ISRAELI FACTIONS ASSESS THE WAR
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 23I think this was the war of the righteous, said Moshe Shamir, a writer and editor. Both sides feel their case was proved right.

title: Bruins Defeat Leafs On Edestrand Goal
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)A defenseman, Darryl Edestrand, scored the winning goal in the third period tonight in the Boston Bruins' 43 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. It kept Boston's National Hockey League home record spotless this season with 19 victories and a tie.

title: Leases Here Are Up 17% As Off ice Industry Revives
description: New York's office industry, the basic and the most depressed sector of the city's economy only two years ago, achieved a 17 per cent increase in space leased in new buildings this year, and analysts say this may be the start of a new boom for the business.

title: A Jetliner Crashes In Moroccan Hills, Killing 106 Aboard
description: TANGIER, Morocco, Dec. 23 A chartered airliner carrying 106 persons, many of them Moroccans going home for the holidays, crashed in the Rif mountains near the Mediterranean coast, airport officials said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: GRANDMASTERS OF CHESS, By Harold C. Schonberg. 317 pages. Illustrated. Lippincott, $10.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal office in charge of allocating fuel oil in the New YorkNew Jersey area will soon have a 1,000member investigating team to control a black market, Nancy Velardi, the Federal allocation officer for New Jersey, said yesterday. Speaking on a radio program over WJLK in Asbury Park, Miss Velardi said the force would operate similarly to the wage and price control investigators working under the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Montreal: 'Joual' Divides the French
description: MONTREAL  Should the literature of Quebec be written in proper, schoolmaster's French, or in the earthy language of the streets? That is the essence of a controversy that has divided playwrights and novelists here in North America's citadel of French culture, and generated fiery feeling among the public.

title: Pop Music: Rock of Lou Reed Is Listenable if Nto Hummable
description: Lou Reed once said he did not think he wrote hummable lyrics. He must have considered it somewhat chancy to appear with his backup group onstage for two hours on Friday at the Academy of Music on 14th Street, His was the only group on the bill. However, it was a successful concert and further enhanced Mr. Reed's image as a New York cult and culture hero.

title: NEW GOAL SOUGHT ON HEALTH POLICY
description: A group of health professionals and health insurance representatives is forming a committee to try to devise health insurance plans that pay for preventive health services, rather than for hospitalization, which is their main function now.

title: Radio Revenues Showed 11.8% Increase in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Radio broadcasters in the United States increased their revenues by 11.8 per cent in 1972, with an increase in profits before taxes of 30.6 per cent.

title: Milling 200,000 Fill 5th Ave. Mall
description: The Fifth Avenue holiday mall, canceled for two Sundays by bad weather, looked in yesterday's sunshine like three Sundays rolled into one.

title: DEWEY BROWN
description: NEWTON, N.J., Dec. 23 (AP) Dewey Brown, a golf pro who made clubs for President Warren G. Harding, died yesterday at the age of 74

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1973

title: Screen: That Man Bolt
description: It hasn't been much of a year for Jim Brown. First O. J. Simpson bettered his National Football League rushing record. And nowjudging by That Man Bolt, which opened last week at the DeMilleFred Williamson is expanding his inroads on Mr. Brown's hegemony over the black action genre that has become one of the giltedge Bonds of cinema in the seventies.

title: Denice B. Heiman, Mark Rein Marry
description: Miss Denice B. Heiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Heiman of New York and Hewlett Bay Park L.I., was married here yesterday evening to Mark A. Rein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rein of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by Rabbi Joel Y. Zion of Lawrence, L.I., assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: Baker, Not Absent in 15 Years, Is Shot 3 Times but Gets to Job
description: A 53yearold Queens baker who had not missed a day's work in 15 years was shot three times by a band of muggers as he left home before dawn yesterday, but he struggled two miles to work by bus and on foot and lighted his ovens before being hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Three RapeMurders Stir Rochester Area
description: ROCHESTERIn the last two years three young girls have been raped and murdered here, and some people see a bizarre and inexplicable pattern in the crimes.

title: NEW HEART TESTS FOR SKYLAB CREW SEEK VITAL DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The Skylab 3 astronauts, preparing for a busy holiday week in their orbiting laboratory, are engaged in a study to determine the effects of prolonged space flight on the human heart.

title: Denice B. Heiman, Mark Rein Marry
description: Miss Denice B. Heiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Heiman of New York and Hewlett Bay Park was married here yesterday evening to Mark A. Rein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rein of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by Rabbi Joel Y. Zion of Lawrence, L.I., assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: Miss Margaret Steckler Marries
description: Miss Margaret Jon Steckler and Robert Thomas Prouse, graduates of the University of Michigan, were married at the Harmonie Club here yesterday afternoon by Melvin Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester.

title: Homes Are Reoccupied as Flood Waters Recede
description: Flood waters receded in New Jersey yesterday and families returned to their watersoaked homes.

title: Bullets Pin 11085 Loss On Braves
description: TORONTO, Dec. 23 (UPI)Phil Chenier scored 27 points and Manny Leaks and Elvin Hayes added 19 and 17 points, respectively, to help the Capital Bullets defeat the Buffalo Braves, 11085, tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens. A crowd of 7,112 watched the National Basketball Association game.

title: ThistleBottomism
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Miss Thistlebottom's Hobgoblins was the name of a delightful book about word usage written by. Theodore Bernstein of The New York Times two years ago.

title: N.F.C. Title Game First at 1 P.M. Sunday
description: The National Football Conference championship game at Dallas between the Cowboys and Minnesota Vikings will lead off Sunday's pro football television doubleheader starting at 1 P.M. New York time.

title: About New York
description: A man and his daughter walked up Fifth Avenue yesterday, and thought of Christmas in their separate ways. This was to be the daughter's 11th Christmas, and while the man had no very clear recollection of her first one, he remembered the second one quite well. That was the time she had been stuffed into a blue snowsuit and big red boots, and he had carried her out and stood her up in the snow. She had looked at him reproachfully for just a moment and then, unable to move a step, she had toppled gracefully into the snow.

title: Mott Beats Krauss In Junior Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L,I., Dec. 23Tom Mott of Wilton, Conn., defeated Gary Krauss of Yonkers, 63, 62, in the junior division opening round of the Eastern Junior and Boys indoor tennis championships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Bengals Tip Helmets to Conquerors
description: MIAMI, Dec. 23 (UPI)The Cincinnati Bengals held their heads high in defeat today. To a man, they figured it had taken world champions to beat them.

title: College, School Results;
LongTime Contributors Aid Neediest
description: Charity is an elusive thing and so are the motives of those who practice it.

title: JERSEY NOFAULT CALLED A SUCCESS
description: TRENTON, Dec. 23  New Jersey's new no fault automobileinsurance law seems to be fulfilling expectations.

title: BERME SPLITTING HOUSING AGENCY
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday took the first formal step toward breaking up the city's Housing and Development Administration, the superagency assembled by Mayor Lindsay six years ago to coordinate city programs in urban renewal and public housing.

title: Holiday Closings Set
description: The major United States stock exchanges will operate on normal schedules today, but will be closed tomorrow, Christmas Day. Canadian stock exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be closed today and tomorrow. Banks in New York State will be open today and closed tomorrow.

title: GERALD L. WENDT, HAD AIDED UNESCO
description: Dr. Gerald L. Wendt, an author, editor and lecturer on science who retired in 1967 as head of the publication center here of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Saturday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 160 East 48th Street.

title: Bullets Pin 11085 Loss On Braves
description: TORONTO, Dec. 23 (UPI)Phil Chenier scored 27 points and Manny Leaks and Elvin Hayes added 19 and 17 points, respectively, to help the Capital Bullets defeat the Buffalo Braves, 11085, tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens. A crowd of 7,112 watched the National Basketball Association game.

title: China's Harvest of Grain Exceeds Record Set in 1971
description: PEKING, Dec. 23China's grain harvest this year seems to have exceeded, but only just, the record levels of 1971.

title: DR. BRAYTON REDWAY
description: Dr. Brayton Skinner Redway, who practiced dentistry here, died Saturday. He was 72 years old and lived in HastingsonHudson, N.Y.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Swedish Health Care
description: This is the last of three articles on the Swedish health care system, frequently cited as a. model for improving the American approach. The writer, a staff member of The New York Times, recently spent five months in Sweden as a visiting physician at Serafimer Hospital of the Karolinska Institute.

title: GROWING DEFICITS EXPECTED IN WAKE OF OILPRICE RISE
description: PARIS, Dec. 24  Accelerating recessionary forces coupled with further painful increases in the cost of living were foreseen today in both industrialized and developing countries, in the wake of the doubling of the price of crude oil by major Persian Gulf exporting states.

title: Dr. Kuiper Is Dead
description: Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, the internationally known astronomer, who played a key role in the nation's early space program, died Sunday while visiting in Mexico City. Details on Page 24.

title: Mechanics Approve Pact At Pacific Southwest Air
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)  Striking Pacific Southwest Airlines mechanics overwhelmingly ratified a new twoyear contract last night and ended a sixweek walkout.

title: Big Gasoline Tank Ruptured
description: TULLAHOMA, Tenn., Dec. 24 (UPI)A storage tanks of the Union 76 Oil Company ruptured early today, dumping 18,000 gallons of gasoline into a vacant lot. A fire department spokesman said the tank had apparently rusted out near the bottom. Ditches surrounding the field were filled with loose dirt to soak up the gasoline, and a nearby concrete plant was ordered closed.

title: Automobile Kills Its Owner
description: MARBORO, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP)A 31yearold Marlboro man, Harrison R. Crossman, died last night when he was run over by his own car while attempting to start it from underneath at his home, the police said.

title: Rockets Strike Phnom Penh For Second Day in a Row
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Sovietbuilt rockets struck Phnom Penh today for a second consecutive day and the Government sent reinforcements into a battle for a rocketlaunching area only five miles from the capital.

title: ERWIN SWANN DEAD; AN AD EXECUTIVE, 67
description: Erwin Swann, an advertising executive who recently established Swann's Way Productions, Ltd., to make educational films, died of a heart ailment Sunday at his home, 24 West 55th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Shah of Iran Is Seen as a Spur Behind Sharp Advance
description: TEHERAN, lean, Dec. 24Diplomats here are convinced that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi spurred the controversial move by Persian Gulf states to double the price of a barrel of oil.

title: SAM D. TRAUB
description: Sam D. Traub, former executive vice president of Lily of France, Inc., corset manufacturers, died yesterday in the Miami Heart Institute, Miami Beach. He had suffered a stroke several weeks ago in Palm Beach. He was 75 years old and had been living in Florida since his retirement.

title: Water in Upstate Village Is Depleted by 2 Breaks
description: CANASTOTA, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP)A series of water main breaks has depleted this Madison County village's water supply.

title: Carving Up Alaska
description: Alaska, the last great unspoiled open space on the North American continent, continues under siege by the developers.

title: Britons Will Return Some Airco Stock
description: The British Oxygen Company, Ltd., which won its fight for control of Airco, Inc., said yesterday that it would purchase 4 million of the 6.3 million shares it received as a result of its tender offer to pay $20 each for the Airco shares. The British company said that it would return the shares not bought as soon as possible.

title: Woody Hayes Is Rivaled By Woodpecker Batton
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)  The University of Southern California will have its Woody at the Rose Bowl football game in opposition to Woody Hayes, coach of the Ohio State team that plays the Trojans.

title: Bills Pending or Defeated
description: Both houses passed bills giving the President emergency powers to deal with the energy crisis, but were unable to agree on details before adjournment.

title: Requests and Appropriations
description: Following is a table showing the funds requested by President Nixon and the amounts appropriated by Congress during the 1973 session:

title: Christmas Toys Thriving Business in West Germany
description: GOPPINGEN, West Germany  Those Marklin electric trains that hundreds of little boys  and sonic girls  of various sizes and ages will be playing with at Christmas are not made by toiling, bespectacled, meticulous German craftsmen. Instead, they're made, mostly, by women  and by machines that make the factory in this small Swabian city sound more like a real locomotive foundry than the home of the world's bestknown model railroad manufacturer.

title: Nixon Family Christmas Planned at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)  President and Mrs. Nixon plan a quiet Christmas dinner at the White House with family and friends, a spokesman said today.

title: Skylab Crew Sends Greetings Expressing Hopes for Harmony
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Skylab 3 astronauts expressed today the hope of a fruitful and peaceful Christmas Day on earth from their orbiting space laboratory.

title: Blue Cross to Ask Rate Rise
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 24 (AP)  A Vermont official of the New HampshireVermont Blue Cross hospitalization plan said this weekend that a rate increase request would be filed this week. Insurance sources in New Hampshire have indicated the increase would amount to about 17 per cent.

title: Stock Markets Closed
description: The nation's major securities and commodities markets are closed today in observance of the Christmas holiday. Banks, business and Government offices and Canadian and European markets are also closed.

title: GROWING DEFICITS EXPECTED IN WAKE OF OILPRICE RISE
description: PARIS, Dec. 24  Accelerating recessionary forces coupled with further painful increases in the cost of living were foreseen today in both industrialized and developing countries in the wake of the doubling of the price of crude oil by major Persian Gulf exporting states.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Kissinger Seminar
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 As Secretary of State Kissinger's Air Force jet headed home Saturday night from Geneva on the last leg of his 15day trip to 13 countries, the newsmen aboard were invited to his cabin up front for a farewell glass of champagne.

title: ROBBER IS SLAIN, POLICEMAN SHOT
description: A man described as a former customer of an undercover fence operation manned by the police in Queens to receive stolen goods was killed in a wild shootout when he tried to rob the place yesterday, the police said.

title: New Vocationalism Now Campus Vogue
description: College students around the country are changing their tastes in studies away from many of the abstract and theoretical courses that were Popular during the 1960's and ?? studies that teach hard knowledge or that lead to professional training and a comfortable career.

title: 3 Killed as a Bomb Goes Off in Hands Of I.R.A. Member
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 24 (UPI)A bomb went off prematurely in the hands of an Irish Republican Army member today, killing at least three persons and wounding 36 in bordertown pub, a British Army spokesman reported.

title: LEGALIZED GAMBLING SOUGHT FOR NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Dec. 24 (AP)City Councilman Louis M. Turco said yesterday that he would propose legislation to bring legalized casino gambling here.

title: Energy Chief Is Optimistic On End of Arab Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 Sounding increasingly optimistic about prospects for an end to the Arab oil embargo, William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, said today that he could manage the fuel shortage for the next month or more without the emergency powers Congress refused to enact before it adjourned last weekend.

title: Man Slain in Mount Holly
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 23 (UPI)  A 24yearold Mount Holly man was shot to death before dawn today following an argument over a woman, the police reported. The police said Tyron Wakefield was killed when Robert W. Mallette Jr., 31, fired seven shots from a rifle at the home of his estranged wife about 12:20 A.M. Mr. Mallette was held without bail.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH ASSOCIATION CUP First Round

title: A Cold Day at Aqueduct: Turcotte Falls, Wins 3 of 9
description: Ron Turcotte had an ambitious program lined up for himself in clear but cold weather at Aqueduct yesterday, and he did not permit a fall to interfere with his plans. Turcotte is a popular and extremely successful jockey, who, among other things, has ridden Secretariat to success in this year's triple crown of the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes. Yesterday, he participated in all nine races on the card, before a crowd of 19,133, although it looked for a time as if he would not get past the fourth event.

title: Spirit of Christmas
description: The Christmas trees at the White House, at Rockefeller Center and in public places across the nation shine at half voltage this year. Festive lights everywhere, though not extinguished, have been dimmed. Thermostats are turned down ever so slightly, or ought to be, and automobiles travel toward their holiday destinations at a speed just sufficiently reduced to make their passage not only less costly in gasoline but also in human lives.

title: Soviet Aide Denies Any Plan to End Collectives
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24A Soviet agricultural official denied today that the Communist party leadership had approved a program for gradually doing away with that classic Soviet institution, the collective farm.

title: Bridge: Experts Analytical Problem Could Be All Dutch to Some
description: A Christmas problem suggested by a Dutch authority, Herman Filarski, relates to the diagramed deal, which appeared in an article in The Bridge World. The author of the article stated that six clubs could be made against any lead except the rather unlikely choice of the heart two.

title: Holiday Amnesty in Bolivia Frees Political Prisoners
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  Seventytwo political prisoners were released today under a Christmas amnesty issued by President Hugo Banzer Suarez.

title: Beame Aide Tells Clients Of Even Greater Benefits
GOING OUT Guide
description: CARIBBEAN The music that floats up to us from the Caribbean and that we know best here is usually Latin, maybe Haitian and certainly Trinidadian, with its steel drums and calypso. Many people might think that music from Jamaica might be the same as music from Trinidad, but don't say that to a Jamaicannor to a Trinidadian.

title: News Groups Challenging Rate Changes by A. T. & T.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  United Press International and other news organizations are challenging rate changes by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, on grounds they would be discriminatory and impede the free flow of information.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH ASSOCIATION CUP

title: Stock Market Declines In Slow Holiday Trading
description: Taxloss selling and other pressures sent stock prices lower yesterday in slow, preChristmas trading. Some of the nation's bestknown glamour stocks traded at their lowest prices of the year, before a firming trend late in the session trimmed losses.

title: But Miami Recalls Early Defeat by Raiders
description: The Miami Dolphins, threatening to become the Green Bay Packers of the 1970's, are too professional to vow revenge for their early season loss to the Oakland Raiders that shattered their winning streak at 18 games.

title: TENANTS PROTEST NAMING OF STARR
description: The appointment of Roger Starr as the city's new Housing and Development Administrator was denounced yesterday by tenant groups who criticized Mr. Starr's support of the controversial vacancydecontrol and Maximum Base Rent, programs.

title: BRAZIL IS RAISING PRICES OF COFFEE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24 (AP.)Brazil, the world's No. 1 coffee producer, whose main market is the United States, announced major coffee price rises today coupled with sharp cuts in exports

title: S.E.C. May Require More Data On High Interest Rate Effects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering a notice to public companies for fuller disclosure of the effects of high interest rates on operations.

title: MOBILE HOME FIRE KILLS 8 IN MICHIGAN
description: LENNON, Mich., Dec. 24 (AP) A fire believed started by a space heater burned out a mobile home early today, killing eight persons, including a newly married couple and five young children, fire officials said.

title: Many in France Approve Of Santa, a Poll Shows
description: PARIS, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Eightyfour per cent of the French populace, firmly supports belief in Santa Clausknown as Pre Nol  because he gives their children a chance to dream, according to an opinion poll published here today.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Over the months during which these columns have been describing the disaster that has stricken our, standard of eating, they have blamed the food industry in the first place, and, in the second place, food editors and writers and home economists. The assumption has been that a public properly educated would never put up with what passes for nourishment in our country today.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Burned S.I. Church Draws the Faithful
description: I saw a fire color on the window in the next dorm and I knew something was wrong, wrote a 14yearold girl. We ran into the social room and from there we saw what was happening. It was our church, on fire, and couldn't Believe it . . . it was really sad watching it go down and thinking how long it had been there.

title: HAROLD GRISWOLD JR.
description: Harold Ely Griswold Jr., president of the Santa Ana (Calif.) Trust Deed Center, a mortgage company, and brother of the late A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, died Saturday in Balboa, Calif. His age was 64. He formerly lived in Morristown, N.J.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Missing Son of Policeman Is Found Slain in Carolina
description: ROXBORO, N. C., Dec. 24 (UPI)The 21yearold son of a North Carolina highway patrolman was found shot to death in a wooded area near here yesterday after an anonymous caller informed the police and the youth's father.

title: Poland Less Insecure As Social Benefits Gain
description: WARSAW, Dec. 8Poland, forever at odds with herself and her place on the map, appears more at peace than she has been since World War II.

title: Music In The Times
description: Look for the interesting reviews of music old and new, from opera to rare quartets, in performances all around New Yorkall season long in The New York Times.

title: Cooper Upset at Aussie Net
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 24 (AP)  Kio Tanabe of Japan provided the first upset of the Australian tennis championships today by beating John Cooper of Australia, 75, 76, in the first round of the men's singles.

title: Action by 93d Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24Following is a summary of President Nixon's major legislative proposals and of the action taken by Congress in its 1973 session, along with bills pending or defeated:

title: 3 Slain and 2 Shot In Holdup Attempts In 2 Sections of City
description: Three men were shot dead and two others were wounded yesterday during apparent armed robbery attempts at a Queens tavern and a Manhattan discount store, the police reported.

title: U.S. Part of Space Project Located at Alabama Center
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec, 24 (UPI)The Marshall Space Flight Center here will be the headquarters for the American part of the international Spacelab project, the space agency announced yesterday.

title: 3 LINDSAY AIDES CLEARED FOR JOE
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton and two other top officials of the outgoing Lind say administration received clearances yesterday from till city's Board of Ethics to accep highpaying positions in private industry. In each instance, the board ruled that there was no conflict of interest.

title: 25 to 30 Tons of Marijuana Worth $20Million Seized
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 24 (UPI)Federal, state and local law officers arrested 11 persons today and seized 25 to 30 tons of marijuana, believed to be the nation's largest seizure on record. The authorities estimated the street value at more than $20million,

title: New Orders for Machine Tools Declined 17.1% in November
description: Net new orders for machine tools in November totaled $211.6million, down 17.1 per cent from October but 27.6 per cent above the level of orders in November, 1972, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said yesterday.

title: Dr. Gerard Kuiper, Astronomer, Dies
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 24Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, the internationally known astronomer who played a key role in this nation's early space program, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while visiting in Mexico City. He was 68 years old, and had been associated with the University of Arizona here for 13 years.

title: Ski Tow Kills Woman
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Dec. 24 (UPI)A woman was killed yesterday in a freakish accident at a ski slope near Coopers Rock State Forest. The police said Alice Ann Cogar, 23 years old, had been holding onto a mechanical tow rope used to pull skiers up the slope when her coat became entangled and she was dragged into a pulley.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF IN DUEL SESSION
description: Increased fears of inflation brought about by the sharp rise in Persian Gulf crude oil prices pushed prices lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Trading was dull because of the holiday today. Prices also fell in light trading in the overthecounter market.

title: DEDUCTION RULING AFFECTS ARCHIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The Library of Congress and many state libraries and historical societies are suffering from a law change that ruled out income tax deductions for donors of official and personal papers.

title: Poland Less Insecure As Social Benefits Gain
description: WARSAW, Dec. 8  Poland, forever at odds with herself and her place on the map, appears more at peace than she has been since World War II.

title: SPEEDUP IS STUDIED FOR NORTH SEA'S OIL
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP)The British Government and major oil companies, spurred by sharp price hikes for Middle East oil, are urgently studying ways of speeding the arrival of oil from the North Sea. But a Government spokesman said today that the harsh climate of the stormy sea severely limited any acceleration of plans to bring significant amounts of oil ashore by 1975.

title: ROBBERY DEFENDANT QUESTIONS WITNESS
description: Joanne Chesimard, acting as her own attorney in her bank robbery trial here, yesterday crossexamined Avon White, the principal Government witness against her. Mrs. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, her codefendant, are accused of participating in the $3,700 robbery of a Bronx branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company on Sept. 29, 1972.

title: 2 Ranger Lines Shoot Badly
description: No doubt about it, there is a sag in the consistency of the New York Rangers' forward lines. Two have cooled off lately, leaving the scoring burden to the premier line of Jean Ratelle between Vic Hadfield at left wing and Rod Gilbert right. That line accounted for New York's single goal in Sunday's 3t loss to the Flames in Atlanta. The Ratelle line has scored 21 goals in the last 11 games, a pace that recalls the long stretch of the 197172 season in which those three players sustained the label of GAG, GoalaGame Line.

title: Jersey Fire Demolishes Landmark
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 24A fire that the police believe was set by vandals last night flared anew today and destroyed the preRevolutionary War building in which the Universalist Church of the United States was founded.

title: Shortage of Local Musical Talent Troubles Germany
description: BERLINGabriel Chmura, a 25yearold musician from Israel, was recently appointed music director general for the West German city of Aachen. Shortly thereafter, at a competition for young conductors in West Berlin, a Japanese and a Russian shared first prize.

title: French Report Big Deal For Saudi Arabian Oil
description: PARIS, Dec. 24 (Reuters)The French stateowned radio reported today that Saudi Arabia had just concluded a major deal to supply France with 30 million tons of crude oilmore than one quarter of total French oil imports last year.

title: Income in Connecticut Rose To a Record $1.55Million
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 24 (AP)Personal income in Connecticut rose in midNovember to a record $1.55million, according to the state Labor Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Eagleton asserted in a Dec. 3 OpEd article that the new War Powers Act is a dangerous law which confers broad new powers on the President and reduces the Congress to a secondary role in the decision to commit armed forces to hostilities abroad. I respectfully disagree.

title: Pullman Unit Gets Contract
description: The Kellogg International Corporation, a Londonbased subsidiary of Pullman, Inc., has been awarded a contract by the West Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation for engineering procurement and supervision of erection and commissioning of a 1,000shorttonaday ammonia plan. The facilities will be located at Multan, Pakistan. The value of the contract was not disclosed.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When out on the field there arose such a clatter, Cowboys stirred in their boots to see what was the matter. That's what the Christmas poet saidsort of. They didn't have to look long. No sooner had their playoff game with the Los Angeles Rams begun, than the Cowboys knew for sure what had caused the clatter. Santa Claus had arrived and was spilling goodies in boundless profusion. He barely waited to rein in his reindeerDasher and Dancer and all the others, including Donner and Blitzen. He filled the Cowboys' stocking fast. On the first Ram play from scrimmage the jolly old elf gave Dallas an interception. On the second he gave Dallas a recovered fumble. Each was converted into a touchdown, and it was almost as if Santa was urging. Tot he top of the porch, to the top of the wall! Now, dash away! Dash away! Dash away, all!

title: JERSEY MAN FOUND DEAD IN THE BRONX
description: The body of a man, tentatively identified as one of 43 suspects indicted and wanted on Federal narcotics charges, was found yesterday afternoon in a parking lot in a sparsely settled part of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: L.I. Pupils Help to Provide a Sunny Day for Neediest
description: The spirit of Christmas, which, has many facets, was aptly captured by a contribution acknowledged yesterday from Interage. Class 4, 5, 6 of the John H. West School, Bethpage, L. I.

title: School Bus Service Hurt By Fuel Crisis and Prices
description: The Arab oil embargo hit Lewisboro in northern Westchester County last week. Dozens of schoolchildren who were accustomed to being picked up each morning near their homes were told that they must walk up to a mile farther to catch the bus.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Assemblyman Andrew Stein said New Yorkers were losing millions of dollars in interest on Christmas Club accounts, which pay lower rates than ordinary savings accounts. Mr. Stein, a Manhattan Democrat, disclosing the results of a survey conducted by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy, of which he is chairman, said city commercial banks paid uniformly, lower rates on Christmas Club accounts4 per cent on the average compared with 5 per cent for regular savings accounts. He said his commission would recommend legislation forcing banks to grant the same rate of interest and pay back interest in the event a customer cannot meet weekly payments.

title: 14 KILLED BY MOBS IN NORTHERN NIGERIA
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 24 Fourteen men have been reported killed by mobs in five northern Nigerian cities in recent days, and the Government has authorized lawenforcement officials to shoot on sight any person or persons attempting to take life.

title: Aide to Beame Tells Clients of Benefits
description: A man named by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame to one of the key jobs in his administration has sent out hundreds of form letters to customers advising them that their association with his insurance company will be more advantageous to them because of his new post.

title: VOLTAGES ARE CUT 3% IN THE STATE
description: Voltages were cut 3 per cent in the city and across the state yesterday as utility companies began to implement the power cutback ordered last Friday by the Public Service Commission to conserve fuel.

title: Whalers Win in Overtime
description: BOSTON Dec. 24 (UPI)Don Blackburn's goal at 8 minutes 11 seconds of the overtime period today gave the New England Whalers a 54 victory over the Vancouver Blazers in a World Hockey Association game.

title: 3 Escaped Prisoners Held In Robbery of a Grocery
description: BRIGHTON, N. Y., Dec. 24 (AP)Three men who escaped from the Berkshire County, Mass., House of Correction were arrested early today by the police here following the robbery of a grocery store.

title: 5 Children Playing Alone Hurt in Fire in Brooklyn
description: Five children who apparently played with matches while left alone yesterday afternoon, were hospitalized, two of them in critical condition, after an apartment fire in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: DELAY IS PLANNED ON H.E.W. SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Nixon Administration will delay spending most of the newly released 1billion in Federal funds for health and school programs until 1975 and beyond, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

title: Stores Here Jammed as Most Businesses Close for the Day
description: From Bethlehem, where an Israeli police band played Christmas carols, to Bronxville and Brooklyn and Bloomingdale's, where city and suburban shoppers turned their thoughts from the energy crisis and other public troubles in a splurge of buying, the day before Christmas was marked yesterday by a seasonal surge of cheer and goodwill.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Three choreographersAntony Tudor, Gerald Arpino and Maurice Bejartwill receive the 1974 Dance Magazine Awards at the Regency Hotel on Feb. 13. The awards have been presented annually, except in 1971, since 1955.

title: RollOut Offense Is Likely Answer to Vikings' Charge
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 24 With Calvin Hill out of action because of a dislocated left elbow, the Dallas Cowboys will lean even harder on their quarterback, Roger Staubach, for offensive energies next Sunday against the Minnesota. Vikings here in the game for the National Football Conference championship.

title: Bethlehem Crowd Is Smallest in Years
description: BETHLEHEM, Israeli  occupied Jordan, Dec. 24in the town where Jesus was born, Christians, Jews and Moslems gathered tonight in the smallest numbers in many Christmases.

title: Q. and A. on Oil Prices: A Ripple Effect
description: The announcement on Sunday in Teheran, Iran, that major Persian Gulf petroleumproducing countries had more than doubled the posted price for their oil has raised a number of points on the meaning and impact of the action. Following are some questions and answers:

title: Atlantic City Sees Revival if New Jersey Votes Gambling
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 24The famous boardwalk is nearly deserted and the most prominent sight these gray, bleak days are the flashing neon signs on the hotel and motel fronts crying vacancy.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Aboff is a familiar name to basketball fans in Union County. Jack Aboff and his two sons, Ray and Gary, have had a large impact on the sport.

title: Santa (MiddleOld, Real Fast, Father of 8) Lives!
description: In a world where immutable faithin almost anything has become one of our rapidly dwindling resources, there is good news: small children still believe in Santa Claus.

title: Nixon Troubles Reflected In Record of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The 93d Congress, which began its first session last Jan. 3 wondering what to do about impoundment, adjourned Saturday wondering what to do about impeachment.

title: Hyland Girds for Key Role In Byrne's Integrity Drive
description: CAMDEN, Dec. 24Although he wisecracks about his return to public life, calling it a rerun, William F. Hyland realizes he will hold what is probably the most sensitive job in the New Jersey government starting next Jan. 15, when the administration of Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne will begin and Mr. Hyland will take the oath of office as the state's Attorney General.

title: Spain Closes the French Border to Basques in Hunt for Assassins
description: MADRID, Dec. 24Spain has virtually closed the French border to Basques while the hunt continues for six Basques accused in the assassination of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco last Thursday.

title: Blues Drop Brooks
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League returned Gordie Brooks to the Denver Spurs today and called up Frank Spring from the minors.

title: CALLS' DISCLOSURE UPHELD BY A.T&T. It Says Law Requires Data on Newsmen Be Given to Government Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told protesting editors and reporters today that it had no choice except to honor requests by government agencies to disclose records of reporters' telephone calls.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Banks in City Hit by a Rash Of ChristmasEve Holdups
description: New York was hit yesterday by a rash of Christmas Eve bank holdups and a weekend bank burglary was discovered. Nobody was injured in the holdups and no suspects were captured, but a total of about $210,000 in cash was taken in the holdup and burglary.

title: Edmond R. Richer Dead; A Leader in Advertising
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 24 Edmond R. Richer, who retired in 1969 as senior vice president and secretary of the Grey Advertising Agency, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 2 Putnam Park.

title: SIGNATURES SOUGHT BY CRITICS IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 23 Antigovernment protests continued in South Korea today as a group of 30 civic and religious leaders began a nationwide campaign to collect a million signatures to demand a new democrat constitution.

title: North Korea Renews Claim on 5 Islands
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 24 North Korea today reiterated a 20yearold claim to the Yellow Sea waters around five tiny islands held by South Korea.

title: Lionel Stevenson Is Dead at 71; Biographer of Victorian Writers
description: Dr. Lionel Stevenson, author. Victorian scholar and James B. Duke Professor of English at Duke University from 1955 to 1972, died Friday in Vancouver, British Columbia, where he was visiting professor of English at the University of British Columbia. He was 71 years old and lived in Durham, N. C.

title: Old Names, New Rules In Shrine Game Tonight
description: MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP)Two sons of famous athletesMark Harmon and Tim Berra will be in the starting lineups tomorrow night in' the NorthSouth Shrine college allstar game in the Orange Bowl.

title: A Theatrical Haven for Spanish Art
description: The INTAR Spanish theater could hardly he less imposing. Tucked away in a condemned tenement on West 53d Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues, it appears to defy its audience to come and find it amid the darkened garages and warehouses that line both sides of the street. Yet, increasingly they do come from Spanish Harlem, the South Bronx and Brooklynto share, many for the first time, a theatrical experience and to become acquainted with a culture many of them rightfully claim but have never known.

title: JOHN CARTER, 53, LED FAIRCHILD CAMERA
description: MILL NECK, L.I., Dec. 24John Carter, chairman and chief executive officer of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation from 1957 to 1967, died last night of a heart attack in Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived here.

title: Energy Chief Is Optimistic On End of Arab Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 Sounding increasingly optimistic about prospects for an end to the Arab oil embargo, William E. Simon, the Federal energy chief, said today that he could manage the fuel shortage For the next month or more without the emergency powers Congress refused to enact before it adjourned last weekend.

title: Christmas in New Burlington Was a Very Spare Time
description: NEW BURLINGTON. OhioThe cold began after Thanksgiving. By Christmas it was deep and bitter. New Burlington, Ohio, where two streams bent around the tiny farming village like a wishbone, men sat in their kitchens with their overcoats on. It was a Christmas like many other Christmases, but a winter such as no one could remember. The wind blew, ice sheathed the village, and the snow drifted over buggy tops.

title: School Bus Service Hurt By Fuel Crisis and Prices
description: The Arab oil embargo hit Lewisboro in northern Westchester County last week. Dozens of schoolchildren who were accustomed to being picked up each morning near their homes were told that they must walk up to a mile farther to catch the bus.

title: Phillips Increases Price It Will Pay for U.S. Oil
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that, it had increased by $1 a barrel) the price it would pay for domestic crude oil purchased in Colorado, Kansas, Montana, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico and the Gulf Coast. The action was effective as of last Wednesday.

title: PAN AM'S DEFICIT LITTLE CHANGED
1,000 Brave the Cold At Bronxville Pageant
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24  A youthful manger angel in light blue gown and wearing a halo of silver foil led darkness to a creche on the a Mary and a Joseph from the hillside slope of Bronxville's Reformed Church last night shortly after sunset. It was Bronxville's annual Christmas pageant and despite the biting cold about 1,000 persons came to watch the performance and to sing hymns.

title: Costs Expected to Double For Japan's Oil Imports
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24  The increase in the price of oil by Persian Gulf oil states yesterday will double the cost of Japan's oil imports next year and add to the country's already serious inflation, Japanese economists estimated today. The increase will also intensify Japan's balanceofpayments problem.

title: Oysters Rockefeller Tasty by Any Name
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Dec. 24 (AP) For years Oysters Rockefeller has appeared on the menu at L'Alcove Castle Restaurant. The appetizer is still on the menu, but has been renamed Oysters Wilson.

title: AARON BENENSON, EX PROSECUTOR 71
description: Aaron Benenson, a former assistant district attorney and chief of the rackets bureau who was general counsel to the Building Service Employes Union until his retirement after a stroke, died yesterday at his home, 160 West End Avenue. He was 71years old.

title: Soviet Union Is Hearing Mellow Voice of America
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24With the end of Soviet jamming, the Voice of America is coming across loud and clear nowadays but mellower.

title: Bangladesh President Quits, Apparently Over Differences
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  President Abu Sayed Choudhury of Bangladesh resigned today, apparently over constitutional differences with the Government.

title: Christmas on the New Death Row
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 24This is not much of a Christmas for Vernon L. Brown, 22 years old; Bobby Hines, 23, and Jesse L. Walston, 23. These young blacks are on the new Death Row in the North Carolina State Prison, after having been sentenced to die in the gas chamber for the rape of a white woman near Tarboro last Aug. 22.

title: A.B.C. TV Head's Daughter Collapses, Dies Here at 16
description: Diane Louise Duffy, 16yearold daughter of James E. Duffy, president of the American Broadcasting Company television network, collapsed Saturday outside Grand Central Terminal while she and her younger sister, Marcia, were on their way to his home in Glen Ridge, N.J. She was pronounced dead at Bellevue Hospital.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ohio Police Arrest Three Men In Case of Stolen Rembrandts
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 (UPI) Three youths were charged today in connection with the theft of two Rembrandt paintings, one returned by the thieves and the other recovered after payment of $100,000 ransom by the Taft Museum.

title: NIXON SIGNS Bill ON D.C. ROME RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  President Nixon signed today compromise legislation giving partial home rule to the District of Columbia. Re called it a measure of historic significance for residents of the nation's capital.

title: Mrs. Rosenthal Wed To David Ellenhorn
description: Mrs. Glenda Goldstone Rosenthal, assistant professor of political science at Rutgers University, was married at her home here yesterday to David Ellenhorn, a partner in the New York law firm of Kronish, Lieb, Shainswit, Weiner & Hellman. Civil Court Judge Leonard H. Sandler performed the ceremony.

title: Q. and A. on Oil Prices: A Ripple Effect
description: The announcement on Sunlay in Teheran, Iran, that major Persian Gulf petroleumproducing countries had more than doubled the posted price for their oil has raised a number of points on the meaning and impact of the action. Following are some questions and answers:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jerseys daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Maine Ski Resorts. Rely On Their Local Clientele
description: RANGELEY, Me., Dec. 24  Ski operators throughout the Pine Tree State are convinced the energy crisis will do little to cut down their revenue. They feel they have an advantage because their resorts are patronized by mostly instate clientele. Naturally, Maine is also frequented by people from New Hampshire and Massachusetts, John Christie, owner of the Saddleback ski resort, said today. But even these skiers should encounter no problems driving here and getting back home.

title: L. I. Pupils Help to Provide a Sunny Day for Neediest
description: The spirit of Christmas, which has Many facets, was aptly captured by a contribution acknowledged yesterday from Interage Class 4, 5, 6 of the John H. West School, Bethpage, L. I.

title: Atlantic City Sees Revival If State Legalizes Gaming
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 24 The famous boardwalk is nearly deserted and the most prominent sight these gray, bleak days are the flashing neon signs on the hotel and motel fronts crying vacancy.

title: OIL SEEN CAUSING MINOR U.S. IMPACT
description: SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va., Dec. 24 (UPI)  The director of the American Petroleum Institute said today that doubling crude oil prices by the Persian Gulf states will have only a marginal effect on the American economy.

title: Schlesinger's Impact on the Pentagon Is Yet to Be Felt
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24When James R. Schlesinger took over as Secretary of Defense last July, Senator Stuart Symington, who as the first Air Force Secretary and then as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee has seen Defense Secretaries come and go, gave him a bit of fatherly advice.

title: Chess: 5Way Tie for First Leaves Not Much Room at the Top
description: The seventh annual Atlantic Open Chess Tournament, held at the McAlpiia, Hotel, Nov. 22 to 25, fully lived up to the reputation its predecessors had set for hardfought exciting chess.

title: 38 Food Establishments Cited For City Health Code Violations
description: The Health Department yesterday cited 38 more restaurants and food stores in the city for violations of the Health Code after their owners had failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: Thank You, President Nixon
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 24 (UPI)  An advertisement three inches deep by two columns wide, appeared ire today's issue of The Charleston Gazette. It read: Thank you, President Nixon, for the first peacetime Christmas in twelve years. It was signed: Kanawha County Republican Women's Club.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES TIMBER UPGRADING
description: The Soviet Union, with vast northern timber holdings, has onefourth of the world's forest area. But it has been unable so far to translate this natural resource into large  scale exports to help pay for badly needed industrial equipment and advanced technology from the West.

title: Woman on L.I. Is Accused Of Fatally Beating Child, 3
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 24 (UPI)Mrs. Janet Federle of Wyandanch was held in $10,000 bail today in Suffolk District Court on a charge of fatally beating her 3yearold adopted son.

title: Jersey Fire Demolishes Landmark
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 24A fire that the police believe was set by vandals last night flared anew today and destroyed the preRevolutionary War building in which the Universalist Church of the United States was founded.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Landmark Hotel Faces Foreclosure in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Dec. 24 (AP) The Hotel Viking, a Bellevue Avenue landmark for nearly 50 years, faces a possible foreclosure on its mortgage, a bank official says.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARTHA GRAHAM. By Don McDonagh. 841 Pages. Illustrated. Praeger. $10.95.

title: 100 DIE AS A FERRY SINKS OFF ECUADOR
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 24 (UPI)  a ferryboat carryabout 300 people  double its capacity, according to the police  capsized in the Pacific Ocean off Ecuador today. The police said that more than half the crew and passengers had died.

title: Coast Drivers Line Up For Gasoline Giveaway
description: MOUNT SHASTA, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)It took only two hours for Russell Brownell, a service station owner, to dispense 3,600 gallons of free gasoline to motorists who had lined up a half mile in each direction.

title: Skies Not So Friendly To Colleges' Schedules
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 24 (UPI)The University of Oregon athletic director, Norv Ritchey, said today that the energy crisis could largely eliminate intersectional contests from college sports. His counterpart at Oregon State, Jim Barratt, said he hoped it wasn't so.

title: Crowds of LateBuyers  And Some EarlyReturners
description: All around the city today, people are tugging at ribbons and tearing at papers and Oh, oh, they are murmuring, you shouldn't have done it . . .

title: Latest Increase Said to Cover Only First: Quarter of 1974
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 24 (AP)An influential Arab oil minister predicted today that already skyrocketing Middle East oil prices might rise still higher this spring.

title: Maine Ski Resorts Rely On Their Local Clientele
description: RANGELEY, Me., Dec. 24  Ski operators throughout the Pine Tree State are convinced the energy crisis will do little to cut down their revenue. They feel they have an advantage because their resorts are patronized by mostly instate clientele. Naturally, Maine is also frequented by people from New Hampshire and Massachusetts, John Christie, owner of the Saddleback ski resort, said today. But even these skiers should encounter no problems driving here and getting back home.

title: Boy, 13, Charged in Slaying Of His Parents in Carolina
description: ROCKWELL, N. C., Dec. 24 (UPI)  A 13yearold boy, described by the police as quiet and mildmannered, was charged yesterday with killing his mother and father in their trailer home.

title: U.S. Order for Ethnic Survey Challenged by New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 24Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. has challenged the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to a court fight over an ethnic survey of New Hampshire state employes.

title: JERSEY MAY FOUND DEAD IN THE BRONX
description: The body of a man, tentatively identified as one of 43 suspects indicted and wanted on Federal narcotics charges, was found yesterday afternoon in a parking lot in a sparsely settled part of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: 20 From Burlington Church Supper Still Sought for Typhoid Examinations
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 24More than 20 people who attended a church supper last month were still being sought today by Burlington County and state health officials to determine whether they have been infected with typhoid fever.

title: Londoners Refuse to Be Cheerless
description: LONDON, Dec. 24It was leaden gray and wet in London today, and at the annual carol service in .St. Paul's Cathedral the dimmed lights barely tinged the drizzle yellow. Dozens of cold churches offered the characteristic English carol sound that blends the quavering shrillness of 70yearold women sopranos and the fierce shrillness of 10yearold boy sopranos.

title: Inquiry Pushed in Dental School Dispute
description: NEWARK, Dec. 24  Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, said today that he was investigating all aspects of a simmering dispute that had posed serii, ous problems between some faculty members and the administrative staff of the institution's dental school in Jersey City.

description: THE LEADERS

title: 2,000 Refugees From Da Nang Cling To a Tiny Patch of Hope in the South
description: BAU CA, South Vietnam, The Poor and Miserable People of Quang Da Have Come Here to Survive.

title: NIXON'S HOMES BAR FLORIDA ASSESSORS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP)For four years, the Secret Service has refused to allow Dade County tax assessors inside the Florida White House compound to check on additions, an official said today.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: GRAND JURY TO ACT IN FATAL BEATING
description: The case of a former felon, who is accused beating a man to death last month and who was released without bail in a controversial decision on Saturday, will be presented to a grand jury tomorrow, Acting Manhattan District Attorney Alfred Scotti said yesterday.

title: The LongLasting Nylon Gobbler
description: Turkey is far from the worst food in the national diet. It may even be very good if you are lucky enough to find a freshly killed specimen that was grown in nature. These are rare nowadays, for most modern turkeys seem to be produced by Dow, Monsanto, Du Pont and other colossi of synthetic manufactures.

title: Debut of RotaryEngine Vega For 1975 Is Postponed by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation will not bring out its rotaryengine Chevrolet Vega at the start of the 1975 model year as originally planned, a company spokesman said today.

title: Supervisors' Union Chief Vows A Role in Politics of Education
description: The new president of the union that represents nearly 4,000 principals and other supervisors in the city school system said yesterday that his organization would now play a greater role in the politics of education.

title: ROBBER IS SLAIN, POLICEMAN SHOT
description: A man described as a former customer of an undercover fence operation manned by the police in Queens to receive stolen goods was killed in a wild shootout when he tried to rob the place yesterday, the police said.

title: Floor Under Income
description: The first comprehensive test of systematic Government payments to supplement the earnings of the working poor has provided impressive evidence of the practicality of such an approach to putting a floor under family income. The results of the threeyear social experiment in negative taxation should help revive White House and Congressional interest in the imaginative welfare reform plan originally sponsored by President Nixon in mid1969.

title: L. I. Woman Dies of Burns
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 24 (UPI)Mrs. Valerie Caccavo, 38 years old, of 120 Pacific Boulevard, Long Beach, died early this afternoon about nine hours after flames swept the (kitchen of her home. The exact cause of the fire was not immediately determined, but Fire Marshal Raymond Kerr said the woman was cooking French fried potatoes on a stove when (the blaze erupted shortly before 4 A.M.

title: Plane Crashes in Illinois, Killing a Kankakee Couple
description: CISSNA PARK, Ill., Dec. 24 (UPI)A couple flying to Alabama for a holiday visit with their daughters were killed yesterday when their light plane crashed into a farm field.

title: Kissinger and Nixon Confer on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Secretary of State Kissinger, described as optimistic about prospects for peace in the Middle East, reported personally to President Nixon today on the opening of ArabIsraeli talks in Geneva.

title: Stores Here Jammed as Most Businesses Close for the Day
description: From Bethlehem, where an Israeli police band played Christmas carols, to Bronxville and Brooklyn and Bloomingdale's, where city and suburban shoppers turned their thoughts from the energy crisis and other public troubles in a splurge of buying, the day before Christmas was marked yesterday by a seasonal surge of cheer and goodwill.

title: Dr. Kuiper Is Dead
description: Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, the internationally known astronomer, who played a key role in the nation's early space program, died Sunday while visiting in Mexico City. Details on Page 24.

title: People in Sports: Black Coach Turns Down Wichita State Job
description: John Merritt, the Tennessee State football coach, yesterday declined an offer to move to Wichita State and become the first black coach of a major college football team. I have decided to remain at Tennessee State, the cigarpuffing Merritt told a news conference, because of my loyalty to my coaches, to the boys we have recruited recently who expected us to be here, and to the school, which I feel at this time particularly needs me more than Wichita.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Dec. 24 (UPI)  Three Western Kentucky distance runners were injured early last Saturday when a car crashed into their motel room while they slept Most seriously injured of the three, all natives Bristol, England, was Anthony Staynings, 18 years old, the worldrecord holder in the 10,000meter run for 17yearolds. He was in satisfactory condition at Marlboro Hospital with a fractured pelvis, lacerations, pulled muscles and a bruised back. He is expected to be out of action for a year.

title: Kassuba Petition Filed
description: Walter J. Kassuba, a real estate developer, has filed a petition for reorganization of his assets under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. He acted on behalf of himself, the Kassuba Development Corporation and ventures and partnerships he has an interest in. He said he took the action to protect his equity in real estate properties, which is estimated to be in excess of $100million. The properties are valued at $550 million, he said.

title: Increase Is Expected for Venezuela Oil Prices
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 24 (UPI) Venezuela will follow Persian Gulf oil producers in decreeing major rise in its price for oil exports beginning next month, oil sources said today. Observers predicted that prices will soar over the $10abarrel mark.

title: School Election Reform
description: The report by Max J. Rubin on the inadequacies of the city's community school board elections prepares the way for changes in procedures which brought chaos and confusion to last May's balloting. The recommendations, endorsed by State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist, constitute a concise package for speedy reforms.

title: LORD CHURCHILL IS DEAD AT 83
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) Viscount Churchill, a cousin of Britain's wartime Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, has died in Brighton at the age of 83.

title: Business Briefs
description: Acquisition of publicly held manufacturing companies with assets of at least $10million declined to 56 in 1972 from 58 in 1971, making the 1972 total the lowest for large acquisitions since 1960, according to the Federal Trade Commission,

title: A.B.A. Box Score
description: SUNDAY NIGHT

title: LANDER IS SWORN IN AS JUDGE BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in Benjamin E. Lander, a Manhattan lawyer and member of the Liberal party, as Criminal Court judge to fill the vacancy created by the death last weekend of Judge John F. Furey, whose term expires Dec. 31, 1977.

title: Woman Dies in Fire Here
description: A 71year old woman was killed early yesterday in a fire; in her fourth floor apartment at 414 East 94th Street in Brooklyn. She was identified as Elizabeth Gorlyck. No other in juries were reported.

title: Cougars' Move Hinges on Lagging Gate
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 24 (AP)Whether the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association remain in North Carolina depends largely on the attendance for the remainder of the season, General Manager Carl Scheer said today. We have to progress to a 7,500 average for the season, and that means 8,000 to 10,000 gates the rest of the season in Greensboro and Charlotte, Scheer said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1973

title: People and Business
description: Keith L. Turley has been named president and chief executive officer of the Arizona Public Service Company, the largest utility in the state, effective next Tuesday. He will succeed William P. Reilly, who is retiring at the age of 65.

description: MENDHAM, N. J., Dec. 24 Robert McKean Thomas Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Thomas & Betts Corporation of Elizabeth, an electricalfittings concern, died yesterday in Morristown. He was 64 years old and lived here.

description: AMBLER, Pa., Dec. 24 (AP)Fire damaged extensively the home of a former Philadelphia Phillies pitcher, Bobby Shantz, but he and his family were uninjured.

description: TRENTON, Dec. 24 (AP)Governor Cahill's Energy Commission asked the leadership of the 1974 Legislature today to make early appointments to a legislative commission formed to deal with the energy crisis.

description: DENVER, Dec. 24 (UPI)Ten inches of snow wrapped metropolitan Denver in a white blanket today, slowing holiday travel and isolating hundreds of persons.

title: Drivers Find Gas on 3Day Holiday Too
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 24 Motorists here and throughout New Jersey came face to face with the gasoline shortage today as they found hundreds of service stations either closed for three days or running out of fuel.

title: Burned S.I. Church Draws the Faithful
description: I saw a fire color on the window in the next dorm and I knew something was wrong, wrote a 14yearold girl. We ran into the social room and from there we saw what was happening. It was our church, on fire, and I couldn't Believe it ... it was really sad watching it go down and thinking how long it had been there.

title: 3 LINDSAY AIDES CLEARED FOR JOBS
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton and two other top Officials of the outgoing Lindsay administration received Clearances yesterday from the city's Board of Ethics to accept highpaying positions in private industry. In each instance, the board ruled that there was no Conflict of interest.

title: Slight Drop in Day's Fighting Reported in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 25 (UPI)The South Vietnamese military command reported a slight drop in fighting today, but the battle level was still higher than during Christmas a year agoa month before the ceasefire went into effect.

description: HONG KONG, Dec. 25 Universities in China are beginning to turn out graduates from a new system of higher education concepts growing out of the turbulent Cultural Revolution, which swept the country from. 1966 to 1969.
