description: Ismet Inonu, first Premier of modern Turkey and her second President, died yesterday at the age of 89. In association with Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, he administered reforms that helped transform Turkey from a sultanate to a modern state. Page 42.

title: Mandich Fit; Other Ailing Dolphins Set
description: MIAMI, Dec. 25 (UPI)Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins coach, got the Christmas present he was waiting for todayword that Jim Mandich, an injured tight end, would probably play in Sunday's American Football Conference championship.

title: People in Sports: A Pro Skier Attempts to Erase Color Line
description: A 25yearold San Franciscan, Barry Vinson, is determined to become the Jackie Robinson of professional skiing. There aren't many chances left to he a Jackie Robinson, he said, referring to the baseball star who broke the color line in the major leagues. There are few things you can be first in, but skiing's one of them.

title: Dodgers List 24 Games
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP)The Los Angeles Dodgers announced today a 24game 1974 spring training schedule. They will open against Atlanta on March 9 at their Vero Beach, Fla., training grounds.

title: Gifts Flow To Neediest On Holiday
description: The holiday rush apparently failed to dampen the spirit of giving. As a result, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday experienced the secondbest day in the current campaign.

title: JOHN REINITZ
description: John Reinitz, a retired manufacturer of silk, opera and theatrical hats, died on Monday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Jeanne Cordes, 1720 Norman Street, Ridgewood, Queens. He was 92 years old.

title: Quadraplets Are Born To New Mexico Woman
description: ARTESIA, N. M., Dec. 25 (AP)Mrs. Plorenclo Segura, 25 years old, of Ariesia, gave birth on Christmas Eve to four boys, all under three pounds each. They are in incubators at Artesia General Hospital. The Seguras also have a 4yearold daughter.

title: 37 Protesters at White House Liken Nixon to Herod
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) In what the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan called our way of celebrating Christmas, 37 protesters performed a medieval morality play in front of the White House today and said a mass that likened President Nixon to King Herod. Six persons were arrested.

description: An early morning twoalarm fire in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn routed 40 people from a fourstory tenement yesterday, ruining the Christmas celebrations of seven families. No one was injured in the blaze.

description: It's a poor family. It's a large family, encompassing a nononsense grandma, a protective mama and papa and several charming children led by a model eldest son. And it's a loving family, growing closer in adversity and always refusing to give up.

description: A rose may be a rose to Gertrude Stein, but to a perfumer, a rose is combination of any number of multisyllabic chemicals and perhaps even dash of real rose oil. Even then it isn't simple. There are roses and roses. Does one want et deep red rose, or a spicier tea rose, or the elusive delicacy of white rose?

title: SOVIET SCIENTISTS CAUGHT IN SCANDAL
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22As the seven Soviet scientists first told it, they had toiled away the winter high in the snowbound Anzob Pass of northern Tadzhikistan in Soviet Central Asia all in the cause of energy research.

title: Screen: 'Magnum Force':Police Story Is Sequel to 'Dirty Harry' The Cast
description: Let's hear it for hypocrisyor at least, for our old national tradition of hypocrisy refined. Before World War I, sexy scenes were fine onstage as long as they occurred in biblical shows; later, Cecil B. DeMille exploited the same formula in movies. Now, we can enjoy the lushest baths of violence on the screen in the name of law and order. Of course the principle is ancient. Yet it gains more sophistication with each decade.Yesterday's Christmas package, "Magnum Force," which was unwrapped at the Criterion Theater and the 86th Street East, is a sequel to "Dirty Harry." Harry (Clint Eastwood) is the policeman who kills to protect the public from guns other than his own. The movie is a muddle of morality. "Somebody is trying to put the courts out of business" by rubbing out corrupt labor leaders, racketeers, and narcotics tycoonsthe scum that flourishes in a liberal society where the courts fail to prosecute them. However, righteous policemen who kill "hoodlums" are "crucified by those young bastards at the D.A.'s office." Follow that verb.Harry discovers that there's an execution squad within the police department. Hence it's his duty to bump off five policemen who are equally keen on liquidating him. (After a red herring slightly larger than a sperm whale, and music that precedes each killing with all the subtlety of the Valkyries' entrance theme, no audience is going to swoon with astonishment.)Throughout, there's a stress on dear old hubris: Harry earnestly repeats that "a man't got to know his limitations." Thus, it's reasoned that the killings he commits are justified  "There's nothing wrong with shooting, as long as the right people get shot"  but murderers do have to be discriminating.Since the Supreme Court ruling on obscenity, we've seen a predictable acceleration of violence as a substitute for sex. There's little joy between the sheets in "Magnum Force." But bullets in bare breasts are still acceptable. Topless murderees in a swimming pool or nudes stoned at "$900 an ounce" reinforce the morality: people who take off their clothes may have been asking for it. There's also a gratuitous murder of a prostitute, climaxed with a shot of her killer's face grinning through her spread legs.Young men who hold up a store have "hippy-looking hair" and some skyjackers resemble folk singers. The police lieutenant who warns against brutality (Hal Holbrook, behaving rather like a petulant professor of humanities), turns out to be the most demonic death-dealer of all. Still, the movie strains for some liberal seasoning Harry's partner is black, and some young policemen suspected of oddness are defended for their talents: Harry says, "If the rest of you could shoot like them, I wouldn't care if the whole damn department was queer."Mr. Eastwood's unshakable coolas he dismantles a bomb or refuses a local anesthetic for seven stitchesmakes me miss Richard Widmark's style in playing this kind of part. Mr. Widmark's eyes, which appeared to have been drilled into his head, often looked appalledeven frightened or franticin a desperate situation. But all that Mr. Eastwood can manage is a frown that suggests tension. The excitement is mainly in the camerawork, which is stunningthe sense of motion in space, as cars bowl over bridges or a helicopter rises, lends an exhilaration that's absent from the script.You may pause before hastening your children off to this movie. But certainly policemen shouldn't see it. The picture merely thickens the soup of confusion about their role. However, "Magnum Force" might be interesting for caterers. Harry asserts that San Francisco airport "has the greatest burgers in town"  and that's a mystery which is never fully unraveled.

title: Film:1930's Confidence Men Are Heroes of 'Sting'
description: "The Sting," which opened yesterday at Loew's State 2 and other theaters, re-teams the director (George Roy Hill) and stars (Paul Newman and Robert Redford) of "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" in a comedy about a couple of exuberant confidence men operating in and around Chicago in 1936."The Sting" looks and sounds like a musical comedy from which the songs have been removed, leaving only a background score of old-fashioned, toe-tapping piano rags that as easily evoke the pre-World War I teens as the nineteen-thirties.A lot of the other period details aren't too firmly anchored in time, but the film is so good-natured, so obviously aware of everything it's up to, even its own picturesque frauds, that I opt to go along with it. One forgives its unrelenting efforts to charm, if only because "The Sting" itself is a kind of con game, devoid of the poetic aspirations that weighed down "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid."Mr. Newman and Mr. Redford, dressed in best, fit-to-kill, snap-brim hat, thirties spendor, looking like a couple of guys in old Arrow shirt ads, are more or less reprising their roles in "Butch Cassidy."Mr. Newman is Henry Gondoroff, the older con artist in charge of the instruction of Johnny Hooker (Mr. Redford), the bright, eager, younger man who yearns to make what the movie calls the Big Con (swindle), the way tap dancers in the movies about the twenties wanted to play the Palace.Their quarry is a ruthless, vain, fastidious New York racketeer named Doyle Lonnegan, played by Robert Shaw in the broad manner in which the film was conceived by David S. Ward, who wrote the screenplay, and realized by Mr. Hill.The director supplements the period sets and costumes with elaborate technical devices to move from one scene into another: wipes, iris-outs, images that turn like pages. Separating sequences are title cards that recall Norman Rockwell's Saturday Evening Post covers. It's all a little too much, but excess is an essential part of the film's style."The Sting" has a conventional narrative, with a conventional beginning, middle and end, but what one remembers are the set pieces of the sort that can make a slapped-together Broadway show so entertaining. These include a hilarious, thoroughly crooked poker game on the Twentieth Century Limited in which Henry blows his nose on his tie to the horror of Lonnegan, as well as a chase that lasts approximately two minutes, and the final swindle, the mechanics of which are still none too clear to me.The only woman with a substantial role in the film is Eileen Brennan, who plays a madam with a heart of gold and enough time off to be able to assist the stars in the final con. "The Sting" is not the kind of film that takes its women very seriously, and the continuing popularity of these male-male co-starring teams should, I suppose, probably prompt some solemn analysis.It is not, I suspect, a terrible perversion of the romantic movie-team concept idealized by William Powell and Myrna Loy, Clark Gable and Lana Turner but, rather, a variation on the old Dr. Gillespie-Dr. Kildare relationship, with a bit of Laurel and Hardy thrown in. It is also apparently very good box office.

title: Backing Into Crises
description: EAST SETAUKET, L. I.Because we are still applying old policies to new problems, our current energy shortage is worse than it need be. For nearly two years, we have sought to change the rates that electric utilities charge their customers, with the ultimate objective of reducing the excessive growth in demand for electricity. At present, the price of a kilowatthour of electricity decreases with increased consumption. Very large consumers pay only onethird to onethirtieth as much per kilowatthour as do small customers. When rates are not costbased, some customers subsidize cheap electricity for other customers and waste is rewarded. Unfortunately, the same is true of the regulated natural gas industry.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Save on Sunday halffare program made significant gairig on its second Sunday, according to Dr. William J. Ronan, the M.T.A.'s chairman and chief executive officer. Last Sunday, there were 67.5 per cent more riders on the city's buses than on the Sunday before Christmas in 1972, and 22.5 per cent more than on Dec. 16, the first Sunday of the halffare experiment. Last Sunday, there were about 64,000 more riders on subways than on the first halffate Sunday, and 344,000 more than on the Dec. 9, the last Sunday before the program started. Of the M.T.A.'s suburban cqmmuter railroads, only the Long Island showed a substantial increase, 47,289 riders last Sunday compared with 42,849 on Dec. and 27,794 on the Sunday before that.

description: MANILA, Dec. 25 (AP)A Jesuit group in the Philippines has accepted an $82,000 American grant to promote birth control in Asia. The grant comes at a time when Roman Catholic bishops here have been Circulating a letter assailing a campaign to persuade couples to use contraceptive devices.

title: MADAGASCAR BARS VISIT BY U.S. SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Madagascar, dependent upon Arab nations for its oil, canceled a planned visit by United States warships.

title: Astronauts in Space Walk Take Pictures of Kohoutek
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 25The Skylab 3 astronauts made a record sevenhour space walk on Christmas Day and focused their cameras on the colorful comet Kohoutek in a quest for knowledge of creation.

title: 8 StayUps Break Jail
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 25 (UPI)  Eight prison inmates, given permission to stay up late Christmas Eve, escaped from the Alachua County jail by crawling through air ducts.

title: DIPLOMAT IMMUNITY GIVES BOBBIES FITS
description: LONDON (AP)Nigeria's diplomats in London are in a league by themselves for dodging parking fines.

title: Arab Brinkmanship
description: The announcement by the Arab oil nations that they will increase production by 10 per cent in January and supply Britain, France, Japan, Spain and other friendly countries with their full oil needs suggests that the Arabs have grown wary of causing an economic disaster in the industrial world that could backfire upon them. Speaking in Kuwait, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheikh Ahmed Zaki alYamani said, We do not wish the nations of the world to suffer.

title: Suspected Fences Flee Police in Wake of a Shootout in Queens
description: A group of suspected fences, who peddled stolen property in a Queens store operated and staked out by the police, disappeared overnight from their homes and haunts as authorities sought to round them up.

title: LONDON PUB BLASTS INJURE SEVEN MORE
description: LONDON, Dec. 25 (UPI)Two bombs exploded at London pubs shortly before midnight on Christmas Eve, injuring seven more persons in the Irish Republican Army's holiday bomb campaign, the police said.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: 200 Die in Indian Cold Wave
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Nearly 200 people are estimated to have died in cold wave that has gripped much of northern India in the last two weeks, according to official reports reaching here. The victims are mostly poor people who have inadequate clothing and shelter.

title: HAMILTON ASSAILS BEAME ON H.D.A.
description: The proposed dismantling of the city's Housing and Development Administration by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame was strongly decried yesterday by outgoing Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton.

title: Report by F.B.I. Disputes Gray on Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  A confidential F.B.I. report apparently contradicts the testimony of L. Patrick Gray 3d last March that he had no knowledge of nearly 20 national security wiretaps that President Nixon had ordered on newsmen and officials of his Administration.

title: Janet Seewald Has Nuptials
description: The Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Miss Janet Miriam Seewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Seewald of Brooklyn, to Dr. Sanford J. Holland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Holland of West Hempstead, L. I. Rabbi Sholom Gold of the Young Israel of West Hempstead performed the ceremony.

title: Rangers Turn Back Flyers, 2 to 1, on Irvine's Goal
description: The New York Rangers beat the Philadelphia Flyers last night, 21, in the kind of game that shows how bigleague hockey should be played. It was in the style of a playoff match, with tight defense, hard checking and firstclass goaltending.

title: A Morning Stroll Through a Cuisine's History
description: As posited here recently, the bestfed community in New York is Chinatown, in terms of taste, quality and tradition. Food is in fact its main occupation and preoccupation, and a morning stroll along Mott and Mulberry Streets discloses a number of ancient alimentary arts of the Orient being practiced in the shadow of the civic center.

title: Threat Fails a Briton
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England (AP)A man threatened to lav spells on magistrates and policemen if he was not cleared of an assault charge. The judge laid a $24 fine on the defendant.

title: Penn State Rally Tops Fordham Five, 73 to 67
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP)Ron Brown scored 4 of his 13 points in overtime as Penn State rallied for a 7367 victory over Fordham tonight in the opener of the 13th annual Quaker City basketball tournament.

title: Villages in Quebec Fade With Dwindling Power of the Church
description: ST. NARCISSE, Quebec, Dec. 16It used to be, say the oldtimers of St. Narcisse, that the young people would stay home during the long winter evenings, doing what the church and their parents told them to do.

title: 6 Egyptians, in Bunker Since October, Give Up
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  Six Egyptian soldiers who had held out in a narrow bunker north of Suez city since October surrendered to Israeli forces Monday, military sources said here today.

title: Panel for dh Goes To Bat for Cepeda
description: MANCHESTER, N. H. (UPI)  The Boston Red Sox slugger, Orlando Cepeda, whose career appeared finished when he was released by Oakland a year ago, has been named the major league's first outstanding designated hitter.

title: Hull's Goal Helps Beat Cougars
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 26 (AP)Bobby Hull broke a 22 deadlock with less than four minutes gone in the third period tonight and the Winnipeg Jets went on to defeat the Chicago Cougars, 42, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Japan Delaying Fuel Cut On Arab Supply Pledges
description: TOKYO, Dec, 26  The Japanese Government decided today to postpone scheduled emergency reductions in the use of oil and electric power by industry following the announcement that Arab states would ease their oil cutbacks.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Turbodyne Corporation announced yesterday that it had received an $81.2million order from the San Diego Gas and Electric Company for all the major equipment in a combined cycle gas turbine plant with a rated capacity of 700 megawatts.

title: Mormon Leader Dies
description: Harold B. Lee, leader of 3.3 million Mormons as president, of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints died last night in Salt Lake City at the age of 74. Page 40.

title: A Woman's Body Is Found Near Buffalo Shopping Site
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 26 (AP)The partly clothed body of an unidentified young woman was found early today near a shopping plaza in northern Buffalo by a man walking his dog.

title: Records: Classical Works for Youth
description: All the big record companies would love to sell more classical music to young people. Part of their motivation no doubt is a disinterested, painfully sincere desire to spread culture to the benighted. But the main reason is money: American teenagers have enormous amounts of money to spend, and they spend a lot of it on records, mostly rock records. Record executives understandably would love to expand their market by encouraging kids to branch out into the relatively unprofitable classics.

title: Maniago Excels As Stars Down Islanders, 1 to 0
description: BLOOMINGTON, MINN., Dec. 26 (UPI)Cesare Maniago recorded his first shutout of the National Hockey League season tonight as the Minnesota North Stars won, 10, from the New York Islanders.

title: MRS. PAUL KRIEGER
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 26  Mrs. Ruth Tow Krieger, president of American White Cross Laboratories, Inc., died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital after a heart attack. She was 70 years old and the wife of Paul H. Krieger, also an executive of the company, which manufacturers bandages and first aid kits, and which was established by her father, Harris Tow. She lived at 142 Overlook Road.

title: Change in Command Setup Urged for Navy Academy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  The United States Naval Academy's Board of Visitors has recommended that the academy's command structure be changed so that its superintendent reports directly to the Chief of Naval Operations.

title: Nixon Flies to Coast on Commercial Airliner
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26President Nixon, a party of 11 and Secret Service agents slipped away from the White House this evening and took a commercial airline flight to Los Angeles to spend a postChristmas holiday at his San Clemente home.

title: Japan Delaying Fuel Cut On Arab Supply Pledges
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26  The Japanese Government decided today to postpone scheduled emergency reductions in the use of oil and electric power by industry following the announcement that Arab states would ease their oil cutbacks.

title: Cleaver Is Writing a New Book And Charting 2 Legal Battles
description: PARIS, Dec. 26 (Reuters) Eldridge Cleaver, black militant who has been abroad since fleeing the United States in 1968, is now working on a new book and preparing for coming legal battles at a secret address.

title: Saigon Battalion Said to Suffer Heavy Casualties in Delta Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec., 27 (AP)  A Government battalion of 500 men was knocked out of aclion in fighting for control of the Mekong Delta rice harvest, Saigon military sources said today.

title: PATERSON FIGHTS RISE IN MEASLES
description: PATERSON, Dec. 26More than 100 cases of measlesincluding 60 in Decemberhave been reported here since August in an outbreak that is approaching epidemic proportions, according to the city's Department of Health.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 26A familiar face, once an integral part of Princeton basketball as a player, has returned as a coach.

title: Los Angeles a Shadow Of Its Usual Radiant Self
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26This sprawling, highvoltage city was a shadow of its normal radiant self Christmas weekend as mandatory curtailments of electricity surpassing even the World War II cutbacks took effect.

title: Stage: Having a Wonderful Holiday
description: There is a special pleasure in encountering a play that one had heard about but did not know, and then discovering that it is a genuine find, a play that had for too long been shamefully neglected. Such a play is Philip Barry's joyous comedy Holiday, which the New Phoenix Repertory Company introduced into its programs at the Ethel Barrymore Theater last night.

title: Metzenbaum Pays to U.S. $118,102 in Back Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  Howard M. Metzenbaum paid $118,102 in back taxes on Dec. 17, two days before he was named to be a United States Senator from Ohio, records of the United States Tax Court show.

title: TroubleShooter Trouble
description: Mayorelect Beame has bucked to the Board of Ethics a tough but, it seems to us, inescapable decision regarding a key appointment to his incoming administration.

title: Chervet Regains Title
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 26 (UPI)Fritz Chervet of Switzerland regained his European flyweight boxing crown today when he knocked out Fernando Atzori; the Italian titleholder, in the seventh round of their scheduled 15round bout.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: Reports that wheat harvests, both in this country and China, would be greater than expected, caused prices of wheat futures. on the Chicago Board of Trade to fall the limit of 20 cents yesterday.

title: DISASTER RELIEF FOUND GENEROUS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)Federal disaster relief is now so generous that it discourages homeowners and businessmen from buying insurance and encourages them to build in troubleprone areas, a University of Pennsylvania economist said today.

title: Georgia Judge Rules Alimony Unconstitutional
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 26 (UPI)A Fulton County judge ruled today ruled that alimony payments were unconstitutional in Georgia because they were a form of sex discrimination.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1973

title: Terry a Seasoned Campaign Assistant Who Worked for All Factions of Party
description: Seymour Terry belongs to that small, closely knit fraternity of. professional campaign workers  ballotbox technicians who know the city's back rooms, the lines of influence, the techniques of canvassing, the secrets of scheduling and the best way to pull out the vote.

title: A Normal Flight for Passengers Except When Nixon Appeared
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26Through most of the trip none of the passengers aboard United Air Lines Flight 55 from Washington had any idea that the President was on board.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DETROIT, Dec. 26The injuryplagued Knicks, their ranks already thinned by incapacitating injuries to Willis Reed and Earl Monroe, stumbled into another physical problem tonight, but overcame it to subdue the Detroit Pistons, 9691, at Cobo Arena before the Pistons' largest crowd of the National Basketball Association season11,248.

title: I.R.S., in Shift, to Watch Holiday Gasoline Prices
description: Following reports of gasoline price gouging over the Christmas weekend, officials of the regional office of the Internal Revenue Service, whose agents had taken the holiday off, said yesterday that the office was changing its procedure and that the agents would be on duty over the New Year weekend to prevent price violations.

title: Ethics Board Meets To Question Terry On Letter to Clients
description: The city's Board of Ethics, in an emergency session unparalleled in its 13 years, questioned one of Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's key appointees yesterday on whether he tried to use his prestige in the upcoming Beame administration to improve his insurance business.

title: LAOS COMMUNITY NOW FEEDS ITSELF
description: AT THE NAM TAN IRRIGATION DAM, Xaignabouri Province, Laos, Dec. 15The 16,000 people in this valley area around the small dam on a tributary of the Mekong River harvested a rice surplus this year, but they are still learning to cope with some of the problems that came with the 43 miles of irrigation canals and ditches that made the surplus possible.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TRADE The China Institute of America, 125 East 65th Street (7448181), has a small room on the main floor that serves as a gallery. Despite its size, its contents are invariably grand. The current show, through Jan. 27, deals with China Trade Porcelain, and what you see is a handsome display of porcelains made for China's foreign trade from the 16th century through the 18th century, when such items were eagerly sought by European households.

title: Rallying Cry for Fuel Crisis: Everybody Into a Pool!
description: A new kind of sign is springing up along highways in this metropolitan areadirections to staging areas for commuter car pools.

title: NATHANIEL E. WALDMAN
description: Nathaniel E. Waldman, an investment counselor associated since 1945 with Carl M. Loeb, Rhodes & Company, died of a heart attack Dec. 17 in the BMT subway station at Rector and Trinity Streets. He was 75 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

title: Mrs. Chesimard, in Summation,Terms Holdup Case Contrived
description: Joanne D. Chesimard, the suspected member of the Black Liberation Army, told a Federal jury of six men and six women yesterday that the evidence linking her to a bank robbery had been manufactured by the Government's two key witnesses, whose main concern, she said, was to reduce their own prison terms.

title: Martin to Quit in 1975
description: KEARNEY, Neb., Dec. 26 (UPI)  Representative Dave Martin of Nebraska, the ranking Republican on the House Rules Committee, said yesterday that he will step down at the end of his seventh twoyear term in January of 1975.

title: Crude Oil, Crude Politics
description: There is no room for complacencymuch less rejoicing at the decision of the Arab petroleum producers increase the flow of oil to countries which have bent their Mideast policies in ways pleasing to the Arab states. The exercise of political extortion remains all too explicit; the economic consequences of doubling the price of oil virtually overnight could be as threatening to the industrial economies as were the cutbacks available supply.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Soviet Envoy Confers With Nixon and Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin conferred for an hour this morning with President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger at the White House, mostly about SovietAmerican relations, a spokesman reported.

title: Teacher Is Given 4 Years As Agitator Against Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  A Moscow technical school tenacher has been sentenced to four years in a labor camp on charges of antiSoviet agitation and propaganda, Soviet dissident sources said tonight.

title: Aspin Sees Move to Raise Natural Gas Prices 300%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the Federal Power, Commission and the natural gas industry were using the energy shortage as a phony excuse to attempt to raise gas prices 300 per cent.

title: Celtics Set Back Braves On White's Goal, 125123
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 26 (UPI)Jo Jo White's 20foot jumper with two seconds to play tonight, lifted Boston to a 125123 victory over Buffalo and gave the Celtics their 21st straight triumph against the Braves over a fouryear period.

title: Harnessing Oil Money
description: PARIS, Dec. 26The magnitude of recent oil price increases has intensified the need for international agreements to avoid the danger of economic collapse comparable to that of the nineteenthirties. The fundamental question, as posed by international experts is how thee higher cost of oil will be paid for. The quadrupling of posted prices in the last. year means it will take four times as many Italian shoes, American trucks, British woolens or Japanese radios to buy the same amount of oil.

title: Basic Recipe for Delicate Bean Curd
description: Bean curd is an inexpensive, custardlike, delicately flavored food that serves as a remarkable replacement or stretcher for meat, and lends protein support to greens. The fresh Chinatown product is available in Oriental stores; it is superior to the canned import but should be used as soon as possible.

title: Chase Opens Automated Banking Center
description: In another step on the road toward automated banking, the Chase Manhattan Bank opened yesterday a branch with money machines and no tellers on the main concourse of Grand Central Station.

title: EndGame
description: BOSTON, Dec. 26Other ages have had comets and new religions and revolutions. The change of the year is always likely to remind us that change is the law of life, But the sense of change, and the apprehension of it, cannot often have run so deep as they do this year. Many of us feel what an Englishman said in a letter to the editor the other day: Our world Is not ever going to be the same again.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Each year the United States Department of Agriculture publishes a yearbook, generally on a specific subjectsuch as Trees, in 1949 (and still a regular seller), and Outdoors, USA, in 1967. This year the yearbook is called Handbook for the Home, and it is a 388page, hardcover book packed with general and specific information on family problems, housing, home furnishing and community affairs.

title: Byrne Bids Nixon Resign
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26 (AP)Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne, a Democrat, has called for the resignation of President Nixon because of loss of confidence brought on by Watergate. In an interview with The Daily Journal of Elizabeth, he said that Watergate and other issues had made it difficult for Mr. Nixon to run the Government.

title: Mexican Police Say Chief Of Kidnappers is Seized
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 (Reuters)The Mexican police today announced the capture of the head of a gang allegedly responsible for more than 20 kidnappings over the last two years. He was identified as a former policeman,

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Corvette Owner Sues G.M. For $1Million in '68 Crash
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 26 (AP)A $1million negligence suit has been filed in State Supreme Court against the General Motors Corporation by the owner of a 1966 Corvette who lost his arm in a 1968 automobile accident.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Suspect Seized in Killing Of a Woman in Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 26 (UPI) The police arrested a suspect early today in the slaying of Mrs. Beatrice Watson, 68 years old, whose body was found in her home on Christmas day. The police said Ronald Wallace, 18, of Rochester, had been charged with murder, robbery and burglary. They said they were looking for a second suspect.

title: Los Angeles a Shadow Of Its Usual Radiant Self
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26This sprawling, highvoltage city was a shadow of its normal radiant self Christmas weekend as mandatory curtailments of electricity surpassing even the World War II cutbacks took effect.

title: Large Deposits of Uranium Reported Found in Punjab
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 26 (UPI)Dr. Munir Ahmed Khan, chairman of the Pakistan's Atomic Energy Commission, said today that large deposits of uranium had been discovered in the southern part of Punjab.

title: Findings of Research Promise Hope to the 70 Million Overweight Americans
description: Obesity, long the subject of cruel humor, dangerous crash diets and questionable reducing gimmicks, is beginning to yield its secrets to serious scientific investigators.

title: FOUR POLICEMEN HURT IN A MELEE
description: A neighborhood group of young men and women battled police officers, injuring four of them, who were arresting suspect in a shooting on West 78th Street early yesterday morning.

title: Byrne Bids Port Unit Offer TollFree Commuter Calls
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26Governor elect Brendan T. Byrne today asked the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to establish a tollfree telephone number that commuters could cell for fast and accurate bus and train schedule information.

title: P,S.C.URGED TO BAR CON ED RISE ON GAS
description: An examiner for the State Public Service Commission recommended yesterday that the panel deny a request by the Consolidated Edison Company for a temporary increase of $13,788,800 a year in gas rates.

title: PLEDGE ON BUDGET IS GIVEN BY H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 Frank C. Carlucci, the Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that there would be no compensating cutbacks in the department's 1975 budget request as a result of the release this month of more than $1billion in impounded 1973 funds for education and health programs.

title: Hogan Resigns, Ending 32 Years as Prosecutor
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan submitted his resignation to the Governor yesterday, ending a career of almost 32 years as the Manhattan prosecutor.

title: Fraser Turns Himself Into a Good Loser
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 26 (AP)  Neale Fraser, captain of Australia's victorious Davis Cup tennis team, caused the major surprise of the first round of the $74,500 Australian open today when he pulled out of his match against a countryman, Colin Dibley, while on the verge of winning.

title: Snow Gone, Irish Drill Outdoors
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 26 (UPI)Notre Dame practiced on its artificial turf today for the first time since the team began workouts last week for the New Year's Eve Sugar Bowl battle with No. 1ranked Alabama.

title: Dr. Harry Bakwin, Pediatrician Who Was Art Collector, Dies
description: Dr. Harry Bakwin, a retired professor of clinical pediatrics at New York University and the owner of a notable collection of painting and sculpture, died Tuesday at his home, 132 East 71st Street. He was 79 years old.

title: People in Sports: Dawson Cast in Receiver's Role
description: Manoftheyear honors in the National Football League aren't necessarily based on playing statistics. Len Dawson, the Kansas City Chiefs' quarterback, who was out of action half of the season, was voted the award yesterday. A player's civic contributions are considered as well as his athletic ability.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 26 (AP) The Government said today that the Venezuelan oiltax reference values used to calculate taxes paid by foreignoil companies would increase substantially next Tuesday. Hugo Perez la Salvia, the Mines and Hydrocarbons Minister, said the increase would be disclosed later this week. Oilindustry sources speculated that the increase would bring Venezuela's prices in line with those of Persian Gulf countries, which doubled their prices last week to more than $11 a barrel. The taxreference price on Venezuelan oil  roughly similar to the posted price on Arab oil  stands at an average of $7.74 a barrel. The price, $3.11 last January, has gone up 11 times since then.

title: No. 2 Men in Tokyo Ministries Are No. 1 in Real Power
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21Promptly at noon every Monday and Thursday 24 men who constitute perhaps the single most powerful group in Japan gather around a large dining table on the ground floor of the Premier's offices.

title: Twin Parks, an Effort to Alter the Pattern of Public Housing
description: What happens when four highly sophisticated young architectural firms, none of which had ever built any public housing, try their hands at it? That's what happened at Twin Parks in the Tremont section of the Bronx, where the State Urban Development Corporation, the quasipublic agency started in 1968, set out to change the standard pattern of publichousing design by architectural drones, by deliberately offering commissions to the sort of highstyle designers who have generally been kept away from such work.

title: Wilkes to Stage 41st Mat Tourney
description: The 41st annual Wilkes College open wrestling tournament, the oldest event of its kind in the country, will be held at the Wilkes College gymnasium on Friday and Saturday, Dec. 28 and 29, in WilkesBarre, Pa.

title: GUNFIRE ON CANAL DISRUPTS SUPPLY
description: CAIRO, Dec. 26Daily outbreaks of shooting between Israeli and Egyptian forces have reportedly constricted the movement of supplies to Egypt's III Corps, cut off in the Sinai Peninsula along the southern section of the Suez Canal.

title: Dolphin Game Sold Out
description: MIAMI, Dec, 26 (AP)The Miami Dolphins said the last of the 80,000 Orange Bowl tickets for Sunday's American Football Conference playoff game with Oakland were sold today. The sellout means the game will be shown on local television.

title: CHEMALLOY SETTLES WITH GENERAL HOST
description: TORONTO, Dec. 26 (UPI)Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., has paid $2million to General Host Corporation in settlement of the direct claims of General Host growing out of litigation last year in which the cornpany claimed that Chemalloy breached terms of a $6.1million note resulting from a tantalum mining operation.

title: Boy Killed in Truck Mishap
description: ANDOVER, Me., Dec. 26 (AP) A 15yearold boy was killed today while shoveling salt from a truck onto an icy road in this western Maine hamlet. The state police said that the truck slid off the road, syent over an embankment and overturned on the youth, Elwin Ornery. They said that the truck was being driven by the victim's father. wirbur Chenery, 12.

title: Pretrial Hearing Put Off In Case of 3 Nixon Aides
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (UPI)  A pretrial hearing scheduled for today was put off until Jan. 14 in the case of John D. Ehrlichman and two other former White House aides charged in connection with the burglary at the office of Dr, Daniel Ellsberg's former psy, chiatrist.

title: Deaths by Freezing Stir Calls for Laws
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 26Calls or the kind of legislation that might have prevented the death by freezing of an elderly couple were made by Icity officials and civic groups today as investigationssome aimed at a possible indictment of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporationwere started.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Manhattan grand jury opened an investigation yesterday into the controversial case of an accused killer who was set free without bail last week by Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright. The suspect, Seymour Popkin, who has a long criminal record, is charged with beating to death Robert Nee in a fist fight at 47th Street and Ninth Avenue on Nov. 30. At Mr. Popkin's arraignment last week, Judge Wright ordered him released in his own recognizance after the prosecutor refused to disclose the names of prospective witnesses against him.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: Stock prices soared yesterday after the announcement that Arab producers would increase the flaw of oil to most countries. Page 57.

title: Rain, Thaw Is Hurting Ski Industry
description: FRANCONIA, N.H., Dec. 26  Just like the fasttalking magician who digs into his top hat and pulls out a lemon instead of a rabbit, New Hampshire's ski industry has been reaching out for skiers only to come up with cancellations.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange and the New York Stock Exchange issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by major shareholders, directors and officers in listed companies. Following are the changes reported:

title: Legislature Must Draft State Occupational Safety Code by March 31
description: ALBANY, Dec. 26  New York State must choose between coming up with its own standards for occupational safety and health by March 31 or relinquishing the field to they Federal Government. A state legislative committee has already heard spirited debate on the wisdom of both courses of action.

title: Oil Is Stockpiled by Some Corporations
description: Some corporations have moved swiftly in recent months to stockpile millions of gallons of fuel oil, even as the Nixon Administration has urged homeowners to turn down their thermostats and drivers to reduce their use of automobiles.

title: Fraser Turns Himself Into a Good Loser
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 26 (AP)  Neale Fraser, captain of Australia's victorious Davis Cup tennis team, caused the major surprise of the first round of the $74,500 Australian open today when he pulled out of his match against a countryman, Colin Dibley, while on tile verge of winning.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Easier Mortgages Seen As Rate of Interest Rises
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26  Bankers today began increasing interest charges to the new higher rate permitted by the State Banking Department amid predictions that the change would make more money available for prospective home buyers.

title: Nastase Wants to Play for New Yorkers
description: Ilie Nastase, the No. 1 attraction in professional tennis, has notified officials of World Team Tennis that he would play only for the New York franchise next year, if he plays at all.

title: ACCOUNTING BOARD SCHEDULES HEARING
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board announced yesterday that a public hearing would be held starting March 15 on accounting for research and development and similar costs. A 126page discussion memorandum analyzing issues to be resolved in developing a statement on financial accounting standards on the subject will be distributed Tuesday.

title: Impeachable Offenses
description: The President, Vice President and all civil Officers of the United States, shall be removed from Office on Impeachment for, and Conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Golden Door: Enter Fat, Exit Wiser
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif.Maurice H. Stans paused in his walk, gasped slightly for breath, and squinted into the early afternoon sun. It's, a great experience to drop everything and take inventory, he said.

title: Advertising: More Syndication
description: A number of large ad agencies are moving strongly into televisionprogram production but in an altogether different way from the golden age when they had producers and directors on their staffs.

title: Eaton at 90: Still Active and Dogged in Beliefs
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 The Nova Scotia youth to whom John D. Rockefeller Sr. took a shine some 75 years ago and started in business celebrates his 90th birthday tomorrow as one of the country's foremost active capitalists. He is Cyrus S. Eaton Sr., the multimillionaire chairman emeritus of the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway Company, a man who is a strong believer in private enterprise for the United States and yet holds with pride a Lenin Peace Prize.

title: Death Threat Alleged
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Dec. 26 (UPI)A 40yearold native of Hungary was arrested today on charges of threatening to kill Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. United States Magistrate William Mallet set bond for Istvan Kispal Kovacs, a resident of Beaverton, Ore., at $75,000 The F.B.I. said Mr. Kovacs allegedly threatened to kill Senator Hatfield Monday in the presence of an F.B.I. agent at an international bridge crossing from Mexico. No motive was given.

title: Leaks in Shape for Bowl
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 26 (UPI) Roosevelt Leaks, Texas fullback who strained a knee Thanksgiving Day, was pronounced 100 per cent recovered today for the Cotton Bowl game next Tuesday. Leaks took part in the Longhorns' first official workout since the end of the regular season. He had strained the knee in the game against Texas A. and M.

title: Bridge:
description: For reasons that can be and are, argued at length major championships are dominated by men, But the gentler sex makes its pres ence felt from time to time as in the Swiss team championship at the Fall Nation als in Las Vegas, Nev., early this month.

title: Fiedler in Hospital
description: BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP)Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra, has entered a hospital for treatment of high temperature and pneumonia. A spokesman for New England Medical Hospital said the 79yearold conductor was admitted Monday and is now in good condition. The spokesman said Mr. Fiedler should be up and around within a few days.

title: A New School Election Is Ordered for District
description: Federal Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. has decided to order a new election in Community School District 1 because, he said, the rights of some voters in the Lower East Side district had been violated in last May's election.

title: Major Oilwell Fire in Wyoming Is Put OutAfter Flaring Anew
description: CASPER, Wyo., Dec. 26A team of oilwell fire fighters quelled today what was described as the worst oilwell conflagration in United States history after it flared up again Christmas Eve.

title: Flooding and Snow Strike Central and Southern France
description: NICE, France Dec. 26 (UPI) Rainstorms and heavy snowfalls have caused widespread flooding and other disruption throughout central and southern France, the police said today.

title: People and Business
description: Acting on the premise that something good had to come from bringing businessmen and college students closer together, the Institute of Life Insurance this year got the industry's two giantsthe Prudential and the Metropolitanto start their businessmeninresidence program.

title: 3 GUILTY IN DEATH OF POSTAL WORKER
description: A Federal Court jury last night convicted three men of the murder of a postal employe last April 5 during an attempted mailtruck robbery in the Wall Street area.

title: Radio: National Lampoon Takes to the Airwaves
description: Maintaining its zest for determined nuttiness and cheerful tastelessness, the National Lampoon has invaded radio. Billing itself as the first new comedy show specifically created for radio in 25 years, the National Lampoon Radio Hour is carried weekly on about 100 radio stations across the country. In the New York City area, it can be heard on WRVRFM. This Saturday's edition, beginning at 7 P.M., is offering nothing less than a special Impeachment Day spectacular.

title: School Officials Asked to Aid Drive on Cemetery Vandals
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called on school officials yesterday to help in campaign to discourage teenagers from vandalizing cerneteries here. Mr. Lefkowitz said he planned to arrange a meeting with Chancellor Irving Anker at which he would offer the services of his office in enlisting the support of high school students, who appear to be the principal culprits in the desecration of gravestones and mausoleums.

title: Donors to Neediest Cases Fund Send Gifts Rather Than Cards
description: Several persons have sent gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in lieu of holiday greetings but Mr. and Mrs. Allan Hecht are taking the opposite view.

title: IRAN SAID TO WARN JAPAN ON ECONOMY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Iran has seriously warned Japan that continued economic cooperation depends directly on effective measures by Japan to provide Iran with raw materials necessary for industry, authorities announced here today.

title: Carolina Fire Station Burns
description: WARRENTON, N.C., Dec. 26 (UPI) Local residents still had fire protection today but no home for the town's two fire trucks after a blaze destroyed the fire station Christmas Day. A policeman, Kenneth Short, drove the two trucks to safety after discovering the blaze at 1:15 A.M. yesterday. The firemen had to be sumnioned from their homes by telephone since the fire had destroyed the siren.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS FLEXIBILITY IN USE OF TRANSIT FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 President Nixon told Governor Wilson and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller today that he favored the flexible use of Federal funds for mass transit re and that he would allow the use of these funds for operating subsidies.

title: BEAMS APPOINTS 2 AND RETAINS THIRD
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday named two new Commissioners and reappointed a third, who will become the eighth official in the Lindsay administration to be retained by the upcoming administration.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: An unusual experiment in arts sponsorship will be undertaken when the City Center Joffrey Ballet and the Joffrey II Company tour four Midwestern states in January. The tour is sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts and the MidAmerican Arts Alliance, a group made up of the Nebraska Arts Council, Kansas Cultural Arts Commission, Iowa Arts Council and Missouri State Council on the Arts. The alliance was organized recently in an attempt to bring to these four states performing groups they could not afford to sponsor their own.

title: High School Sports
description: The eyes of Texas were upon DeWitt Clinton last weekend, and if those eyes were watching closely, they learned something about basketball. The Governors traveled to Houston for two games in the Dr. Pepper Classic and left with everybody believing you have to be good to make it in New York. Friday night Houston Worthing, one of that city's top teams, was demolished, 9861; Saturday night, Houston Wheatley, Texas state champion, made closer, but lost, 8780.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: Stock prices soared yesterday after the announcement that Arab producers would increase the flow of oil to most countries. Page 57.

title: Chile's Lesson for Leftists
description: The Chilean experience, particularly the bloody destruction of the Allende Government by military coup, has compelled Communist, and some Socialist, parties around the world to reassess their own strategies.

title: JACKSON OPPOSES DELAY IN FUEL ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 Senator Henry M. Jackson, the leading Democratic energy spokesman on Capitol Hill, rebuffed today a request by the Nixon Administration for permission to delay the start of fuel allocation programs required by law.

title: Kunzman Improved
description: UPLAND, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI)Lee Kunzman, a race driver, was reported in fair condition today at San Antonio Community Hospital, where he is recovering from injuries suffered in an accident Dec. 11 at the Ontario Motor Speedway. The United States Auto Club driver from Guttenburg, Iowa, was hurt in a 190mileperhour crash during tire testing in an Eagle Offy.

title: 1500 Political Prisoners Build Their Jail on Pacific Isle Off Chile
description: CONCEPCION, Chile, Dec. 26 (AP)About 500 political prisoners are building their own jail at an abandoned fort on Quiriquina Island in the choppy Pacific off this central Chilean city.

title: The Metropolitan Shows a Wald, a Pace and 173 Others
description: What could be a greater gift for an artist at this holiday season than to have one's work shown at The Metropolitan Museum, especially it the artist has never exhibited before?

title: Opera: Merry Barbiere
description: II Barbiere di Siviglia returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Tuesday night and made Christmas a little bit merrier. Eugene Berman's sets are still neat and bright after nearly 20 years of service (although it seems odd that Bartolo's living room should resemble a Southern California ranch house), while Cyril Ritchard's original staging, refreshed by Patrick Tavernia, moved swiftly and humorously to a happy finale.

title: Chimp Maims Zoo Chief
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 26 (UPI)The director of the Des Moines Children's Zoo, who almost died from a cobra bite in 1969, lost two fingers to chimpanzee Christmas Day. The director, Bob Elgin, was trying to remove the 150pound chimp from its cage when it grabbed his arm and tried to pull him inside. In the struggle, the chimp bit off the first two fingers on Mr. Elgin's left hand.

title: Wilson, in 15 Years, Filed His Holdings only Twice
description: Fourteen years elapsed between the only two declarations of financial holdings filed by Governor Wilson during his 15 years as Lieutenant Governor, according to statements on record with the New York Secretary of State.

title: T.W.A. Completes Accord With Wells Fargo Leasing
description: Trans World Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for a $20million master equipment lease agreement with the Wells Fargo Leasing Corporation and the First Chicago Leasing Corporation.

title: Canucks Set Back Golden Seals, 64
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 26 (UPI)Thirdperiod goals by Bobby Schmautz, Dennis Ververgaert and Paulin Bordeleau today powered the Vancouver Canucks to a 64 victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: Stock Prices Soar; Dow Up 22 Points
description: Santa Claus arrived on Wall Street the day after Christmas with a glittering stockmarket rally in his pack. Some glamour issues displayed substantial gains.

title: Dr. Matthew Given A 3Year Sentence
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the neurosurgeon who won powerful support at the White House for his advocacy of black capitalism, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for having misapplied Medicaid funds.

title: Youth Facing Murder Trial Found Dead in Belfast Jail
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 26 (AP)  A young Protestant awaiting trial for the attempted murder of a Roman Catholic was found dead with head injuries today in a Belfast prison.

title: Israeli and Egyptian Teams Begin Geneva Troop Talks
description: GENEVA, Dec. 26  A fresh attempt to break the deadlock between Israel and Egypt over the separation of their forces on the Suez Canal front was begun here today under the auspices of the Middle East peace conference.

title: Harold B. Lee, President Of Mormon Church, Dies
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 26 (AP)Harold B. Lee, president of the Church of Jesus Christ. of LatterDay Saints, died of lung and cardiac failure at the sage of 74. He had entered a hospital run by the Mormon church here around 3 P.M. for a routine annual checkup and died there about six hours later.

title: HARTEHANKS SALE OF 2 PAPERS CLOSED
description: Harte  Hanks Newspapers, Inc. said it had closed the previously announced sale of the newspaper assets of the Express Publishing Company to News America Publishing, Inc. for $18million. News America is a subsidiary of News Ltd., of Australia.

title: Stanford, 2d Best in West, Aims to Be Best in Festival
description: Continually operating in the shadows of the University of California, Los Angeles, the perennial national champions, can have a negative effect on your image. So it is understandable why Stanford is happy to be a basketball tournament favorite for a change.

title: Personal Finance: Fight Over Escrow Accounts
description: John Warren Carpenter owns property in Boston and pays off the mortgage to the Suffolk Franklin Savings Bank there.

title: Blatty's The Exorcist Comes to the Screen
description: The Georgetown dinner party being given by Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn), a Hollywood movie actress making a film in Washington, is going beautifully, with diplomats, astronauts, Senators and show people carrying on in high style. A movie director gets drunk and tries to beat up the butler while a swinging Jesuit priest plays the piano for a singalong.

title: GOTBAUM ASKS VOTE BY AIDES IN SCHOOLS
description: Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes Union called yesterday for an immediate election to determine whether 9,000 school aides in the city's school system want to be represented by Local 372 of District 37 or by the United Federation of Teachers.

title: U.S. Ranks Fuel Users
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  The basic steel industry is by far the biggest single user of energy in the United States, according to statistics released today by the Cost of Living Council.

title: Bomb at Tavern Next Door Doesn't Halt London Show
description: LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) A bomb blasted the outside of a tavern in central London tonight but failed to halt the performance of a variety show in the theater next door.

title: McLaren Affidavit Says Mitchell Rejected Recommendation for Criminal Action Against Milk Cooperative
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 The Justice Department disclosed today that John N. Mitchell, when he was Attorney General, rejected two recommendations by his department's Antitrust Division to begin criminal proceedings against a milk marketing cooperative that had been a big contributor to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: MRS. NORTON
description: MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 26Mrs. Helen Lambert Norton, a former member of the Connecicut Historical Commission who was a Republican member of the. Connecticut General Assembly from 1953 to 1957, died Sunday in a convalesent home here. The widow of Huntington Norton, a retired stockbroker, she was 82 years old and lived at 92 Old Field Lane.

title: Boyle Resting Comfortably
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 26 (UPI)  W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, rested comfortably but did not see any viistors over Christmas, a spokesman at the Medical Center for Federal Prisoners said today.

title: WATERHEATER FIRE KILLS 3 IN A FAMILY
description: TIVOLI, N.Y., Dec, 26 (UPI) A mother and her two children died early today in a fire traced to a faulty kitchen water heater in their twostory home here, about 90 miles north of New York City.

title: STEEL OUTPUT DOWN 2.6% FROM YEAR AGO
description: Steel production for the week ended Dec. 22 fell 2.6 per cent from the yearearlier period to 2.85 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: HEAVY RAINS CAUSE FLOODING IN SOUTH
description: Torrential rains, with up to 11 inches in 48 hours, caused footanhour rises in some Southern rivers yesterday and the Tennessee Valley Authority prepared for a major flood control effort.

title: Driver in Fatal Bus Crash Loses Appeal for License
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Dec. 26State Supreme Court Justice Morton Silberman today denied an appeal to reinstate the driving license of Joseph Larkin of Stony Brook, L. I., who was driving a school bus on March 24, 1972, when the vehicle was struck at a grade crossing by a Penn Central freight train.

title: Burglar Steals Puppy, With Thanks and Warning
description: RANCHO CALIFORNIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP)A burglar has written to a couple to explain that he stole a basset puppy from their home to provide his children with a Christmas present. He thanked them.

title: Chess: Some People Aren't Content Unless They Get Everything
description: While you're at it, why not take all the marbles?

title: Players' Pep Talk Woke Up Raiders
description: OAKLAND, Cailf., Dec. 26  The Oakland Raiders, whose approach to football may be called elemental, are riding a hot streak of togetherness as they prepare for the Miami Dolphins in Sunday's game for the American Football Conference championship.

title: State Museum Unveils a Wildlife Hall
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26A new exhibition hall  featuring eight lifesize dioramas of major North American mammals from the largest naturalhistory gift ever presented to the 137yearold New Jersey State Museum  has been opened to the public.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Distillers Company, Ltd., described as the world's largest producer and exporter of scotch whiskey, was sued yesterday for allegedly monopolizing the world trade scotch. The suit seeking at least $48million in damages was filed in Federal court here by the Fleischman Distilling Company and the Julius Wile Sons & Co., both of New York and subsidiaries of Standard Brands, Inc.

title: Seoul Warns Critics Not to Go Too Far
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 26Premier Kim Jong Pil declared tonight that his Government would not tolerate any movement for amendment of the nation's restrictive Constitution or for liberal democracy.

title: Saints' Six Owes $10,000 in Back Rent
description: ST. PAUL, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Minnesota Fighting 1 Saints of the World Hockey Association have been given an extension to Jan. 15 to pay more than $10,000 in overdue rental fees to the St. Paul Civic Center Authority.

title: Nixon Flies to Coast on Commercial Airliner
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 President Nixon and a party of 12 and Secret Service agents slipped away from the White House this evening and took a commercial airline flight to Los Angeles to spend a postChristmas holiday at his San Clemente home.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (UPI)Black players for Notre Dame and Alabama turned their hacks today on talk they should boycott the New Year's Eve Sugar Bowl football game to support grievances of New Orleans blacks who accuse the howl's sponsors of racism. My first obligation is to my team, said Eric Penick, Notre Dame running back. Alabama players declined to be quoted by name.

title: A NIXON TEST SEEN IN ELECTION FEB. 5
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 26 A special Congressional election that political observers believe will be a test for the Nixon Administration and portent of other election results in 1974 will be held Feb. 5 in Pennsylvania's 12th Con, gressional District.

title: JOBS IN STATE DOWN BY 5,000 IN A MONTH
description: Employment in New York State in November totaled 7,870,000 down 5,000 from the month before, Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine reported yesterday. The November total was 15,000 above the employment figure for November, 1972.

title: AIRLINE PACT UPSET BY APPEALS COURT
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit voided today a negotiated settlement between two airlines and their cabin attendants that would have permitted a return to work by 600 stewardesses who lost their jobs when they became pregnant.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: PRESIDENT BACKS FLEXIBILITY IN USE OF TRANSIT FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 President Nixon told Governor Wilson and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller today that he favored the flexible use of Federal funds for mass transit and that he would allow the use of these funds for operating subsidies.

title: The Next Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON  As the sound of the fakir's flute hypnotizes the deadly cobra, the gabble of speculation about the next President holds Washingtonians spellbound.

title: First National Control Of Advanced Is Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)The Federal Reserve Board denied today an application by the First National City Corporation, the nation's second largest banking organization, to retain control of the Advanced Mortgage Corporation of Southfield, Mich.

title: Japanese to Continue Talks With Hanoi on Oil Search
description: TOKYO. Dec. 26 (Reuters)Japan's Toyo Petroleum Development Company said today that it would soon a negotiating team to Hanoi for further discussions with the North Vietnamese Government on oil exploration in the Gulf of Tonkin.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 26The Carolina Cougars convinced the New York Nets tonight that they were not going to fold despite the loss of Billy Cunningham because of kidney surgery.

title: JACKSON OPPOSES. DELAY IN FUEL ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 Senator Henry M. Jackson, the leading Democratic energy spokesman on Capitol Hill, rebuffed today a request by the Nixon Administration for permission to delay the start of fuel allocation programs required by law.

title: Giant Stores Stockholders Told Assets Are Unavailable
description: Giant Stores Corporation of Chelmsford, Mass., in a letter to stockholders said that it expected to be declared bankrupt and that there would be no assets available for stockholders. The company said it owed about $46.5million to unsecured creditors while proceeds available for distribution would total about $4million.

title: Leads Are Few as Police Seek Lopatcong Slayers
description: LOPATCONG TOWNSHIP, Dec. 26  Five months have passed since the slaying of Mrs. Elizabeth Ann O'Connor, but the police have come up with few new leads in their search for he murderer of the 38yearold woman.

title: BLUE SHIELD CITED BY STATE FOR LAG IN PAYING CLAM
description: The State Insurance Depart ment said yesterday that it was considering removing from of fice the directors of Blue Shield of Greater New York for what it called failure to make prompt, fair and equitable settlements of claims in which the health insurer's liability was clear.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four police officers who were arresting a suspect in a shooting on West 78th Street in Manhattan were injured by a young group of men from the neighborhood.

title: How Long for Nixon?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26In midAugust It was my belief that what we are witnessing in the Watergate drama is the slow, agonizing fall from power of an Administration. ... Mr. Nixon's resignation may not be inevitable but it is inherently logical and grows slightly more probable with each passing week.

title: Israeli and Egyptian Teams Begin Geneva Troop Talks
description: GENEVA, Dec. 26  A fresh attempt to break the deadlock between Israel and Egypt over the separation of their forces on the Suez Canal front was begun here today under the auspices of the Middle East peace conference.

title: Rich Whites and Poor Blacks Vie Over Carolina Plant
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Dec. 26This 15milelong Atlantic island, streaked with sandy beaches and ...studded with semitropical palmettos, is the plush retirement and vacation playground of some of America's most suecessful board chairmen.

title: CITY STILL SEEKS A HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: After more than seven months of public hearings and private meetings, a special committee charged with recommending a new president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation reports it has narrowed the field to 15 candidates.

title: Harold Hotelling, a Developer Of Biometrics, Is Dead at 78
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Dec; 26  Dr. Harold Hotelling, a mathematical statistician and economist who retired from the University of North Carolina faculty in 1966, died today at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: WILBUR J. M'GOWAN
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 26 (UPI) Wilbur J. McGowan, a former mayor of West New York who was active in Hudson County politics for 45 years, died Tuesday. He was 85 years old.

title: Gabriel Voisin, an Air Pioneer, Who Flew Glider in 1904, Dies
description: PARIS, Dec. 26  Gabriel Voisin, who in 1904 made one of man's first flights in a heavierthanalr machine, died yesterday in his home in Ozenay in central France. He was 93 years old.

title: New Premier Is Appointed in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 26 (UPI)President Lon Nol, in a longexpected move, named Foreign Minister Long Boret Premier of Cambodia today.

title: Casino by the Sea
description: Atlantic City is filled with hope that gambling casinos will soon succeed in restoring its faded glamor where Miss America and Monopoly failed. It is almost taken for granted that 1974 will see New Jersey joining Nevada in legalizing this segment of the gambling industry; Governorelect Byrne has promised to propose the necessary legislationgiving each community the right of local optionand sentiment in the Jersey Legislature appears overwhelmingly favorable.

title: Casino Business Vexing To ExNevada Governor
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 26 (UPI)  Paul Laxalt left the Nevada governorship three years ago, hoping to find his pot of gold in the glittering world of gambling.

title: French in Poll Unimpressed By British Entry in Market
description: PARIS, Dec. 27 (Reuters)Frenchmen regard Britain's entry into the Common Market as one of the least important of seven major events during 1973, according to an opinion poll published here today.

title: LEGAL
description: POSTPONEMENT NOTICE INVITATION TO CONTRACTORS NEW YORK CITY TRANSIT AUTHORITY Contract P217

title: Oil Is Stockpiled by Some Corporations
description: Some corporations have moved swiftly in recent months to stockpile millions of gallons of fuel oil, even as the Nixon Administration has urged homeowners to turn down their thermostats and drivers to reduce their use of automobiles.

title: NORTON SIMON STOCK IS SOLD BY CHAIRMAN
description: David J. Mahoney, chairman, president and director of Norton Simon, Inc., sold 175,000 shares of common stock in the company in late November and another 20,363 shares this month. The principal part of his personal assets continue to be direct ownership of 78,000 Series A preferred shares, which are convertible into 159,900 common shares, it was reported yesterday.

title: Quadruplets Are Stable
description: ARTESIA, N.M., Dec. 26 (AP) Quadruplets who were born here on Christmas Eve were listed as in stable condition today in the nursery of Roswell's Eastern New Mexico Medical Center. Their mother, Mrs. Florencio Segura, 25 years old, remained in the Artesia hospital, where the four boys were born eight weeks prematurely.

title: LINER ELIZABETH MAY BE SCRAPPED
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 26 (Reuters)The owners of the Queen Elizabeth, once the pride of the British commercial fleet, will soon start operations that may turn the liner into scrap almost two years after a fire sank her here.

title: PARIS ARRESTS 13 IN TERRORIST PLOT
description: PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP)  The police today announced the arrest of 13 supporters of Palestine and Turkish guerrilla movements who were said to be preparing for terrorist attacks in Europe before the end of the year.

title: Estonian Capital utters A Tangy Flavor of West
description: TALLINN, U.S.S.R., Dec. 16On a Saturday night here in the capital of Estonia the in place these days is the tall, new Finnishbuilt Hotel Viru, where not only is the decor Western chic but a bearded, goateed, swinging combo mixes hoppedup renditions of Take the A Train or Mac the Knife, with Eastern European rock and Soviet pop tunes.

title: RODRIGUEZ NAMED TO INQUIRY AGENCY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26 (AP)Governor Cahill today announced the appointment of Joseph H. Rodriguez, chairman of the State Board of Higher Education, as chairman of the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Japan Is Said to Cut Aid For South Korea by Half
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26  Knowledgeable officials said today that Japan had agreed to provide South Korea next year with $90million in aid, a figure only about half as large as this year's.

title: Books of The Times
description: COLETTE: The Difficulty of Loving. By Margaret Crosland. With an introduction by Janet Flanner. 284 pages. BobbsMerrill. $8.95.Margaret Crosland has done something quite extraordinary in this book: She has very nearly succeeded in making Colette boring. In fact, I'm not sure that she hasn't. Already, in Janet Flanner's introduction, I sensed her unease or ambivalence about the book. Miss Flanner, who writes from Paris for The New Yorker under the pen name of Genet, is a brilliant stylist, yet we find her, as if by contagion, struggling through sentences like this one in speaking of Colette: Her imagination was used in the creation of her style of writing what she wrote, which was her fortunate limitation and the definition of what eventually became her recognized and singular authentic literary genius.

title: 4 Cases on Prison Reform Returned to Lower Courts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the. Fifth Circuit said today that it was reluctantly sending four cases involying possible prison reforms back to lower courts.

title: End Depletion Allowance, Atlantic Richfield Urges
description: The Atlantic Richfield Comparty, the nation's ninth largest oil company, said yesterday that it now advocated repeal of the depletion allowance for oil operators.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices declined yesterday in quiet trading in the corporate and taxexempt markets.

title: Airedales Find a Home In This Garden of Eden
description: There's nothing closer to the Garden of Eden than a yardful of Airedales, said Mrs. Betty Hoisington of Cordova, Tenn., so we named our kennel Eden. Since the garden had to have flowers, we name our dogs accordingly. Like so many others, Mrs. Hoisington and her husband, Bob, started in obedience. They still are active in that category. Bob has been in obedience for 18 years, Betty for six and both have instructed.

title: DR. JULES SELDIN, TAUGHT DENTISTRY
description: Dr. Jules B. Seldin, who had been a dentist in this city for 53 years and a teacher, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 75 years old and lived at 215 East 79th Street. He conducted his practice at 240 Central Park South.

title: Arthur Daley
description: This is the time of year when about 400 members the Baseball Writers' Association are jostled out of hibernation and asked to vote on the latest batch of candidates for the Hall of Fame. The jostling is done by Jack Lang, dean of the electoral college and guardian of the portals at the Cooperstown shrine. Each ballot contains places for 10 nominations and a name has to appear on threequarters of the voting slips for a man to gain election. Does it sound simple and easy? It isn't.

title: City Blacks Begin Fete Of Kwanza
description: The first day of Kwanza, or the festival of first fruit, was, celebrated by groups of blacks around the city yesterday as the beginning of a weeklong rededication to our community and our way of life.

title: Nude Pictures Prohibited
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (UPI) The County Board of Supervisors approved today an ordinance generally outlawing the display of publications with nude pictures on sidewalk newsstands. The ordinance, effective Jan. 26, prohibits the placing in sidewalk news racks of publications that display pictures of nude persons or similar offensive pictures, unless the photographs are related to a current news event.

title: Neighbor Is Shot to Death In Quarrel on Loud Stereo
description: LYNN, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP)One man was shot to death and another wounded yesterday during a quarrel over a loud stereo system, the police said.

title: Kunzman Improved
description: UPLAND, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI)Lee Kunzman, a race driver, was reported in fair condition today at San Antonio Community Hospital, where he is recovering from injuries suffered in an accident Dec. 11 at the Ontario Motor Speedway. The United States Auto Club driver from Guttenburg, Iowa, was hurt in a 190mileperhour crash during tire testing in an Eagle Offy.

title: Seoul Reports Easing Of Arabs' Curbs on Oil
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 26  The South Korean Foreign Ministry announced today that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait had agreed to greatly ease restrictions on their crude oil supply to South Korea; treating it as friendly country.

title: Congress Aides See Slowdown Causing $20Billion Budget Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 Congressional staff experts estimated today that the probable slowdown in the economy next year would mean a Federal Budget deficit in the neighborhood of $20billion.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Arab Oil Ministers Due to Reconvene In February to Reconsider Ban on U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26The meeting at which the Arab oil producers are to reconsider their oil embargo against the United States and the Netherlands has been set for February, according to Arab diplomatic sources here.

title: EQUALIZATION TAX REDUCED BY U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26Three Government agencies announced today important relaxations in the program of controls over lending and investing by Americans abroad.

title: Fire Kills Three Sisters
description: FOREST, Ind., Dec. 26 (AP) Three young sisters burned to death today when fire swept their twostory home. The state police said Tamera L. Parker, 14 years old, and her sisters Kerri L., 12, and Hope E., 10, were trapped in an upstairs bedroom when the fire started.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The brother of an East Orange City Councilman won new trial yesterday on charges of assaulting a police officer. The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that comments during the trial by James E. Fagen Jr., assistant Essex County prosecutor, were so prejudicial that it reversed the conviction and ordered a new trial, the third on the charge, for Steven Thomas, brother of Councilman William Thomas.

title: Penn State Rally Tops Fordham Five, 73 to 67
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP)Ron Brown scored 4 of his 13 points in overtime as Penn State rallied for a 7367 victory over Fordham tonight in the opener of the 13th annual Quaker City basketball tournament.

title: Notes on People
description: Premier Golda Meir of Israel has been named the most admired woman of 1973 in the annual poll taken by the Gallup organization. She won more than twice as many votes as the woman with the next highest total, Mrs. Pat Nixon, who headed the list of the 10 most admired women last year.

title: SOYUZ 13 RETURNS TO EARTH SAFELY
