description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26  Th Soviet Union today brought its Soyuz 13 manned spacecraft back from an eightday, 128orbit mission that overcame a snowstorm and high winds in landing to demonstrate its technical readiness for a joint space flight with the Americans.

title: Off Broadway Faces Strike Threat by Actors Equity
description: Off Broadway theaters are facing a strike of actors and stage managers next week unless a contract dispute is resolved between Actors Equity Association and the League of Off Broadway Theater and Producers.

title: ADVANCES SCORED BY AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market bounded ahead yesterday. Analysts attribute?? the rise to the easing by the Arabs of the oil curbs for Europe and Japan, believing that the move would have a beneficial effect around the world.

title: Books of The Times
description: COLETTE: The Difficulty of Loving. By Margaret Crosland. With an introduction by Janet Ftanner. 284 pages. BobbsMerrill. $8.95.

title: TISHMAN NET UP BY 7.4% IN. YEAR
description: The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., a leading builder of office buildings, showed a 7.4 per cent increase in net income to $6.5million, or $1.06 a share, for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

title: Trotters Get 10,568 Believers
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 26 Fetlock deep in trouble, Roosevelt Raceway opened its long winter meeting tonight with the dubious consoIation of knowing that things can't get much worse.

title: Hogan Quits After Serving For 32 Years as Prosecutor
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan submitted his resignation to the Governor yesterday, ending a career of almost 32 years as the Manhattan prosecutor.

title: Dec. 26: When the Gifts Return
description: Some of the presents got are too conservative for me, so I'm exchanging them, said Robert Fosdal of Brooklyn.

title: ALGERIA OFFERS PLAN TO MANAGE OIL FUNDS
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 26 (AP)Algeria has submitted to its Arab League partners plans for an association of Arab stateoperated and private banks that would help manage the rapidly rising earnings from Arab oil resources.

title: Subliminal Ad Pops Up in National TV Promotion
description: Subliminal television advertising, a prominent issue in the late nineteenfifties, appeared anew this Christmas season in a 60second product commercial that at four intervals flashed a barely visible printed message, Get It.

title: I.R.S., in Shift, to Monitor Holiday Gasoline Prices.
description: Following reports of gasoline price gouging over the Christmas weekend, officials of the regional office of the Internal Revenue Service, whose agents had taken the holiday off, said yesterday that the office was changing its procedure and that the agents would be on duty over the New Year weekend to prevent price violations.

title: Harness Dates
description: MONTICELLO RACEWAY

title: The Stage
description: One of the prime virtues of a repertory company is that actors are able to play a variety of characters. This stretches talent but it can also overextend it. As the City Center Acting Company enters its third stage (from Juilliard to Off Broadway to the current season on Broadway), it is clear that even with such a young, growing company, all actors are not equal.

title: BLUE SHIELD CITED BY STATE FOR LAG IN PAYING CLAIMS
description: The State Insurance Department said yesterday that it was considering removing from office the directors of Blue Shield of Greater New York for what it called failure to make prompt, fair and equitable settlements of claims in which the health insurer's liability was clear.

title: P.S.C. URGED TO BAR CON ED RISE ON GAS
description: An examiner for the State Public Service Commission recommended yesterday that the panel deny a request by the Consolidated Edison Company for a temporary increase of $13,788,800 a year in gas rates.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Film: 'Keep On Rockin':The Cast
description: Surely, nostalgia is fattening. Mooning over what's bygone hardly stimulates the mental musclesinstead, it tends to stiffen the perceptions, to swell the spiritual flab. But time-traveling is very good exercise. When you're required to weave back and forth between the past and present, to study what has and hasn't changed, the consciousness can be limbered, clarified. D. A. Pennebaker's "Keep On Rockin' " affords us some excellent time-traveling, since it recreates the September, 1969, Toronto Rock and Roll Revival. At that festival, the music of the mid-nineteen-fifties captivated an Aquarian audiencejust midway in time between Woodstock and Altamont.This fine documentarythe first of the First Avenue Screening Room's program of pictures that haven't received adequate attentionwill appear tomorrow and Saturday. The movie is prefaced by some footage of Janis Joplin and Jimi Hendrix: two ghostly guides to the musical past that preceded them. Then we're pitched into 1955 and 1956, with the swamp rhythms of Bo Diddley and the rockabilly of Jerrry Lee Lewis, who tells his fans, "Ah love yew like a hawg loves slop." We're back in an era when the guitar was handled tenderly, rather than set afire, and it's a shock to see a short-haired violinist in a tie.Chuck Berry's mournful, worn face splits with smiles as he lets loose with "Sweet Little Sixteen." Lights spring off Little Richard's mirrored tunic as he crows, screams and unleashes some falsetto whoops before he zeros in on "Tutti Frutti." His body glistens with sweat as he strips and hurls his garments to the crowd, holding up each garment like a teasing auctioneer.Rock songs in praise of rock, lines about having fun tonight: The fact and the act of rockin 'n' rollin' emerge as the prime theme of these lyrics. To an ear that was later formed by Bob Dylan, the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, most of the music is far too repetitive to be exciting. But it's a pleasure to watch these seasoned professionals, whose energy equals their experience. Their songs show that they came from a time when people wanted extremely simple things. This is solid, reliable stuffit seems unlikely that listeners could use it to summon any kind of high. Hence, it's intriguing that the very young (also very white) audience of 1969 was delighted by this blast from the past.Mr. Pennebaker's film is an anthology of smiles: again and again, the camera closes in on beaming faces. (Sometimes, he begins with a dancing torso, or a pair of thighs and kneeswe meet the head a few moments later.) We can't really tell if the film maker looked for innocence and stressed it, or if that was the over-all character of the crowd. But no one on screen looks druggy, most of the skin is fresh and clear, and there's even a flash of shaved armpits. Did the music of the fifties attract a rather sheltered audience in the late sixties? Or was this an early sign that some were eagerly retreating from the turbulence of that period?Mr. Pennebaker, whose movies include "Monterey Pop" (1968) and "Don't Look Back" (Bob Dylan in 1965), both produced with Richard Leacock, is a specialist in observing changes. So we trust his instinct and his eye. And this film shows a sensitivity to individuals that some rock moviessuch as "Woodstock"lacked. Just when the press was awash with theories about death trips and the counter culture, Mr. Pennebaker witnessed something entirely different. And his work does tend toward prescienceto record what will be important before most of the public is aware of it.

title: Broadway Gives Regards to Lindsay
description: Broadway said goodby last night to Mayor Lindsay with a surprise party and impromptu show that was calculated to tell him that he had been an eightyear smash hit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am certain that there are many citizens of this state who will not agree with the thinly disguised tone of both the lead article on the front page and the editorial that due to the Governor's resignation the G.O.P. is hurt and that Governor Wilson will be less capable. I am referring to the Dec. 12 issue.

title: Mr. District Attorney Retires, but Legend Lives On
description: Mayors came and went and so did Police Commissioners and Congressmen, but always, year after year, decade after decade, Frank S. Hogan stayed. There was no such office any more as the Manhattan District Attorney; it was simply Hogan.

title: Local Trainer Wins His First at Big A
description: Joe Di Angelo had the thrill of his career yesterday. The 29yearold native of Astoria, Queens, saddled Sharp Gary for Edward Scharps and the 2yearold gelding won the six furlong test by four lengths, at $19.60 for $2. His victims included the odds  on Unanimous Verdict.

title: Illinois Central Spending Up
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (UPI) Illinois Central Industries, Inc., said today it would have record capital outlays of $152million in 1974, up 32 per cent from this year's expenditures.

title: Prisoners Get Furloughs As ExInmates Fill Jobs
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 26 (AP)Fifteen former inmates of the Milwaukee County House of Correction worked in place of current prisoners there so some could spend the holiday with their families.

title: Dr. Matthew Given A 3Year Sentence
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the neurosurgeon who won powerful support at the White House for his advocacy of black capitalism, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for having misapplied Medicaid funds.

title: Airco Cheers Success Of British Oxygen Offer
description: George S. Dillon, the chairman of Airco, Inc., said here yesterday he was glad that the British Oxygen Company had succeeded in its tender offer for 4 million shares of Airco at $20 a share.

title: Model Prosecutor
description: The standards of integrity and effectiveness that marked Frank S. Hogan's three decades as Manhattan District Attorney have been an inspiration to all who recognize responsible lawenforcement as the foundation stone of a sound society. His concept of justice blended awareness of the need for community protection with zeal in defense of individual rights.

title: Ethics Board Meets To Question Terry On Letter to Clients
description: The city's Board of Ethics, in an emergency session unparalleled in its 13 years, questioned one of Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's key appointees yesterday on whether he tried to use his prestige in the upcoming Beame administration to improve his insurance business.

title: Compensation Is Set For Wrong Listings In Telephone Book
description: The Public Service Commission ordered yesterday that telephone companies in the state compensate customers who are listed incorrectly in the white pages of directories, starting next March.

title: Hughes and 4 Associates Indicted in Air West Case
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 27 Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, two of his top aides and two other associates were named today in a ninecount criminal indictment by a Federal grand jury here.

title: Sperm Screening in Lab May Help Produce Boys
description: A technique of screening human semen has been developed that, the experimenters believe, can increase sharply the likelihood that a couple desiring to produce a boy rather than a girl can do so.

title: Money Factor in Secretariat Tests
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 27 (UPI)Mrs. Helen (Penny) Tweedy, owner of Secretariat, 1973's Triple Crown winner and Riva Ridge, a former Kentucky Derby winner, said today the only reason the two horses had not completely passed their fertility tests was because of the large sums of insurance money resting on the outcome. Secretariat, the first horse in 25 years to win the Triple Crown, is insured for $6,080,000 and Riva Ridge, his stablemate, is covered for $5.6million.

title: Nancy Browning Married in South
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 27Miss Nancy Browning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Prentice Browning of Holmes Beach, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Walter E. Afield, professor and chairman of the department of psychiatry at the University of South Florida College of Medicine here. He is the son of Mrs. M. E. Afield of St. Petersburg and the late Mr. Afield.

title: The Pop Life
description: Oldies but goldies should have been coined to describe The Dixie Hummingbirds.

title: ExConvict Freed In Slaying Is Held As Parole Violator
description: A 40yearold exconvict who had been charged with heating a man to death and was released on his own recognizance last weekend by Criminal Court Judge Bruce M. Wright, was being held yesterday in the Dutchess County Jail as a parole violator.

title: Temple Tops Harvard; St. Bonaventure Loses
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP)  Jerry Baskerville's scoring and rebounding sparked Temple to a 6159 victory over Harvard tonight in a firstround gaine of the Quaker City basketball tournament.

title: 400,000 Being Laid Off, British Estimate
description: LONDON, Dec, 27  The Government estimated today that 400,000 workers were being laid off because of the fuel shortage, nearly doubling the national unemployment total.

title: James Earl Ray to Move to U.S. Prison
description: James Earl Ray, convicted of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is being transferred from a state to a Federal prison for security reasons, the Justice Department said in Washington yesterday.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Comet Viewers Warned Of Possible Eye Injury
description: As Comet Kohoutek loops the sun today and begins its return journey out of the inner solar system, it may be dimly visible in daylight. However, New Yorkers were warned yesterday by the City Health Commissioner, Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, against trying to view it, assuming the sky is clear.

title: Egyptian Minister Leaves Geneva as Talks Continue
description: GENEVA, Dec. 27Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt left here today, the last of the foreign ministers to leave after opening the Middle East peace conference last week.

title: Patrolman Slain in Denver
description: DENVER, Dec. 27 (AP)State Patrolman Thomas R. Carpenter, 31 years old, was shot and killed today while issuing a traffic citation to motorist. The shooting occurred behind an apartment. Officials searched for two suspects.

title: OCCIDENTAL FRAUD ALLEGED BY S. E. C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and its chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, with defrauding the public in connection with the sale of securities. The company and Dr. Hammer quickly agreed to a consent decree in the S.E.C. complaint, which was filed in United States District Court here.

title: Time to Try Out Those Christmas Gifts
description: Where are the sleds of yesteryear? Parents, with fond memories of zooming down frosty hills on their Flexible Flyers, found themselves rethinking their children's Christmas lists this year. With New York virtually snowless in recent winters, sleds got crossed off to be replaced with plastic scooters and educational games and even golf clubs.

title: SIMON ANNOUNCES STANDBY SYSTEM ON GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27William E. Simon, the Federal energy director, announced today the establishment of a standby gasolinerationing system but said he was personally optimistic that rationing could be avoided if the American public continues to cooperate.

title: LEFKOWITZ BACKS WILSON ON FILING
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that there was nothing in the law that required Governor Wilson to have filed statements of his financial holdings during his 15 yeats as Lieutenant Governor.

title: Canada May Raise Export Tax On Oil to $6.50 a Barrel Feb. 1
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 27 (Reuters) The export tax on Canadian (crude oil will rise to about $6.50 a barrel Feb. 1 unless some other arrangement is made at the Federalprovincial premiers' conference in late January, Energy Minister Donald Macdonald said today.

title: House Panel Urges Stricter Air Rules For Shipping Pets
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) A Congressional subcommittee has recommended joint action by the Civil Aeronautics Board, the Federal Aviation Administration and the Agriculture Department to monitor conditions under which animals are sent to pet markets by air.

title: Children's Gifts to the Neediest Indicate Size Isn't Everything
description: The size of a donation sometimes does not reflect the thought and effort behind a gift.

title: Pregnant Whale's Fetal Heartbeats Elude Detection
description: A sonartype device was used in the New York Aquarium yesterday in an unsuccessful effort to pick up fetal heartbeats from a pregnant white whale.in the outdoor pool at the aquarium was lowered to three feet, the 14footlong whale was guided onto a canvas stretcher and the listening probe was placed at various places along the whale's belly.

title: JERSEY BELL RISE IN RATES OPPOSED
description: NEWARK, Dec. 27Rate at torneys representing the public interest said today that they would ask the courts to enjoir the implementation of a Public Utilities Commission order per mitting the New Jersey Bell Telephone to pass part of its increased operating costs on to customers without the need to go through formal rate hearings.

title: Tarkenton Is Unfazed by Cowboys' Artificial Turf
description: In Tulsa, Okla., yesterday, where the Minnesota Vikings are practicing on the Tartan turf of Skelly Stadium, Fran Tarkenton was asked if the Vikings would be handicapped, on Sunday in the National Conference championship game at Dallas because the Cowboys were so much more accustomed to artificial turf.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In a move called unusual by many officials, the City Couneil of Long Beach, L. I., prohibited persons requiring continuous psychiatric, medical or nursing care from living in the many old hotels of this seaside resort.

title: Temperature, Over 60, Attracts Throngs to City
description: After 10 days of alternating snow, sleet and fog, activity In the city swelled like the season's first crocus yesterday as the temperature rose to 61 degrees, two degrees short of the record for the day, set in 1936. The high was recorded at 1 P.M.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 27 (UPI)Iraq's revenue from oil after the latest rise in the price of Persian Gulf oil will be $8.337billion a year, the Iraqi newspaper A1 Taakhi said today. Iraq has refused to join other Arab oil countries cutting production as pressure on the West.

title: 17 Hurt in Bus Crash
description: JORDAN VALLEY, Ore., Dec. 27 (UPI)  Seventeen persons were injured today when a bus went out of control on a snowcovered highway and crashed into roadside rocks. The bus was on the way to Winnemucca, Nev.

title: HERBERT TINGSTEN OF SWEDISH PAPER
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 27Herbert Tingsten, one of Sweden's leading postwar newspaper editors, died yesterday at the age of 77.

title: Intercity Trains Ordered To Improve Their Quality
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27In its first decision regulating the quality of rail travel, the Interstate Commerce Commission issued today detailed rules requiring nationwide reservation service 24 hours a day and free meals and hotel rooms for passengers missing connections because of late trains.

title: BLUE SHIELD SAYS IT HAS PROBLEMS
description: A spokesman for Blue Shield conceded yesterday that there was some validity to charges by the State Insurance Department that Blue Shield had failed to make prompt and fair settlements of claims in which its liability was clear.

title: MILK CO IN U.S TRUST CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today against MidAmerica Dairymen, Inc., one of three big middle Western milk marketing cooperatives that made heavy contributions to President Nixons reelection campaign.

title: KISSINGER ASSERTS U.S.SOVIET GAINS HINGE ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that improved American relations with the Soviet Union were possible only so long as Moscow maintained a responsible course in the Middle East.

title: EUGENE M'NEELY OF A.T.E. IS DEAD
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 27Eugene J. McNeely, who served as president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from Aug. 16, 1961, until he retired on Dec. 31, 1964, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: GAINS IN 1974 SEEN FOR RCA AND XEROX
description: The chief executives of two of the nation's leading companies, the RCA Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, in yearend statements yesterday acknowledged problems but expressed confidence in both their companies and the nation's economic performance for 1974.

title: 2d Jury Here Begins Weighing Chesimard BankRobbery Case
description: For the second time this month the bankrobbery case against Joanne Chesimard and Fred Hilton has gone to Federal jury.

title: U.S. Advantage in Oil Helps Lift Dollar
description: PARIS, Dec. 27The stronger position of the United States, relative to other industrial countries, in the wake of recent sharp increases in the price of crude oil, was translated today into sharply higher values for the dollar against leading currencies.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Tough Transit Options
description: President Nixon's declaration that he now favors use of Federal funds to subsidize mass transit operations offers some hope that Washington may yet offer help to City Hall and Albany to save New York's 35cent fare. However, the Administration's change of heart on operating subsidies falls far short of providing an adequate answer to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $300million deficit problem.

title: Intercity Trains Ordered To Improve Their Quality
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 27In its first decision regulating the quality of rail travel, the Interstate Commerce Commission issued today detailed rules requiring nationwide reservation service 24 hours a day and free meals and hotel rooms for passengers missing connections because of late trains.

title: NIXON FEELS TRIP SCORED POINTS
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Dec. 27President Nixon began a postChristmas vacation at his San Clemente estate today convinced, as one aide said, that his trip across the country by commercial jet had scored points with the public.

title: Red Smith
description: San Diego prides itself on the healthiest and most agreeable climate in America, yet the city's baseball team has been last in the National League West every year its existence, and in 1973 finished a tidy 39 games off the pace. Summers can be unbearable in Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, and life wasn't all one sweet song for the Seattle Pilots during their season in the majors, yet if the Padres move to either town the chances are they'll get better. In the District of Columbia and the State of Washington Oriental specialists are permitted to practice the ancient art of acupuncture. And anybody who doesn't believe that four or five needles in the knees and elbows can do more for the batting average than the same number hennies, or pep pills, ought to talk to Clete Boyer or study the record of Taiwan's Little Leaguers.

title: STATE REVERSING DIRTY FUEL STAND
description: New York State's new commissioner of Environmental Conservation charged yesterday that the energy crisis had been overblown and exaggerated, and said he saw no need to extend the emergency variance granted Consolidated Edison to burn dirtier fuel oil and coal.

title: 2d National Black Convention Set for March 15 in Little Rock
description: The second National Black Political Convention will be held in Little Rock, Ark., beginning next March 15, according to Imamu Amiri Baraka, one of the leaders of the convention's assembly. The first, in 1972, drew 8,000 blacks to Gary, Ind.

title: Wide Effort Begins to Clear Oil Spill in Delaware River
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) Salvage crews, environmentalists and the Coast Guard joined today in efforts to clean up a major oil spill in the Delalware River between Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

title: Estonians Retain Identity but Mix More With Russians
description: TALLINN, U.S.S.R.I don't know the statistics, but from the young people I know it seems that more marriages are taking place between Russians and Estonians, said a young Russian teacher and housewife. But they do not always end happily. There are many divorces, because the people are used to living by two different traditions.

title: MORE WOMEN HEAD POOR BLACK HOMES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27Sixtyfour per cent of all poor black families were headed by a female in 1972, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1973

title: Dr. DauLin Hsu, 67, Aide To Chiang, Taught in U.S.
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 27 (AP)Dr. DauLin Hsu, former personal secretary to Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek and professor of Asian languages and literature at the University of Washington, died Monday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: Boston U. Wins on Ice
description: TROY, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP)Bill Buckton scored two goals and Ed Walsh, the goalie, mane 29 saves to lead Boston University to a 31 hockey victory over Dartmouth tonight. It was the first game in the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute tournament.

title: Kings' Rally Beats Cays By 110100
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP) Hot shooting in the second half by Nate Williams and Jimmy Walker led the Kansas CityOmaha Kings to a 110100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: IRVING H. LAROM
description: CODY, Wyo., Dec. 27Irving H. (Larry) Larom, who from 1915 to 1969 ran Valley Ranch, a dude ranch near here, acting as host to many socially prominent New Yorkers, died Sunday at the age of 84.

title: Greece Devalues Drachma
description: ATHENS, Dec. 27 (AP)The Bank of Greece announced today a devaluation of the drachma. The new exchange rate set by the central bank put the dollar at 293 drachmas, devalued from 28 to the dollar and close to the 30drachma level it held two months before a 10 per cent upward revaluation of the Greek currency.

title: Auto Exports by Japan Up
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27 (AP)Japanese automobile exports in November totaled 179,721 units, up 5.2 per cent from October and up 12.7 per cent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: Miss Dietrich Sidelined
description: Marlene Dietrich, who injured her leg in a fall last month, briefly entered Santa Monica Hospital in California last Sunday for what, her agent here said was a skingraft operation on her left leg. The 69yearold actress postponed indefinitely a fourday appearance scheduled to open at Carnegie Hall next Thursday. A spokesman said ticket refunds would be available at places of purchase.

title: CommunistLed Insurgency in Villages of Northeast Thailand Spreading and Becoming More Violent
description: NA KLANG, Thailand, Dec. 20Neatly stacked on the red earth at the edge of a pagoda, funeral pyres crackled in the soft afternoon haze.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH F.A. CUP

title: Market Place: Change Studied S.I.P.C. Law
description: The liquidation of Weis Securities, Inc., this year has pointed up important deficiencies in the threeyearold law designed to protect investors in brokeragehouse failures.

title: Briton Joins Tennis Tour
description: LONDON, Dec. 27 (UPI)Buster Mottram of Britain signed today with World Championship Tennis to compete in a ninetournament circuit in the United States beginning in Philadelphia Jan. 21. The 18yearold Mattram has won $8,750 since leaving school in July.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW RISE AGAIN
description: Scoring their biggest advance in more than five months, prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second straight session. Prices in the overthecounter market also rose.

title: No Deal With Terror
description: The outrages committed by the five Arab terrorists who indiscriminately murdered 32 innocent persons at the Rome and Athens airports cannot properly be dealt with in any manner other than trial in a court of law.

title: FIGHTING IS HEAVY NEAR PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 27 (UPI)Heavy fighting was reported near Phnom Penh today as Cambodian Government troops pushed into an area used by the rebels to aim rockets at the capital.

title: Newcombe, Connors Triumph
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 (AP)  Topseeded John Newcombe of Australia and Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., secondseeded, led the advance today through the second round of the men's singles in the $74,500 Australian open tennis championships.

title: 8 CAMPAIGN GROUPS IN '72 FACE CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Eight local political committees, seven organized by supporters of Senator George McGovern and one by supporters of President Nixon, were cited today for failing to file 1972 campaign reports.

title: 3 Young Women Bow At Metropolitan Club
description: Three young women were presented at the ninth annual debutante ball of the Metropolitan Club last night.

title: Susan L. Stoddard Wed to S. A. Apter
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 27Miss Susan Lee Stoddard, and Steven Allan Apter were married here this afternoon in the Vassar College Alumnae House by Rabbi Jonathan J. Prinz.

title: BIRTH RECORD LINKED TO M'GOVERN BARRED
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Dec. 27 (UPI)  The Indiana Supreme Court blocked a newspaper today from obtaining a copy of as:birth record that might show whether Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, was listed as the father of an illegitimate child.

title: 80th Birthday of Mao Passes With No Fanfare, as Was Expected
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 27China's venerated leader, Mao Tsetung, turned 80 years age yesterday, but his birthday received little or no public attention in his own country. Since they came to power in 1949 the Communists have forbidden public celebrations of the birthdays of living public figures. But even if they did celebrate them, this might not have seemed a great milestone to the Chinese for by their reckoning Chairman Mao turned 80 nearly two years ago.

title: Elizabeth R. Elkinton Married To Charles Carrington Barr
description: HEWLETT, LI. Dec. 27Miss Elizabeth Robertson Elkinton, daughter of Mrs. Chalmers Handy of Lawrence and the late Herbert Roberts Elkinton of Far Hills, N.J., was married here this afternoon to Charles Carrington Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Barr 3d of Louisville.

title: Long Beach Hotels to Ban Former Mental Patients
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 27 In a move called highly unusual and blatantly discriminatory by critics, the outgoing City Council today banned persons requiring continuous psychiatric, medical or nursing care from residing in hotels and boarding houses here.

title: Yachts of the Wealthy Sit Out Fuel Crisis
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 21Like directors at a board meeting of a giant corporation, the great luxury boats of Florida's winter fleet sit rail to rail in the slips of marinas and yacht clubs in sunsplashed, protected bays.

title: Terry Dropped by Beame After Appointee Urges It
description: Seymour Terry, who was being investigated by the city's Board of Ethics over a possible conflict of interest, asked Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to drop him from a key job in the administration, and Mr. Beame instantly agreed.

title: 4 Seized Near Manhole in Alleged Plot To Free Black Army Friends in Tombs
description: Four alleged sympathizers of the Black Liberation Army were arrested at dawn yesterday in lower Manhattan in what the police said was part of a plan to free fellow members from Manhattan House of Detention for Men, known as the Tombs.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Exhibiting the awesome power of the pressthe fullcourt press and the zone press, respectively  LaSalle defeated Stanford, 77.66, and Manhattan romped over St. Louis, 8865, yesterday, in the opening round of the 22d annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pop Music: By Phil Ochs, Nostalgic Protest Songs
description: Phil Ochs appears singlehandedly to be trying to keep the protest song alive, if his Wednesday performance at Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South at 17th Street, is to be judged. And in doing so he seems to be turning it (particularly the latterday variety) into a nostalgia form. His protestations, performed with guitar, range wide: bombing in Vietnam, right back to the Wobbly days (industrial Workers of the World) and the union martyr Joe Hill. Mr. Ochs turns Jesus into a Marxist with a fervent reading of Ewan MacColl's Jesus Was a Working Man.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: New Jersey college basketball teams are involved tournaments from Trenton to Oklahoma.

title: TV: The Rockefellers, Fine 2Hour Documentary
description: The Rockefellers, a production of C.B.S. Reports, is a detailed examination of a single family's wealth, power and influence. The extent of all three areas is perhaps best reflected in the fact that the documentary is being given not one but two hours, from 9 to 11 this evening, on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Nixon Pleased by Trip
description: A White House aide says President Nixon is convinced that his trip to California by commerical airliner had scored points with the public on the issue of fuel conservation. But the Secret Service and the Federal Aviation Administration expressed concern about the trip. Page 12.

title: MILK COOP IS SUED IN U.S. TRUST CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today against MidAmerica Dairymen, Inc., one of three big Middle Western milk marketing cooperatives that made heavy contributions to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Terry Dropped by Beame After Appointee Urges It
description: Seymour Terry, who was being investigated by the city's Board of Ethics over a possible conflict of interest, asked Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to drop him from key job in the administration, and Mr. Beame instantly agreed.

title: Repairman Held in Death
description: RAHWAY, Dec. 27 (UPI)A 31  year  old equipment repairman is being held in $100,000 bail in connection with the death of a Boston woman whose charred body was found in his burnedout apartment. The man, Richard M. Harter, was ordered field in lieu of the bail at his arraingment in Superior Court yesterday one day after the body of Linda Cecil, 23, was discovered by firemen.

title: Missing Tiepolo Is Found
description: VENICE, Italy, Dec. 27 (AP) A missing altar painting by the 18thcentury Venetian master Giovanni Battista Tiepolo has been found in an abandoned farmhouse near Venice, the police said today. The painting, measuring about 7 by 4 feet, was stolen five days ago from a church in Mirano, about 30 miles from Venice.

title: MORTIMER BRANDENBURG
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Dec. 27Mortimer Brandenburg, president of the Distillers, Rectifying, Wine and Allied Workers Union of America since 1958, died today at his home here. His age was 63.

title: Tribal Clashes Kill 24 in South Africa Within Three Days
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)Twentyfour persons have been killed and 37 wounded in three days of tribal fighting in the eastern part of South Africa.

title: Stage: The Au Pair Man in Allegorical Guise
description: One hardly knows whether Hamlet would have minded, but with the second new work the New York Shakespeare Festival is presenting at its Vivian Beaumont Theater, the play is very definitely not the thing. The merits of the evening belong chiefly to the players, the lovely Julie Harris and the accomplished Charles Durning. Both are delightful.

title: Student Protest: Greek, Thai and Korean Tell How They Shook Governments
description: ATHENSWe started off protesting over academic issues  the Government interference, the abolition of draft deferment for student protesters, the rigging of studentunion elections all that. But we came to a point of realizing that all these things cannot be put straight, that we cannot have academic freedom and educational reforms, unless there is freedom in the broader context of democratic rule in Greece.

title: Nelson Award to Stoeckel
description: BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP)Jim Stoeckel, a Harvard quarterback, was named tonight as the winner of the Nils V. (Swede) Nelson Award for sportsmanship by the Gridiron Club of Greater Boston.

title: People in Sports: It's A Big Prize Package
description: Outstanding performances for the year continue to be recognized with awards: yesterday, they were announced on both sides of the Atlantic. Winner of the Eclipse Award as the outstanding thoroughbred horse trainer was H. Allen Jerkens, who sent out Onion and Prove Out to upset Secretariat, horse of the year.

title: Santa Anita Opener Won by Long Shot
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 27 (UPI)  Don Pierce rode Woodland Pines to a length victory today in the 22d running of the $34,300 Palos Verdes Handicap, the traditional openingday feature of the Santa Anita winter thoroughbred meeting.

title: Kohoutek, the Scientist, Is Pleased by the Comet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The comet Kohoutek, which is to whip around the sun tomorrow, is losing its glow as a postChristmas spectacular for the average neckcraner, but it still ranks as the probable comet of the century for scientists.

title: U.S. Advantage in Oil Helps Lift Dollar
description: PARIS, Dec. 27The stronger position of the United States, relative to other industrial countries, in the wake of recent sharp increases in the price of crude oil, was translated today into sharply higher values for the dollar against leading currencies.

title: Occidental Accused
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and its chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, were accused yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of defrauding the public in connection with the sale of securities. The company agreed to a consent decree. Page 43.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: A Settlement Is Completed By Commonwealth and G.E.
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and the General Electric Company announced yesterday the successful completion of settlement discussions covering outstanding issues under the turnkey contracts for construction of four 800 megawatt nuclear power plants entered into in 1965 and 1966.

title: Nixon Feels Flight to Coast on Commercial Plane Scored Points With the Public
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Dec 27President Nixon began a postChristmas vacation at his San Clemente estate today convinced, as one aide said, that his trip across the country by commercial jet had scored points with the public.

title: Johnson in Broadcast Consumer Unit
description: Two of the most prominent figures in the broadcast consumerist movement in Washington are joining forces as the new heads of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, which is reorganizing.

title: Predicts High Rate Will Continue a While and Then Fall Under 5%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that inflation would continue at a pretty high rate early next year but that it should drop below a rate of 5 per cent in the latter half of the year after the worst of the impact of energy and food prices is over.

title: Miss Mueller Has Nuptials
description: ENGLEWVOOD. N.J., Dec. 27In the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon Miss Margaret Sterling Mueller, daughter of Mrs. Francis Olmstead and the late Dr. Reginald Sterling Mueller, was married to Lennart Christer Rundlof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lennart Vilhelm Rundlof of Malm, Sweden, The Rev. John Van Zanten performed the ceremony.

title: ExGov. Christopher Del Sesto Of Rhode Island Is Dead at 66
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 27 (AP)Former Gov. Christopher Del Sesto of Rhode Island, who was an associate justice of the state's Superior Court since 1966, died today at his home. He was 66 years old.

title: POLICE EXTORTION IS REPORTED CUT
description: The systematic extortion of bribes by groups of New York City police officers has been substantially reduced in recent years, but allegations of illegal involvement in narcotics by individual officers has increased, according to a police corruption study.

title: People and Business
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation, holding company for the First Pennsylvania Bank and other financial services companies, announced a series of top management realignments yesterday. As a result of the changes, which will go into effect on Jan. 1, the senior officers of the corporation will hold the identical titles at the bank.

title: PATHET LAO NAME ENVOY FOR TALKS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 27 (Reuters)The proCommunist Pathet Lao forces have appointed an envoy to negotiate with the Laotian Government on all matters, a Government spokesman said today.

title: The Economic Warriors
description: It is a common habit with nations that they seldom think much about economic warfare until it is turned against them. This is a subject worth thinking about some night if you run out of heating oil or gas, and it certainly a topic that will have to be considered in the forthcoming talks on world trade.

title: A New Year's Hazard: Walking While Drank
description: If you drink, don't walk, the New Jersey State Safety Council advised at the start of the New Year's holiday weekend.

title: It Will Be a Dimmer New Year's Eve
description: In a winter of discontent, New Yorkers are preparing to celebrate a New Year's Eve marked by the energy crisis, higher prices in nightclubs and less money for the annual party in Central Park.

title: Lee Rites Listed Tomorrow At the Mormon Tabernacle
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 27A funeral service will be conducted here Saturday for Harold B. Lee, 11th president of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints, in the Tabernacle on Temple Square.

title: Discrimination Is Charged By 40 Women at Newsday
description: Forty women employes of Newsday, including reporters and editors, filed charges yesterday with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charging that the Long Island newspaper maintains a pattern and practice of employment discrimination against women employes.

title: OnceOutraged Black Helps Make Peekskill's Renewal Work
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 27 There was a time when Pearl Woods, a mother of six living in a downtown area scheduled for redevelopment, was always the first on her feet at public hearings, asking indignant questions about relocation.

title: Music: New York Chamber Soloists
description: In years past, the Metropolitan Museum's holiday week concerts presented in front of its glorious Christmas tree in the Medievel Sculpture Court have had a distinctly festive air that made them seem Christmasy even when some of the music in them had no direct connection with the holiday.

title: U.S. Charges Price Fixing in Gypsum
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  The nation's six largest manufacturers of gypsum board, a major component of home construction, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on pricefixing charges.

title: Senator Jackson Reports Terrorists Threatened Him
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 27 (AP)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he had been threatened by Arab terrorists but that I personally am not going to be blackmailed.

title: Champion Home Net Shows an 81% Drop In the 3d Quarter
U.S. Hails Textile Accord As a Good Trade Portent
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27United States officials hailed today the new international textiles trade agreement, signed last week in Geneva, as good portent for success in the broader trade negotiations due to begin next year.

title: Israeli Complaints to U.N. Charge Egyptian Advances
description: CAIRO, Dec. 27New Israeli complaints of Egyptian troop advances along a sensitive sector of the ceasefire lines were reported today by the headquarters here of the United Nations Emergency Force.

title: Answers to Rationing Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27Following are questions and answers about the Government's standby gasoline rationing plan:

title: In Bangkok, the Movement Will Act Again if It Must
description: BANGKOK, ThailandWirach Rochnapithyakorn, like most Thai students, does not have an ideological turn of mind.

title: BURGER SON'S PAY AT G.S.A. REPORTED
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 27 (AP) Wade A. Burger, son of Chief Justice of the United States Warren E. Burger, is drawing government salary of $25,863 more than seven times what he had earned as a real estate salesman, The Norfolk VirginianPilot said today.

title: Nuptials Are Held For Patricia Moss
description: In the Church Center of the United Nations, Miss Patricia Moss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Moss of New York, was married yesterday to Robert James Vreeland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vreeland of Whippany, N. J. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the ceremony.

title: KISSINGER ASSERTS U.S.SOVIET GAINS HINGE ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that improved American relations with the Soviet Union were possible only so long as Moscow maintained a responsible course in the Middle East.

title: Still Missing
description: The year that brought an end to the massive United States war effort in Vietnam brought no end to the doubts and tragedies that fell upon some twenty young men and their families far away. These men went to Southeast Asia voluntarily; they were unarmedexcept for pencils, notebooks and cameras, the tools of their profession.

title: SOVIET EXCOLONELS TELL OF PRESSURE
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (Reuters) Three Jews who are former colonels in the Soviet Army said today that they were subject to continuing reprisals for seeking to emigrate to Israel and two of them said that they were formally renouncing Soviet citizenship.

title: DIRECTOR OF V.A. OUSTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (UPI) The director of the Southern California region of the Veterans Administration, Gordon Elliott, has been replaced following delayed payments to thousands of student veterans for months, incurring the anger of President Nixon.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: St. John's, offensively aggressive, and Princeton, with a tempered offense, advanced to the semifinal round of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: 54 Favorite Scores by 8 In Sweeps
description: LEOPARDSTOWN, Ireland, Dec. 27 (AP)Comedy of Errors romped to an eightlength victory today in the Irish Sweeps Hurdle and rewarded 12 Irish Sweepstakes ticketholders around the world with prizes of $120,000 each.

title: 75 Rescued From GasFilled Brooklyn Apartments
description: Seventyfive persons were removed and saved from carbonmonoxide poisoning shortly after midnight yesterday after gas fumes from a defective heating system seeped through the apartments of a fourstory building in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: WILLIAM HAINES, 73, FILM COMEDIAN, DIES
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) William Haines, a film comedian of the nineteentwenties and thirties died of cancer yesterday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica. He was 73 years old and lived in Brentwood.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW A RECOVERY
description: Corporate bond prices recovered some of Wednesday's losses in light trading yesterday. Dealers attributed the improvement to short covering accompanied by the reduction announced by the First National Bank of Boston in its base lending rate. Another factor cited was word that the Federal Reserve System was in the market for its own account for agency issues.

title: HotelShopsTheater Complex Planned for a Site on Palisades
description: FORT LEE, Dec. 27  Plans were announced here tonight for a $250million shoppingrecreationresidential center on the Palisades.

title: OnceOutraged Black Helps Make Peekskill's Renewal Work
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 27 There was a time when Pearl Woods, a mother of six living in a downtown area scheduled for redevelopment, was always the first on her feet at public hearings, asking indignant questions about relocation.

title: November Surplus In Trade Is Pared
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) The United States registered its third consecutive monthly trade surplus in November, although the surplus was sharply reduced by higher costs of imported petroleum and other fuels, Government trade figures showed today.

title: Reserve's Statistics Show Interest Rates Are Falling
Bridge: Unsets Mark Early Play Fer Von Zedtwitz Trophy
description: Two substantial upsets marked the early rounds of play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Double Knockout Team Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy, in which 53 teams are entered.

title: Sperm Screening in Lab May Help Produce Boys
description: A technique of screening human semen has been developed that, the experimenters believe, can increase sharply the likelihood that a couple desiring to produce a boy rather than a girl can do so.

title: A Mexican Casserole and an Indian Chicken Dish
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: About New York
description: It was 3:10 on a cold, rotten morning on a mean street in Brooklyn last January, and Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy was holding a news conference in the rain. Around the corner, four gunmen were holding 10 hostages in a sportinggoods store, and the Commissioner was saying that things were tense, that the police had plans and that, of course, he could not say what they were.

title: $235,000 Offered By Mrs. Onassis To Settle Lawsuit
description: Aristotle Onassis said yesterday that his wife, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, would pay, the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison $235,000 today to settle a claim against Mr. Onassis.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Anaconda Company said yesterday that it had informed its customers in the United States that 1974 deliveries of refined copper would be reduced by about 25 per cent from 1973 levels due to the exclusion of all but domestic ores from those shipments.

title: Dining Out: The Place May Be a Tourist Attraction, but the Food. There Is Fine
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: 2,000 Youngsters Throng Synagogue At Hanukkah's End
description: Two thousand Jewish youngsters filled the Lubavitch Synagogue in Brooklyn yesterday with joyous music and sons as candles glowed on two ?? candelabra.

title: Sabres Top Wings, 31; Martin Star
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 27 (UPI)Rick Martin picked up two goats and Gil Perreault added the third tonight as the Buffalo Sabres skated to a 3.1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.

title: SPATE REVERSING DIRTY FUEL STAND
description: New York State's new commissioner of Environmental Conservation charged yesterday that the energy crisis had been overblown and exaggerated, and said he saw no need to extend the emergency variance granted Consolidated Edison to burn dirtier fuel oil and coal.

title: New Soviet Wharf In Pacific Opened
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 27The Soviet Union today announced the commissioning of the first wharf of a major new Pacific port on Wrangel Bay, being built with Japanese help and an $80 million credit from Tokyo.

title: Spanish Papers Charge French Shelter Killers
description: MADRID, Dec. 27 (AP) Spanish newspapers accused French authorities today of harboring the killers of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco. One newspaper said that the Government here would request extradition.

title: Occidental Accused
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and its chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, were accused yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of defrauding the public in connection with the sale of securities. The company agreed to a consent decree. Page 43.

title: Delay on New Rail Tunnel Under the Hudson Is Urged
description: A bistate task force on commuter service said yesterday that construction of a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River at 48th Street should, be deferred.

title: Music: Hansel Gretel, Ted & Alice
description: Prof. Peter Schickele, the world's foremost authority on the life and music of P.D.Q. Bach, opened an engagement on Wednesday night at Town Hall, where he will be appearing through Sunday. His illustrated discussion of the composer is centered this time on the intimate (as opposed to inanimate) aspects of the latter's oeuvre.

title: Secured Kassuba Loans Total Over $125Million
description: Secured loans of the Kassuba Development Corporation, a large national real estate company that has filed for an arrangement with the creditors in the United States District Court in Chicago totaling well over $125million have been reported by a growing number of mortgage investment trusts.

title: PUBLIC RELEASE OF TAPES IN DOUBT
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Dec. 27Administration officials indicated tonight that it was highly unlikely that either transcripts or summaries of tapes of President Nixon's Watergate conversations would be released to the general public.

title: NEW PLAY MARKS KWANZA FESTIVAL
description: NEWARK, Dec. 27A weeklong Kwanza festival, the Africanoriented celebration that is gaining favor among many American blacks, was begun here by the Committee for a Unified Newark this week with musical and dramatic events, including a new play by Imam Atniri Baraka satirizing Newark politics.

title: Decline of the Giants a ManySided Tale of Woe
description: Alex Webster approached Jim Garrett on the sidelines at Yale Bowl during the first half of the New York Giants' game against the Dallas Cowboys this year.

title: Harried Gas Dealers Try Barricades
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 27  At Charles Regini's Exxon station in the middle of Bloomfield, the pumps were barricaded tonight by a wrecker, a blue Buick, a panel truck, a purple Jeep, a red Volkswagen, a blue and white Scout, two garbage cans, two oil drums and a saw horse.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Advertising: Jobs and Salaries
description: If you're looking for an experienced account man in the $35,000 salary class you'll have no trouble finding one. If, however, you have in mind an assistant account executive with two years' experience in the $18,000 to $25,000 variety you will find slim pickings.

title: POLICE EXTORTION IS REPORTED CUT
description: The systematic extortion of bribes by groups of New York City police officers has been substantially reduced in recent years, but allegations of illegal involvement in narcotics by individual officers has increased, according to a police corruption study.

title: Basketball Scoring
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: In a GiftHorse's Mouth
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  It is unprecedented and unbelievable that Richard M. Nixon's papers donated to the National Archives were appraised as a charitable gift valued at $576,000.

title: Lack of Feedstocks Closes PPG's Puerto Rico Unit
description: PPG Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that lack of petroleum  based feedstocks would keep the Puerto Rico Olefins Company closed for an indefinite period and would continue to cause a severe curtailment at PPG'S wholly owned chemical complex at Guyanilla, Puerto Rico.

title: BERRIGAN REJECTS GANDHI PEACE PRIZE
description: The Rev, Daniel Berrigan has rejected the Gandhi Peace Prize. The directors of the organization that was going to make the award  Promoting Enduring Peace  were reconsidering it in light of a recent speech by Father Berrigan that had been criticized as antiIsrael and antiJewish.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: All 15 prison guards on the day shift, reportedly disgruntled over concessions made to inmates, staged a sickout yesterday at the minimumsecurity Mercer County Corrections Center in nearby Hopewell Township. Spokesmen for Local 107 of the Mercer County Corrections Officers were unavailable for comment, but guards belonging to the union said the action involved alleged partial treatment of prisoners. Some 135 inmates staged a sitin Wednesday to protest the confinement of a prisoner with long sideburns. A code change was made prohibiting such treatment without a hearing before a disciplinary committee. Warden Theodore Molner said inmates were following regular routine, with nightshift guards remaining on duty, He said he would meet with representatives of the guards and with Superintendent of Corrections Roy Beans as soon as possible.

title: Guerrilla Committee to Question Five Arab Hijackers in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 27 (AP) Five Arab guerrillas who staged the hijacking attack at Rome's airport last week will be interrogated here by a special guerrilla committee, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.

title: Maryland To Kick Off Bowl Season
description: Maryland makes its first postseason appearance in 18 years tonight against Georgia in the Peach Bowl, which kicks off a run of eight games that could severely shake the top 20 teams in majorcollege football.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Negotiations for a new contract to replace the current Off Broadway pact, which expires Jan. 6, will be resumed Wednesday at a P.M., it was announced yesterday.

title: SOVIET IS WORRIED BY AIRLINE SAFETY
description: MOSCOW, Dec, 27 (AP)Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, has recognized that it has a safety problem.

title: Byrne Says Plans To Add to Turnpike Are Being Postponed
description: NEWARK, Dec. 27Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne said today that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has assured him it would not award any additional contracts for construction of a turnpike route to Toms River, which he has opposed, until his office had completed further exploration of several areas of disagreement he has with the authority's commissioners.

title: SIMON ANNOUNCES STANDBY SYSTEM ON GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27William E. Simon, the Federal energy director, announced today the establishment of a standby gasolinerationing system but said he was personally optimistic that rationing could be avoided if the American public continues to cooperate.

title: A Double Standard For Mr. Agnew
description: With no intent to violate the season of good will, it has to be asked why the State of Maryland should make further exception in the case of Spiro T. Agnew and suspend rather than disbar him from the practice of law. He has already been shown more favor than would have been granted most high officials who did not contest a felony charge involving moral turpitude and there is nothing in American life much more disgraceful than the double standard of justice that Mr. Agnew wants extended to him again.

title: Rationing on Standby
description: The Administration is still trying to keep its options open on a program for dealing with the energy crisis. The announcement by Federal energy chief William Simon of a standby rationing scheme for gasoline really a way of deferring the tough decision on whether or not to ration.

title: VIOLENT CRIME UP 3% FOR 9 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Violent crime rose 3 per cent in the United States in the first nine months of 1973, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: Soybeans Up More Than 10c a BushelCorn Adds 4c
description: Most futures prices rose yesterday on commodity exchanges around the country as a result of the announcement on Wednesday that the Arabs were easing their oil cutbacks for Europe and Japan.

title: DR. F. THEODORE REID
description: Dr. F. Theodore Reid, who had practiced medicine in this city for 53 years died yesterday at Columbus Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 211 West 138th Street.

title: RALLY CONTINUES IN STOCK MARKET
description: Wall Street's yearend rally continued yesterday as the DowJones industrials added 13.45 points to Wednesday's advance of 22.75 points.

title: JOHN CALVIN HILL A CAREER DIPLOMAT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 John Calvin Hill, a career Foreign Service officer, died today of cancer in the Georgetown University Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: Rear Adm. Richard Bates, Held Commands in Pacific
description: NEWPORT, R. L, Dec. 27Rear Adm. Richard Waller Bates, U.S.N. retired, died today at the Naval Hospital here. He was 81 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Right Man, Wrong Job
description: In making Roger Starr his chief housing adviser, Mayorelect Beame has picked one of New York City's bestqualified experts on the economics of housinga thoughtful, articulate analyst of problems that have contributed so drastically to the decay of neighborhoods and the shortage of good housing for middleclass and poor families.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON POLICE CONTRACT
description: A tentative agreement was reached last night on a oneyear contract for police officers after an allday mediation session yesterday between Herbert L. Haber, the city's Director of Labor Relations, and officials of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: MEASURES WEIGHED ON POWER CUTOFFS
description: Federal and state legislation will be sought to bar public utilities from turning off power or heat to residential customers for nonpayment of bills without first notifying police or welfare officials, several legislators said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Human Resources Administration yesterday requested an increase of $220million in its expense budget for 197475, despite a projected decline in welfare rolls and the Federal assumption of responsibility, as of Jan. 1, for the categories of aid to the disabled, aged and blind. The agency is seeking a total of $2.578billion.

title: Blue Shield Agrees State's Accusations Have Some Validity
description: A spokesman for Blue Shield conceded yesterday that there was some validity to charges by the State Insurance Department that Blue Shield had failed to make prompt and fair settlements of claims in which its liability was clear.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW RISE AGAIN
description: Scoring their biggest advance in more than five months, prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday for the second straight session. Prices in the overthecounter market also rose.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSS

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TWO BY FOUR The Rillhard String Quartet and the Modern Jazz Quartet work different musical streets, have never met, and are each 21 years old. That's not the end of it. Tonight at 8 the two quartets are performing together in a concert at Carnegie Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (CI 77459).

title: Food Here 8.3% Costlier Since May
description: Food prices in the city rose 8.3 per cent from May to the second week in December, according to figures compiled by the Consumer Affairs Depart. ment for its weekly Market Basket.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Anaconda Company said yesterday that it had informed its customers in the United States that 1974 deliveries of refined copper would be reduced by about 25 per cent from 1973 levels due to the exclusion of all but domestic ores from those shipments.

title: Giant Stores Ban Lifted
description: The Securities Exchange Commission said yesterday that the ban on overthecounGiant Food Stores Corporation would be lifted beginning Wednesday. Suspensions in trading of OmegaAlpha, Inc., and the Seaboard Corporation would be continued through Jan. 5, the S.E.C. said.

title: HENRY WILLCOX, LED CONSTRUCTION FIRM
description: SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 27Henry Willcox, founder and president of the former Willcox Construction Company of New York, which specialized in public housing, died here today, He was 83 years old and lived here.

title: Delay on New Rail Tunnel Under the Hudson Urged
description: A bistate task force on commuter service said yesterday that construction of a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River at 48th Street should be deferred.

title: Seiple May Take a Hand In Things
description: In preparing for Miami's American Conference championship game with Oakland, Larry Seiple knows he'll punt against the Raiders, but he also wonders whether he'll play tight end and the Raiders wonder whether he'll play running back.

title: Velasquez Rides 4 Winners and Misses 5th on Foul
description: Jorge Velasquez, the star 27yearold jockey from Panama, made the 20,807 fans at Aqueduct yesterday forget all about Ron Turcotte and Angel Cordero. Velasquez, one of the most dependable riders on the continent, rode four winners on the ninerace program, and only a disqualification out of a first place finish took a fifth triumph away from him.

title: REALTY COMPANIES FACE CITY BIAS FIGHT
description: The City Commission on Human Rights opened a campaign yesterday to end the realestate concerns' practice of racial steering, or sending white home buyers to allwhite neighborhoods and blacks to mixed or allblack areas.

title: In Seoul, Radicalized Girl Belittles Harsh Treatment
description: SEOUL. South KoreaLast summer a shy student from a conventional middleclass family in Seoul worked in a factory as part of a program organized by the Christian churches here.

title: GREENLAND PUNS TO HUNT FOR OIL
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 27The Danish Government will start negotiating Oilsearch leases for Greenland's west coast within a few months and the outlook is promising, according to Lars Chemnitz, head of Greenland's Government.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Tamara Melcher and Larry Rothschild have been cooperating for a year or more in designing and makclothes of velvet appliqu, but in Opening Tamale/Design Works, a craft studio in SaHo, they have widened their scope considerably. Here, they are combining their talents with those of other craftsmen.

title: Keeping Cool in Alaska
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif.In 1972 Congress voted to award Alaskan Indians, Eskimos and Aleuts 40 million acres of land and nearly a billion dollars as compensation for their aboriginal title to our 49th state.

title: Donna Israel Is Wed to David Berliner
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 27Miss Donna G. Israel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Israel of West Orange, was married here this evening to David C. Berliner, a freelance writer, in Congregation Oheb Shalom. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Louis Levitsky and Alexander Shapiro. They were assisted by Cantor Edgar Mills.

title: J. PEARCE MITCHELL, STANFORD CHEMIST
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 27 Dr. J. Pearce Mitchell, a former professor of chemistry and registrar at Stanford University, who also was a former Mayor of Palo Alto and a member of the City Council, died at his home here today. He was 93 years old.

title: Miss Fascell Is Wed to F. B. Diamond Jr.
description: MIAMI, Dec. 27  Miss SandraJeanne Fascell, daughter of United States Representative Dante B. Fascell and Mrs. Fascell, was married here this evening to Frank Berry Diamond Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Diamond of Lower Merion, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Emmett Alan Frank in the courtyard of Vizcaya, a Miami museum on Biscayne Bay.

title: Thai Delegation Ends Visit To Peking, First Since 1949
description: PEKING, Dec. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)Gen, Chatichai Choonhavan, Thai Deputy Foreign Minister, left today after a weeklong stay in Peking, the first official visit by a Thai delegation to mainland China since the Communist Government was established in 1949.

title: Knick Victory Gratifying But It May Prove Costly
description: The 9691 victory that the Knicks posted over the Pistons in Detroit on Wednesday night was gratifying, since it came over the team with the fourthbest record in the National Basketball Association. But it may have been costly.

title: Miss O'Callaghan Wed in Suburb
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 27  In the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Michael Ellen O'Callaghan, daughter of Thomas A. O'Callaghan of Montclair and the late Mrs. O'Callaghan, became the bride of Jonathan Staebler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Staebler of Richmond, Ind.

title: Paris Police Say 10 Seized Turks Were Trained by Arab Rebels
description: PARIS, Dec. 27  French authorities said tonight that group of Turks arrested Dec 20 in the midst of an arsenal in a villa outside Paris had been trained by Palestinians for terrorism and revolution in Turkey and elsewhere.

title: DETECTIVE IS HELD IN THEFT OF FUNDS
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 27 The former head of the Suffolk County narcotics squad was indicted today on charges of stealing $48,000 of police money.

title: Hughes and 4 Associates Indicted in Air West Case
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 27 Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, two of his top aides and two other associates were named today in a ninecount criminal indictment by a Federal grand jury here.

title: Phone Caller Charms Diamonds Out of Ritz
description: PARIS, Dec. 27 (UPI)The man who telephoned the Ritz sounded cultured and authoritative.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: ZURICH, Switzerland  Fritz Chenet, Switzerland, knocked out Fernando Atzori, Italy, rounds, flyweights: Civervet et regained European flyweight crown.

title: Roslyn Braeman Married in Missouri
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27The marriage of Miss Roslyn Fay Braeman, a vice president with Eastdil Realty, Inc., an affiliate of Blyth, Eastman, Dillon, New York investment hankers, was married at noon today to Lisle D. Payne, president and chairman of the board of Fox & Carskadom Financial Corporation in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Gas Station Operator Fights Gulf Eviction:
description: TEANECK, Dec. 27  For more than 30 years, the Gulf gasoline station here on Cedar Avenue has been operated by the Quirk family.

title: Gloom Comes Over the Mountain
GRIMSBY IS UNHURT IN ICEPICK ASSAULT
description: An apparently disturbed young woman attempted to stab Roger Grimsby, an anchorman on WABCTV's Eyewitness News show, with an icepick shortly after 7 o'clock last night on West 66th Street.

title: Heller Warns Lifestyle in U.S. Will Undergo Profound Change
description: Walter W. Heller, incoming president of the American Economic Association, warned today that the energy shortage would not soon go away and that the United States was in for a fairly profound change in its way of life.

title: Books of The Times
description: EARLY RECOLLECTIONS AND LIFE OF DR. JAMES STILL. By James Still. 274 pages. (Rutgers University Press, $7.50).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There are about a million longhaul trucks operating on our highways today. These tractortrailer rigs move about 22 per cent of our freight. They do so while consuming almost ten billion gallons of diesel fuel and gasolineabout 10 per cent of that sold commercially.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  Australia could be without most of its top players in its quest this year to retain the Davis Cup. Four members of previous teams, Colin Dibley, Ross Case, Geoff Masters and Bob Giltinan, announced today they would be unavailable for earlyround matches because they would be playing on the World Championship Tennis circuit.

title: Notes on People Judge Hoffman Returns to Bench
description: Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who presided over the tumultuous Chicago seven conspiracy trial of 196970, has been called back to the bench in Illinois. The 73yearold Judge Hoffman has been in semiretirement, but the chief judge for the United States District Court, Edwin A. Robson, wants him to sit temporarily in the Appeals Court after Jan. 1, to help handle a backlog of cases caused by the absence of another judge, Otto Kernber.

title: RHINECHEM EXTENDS CUTTER STOCK OFFER
description: The Rhinechem Corporation, a subsidiary of Bayer, A.G., the West German chemical company, announced yesterday that it had extended to Jan. 18 its offer to purchase at $18.50 a share all the outstanding class A and class B common stock of Cutter Laboratories, Inc.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Franco Moves to Choose Premier
description: MADRID, Dec. 28Generalissimo Francisco Franco moved today to choose a new Premier to succeed Adm, Luis Carrero Blanco, who was assassinated a week ago.

title: HOGAN UNDERGOES TESTS IN HOSPITAL
description: Frank S. Hogan, who on Wednesday announced his resignation as Manhattan District Attorney after nearly 32 years in the office, has been admitted again to St. Luke's Hospital, where his condition was reported as serious yesterday.

title: Having And Eating Oilcake
description: PARISThe political aspect of the Arabs' oil embargo against states considered unfriendly to their cause has been permitted to obscure the far more important fact that the age of petrole umfueled industry is drawing to close just as, to a considerable degree, the industrial revolution fueled by coal drew to a close earlier, or at any rate shifted gears.

title: Nixon Is Cheered and Booed at Friend's Wedding
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI)President Nixon ran a gantlet of mixed cheers and boos outside a chapel today to attend the wedding of his personal physician and friend, Dr. Walter R. Tkach.

title: Panel That Named Hughes Believed Pressing Inquiry
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 28The Federal grand jury that indieted Howard Hughes and associates yesterday on charges of stock manipulation will reportedly continue to hear evideuce that could lead to further

title: Paris Newspaper Robbed; PasserBy Killed in Chase
description: PARIS, Dec. 28. (UPI)A passerby on the ChampsElyses was short to death today during a gun battle between policemen and robbers who had held up the newspaper Le Figaro.

title: A.E.C. Promulgates Stiffer Safety Rules On Power Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Atomic Energy Commission tightened today the safety criteria that are meant to prevent the growing number of nuclear power reactors from overheating, melting their shields and emitting radiation that could injure and kill people in nearby communities.

title: Drivers Hunt for Gasoline; Warning on Prices Issued
description: As motorists formed lines as much as six blocks yesterday at gasoline stations that remained open in the metropolitan area, Federal and state officials warned of increased measures against gasoline pricegouging over the New Year's holiday.

title: ARMY INVESTIGATING RECRUITING UPSURGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) Army officials are trying to find out whether a recent upturn in recruiting was spurred by fears of economic recession.

title: Remembering a Captor, Fondly
description: Cheese was quite thin. Even in a country of small, light people who do not become fat, Cheese seemed frail. But he was not. There is an Anierican living in the suburbs of Chicago who thinks of Cheek in Hanoi and wonders what he is doing. He is John A. Young, a former enlisted man in the Special Forces and a prisoner of war for five years in four different camps in North Vietnam. Cheese was a ranking Vietnamese political officer.

title: Shell Sells Major Italian Interests to State Agency
description: ROME, Dec. 28The stateowned oil and gas agency. Ente Nazionale IdrocarburiE.N.I.will take over most of the Italian interests of Shell under an agreement announced tonight.

title: Blues Are Victors Over Penguins, 31
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Pierre Plante' two goals in the second period tonight gave the St. Louis Blues a 31 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Jaspers, St. John's Gain Festival Final
description: A basketball game between St. John's and Manhattan, the first since the 196263 season, will be played tonight in the final of the Holiday Festival Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Creating an allNew York finale, St. John's, the pretournament favorite, advanced to the final round by defeating Princeton, 6451, after Manhattan beat La Salle, 7365.

title: '73 Racing
description: The latest closing of a thoroughbred racing season in this state will occur today when the New York Racing Association presents its final 1973 card at Aquaduct. Featuring the program will be the Aqueduct Handicap of 1 1/8 miles for 2 year olds. John Olin's Cannonade, who will be ridden by Petey Anderson, is the topweight in the field of nine at 126 pounds. This homebred son of Bold Bidder has won two stakes, the Great American at Aqueduct and the Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs. He is the overnight choice at 21.

title: People and Business
description: Jared L. Rosenthal, who has been recuperating for the last three months from a heart attack, has been relieved of his duties as president and chief executive officer of the Mangel Stores Corporation, the company announced yesterday. Mangel operates 90 women's specialty stores, 46 Shoppers Fair discount stores and six leased departments. During the illness of Mr. Rosenthal, who is 60 years old, Mangel has been run by a fiveman committee appointed by the board.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS MIXED ON AMEX
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than 11 months. Prices in the overthecounter market were higher.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Pregnant Women Win Suit For Aid to Unborn Children
description: BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) A Federal judge has ruled that pregnant women may receive welfare benefits for their unborn children.

title: Late Canada Goal Beats U.S. Six, 54
description: LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Dec 28 (AP)Bill Evo scored his second goal of the game with eight seconds left to play to give Canada a 54 victory over the United ptates today in a sixnation Junior hockey tournament.

title: Stocks Decline 2.99
description: The stock market's yearend rally sputtered a bit yesterday, but some leading gold issues traded at their highest prices on record.

title: A 20% SHORTAGE IN GASOLINE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) The Federal energy chief, William E. Simon, said today that automobile drivers faced moderate form of rationing in January because service stations would be able to meet only 80 per cent of the demand for gasoline.

title: ASHBY LEE BIEDLER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 28 Ashby Lee Biedler, president of the Ashby Lee Biedler insurlance agency in New York City, a business founded by his father in 1894, died yesterday at his home, 20 Church Street. He was 76 years old.

title: DINKINS PULLS OUT AS AIDE TO BEAME; FAILED TO PAY TAX
