description: David N. Dinkins, the first black to be selected for the job of Deputy Mayor here, asked Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday to withdraw his name because of difficulties that stemmed from his failure to pay Federal, state or city personal income taxes for four years.

title: PROFIT REPORTED FOR INDIAN HEAD;
Service for Dr. Wendt
description: A memorial service for Dr. Gerald L. Wendt, who retired in 1967 as head of the publications center here of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, will he held at noon Thursday in the chapel of the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street. Dr. Wendt, an author editor and lecturer, died lass Saturday at the age of 82.

title: Miss Madeleine K. Pagon Has Nuptials
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., Dec. 28Miss Madeleine Kilvert Pagon and Lieut. Graham Crispin StoddartStones of the Royal Navy were married here this evening in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. Richard Hawkins.

title: Israel's SoldierVote Is Seen as a Key to the Election
description: WITH ISRAELI TROOPS, in Occupied Syria, Dec. 27 Rarely has an army represented so important a part of the electorate as does the Israeli Army in the national election set for Monday.

title: PAUL H. HEDRICK
description: ARMONK, N.Y., Dec. 28Paul H. Hedrick, former president of Hedrick & Johnson, a nowdefunct New York advertising agency, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 75 years old and lived at 7 Spruce Hill Road.

title: In the Corporate World, Men Move Upbut Families Just Move
description: They're the perennial New Neighbor. Instant friendships, instant homes, even instant permanence are the hallmarks of their nomadic existence as they follow their husband from one town to another while he inches up the corporate ladder.

title: City and 3 Unions Reach New OneYear Contracts
description: Mayor Lindsay, in the waning hours of his administration, announced yesterday that new oneyear contracts had been negotiated with the city's policemen, sanitationmen and correction officers.

title: Venezuela Oil Price Up
description: Venezuela, a major United States supplier, raised its taxreference price for crude oil by 81.9 per cent to $19.08 a barrel. That will not be the market price, but a basis for calculating tax and royalty payments. Page 31.

title: Aussie Sloop Leads Race to Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 28 (AP)The new 72foot sloop Helsal from Sydney was 140 miles from the finish in the SydneytoHobart yacht race tonight and seemed headed for a race record. The United States yacht Ondine set the record in 19623 days 3 hours 46 minutes seconds. Trailing Helsal for line honors was the Hong Kongcrewed Apollo, followed by Siska of Western Australia, with Prospect of Whitby and Quailo III, both Britain, next. The United States yacht Improbable lay seventh.

title: Bridge: Culbertson HeirDesignate Recalled by an ExPartner
description: If someone had asked Ely Culbertson, in his heyday four decades ago, to suggest his most likely successor at the top of the bridge ladder he would not have named Charles Goren, then a littleknown protg of Milton C. Work.

title: Mrs. Tedder Married To Alfred S. Gussin
description: RYE, N.Y., Dec. 28  Mrs. June Anderson Tedder, who owns and operates a design studio specializing in showroom and retail store interiors in Thodasville, N.C., and New York, was married this afternoon to Alfred S. Gussin, vice president and senior marketing officer of the Furnishings Group of Champion International in New York.

title: M'Kinley Gets Post
description: WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Dec. 28 (UPI)  James McKinley, an assistant coach at Eastern Michigan University for the last two years, has been named head football coach at Central State University. McKinley coached linebackers and was recruiting coordinator at Eastern.

title: Seoul Sets Limits on Freedom of Press
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 28  The Ministry of Culture and Information, spelling out the limits to press freedom in South Korea, said today that the country's present political system must not be denied or challenged.

title: Commodity Price Index Up Shows Increase for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 206.6 from 205.4 last week.

title: Walter Denton Weds Mrs. Everson
description: BRANFORD, Conn., Dec. 28The Walker Chapel of the First Congregational Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Mrs. Florence Wheeler Everson of Pine Orchard to Walter Frank Denton of Waterbury. The Rev. Roger Manners performed the ceremony.

title: Divers Confirm Finding of Sludge a Half Mile Off L.I.
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., Dec. 28Scientists in diving gear who scoured the ocean bottom today confirmed that sewage sludge had drifted to within a half mile of the beach here and that it apparently was being held in place, at least temporarilyin large under water trenches.

title: Tankers Line Up Off East Coast Seeking Dock Space to Unload
description: Scores of oil tankers are lining up along the East Coast for the dwindling dock space and scarce storage facilities to unload their cargo, according to Coast Guard and petroleum industry officials.

title: British Power Engineers Agree to End Slowdown
description: LONDON, Dec. 28Britain's electricalpower engineers, one of the three labor unions whose job actions have jeopardized the national supply of energy, agreed today to resume normal work procedures.

title: JOHN HARRIS, 87, BUILDER, IS DEAD
description: John W. Harris, a builder for 60 years, who executed contracts worth more than a billion dollars throughout the world, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Ice in Mohawk Raises Flood Threat
description: Ice jams on the Mohawk River created a flood threat yesterday for the lowlying communities of Cohoes and Waterford, near Albany.

title: Federal Panel Bids White House End Hiring Role
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Consumer Product Safety Commission asked the White House today to stop interfering with its efforts to hire top staff per sonnet in a nonpolitical, non partisan manner.

title: A Study of Radicals On Campuses Hints Recurring Pattern
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UPI)Campus radicals of the nineteensixties were the offspring, literally and figuratively, of the campus radicals of the nineteenthirties, and the large number of common traits suggests that radical movements may be a recurring pattern, professor at Michigan State University said today.

title: Energy and Jobs
description: WASHINGTONFrom the spate of press releases turned out in the last few weeks, the Administration has made one thing perfectly clearit still isn't telling us how bad the energy shortage is going to be and how many people will be put out of work. This should come as no surprise. We have seen five conflicting energy messages and two energy czars come and go within a single year while Presidential advisers compete to issue the rosiest press release.

title: Paris Printing of Expos Allowed by Solzhenitsyn
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prizewinning author, published in Paris yesterday a massive historical expos of the Soviet secret police, prison camp and terror system, called The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956.

title: Irving Rosenthal, 77, Is Dead; Palisades Operator 37 Years
description: Irving Rosenthal, who owned and operated Palisades Amusement Park in Fort Lee, N. J., from 1934 to 1971, died of a heart attack at his home here Thursday. His age was 77.

title: Japanese Official Ends Arab Tour and Plans U.S. Trip
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28Deputy Premier Takeo Miki returned here triumphantly today after a 19day tour of seven Middle East countries, which Japanese officials believe helped persuade the Arabs to reclassify Japan as a friendly nation and assure her full oil needs.

title: Marshall Signs Pact
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (UPI)Mike Marshall, the relief pitcher obtained in a trade from Montreal for Willie Davis, an outfielder, agreed to terms today with the Los Angeles Dodgers for 1974.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York said yesterday that it had asked the 42 municipal and rural cooperative customers who are wholesale purchasers of its power to reduce their voltage by 3 per cent to consrve energy. The action was taken in cooperation with statewide voltagereduction measures undertaken by other utilities.

title: COURT TO REVIEW PHONE RATE RISE
description: BRIELLE, Dec. 28  Judge Robert A. Matthews turneddown today a request by attorneys representing the public interest for an immediate restraining order against a 2.6 per cent rate increase for the New Jersey Bell Telephone. Company scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1.

title: Time of the Dromedary
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28On the theory that the Arabs are a cannier people than we are, I have been considering buying a camel. A camel is much cheaper than a car to operate, can carry a lot more luggage and doesn't need expensive snow tires or chains to keep going in heavy footing.

title: Blues Are Victors Over Penguins, 31
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Pierre Plante two goals in the second period tonight gave the St. Louis Blues a 31 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Easing the Transition
description: The incoming Beame administration got welcome assurance yesterday that it would be spared early labor tribulations of the kind that plagued the start of the Lindsay administration eight years ago. The conclusion of agreements with all the unions representing the uniformed services, and the designation of an impartial panel resolve differences over nonmonetary issues for 125,000 clerks and administrative employes, assure relatively smooth transition on the municipal labor front.

title: The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956
description: 1973 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn English translation 197374 Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.

title: South Africa Police Hold 304 Tribesmen After Fatal Clashes
description: BERGVILLE, South Africa, Dec. 28 (Reuters)More than 300 tribesmen have been arrested after a tribal clash near here in which 20 men were killed.

title: MAN SHOT BY ROBBER HE FINDS IN HIS HOME
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 28 (UPI)A salesman was shot and wounded shortly before midnight last night in his home here when he tossed a coffee pot at one of two burglars he surprised when the family came home.

title: Game Officials Named
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28 (UPI) National Football League officials today announced that Norm Schacter would be the referee for Sunday's N.F.C. title game between Minnesota and Dallas. Other game officials are: Lou Palazzi, umpire; Tony Veteri, head linesman; Art Hoist, line judge; Tom Kelleher, back judge, and Tony Skover, field judge.

title: Canada Has Snow and Gas
description: VAL DAVID, Quebec, Dec. 28  All available sleeping space for guests is sold out in Canada's Laurentians and it's small wonder. All the slopes, from St. Sauveur to the south to Mont Tremblant in the north, have substantial snow depths. This happy situation for skiers provides a sharp contrast to the dismal picture in America's great northeast. As of this morning, none of the ski centers from Pennsylvania's Poconos to Maine could offer anything better than limited skiing  and with skimpy covers.

title: JOHN SCHADLER
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Dec. 28  John Schadler, founder of John Schadler & Sonse, wholesale hardware and piano supplies company in Clifton, died Wednesday in Livingston. He was 91 years old and lived here.

title: Suit Seeking Access to Papers President Donated to Archives
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28A lawsuit seeking access to the VicePresidential papers donated by President Nixon to the National Archives was filed today in United States District Court here.

title: Late Rally By Pistons Tops Bullets
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP)Bob Lanier and George Trapp led a fourthquarter rally tonight that helped the Detroit Pistons to 10 consecutive points and a 10293 National Basketball Association victory over the Capital Bullets.

title: Eisenhower Gathering Marks Debutante Ball
description: Fortynine young women were presented at the 19th annual International Debutante Ball in the Waldorf. Astoria's Grand Ballroom last night. The occasion was in the nature of a family reunion for the Eisenhowers, who came from far and near to see Mary Jean, the late President's youngest grandchild, lead the presentation ceremony as representative of the United States.

title: Maine Flood Aid Asked
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 28 (AP) Following receipt of revised flood damage figures, Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis asked the Federal Government today to declare flooddamaged portions of the state as disaster areas. Civil defense officials reported that damage across the state Inow totals $5,344,691.

title: FRANK BAGOLIE
description: Frank Bagolie, Western manager in Canada for the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union for the last 12 years, covering the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Winnipeg. He was 64 years old and made his home in Winnipeg.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS MANPOWER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 President Nixon signed into law today legislation designed to give state and local governments a larger role in determining their need for a variety of employment and training programs.

title: Cosmos 626 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has launched another in its series of Cosmos earth satellites Cosmos 626to explore outer space, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: OUTPUT OF GASOLINE UP IN U.S. FOR WEEK
Australians Find Tapestry Stolen From City Building
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  A Frenchdesigned tapestry valued at $85,000, stolen from the wall of a city building six months ago, was recovered today from a motorboat under a house in a seaside suburb of Sydney.

title: RISE IN MAIL RATES PUT OFF TO MARCH 2
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The United States Postal Service said today that it would Postpone rate increases scheduled for Jan. 5 until March 2 in :ompliance with a directive by the Cost of Living Council.

title: MINORITY HIRING GAINS EXTENSION
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI)The controversial Philadelphia Plan, which requires Federal construction contractors to hire certain numbers of blacks and other minorities has been extended.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Buying Queens Water System

title: Books of The Times
description: Although we Americans are a polynational people, Puritanism, even in its extenuated form in the nineteenseventies, exerts a tremendous force on our mores. Its doctrines, attitudes of mind and its value systems, having come over on the Mayflower, are sanctified by historicity, and so when an appeal is made to tradi

title: TURKS SENTENCE 3 FROM U.S. TO LIFE
description: ANTIOCH, Turkey, Dec. 28 (UPI)Three young Americans convicted of smuggling 225 pounds of hashish into Turkey from Syria were sentenced to death by a Turkish court today. The court then commuted their sentences to life in prison.

title: Venezuela Oil Price Up
description: Venezuela, a major United States supplier, raised its taxreference price for crude oil by 81.9 per cent to $14.08 a barrel. That will not be the market price, but a basis for calculating tax and royalty payments. Page 31.

title: New. Jersey Sports
description: RAHWAY, Dec. 28For a Litle fellow, Joe Bost gets tangled up quite a bit. When Joe isn't involved in the sport of judo, he's wrestling for Rahway High School:

title: TestFirings of Missiles Over Five States Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Defense Department announced today plans to testfire Minuteman missiles without nuclear warheads from an Air Force bake in Montana over five Western states into the Pacific Ocean.

title: A.E.C Promulgates Stiffer Safety Rules On Power Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Atomic Energy Commission tightened today the safety criteria that are meant to prevent the growing number of nuclear power reactors from overheating, melting their shields and emitting radiation that could injure and kill people in nearby communities.

title: Back Injury Idles Bucks' Robertson
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 28 (AP) Oscar Robertson of the Milwaukee Bucks was hospitalized today for treatment of a back ailment and was expected to be sidelined about 10 days.

title: Padres Stay WestIf Sale Is Approved
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) C. Arnholt Smith informed the National League today that he had sold the Padres baseball club to a Los Angeles group without the league's blessing. The group intends to keep the team in San Diego.

title: Egypt Charges Israelis Mistreated 43 Prisoners
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 28Egypt has complained to the Security Council that Israeli authorities subjected 43 Egyptian prisoners of war to cruel, inhuman and illegal treatment.

title: Stage: For Youngsters
description: The Bil Baird Theater has consistently rejuvenated familiar material (While many other children's theaters have tried to capitalize on that familiarity). An excellent example is the current Baird show, Pinocchio. Instead of imitating Disney or even overly evoking Carlo Collodi, the authors (book by Jerome Coopersmith, music by Mary Rodgers, lyrics by Sheldon Bernick) use Pinocchio as a catapult for their own imaginations.

title: GYPSUM COMPANIES TO FIGHT U.S. CASE
description: The nation's six largest manufacturers of building supplies say they will put a vigorous defense against Government. charges that they have fixed prices on gypsum board since 1960.

title: A Straight Answer
description: New York State's new Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, James L. Biggane, is off to a good start. While his remarks on the energy crisis, following his induction, indicated no essential difference from the policy laid down by his admirable predecessor, Henry Diamond, the approach was reassuring. Consolidated Edison was given a variance by Commissioner Diamond to burn higher sulphur oil and coal until March 31, 1974, in view of an emergency then generally conceded. All that Commissioner Biggane is saying now is that he doubts that circumstances will dictate a renewal of that variance.

title: REBEL POLICEMEN RETRACT PROTEST
description: RARITAN TOWNSHIP, Dec. 28This 35squaremile rural community in Hunterdon County will have its old police force on duty, plus two new members, when 1974 arrives at midnight Monday.

title: 75 Years or So LaterMackintosh Could Make It
description: Will 1974 be Charles Rennie Mackintosh's year?

title: Business Briefs
description: State Mortgage Loans Increase

title: DINKINS PULLS OUT AS AIDE TO BEAME; FAILED TO PAY TAX
description: David N. Dinkins, the first black to be selected for the job of Deputy Mayor here, asked Mayorelect Abraham D. Beanie yesterday to withdraw his name because of difficulties that stemmed from his failure to pay Federal, state or city personal income taxes for four years.

title: Israel Votes
description: Not for six years, and perhaps not for 25 years, has Israel found itself in such a state of political convulsion and uncertainty. Monday's quadrennial election will almost certainly not set a decisive policy for the nation's future, but the government that emerges will have the responsibility for negotiating the peace settlement that has eluded Israel for so long.

title: WHEAT FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: With considerable short covering in the last hour developing as a result of heavy export buying of wheat, futures prices Of wheat advanced about 18 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of those shortterm securities.

title: Phone Need Foiled Computer Concern
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 28 (UPI)The nation's first home computer service, which brought customers data processing services by telephone, will go out of business tomorrow after six months of operation.

title: DeCavalcante Gets Mandatory Release From U.S. Prison
description: Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, a reputed New Jersey rackets figure known as Sam the Plumber, has been released from the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta after serving more than half of a fiveyear term on gamblingconspiracy charges.

title: Desegregation Plan Ordered For Kentucky School Area
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 28 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ordered today a desegregation plan prepared for all three school districts in Jefferson County, Ky,, including Louisville.

title: Kidnappers Seize West German In Front of His Home in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 28A West German industrialist who is also his country's honorary consul here was kidnapped from his home last night.

title: Hampton and Dela. State Win in Freedom Classic
description: Wade Pittman, a 6foot4inch junior guard, tallied 16 of his gamehigh 26 points in the second half to lead Delaware State to a 7976 victory over Shaw University in the opening game of the Freedom Classic at City College last night.

title: Jaspers, St. John's Gain Festival Final
description: A basketball game between St. John's and Manhattan, the first since the 196263 season, will be played tonight in the final of the Holiday Festival Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Creating an allNew York finale, St. John's, the pretournament favorite, advanced to the final round by defeating Princeton, 6451, after Manhattan beat La Salle, 7365.

title: Federal Policies Puzzle Economists
description: When the smoke had cleared and the chatter died down yesterday at the opening session of the American Economic Association's annual convention, the nation's best and brightest economists came forth with a resounding I don't know.

title: LAW ON OBSCENITY IS UPHELD IN STATE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28The Stat Colin of Appeals today upheld, 4 to 3, the constitutionality of the state law on obscenity and pornography, declaring that the statute more than complies With tests laid down by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Owner of Club Falls Dead After an Attempted Holdup
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 28 (AP)Two men attempted to rob customers of the 223 Club at knifepoint today, but jumped through a window when they were frightened off. The owner of the club collapsed and died.

title: Cortland Ames Dies at 50; Led Lone Star's Land Unit
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 28Cortlandt F. Ames, former president and general manager of Lone Star Properties, Inc., landdevelopment subsidiary of Lone Star Industries, Greenwich, Conn., died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday. He was 50 years old and lived on Raider's Lane.

title: Dance: The Little Angels
description: The General Assembly Hall of the United Nations had never been opened to the public for a cultural performance before Thursday. It was fitting that the first group to perform there was the Little Angels, the National Folk Ballet of Korea, and that the performance was staged to benefit UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund. The group of thirtyone girls between 8 and 12 years old, augmented by three spectacularly acrobatic boys and five adult members of the Little Angels Court Music Orchestra, filled the stage with colorful song and dance and a spirited freshness. Judging from the standing ovation the children received, their performance of sometimes exotic national dance to music played on replicas of ancient Korean instruments has a universal appeal.

title: The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956
description: (1973 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn English translation 197374 Harper & Row. Publishers, Inc.

title: Stalin Said to Have Planned a Vast Pogrom
description: Two of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's most dramatic accusations in his account of the Soviet laborcamp system relate to Stalin and form the basis for excerpts being published in three installments in The New York Times starting today.

title: Georgia Triumphs in Peach Bowl, 17 to 16
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 28 (UPI)Andy Johnson scored orre touchdown and passed for another and a defensive back, Dick Conn, recovered two crucial Maryland fumbles to give Georgia a 1716 Peach Bowl victory tonight.

title: Paris Printing of Expos Allowed by Solzhenitsyn
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prizewinning author, published in Paris yesterday a massive historical expose of the Soviet secret police, prison camp and terror system, called The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956.

title: 5,200 at T.W.A. And American Air Get Layoff Notices
description: Layoff notices were sent to a total of 5,200 employes yesterday by American and Trans World Airlines.

title: A Teasing, Chiding Mao Shown in Papers New to West
description: A collection of speeches, conversations and directives of Mao Tsetung, printed for limited circulation in China, has come into the hands of scholars here. The documents provide intimate glimpses into the personality of Chairman Mao, and as scholars study them, they are expected to shed light on doctrinal disputes within the Chinese Communist party.

title: SAMUEL BROWN
description: EDISON, N. J., Dec. 28 Samuel Brown, who retired in 1960 after 48 years as the owner of the Quality Shop, a retail clothing store, and a civic leader in Perth Amboy, died yesterday in the John F. Kennedy Community Hospital here. He was 85 years old and lived in Redfield Village.

title: U.S. Aides to Crack Down On Weekend Gas Gouging
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork announced today that the Department of Justice would seek restraining orders against gasoline dealers found to be charging motorists excessive prices over this weekend.

title: The Modern Salutes Duchamp, the Myth and the Man
description: There are two Marcel Duchamps. One is a figure of legend and the object of a cultthe archetype of the avantgarde leader whose ideas and influence enjoy a mythical, almost mystical status among the cognoscenti of artists, critics, curators and collectors. The other is a more mundane figure of historya French artist born in 1887 and deceased in 1968, who produced a small quantity of paintings and drawings in the established modern styles, experimented with new modes of construction and foundobject art and for decades thereafter pretended (with much publicity) that he had abandoned the artistic vocation he continued to practice to the very end of a long lifetime.

title: Justice Stewart's Mother
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 28 (AP)Harriet P. Stewart, mother of Associate Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court, died Wednesday. She was 89 years old. She leaves, besides her son, another son, Dr. Zeph Stewart; a daughter, Irene Bannard; eight grandchildren, and three greatgrandchildren.

title: Hunt and Barker to Be Freed Without Bail
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The United States Court of Appeals here ordered today that E. Howard Hunt, Jr. and Bernard L. Barker be released from prison without bail pending the appeal of their conviction in Watergate case. The court gave no reason for its decision.

title: Court of Appeals Allows Suits in Attica Assault
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28The State Court of Appeals ruled 4 to 3 today that the widow of a state employe held hostage during the 1971 rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility and killed when troopers quelled the rebellion with gunfire could sue the state.

title: Drivers Hunt for Gasoline; Warning on Prices Issued
description: As motorists formed lines as much as six blocks yesterday at gasoline stations that remained open in the metropolitan area, Federal and state officials warned of increased measures against gasoline pricegouging over the New Year's holiday.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: Cowboys Eye Staubach For Super Bowl Ticket
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28Roger Staubach first came on the national sports scene a decade ago when he won the Heisman Trophy as a junior quarterback at the Naval Academy, made the cover of Sports Illustrated and generally became a household football word. Then he more or less dropped out of national sight until the Super Bowl game of 1972 in which he helped the Cowboys to an easy victory over Miami at New Orleans. On Sunday, in Dallas, all eyes will be on Staubach again as he leads the Cowboys against the Minnesota Vikings with the National Conference championship and a trip to the Bowl at stake.

title: 2 HIGH OFFICIALS NAMED BY BEAME
description: George Bundy Smith, the president of the Harlem Lawyers Association and law secretary to Justice Harold A. Stevens, presiding justice of the Appellate Division's First Department, was named yesterday by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame as Model Cities Administrator.

title: Dolphins, Artificial Turf Lie in Wait for Raiders
description: MIAMI, Dec. 28The Oakland Raiders could boycott Sunday's American Conference championship game with Miami and picket the Orange Bowl with signs proclaiming, Dolphins Unfair to Visiting Teams.

title: No Time for Concrete
description: Well in advance of the moment he is scheduled to become Governor of New Jersey, Brendan T. Byrne has confronted his first executive test and met it headon.

title: Wealthy Indian Tribe Suing Over Its Palm Springs Land
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. The first of a million winter visitors to this popular desert oasis are lounging around the swimming pools of the hotels and private clubs, soaking up the warm sunshine and blissfully unaware that the town is under attack by Indians.

title: COAST PAPER BOUGHT BY SCRIPPSHOWARD
description: The ScrippsHoward Newspapers yesterday purchased The Daily News Tribune of Fullerton, Calif., from Edgar F. Elfstrom, who started his newspaper career as secretary to the late E. W. Scripps, founder of the ScrippsHoward chain.

title: JOHN GROVES DIES; STEEL NEGOTIATOR,
description: Piittsburgh, Dec. 28 John E. Groves, corporate vice president for industrial relations of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, died today at West Penn Hospital, after having, suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 58 years old.

title: SUSPENSION SPARKS A.T.&T. WALKOUT
description: Some 900 members of Local 1150, Communications Workers of. America, walked off the job yesterday morning in a dispute with the American Telephone & Telegraph Company over the suspension of a shop steward, the company said.

title: 80 Injured in Derailment on Coast
description: ANDERSON, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI)Three sleeping cars of the Coast Starlight Amtrak train, carrying 400 holiday travelers at 60 miles an hour, jumped the tracks and overturned today, injuring 80 persons.

title: Dinkins' Departure
description: David Dinkins took the right course yesterday asking Mayorelect Beame to withdraw his designation as Deputy Mayor for Planning. Whatever the accuracy of Mr. Dinkins' statement that there was nothing illegal about his failure to file Federal, state or city personal incometax returns for four years, he could only have brought embarrassment to the new administration by taking high office before his tax difficulties had been fully adjusted.

title: Wedding Is Held For Miss Allis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28Miss Octavia Allis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Ashton Allis of Wallingford, was married here this evening to Dominic Anthony Garofalo of Cornwell Heights, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Santo Garofalo of Philadelphia.

title: DeCavalcante Leaves Prison Alter Serving Over Two Years
description: Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, a reputed New Jersey rackets figure known as Sam the Plumber, has been released from the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta after serving more than half of a fiveyear term on gamblingconspiracy charges.

title: Eliot Cutler Weds Melanie S. Stewart
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 28 Miss Melanie S. Stewart, a student at the Georgetown University Law Center, was married here this afternoon to Eliot Raphael Cutler, a lawyer in Washington.

title: Two Priests in Spain Given Detention in Monasteries
description: VALLADOLID, Spain, Dec. 28 (Reuters)Two Roman Catholic priests from this northern Spanish town have been sent to monasteries for a month's detention after failing to pay fines imposed on them for assisting a strike last October, informed sources said today.

title: Charlotte Leidy Becomes Bride
description: Miss Charlotte Anne Leidy and Wilhelmus Bogart Bryan 3d, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Side Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Kenneth O. Jones.

title: Soviet Presses China on Border Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28  The Soviet Union, pursuing its arguments with China, has given new indications that the border dispute between them remains unresolved despite nearly four years of spasmodic border talks.

title: Business Group Abandons Its Ties to Soap Box Derby
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 28 (UPI) The Akron Chamber of Commerce annonced today that it was ending all financial and admnistrative responsibility for the AllAmerican Soap Box Derby. It said the event had been killed by cheating, faud and hoax.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the most elaborate and expensive New Year's resolution in sports, the American Basketball Association is determined to acquire Bill Walton not only by offering him a zillion dollars but also by proposing two other inducements. He would play next season with Wilt Chamberlain, thereby reducing the anticipated energy crisis in his knees, and he would be joined by several of his allwinning U.C.L.A. teammates. The site of the extravaganza is uncertain. The club might remain in San Diego, where Walton grew up and where Wilt coaches the Conquistadors now. It might be replanted with new owners in Los Angeles, where the charismas of the former Laker center, Walton and the U.C.L.A. champions would challenge the popularity of the National Basketball Association franchise.

title: Connors, Newcombe Gain at Net
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 28 (AP)  John Newcombe, Evonne Goolagong, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert continued the AustralianAmerican domination of the Australian Open, the first of tennis's Big Four tournaments, today. But weary Bjorn Borg and a weakened Peggy Michel were ousted.

title: Geneva Reports Progress On Disengagement at Suez
description: GENEVA, Dec. 28  Israeli and Egyptian generals reportedly agreed today on some of the principles that would govern the separation of their forces on the Suez Canal front.

title: 60 Minutes': The Knotty Problem of Scheduling
description: The fact that the Columbia Broadcasting System's respected news omnibus, 60 Minutes, must hibernate each Year for the duration of the professional football season illustrate the priorities of the television business. In an autumn that was bountiful with news developments and during which the air was full of crises, both domestic and international, the C.B.S. News magazine which might have made important contributions to the general ??nlightenment  idled on the sidelines until the football games surrendered the 6 P.M. Sunday hour to, which 60 Minutes has been assigned since January, 1972.

title: Safety Council Estimates Motorists' Economy Steps
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) Most motorists would probably have to buy an economy car or drive about 40 per cent less under the Federal gasoline rationing limits proposed yesterday, according to National Safety Council figures.

title: Knicks' LineUps AT GARDEN, 1:30 P.M.
description: (Radio, WNBCAM, 1:25)

title: Guy G. Rutherfurd Jr. Weds Miss Marie Therese Seilern
description: Miss Marie Therese Seilern, a member of the Austrian mission to the United Nations since 1969, was married in Vienna yesterday to Guy G. Rutherfurd Jr., a vice president of White, Weld & Co. Inc., investment bankers.

title: Mourners Throng Funeral in Turkey For Premier Inonu
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 28 (UPI)Ismet Inonu, the first Premier of modern Turkey and her second President who died at the age of 89 here Tuesday, was buried today in a state funeral witnessed by more than one million people.

title: Notes on People
description: Three days ago and without fanfare, a controversial and unsmiling portrait of Spiro T. Agnew was hung in the reception room outside the Governor's office in the Maryland state house at Annapolis. There was just myself and two guys with hammer and nails, said Lieut. Gov. Blair Lee 3d, when asked who attended the picturehanging. The likeness of the former Vice President and Maryland governor which cost the state $2,000, was to have been hung last February, but Agnew aides whisked it away to Washington for a touchup job, as there had been complaints about what appeared to be a halo around Mr. Agnew's head in the original version. The Agnew portrait now faces, across the reception room, a portrait of King Charles I of England who issued the charter founding Maryland. It's ironic they should be facing each other eyeball to eyeball, said Mr. Lee. One fell from grace and had to live with it, while the other fell and was beheaded.

title: Antiques: Tureens That Have Everything but Soup
description: HARTFORDPossibly the only element missing from the arresting display of 18thand 19thcentury tureens on view here at the Wadsworth Atheneum (through Jan. 13) is the aroma of broth or such hardier fare as splitpea soup.

title: MRS. CHESIMARD WINS ACQUITTAL
description: A Federal jury yesterday acquitted Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, suspected members of the militant Black Liberation Army, on charges of robbing a Bronx bank.

title: Shah and Faisal Were Prime Movers in Strategy on Oil
description: PARIS, Dec. 28  Political pressures and intrigues, economic considerations and tremendous amount of jockeying for power were behind the strategy of the oil states in easing their production cutbacks while more than doubling their prices in the last five days.

title: M'Kinley Gets Post
description: WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Dec. 28 (UPI)  James McKinley, an assistant coach at Eastern Michigan University for the last two years, has been named head football coach at Central State University. McKinley coached linebackers and was recruiting coordinator at Eastern.

title: Appeals Unit Backs State Obscenity Law
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28The State Court of Appeals upheld today, 4 to 3, the constitutionality of the state law on obscenity and pornography, declaring that the statute more than complies with tests laid down by the United States Supreme Court.

title: U. S. Aides to Crack Down On Weekend Gas Gouging
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork announced today that the Department of Justice would seek restraining orders against gasoline dealers found to be charging motorists excessive prices over this weekend.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Pacific Lighting Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the Pacific Lighting Marine Company, had contracted with the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., for the construction of two liquefied natural gas ships and an option for three additional vessels.

title: Contrasts in Puerto Rican Life Exhibited in Photos
description: In Dos Mundos, the exhibition by 12 Puerto Rican photographers now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, the point is too rigorously and too easily driven home the point being the contrast of lifestyles in the Caribbean island and in the barrios of New York  but the show is a forceful and interesting documentary nevertheless.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS MANPOWER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28President Nixon signed into law today legislation designed to give state and local governments a larger role in determining their need for a variety of employment and training programs.

title: Wesleyan Art Center: A Refreshing Design
description: For the new Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo and Associates, which is best known for such largescale extravaganzas of glass and structure as the Ford Foundation building in New York, has created a complex of buildings that is neither large in scale nor dazzling in structure.

title: California Conquers Penn State
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI)Rickie Hawthorne a sophomore made two free throws with 12 seconds remaining tonight, enabling California to edge Penn State, 6463, in the semifinal round of the Quaker City basketball tournament.

title: Extended Vacation Rejected
description: BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP)Classes will resume as scheduled next Wednesday for Boston schoolchildren following a vote by the Boston School Committee not to extend the holiday vacation. The committee voted yesterday to rejec three extra days vacation for the city's 20,000 students to conserve heating oil.

title: Justice Department Releases Letters on Its Antitrust Views
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  The Justice Department made public today examples of how it puts a ston to corporate activities it objects to

title: Breitel Sworn In as Head Of State Court of Appeals
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP)Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel, who won a bitter election battle in November, was sworn in today as chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: Nationalists or Partners?
description: Secretary of State Kissinger went to some pains in Brussels and London this month to assure the European Community and its chief new member, Britain, that the United States still favors West Europe's evolving union. He gave special welcome to the Common Market's enlargement from six nations to nine.

title: ROBERT R. NEWTON
description: Robert R. Newton of Douglaston, Queens, a staff supervisor of the New York Telephone Company and tenor soloist at the First Cogregational Church of Flushing, died Thursday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. His age was 52.

title: Kenton Corp., a Retailer, Seeking Reorganization
description: The financially troubled Kent ton Corporation, which operates a chain of 33 discount stores and Cartier and several other prestige stores in New York, announced yesterday that it would file a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act early next week.

title: Colorado Law to Be Pressed On Aid to Poor Relations
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 28, (AP)  Residents of this area may find that having poor relations can be costly.

title: Deaths
Meadowland Pledge Challenged by Suit
description: TRENTON, Dec, 28  East Rutherford and its Mayor filed a suit in Superior Court here today challenging the constitutionality of a moral pledge by the Legislature designed to improve the salability of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's bonds.

title: Police Say Boston Mayor Got Threat on Christmas
description: BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP)Spokesman for the Boston Police Department and Mayor Kevin H. White have confirmed that the Mayor's life was threatened Christmas Day by an unidentified Militant group.

title: $250Million Ft. Lee Development Is Denied a Permit
description: FORT LEE, Dec. 28  The Mayor and other officials of this borough expressed strong reservations today about a proposed $250million shopping recreation  residential center that would be built on a site overlooking the George Washington Bridge.

title: NIXON TAPE SHIFT MAY BRING CLASH
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Dec. 28  The White House confirmed today that the release of the Presidential Watergrate tapes was in doubt, and officials said privately that the tapes would not be made available to the public.

title: Communist Attacks In Central Highlands Reported by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 39 (AP)  Heavy fighting broke out yesterday in South Vietnam's Central Highlands near the Cambodian border, after a lull of more than two weeks, the Saigon command said today.

title: California Conquers Penn State
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI)Rickie Hawthorne, sophomore, made two free throws with 12 seconds remaining tonight, enabling California to edge Penn State, 6463, in the semifinal round of the Quaker City basketball tournament.

title: TestFirings of Missiles Over Five States Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Defense Department anpounced today plans to testfire Minuteman missiles without nuclear warheads from an Air Force base in Montana over five Western states into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Ray Seeks $500,000 Damages In Lawsuit Against Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 28 (AP)James Earl Ray, serving a 99year sentence in the Tennessee State Prison for the slaying in 1968 of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., filed a $500,000 damage suit in Federal Court against the state yesterday.

title: VOTESIPHOR PLOT LAID TO DEMOCRAT
description: MINEOLA, LI., Dec. 28A Conservative party candidate in one of last year's Assembly races said yesterday that he had been given funds by the Democrats in a scheme to siphon off votes from the Republican candidate.

title: CHRISTMAS SAGES TERMED STRONG
Stars Win, 107 to 97, From Nets
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 28  The New York Nets, once the hottest team in the American Basketball Association, failed to come up with the rebounds in the second period tonight against the Utah Stars.

title: New Level, $14.08 a Barrel, Exceeds Persian Gulf's
Dance: The Little Angels
description: The General Assembly Hall of the United Nations had never been opened to the public for a cultural performance before Thursday. It was fitting that the first group to perform there was the Little Angels, the National Folk Ballet of Korea, and that the performance was staged to benefit UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund. The group of thirtyone girls between 8 and 12 years old, augmented by three spectacularly acrobatic boys and five adult members of the Little Angels Court Music Orchestra, filled the stage with colorful song and dance and a spirited freshness. Judging from the standing ovation the children received, their performance of sometimes exotic national dance to music played on replicas of ancient Korean instruments has a universal appeal.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld the conviction of a state trooper for misconduct in office in connection with the alleged branding of an Ocean County man. The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that Dennis Weiglein, no longer a trooper, got a fair trial last year on the charges for which he and a fellow trooper, Thomas Grabowski, were convicted.

title: WINE TALK
description: 'Tis the season to be merry, and, subsequently, hung over. Ordinarily wine drinkers are smug about this delicate subject. They kiss it off with something like: Oh, I haven't touched hard stuff in ages.

title: A French Auto Executive Is Kidnapped in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28 (AP)A French automobile company executive was kidnapped by seven armed men today as he drove to his office 20 miles south of here, police sources said.

title: A System for Solar Power Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Man may in time solve the earth's energy shortage with sunbeams. A system for producing electricity with satellite solar power stations was patented this week on behalf of Arthur D. Little, Inc., research consultants in Cambridge. Mass.

title: MURDER CONFESSION VOIDED, MAN FREED
description: BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 28 (UPI)  Authorities freed Saratoga County man yesterday after state courts said his confession that he had started a fire that killed his wife and daughter was inadmissible evidence.

title: American Tells of His Arrest and 8 Years as Soviet Captive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Alexander M. Dolgun left his office in the United States Embassy in Moscow about 1 P.M. on Dec. 13, 1948, to meet a friend for lunch. He never kept the appointment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STEEL PRODUCERS INCREASE PRICES
description: Several major steel producers moved yesterday to increase prices on a variety of products that utilize large amounts of scrap.

title: Grand Teton Climb Starts
description: MOOSE, Wyo., Dec. 28 (AP) Paul Petzoldt, 65 years old, and 25 other climbers left here at 9:30 A.M. today on the first leg of the annual midwinter assault on the 13,766foot Grand Teton Peak.

title: Cowboys Eye Staubach For Super Bowl Ticket
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28Roger Staubach first came on the national sports scene a decade ago when he won the Heisman Trophy as a junior quarterback at the Naval Academy, made the cover of Sports Illustrated and generally became a household football word.

title: People in Sports: Royal Shuns Giants
description: Despite rumors that he is being considered by the New York Giants to be their next head coach, Darrell Royal of the Texas Longhorns said yesterday in Austin, Tex., that he had not heard from anyone connected with the football Giants.

title: 13 CITED AS HEADS OF GAME RING HERE
description: Thirteen men described by the police as known gamblers were indicted yesterday for operating an $80millionayear bookmaking and sportswagering business in Queens, the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: KASSURA INNS GETS STATE MUTUAL LOAN
description: State Mutual Investors, real estate investment trust in Worcester, Mass., said yesterday that it was a participant in a first mortgage loan of $5.7million to Kassuba Inns of Missouri, Inc., and had issued $4million standby first mortgage loan to the Walter Kassuba Realty Corporation.

title: Thieu's Warnings of a Communist Drive Are Greeted in Saigon by Weary Shrugs
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28The people of Saigon, who once thought that there might be peace, are now being told that there is going to be much more war. Over their television sets and radios, they hear President Nguyen Van Thieu telling them in his blunt, unadorned Vietnamese that they must steel themselves for a Communist offensive.

title: DR. KOHOUTEK HAILS FINDINGS ON COMET
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 28 (AP)The discoverer of the comet Kohoutek told the Skylab 3 astronauts today that their findings could give mankind new clues to the origin of the solar system.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Kandinsky Prints For Guggenheim

title: New Reports of Extortion To Be Pursued by Stern
description: NEWARK, Dec. 28United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that his office would follow up on the new disclosures of alleged extortion by New Jersey political figures that have been unveiled by a special Philadelphia grand jury.

title: Meminger and Jackson Available to Knicks Today
description: Opening a rugged eightday stretch during which they play six National Basketbail Association games, the Knicks expect to have Dean Meminger and Phil Jackson available for service this afternoon when they face the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Trial of Five Arabs in Rome Is Postponed Until Feb. 20
description: ROME, Dec. 28A trial of five Arabs accused of a plot to shoot down an El Al airliner with missiles near here on Sept. 5 resumed today and was again postponed. It is scheduled to reopen Feb. 20.

title: Dolphins, Artificial Turf Lie in Wait for Raiders
description: MIAMI, Dec. 28The Oakland Raiders could boycott Sunday's American Conference championship game with Miami and picket the Orange Bowl with signs proclaiming, Dolphins Unfair to Visiting Teams.

title: HACKENSACK RECORD ACQUIRING 3 PAPERS
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 28 (AP) The Record of Hackensack, the state's largest evening newspaper, announced today that its purchase of three central New Jersey weekly newspapers had been agreed to in principle.

title: YANKS GET LEASE FOR SHEA STADIUM
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday approved an arrangement for the New York Yankees to lease Shea Stadium for $1 a year while paying $760 gameor $61,800 a year for regular seasontoward operating costs.

title: Marshall Signs Pact
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (UPI)Mike Marshall, the relief pitcher obtained in a trade from Montreal for Willie Davis, an outfielder, agreed to terms today with the Los Angeles Dodgers for 1974.

title: Japanese Official to Sign Trade Accord in Peking
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that he would visit China from Jan. 2 to 6 at the invitation of the Chinese Foreign Minister, Chi Pengfei.

title: RAISE FOR GOVERNOR IS SIGNED BY CAHILI
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28 (AP)Governor Cahill today signed legislation increasing the salary of the Governor by $15,000, a year to $65,000, a measure that will benefit his successor, Brendan T. Byrne, next Jan. 115.

title: Lindsay Vetoes a Raise For Board of Estimate
description: Mayor Lindsay vetoed two bills yesterdayone that would have raised the pay of members of the Board of Estimate by $10,000 and one that would have raised the permissible sound level of automobile horns.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: BARKS IN TEXAS PROPOSE MERGER
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc., announced yesterday a preliminary agreement to acquire the First Security National Corporation of Beaumont, Tex. Both companies are bank holding concerns.

title: NORMAN J. MARSH
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 28Norman J. Marsh, who retired as a New York stock broker in 1970, died Wednesday in Pawling. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: MELITTA SPERLING, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Melitta Sperling, a former clinical professor of psychiatry at the Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, and a Freudian psychanalyst, died yesterday at her home, 960 Park Avenue. She was 74 years old.

title: TRENTON CONVICT SCALDED TO DEATH
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28An inmate at the Trenton State Prison was found scalded to death in his cell today, prison officials reported.

title: Vienna Choir Boys' Fans Find Annual Visit Uplifting as Ever
description: If all other means of identifying this season of the year were to vanish, we could probably count on the annual visit of a contingent of Vienna Choir Boys to remind us.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Clinton, Taft Meet For Tourney Title
description: The championship of the second annual ElmCor High School Christmas Classic will be a battle between two Bronx rivals, Dewitt Clinton and William Taft, at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow at St. John's University.

title: Libyan Said to Prefer Revolution Over an EgyptianIsraeli Peace
description: I BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 28The Libyan leader, Col. Muamar elQaddafi, was quoted here today as saying that every possible means should be used, including revolution, to stop Egypt from concluding peace with Israel by herself.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STAMINA The Brooklyn Philharmonia, which consolidates its long runs into one evening, is at it again. Tonight it is presenting The Festival of Modern Combos from 6:30 to midnight in three halls of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue (6364141).

title: P.S.C. Chairman Calls Shift From Oil To Coal Necessary in Energy Crisis
description: Joseph C. Swidler, chairman lof the Public Service Commission, declared yesterday that fundamentally there has been no change in the oil shortage and the proposed shift from coal to oil is needed.

title: Tankers Line Up Off East Coast Seeking Dock Space to Unload
description: Scores of oil tankers are lining up along the East Coast, for the dwindling dock space and scarce storage facilities to unlord their cargo, according to Coast Guard and petroleum industry officials.

title: Skipper and 2 in Tanker Crew Perish in Storm in Alaska Gulf
description: HOMER, Alaska, Dec. 28 (UPI)The captain, chief mate and a crew member of the Chevron Mississippi oil tanker perished yesterday during a storm in the Gulf of Alaska while trying to lash down gear.

title: G.M. TO LAY OFF 86,000 WORKERS; SALES LAG CITED
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28The General Motors Corporation announced today that it planned to lay off 86,000 workers because of the drop in sales of its standardsize cars resulting from the energy crisis.

title: Padres Stay WestIf Sale Is Approved
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) C. Arnholt Smith informed the National League today that he had sold the Padres baseball club to a Los Angeles group without the league's blessing. The group intends to keep the team in San Diego.

title: Dinkins Backers Are Stunned by His Withdrawal
description: Black political figures who vigorously supported the appointment of David Dinkins as the city's first black Deputy Mayor said yesterday that they were stunned by his withdrawal, but that they were determined to have black community representation at the Deputy Mayor's level.

title: G.M. TO LAY OFF 86,000 WORKERS; ALES LAG CITED
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28The General Motors Corporation announced today that it planned to lay off 86,000 workers because of the drop in sales of its standardsize cars resulting from the energy crisis.

title: 36 ExLegislators in Greece Protest Detentions
description: ATHENS, Dec. 28Thirtysix former members of Parliament today protested the continued detention of political prisoners and urged Greece's new militarybacked Government to end persecutions and arrests.

title: Egypt Says Israeli Aircraft Is Downed Near Suez City
description: CAIRO, Dec. 28  Egypt said] today that her troops shot down an Israeli plane that intruded over Egyptian lines this morn ing near the city of Suez at the southern end of the Suez Canal.

title: VOTESIPHON PLOT LAID TO DEMOCRAT
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28A Conservative party candidate in one of last year's Assembly races said yesterday that he had been given funds by the Democrats in a scheme to siphon off votes from the Republican candidate.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Michigan Inquiry Ordered On Mobile Home Industry
description: FLINT, Mich., Dec. 28 (UPI) The Genesee County Prosecutor, Robert F. Leonard, has ordered a grand jury investigation into the state mobile home industry, asserting that 800,000 mobile home occupants of Michigan are flirting with imminent disaster.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Sister Attendant Of Miss Souder At Her Bridal
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 29Miss Marshall Holt Souder, daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. Walter Holt Souder, was married here at noon today to John Studebaker Winder. The bride's father performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Episcopal Church, of which he is rector. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dodd Winder of New Haven and Peru, Vt., and a greatgreat grandson of John Studebaker, a founder of the Studebaker Brothers Manufacturing Company, which became the Studebaker Corporation, automobile manufacturers.

title: The Secret Life of Plants
description: Psychic research has always been a refuge for the spiritual longings banished by Enlightenment science. Nineteenthcentury amateur psychic research was associated with spiritualism. Now, the recent flurry of experimentation with plants in the psychic research underground has reached New Yorker cartoon fame: The only thing that seems to be wrong with your plant, Mrs. Jones, is that you've been talking to it too much. But it hasn't been generally realized above ground that all those plants wired up to oscilloscopes, electroencephalograms (EEGs) and other recording devices were hopefully meant to demonstrate Cosmic Consciousness. The ideain some minds wasn't just to show that plants appreciated attention. The idea was to show the mystical interconnectedness of all life. Or perhaps that there is spiritual energy hologram behind all matter.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Movie mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: SO SOMEBODY really does care about good movies! James Monaco's article (Mother's Day Will Be a Little Late This Year, Dec. 2) singing the praises of Jean Eustache's The Mother and the Whore was a totally unexpected pleasure and, in almost every respect, an accurate and complete statement of the merits of this excellent film.

title: The Workers in Flint, Mich., an Auto Town Hit by G.M. Layoffs, Worrying More About Gasoline Than Jobs
description: FLINT, Mich., Dec 29As you pull off the expressway onto Bristol Road to enter this city known as the birthplace of General Motors, a big sign proclaims: Buicktown and asks: Wouldn't you really rather have a Buick?

title: NIXON AIDE HINTS NEED FOR AGENCY TO PLAN ECONOMY
description: Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that the United States might need to create a huge planning agency to coordinate and direct Government economic policy. Such policy making is now scattered about Washington in various smaller agencies.

title: IRA PHILLIPS, 72, SERIALS WRITER
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) Irna Phillips, creator of As the World Turns and writer of other soap opera scripts since 1930, died last Sunday, it was learned yesterday. She was 72 years old.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: It would appear that The Times has adopted the unfortunate practice of having radical feminists review all those books both favorable and unfavorable to the Movement. Mrs. Hennessee's grossly biased treatment of the principal theses presented in George F. Gilder's Sexual Suicide (Dec. 9) attests to the crying need for The Times to retain critics who will take a more reasoned, objective approach in reviewing the plethora of books that have flooded the market in the wake of Women's Liberation.

title: Laurie Hathaway to Be June Bride
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 29Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Holmes Hathaway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Ann Hathaway, to Robert Lloyd Lawrence. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Tharp Lawrence Jr. Both families live here. A June wedding is planned.

title: U.N. Delegates Say They Can't Get Gas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29United Nations diplomats have complained that they are having difficulty getting gasoline, and the United States has promised to consider putting a gasoline pump somewhere in the international enclave here.

title: SILBERT CONSIDERED FOR U.S. ATTORNEY
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP)  Earl J. Silbert, the former chief prosecutor in the Watergate breakin, is under consideration for appointment as United States attorney for the District of Columbia, a White House spokesman, Gerald L. Warren said today.

title: Diving Into The Wreck
description: This is Adrienne Rich's seventh book of poems, and it is an extraordinary one. When I first heard the author read from it, I felt as though the top of my head was being attacked, sometimes with an ice pick, sometimes with a blunter instrument: a hatchet or a hammer. The predominant emotions seemed to be anger and hatred, and these are certainly present; but when I read the poems later, they evoked, a far more subtle reaction. Diving Into the Wreck is one of those rare books that forces you to decide not just what you think about it; but what you think about yourself. It is a book that takes risks, and it forces the reader to take them also.

title: Human and other beings
description: By Ian Serraillier. Illustrated by Ed Emberley. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $5.95.

title: Israeli Mobilization Rush Put U.S. Tourist in Fight
description: ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 29 (AP) When the Israelis rushed to mobilize at the outset of the October war, they took an unsuspecting 24yearold American with them.

title: Stormy Hearings Due on PATH Extension
description: NEWARK  Five public hearings, all of which promise to be heated ones, are scheduled next month on the Port Authority's $222million plan to extend the PATH rapidtransit line and provide quick service to Newark International Airport.

title: Stay of Execution
description: If you have to admire the courage and honesty it took for Stewart Alsop to write this story of his own mortal illness, you also have to be astonished at his professional writer's skill. Against heavy odds (how great, for instance, must have been the temptation to selfpity), he not only shows in a cleareyed, lucid way what it feels like to be dying, he even makes us eager to read about the progress of the disease that's killing him; and, great miracle, he never leaves us depressed. The man is endowed with too much good cheer and vitality, and he is blessed with too many sustaining memories to write a deadening book.

title: Chloe E. Oldenburg Married To Alfred M. Rankin in Ohio
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Dec. 29The First Unitarian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Chloe Elizabeth Oldenburg of Cambridge, Mass., daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Alan Oldenburg of Cleveland Heights, to Claiborne Read Rankin, also of Cambridge. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Marshall Rankin of Chagrin Falls.

title: 4 Enter G.O.P. Primary for Ford's Seat
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 29The first serious primary battle here in 25 years is shaping up in the Republican race for the Congressional seat vacated by Vice President Ford.

title: Sudden Death in Effect In Case of N.F.L. Ties
description: If either of today's National Football League conference championship games end in a tie after regulation time, suddendeath overtimeperiods will be held.

title: Sara Tassie Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Brogan Tassie of Princeton, N.J., and John M. Tassie of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Tassie, to Hugh M. Boyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Boyd, also of Princeton.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Charles O. Finley, the controversial Oakland A's owner, as he sees himself as an employer: I'm the easiest person in the world to work for if the individual who is taking my money is loyal and willing to give me a day's work for his pay. If he's not willing to do either, he can't play on my team or be a member of my organization.

title: Letters: In Defense Of Islamic Women
description: To the Editor: Fergus M. Bordewich's article, Where Women Are an Annoyance That Disturbs the Symmetry of Life (Travel Section, Dec. 9), has no claim to scholarship, is deceptive, arbitrarily selective and full of undue exaggeration. While he recognizes that the veil is nowhere prescribed in the Koran or by Mohammed, and acknowledges the fact that the Prophet was a liberalizer of women, Mr. Bordewich makes the outrageous accusation that according to orthodox Islam, women do not have souls and emphatically asserts his denial of a relationship between woman and God in the Islamic context.

title: U.S. to Increase Payment For School Lunch Progrim
description: WASHINGTON, Dec,29 (UPI) Coinplying with a law passed last month, the Agriculture Department said yesterday that it was increasing payments to schools to help offset the rising cost of school lunches and breakfast.

title: Connecticut's Lottery Paid $14Million in the Last Year
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 29 (UPI)The State of Connecticut gave out more than $14million in the 1973 state lottery, but holders of some 40,000 winning tickets failed to collect $1millien more.

title: Mindy Marvin Wed To John C. Kitteil
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Dec. 29  Miss Mindy Marvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Marvin of New Canaan, Conn., was married here this morning to John Charles Kittell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Kittell of Elnora, N. Y.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: I. T. T./Rayonier, a paper manufacturer, has leased 45,960 square feet of office space in the Burroughs Building, 605 Third Avenue, for 15 years at an aggregate rent in excess of $7million.

title: News of the Camera World
description: AN allday conference on The Future of Photography in Education will be held under the aegis of the Society for Photographic Education on Saturday, Jan. 12 in the Faculty Lounge of Fordham University at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue. Designed primarily for educators, the conference will include discussions on photographic instruction in secondary schools, universities, workshops and study centers, and it will be aimed at providing a greater understanding of the role photography will play in the future of these institutions.

title: Gardens
description: WITH the new year beginning, the time is right for New Year's resolutions. Here are several especially designed for gardeners:

title: Rights Unit Will Study Outbreaks At School
description: The City Commission on Human Rights will conduct an indepth inquiry into recent racial disturbances at James Madison High School in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Basketball

title: Music Between Covers
description: It's a risky proposition writing books for young readers about rock, the word used to describe every kind of contemporary popular music from hard blasting rocknroll to soft, lilting folk. With radios and records forming the sound backdrop of their existence, kids have been hearing this music for a good part of their lives and so know a lot more about the subject than most of their elders.

title: Tanker JamUp to Be Studied for Evidence of OilCompany Plot
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he would expand his investigation of the oil industry to include the question of whether the jamup of tankers waiting off the coast to deliver petroleum was a product of collusion among the oil companies and whether the jamup was delaying delivery of petroleum.

title: For Ukrainians, It's Christmas Twice a Year
description: NEWARK  The large Ukrainian contingent in the West NewarkIrvington area knows how to keep a good thing going. Why a Christmas feast once a year, they ask, when we can have it twice?

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: MARK TWAIN: (THE)INNOCENTS ABROAD

title: Holly F. Lewis Plans Nuptials
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 29Miss Holly Finch Lewis and Eric Harrison Levine have made plans to be married Aug. 17.

title: At Rose Bowl: Walloping Woody vs. Joshing John
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29  Crusade or Clambake? Should the Rose Bowl be a torturerack or a reward for the players?

title: Constance H. Stafford Is Married
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 29  St. Joseph's New Roman Catholic Cathedral was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Constance Holloway Stafford, greatgranddaughter of Orator F. Woodward, founder of the JellO Company, to Walter Edwin Constantine Jr.

title: Anker Asks $2.6Billion InRecord School Budget
description: New York City Board of Education Source of Funds and Budget Estimate

title: Jogging to Cape Cod, and Other Ways To Keep Moving Without Unduly Taxing Our Nation's Reserves of Fuel
description: THE gasoline shortage notwithstanding, Government policies that encourage the cancellation of travel are bad. They are bad because they contribute to the breakdown of American society, What the Government does not seem to realize is that the chance to get away from home is the major thing holding the American home together today. If anyone doubts that the Administration is creating a problem by discouraging pleasure travel, we only have to look at the way people spent their leisure time over the Thanksgiving Day holiday this year.

title: Blues Recall MacNeil
description: ST. LOUIS. Dec. 29 (AP)The St. Louis Blues sent Bob Collyard, a center, to their Denver Spurs farm club of the Western Hockey League today and recalled Bernie MacNeil, a left wing.

title: John Sibal to Wed Miss Ellen Keats
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 Rear Adm. Edgar S. Keats, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Keats, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Wentworth Keats, to John Woodruff Sibal. He is a son of Abner W. Sibal, former Congressman from the Fourth District of Connecticut, and Mrs. Sibal of McLean, Va.

title: The Games Economists Played in 1973
description: Looking back on 1973, you wonder how we ever got through it. It was the year of hamburger at more than $1.25 a pound, wheat more than $5 a bushel, the banks' prime lending rate at 10 per cent, oil more than $17 a barrel, gold more than $125 an ounce and the Dow Jones Industrial Average a record 1051before sinking to woeful 788.

title: Canadiens Turn Back Rangers, 71
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 29The Montreal Canadiens gave the New York Rangers a schoolboy lesson in basic hockey tonightsimple things like skating, checking, defense and penaltykilling  and overwhelmed them, 71, at The Forum.

title: EXTORTION CHARGE DISMISSED BY U.S.
description: An extortion indictment has been dismissed here, ending Federal charges that involved a $72,000 cash payment by the Mobil Oil Corporation to three reputed members of organized crime.

title: The October war changed everything
description: THE notion would probably amuse Egypt's President Anwar elSadat and Syria's Hafez alAssadno doubt they never intended itbut it is becoming clear that with their surprise attack on Yom Kippur, the Arabs inadvertently launched the first Israeli revolution. A peaceful, bloodless, gunless, civilian revolution it will be, one that may take months or perhaps more than a year to be fully realized, but it is already irretrievably under way, and it is going to result in the transfer of power from the immigrant generation of East European socialist leaders to the generation born and raised in Israel. Time alone would, of course, have wrought the same changes. Prime Minister Golda Meir is 75, and her closest colleagues are not far behind. But the Yom Kippur war has quickened the dramatically.

title: 2 Astronauts Walk To Take Pictures Of Comet Kohoutek
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 29 (AP)Two Skylab 3 astronauts walked in space today to photograph the sunscorched comet Kohoutek.

title: Iran Irks Arabs but Keeps Israeli Ties
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 26 Two armed policemen stand beside an unmarked door. Once inside the courtyard, behind a high cement wall, visitors are frisked, carefully identified and escorted into the building.

title: G.O.P. in Suffolk Rejects Parks Norninee
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 29The second Suffolk County Legislature ended its twoyear tenure late Thursday amid parliamentary maneuvering by Republicans that resulted in their shouting at one another and voting, down their party's own nominee for the post of Parks Commissioner.

title: Howard Law 3d Weds Linda A. Martin
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 29Miss Linda Ann Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Martin, and Howard Adams Law 3d, son of Mrs: Howard A. Law Jr., of Harvey Cedars and the late Mr. Law, were married here this afternoon in St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. John J. Brown performed the ceremony.

title: They Don't Make 'em Like That Any More
description: Miriam Hopkins was the belle of the ball in Becky Sharp, below, and if you want to find out why, just drop by Theatre 80 St. Marks today or tomorrow, where Rouben Mamoulian's 1935 film is paired with Midnight, Mitchell Leisen's 1939 comedy with Claudette Colbert and John Barrymore. And if you're really in the mood for oldiesbutnotmouldies this weekfrom Chaplin to Cagney, from Hayworth to Hutton, from Dietrich to Davis, from Bogart to Betty BoopNew York, or Revival City, is the place to be. Like a bigscreen Late Late Showwithout the commercials.

title: What's Opened Lately at the Movies?
description: SERPICO, directed by Sidney Lumet from a screenplay by Waldo Salt and Norman Wexler and starring Al Pacino, got 15 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Jerry Oster, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Leonard Hai is, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Pauline Kael, New Yorker; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Judith Crist, New York; Robert Hatch, The Nation), 5 mixed (Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Frank Rich, New Times) and 1 negative review (Jay Cocks, Time). At the Baro

title: Cognac Output at New High
description: COGNAC, France, Dec. 29 (Reuters)The production record cognac brandy will he broken this year by 45 million bottles, experts report. The former record was 230 million bottles in 1970.

title: Penn State Brings an Offense This Time
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29  Joe Paterno brought an undefeated and untied Penn State football team to both the 1969 and 1970 Orange Bowl games and the Nittany Lions won each1514 over Kansas and 103 over Missouri.

title: A JUDGE ORDERS CANCER SURGERY
description: Mary Rood is about 65, mentally ill, alone and suffering from breast cancer.

title: BUSINESS FACES IN THE NEWS1973
description: When Federal Reserve chairman Arthur F. Burns was pushed early last spring into the untenable position of arguing that the prime rate should be free to rise, but that it should not do so, he tossed out a suggestion to the banking community, Willard C. Butcher, 47, the new president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, caught on quickly. The next day Chase announced two prime rates  one for small companies borrowing up to $500,000, and one for major corporations. This plan, after some initial wrangling about the proper levels, proved the formula for placating Congress. At the same time it permitted a rising prime rate to brake an overheating economy. From 6 per cent in late March, the prime rate rose steadily to 10 per cent by Sept. 18, Some minor easing occurred in the fall on slowing loan demand but the rate moved back to the peak levels again in December.

title: 21 Teams Plan to Climb Himalayas in the Spring
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 29 (AP)Eight countries have permission to send 21 mountaineering teams to climb the Himalayas next spring, the highest total in one season since Nepal opened her peaks to foreigners in 1950.

title: News of the Screen
description: Susan Sontag, who has produced criticism, essays, a couple of novels, short stories and the movies Duet for Cannibals and Brother Carl, has now completed shooting her first documentary feature. Filmed in embattled Israel, the film is titled Promised Land. She wrote and directed the picture, which was coproduced by Nicole Stephan and an Israeli company, Israfilm.

title: Directory in Nassau Published for Aged
description: The Nassau County Department of Senior Citizen Affairs has published a Directory of Service Available to Senior Citizens.

title: Cultural Events to Mark Inauguration
