description: TRENTON  Free cultural events are expected to heighten public interest in the inauguration of Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne next month

title: All Aboard
description: The new rules issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission to upgrade the quality and comfort of rail travel are long, long overdue, and it's a disgrace to the I.C.C. that they hadn't been promulgated years ago. One of the good things about the energy crisis is that it has at last awakened the nation to the vulnerability of a transportation system that has heretofore relied primarily on aircraft, buses and automobiles.

title: Ousted Coach Is Defended In Foreign Player Dispute
description: Being dismissed on Saturday is becoming an inthing. First, it was Archibald Cox and most of the Department of Justice, then last weekend Boston University's hockey coach, Leon Abbott, was suddenly dropped and replaced by Assistant Coach Jack Parker. Much like his more famous counterparts, Abbott has, been a controversial figure whose leadership on the tough issues led to his dismissal. Last season, he was embroiled in a major eligibility dispute, and also led the drive for reform in Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I Hockey.

title: Miss Mary V. Rue, a Teacher, Married to Peter D. Brodhead
description: ST. ALBANS, Vt., Dec. 29 Miss Mary Virginia Rue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Rue Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Peter Dalzell Brodhead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar R. Brodhead of Montreal and Fairfield, were married here today in St. Luke's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stanley Irving, the rector, who was assisted by the Rev. John Withall of St. Hubert, Quebec.

title: Mrs. Evelena S. Kenworthy Rewed
description: CHESTER DEPOT, Vt., Dec. 29Mrs. Evelena Stevens Kenworthy and James Lowell Oakes of Brattleboro, a judge of the United States Circuit Court, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride by the Rev. Fred H. Miller, retired Minister of All Souls Unitarian  Universalist Church in Brattleboro.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The yearend rally that had eluded Wall Street finally made its appearance last week. It was touched off by the Christmas Day announcement that Arab petroleumproducing nations would increase the flow of oil, notably to Japan and Western Europe.

title: Big A's Farewell Is a Blast.
Raiders Seek Status, Dolphins Status Quo in A.F.C. Contest
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29For the Oakland Raiders, tomorrow's American Conference championship game is a necessary step toward gaining the status they've always felt they deserved but never have achieved. For the Miami Dolphins, it's a necessary step toward achieving a, status no team in pro football has experienced.

title: Let's Look at the Record
description: This is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Alfred Emanuel Smith. He was onefourth Irish, onefourth English, onefourth German and onefourth Italian. His paternal grandfather, who came from Genoa on Dec. 30, 1842, was baptized in American citizenship by a tired immigration officer on a busy day and was given a convenient, anonymous AngloSaxon name. The family name might well have been Ferraro, which is Italian for Smith. The grandson became the foremost Smith in America.

title: Advice for the Driver Who Drinks
description: TRENTONAny New Jersey motorist who is not quite sure whether that next drink is really the one for the road should acquire a walletsized card that is being distributed by the Alcohol Countermeasures Project of the state's Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. 1st Signer of U.N. Pact On Safeguarding Envoys
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29The United States became the first signer yesterday of a treaty that aims to protect diplomats from terrorist attacks and threats.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ARAB COUNTRIES announced a 10 per cent increase In petroleum production for January instead of a 5 per cent cut. More oil will be shipped to European countries and Japan [but none to the United States].... Producers on the Persian Gulf, however, raised the posted price of oil from $5.11 to $11.65 a barrel.... Canada expects to increase the tax on oil shipped to the U. S. to $6.50 a barrel on Feb. up from the $2.20abarrel tax in January.... William Simon, Federal energy chief, announced a standby gasoline rationing system for use March 1, if needed

title: Tis the Season to Be Rural
description: CORTLANDT, N. Y.  One by one, the neighbors came bursting through the door of our 100yearold farmhouse, shaking off the snow and rubbing their hands together. They were still humming snatches of the Christmas carols we had sung at the local retirement community.

title: JAMES S. PHAIR
description: James Seward Phair, a lawyer and president of the Parish Council of Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights, died here Dec. 22 of a, heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: A Hospital Program for Children it Crisis to Open Jan. 14
description: MELVILLE, L. I.A hospital program for the eirnergency treatment of children in crisis is to begin at the Sagamore Children's Center here on Jan. 14.

title: Bluths Have Daughter
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29A daughter was born here Dec. 11 at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital to Dr. and Mrs. Edward Bluth. The child has been named Rachel Lorraine. Dr. Bluth is a radiology resident at the hospital.

title: Britain Is Reported Seeking a Deal for Saudi Oil
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29Britain is reported to be negotiating a deal under which she will receive 30 million tons of crude oil annually from Saudi Arabia for the next 10 years.

title: U.S. Officials Say Gas Will Be Cut 20% in 2 Weeks
description: Threat turned to reality in a number of ways last week as the United States began to take a more accurate measure of the oil shortage:

title: JERSEY PLANNING 3DIGIT LOTTERY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29Officials of the New Jersey State Lottery Commission said today that they hoped to introduce a new form of the lottery that would be patterned after the illegal numbers racket.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS BILL FOR REFORM IN MEDICAL CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 President Nixon signed today a health bill that experts in his Administration expect to have a major impact on medical care.

title: Dance
description: THIS is going to be a love letter to Lincoln Center. I have a feeling it doesn't get many. I empathize.

title: American Inventory
description: The year that is drawing to a close has forced the American people to question many comfortable assumptions about their governmentand about themselves. That anonymous Silent Majority, which President Nixon had earlier hailed as the bedrock of loyalty on which to rest his mandate, has found its voiceto question rather than to uphold that mandate. Within the short span of a year, a President reelected by a record plurality had lost the confidence of the majority of the electorate and could no longer rely on silent acquiescence.

title: Mordecai Sandberg, 76, Dead; Set Book of Psalms to Music
description: TORONTO, Dec. 29  Mordecai Sandberg, who set to Music the complete Book of Psalms as part of a project of Writing a musical score for the entire Old Testament, died here yesterday. He was 76 years old and moved here from New York three years ago.

title: Debutante Parties Enjoying Renewed Popularity
description: Only a couple of years ago debutante parties seemed on the way out. Some of the girls were refusing to be presentedusually to the consternation of their mothers. Others were going through with it as a martyrdom and the parties were ordeals to be suffered for the sake of the family. In a few instances, even the families said they thought the custom had become an anachronism and that they wanted nothing to do with it.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Brogan
description: A son was born Dec. 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Brogan 2d at Doctors Hospital. The child has been named Rodric Herlihy. Mrs. Brogan is the former Miss Catherine Herlihy of New York and Southampton, L.I. Her husband is a lawyer with Arthur Young & Co.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Byron Dyce of the Florida Track Club turned in the fastest halfmile ever run on the 168th Street Armory's 220yard flat board track Friday night when he won a handicap 880yard race from scratch in 1:51.9. Dyce is a 1970 N.Y.U. graduate who is studying for his master's degree in mathematics at the University of Florida.

title: When Their Canvas Was the Stage
description: IN the erratic history of the public acceptance of modern art, theater has played a rather special role. Modern artistsmany of them major figures in the vanguard of arthave found the theater an agreeable vehicle for their work.

title: Franco Names Premier With Police Background
description: MADRID, Dec. 29Generalissimo Francisco Franco today named the 65yearold Interior Minister, Carlos Arias Navarro, a man with long experience in the enforcement of law and order, as Premier to replace Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, who was assassinated nine days ago.

title: Lawyer's Lawyer
description: To his wife he was the most perfect husband any woman ever had. To his valet, giving lie to the old saw, he was very much a hero. To King George V of England, he was the most perfect gentleman the monarch ever met. To Oliver Wendell Holmes, who sat for 30 years as Justice on the Supreme Court, no advocate who ever argued before him was more elegant, more clear, more concise, or more logical. So apparent were his qualities that half a century ago the Democratic party nominated him for President with his barely lifting a finger. Indeed, few American lives have been more exemplary of the impulses that distinguish us as a people, and yet for all the grace and virtuosity of the man, no schoolboy's lips now pronounce the name of John William Davis.

title: Nancy A. Gill, Nurse, Is Wed
description: LOCUST VALLEY, LI., Dec. 29  In St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church here this morning Miss Nancy Ann Gill, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Disk of Syracuse, was married to Alexander F. Haines. He is a son of T. F. Davies Haines of New York, retired president of Ciba Pharmaceuticals, Inc., and the late Mrs. Haines. The Rev. Howard Lowell performed the ceremony, which was followed by a luncheon reception at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Minton, brotherinlaw and sister of the bridegroom.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Plaza in Addresses Is Causing Dismay
description: The post office has a growing headache that might be termed the plaza syndrome.

title: Chilean Freedom Loss Termed Worst of 1973
description: Chile suffered the most serious loss of free government this year, and Thailand made the greatest gain, Freedom House concludes in its annual report.

title: Beame Names Erazo to Fill Terry Post
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph Rodriguez Erazo, a 38yearold lawyer, to fill the post that was to have gone to Seymour Terry, Mr. Beame's nominal campaign manager, who withdrew under pressure on Thursday.

title: 4 Brothers Stringing Along In Harmony
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. When 19yearold Stephen Wood, readies his firstvioIlnist's downbow to lead the string quartet in 'ziiching Haydn or Beethoven, he knows he will get good teamwork.

title: Selected Poems
description: Poetry is an immodest art. The poet may be modest, imagining that the times pass him by, ignoring his pain, regarding his delicate intermediation of time and eternity as irrelevant to the large enterprise of social architecture and historical reconstruction, but the poet knows a secret which only egregious selfdestructiveness obscures, that the great poem sings a succinct universe, compasses the whole myth of man's life and death. Culture may despise poets, but it cannot endure without poetry (and as well, paintings, sculpture, novels, music, although it can despise, punish and murder their creators).

title: Also We Have Trujillo's Bootblack
description: Dear Sirs and Ms.:

title: Turkish Crisis Goes On
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 29 (UPI)  President Fahri Koruturk today refused to accept the resignation of Premier Naim Talu and ordered him to renew efforts to form a new government. The President acted at the end of the ninth week of a political crisis that has left Turkey without a permanent Cabinet since national elections Oct. 14.

title: Bullets Exploded by Fire In Police Electronic Desk
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 (UPI)The $1,200 electronically equipped desk of the chief of police in suburban Florissant caught fire Wednesday, and the blaze sent firemen ducking for cover as it ignited bullets in; the desk.

title: NoShows: It's Up to Congress
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29National Football League noshows, as popular a topic this season as field goals and point spreads, will become a subject of great offseason interests as well.

title: Secretariat Has 37 Dates, a Willing Heart and a Little Problem
description: Around the breeding shed at Tartan Farm in Ocala, Fla., they still remember My Dear Sir as a great lover.

title: Schorr Case: Memo Points to Haldeman
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A personal memorandum from the late J. Edgar Hoover has disclosed that H. R. Haldeman prompted the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the White House to issue a misleading explanation of the bureau's controversial investigation of Daniel Schorr, a newsman for the Columbia Broadcasting system.

title: Agnes Acuff Has Bridal
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29Miss Agnes Sweeney Acuff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelley Acuff of this city, and Donald George Hunsicker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Hunsicker of Harrisburg, Pa., were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament. The ceremony was concelebrated by Msgr. John E. Grimes, the Rev. Joseph C. Shenrock and the R?? James O'Neill.

title: The Gulag Archipelago: Solzhenitsyn Gives an Account of Soviet Prison System
description: 1973 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn English translation  1973 Harper & Row. Publishers, Inc.

title: A.F.C. Championship
description: (TelevisionChannel 4, 4 P.M.; RadioWMCA, 4 P.M.)

title: 5Hour Battle is Reported On EgyptianIsraeli Front
description: CAIRO, Dec. 29A smallarms battle that lasted five hours and 40 minutes was among 40 violations of the EgyptianIsraeli ceasefire reported today by the United Nations Emergency Force.

title: 3 Fumbles By Auburn Aid 3417 Victory
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 29 John Moseley returned a kickoff 84 yards for a touchdown, and Missouri's defense turned three Auburn fumbles into scores today as the Big Eight Conference eleven gained a 3417 victory in the Sun Bowl.

title: The Bismarck Connection Why Kissinger must choose between Nixon and the country
description: OR most sober Americans, there are three central problems: national politics, world politics and Richard Nixon. The first two meet, interact and come together in thousand important ways. Unfortunately, our capacity to come to grips with them is at present grievously, perhaps dangerously, imperiled by the third. For his remaining days in office, it is essential to consider how to minimize the Nixon factor and attenuate the Nixon connection.

title: World Cup Soccer Pairing
description: Fifteen wooden capsules,each bearing the name of a country, and one capsule bearing the names of Spain and Yugoslavia will hold the attention of the soccer world Saturday when the draw for the World Cup takes place in Frankfurt, West Germany. An 11yearold boy from Berlin has been designated to draw the capsules. Guided by Sir Stanley Rous, the president of the International Soccer Federation, the world governing body of soccer, the youngster, Detlev Lange, will pick teambyteam and transfer the names to a large wooden board.

title: Retired Policeman Accused Of Being West Side Fence
description: A retired policeman was charged with possessing stolen property and accused of being a fence by police officers of his old West Side precinct who were led to him by two men allegedly caught in the act of burglarizing a truck.

title: China's Movies: Audience Vast, Budget Low, Box Office Ignored
description: CHANGCHUN, China Imagine a movie studio that shuts down for four years but keeps 1,600 people on the payroll and that pays one of its top directors $21 a week to make films that outdraw Gone With the Wind.

title: Case Upsets Newcombe In Aussie Quarterfinal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 29 (AP)  Ross Case upset John Newcombe, the defending champion, in a twohour quarterfinal match played in 105degree heat today at the Australian open tennis championships.

title: Back by popular demand
description: Warm is what is needed, especially when it comes to nightgowns and the oldfashioned flannel variety is the coziest, cuddliest sort to own (better grab one quick while they're still around; stores report they're being snapped up).

title: Herr on Watergate Classics
description: NEW HAVEN

title: SEVENTH AVE.
description: The stock market decline and the Yom Kippur war hurt sales, but the energy crisis may prompt people to buy a fur coat instead of a second car.

title: In 1974, I Promise Not to Write About . . .
description: GEE (another year has come and gone) whiz. It's time to crank up the generalizations, chip the ice off the windshield of one's overview, make lists and resolutions. My list is a short one: The most compelling sitcom of 1973 was the first phase of the Senate Watergate hearings, especially if you watched the rerun late at night on public television. All those clerks of Nixonia, sleek in their contrition, bringing their wives along like stuffed dolls to console them in the naptime of their souls, seemed plausible late at night, as though Senator Baker were Mery Griffin. The rest was rodomontade.

title: Vacancies
description: ACROSS

title: Warmups
description: Staying warm is on most people's minds now that the facts of energy have been spelled out. Portable room heaters are one solution, but they have all but vanished from the stores and, don't forget, they run on electricity. So if the power goes off ... Here are other lowenergy ways to beat the chill.

title: I.R.S. Ruling Called Big Tax Advantage For Nixon Panels
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) An Internal Revenue Service ruling spared President Nixon's reelection campaign from paying taxes on more than $15million in stock contributions, Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Tennessee Bows, 2819, In Gator Bowl Battle
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29Texas Tech's quarterback, Joe Barnes, passed for two touchdowns, one a 79yard bomb to Lawrence Williams, and scored another to lead the Red Raiders to a 2819 Gator Bowl victory tonight over the Tennessee Volunteers.

title: Lack of Wind Spoils Rye Dinghy Racing
description: RYE, N. Y., Dec. 29 The American Yacht Club's 10th annual New Year's frostbite regatta had an unfavorable beginning today. Lack of wind prevented completion of even one race in Milton Harbor.

title: Military Appeals Judge Quits
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Dec. 29 (UPI)President Nixon accepted with regret the resignation today of William H. Darden as a member and chief judge of the United States Court of Military Appeals. Judge Darden, 50 years old, has been a member of the court since Jan. 15, 1969, and chief judge since Julie 23, 1971. He plans to return to private life.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: A Coal Town: Boom Times Have Returned, but for How Lang?
description: CLYMER, Pa.Suddenly the demand for coal is endless, and here in this mining town isolated in the mountains of Western Pennsylvania it is like boom times again.

title: Bushwick Remembers' Physician Who Cared
description: Fate brought the late Dr. Maxim Mandelstamm, a Russianborn physician and cousin of the famed Soviet poet, Osip Mandelstam, to live and work on Halsey Street in Brooklyn's Bushwick section for 25 years.

title: A Tough Year Is Predicted for Economy of Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 29Despite its friendly nation status in the eyes of Arab countries, Taiwan is expected to suffer seriously in the coming year from shortages and the high price of oil.

title: West Is Beaten, 357, in Shrine Football
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 With Norris Weese, Mississippi quarterback, and Barty Smith of Richmond leading its running attack, the East squad beat the West, 357, in the 49th annual Shrine football game today at Candlestick Park.

title: Jazz
description: THE late, lamented guitarist Eddie Condon was a feisty character given to bow ties, striped shirts and witty, sometimes caustic comments on music, art and life in general. He will forever be identified as the catalyst of the Chicago style, an exuberant, rambunctious species of traditional jazz that evolved from a background of ragtime and riverboats.

title: Maribeth Irwin Marries Here
description: Miss Maribeth White Irwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Irwin, was married here yesterday to Sgt. Robert Scott Lynch, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hampton Simpson Lynch of New York and Nantucket, Mass.

title: Political Gifts By Business On the Wane
description: Evidence is growing that political contributions, both legal and illegal, from business and industry have fallen off sharply and will be increasingly scarce in the months ahead.

title: Death Rows: 44 May Avoid Execution
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 28The trial flash back to me all the time, like, you know, when the jury say that they find me guilty. I can see it in my mind, I didn't know about the death penalty; you know, it really shocked me, because I didn't know the death penalty was still in. It's one of the most horrible feelings that a man can have.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: At 80, Chairman Mao May Have More Revolution in Mind
description: HONG KONGMao Tsetung, who has unquestionably been the dominant figure in the history of China in this century, described himself three years ago, in a whimsical moment, as a lonely monk walking the world with a leaky umbrella.

title: Knicks Rout 76 ers At Garden, 11292
description: The Knicks were sharp and the Philadelphia 76ers, the lastplace team in the over all National Basketball Association standings, looked like a team that had played its last five games on the road. The result yesterday at Madison Square Garden was hardly surprising. Before a capacity crowd of 19,694, the Knicks chose to win by only 20 points, 11292.

title: OILMAN GOT DRAFTS OF ALLOCATION DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Federal officials who wrote the new oil allocation regulations passed working drafts to the oil industry through an oilman who is temporarily on the Federal payroll, Government officials concede.

title: DEMONSTRATOR CURB VOIDED IN COLORADO
description: BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 29 (UPI)A Colorado law barring demonstrators from disrupting lawful gatherings has been declared unconstitutional by county judge who ruled that it violated the First Amendment right of free speech.

title: Ohio State Band Changes Its Tune After 95 Years
description: On New Year's Day, Ohio State will battle Southern California in the Rose Bowl for the second consecutive year. But this time the Buckeyes will be marching to a different drum.

title: Harried Drivers Lose Tempers
description: Short tempers, anger and even acts of violence flared yesterday as harried motorists in the metropolitan area drove about in search of hardtofind gasoline.

title: Should be words
description: ACROSS

title: New Threat of a Tribal Clash Reported Ended in South Africa
description: PIETERMARTIZBURG, South Africa, Dec. 29 (Reuters)The leaders of two feuding tribes that threatened to engage in clash similar to one in which 20 tribesmen were killed this week have been persuaded to end their quarrel.

title: Coneys Sets Pace In Frostbite Races
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI., Dec. 29  Matt Coneys of the Port Washington Yacht Club was the Penguin Class leader, today after five races in the New Year's frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay. Howard Seymour and James B. Moore Jr. of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club were tied for the interclub lead in the 43d annual competition that is cosponsored by the Port Washington and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs under the auspices of Frostbite Yacht Club.

title: Margaret Donovan Wed in Suburb
description: PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 29 Miss Margaret Donovan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Donovan, was married here this afternoon to John N. Donovan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Donovan. The families of the couple, who are not related, reside in Pelham.

title: Paper Could Invalidate Obscenity Ordinance
description: WINCHESTER, Ind,. Dec. 29 (UPI)  Winchester's new antipornography ordinance may not take effect because the local newspaper says its language is not in good taste.

title: Nimrod Series Sets New Prize Gimmick
description: The second of the Nimrod Farm winter indoor horse show series is scheduled for Sunday, Jan. 20, with an add back feature in the regular and suitable working hunter divisions. Under the add back system, which has been popular on the West Coast for several years, Nimrod will hold out $1 of each entry fee in the two divisions and divide it among the four horses that compile the highest number of points during the series.

title: Explosive Book Published by a Quiet Shop
description: PARIS, Dec. 29Ivan Morozov, the Estonianborn publisher of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's huge work, The Gulag Archipelago, sat in his tiny Left Bank office here today above a bookshop as quiet as a church and spoke of the Soviet author he has never seen and to whom he has never spoken.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Margo Marusi, Kissinger Aide, To Wed Feb. 23
description: RED BANK, N. J., Dec. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Augustine R. Marusi have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margo Victoria Marusi, to Terence Patrick Boyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Boyle of Omaha.

title: Bishop Blaise S. Kurz, 79, Of Catholic Traditionalists
description: The Most Rev. Blaise S. Kurz, exiled Roman Catholic Bishop of Yungchow, China, and Episcopal Moderator of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, died Dec. 17 in Waldsassen, Germany. He was 79 years old.

title: Soviet Orbits Cosmos 627
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP) The Soviet Union launched Cosmos 627 into an earth orbit today and the press agency. Tess, said that instruments aboard the unmanned satellite are functioning normally. Cosmos is an umbrella name given to various Soviet satellites ranging from routine test shots to secret research craft.

title: Beman, 35, Will Head Pro Golfers
description: Deane Beman, a 35yearold professional from Bethesda, Md., was named yesterday to succeed Joseph C. Dey as commissioner of pro golf.

title: R. H. Tawney and His Times
description: This biographical and analytical study of R. H. Pawney has three important merits. It is brief but dense (in the best sense). It is shrewd and reticent in its comments. And it is timely. Democratic socialism has run out of ideas and, still more, inspiration, and is currently whoring after such unpromising material as the European Common Market. It is good to be reminded that in Tawney's work we have a rich and permanent body of wellargued propositions, awaiting discovery by the younger generation, and rediscovery by their elderi. The world we live in is woefully discouraging to those who still believe that wellmeaning intellect's can solve any of its problems, but Tawney's Equality and The Acquisitive Society contain some powerful nourishment for hope, and I am grateful to Ross Terrill for spurring me to look at them again.

title: STOCK SALE IS SET BY METZENBAUM
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 29Howard M. Metzenbaum, who is scheduled to become the newest United States Senator next week, said he planned to make a full financial disclosure shortly, and already has begun taking steps to avoid possible conflicts of interest.

title: Detroit Mayor Sworn Early
description: DETROIT, Dec. 29 (UPI)Coleman A. Young, Detroit's first black Mayor, took the oath of office yesterday with only a handful of witnesses present. He will take a ceremonial public oath of office Wednesday. The city charter requires that the Mayor assume office promptly on Jan. 1. It was either do it now, Mr. Young said, or come down to City Hall on New Year's Day.

title: Mormons Pay Tribute to Lee In Funeral Rites at Tabernacle
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 29 (UPI)The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints paid final tribute today to its 11th prophet, seer and revelator, in a funeral service at the Mormon Tabernacle for Harold B. Lee. Mr. Lee, who was 74 years old, died Wednesday night after having served for 17 months as president of the 3.3million member church.

title: A brick is better for stopping doors
description: Normal books, ho hum, are retailed one by, one: 10,000 copies, 10,000 decisions to buy. It's coaxing 10,000 Americans to do the same thing that drives sales departments to drink. But the college text, that's a sexier proposition. Impress one (1) instructor, fasttalk him, blizzard him with leaflets, even give him a free copy if that helps, and you get an adoption, which 4s like getting a centipede's shoe account: automatic sales of 30, 50, perhaps 500, a year. Multiply by all the instructors you can hope to impress, reflect that once they've dittoed syllabi they'll shrink from switching to a different book next fall; project, therefore, a growing list of adoptions into a long vista of years, and you have a way to run a business. So we find Oxford University Press deep in a fantastically expensive venture in bookmaking, yet confident it will be amortized by megacarloadsoaf sales.

title: Posted Price of Crude Oil Raised 37% by Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 29 (Reuter)Ecuador has increased the posted, or taxreference, price for her crudeoil exports by 37 per cent to $13.70 a barrel, beginning Jan. 1.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The recent demand by the teamsters' union to reopen their wage contract because of the energy crisis may be only the beginning of an explosion of labor unrest.

title: Sula
description: In 1970, when Toni Morrison's first novel, The Bluest Eye, appeared, she reaped the benefits of growing, middleclass women's movement that was just beginning to acknowledge the reality of its black and poor sisters. As a result, her novel probably attracted more attention than it otherwise might have in the publishing industry and was received rather uncritically by readers and reviewers: socially conscious readersincluding myselfwere so pleased to see a new writer of Morrison's obvious talent that we tended to celebrate the book and ignore its flaws.

title: A JUDGE ORDERS CANCER SURGERY
description: Mary Rood is about 65, mentally ill, alone and suffering from breast cancer.

title: To make adifference By Jean Hewitt
description: Boeuf en daube

title: The Old Farmer's '74 Almanac
description: JANUARY: Blustery weather... President gives up electric toothbrush to set example ... Rev. Billy Graham says things are bad enough, asks President to stop setting examples... Dolphins win Super Bowl ... In State of the Union Message, President calls for warm weather, blames newspapers for the energy problem, asks fortymile speed limit ... Massachusetts threatens to secede from the Union.

title: Hamine soulI say alas and I say alas and alas and alas!
description: If only the editors of this anthology wouldn't take themselves with such grisly seriousness, there would be no problem in reading or reviewing this collection at all: we could all forage in its fields, amusing ourselves with its good and bad poems alike. But the solemn editors insist on framing their collection with pretentious introductions and ponderous vocabulary, so as to take all the fun out of the reading.

title: Ismet Inonu
description: When democratic institutions are under attack almost everywhere, the achievement of Ismet Inonu that stands out above other substantial services to the Republic of Turkey was his deliberate dilution of his own political power to foster a democratic system after World War II. In line with that philosophy, he stepped down graciously when his party the .party he had helped Ataturk to foundunexpectedly lost a free election in 1950.

title: Inside His Script He Wrote: Jason, Trust Yourself!
description: I HAVE nothing against James Earl Jones but I am pleased that some of the reviews of his Hickey in The Iceman Cometh have recalled Jason Robards in that role 17 years ago at the old Circle in the Square. And it's nothing against Lee Marvin, who was Hickey in the recent film of Iceman, that many of us will have a hard time shaking Jason out of our memories. His performance has defined O'Neill for a generation. The role made him a star and it also made him an actor; it showed him where his strength was. The pity is that he has so seldom found an opportunity to use it since. I am glad he came back to Broadway last night as another doomed O'Neill figure in A Moon for the Misbegotten.

title: The Guitar CrazeWhere Is It Going?
description: IF there is a jazz revival on the horizon, as many jazz people have been optimistically predicting, the instrument that is going to lead the new trend is the very same instrument that buried jazz in the sixties: The guitar.

title: Ousted Chief of Seoul C.I.A. Reported in Britain
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 29Lee Hu Rak, ousted this month as chief of the controversial South. Korean Central Intelligence Agency, left the country for Britain quietly last week for medical treatment, it was officially reported here today. The Foreign Ministry said he was receiving treat for heart trouble at a British hospital, which it did not identify.

title: News of the Stage
description: A longing for things past appears to be pervading the New York stage these days.

title: Zaire for Greet Visitors With Drums, Not Guns
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Dec. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)African drums will replace 21gun salutes for heads of state visiting Zaire, according to Government circular.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Colin Mason's HOSTAGE (Walker, $5.95) is not a kidnap story. As the dust jacket loudly proclaims, the, hostage is the continent of Australia. Mason thinks big. The idea behind his book starts with the assassination of an Israeli defense minister (substitute Moshe Dayan) by Arab extremists. Israeli extremists retaliate by exploding three atom bombs over Cairo. Goodbye Cairo. That is where the Soviet Union steps in. The complete elimination of Israel as a State is demanded. Otherwise the city of Sydney in Australia will be destroyed.

title: Quaker City Final Taken By Temple
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (UPI)Joe Anderson and Joe Newman scored 13 points apiece tonight as Temple pulled away in the second half to defeat California, 5142, and win the Quaker City tournament.

title: Miss Katherine S. Showe Is Bride
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Dec. 29  In Congregation B'nai Jacob here this evening Miss Katherine Elizabeth Showe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Showe, was married to Jeffrey Stuart Chavkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Chavkin of New York and Pompano Beach, Fla. Rabbi Arthur Chiel performed the ceremony.

title: Black Hawks Overcome Penguins, 42
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (UPI) A freak goal and excellent goaltending by. Tony Ehposito tonight helped the Chicago Black Hawks defeat Pittsburgh Penguins, 42, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Oil Has Carried the Sheiks Far Into the 20th Century
description: BEIRUTThe traditional picture of the Middle East, particularly the area around the Persian Gulf, has been of a sandy waste populated largely by camels and their picturesque but backward Bedouin drivers. It never was an entirely accurate image, and it is entirely inaccurate now: it has become an area of great wealth and economic power, and some of its people, though primitive in many respects, live in welfare states beyond the hopes of even socialist countries.

title: Fuel Crisis Could Make Every Sport a Gasser
description: Out there in motor sports land, the natives are growing restless. In the winter of their discontent, they are demanding automobile racing be treated just as fairly as any other sport during the dreaded fuel crisis. Or, put in a more indelicate way, they are asking that other sports be dealt with in the same offhanded manner that has led to the complete, if temporary, demise of the sport in other lands and the curtailment of it here.

title: Bradford D. McKean Marries Blair R. Reid
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29In the Shady Side Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Blair Ramsden Reid, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Charles Allen Reid of Fox Chapel, was married to Bradford Darr McKean, so of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Doty McKean also of Fox Chapel. The Rev. Robert Cleveland Holland performed the ceremony.

title: the traveler's world
description: ALL the deepthinking political and social scientists are busy today looking back over the whirling 12 months of 1973, so we, too, might as well cast a backward eye on what the year did to and for the tourist and travel industry, and possibly take a look ahead to 1974. This is not necessarily in order of first importance, but 1973 did create a brand new sightseeing attraction  Watergate, not Watergate the political scandal but Watergate the office building and hotel and apartment complex which leaped overnight onto the Washington, D. C., rubberneckbus tours.

title: Small Fry Take to the Ski Slopes
description: WARREN, Vt., Dec. 29At downstate Mount Snow all Rudi Wyrsch, the Pied Piper of skiing, has to do to attract a crowd and appear in front of the base lodge. Within five minutes, small fry are swarming around him. Here at the more sophisticated Sugarbush area, once known as the Jet center of the ski world, Sigi Grottendorfer, the ski school director has his own way of attracting children. He sets up a little slalom course with ski poles near the ski school lift. Soon he's produced the same kind of magic.

title: State Law Agency Grants $950,727
description: TRENTONThe State Law Enforcement Planning Agency focused on improvement of police services and juvenile delinquency programs in awarding $950,727 in grants earlier this month.

title: David Michael Woodard Weds Miss Ruckelshaus
description: AIKEN, S. C., Dec. 29St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Gail Ruckelshaus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Ruckelshaus of Indianapolis and Aiken, to David Michael Woodard, son of Mrs. Marion Leonard Woodard of Gallup, N. M., and the late Mr. Woodard. Msgr. George Lewis Smith performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1973
description: Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain named the 65yearold Interior Minister, Carlos Arias Navarro, who has a long record in law enforcement, as the new Premier and successor to Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, who was assassinated Dec. 20. A few hours before the appointment became official, the Tribunal of Public Order, a special political court, gave a striking example of how firmly the Franco regime intended to defend itself after the assassination of Admiral Carrero Blanco, one of its key figures, by announcing prison terms ranging from 12 to 20 years for 10 labor organizers who had been condemned for leading underground workers' commissions. [1:12.]

title: Delaware State Scores In Freedom Game, 9867
description: Delaware State, one of the better teams in the Interreligious Foundation for Community Organization Freedom Classic and the only entry of eight teams with a winning record this season, scored a 9867 victory over Hampton Institute last night at City College's Mahoney Gymnasium.

title: Artist of the Snapshot
description: LIKE that of many of his contemporaries, the work of Emmet Gowin involves itself with the cultural history of the snapshot. The snapshot is a vernacular form of photography, a democratization of the medium; as such, it is unique in the history of graphic communication. It would also seem to be particularly Western, in that the act of taking a snapshot is an interruption of the flow of events and of time, an interruption whose purpose is to preserve rather than observe. For all its smallness, fragility and evanescence, a snapshot is not just a memento but a monument.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Lindsay had no trouble in office until his first day at work, when he walked into a transit strike. Abraham D. Beame has gone him one worse: He is still a week away from taking over City Hall, but two of his major appointees have withdrawn from his administration for legal and ethical reasons.

title: Power of Senators Facing a New Test
description: TRENTON  A decisive confrontation over efforts to abolish the power of individual State Senators to block gubernatorial appointments has been set for Friday, when the Senate's Democratic majority members meet to adopt rules for the new session convening on Jan. 8.

title: People in Queens Feel They're Out on a Lime
description: The unseasonably warm temperature during part of last week made many people forget the pelting ice storm of Dec. 16 and the damage it caused  many people, that is, except in Queens, where communities from Woodside to Bayside and from Jamaica to Far Rockaway were still strewn with tree branches and limbs that fell en masse two weeks ago.

title: The First of Our Publicity Masterpieces
description: SIX decades after Marcel Duchamp's painting, Nude Descending a Staircase, provoked a public scandal in the 1913 Armory Showamong other things, it managed to incur the wrath of no less an eminence than Teddy Rooseveltthis benign example of derivetive Cubism has returned to New York once again. It is included in the mammoth Duchamp retrospective that opened two days ago at the Museum of Modern Art (reviewed on this page, after its Philadelphia showing, on Dec. 9).

title: Economists Plead Uncertainty on 1974 Outlook
description: Economists, still reeling from their mistakes of 1973, are off and running again in the forecasting derby of 1974. This time, however, even the experts are taking their own forecasts with a grain of saltif not aspirin.

title: Idaho Asks Time Exemption
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 29 (UPI) Gov. Cecil D. Andrus has signed a proclamation exempting southern Idaho from daylight saving time, a step he hopes will make it unnecessary to go to the Legislature to keep the state on standard time. The proclamation was sent to the Federal Transportation Department for approval.

title: Television
description: IT'S usually easy to put together a list of the worst television programs of the year. Can(Mates are plentiful. This year, significantly enough, it's unusually easy to compile a list of the best. Recognizing that nothing is flawless, not even reviewer lists obviously tailored on a personal bias, the exercise begins with the best:

title: INSURGENTS SHELL LON NOL'S PALACE
description: PHNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sunday, Dec. 30 (AP)Khmer Rouge insurgents fired two rockets into Phnompenh early today hitting the palace compound of President Lon Nol and the residence of two American Embassy officials.

title: Whose Heritage?
description: Planning for the Law of the Sea, Conference began three years ago when the General Assembly declared that the rich resources of the ocean floor beyond national jurisdiction are the common heritage of mankind.

title: Murder Record in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI)The police reported today that homicides set a record in Chicago in 1973. Murders totaled 856 even before the final week end, up from a high of 824 in 1971.

title: Forecast: Partly Cloudy
description: DALLAS, Dec. 29 (AP) Partly cloudy skies and temperatures in the 50's were forecast for the playoff game tomorrow between the Dallas Cowboys and the Minnesota Vikings. The wind is not a factor because Texas Stadium is partially covered.

title: Sugar Bowl Overshadows Bourbon Street
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29A football game finally has overshadowed Bourbon Street as the source of excitement in this Southern city.

title: Mr. Park and His Critics Have Surprised Each Other
description: When a liberal Korean Protestant minister recently received a copy of Newsweek magazine with a critical article on the South Korean Government excised by censors, he received, within hours, four Xeroxed copies of the missing page, delivered to him, by four different groups.

title: Charities Deluged for Help
description: NEWARKCharitable organizations throughout New Jersey were deluged with unprecedented demands for food and clothing at Christmas, and officials attribute the growing requests for aid to mushrooming unemployment, inflation and the energy crisis.

title: HUGHES CONCERN DENIES CHARGES
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 The Summa Corporation, wholly owned by Howard R. Hughes, denied today charges in a Federal grand jury indictment that the reclusive billionaire was guilty of stock manipulation and fraud in the 1968 acquisition of Air West, a regional airline.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Nineteen seventythree was the year America became a comedy, and what glorious comedy it was, and what a year it gave us. Youngsters lucky enough to have lived through it will bore their grandchildren with tales about the wonder of it deep in the 21st century, just as oldtimers nowadays try to make their own young grasp the magic of the great age of radio comedy. Fred Allen, Jack Benny, Ed Wynn, Fibber McGee...

title: How Boat Show Navigates the Streets of New York
description: Like the beautiful gliding swan that becomes an ugly, awkward bird when it leaves the lake to waddle on shore, so the smoothsailing yachts that will be displayed at the National Boat Show become cumbersome objects as their owners haul, pull and drag them to the New York Coliseum.

title: Hangover Remedies Around the World: A Sobering Examination
description: THE moderate drinker who feels in need of moral support this New New Year's Eve may want to clip out the following quotation from a profilt analysis of types of drinkers lifted horn the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's First special Report to the U.S. Congress on Alcohol & Health: Compared with moderate drinkers, both abstainers and heavy drinkers tended to be somewhat more alienated from society and more unhappy with their lot in life. The general reader may find it bemusing to note that this report, published in 1971, is already of historical interest: it begins with a letter from Eliot Richardson, then Secretary of H.E.W., to the Hon. Spiro Agnew, then Vice President, in his role as President of the Senate, and concludes with the text of an afterbanquet speech on alcoholism delivered by the then Attorney General, John

title: Miss Waterbury Married in Wales

The ceremony in St. Mary's Priory Church was performed by Canon Henry Rees SprouleJones.

description: Manhattan College saved its best game for the final round and upset. St. John's, the pretournament favorite, 7465, last night to win the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP)The Willy Watts and the Branded Legion Band, composed of inmates from Atmore State Prison, will play at the New Year's Eve dance for the Huntsville chapter of the Fraternal Order of Police.

Only now and then does one catch a glimpse of the banner: The South Shall Rise Again!mince as ubiquitous in the Southern landscape as the dire Where Will You Spend Eternity? road signs.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 29  Miss Pegeen McCarthy and Robert Shelton Burgess, 1973 graduates of Marietta College, were married in the Round Hill Community Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Arnold Miller performed the Methodist ceremony.

The ceremony in the First United Methodist Church was performed by the Rev. John W. Yates, assisted by the Rev. Stacy Selph.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29The Arab League is sending special envoy to the United States to put the Arab case before the American people and to try to bridge what the envoy described here today as the gap in ArabUnited States dialogue.

description: I have some good news for you and some bad news, runs the old leadin for a series of jokes.

title: FOOD SHORTAGES EMBITTER NAPLES
description: NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 26Neapolitans say the year is ending with a bitter taste because there Is no sugar in the food stores. But the diffuse bitterness here has deeper roots.

title: J. A. DANNEFELSER
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Dec. 29 John A. Dannefelser, who retired in 1965 as manager of the John P. Dannefelser sporting goods store in New York, which had been founded by his father in 1884, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 82 years old and lived at 24 Severna Avenue.

title: Times Square Arrests Rose 20.6% in 1973
description: The first year of a concerted drive by city agencies to clean up Times Square has resulted in a 20.6 per cent increase in arrest's for serious crime and in the apprehension of 400 Johns for patronizing prostitutes, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: Decision on Padres Is Facing Delay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 That the National League's 12th team will operate in San Diego in 1974, and not in Washington, seemed all but certain todaybut under whose auspices remained unclear. And nothing definite can happen until the owners of the other 11 clubs have a meeting, probably in about 10 days.

title: Daughter of Jeweler Abducted During Robbery in His L. I. Shop
description: COMMACK, L. I., Dec. 29 An unidentified gunman kidnapped a young woman and locked her in a car trunk last night after robbing her father, a jeweler, of an undetermined amount of money and jewelry.

title: Gardens

description: WHEN the new year bows in at midnight tomorrow, there is bound to be a note of hopeful optimism sounding in the toasts raised by investors and those who labor in the vineyards of the various security, financial, foreignexchange and commodity markets.

description: Stanley Harwood, the Nassau County Democratic chairman, said yesterday that he would make available by next Wednesday a full and complete disclosure of my personal finances to document his denial of charges that he had given $3,000 to his Conservative party opponent in a 1972 Assenibly race.

description: THIS is the time of year to think of the less fortunate  the children, the aged, the handicappedand this is the time of year countries put out stamp issues to help the less fortunate.

title: Bridge
description: Take a concrete case. Your side has bid four spades, but the opponents have annoyed you by bidding five hearts. Should you now bid five spades? To answer such a question you must ask yourself a whole series of other questions. Can you make five spades? Can the opponents make five hearts? If they can, will five spades represent a cheap save? And what will happen if you push them to six hearts?The nation's motorists are only just now beginning to face a question long pondered by bridge players: Should call a halt, or dare I drive a little further?

description: THE next round in the clearanee sale of Carson City silver dollars by the General Services Administration is expected to begin Feb. 1. description: PARISThe West and Japan must obviously readjust commercial and economic policies to meet the challenge posed by bleak realization that cheap and plentiful petroleum is now and forevermore a thing of the past. There are three obvious approaches.

description: State Tax Commissioner Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that his department was looking into the failure of David N. Dinkins to file state tax returns over a fouryear period.

In the Bogdanovich tradition, a new breed of young filmmakers, whose work clearly shows that they have been to the movies often and lovingly, are signing their pictures with the imprint of the buff.

title: Philadelphia Group Challenges SwearingIn of New Prosecutor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 Although he does not take office as District Attorney for another week, F. Emmett Fitzpatrick is already facing major problems.

description: DALLAS, Dec. 29  The Dallas Cowboys and Minnesota Vikings meet here tomorrow in a contest rated dead even with the National Conference championship and qualification for the Super Bowl at stake. The game in Texas Stadium begins at 1 P.M., New York time, and Will be televised there on Channel 2. It is a sellout here with the last of 65,111 seats bought up last Thursday.

description: AFTER THE ICE

title: Arthur Daley
description: Not since the invention of the current playoff system have there been such intriguing matchups as will be handed the viewing public today by their evergracious television hosts, the benevolent despots, who rule the world of sports. The virtually invincible Miami Dolphins will face the slightly invincible Oakland Raiders in one same of this show biz spectacular while the Dallas Cowboys and the Minnesota Vikings, solid teams of equal strength, will bump heads in the other. The winners advance to the Super Bowl in Houston a fortnight hence.

title: Money Lender, $4, LongdenTrained, Wins Coast Stakes
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (UPI)  John Longden, the former champion jockey who as a trainer developed Majestic Prince into a Kentucky Derby winner, saddled another potential champion today when Money Lender captured the 34th running of the $60,375 California Breeder's Champion Stakes for 2yearolds at Santa Anita.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29At the snap, the defensive backs and the linebackers of the Miami Dolphins scatter into one of about 30 different coverages. Many of the coverages resemble one another, but each has a subtle difference, like the pieces of a difficult jigsaw puzzle or the clues in a clever crossword puzzle. As he searches for a receiver, the opposing quarterback has only two or three seconds to solve the puzzle of where to throw. If he takes too long, he often is sacked. If he hurries, he often is intercepted. The No Name defense of the Dolphins is a misnomer. It should be the No Mercy defense, particularly on passers trying to solve the puzzle for the first time. In tomorrow's American Conference championship game, Ken Stabler of the Oakland Raiders will be surveying the Dolphin pass defense for the first time. His success or failure in solving the puzzle is likely to determine the outcome.

title: RATE OF JOB LOSS FELL HERE IN '73
description: New York City experienced a relatively, moderate decline. in employment in 1973, compared with dramatic job losses in the previous three years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Gas Situation Spotty as Drivers Find Some Stations Chaotic, Some Normal
description: Motorists who had not yet given up on the horseless carriage had another tedious day yesterday searching for stations still selling the holiday weekend's dwindling supply of gasoline, while Federal and state officials continued their checks for pricegouging.

title: Arts Roundtable Planned at Drew
description: MADISON  Ralph Burgard, director of the Associated Councils of the Arts, a national organization, will, be the keynote speaker at an allday Roundtable of the Arts, which will be held at Drew University on Jan. 12. His subject will be What Is an Arts Council?

title: The World
description: The everbolder critics of the government of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea have been warned that they had better not go too far.

title: A Cook With a Penchant for Sweet Recipes
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., When Lee Haiken endedher career commitment about eight years ago to raise a family, she knew that she and her husband, Martin, an importer, would be eating many dinners at home. So she taught herself to cook.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Dreaming
Dimmer Times Square Awaits New Year Fete
description: Despite the fuel shortage, Times Square will be illuminated as usual on New Year's Eve. However, the Bulova Watch Company will reduce the power usage in the huge Times Square film display by 20 per cent. Similar cutbacks are planned by other cornpanys whose signs help light up the square.

title: Public Men and Their. Private Interests
description: Fifteen years ago, Malcolm Wilson, then the newly elected Lieutenant Governor, filed a statement of his holdings excess of $10,000 in companies subject to state regulation. He filed under a section of the Public Officers Law requiring any officer or employe of a state agency to make such disclosure.

title: What's Doing in New York City
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE  The old year's going out and soon Monday nightshould you. You can, of course, revel at one of those hotel parties with noisemakers, paper hats and hefty tabs, but if you want to be different, the biggest New Year's Eve bash is outdoors and free. It's the seventh annual New Year's Eve party in Central Park, at Bethesda Fountain and on the Mall near East 72d Street. The party starts at 10:30 P.M. with a parade, the accent being on the nineteenthirties and forties, and continues with movies, dancing to a Latin band and fireworks at midnight. Balloons are free, and you can buy hot chocolate or coffeebut no wassail bowl. Making the scene at the Metropolitan Opera is something of a tradition on the last night of the old year, but, again, there's an alternative that would provide a nice change of pace. Try the Amato Opera, which at 319 Bowery is in a considerably less glamorous setting than the Met. The Amato is a tiny place that has been presenting opera at low prices for many years, with a piano and one or two other pieces making the music. The New Year's Eve program offers La Boheme, followed by a homecooked buffet supper and, after midnight, much toasting and dancing, for $25 a couple. Reservations are necessary; call 2288200. If you want to avoid the crowds, try the top of the Empire State Building (Fifth Avenue and 34th Street). The observation roof closes at 11:30, leaving you enough time to rush off somewhere to get caught up in the brash spirit of the occasion. Or take a Staten Island Ferry ride (round trip: 10 cents) on which you'll hear the ships moored in the harbor tooting away as 1974 is born.

title: A French Village Rings In the New Year All Around The World
description: A GREAT many of the bells hanging in church towers and public buildings which will be stirringly pealing in 1974 the day after tomorrow have been cast by a single foundry. It is the Paccard Foundry, which is open to visitors in little AnnecyleVieux in the Alps of the HauteSavoie in southeastern France. As the old year dies not a moment will go by but that a bell fashioned by Paccard will not sound somewhere. Since 1796 the Paccards seven generations of them  have made more than 80,000 bells and sent them all over the globe. They are tolling now in Tokyo and Phnom Penh, in Brussels, Monaco, Tangiers and Beirut, and in New York and Milwaukee, too.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The company is young, not quite 20 years old, but there is a strong tradition of candor, outspokenness and harddriving vigor at the McDonald's Corporation, the nation's preeminent purveyor of hamburgers.

title: WILLIAM WHITNEY, LAWYER, 74, DIES
description: William Dwight Whitney, a noted courtroom lawyer who helped to win in 1953 a sixyear trial brought by the Government against 17 leading investment houses on a charge of monopoly and conspiracy, died Friday at his home in La Tour de Peilz, Switzerland. He was 74 years old.

title: Why Not Homage To the Movie
description: MOVIES about male comradeship were very big this year. So were movies that looked fondly back to what are usually called simpler, more innocent times. Women got it in the neck, often from women, and all America suddenly didn't know it was waiting to see the screen version of Jonas than Livingston Seagull. The huge billboard advertising the Hall Bartlett production had a longer run on Times Square than the film itself had at the Sutton.

Solzhenitsyn had already been made known and they declined to say specifically what measures might be taken either against the Nobel Prizewinning author or his foreign publishers.

title: THOMAS HIGGINS, ACCOUNTANT, DIES
description: Thomas G. Higgins, who rose from clerk to senior partner of Arthur Young & Co., international public accountants, died yesterday at his home at 711 Parsons Road, Ridgewood, N. J. He was 73 years old.

title: Child Care Eases Visits to Inmates
description: Fiveyearold George was playing B quietly in a corner of the rooklyn Quaker Meeting House on Christmas Day, trying not to muss his new velvet bow tie and navy blazer. In a little while he would be taken around the corner to meet his father at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men. This marked George's second Christmas without his father, who has been awaiting trial here for 15 months on charges of theft and assault.

title: Is This the Best Of All Possible Candides'?
description: CANDIDE may at last have stumbled into the Abest of all possible productions. I take back stumbled, instantly. For there is nothing at all inadvertent about the magician's pass director Harold Prince has made at the songanddance celebration of Voltaire's calculated insult to the best of all possible worlds. Mr. Prince has looked at the materials, long, hard, and lovingly, decided what kind and degree of theatrical impudence is called for, got himself a new and freefloating libretto by Hugh Wheeler, and then simply rebuilt a theater to suit Leonard Bernstein's sweetly irreverent score.

Among them is this possibility: Why not increase the number of jetliner's seats by doing away with the firstclass sectionwhere each passenger enjoys about 60 per cent more space than the person in coach classand in that way make room for more passengers, all traveling economy class?

title: Cowboy or Cop, Bayne Never Wanes
description: I LIKE your hair, drawls the big boulder of a man leaning forward in his too tiny chair at the Pierre. Since he's John Wayne, I naturally wonder if my ears, are playing tricks on me, or if maybe I'm being taken for a hippie.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: When the American humorist Robert Benchley was an undergraduate at Harvard, he had to answer an examination question in international law on the Northwest Atlantic fisheries dispute. Finding himself unprepared on the issues, he began: Some people may care to discuss this case from the point of view of England, others from the point of view of the United States, but I shall discuss it from the point of view of the fish.

title: Rebuttal
